title: HIGH COST OF MILITARY PARTS
description: A thumb-sized plastic knob for the cockpit of the Navy's A-7 jet fighter can cost $400. A tiny machine screw for the Minuteman 2 missile can cost $36.77. A ring seal used in the engine of B-52 bombers can cost $2,020.50. And the Navy paid $435 for an ordinary hammer.

HERS
description: ''YOU didn't see me, but I saw you and your husband on the subway yesterday,'' a friend told me mischievously. ''Frankly, I couldn't believe how happy the two of you looked. And you've been married for 20 years!'' The surprised tone of her surveillance report made me realize how many of my friends simply do not trust marital satisfaction. More precisely, most people want it but few believe it exists. And for good reason.

The company also said it would increase its gas rate request to $39.2 million, from $24.5 million. Arizona Public said the higher rates are needed to pay for cost increases at its Palo Verde nuclear plant.

description: ONE sunny morning, before he retired as president of the General Motors Corporation in 1981, Elliott M. Estes stood in the outdoor dining area of the Tavern on the Green in Central Park, talking about the push for fuel economy. ''We've done the easy part,'' he said. ''We got rid of the fat. The rest is going to be tougher.''

title: Pope Appeals for Lebanon
description: Pope John Paul II called today for prayers to end the fighting in Lebanon. ''I invite you once again to remember to pray for Lebanon, which has fallen prey to fratricidal struggle,'' the Pope told 30,000 pilgrims and tourists at his weekly general audience at St. Peter's Square.

title: HOSPITALS' PLANS IN CITY CALLED 'UNAFFORDABLE'
description: Plans by New York City's private hospitals and medical centers to spend more than $4 billion on renovations and new technology should be drastically cut, the city's federally financed health planning agency advised Governor Cuomo yesterday.

title: Pakistan Opposition Leader Quits Hospital to Join March
description: The ailing leader of a Pakistani opposition party has left a Karachi hospital to lead a march Thursday against the country's military Government, members of his party said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST THURSDAY, SEPT. 1, 1983
description: The Economy Leading economic indicators rose just 0.3 percent in July, the smallest of 11 consecutive monthly gains, the Commerce Department reported. The figure suggests that the recovery's strong pace, which was worrying many economists, is slowing down. With slower growth, experts said, interest rates might recede a bit. But they cautioned against putting too much importance in a one-month change in the index. (Page A1.) Prices farmers get for raw products climbed 4.6 percent in August, the sharpest such increase in more than three years, the Agriculture Department reported. The increase, after two months of declines, was linked to widespread drought and the payment-in-kind acreage program, both of which are squeezing supplies. (D1.)

title: Food, Not Drugs
description: A United States Olympian from 1968 and 1972 who still holds track- and-field world records said he believed that special foods can be a stronger supplement to athletic training than anabolic steroids or other drugs. Lee Evans , who has world records in the 400-meter dash and as a member of the United States 1,600- meter relay team, now coaches other athletes and is an advocate of special nutritional programs.

title: THE BROADWAY SEASON STRETCHES INTO SUMMER
description: It was like a ''What's Wrong With This Picture?'' quiz. A big, expensive musical opened on Broadway, complete with all the attendant hoopla. But there was one thing out of place. When ''La Cage aux Folles'' arrived in New York, the month was August, and only a few years ago that would have been unthinkable.

description: ''NO one at my office ever asked me about what it was like to live in the South Street Seaport area before all this publicity about its opening,'' says Stephen Van Anden, a systems engineer with IBM, and a painter. ''Now everybody's curious; one of the executives who's about to retire has even been looking for a place to buy. People are recognizing it's not just a 9-to-5 community.''

Exploratory talks about a possible joint venture at New Stanton, Pa., have ceased, Volkswagen says, but discussions of other cooperative efforts continue. A related article appears on page D2.

title: ADVERTISING ; Spending Up Sharply For Newspaper Ads
description: Spending on ads in daily newspapers climbed 23.7 percent in June from June of last year, to $1.8 billion, according to preliminary estimates of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau.

description: In a city of lawyers, where hourly rates can reach $250 and where beginners in many large firms draw salaries of $40,000 a year, there is a group of practitioners who feel they are grievously underpaid.

description: President Reagan today dropped his proposed pay freeze for the Federal Government's 1.4 million white-collar workers, calling instead for a 3.5 percent salary rise, effective Jan. 1.

description: Jim Fregosi won the 1983 Casey Stengel Award as manager of the year in the American Association. Fregosi, the former manager of the California Angels, led the Louisville Redbirds to first place in the American Association's Eastern Division. . . . Scott Frank , the 25-year-old heavyweight from Oakland, N.J., said that the cut he suffered during a sparring session last Friday would not jeopardize his challenge on Sept. 10 in Atlantic City for Larry Holmes 's World Boxing Council title. . . . Jacques Burrelle , the general manager of the Montreal Manic, has reversed his plan of protest by saying his club would play the Chicago Sting at home Saturday night.

description: THIS is the month when outdoor plants begin to slow down, which is a shame since September is a time when outdoor activities are a delight. But spring begins in the fall, and the chores that remain to be done yield a colorful and healthy garden next year.

title: Catholic Teachers Threaten Strikes
description: A union representing 4,700 lay teachers at 300 Roman Catholic schools failed to reach a labor agreement yesterday with the Archdiocese of New York. The union said talks would not resume until Sept. 6, the day before school is scheduled to open.

title: BATES MOTEL IS MEASURING UP
description: When a big brown yearling colt by Sir Ivor was led into the auction ring at Newmarket in October 1980, the British breeders and buyers in the sales pavilion exchanged a roomful of knowing smiles and winks. The thoroughbred up for sale was a full brother to Super Asset, one of the best 2-year-olds in England the previous year, and his owners expected a fat price for the brother. But the buyers at Newmarket were too smart to be duped by the fancy pedigree.

title: THE DANCE: MISS GAMSO IN CHELSEA
description: -modernist choreographer with a great many ideas. She took chances, too, in the dances she and her company presented on Tuesday at the Newfoundland in Chelsea. And both dances were memorable, though for very different reasons.

title: Korean Gas Project
description: France's Technigaz Corporation and Japan's Marubeni Corporation will help construct a liquefied natural gas facility in South Korea, the Korea Gas Corporation said today. Technigaz has won a $130 million contract to build storage tanks, and Marubeni has won a $16 million contract to lay pipelines.

title: El Paso Layoffs
description: The El Paso Company said its chemical manufacturing subsidiary would lay off about 400 workers, or 25 percent of its total work force, in three Texas cities. El Paso's president, J. Virgil Waggoner, said the cutback, ''although regrettable, is the only way to keep our chemical manufacturing business in a competitive cost position.'' The unit has posted losses for nine consecutive fiscal quarters.

title: PUBLISHER REJECTS 'OFFENSIVE' BOOKS
description: Dodd, Mead & Company, the 144- year-old New York trade-book publisher, has canceled two novels advertised in its fall 1983 catalogue and withdrawn a volume of verse that is already in print. Dodd, Mead was ordered to take these actions by its parent company, Thomas Nelson Inc. of Nashville, the world's largest Bible publisher, which considered some of the language in these books objectionable.

description: The Soviet Union expressed concern today at the ''use of armed force'' by United States Marines in Beirut, saying that their actions had aggravated the situation and created a new threat to peace in the Middle East.

description: The Challenger astronauts successfully launched a communications- weather satellite for India early today and received a telephone call from President Reagan, who said the presence of a black in the crew was evidence that ''we are in an era of brotherhood here in our land.''

title: CABARET: MISS GALLO, SATARIST
description: MARION GALLO, a vivacious singer and comedienne with a small cult following, specializes in parodies of dumb and not-so-dumb 1950's-style blonde bombshells. In her cabaret act, for which she has created both the songs and the patter, Miss Gallo goes from playing a French showgirl whose lovers all die violently to a torch singer recollecting a Parisian dalliance.

description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid in January.

title: Nicaraguan Rebels Say They Got Heavy Arms
description: Nicaraguan rebels based in Costa Rica said today that they had added mortars, heavy machine guns, bazookas and rocket-propelled grenades to their arsenal.

title: German-Chinese Talks
description: SMS Schloemann Siemag, the West German steel plant builder, is discussing a deal with China, industry sources said today. The chairman of SMS is in Peking, a company spokesman said.

title: Bank Rate Up Again
description: Interest rates offered by banks for money market deposit accounts rose again in the latest seven-day period, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.

title: WOMAN, 20, IS FOUND STRANGLED AFTER ROBBERY IN HER L.I. HOME
description: A 20-year-old woman was found strangled Tuesday night in her ransacked home in this community on the Queens- Nassau County border, the police said today.

title: A Caterpillar Closing
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said yesterday that its British subsidiary would close an assembly plant at Newcastle-on-Tyne next year. Some production will be shifted to the company's Glasgow plant.

title: HARRIS BANKCORP MAY BE ACQUIRED
description: The Bank of Montreal, which unsuccessfully tried to buy the New York area branches of the Bankers Trust Company in 1978, is negotiating to acquire Harris Bankcorp, the third-largest bank in Chicago and the 36th-largest in the United States, according to banking industry sources.

title: JerseyLotterySets 3 Annual Records
description: The New Jersey Lottery broke annual records in sales, prizes and revenue during the fiscal year that ended June 30, Governor Kean announced today.

title: MAYOR OF CHICAGO SUSPENDS LAYOFFS
description: Mayor Harold Washington today suspended his plan to dismiss 2,045 city employees. He did so several hours after the City Council voted to rescind $11.9 million of a $22 million property tax cut.

title: CORRECTION
description: A photo caption accompanying an article on kosher carryouts in yesterday's Living Section incorrectly identified the dish shown. It was a noodle and raisin kugel that contained no cheese or other dairy product.

title: YALE MUSEUM PIECES COPIED
description: THE newest arrival in the field of museum reproduction furniture is the Garvan collection at Yale. In 1930, as a gesture to his wife on their 20th wedding anniversary, Francis P. Garvan, Yale '97, donated an extensive collection of American decorative arts and furniture to his alma mater and started the Mabel Brady Garvan rooms at the Yale University Art Gallery.

title: Triangle Offering $76.5 Million Issue
description: A $76.5 million issue of Triangle Industries 11 1/2 percent subordinated debentures due in 2003 with common stock purchase warrants was offered yesterday at $850 a unit through underwriters led by L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Tobin.

title: Eurobonds Weak In Quiet Trading
description: Fixed-interest bonds denominated in dollars continued to drift lower today in quiet trading, with declines of about 3/4 point, dealers said. Trading was depressed by the opening price weakness in United States credit markets and by a relatively high Federal funds rate of 9 5/8 percent.

title: Dutchess County Drops Liquor Plan
description: The Dutchess County Alcohol Beverage Control Board has dropped a plan to cut bar hours and change hours for liquor sales at package stores and supermarkets.

title: PCB'S IN BUILDINGS CALLED WIDE PERIL
description: An expert warned Tuesday that fires in electrical transformers insulated with polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, were a far greater public health hazard than such widely feared poisons as Agent Orange or the dioxin found at Times Beach, Mo.

title: U.S. Aide Says Rebels Shun Salvadoran Vote
description: Richard B. Stone, the special American envoy, said today that the insurgents ''apparently reject'' participation in elections and he warned that rebel attempts to gain power by force would be unacceptable to El Salvador.

title: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 1, 1983 International
description: Lebanon's army counterattacked the leftist Moslem militiamen who had seized large parts of West Beirut. In a major show of force, about 6,000 troops made an armor and infantry assault stretching across all of the largely Moslem half of the capital, and by nightfall the army appeared to have regained control of most key sectors. (Page A1, Column 6.) The Reagan Administration denied for the third day that the American marines in Lebanon had been involved in hostilities or had been the targets of Molsem militia units. Secretary of State George P. Shultz, speaking at a news conference, said there were no plans to increase the size of the contingent or to expand its largely passive mission. (A1:5-6.)

description: AMONG growth industries, the exhibition catalogue must take a high place. In fact the two classes of people in the art world who are most likely to make a steady income are the ones who frame the pictures, on the one hand, and the ones who print the catalogues, on the other.

title: McRae Oil Vote
description: McRae Consolidated Oil and Gas Inc. said that election inspectors had certified results of a vote that showed shareholders had rejected a proposal to convert the company to a partnership. The defeat paves the way for McRae to be acquired by the Lear Petroleum Corporation of Dallas. Lear owns 50.48 percent of McRae.

title: VENEZUELA GETS NEW HEAD OF STATE OIL CONCERN
description: Humberto Calderon Berti, Venezuela's Minister of Energy and Mines and a former president of the Organzation of Petroleum Exporting Countries, was sworn in last night as president of Petroleos de Venezuela, the national oil company.

title: 2 in Herstatt Case Jailed
description: A court today closed the books on the case concerning the collapse of I. D. Herstatt, a private bank, convicting the final two defendants of fraud and complicity in the largest bank failure in West German history.

title: AMERICANS FOUND MORE TOLERANT AT THE POLLS
description: Americans are expressing a growing willingness to disregard barriers of race, religion and sex in voting for a President, according to two public opinion surveys published this week.

title: MR. BEGIN'S LEGACY
description: A longtime correspondent in Israel, Michael Elkins of the BBC, once asked Menachem Begin how he would like to be remembered in history. He answered without hesitation: ''As the man who set the borders of the Land of Israel for all eternity.''

title: CHI-CHI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a pooling of interests related to restaurant acquisitions.

title: No Headline
description: Jack Somack Is Dead at 64;Television and Movie Actor

title: 3 Thrift Units
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said it had approved the merger of three Indiana savings and loan associations - First Federal of East Chicago, Gary Federal and Citizens Federal of Hammond. Before the merger, First Federal had $209.5 million in assets and five offices, Gary Federal had $15.2 million in assets and two offices, and Citizens Federal had $260 million in assets and four offices. Citizens Federal is the surviving institution.

title: Sentence in Poison Threat
description: A man has been sentenced to 25 years in prison for threatening to poison cereal manufactured by the Kellogg Company unless he received $32 million in gold. Wendell Leonard Prowse, 38 years old, formerly of Kalamazoo, pleaded guilty July 13 and was sentenced Monday by Federal District Judge Richard Enslen.

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to July 20
description: The share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split effected in April 1983.

title: M.T.A.toReconsider Buying Foreign Steel
description: Under pressure from Governor Cuomo, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will restudy its decision to use Korean-made steel in rebuilding the Throgs Neck Bridge, a spokesman for the M.T.A. said yesterday.

title: SIMON OAKLAND, 61, ACTOR WHO STARRED IN 3 TV SERIES, DIES
description: Simon Oakland, a character actor who appeared in dozens of plays, films and television shows, died at his home here on Monday. He was 61 years old.

title: CHILE AIDE SAYS CHANGES WILL CONTINUE
description: Chile's Interior Minister, Sergio Jarpa Reyes, said in an interview here today that Chile's promised political changes would continue despite the assassination Tuesday of a senior official.

title: WILANDER AND LENDL ADVANCE
description: Mats Wilander says he is not ready to win the United States Open singles title. There is more work to be done, he thinks, on his serve, volley and attacking game.

title: Gunmen in Colombia Kill 2 American Bus Riders
description: A band of armed men stopped a bus in northeast Colombia on Tuesday, dragged three Americans off the vehicle and killed two of them and wounded the third, the police said today. A police spokesman said the murders appeared to have been committed by drug traffickers.

title: FAT-FEAR MAY DELAY MATURITY
description: Youngsters who skip meals because they are afraid of getting fat may slow or permanently stunt their growth and delay their sexual development, a study has reported.

title: ANADITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: U.N. CHIEF REPORTS NO REAL PROGRESS ON NAMIBIA
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said today that he had failed to make ''real progress'' toward gaining the independence of South-West Africa from South Africa's rule.

title: URS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Common Market Duty
description: The European Economic Community's Executive Commission said today that it had reimposed antidumping duties on imports of hardboard from Poland, Sweden and Czechoslovakia. A spokesman for the Common Market said the duties, ranging from 10.3 percent to 19.9 percent, were imposed after the commission discovered that exporters had violated earlier limitations on sales.

title: NEW TRAFFIC LAWS STARTING IN NEW YORK
description: A series of strict new traffic laws will go into effect on Thursday throughout the state. Here are brief descriptions of the new laws as outlined by the the Motor Vehicles Commissioner, John A. Passidomo:

title: NIMSLO HOPES ITS TROUBLES ARE OVER
description: Nimslo International Ltd., a company that attracted millions of dollars in venture capital in Britain last year by selling itself as the next Polaroid, is going through turbulent times.

description: President Reagan has urged Federal employees in a memorandum not to make unauthorized disclosures of classified information and warned that criminal prosecution would follow in cases ''where circumstances warrant.''

title: Henrietta M. Larson Is Dead; Former Professor at Harvard
description: Henrietta M. Larson, a business historian and the first woman to hold a full professorship at the Harvard Business School, died Friday at her home in Northfield, Minn. She was 88 years old.

title: SCREEN: 'CHICAGO BLUES,' A HISTORY
description: ''CHICAGO BLUES'' is an angry film. To document Chicago blues at its source, the British director Harley Cokliss went to South Side clubs, storefront churches and homes. He wound up with both a performance film and an anti-travelogue on ghetto life. It is a stark, forceful combination.

title: Playboy Is Denied A Casino License
description: An appeals court today rejected pleas by Playboy Enterprises Inc. and its chairman, Hugh M. Hefner, for a state casino license. Playboy plans to appeal to the State Supreme Court.

description: b-Net income.

title: THOUSANDS MARCH IN POLISH CITIES ON THE FOUNDING DAY OF SOLIDARITY
description: Tens of thousands of Poles demonstrated today on the third anniversary of the accords that permitted the formation of the independent trade union Solidarity.

description: The Reagan Administration announced today the first big step toward standard nationwide rates for hospitals treating elderly and disabled patients under the Medicare program.

description: Agriculture Department officials will be posted along major Interstate highways leading from the Northeast beginning Oct. 3 to make sure outdoor goods in transit are free of gypsy moths, the Government said today.

title: SEDCO INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After income of $6.1 million from discontinued operations. The fiscal 1983 income included a loss equal to 30 cents a share from taxes on prior years' unremitted foreign earnings. The fiscal 1982 net income included a loss equal to 52 cents a share from taxes on prior years' unremitted foreign earnings, a loss from litigation equal to 34 cents a share, and a gain on sale of securities equal to $4.97 a share.

title: Teacher Strikes AffectOver 60,000 Students By The Associated Press
description: More than 60,000 students stayed home on extended summer vacations in two states today as teachers walked picket lines.

description: A battle for the leadership of the Herut Party began to take shape today as senior party men failed in their effort to make a smooth, swift choice of a successor to Menachem Begin.

description: The MCI Corporation today reiterated its belief that last week's ruling by the Federal Communications Commission on telephone access charges will have a negligible effect on the company.

description: Damage claims from Hurricane Alicia could reach $1.4 billion, a State Farm Insurance spokesman said Tuesday after studying preliminary figures. The hurricane hit the Texas Gulf Coast Aug. 18, killing 21 people.

title: Language and Politics
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:In response to your comment in the Hers column (Aug. 18): I did not mean, say or imply that feminist politics are by definition fine points; nor do I excuse degrading language claiming to be humor. That there are fine points of feminist politics is undebatable to those of us who have spent hours debating them: from allowing men to attend our meetings (early) to whether we have reached the ''second stage'' (recently).

title: CITY IS SEEKING MORE TEACHERS OF HANDICAPPED
description: There will be a shortage of teachers for handicapped children when New York City's schools open Sept. 13, school officials said yesterday.

title: ZIMBABWE AIRMEN CLEARED AND SEIZED ANEW
description: Six white Zimbabwean air force officers were found not guilty today of having aided in the sabotage of 13 warplanes, but then were detained again by the Government 40 minutes later.

title: E.E.C. BIDS U.S. PAY ON STEEL
description: The European Economic Community, angered by protection that the United States has recently given to domestic producers of specialty steel, has demanded up to $150 million a year in trade compensation, European officials said today.

title: KEY BEIRUT AREAS RETAKEN BY ARMY FROM MILITIA UNITS
description: The Lebanese Army, engaging in a major show of force today, counterattacked the leftist Moslem militia units that had seized large parts of West Beirut.

description: Zenith Jones Brown, who wrote mysteries under the pen names of Leslie Ford and David Frome, died Thursday at the Church Home in Baltimore.

title: ON U.S. LATIN POLICY
description: Because of enormous public confusion over the United States' involvement in Central America, I recently visited the region with a delegation of Congressmen to see it first-hand. I went holding political views of El Salvador and Nicaragua shared by many liberals and centrists in our nation. I returned impressed with the effectiveness of United States policy and convinced that we need to be involved.

description: A South Korean airliner with 269 people aboard disappeared this morning near the Soviet island of Sakhalin, off the Pacific coast of Siberia, according to reports in Tokyo and Seoul.

title: No Headline

description: Harvey L. Schein, one-time chairman and chief executive of the Sony Corporation of America, has been named president and chief executive of a Rupert Murdoch company, Skyband Inc. The company plans to broadcast television programs via satellite to homes where cable service is unavailable.

description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. said it is holding discussions with the Boeing Company to delay the delivery of 12 medium- range 757 jets now on order for 1984 and 1985.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A leader of the Agudat Israel Party was misidentified in some editions of The Times yesterday and Monday in captions provided by United Press International for pictures from Israeli Cabinet meetings. He is Menachem Porush.

description: Former Gov. Dan Evans testified Tuesday in Federal court that he believed women working for the state of Washington had experienced wage discrimination.

description: Yardney is a majority-owned subsidiary of the Whittaker Corp.

description: It was meant as a fantasy adventure, but a new CBS prime-time series, ''Whiz Kids,'' has collided with the reality of a disturbing social trend: computer tampering.

description: Bishop Edward A. McGurkin, a Maryknoll missionary and retired bishop of Shinyanga, Tanzania, died of cancer Sunday at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 78 years old and lived at the Maryknoll Center in Ossining, N.Y.

title: Another Butcher Filing
description: Lionel B. Wilde, a brother-in-law of Jake Butcher, the Tennessee financier whose banking empire was dissolved by regulators, has filed for protection from creditors, according to Federal Court documents that came to light yesterday. They indicated Mr. Wilde and nine of his Atlanta-based companies owe $33 million.

title: AdvertisingN. R. Kleinfield Taxis Offer New Space For Ads
description: ''LIKE everybody else, you're always trying to find another place to put advertising,'' Norman Kravis said. About eight months ago, he was riding in a cab, thinking hard. He glanced at the back of the front seat, and mused to himself, ''Hey, here's an empty space.''

title: France Tightens Curbs On Illegal Immigration
description: France today adopted tough measures against illegal immigration to stem a rise in racism and the steady growth of a foreign population of 4.5 million.

description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato yesterday toured an area on the Lower East Side between Avenues A and D known for narcotics sales and announced that 35 more Federal drug- enforcement agents would be assigned to city.

description: The Government has received 37 applications for licenses to provide and operate 12 pilot cable television stations in Britain, a Home Office spokesman said today. Names of the applicants were not released.

title: Free Patriots Tickets
description: Faced with poor ticket sales for their season opener Sunday with the Baltimore Colts, the New England Patriots are sending two complimentary tickets for the game to each of their 7,500 season-ticket holders, many of whom have more than one season ticket, said a team spokesman, Tom Hoffman .

description: The Turner Broadcasting System has said that it recorded a profit in the second quarter of $4.3 million, or 21 cents a share, marking its third straight profitable quarter.

description: The value of the typical single-family home built since 1970 climbed to $70,900 in 1981, the Government said today.

title: QUESTIONS REMAIN ON FOAM INSULATION
description: THE last year and a half has been a period of confusion for the owners of houses that contain urea-formaldehyde foam insulation, a material that was banned in February 1982 by the Federal Consumer Product Safety Commission. That confusion was compounded last week when the Reagan Administration decided to allow the insulation back on the market.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: -SPEAK EASY The Bottom Line, a nightclub in Greenwich Village at 15 West Fourth Street (228-6300), is a place where the sound is loud. Tonight, however, in shows at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M., sound will be incidental; it is a program called ''Sight Gags - An Evening of Visual Comedy.''

description: The General Accounting Office today issued what it called a final report concluding that some of President Reagan's appointees to the Legal Services Corporation had acted properly in paying themselves consulting fees and expense reimbursements last year.

title: MARINES SEE NO NEED TO ALTER POLICY
description: The United States Marines do not feel the need for changes in their instructions in Lebanon, or believe that the fighting of recent days poses unacceptable risks, a senior Marine officer said today.

description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said it had approved the merger of Washington Federal Savings and Loan Association of New York and Community Federal Savings and Loan Association of Hialeah, Fla. The merged associations will form a newly organized Federal stock savings bank to be known as the Ensign Bank, which will be owned by the Hamilton Holding Company, an investor in tourism and real estate.

description: THE benign days of September fool gardeners into thinking that their house plants are safe outdoors. Not so. For all house plants except Christmas cactus, vacation is over.

description: Fares for train riders and intrastate bus riders of N.J. Transit are scheduled to go up on Thursday by an average of 8 percent.

title: EX-CONVICT FIGHTS FOR HIS NEW JOB AS SCHOOL CHIEF
description: A former felon hired as superintendent of schools here six weeks after leaving prison said today that he would not approve of just any convict running a school.

title: Peking Curbs Use of Knives In Move to Cut Violent Crime
description: The Public Security Ministry has ordered strict controls on the carrying and use of knives to reduce violent crimes, the official newspaper People's Daily said today.

title: ECONOMIC INDEX SHOWS RECOVERY IS SLOWING A BIT
description: A gauge the Government uses to predict the performance of the nation's economy suggests that the strong pace of recovery so far this year, which had begun to worry many economists, is slowing down, the Commerce Department reported today.

REASONABLY PRICED CLOST ORGANIZERS
description: ANEW line of reasonably priced closet organizers makes it possible for even the moderately handy person to make more effective use of space.

title: General Dynamics
description: The General Dynamics Corporation was awarded a $110.9 million Navy contract for 730 missile guidance controls. The controls include autopilot battery kits and 51 spare guidance sections.

title: HER BROTHER IS ACCUSED
description: A 31-year-old New Jersey woman and her two young children were beaten to death yesterday with a piece of pipe in the bedrooms of their three- story frame home in Jersey City, a spokesman for the police said.

title: 'LEMON LAW' TAKES EFFECT AMID DISPUTES ON COVERAGE
description: Even as New York State's new ''lemon law,'' designed to protect consumers from persistent defects in new cars, goes into effect today, a court battle is set to begin over just which consumers are covered by the law.

description: Potential crude oil resources in Chinese waters in the South China Sea total between 40 billion and 100 billion barrels, Zhai Guangming, chief geologist of the Petroleum Corporation of China, said today.

description: Treasury note and bond prices fell for the fifth consecutive day with some issues showing cumulative declines of more than four points, or $40 per $1,000 face amount in that period.

title: ADVERTISING ; Dancer Regrouping Creative Departments
description: Back in 1965, Dancer Fitzgerald Sample broke its creative department into autonomous groups that eventually grew to seven. Now the agency has decided that things were a bit unwieldy and it is reorganizing the seven departments into three divisions.

title: Metromedia Inc.
description: Metromedia Inc. said it expects 1983 earnings from operations to rise to between $42 million and $45 million from last year's $36.1 million. Metromedia said its preliminary estimates for 1984 indicate strong growth for the company's broadcasting and telecommunications operations and suggest substantial improvement for net income and sales.

description: OUTDOOR lighting, once used only on large estates and mansions, has become increasingly popular, primarily because of the development of low-voltage systems that any do-it- yourselfer can safely install with just a screwdriver. No special skills are needed, and most systems have lights that can easily be moved or added to.

description: Japan's leading indicator of future economic activity fell to 66.7 in June from 79.2 in May, the Economic Planning Agency said today.

title: Peerless in Accord
description: Peerless Insurance said it had agreed to acquire the Excelsior Insurance Company for $22.36 a share, or $19 million. Completion of the acquisition, which requires approval by holders of two-thirds of Excelsior's shares outstanding, is expected later this year. Excelsior's directors, who hold 42 percent of the company's stock, have agreed to vote their shares in favor of the acquisition and have granted Peerless an option to acquire their shares, Peerless said.

U.S. Calls U.N. Council Powerless in Chad Crisis
description: Charles M. Lichenstein of the United States accused the Security Council today of failing to resolve the crisis in Chad, saying that its deliberations demonstrated ''its utter futility as an effective instrument of international peace and security.''

title: 8 KILLED IN BLAZE AT MENTAL FACILITY
description: A fire that quickly spread through a rustic cottage-style dormitory at a rural home for the mentally handicapped killed eight people today and injured two, the authorities said.

title: No Headline
description: Make Gas-Guzzlers Pay With sales booming and generous earnings in sight, the auto industry is all smiles. Well, not quite. The resurgence is based largely on the demand for larger, less fuel-efficient models. Ford and General Motors, by their own projections, will be unable to meet Federal fuel economy standards in coming years, leaving them liable to fines of hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: A MILLION FILIPINOS LINE THE AQUINO FUNERAL ROUTE
description: Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the slain opposition leader, was buried tonight after a 10-and- a-half-hour funeral procession that passed through crowds that the police said totaled a million people.

title: BEAUMONT: MUST IT BE REMODELED?
description: The proposed renovation of the thrust-stage Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center has become the major source of contention between the Beaumont and Lincoln Center boards. Should the theater be completely remodeled? And if so, must renovation take place before a season of plays can be successfully presented, or would minor modifications suffice?

title: Apache Petroleum
description: The Apache Petroleum Company said it had acquired an average 82 percent working interest in 34 producing oil wells in the Riffe Field in North Center, Kan., for $31.9 million. The wells, all drilled in the last 18 months, have produced 907,280 barrels of oil to date, the company said. Currently, they are producing at the rate of about 1,090 barrels of oil daily net to Apache's interest, it said.

title: ART: A MUSICAL TASTE IN ITALIAN DRAWINGS
description: ''FIFTY ITALIAN DRAWINGS: 1375-1775,'' in the cloister of the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, through Nov. 13, presents the cream of Janos Scholz's collection of 1,500 Italian drawings as selected by Cara Denison, associate curator of drawings at the Morgan. Mr. Scholz's drawings have been exhibited around the world, usually in theme shows, but never before in New York in a way that would allow the collection - a promised gift to the library - to be seen by itself.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: BARON HANS HEINRICH THYSSEN-BORNEMISZA says he doesn't always give parties before a showing of segments of his vast art collection. But he has lots of friends in New York, and on Monday evening, two days before 75 paintings of 20th-century masters from the Thyssen-Bornemisza holdings were opened to the public at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Baron invited 100 friends to cocktails at the museum, followed by dinner at the Union League Club.

title: Head of Brazil's Central Bank Quits
description: The head of Brazil's central bank, Carlos Langoni, quit today, according to a central bank spokesman. Mr. Langoni disagreed with demands made by the International Monetary Fund that Brazil balance its budget and sharply reduce inflation, the spokesman said.

title: 3 States Hold Bank Talks

title: IN SEARCH OF THE SITES OF NEW YORK'S LABOR HISTORY
description: LABOR, which is being celebrated this holiday weekend, has been important in the life of New York City since before the United States became a nation. On April 2, 1747, for instance, a petition was sent to the royal Governor from 100 ''of his majesty's loyal subjects & freemen of this flourishing City of New York,'' complaining that people in neighboring provinces ''make a practice of coming into this City after the laying of Our Taxes yearly, there to exercise their several handcraft trades such as carpenters, bricklayers &c., undermining us, the ancient Freemen of the afd. city, by offering the services of themselves, journeymen & servants'' at the rate of $:20 or $:30 a job less ''than has been agreed to by us.''

title: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 2, 1983 Downing of Flight 7
description: A South Korean 747 was shot down in the Sea of Japan by a Soviet fighter near a Soviet island off Siberia, the United States announced. There were no known survivors aboard the plane carrying 269 people on a flight from New York to Seoul. American, Soviet and Japanese ships and planes fruitlessly searched the frigid seas north of Japan where the airliner apparently went down. There was an unconfirmed report that the long-missing plane had experienced radio difficulties and thus may have been unable to hear or respond to any Soviet warnings, but there was no clear explanation for the attack. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Moscow was silent for nearly 24 hours and then confirmed that its fighters had intercepted and warned ''an unidentified plane'' that it was intruding on Soviet air space. But the late report by the official press agency Tass made no mention of any attack on the South Korean airliner. (A1:3.)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST FRIDAY, SEPT. 2, 1983
description: Markets The first grain sale to the Soviet Union under a new agreement was announced by the Agriculture Department, even as the Senate Democratic leader called for the pact's cancellation because of the apparent downing of a Korean jet by the Russians. (Page D1.) Grain and soybean futures prices sank, reflecting fears that the grain accord would be jeopardized. (D8.) The dollar surged on foreign exchange markets, reversing two days of losses. Analysts cited the dollar's appeal as a haven during crisis. Gold prices rose $1.25 an ounce, to $415.25, in New York. (D8.) The U.S. apparently did not intervene in foreign exchange markets to stabilize the dollar's value, traders said. (D8.)

title: STREAK ENDED AT 8

title: BEGIN'S PARTY CHOOSES SHAMIR AS NEW LEADER
description: Yitzhak Shamir, the 68-year-old Foreign Minister of Israel, was elected early this morning to succeed Prime Minister Menachem Begin as leader of the governing Herut Party. This placed him in a favorable position to become the next Prime Minister if he can hold together Mr. Begin's coalition of right- wing and religious factions.

Until the divestiture of the Bell System next January, Ameritech Mobile Communications will remain a unit of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: THEATER: PHILIP BOSCO JOINS CAST OF 'MUTINY'
description: PHILIP BOSCO is a fine American actor in the British tradition. Dedicated to the theater, he moves from play to play, from leading to featured roles, and he never stops working. Recently he was the father in ''Ah! Wilderness'' at the Roundabout. When that play closed, he was transformed into Captain Queeg in ''The Caine Mutiny Court-Martial'' at Circle in the Square. While not slighting the captain's martinet personality, he gives a performance that is filled with empathetic understanding.

title: No Headline
description: WINTER'S TALE. By Mark Helprin. 673 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $14.95. I KNOW a divorced father with literary aspirations who makes up interminable bedtime stories for his 7-year-old son on the one night a week the boy sleeps at his place. The stories are picaresque, filled with adventure, magic, love and violence. They also contain surprisingly beautiful digressions, in which the father seems to be confiding his undisguised hopes and fears to his son. The boy is restless listening to these stories, but he realizes that his father needs to tell them.

title: MORGAN LIBRARY SHOWS TREASURES OF THE OPERA
description: It all started in Florence in 1600, when a group of gentlemen decided to re-create what they thought sung Greek drama to be. From there it went on to Monteverdi, Handel, Gluck, Mozart, Wagner, Verdi, Strauss, Debussy, Puccini, Massenet, Berg, Britten. And thousands and thousands of other composers who composed thousands and thousands of operas, most of which are forgotten. The once-famous Alessandro Scarlatti (1660-1725) alone wrote about 115. Not one of them has remained in the repertory.

Berry and the university are suing the National Collegiate Athletic Association, which has ruled that, because he left Benjamin Franklin High School without graduating and has never passed an equivalency test, he is ineligible.

description: The final series of races to choose an America's Cup defender came to an unexpectedly quick end this evening with the selection of Liberty.

title: 9-TO-5 VICTORY OVER THE U.S. CHEERS NICARAGUANS
description: A wave of patriotic delirium swept through town this week, and why not? Nicaragua had defeated what it considers its most powerful enemy, the United States, in head-on combat.''We Wipe Out the Yankees!'' screamed a headline in the Sandinista newspaper Barricada. The triumph came at the Pan American Games in Caracas, Venezuela, where Nicaragua's national baseball team, a scrappy if not exceptionally talented squad, defeated the Americans by a score of 9 to 5 and came home with a silver medal. Cuba won the gold, and the United States had to settle for bronze in the sport it invented.

title: Coe's Disorder Rare
description: A series of tests at Leicester Hospital in England has confirmed that Sebastian Coe , who holds the world records in the 800-meter and one-mile runs, is suffering from a rare glandular disorder. Dr. Karl Nicholson , a consultant in infectious diseases, said Coe had glandular toxoplasmosis, an infection that the doctor said affected fewer than 200 people in England each year and that can resemble glandular fever. Coe, who underwent the tests after four straight exceptionally poor outings, probably contracted the disease last April or May, Dr. Nicholson said. Coe is not likely to start training again for several months.

title: Canada Trade Surplus
description: Canada's current account balance of payments surplus rose to $1.1 billion in the second quarter, seasonally adjusted, from an upward revised $253 million in the first quarter and a $965 million surplus in the second quarter last year, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today. The surplus resulted from a sharp increase in merchandise exports, which brought the trade surplus to a new quarterly high.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, SEPT. 3, 1983
description: The Economy The jobless rate edged up to 9.4 percent in August, its first increase since December, the Labor Department reported. The 0.1 percent increase was regarded as insignificant, however, especially since it followed an unexpectedly large decline of 0.5 percent in July. Moreover, the increase was accompanied by another strong gain in employment and other positive figures, prompting experts to say that the strong labor-market improvement since early winter is, in effect, continuing. The jobless rate for the civilian labor force was unchanged at 9.5 percent. (Page 1.) New York City's jobless rate in August was unchanged at 10.6 percent. (9.) Despite the recent recession, employment among women has shown strong growth. (9.) New-car dealers say their sales have been so strong in recent months that they are losing sales now because of depleted inventories. Because this is the end of the model year, they have been unable to replenish their supplies. (29.) Chrysler and the U.A.W. will try again this weekend to agree on a new contract. (8.)

Wilson joined the Saints in 1981, having been forced out of college football by the conference's decision that he had used up his eligibility by playing at a junior college in California and then one season at Illinois.

title: TO MEET THE TRANSIT NEEDS HERE
description: Twin resignations at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will allow Governor Cuomo to appoint a new chairman of the board and chief operating officer for the city's subways and buses. In leaving, chairman Richard Ravitch and president John Simpson cited family responsibilities and personal exhaustion, but political considerations dominated their tenure and their departure. Their public legacy lies in the new policies they mapped out and the momentum they established. The question as we look ahead is whether the political process will allow their successors to follow the course they set.

But whose emissions should be cut? And who should pay?

title: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1983 Downing of Flight 7
description: Moscow said a Soviet jet fighter had fired ''warning shots with tracer shells'' along the route of the Korean Air Lines 747 that went down over the Sea of Japan. The statement said the airliner had been sent by the United States on a ''pre-planned'' spying mission and expressed the Soviet leadership's regret ''over the loss of human life.'' It also expressed ''a resolute condemnation of those who consciously or as result of criminal disregard have allowed the death of people and are now trying to use this occurrence for unseemly political ends.'' (Page 1, Column 6.) Mosow's latest statement on the downing of the Korean airliner was rejected by Secretary of State George P. Shultz who accused the Soviet Union of a continuing effort ''to cover up the facts.'' Mr. Shultz said the ''the world is waiting for the Soviet Union to tell the truth.'' (1:5.)

title: CHALLENGER DROPS ORBIT BY 54 MILES

title: TESTS VINDICATE FEMALE ATHLETES
description: SOME sports authorities feel that drug testing, particularly for steroids and male hormones, is just a feckless procedure used as a political ploy. For sportswomen, however, it is an imperfect but necessary beginning for solving their most critical problem - what is a woman? My personal experience should help explain.

title: NO NEW HOPE, JUST AN OLD PEACE PLAN
description: The hopes of progress toward a Middle East peace that President Reagan and his advisers held a year ago have faded. There is no longer any expectation of an early withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces from Lebanon or of a wider negotiation. Secretary of State George P. Shultz, who came to office last summer dedicated to pursuing with vigor a solution to the endemic Middle East issues, seemed a bit defensive at a news conference last week. ''The job is long and difficult, and requires patience and determination,'' he said. The irony was not lost on State Department officials, who remarked that a year ago, President Reagan was outlining sweeping ideas for settling such issues as the Palestinian problem and Israel's ultimate borders. His attention is now devoted to bringing about an end to the street fighting in Beirut, avoiding involvement of the marines there in a civil war, and figuring out Israel's conduct with Menachem Begin no longer in command. Many in Congress are questioning, in the light of the death of two marines last week, whether the United States should assume the role of mediator between ethnic and religious factions that have been at each other's throats for years. There have been many miscalculations in the past year, notably the decision by Mr. Reagan to start his peace initiative before there had been a conclusion of the Lebanese crisis. His peace program - which ruled out Israeli sovereignty over the West Bank - immediately antagonized Mr. Begin and led to a period in which the Israelis openly tried to sabotage American efforts.

title: No Headline

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: AN ORPHAN IN HISTORY: Retrieving a Jewish Legacy. By Paul Cowan. (Bantam, $3.50.) Born into a highly assimilated and prominent Jewish family, Paul Cowan graduated from Choate and Harvard, became a writer for The Village Voice and then embarked, at the age of 36, on a search for his religious and cultural roots that has now led him to see himself partly as Saul Cohen, the descendant of rabbis. Our reviewer, Charles E. Silberman, found this chronicle of a spiritual voyage beautiful and moving. ''An Orphan in History,'' he said, ''will interest hyphenated Americans of every variety.''

description: Mr. and Mrs. Allen L. Boorstein of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Gail Louise Boorstein, to Gary Joseph Palmucci, son of Mr. and Mrs. Remo Palmucci of Concord, Mass. A November wedding is planned.

title: 32 BEETHOVEN SONATAS, AND MORE
description: AS far as Robert Sherman is concerned, there is no point in staging a music festival if ''you don't do something other than a normal concert would do.''

title: CITY SEES LARGER CLASSES FOR THE HANDICAPPED
description: The number of students in classes for the physically and emotionally handicapped will be larger than ever this fall in the New York City schools despite efforts to alleviate overcrowding by moving children into regular classes, according to school officials.

title: THE SOVIET TRAGEDY
description: The Russians have done it again. Almost every time there seems to be a chance of improving United States- Soviet relations, Moscow makes some appalling blunder.

title: THE BURGANDY QUESTION
description: Said thoughts were inspired - provoked may be a better word - by a recent book by Anthony Hanson, a writer and wine merchant, called, simply, ''Burgundy.'' It is Mr. Hanson's contention that a lot of Burgundy is not what it should be, hardly a contentious stance to anyone who has opened even a few bottles of Burgundy in recent years.

title: KEY PLAYERS FACING A FULL SEASON OF CHALLENGES
description: JOHN UNITAS was 14 games from the end of his legendary career when he first met Dan Fouts. They became teammates on the San Diego Chargers within a few months of each other in 1973. The Chargers had bought Unitas's contract from the Baltimore Colts in January and taken Fouts in the third-round of the college draft a few months later. The Chargers opened that season with a soon-to-be Hall of Famer as the starter and a rookie as his backup.

title: NASSAU MAN GETS ALBANY POST ON L.I.
description: CLARENCE D. RAPPLEYEA, the Assembly minority leader, has finally appointed his Long Island aide, after an eight-month selection process in which at least three potential appointees lost out. They lost out for such reasons as having been indicted on extortion charges and having been on the losing side in a political fight.

title: New Superpoison Reported Effective Against Superrats
description: Chemists say they have developed a powerful new weapon for mankind's world struggle against pesticide-resistant rats: a superpoison to use against superrats.

title:
LEISURE;
A GARDENER TALLIES HIS PERENNIAL LOSSES AND GAINS
description: Eugene W. Jackson is a professional writer who gardens as a hobby.

title: FILM VIEW ; 'DANIEL' CONFUSES MORE THAN ONE ISSUE
description: When a film begins the way ''Daniel'' does, it's being either very foolhardy or very brave. The opening image is that of the narrator in tight close-up, scowling furiously as he describes the process of electrocution. Moments later, we see this same young man at a family dinner, sounding no less bitter or sarcastic as he quarrels with his younger sister, who is herself equally enraged. It's a daunting beginning, at the very least. Any audience is bound to be uneasy in the presence of such an abrupt outburst of anger.

title: Widow's Closet Held Skeleton of Husband
description: A skeleton discovered in a closet of a home was the husband of a former occupant who could not afford to have him buried, the police say.

title: LINDA RONSTADT CELEBRATES THE GOLDEN AGE OF POP
description: ''What's New'' (Asylum 60260), Linda Ronstadt's collaboration with the veteran arranger-conductor Nelson Riddle on nine standards of the 30's and 40's, signals a shift in the prevailing winds of pop. Eschewing the trappings of rock, Miss Ronstadt and Mr. Riddle have created a beautiful torch album closely modeled after Frank Sinatra's classic ''Only the Lonely,'' which he recorded with Mr. Riddle 25 years ago. In fact, three of the songs on ''What's New'' were on that album.

title: No Headline
description: Melinda Allison Schneider and Timothy Hugh Carney, graduates of Loyola College in Baltimore, plan to be married Oct. 15. The future bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Joseph Schneider of Hillsdale, N.J., who have announced her engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Gerard Carney of New York and Amagansett, L.I.

title: Q&A
description: Question:

title: HOPES STILL RIDE ON PEDAL AIRCRAFT
description: THE day Christina Kohm pedaled across the North Shore sky, history was made. For one mile, the 14-year- old pedaled a plane that looked like a mammoth prehistoric bird at an airstrip at Brookhaven Municipal Airport. The date was Oct. 1, 1982; the record time was 4 minutes 30 seconds.

title: CRITICISM AS IDEOLOGY
description: LITERARY THEORY

title: THE BIGGEST ISSUE FOR 1984 MAY HAVE ALREADY BEEN IDENTIFIED
description: When politicians in Washington sit around and talk about the 1984 election, they try to guess what the economy will be like, and what it will seem like, in the fall of that year.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books

title: APARTMENTS IN A QUARRY
description: Ground will be broken this month for an opulent high-rise condominum in a former stone quarry directly across the street from the entrance to South Mountain Reservation State Park in South Orange, N.J. The development will be called Cambridge House and it will be built by the First Regency Development Corporation, a company that has built primarily in Florida.

title: A Correction
description: In an article on Col. Muammar el- Qaddafi of Libya in the Aug. 14 Week in Review, the whereabouts of Idi Amin, the ousted Ugandan leader, was incorrectly stated because of an editing error. He is in Saudi Arabia.

title: WHERE THE WEST BEGINS
description: DAN HULBERT is theater critic of The Dallas Times Herald. Fort Worth has never seen itself as a tourist city, which is, of course, precisely the reason that many discriminating tourists have taken it to their hearts. When a reporter from a national magazine visited recently to consider the White Elephant Saloon as ''one of the top 100 bars in America,'' the bartender presented him with a mythical house specialty called ''Buffalo Sweat,'' a drink which he had hastily improvised below the bar, using whatever ingredients happened to be within reach.

title: Talks Set on Baltic Dispute
description: Sweden and Denmark will hold formal talks over a disputed zone of the Baltic Sea where the Danes are drilling for oil, the Swedish Foreign Ministry announced today. It said the two countries had agreed not to sink any new test wells during the talks and that Sweden had accepted provisions under which current prospecting by a Danish company could continue in an area 15 miles north of the Danish island of Hesselo.

title:
STAMPS;
FOR THE MET'S 100TH BIRTHDAY
description: The Metropolitan Opera, which is the subject of a commemorative being issued Sept. 14, came into being 100 years ago largely because of the thwarted fancy of some of New York's new millionaires in the booming post-Civil War period.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: LIBERTARIANS PICK TOP OF 1984 SLATE
description: The Libertarian Party nominated David P. Bergland of California yesterday as its Presidential candidate in a heated contest that took four ballots and an opponent's withdrawal to resolve.

title: LOW-COST LUXURY
description: HICKEN DOUBTless is the single food that best combines versatility, excellence in flavor and texture, and modesty in cost. And it almost goes without saying that the choicest part of the bird is the breast, known for a very good reason in the French kitchen as the supr^eme de volaille. Small wonder that the benevolent Henry IV wanted no peasant in his kingdom ''so poor that he will not have a chicken in his pot every Sunday.''

title: THE XEROX SHUTTLE: A LOOK AT THE ROLE OF CORPORATE AVIATION
description: THE passengers were no sooner seated for a scheduled 3:10 P.M. flight to Rochester the other day at the Westchester County Airport than one of them extended a hand toward the man sitting opposite her.

title: Memorial Service Set For Flight 7 Victims
description: A memorial service for the victims of the Korean Air Lines jet that went down over the the Sea of Japan has been scheduled for Wednesday in Seoul, South Korea, airline officials said yesterday. The airline is providing free air passage to Seoul for relatives.

description: Elizabeth Ann Mortimer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald W. Mortimer of Riverside, Conn., was married there Aug. 27 to Malcolm John Dixon, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Dixon of Greenwich, Conn.

description: The democratization of sculling that Peter Stoler discusses in his article ''The Solitary Joys of Sculling'' (July 24), is actually on its second time around.

title: Service Set for McDonald
description: Kathryn McDonald, the widow of Representative Larry P. McDonald of Georgia, one of 269 people presumed killed in the attack on a Korean airliner Thursday, has organized a memorial service for Sept. 11.

title: Scanlon Is Keeping Vow to Try Harder
description: There was a lot of milling around near Court 17 on the outskirsts of the National Tennis Center at Flushing Meadows yesterday. Most people were leaving a match that had just finished, but amid this scene two men were silently reaffirming a vow.

title: GRASS-ROOTS GROUPS GO NATIONAL
description: IN CITIES, SUBURBS AND SMALL TOWNS FROM NEW Hampshire to Oregon, platoons of activists ranging from unemployed factory workers to high-school youths are knocking on at least 50,000 doors every evening to press the issue of the day, be it toxic waste in Missouri, utility rates in Ohio or tax reform in Connecticut. Late in the evening, they return to small, bare offices with money, commitments for assistance and names and addresses for computers. Soon, many will be installing telephone banks for the 1984 elections and beyond.

description: It's early afternoon. Long hours stretch ahead. Outside, it is one of the most beautiful days of fall. Or winter. Or spring. But here heads are bent over yellowed

title: NAVY'S BOMB NARROWLY MISSES TRUCK DRIVER
description: Naval officials are trying to determine what went wrong on a practice bombing mission this week after an errant bomb narrowly missed a truck driver in the Ocala National Forest.

description: Andres Zaldivar, a former Chilean Finance Minister and former leader of the banned Christian Democratic Party, returned here today from three years of exile in Spain.

title: LEAGUE OF VOTERS TACKLES 80'S ISSUES
description: MARLENE WENOGRAD says she was once ''completely antiorganization,'' avoiding groups and clubs and even intentionally attending a college without sororities.

description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. used to scold Connecticut Republicans for running their affairs like a ''country club.'' He has lately begun to insist that the G.O.P. open its membership to all and, much to many people's surprise, Republican state party leaders are taking the idea quite seriously.

title: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1983 Downing of Flight 7
description: The downing of the Korean airliner is an international issue requiring world leaders to deal with the Russians ''in a calm, controlled, but absolutely firm manner,'' President Reagan said. After Mr. Reagan met with advisers Friday, senior officials said there would be no trade sanctions against the Soviet Union or a suspension of the arms control talks. They said the United States would seek redress through action in the International Civil Aviation Organization and by the International Federation of Airline Pilots Associations. (Page 1, Column 6.)

description: President Reagan, who cut short his California vacation Friday to return to Washington because of the reported shooting down of a South Korean airliner, canceled his planned Labor Day visit to the Kennedy Space Center.

title: NASSAU SOCIAL SERVICE 'WIZARD' RETIRES AFTER 49 YEARS
description: She has been, according to her colleagues, the quintessential dedicated civil servant: 49 years on the job, 73 years old and working up to the very last day she was permitted.

title: PRETORIA SHELVES UNIVERSITY QUOTAS
description: The Government has decided to shelve, for the time being at least, a system of racial quotas on university admissions that aroused strong campus protests when it was enacted into law by the white Parliament only two months ago.

title: NEW PARTIES IN TURKEY STILL FACING A HURDLE
description: The three political parties that Turkey's military rulers have approved for parliamentary elections scheduled for Nov. 6 still face another hurdle. Their candidates must be approved by the ruling National Security Council before the end of September.

title: Curry Stops Stafford To Retain W.B.A. Title
description: Donald (Cobra) Curry of Fort Worth retained his World Boxing Association welterweight title tonight by stopping Roger Stafford of Philadelphia at 1 minute 42 seconds of the first round after the referee stopped the bout on a three- knockdown rule.

title: LABOR DAY PARADE IS FIRST SINCE 1966
description: UNION workers have marched on New Haven streets several times in the last year, picketing a hotel, a factory, a symphony and an outdoor-billboard company.

title: MEXICO PROPOSES MAJOR REVISION OF ITS PANEL CODE
description: Mexico's Attorney General has proposed a major revision in the country's penal code that is intended to add greater flexibility to the judicial system and give fairer treatment to defendants.

title: ELEPHANTS ARE PART OF FAMILY'S BUSINESS
description: BARBARA COMMERFORD knows that ''Elephants are very careful where they put their feet.'' She also knows that ''they are agile and we've brought ours up in freight elevators if they have a big enough door.''

title: THE BIRMINGHAM BOMBING --
description: Howell Raines's article impressed me with its sensitivity. However, Mr. Raines's decision to shelter Robert Chambliss from knowing that it was his wife who put him in prison showed misplaced compassion.

description: IN the office of David L. Blumenfeld on the 26th floor of 111 West

title: Misspellings Prompt 'Police English' Class
description: Investigation reports with misspellings of simple words like ''scene'' and ''their'' have prompted officials to send police recruits to classes in ''police English.''

title: ISRAEL UNITS START THE WITHDRAWAL FROM BEIRUT AREA
description: Israeli tanks and military vehicles by the hundreds streamed southward early this morning as Israel began its long-awaited withdrawal from positions near Beirut.

title: EUROPE FACES HOT AUTUMN ON HOSTILITY TO MISSILES
description: For Western Europe, summer ended last week with the kind of traffic jams and chaotic airports that the United States will experience today and tomorrow. Among other things, the advent of fall marks the beginning of a politically testing season. First and foremost, it is to be the season of the missiles. Unless, by some miracle, American negotiators can wrest a last- minute agreement from the Soviet Union at Geneva, the next few months - the exact dates have not been made public - will see the deployment of United States cruise missiles in West Germany and in Britain. The consequences are hard for anyone to calculate. Chancellor Helmut Kohl disparages predictions of a ''hot autumn'' in West Germany, but he is all but alone in doing so; the general expectation in Bonn is that he will spend much of his time in the weeks to come dealing with a campaign of hunger strikes, protest marches and attempted blockades of NATO bases. The antinuclear movement gave a preview last week with a peaceful demonstration that featured Heinrich B"oll, the Nobel Prize-winning novelist, some members of Parliament and about 1,000 other people outside the gates of a United States Army base in Mutlangen where Pershing 2's are due to be installed. Base officials refrained from calling in the police, which helped keep things quiet. What Mr. Kohl must try to avoid, his aides say, is the creation of a martyr or the involvement of American soldiers in a violent incident, either of which could convince the German public that the missiles are more of a threat than the Soviet threat they are meant to neutralize.

title: 'LONELY HEARTS,' AUSTRALIAN COMEDY
description: ''Lonely Hearts'' is the terrible title of a good, new Australian comedy about the romance of a flawed, middle-aged piano tuner and a pretty, no- longer-young, sexually repressed bank clerk.

title: THE WORLD
description: Hoping Libya would take a hint and abandon its support of armed insurrection in Chad, France sent 2,000 troops to Ndjamena last month and established a defensive ''red line'' across the country. But the lull was broken last week when heavy fighting erupted at the Government outpost of Oum Chalouba, north of the French line.

title: ...COLLEGES STEP UP RECRUITMENT
description: COMPETING for a declining pool of local students, Long Island colleges and universities are seeking to minimize their tuition increases, maximize their financial aid packages and step up out-of-state recruitment.

title: No Headline

description: GOLF communities, where an avid golfer can step out his front door and tee off down a rolling fairway, have spread across the Sun Belt in the last two decades and are now making strides in the Northeast, particularly in the New York metropolitan area.

title: THE POLITICS BEHIND FOUNDATION DIVESTITURE
description: To the Editor:

title: INQUEST IN THE ANDES
description: Mario Vargas Llosa fails to explain how Sendero Luminoso, with only a handful of followers, has managed to terrorize Peru.

title: 'MACNEIL/LEHRER' GEARS UP FOR AN HOUR
description: Beginning tomorrow evening, the Public Broadcasting Service will do something the commercial television networks have talked about doing for years: broadcast an hour- long news program in prime time. ''The MacNeil-Lehrer Newshour'' is a venture that could blaze new trails both for PBS and for network television news. At the same time, it is a considerable gamble.

title: EX-IM BANK
description: To the Business Editor:

title: David Bergamini Dies; Wrote About Hirohito
description: David Howland Bergamini, whose 1971 book on prewar imperial Japan touched off an international dispute, died of cancer early yesterday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived in Rowayton, Conn.

title: COMPLEX ISSUES SLOW UP STUDY OF SHOREHAM
description: LIKE virtually everything else that has to do with the Shoreham nuclear power plant, the commission that Governor Cuomo appointed to study Shoreham- related questions is behind schedule.

title: MARRIED PRIESTS TO PETITION POPE
description: About 50 Roman Catholic priests from six countries, many with their wives and some with their children, gathered here this week for what they called the first international synod of married priests.

title: Suspect in Two Deaths May Face New Counts
description: A 24- year-old kitchen worker at a residence for the elderly who has been charged with raping and killing two residents will be charged with four additional counts of rape and murder next week, officials said.

title: RIVAL OF TRUDEAU GAINING IN CANADA
description: Promising to build ''a brand new Canada,'' Brian Mulroney moved a big step toward his goal of becoming this nation's next Prime Minister by winning a landslide victory Monday in his first bid for a seat in Parliament.

title: CAN PINOCHET FIGHT OFF MOUNTING OPPOSTION?
description: Ten years ago next Sunday, Gen. Augusto Pinochet led the coup in which the elected President of Chile, the Marxist Salvador Allende, died. This week, the Government is planning celebrations but they are shadowed by questions as to how much longer the regime can survive. Two years of economic depression have brought popular discontent and demands for General Pinochet's resignation. At least 34 people have been killed in four nationwide protests called by opposition political and labor leaders over the last four months. The fifth protest is planned for Thursday. And late last month, terrorists assassinated Carol Urzua, a retired major general who was chief administrator of Santiago, the capital. He was the highest-ranking official killed since the coup. During last month's day of protest, General Pinochet tried cracking down, sending 18,000 army troops into the streets of Santiago to curb demonstrators. But the tough tactics backfired. The resulting melee of wild shooting led to 24 deaths, increasing opposition resolve and drawing international criticism, notably from the normally friendly Reagan Administration. Perhaps equally important, the violence upset foreign bankers and creditors. General Pinochet is now trying a softer approach. His new Interior Minister, Enrique Jarpa Reyes, has begun the regime's first dialogue with the opposition in a decade and has offered the beginnings of a transition to democracy. He also promised to legalize political parties next year and to hold Congressional elections well before the scheduled date of 1990. Last week, Mr. Jarpa ended the state of emergency, withdrawing curfew and censorship powers held by local military commanders.

title: PERSONALITIES PUT FIRST IN CONGRESS
description: Senators and House members select their institutions' leaders more on the basis of personal compatibility than because of political ideology, as is often assumed, according to several leading scholars.

title: Mead Festival to Show Anthropological Films
description: About 50 anthropological films from around the world, some never before shown in New York, will be screened at the seventh Margaret Mead Film Festival which begins on Sept. 12 at 6:30 P.M. at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street. The festival will run through Sept. 15 and films will be shown simultaneously in the museum's four theaters.

title: THE NATION
description: The EconomyCools DownTo a SimmerWhen is a slower economy more cause for cheer than concern? The answer was evident in the reaction to last week's report of a fractional increase in the index of leading indicators for July. The time is now.

title: TWO RESTORERS
description: Two Brooklyn restorers of antique objects - one specializing in rugs and the other in textiles - are carrying on in something of the Old World workshop tradition, yet with a certain informality and immediacy that goes with the character of the borough.

title: PARTY STRIFE HALTS PERONISTS' CONVENTION IN ARGENTINA
description: Argentina's largest political party, the Peronist party, began its presidential nominating convention today amid such discord that it was recessed until Monday.

title:
MUSIC VIEW;
WHAT WOULD WE DO WIHTOUT K. AND D.?
description: Many great thinkers, recognizing that the human race is a house temperamentally divided against itself, have tried to construct categories in hopes of making the problem understandable. For Nietzsche the split was between Apollo and Dionysius, for Sir Isaiah Berlin between the Hedgehog and the Fox, for Arthur Koestler between the Yogi and the Commissar. Robert Pirsig's ''Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance'' varoomed at the question from still another direction.

title: Gales Kill 4 in British Isles
description: At least four deaths were attributed to gales that swept across much of England, Wales and Ireland Friday night and this morning.

title: THE DAZZLING ART OF THE OTTOMANS
description: Aferocious horde sweeping in from the deserts of Mongolia, only to become the most decadent and luxurious of civilizations. That, along with turbans, scimitars, harems and minarets, is the image most of us have of the Ottoman Empire; and it is very far from being wrong. No sooner did the nomadic Turks reach the heartland of the Byzantine Empire than they began to see the point of a more settled, more self-indulgent way of life. It was not, however, until they finally conquered Anatolia in the 15th century that they developed a culture of legendary splendor. Clearly it was no accident: Anatolia, the link between Europe and Asia, was more than just a geographical entity.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

description: The political message used to be the only medium in contemporary Chinese theater. During the 1966-1976 Cultural Revolution, ideologues even dictated the plots and sent playwrights to research the details firsthand among the masses, who enjoyed final script approval.

title: THE WORLD

Marcos. Mr. Marcos and his ministers were absent from the funeral but perhaps as many as one million other people were present at the church service and along the 19- mile route to the cemetery.

description: John J. Sidote, who is imprisoned here, filed suit Thursday asking to be excused from testifying when the trial starts in New Orleans Oct. 11.

title: BOUND FOR GLORY
description: AS WITH NO OTHER GARMENT, men seem to develop a sentimental attachment to their trench coats. Maybe Hollywood has something to do with it. After all, the trench coat became a virtual second skin for the likes of Humphrey Bogart, Robert Mitchum, Burt Lancaster and Edward G. Robinson, to name but a few. Indeed, even Marlene Dietrich and Bette Davis were at their feisty best (as in ''Witness for the Prosecution'' and ''Deception'' when devilishly draped in such decidedly masculine apparel. On the other hand, its appeal may be simply that the coat is flattering on anyone who wears it.

title: EVANGELICAL SCHOLARS START AMBITIOUS VENTURE
description: A group of noted Christian evangelicals have begun a publishing venture aimed at countering what they believe to be a serious neglect of Christianity by American intellectuals.

title: DerekJ.deSollaPrice, Professor at Yale, Dies
description: Dr. Derek J. de Solla Price, Avalon Foundation professor of the history of science at Yale University since 1960, died of a heart attack yesterday at St. Mary's Hospital in London. He was 61 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: CITY SURVEY FINDS UNSKILLED IN BIND
description: The decline in manufacturing activity in the city in recent years and a lack of job opportunities in the expanding service fields for people with few skills and limited education are two key factors in the city's continuing unemployment problems, according to a study of adult workers here.

CAMERA;
A PHOTO SAFARI-AT THE LOCAL ZOO

title: INN FOR STAMFORD
description: Travelers throughout the Northeast have been known to make detours to stop at the award-winning restaurant in the Copper Beech Inn in Ivoryton, Conn., which was bought and restored in the early 1970's by Jo and Robert McKenzie. The couple ran the small hotel and restaurant until 1981, when they sold the business.
