description: OUTRAGEOUS ACTS AND EVERYDAY REBELLIONS

title: RETURNING TO THE ROMANTIC SYMPHONY
description: Like nearly all musical forms, the symphony never really solidified: it was - and is - in a process of constant evolution. Nonetheless, the idea of a symphony remains fixed in people's minds in the late-Classical pattern, meaning a sonata-form fast first movement, with or without a slow introduction; a slow movement; a three-quarter-time minuet or scherzo, and a bustling finale.

title: Convicts to Clean Riot Site
description: Gov. George Nigh said today that he had ordered officials to return convicts immediately to the Conner Correctional Center to clean up the riot-torn prison. One inmate was killed and 20 inmates and 3 guards were injured in the riot Monday at the prison in Hominy, Okla.

title: COSMOS FINISH IN FAMILIAR POSITION
description: The Cosmos joke now that they have captured their sixth consecutive overall point championship in the North American Soccer League. But they had believed in the middle of the season that they would finish behind the Vancouver Whitecaps in the overall standing before going into the playoffs.

title: 'Winter's Tale'
description: ARRIVING late at an elegant London dinner party, the narrator of ''Tamar,'' a short story in Mark Helprin's ''Ellis Island, and Other Stories,'' is seated at the ''children's table,'' as a kind of genteel punishment. (The time is close to the start of World War II; the narrator is in London on a mission that fails - raising escape funds for European Jewry through an art exchange.) The teen-agers in attendance are new to him and charming - lively, intelligent, dream-ridden. Amused by their chatter, instantly infatuated with a bright beauty who's the eldest girl in the group, the narrator finds himself under compulsion to entertain. He launches a ''long story about Palestine,'' then races on - his imagination freed - ''because they were children, more or less'' - to wilder stuff. ''I spoke of impossible battles . . . of feats of endurance which made me reel merely in imagining them, of horses that flew, and golden shafts of light, pillars of fire, miracles here and there . . . anything which seemed as if it might be believed.''

title: SALISBURY FLEA MARKET A TRADITION
description: AGENERATION ago, the small world of antiques selling and buying was quite different from the one in which collectors travel today. Shopkeepers who sold old furniture and accessories sorted themselves out into three distinct categories. Their shop signs clearly indicated the difference in inventories: ''Antiques,'' ''Used Furniture,'' ''Second Hand Goods.'' Today, the last two signs almost qualify as collector's items for some so- called folk art enthusiasts.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective. Corrections, also on this page, continue to deal with factual errors.

title: Virginia Cowles to Wed in November
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gardner Cowles of New York and Indian Creek Island, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Cowles, to Jon Miles Kurtis, son of Donald Kurtis of Old Saybrook, Conn., and Mrs. Walter H. Manley of New York.

title: A Realignment
description: Edward H. Jennings , president of Ohio State, has asked Larry R. Thompson to take over the management of student athletic programs on a temporary basis. Jennings said the reassignment was needed because of the increased work in many areas of student services. Jennings also said that he has assigned Russell Spillman , associate provost, to be responsible ''for the academic matters associated with athletics to insure that these academic matters are properly retained within the office of academic affairs.''

title: RESHAPING ROLES IN LATER LIFE
description: THEY were the nurturers, women who cooked and cleaned and raised their children, all the while merging their identities with those of their husbands, their lives structured by the needs of others. Some held jobs, not for self-fulfillment but to survive and make life better for the family. Today they are living longer and living alone in suburbia - having outlived spouses and lost the companionship of friends who moved away or died - and they are often in greatly reduced financial circumstances.

title: FOES OF SANDINISTAS RALLY IN MANAGUA
description: In a rundown movie theater last weekend, 90 members of the Democratic Conservative Party gathered for the first opposition political convention held in Nicaragua since the Sandinista National Liberation Front swept into power four years ago.

title: THE BIG GUYS GET INTO THE ACT
description: Not every successful software company was founded by an innovative programmer who toiled night after night in the basement, using a $4,000 investment in computer equipment to write a program worth millions. It only seems that way.

title: Pitt Triumphs, 13-3; Quarterback Hurt
description: John Cummings, a junior from Montclair, N.J., who won the job as successor to Dan Marino as starting quarterback, threw a 56-yard touchdown pass to help Pitt beat Tennessee tonight in the season opener, but later suffered an apparent fracture of his left collarbone.

title: BEST SELLERS FICTION
description: 1111 THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco.

title: CUOMO SEEKS RENT AID INCREASE FOR WELFARE FAMILIES
description: Governor Cuomo, reacting to recent findings of squalid conditions in New York City hotels housing displaced people, says he will seek increases in the rent allowances provided to all welfare families.

title: BEGIN QUITS AT A PERILOUS MOMENT IN MIDDLE EAST
description: JERUSALEM FOR nearly a year, Menachem Begin has been fading away like an old soldier. Gone is the combative orator whose blistering candor infuriated Washington and thrilled much of Israel. Gone is the master politician with the perfect sense of timing to invoke decisive authority over squabbling ministers.

title: TOM BASS: POET AND COACH
description: SAN DIEGO HE was planning to be a Marine lieutenant or a professional football lineman, but an attack of polio ended those dreams while he was in college. Instead, Tom Bass became one of the renaissance men of the National Football League, a poet and a patron of the arts as well as an assistant coach who is proud of teaching the game to female fans.

title: From Girl Reporter to Feminist Leader
description: It would be a most insecure male or dogmatic misogynist who, looking back at the past 20 years of the women's movement, would not concede the sensible moderation and practical fairness of the issues raised by the first feminist leaders, especially when compared to some of today's social developments - like lesbian adoption or sperm banks for single women - which may indeed make men feel unwanted and unneeded. But, like other early speakers on women's issues, Gloria Steinem has had to endure a good deal of obloquy. Since she began as an eager and ambitious ''girl reporter,'' good-looking enough to disguise herself as a Playboy Bunny - an experience she records in the first essay in this volume - perhaps hers seemed a particularly regrettable defection from the ranks of the pretty girls who had the Stuff it took to be one of the boys.

title: 5 Foor Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited five food establishments last week for violations of the city's health code.

title: ROAD PLANS STIRS BRIDGE'S FOES
description: APROPOSAL to widen and renovate West Shore Road, a two-lane road that runs from Oyster Bay through Mill Neck and into Bayville, is reawakening fears that a bridge will be built across Long Island Sound - connecting the Island with Rye, N.Y., or Connecticut - that will adversely affect the character of these residential communities.

title: CUOMO THINKING BETTER OF TRYING TO CONTROL M.T.A.
description: One of the few points on which Mario Cuomo and Lewis E. Lehrman agreed during their gubernatorial race last year was the need to bring the semi-independent Metropolitan Transportation Authority under state control. Someone, both candidates argued, had to make the M.T.A. accountable. People who were forced to endure dirty subway cars and perpetually late commuter trains had to be given the chance to vote out those who were responsible - or so the candidates maintained. But positions articulated coolly in the midst of a fall election campaign can wilt quickly in the hot August reality of running the nation's largest mass-transit system. Last week, Governor Cuomo was presented with the first opportunity to place his stamp on the M.T.A., an agency he had often said he wished to bring under his wing since taking office eight months ago. But rather than embrace the opportunity, the Governor ultimately shied away. Many familiar with the M.T.A. continued to debate the merits of the agency's independence, but the fact of its autonomy was as firm by the end of the week as it had been at the beginning. On Monday, Richard Ravitch unexpectedly resigned as M.T.A. chairman, catching the Cuomo adminstration off guard. The Governor and his top aides spent several days scrambling to define a position. Mr. Cuomo remained wedded to his belief that the M.T.A., if it should not be abolished, should at least be restructured and brought under the direct control of the Governor.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: ROUGHNECK The Life and Times of Big Bill Haywood. By Peter Carlson. Illustrated. 352 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Co. $17.50.

title: '81 Cholera Outbreak Traced
description: An outbreak of cholera that infected 16 people in 1981 has been traced to poor plumbing on a floating oil rig in Texas. Doctors from the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta reported Wednesday in The New England Journal of Medicine that the outbreak had been caused by tainted rice served on an oil rig in a marshland south of Port Arthur, Tex. An open valve permitted the rig's drinking water to be contaminated by sewage-tainted canal water, in which the rice had been rinsed.

This centenary tribute is the first Manet show in New York in 35 years. With 95 paintings and 95 works on paper, it is by far the largest Manet exhibition ever held in this country.

description: OVER the past decade churches, individuals, unions and other institutional investors have used their rights as shareholders to put socially-related resolutions on corporate proxy statements. The ultimate disservice was done to four little girls that morning, but if we do not recognize the positive things that derived from their horrendous deaths, then they have surely died in vain.

The lawyers said the judge instructed the jury improperly and did not let the defense admit relevant evidence.

title: GET OUT OF LEBANON
description: A couple of mornings ago, I spoke with one of my cousins who left Beirut during the last civil war, in 1975, and who is, naturally, watching with unrestrained horror the slaughter that has begun anew there. ''For the American Government,'' she told me, ''Lebanon has always been a political game where they could have fun moving people and events around the board. But now that some Americans are getting hurt, they're beginning to take it seriously. Maybe, they'll do something about it now.''

title: CRIME
description: It is not that Jonathan Valin's style has completely deserted him in NATURAL CAUSES (Congdon & Weed, $13.95). There are enough pages of smart and sophisticated dialogue to demonstrate that Mr. Valin remains a superior writer. But measured against his previous four Harry Stoner books, ''Natural Causes'' seems to lack flow. There is something labored about it; sections are stretched out, and the manipulative hand of the author is too much in evidence.

title: Triathlon Takes Shape

Six hundred competitors who will participate in the three-sport event - a mile-and-a-half open water swim, a 25-mile bike race and a 10-mile run.

The Rev. William Shively performed the ceremony.

title: Iowa's Crab Wins Bay Race
description: Hawkeye, a hard-shelled crab representing the landlocked state of Iowa, skittered past 22 competitors to win the 24th Governor's Cup race today by a claw. He edged out South Dakota's Buffalo Bill on the 16-foot course, in a race witnessed by more than 10,000 spectators at this Chesapeake Bay fishing community.

title: KEEPING THE CROOKS OUT OF COMPUTERS
description: No sooner had the F.B.I. tracked a series of surreptitious entries into computer systems to a group of teenagers in Milwaukee than chief executives across the country started to get nervous.

title: MEGAMORPHOSIS
description: L. awoke one fine morning to discover he had been transformed into a human being. The shiny, hard black shell of which he had been so proud, the tough, thin legs with which he had scampered so quickly behind the stove and refrigerator and under the sink were all gone. In their place, moving feebly under the bedclothes, were vast, seemingly formless globs of soft tissue in which he could detect neither muscle nor skeleton.

title: BEHIND THE MAGICAL IMAGES OF MAX ERNST
description: Max Ernst has a public reputation as one of the most gifted, inventive and versatile of 20th-century artists. As summarized in 1968 by William S. Rubin, ''in the extraordinary variety of his styles and techniques, Max Ernst is to Dada and Surrealism what Picasso is to 20th- century art as a whole.'' One could add that in late paintings by Max Ernst there is often a seraphic lightness of touch and a lyrical sweetness that was not forecast by his earlier work.

title: IN EL SALVADOR, BATTLEFIELD IS STILL THE COMMON GROUND
description: For all the flurry, the meetings last week between the Salvadoran leftist rebels and the American and Salvadoran Governments seemed to produce little more than inconclusive skirmishing. In Bogota, for the first time in three years, Salvadoran officials faced insurgents from their own country, one of whom had recently fled to Mexico after being released from a Salvadoran jail. The following day in San Jose, Richard B. Stone, the Reagan Administration's special envoy to Central America, talked for three hours with four Salvadoran leftist leaders. The meetings made for interesting pictures, but the participants' statements afterward indicated they had found little common ground or readiness to compromise. The Salvadoran Government has authorized its Peace Commission to discuss only the left's participation in presidential elections, which are tentatively set for some time in the first three months of next year. The Salvadoran left has flatly rejected any interest in those elections. They want to be incorporated in a provisional Government that would then oversee elections for mayors as well as deputies to the 60-member Constituent Assembly. American and Salvadoran officials skeptical of the whole process believe that the negotiating activity is merely a propoganda ploy for all sides. As long as meetings are being held, the Reagan Administration and the Salvadoran Government can demonstrate to Congress that they are trying to reach a political settlement. The Salvadoran left also gets the benefit of appearing conciliatory, as well as some publicity in its own country.

title: ADULT CHILDREN FOLLOW HOMING INSTINCT
description: NOW that our three adult children have left home, I await the trauma commonly referred to as the Empty Nest Syndrome. In my case the term ''Empty Nest'' is wrongly applied. True, our children no longer reside under our roof, but the nest is far from empty!

title: GROUP FIGHTS END TO BAR CARS
description: FOR thousands of Connecticut commuters, the cafe cars on the New Haven division of the Metro-North rail line offer a modicum of relaxation on the long ride home during the evening rush hour. But like the old, more comfortable coaches of yesteryear, which now exist only on the Danbury branch, the 20 cars on the New Haven division appear destined for oblivion.

title: COAST POLICE KILLING OF HOSTAGE INVESTIGATED
description: Officials of Escondido, 35 miles north of San Diego, are investigating an Aug. 26 incident in which the police killed both a bank robbery suspect and the woman he was holding hostage.

title: REAGAN'S ANTI-HUMAN RIGHTS POLICY
description: Human rights are in trouble. So obsessed is the Reagan Administration with left-wing insurgencies in Central America that it has not hesitated to twist through redefinition the meaning of human rights in order to downgrade the most basic right of all, the right to life. Its acquiescence in patterns of torture, murder and other forms of state terrorism practiced by client governments not only violates the intent of human rights legislation, it comes close to condoning the kinds of crimes against humanity condemned at the Nuremberg war crimes trials.

title: SEOUL CALLS THE CHARGES OF SPYING 'FLAGRANT LIE'
description: The Korean Government today dismissed the assertion by the Soviet Union that the Korean airliner carrying 269 people that was downed early Thursday was engaged in a spying mission for the United States, calling it ''a flagrant lie.''

title: Athletics at Furman Cited as Discriminatory
description: Federal civil rights officials say Furman University's athletic department discriminates against women.

title: HOW EDUCATION IS CRUSHING THE LIFE OUT OF HIGH SCHOOL
description: THE other day they delivered a dozen computers to my school. Soon one will be perched in my office. If ever I achieve computer literacy, it will be something of a private quantum leap. My generation's ''high tech'' was the slide rule. Having been educated in the aftershock of Sputnik, however, does help me understand the current mad dash of educators to embrace the computer age and harness it to the classroom. But during this educational revolution, I am sitting on the other side of the desk.

title: JETS AND GIANTS START SEASON WITH NEW COACHES
description: ''We're not hiding any injuries,'' a San Diego Charger official said last week. ''How could we? The Jets have had someone tailing us from the first preseason game.''

title: FOR WALESA, SOME CHEERS AND AND UNCHEERFUL FUTURE
description: Striding toward the Gdansk shipyards last week, a big bundle of flowers in his arms and a chanting, cheering crowd at his back, Lech Walesa looked like a leader again, at least for a moment. It was the third anniversary of the Aug. 31 signing of an agreement with shipyard strikers that gave birth to Solidarity, the first and last independent trade union in the Soviet bloc. The Polish authorities saturated the streets of Gdansk, Warsaw, Nowa Huta, Wroclaw and other major cities with riot police to snuff out any dissent left after more than 18 months of military rule. Nevertheless, tens of thousands managed to demonstrate support for the outlawed Solidarity - some by battling with the police, many by going to special masses in Roman Catholic churches. In the process, they restored some of Mr. Walesa's luster. ''Lechu, Lechu,'' shouted the jubilant crowds that managed to rally around St. Bridget's Church in Gdansk, using the familiar form of his name. Crowds in other cities also chanted the name of the man authorities had scorned as ''the former head of the former union.'' It has been a difficult time for Mr. Walesa and the movement he symbolizes. The Government, even as it announced the lifting of martial law in July, kept sweeping powers to control the streets and factories; it has shown little reluctance to use them. The beleaguered underground has yet to come up with effective tactics. Mr. Walesa has seemed vacillating and uncertain, even worrying in public about going to jail.

title: PLANE TRAGEDY POSES TOUGH EAST-WEST ISSUES
description: Ever so rarely, something happens that cuts through the ambiguities of politics and proves a point. Last week, a Soviet fighter plane shot down a South Korean passenger airliner that had strayed over Soviet territory, killing 269 people. The point, if it needed reaffirmation, was that the leadership of the Soviet Union is different - call it tougher, more brutal or even uncivilized - than most of the rest of the world. President Reagan said the incident was ''horrifying'' and cause for ''revulsion,'' whatever the exact or possibly extenuating circumstances. The Soviet invasion of Afghanistan and its intimidation of Poland may be explained away, at least in part, as power politics. But not this and not acts such as trumping up charges against dissidents, not inhuman and elemental acts, to judge by the reaction from Congress and elsewhere. Nevertheless, the Reagan Administration was still left with the question of how to respond in other than feeble, symbolic or self-defeating ways, and what to do, more generally, about Soviet-American relations. In the short run, the incident lends great weight to Mr. Reagan's portrayal of the Soviet Union as an ''evil empire.'' It strengthens him politically on the Pentagon budget and Central America and diplomatically in marshaling support in Europe for deploying new missiles. But in the long run, the harder Mr. Reagan comes down on Moscow now, the more difficult it will be to improve relations later. By Presidential election time, he may need to show progress in reducing Soviet-American tensions and producing an arms control treaty.

title: MONDALE'S SOUTHERN EXPOSURE, AND GLENN'S PRIMARY CONCERN WALTER F. Mondale's campaign advisers appear to have concluded that among many voters, and especially those in the South, Jimmy Carter's time in the White House may be remembered as not all that bad after all.
description: So last week the former Vice President, who in his pursuit of the Democratic Party's nomination almost never mentions his Carter connection, made his way to a hard-to- get-to log cabin on a mountain top in northern Georgia for an audience with his old boss. For his troubles, Mr. Mondale, who was shown in a recent poll to be trailing Senator John Glenn of Ohio in the region, was endorsed by Mr. Carter as a fiscal conservative and a steadfast believer in a strong military - in short a man many card-carrying Southerners should feel comfortable with.

But according to the Town of Brookhaven's environmental director, Thomas Cramer, the area ''sounds more like a freeway'' when water skiers arrive with powerboats to take advantage of the glassy-smooth water that rises to a depth of 6 to 10 feet at high tide.

title: A NEW SPEAKER IS NOTABLE FOR UNIFORMITY OF SOUND

It has already fulfilled the smoldering desire of audio fans for a noise-free recording medium in the form of the Compact Disk, and lately the laser has been cracking some tough nuts for the benefit of loudspeaker designers.

title: OUTDOORSNelson Bryant Salmon in Canada A Bitter Harvest
description: CANADA and its Maritime Provinces continue to agonize over how to apportion fairly the country's harvest of Atlantic salmon among sport and commercial fishermen and a subsistence fishery by native Indians, while maintaining viable populations of one of the world's most highly prized food and game fishes.

title: MUSIC LIGHTENS THE RIGORS OF LIFE IN MOSCOW
description: Harlow Robinson, who writes frequently about Russia and is currently at work on a biography of Sergei Prokofiev, has visited Moscow frequently for purposes of study and research. Shortages - of butter, shoes, even tires - are a fact of daily life in Moscow. One item, however, is never in short supply: music. On any given evening during ''the season,'' which begins in earnest in late September and runs through May, one can choose from a dizzying assortment of symphonic concerts, chamber music, recitals and opera, ranging from Bach to Glinka, from Tchaikovsky to Shostakovich and beyond. Few cities - including New York or Vienna - boast a richer or more varied musical life.

The first race there was on Labor Day 1951. Police estimated that 100,000 fans jammed into the track for the first Southern 500.

title: THE BITTER LIFE OF CHAD
description: It is a time of uncertainty, overlaid this year, as so often in Chad's cruel and contorted history, with conflict and intimations of disaster. The gaunt men who squat at night before flat- roofed houses of baked clay seem to sense it, whispering fears and secrets to one another, the whiteness of their turbans, skull caps and djellabas framing ebony faces caught somewhere between the North African desert and the savannah of the south. The wind blows from the swollen, mud-brown Shari River, ruffling trees but offering no real relief.

title: INQUEST IN THE ANDES
description: Mario Vargas Llosa criticizes the ''incomprehensible abstraction'' that socialism, communism and other ideologies represent for the Indians, and yet he brandishes the term ''democracy'' as if that particular abstraction were to be readily understood and embraced by everyone. He is honest in acknowledging, even indirectly, that as a writer and envoy of ''Mr. Government,'' he is part of the privileged ''sector of society'' that he criticizes; but he does little to bridge the gap between the cultural richness and the material poverty of the Indians and those, such as himself and his reader, privileged enough to observe, write and read about it.

title: TENNANTS NOTICE A CATCH IN NEW YORK'S RENT CONTROL REFORM
description: New York City's system of rent regulation, under which landlords finance the quasigovernmental agency that is supposed to prevent them from overcharging tenants, has often been described as a henhouse guarded by foxes. A new system takes effect next April, with New York State taking over the watchdog role. Tenant advocates say that as a result, however, a lot of illicit chicken dinners over the last few years will be legitimized.

title: Ivis L. Villar Married To Thomas C. Carey

Carey of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Roland Villar, the bride's brother and a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Union Church in Waban, Mass.

title: THE BIRMINGHAM BOMBINGS --
description: I am bitten with curiosity about the women - ''the small network of women with Klan ties who passed information to the authorities.'' Why? What did they need that they were willing to risk so much? Were their lives such a hell because their men were monsters? Or did they have a courage and moral conviction that I, for one, would surely like to hear more about. PAM MOTTLEY Peconic, L.I.

title: HEADLINERS Revolutionary CoupForeign Office Document No. 93/8/2 looked innocuous enough among the 80 miles of shelves in the Public Record Office in London, alongside wills signed by the likes of William Shakespeare, the Domesday Book property survey made under William the Conqueror and other historic texts. The thin leather-bound volume is, in fact, the Treaty of Paris by which King George III recognized the United States ''to be free Sovereign & independent.'' Last week, it came to New York to mark the bicentennial of its signing. ''The British had every reason to say no. The treaty? No. New York? No. On a plane? No.'' said
description: Joseph Veach Noble , director of the Museum of the City of New York, where the 13-page document will be displayed. Mr. Noble said the museum ''did not dare hope'' for its release; no treaty had left Britain before. But the Foundation for the Preservation of the Archeological Heritage, a nonprofit organization, lobbied British ministries and officials for a year - and won.

title: TREASURE HUNTS IN NORMANDY
description: -based writer.

title: THE REAL JOB BOOM IS LIKELY TO BE LOW TECH
description: Kevin Thomson, who just turned 19, got his first job working behind the counter at the new Roy Rogers restaurant in Times Square. That was in June. He expected it to be a summer job that would continue on a part-time basis when he returned for his sophomore year at City College. Instead of going back to college this month, however, Mr. Thomson has decided to enter a 10-week training program to become a manager in the Roy Rogers chain. The fast-food business, he says, has more appeal than college. More young people may be following a similar route during the 1980's. Despite the attention lavished on employment opportunities in high technology and computers, most jobs available this decade will be decidedly low-tech. Reports from the Federal Government's Bureau of Labor Statistics show the greatest demand - in descending order - will be for secretaries, nurses' aides and orderlies, janitors, sales clerks, cashiers, nurses, truck drivers, fast-food workers, office clerks, waiters and waitresses. Jobs for programmers, systems analysts, operaters, data entry workers and other computer specialists will account for only 5 percent of the employment growth during the 1980's, bureau statistics show. Meanwhile, 75 percent of all young people today graduate from high school; about 33 percent spend some time in college. For high school and college students, the push for computer literacy is on. But as Herbert Bienstock, director of the Center for Labor and Urban Programs, Research and Analysis at Queens College, noted: ''Most jobs in this country require very little in the way of skill development or training.''

title: PROGRAM AIDING 'FAMILIES IN TRANSITION'
description: DIVORCE. It used to be an ugly word. Something, like an accident or an illness that always happened to someone else, it has now become the norm. Counselors believe that one out of every two marriages in the United States today is destined to break apart. And in the county alone last year divorces were occurring at an yearly rate of 2,600. Experts say that children are the hardest hit, experiencing guilt, fear, anger and even grief over the loss of what their family has meant - over the loss of hope.

title: Injured Fighter Critical'
description: Francisco (Kiko) Bejines was comatose today after emergency surgery to remove a section of the frontal lobe of his brain after he was hurt in a bout with Alberto Davila.

description: A nationwide drive for seat belts in school buses, once part of the overall push for improved transportation safety, is taking a back seat to school districts' overriding economic problems.

title: 4 OF 6 ARE GUILTY IN U.S. BRINK'S CASE
description: Two defendants were convicted in Manhattan yesterday of a Federal conspiracy charge involving the Brink's robbery, several other armored-car robberies, four murders and a prison escape. The jury convicted two other defendants of accessory charges, but acquitted them of the more serious charges. It completely acquitted two additional defendants, who were freed. At 5:10 P.M., as tension heightened in the hushed courtroom, the jury began announcing the verdict, count by count, after three days of deliberations in the five-month-old trial in Federal District Court.

title: WAR PARTIES PADDLE IT OUT
description: DESPITE its bellicose name and the Penobscot Indian paddling on the bow of the boat called the State of Maine, the National War Canoe championships held in Cold Spring last Sunday went off more with a spirit of effervescence than with the ferocity that would have reflected the sport's historical roots. But one war party, the ''unbeatable'' canoe men from Maine, went down to unexpected defeat at the hands of an all-star crew from the canoe clubs of the Atlantic division of the American Canoe Association.

title: MEDICARE: THE NEXT CRISIS OVER 'ENTITLEMENTS'
description: THE politics of the Social Security rescue plan just behind them, Congress and the White House are bracing themselves for Part 2 of the entitlements drama. It involves Medicare, the Federally subsidized health insurance system, created in 1965, that now serves 26 million elderly and three million disabled Americans. Even under an optimistic scenario, the system's trustees report, ''either disbursements will have to be reduced by 30 percent or financing will have to be increased by 43 percent'' to prevent exhaustion of the Hospital Insurance Trust Fund by 1996. The pessimistic scenario brings bankruptcy in 1988; the intermediate scenario, in 1990 (see charts at right).

title: N.J. TRANSIT TIPS
description: Remember ''Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House,'' the film comedy whose final laugh on the hero is his too-late discovery that the only commuter train that will get him to his New York job on time leaves before dawn? Shows how important it is to ask about commuting schedules before buying a house - and yet few real-estate brokers keep such information on file for quick reference by clients. Now, however, some do, and more will, thanks to N.J. Transit.

title: REAGAN SEES NEED FOR WORLD ACTION IN PLANE INCIDENT
description: President Reagan said today that the Soviet Union's downing of a South Korean airliner was an international issue that required world leaders to deal with the Russians ''in a calm, controlled but absolutely firm manner.''

description: Iran has vowed revenge for what it called repeated Iraqi air attacks on the northwest border town of Marivan, saying at least 45 people have been killed and 200 wounded, the national Iranian press agency said.

title: Inquest in the Andes
description: In his article ''Inquest in the Andes'' (July 31), Mario Vargas Llosa goes beyond the reporting and analysis of a single event. With the eye and ear of an artist, he unites understood subtleties, discriminantly rendered detail and his own emotional response to the massacre with a portrayal of the larger, temporal environment in which this conflict occurred.

title: THE WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: At last, the economy may be cooling off, giving some comfort to those who feared a reheating of inflation, if feverish second-quarter growth rates continued. The Government's index of leading economic indicators - a reading of the economy's future course - rose a modest three-tenths of one percent in July. The rise, following hefty advances in earlier months, was the smallest in nearly a year. There were other signs, too, in July that expansion had slowed: New factory orders fell 1.7 percent; new- home sales dipped 6.5 percent, and civilian unemployment flattened at 9.5 percent. But, according to preliminary reports from the nation's largest retailers, consumer spending perked up in August - a cue that the cooling-off period may be short-lived. Sales at Sears, K Mart and Dayton Hudson, among others, jumped as much as 20 percent over year-earlier levels.

title: NIGHTS AT THE OPERA
description: THE METROPOLITAN OPERA'S CENTENNIAL this fall is a double celebration. First,of course, it is a time to commemorate 100 years of musical pageantry. But second, it offers an opportunity to recall a sartorial - and social - cavalcade, unlike any other witnessed in this country. Only in the last few decades has this glittering spectacle of high fashion and high society dimmed.

description: WHEN he was considering writing a book on pregnancy, Dr. Howard Shapiro, a Westport gynecologist and obstetrician, concluded that the last thing women needed was one more book covering the same aspects of pregnancy that had been written about dozens of times.

title: THE STRANGLING OF A RESORT
description: HERE ARE FEW RESORTS IN the world like the Hamptons. Less than 100 miles from midtown Manhattan, this 50-mile stretch of villages and hamlets along Long Island's southeastern coastline contains not only wide, sweeping beaches but also miles of farmland, dense pine forests, woods of scrubby oak, meadows, dunes, marshes, ponds, bays and inlets. Not even Martha's Vineyard or the coast of Maine matches that rich array of landscapes. Though the crowds that swarm the beaches in midsummer may not see it, the Hamptons are the country as much as the seashore.

title: Jail Term for Absent Juror
description: Phyllis Chambers of St. Albans, who said she missed two court cases because her watch stopped, spent her second day in jail today and must pay a $200 fine for failing to appear for jury duty. The sentence was imposed by Justice Donald Alexander of Somerset County Superior Court, who said it was needed as a warning to others who shirk jury duty.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
 ART AUCTION
description: Although traditionally they are unsung (and frequently underpaid), when they ''arrive'' professionally, artists generally are generous with their time and talents. Give them a cause they can sink their altruism into, and they respond. On the East End, the Animal Rescue Fund of the Hamptons is just such a cause, and everyone who is anyone in the fabled local art world has donated at least one work to be auctioned off today to help ARF care for the community's homeless dogs and cats.

title: WEIGHING THE FACTS IN WESTMORELAND VS. CBS
description: The libel suit brought by Gen. William C. Westmoreland against CBS, seldom quiescent since its inception last September, recently grew heated again. Lawyers for CBS said they had discovered the ''smoking gun'' that would destroy the general's case, and although this was debatable, it did in its way return the argument to what it was supposed to be all about in the first place. The general said that ''The Uncounted Enemy: A Vietnam Deception,'' broadcast Jan. 23, 1982, had libeled him when it said he had deliberately suppressed information about the strength of the Vietcong. CBS had answered by saying it would prove the charge was true. At issue was a question of journalism: What are facts, and what do facts mean? It is a more complicated question than it seems.

title: No Headline
description: Labor's Day, Labor's Challenge American unions are in trouble this Labor Day, suffering membership losses, contract setbacks, political reverses. Much of the public sees them as selfish but ineffective survivors of another era. But most of labor's problems are also the nation's, caused by a historic shift of the American economy out of the old smokestack industries that provided the core of organized union strength.

title: SECRETIVE BRENNINKMEYERS
description: In an unassuming building in Amsterdam's trim Weesper Straat, 50 or so executives meet four times a year to discuss the affairs of what is, by most standards, one of the world's most secretive business operations.

title: ; PECULIAR U.S. WAY OF 'ADHERING TO WORLD LAW'
description: To the Editor:

title: AS JESUITS' LEADER DEPARTS, AN ERA OF CHANGE ENDS
description: The superior general of the Jesuits, the Very Rev. Pedro de Arrupe y Gondra, said goodbye today to the society that he has led for more than 18 years, a period in which many Jesuits espoused liberal views on social and religious matters.

title: ABSOLUTION FOR BRUNNER
description: WHEN the Giants win, rock music blares from their locker-room stereo. But after yesterday's dreary 16-6 loss to the Los Angeles Rams in their National Football League opener, the stereo was as silent as the atmosphere. Instead of celebrating with music, the Giants had to face the music of Bill Parcells's annoyance.

title: Lisa Kaufman, an Actress, Wed to Edward D. Griffith
description: Lisa Deborah Kaufman, daughter of Col. Paul I. Kaufman, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Kaufman of Houston, was married in Manhattan yesterday to Edward Dunbar Griffith, son of Maj. Gen. Stebbins W. Griffith, U.S.A.F., retired, of Colorado Springs and Edna Griffith of Falmouth, Mass.

title: AMBASSADOR OF LUCK WINS
description: Mickey Preger has a sweet problem on his hands. He trains Ambassador of Luck, a 4-year-old filly who can both outrun top sprinters and stretch her speed to beat top distance fillies. As the championship races of the fall approach, he's not sure which Eclipse Award to shoot for - champion sprinter or champion older filly.

title: BRONCOS EDGE STEELERS, 14-10
description: When Ron Egloff caught the fourth-quarter touchdown pass that gave the Denver Broncos a victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers today, John Elway, Denver's rookie quarterback, leaped high into the air with his arms over his head.

title: BEJINES IS DEAD OF INJURIES IN RING
description: Francisco (Kiko) Bejines , who never regained consciousness after being knocked out by Alberto Davila in a championship boxing match Thursday night, died today, officials at Los Angeles County-University of Southern California Medical Center announced.

title: BRIEFING
description: An Unofficial Message

title: LABOR AND RECREATION MIX AT A FAIR ON 42D ST.
description: Traditionally, the Labor Day weekend is the last chance at the beach before the lifeguards pull in their benches. But not everyone was on the sand yesterday. Some, like Heleena van Raan of Manhattan, chose the city asphalt and the annual Labor Day Street Fair.

title: ; PECULIAR U.S. WAY OF 'ADHERING TO WORLD LAW'
description: To the Editor:

title: OSHA, INDUSTRY'S NEW FRIEND
description: On New Year's Eve, 1981, Leon Kruchten, an electrician who works for Oscar Mayer and Company in Madison, Wis., arrived at work just as a power failure disabled two-thirds of the plant. Management was anxious to repair the problem fast and finish the remaining production run before the holiday. Mr. Kruchten grabbed his tools and met his co-workers in the damaged power station. Suddenly, there was a flash of light. The next thing he remembered he was in an ambulance. His body was severely burned, and he lost an arm.

title: DIVORCE AND CLOSE KINSHIP
description: EVER since Martha Goodnough's

title: A CONVENIENT AIRPORT GETS MORE SO
description: The American Airlines jetliner from Chicago, descending along the Potomac River from the south, skimmed by the brightly illuminated Capitol, the Washington Monument and the Lincoln Memorial and, its nose pointed directly at the Pentagon, touched down at Washington National Airport at 11 P.M. on Thursday.

title: PITT'S QUARTERBACK INJURED IN VICTORY
description: The University of Pittsburgh had no chance to enjoy the fact that it found a quarterback to succeed Dan Marino.

title: BATTLE OF RETAILERS IN DALLAS
description: Five miles from the mirrored-glass glitter of downtown Dallas, four lavish shopping malls are drawing the country's major luxury retailers to battle for a share of this city's $21 billion annual retail market.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, SEPT. 5, 1983
description: International Latin American debtor nations begin a meeting today to discuss their financial burdens, and people in the banking community see an improvement in the world debt crisis. They note lower interest rates, the imposition of harsh economic measures on debtor countries and rapid action by lending institutions. But risks remain, and economists are anxious about the next 12 months. (Page 31.)

title: 12 Are Reported Killed In Protests in Pakistan
description: Anti-Government protests in Pakistan stretched into their fourth week today and a clash in Sind Province reportedly left 12 people killed.

title: ASIA TRADE RISE SEEN AFFECTING U.S.
description: A milestone was crossed last year when, for the first time, the United States conducted more trade across the Pacific than the Atlantic.

title: LOSSES BIG
description: Kansas banking authorities said yesterday that they shut the Douglass State Bank of Kansas City, the nation's 17th-largest black-owned bank, after Federal examiners uncovered multimillion-dollar loan losses that rendered the bank insolvent.

title: John D. Neely Weds Leslie Ann Corydon
description: Leslie Ann Corydon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Corydon of Convent Station, N.J., was married yesterday to John D. Neely, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne A. Neely of Cincinnati. The Rev. James S. Weaver performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church in Pluckemin, N.J.

title: PADRES' 6 IN 5TH BEAT METS, 7-5
description: Terry Kennedy not only knows how to hurt people, he knows how to thank them.

title: '82 Drop in Crime Victims Was Largest in a Decade
description: The number of people victimized by crime in the United States dropped 4.1 percent in 1982, the largest one-year decline since the Government began its National Crime Survey 10 years ago, the Justice Department said today.

title: GUIDRY WINS AS YANKS SWEEP MARINERS
description: The Yankees completed a three-game sweep of the Seattle Mariners today with a 4-3 victory and now begin the part of the season they have eagerly awaited, when all their competition comes from the Eastern Division.

title: TASS REPORT ON A SOVIET GENERAL'S COMMENTS ABOUT AIRLINER
description: Following is the text of the Tass press agency report today on Col. Gen. Semyon F. Romanov's comments about the encounter between a Soviet jet fighter and the downed South Korean airliner:

title: TV: 'STOPWATCH,' SPOOF OF '60 MINUTES' ON HBO
description: Concocting a parody of ''60 Minutes'' can't be easy. Some students of television argue that the phenomenonally successful CBS News show has gradually developed into a parody of itself over the years. The weekly roles of Mike Wallace, Morley Safer and Ed Bradley have become as predictable and calculated as anything involving Magnum, P.I., or Archie Bunker. But Home Box Office, the pay-cable organization, has bitten the parody bullet and is venturing forth with ''Stopwatch: 30 Minutes of Investigative Ticking.'' Its broadcast dates include tonight at 11 o'clock.

title: Citizens Party Decides To Seek Presidency
description: The national convention of the Citizens Party voted overwhelmingly today to run a Presidential candidate in next year's election, but left the choosing of the nominee until next spring.

title: Shira Dicker, a Writer, Married to Ari L. Goldman
description: Shira Roni Dicker, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Henry I. Dicker of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Ari Lionel Goldman, son of Marvin Goldman of Hartford and Mrs. Jacob E. Goldman of Westport, Conn. The bride's father, who is a rabbi and pyschologist, performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's mother and stepfather.

title: NO HARD FEELINGS, SAYS RAMS' JETER
description: When Gary Jeter arrived at Giants Stadium today, he walked down the players' entrance ramp and turned to the left toward the Giants' locker room. Then he checked himself and laughed.

title: Manville Hearing Set
description: A Federal Bankruptcy Court judge in New York has scheduled a Sept. 13 hearing on the Manville Corporation's proposed sale of Johns-Manville Canada Inc. for $117 million, the corporation has announced. The Denver-based asbestos and building supply manufacturer said on Friday that the bankruptcy judge first must approve the sale of the company, which owns the Jeffrey asbestos mine in Asbestos, Quebec.

title: East German Says Bonn Ties Are Now on 'Upward Trend'
description: The East German head of state, Erich Honecker, said today that relations betwen East and West Germany were looking brighter.

title: PACKERS TRIUMPH IN OVERTIME, 41-38
description: Green Bay's Jan Stenerud kicked a 42-yard field goal with 9 minutes 5 seconds remaining in overtime to cap a five- touchdown performance by the quarterback Lynn Dickey as the Packers scored a 41-38 victory today over the Houston Oilers.

title: PARTHENON RESTORATION WON'T NEED SCAFFOLDING
description: The Parthenon, one of the glories of ancient Greece, has lost some of its glory over 2 1/2 millenniums, and Melina Mercouri, the Greek Culture Minister, announced today that a way had been found to restore the temple without marring its famous silhouette with scaffolding.

title: U.S. SAYS INTELLIGENCE PLANE WAS ON A ROUTINE MISSION
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that an American reconnaissance plane operating off the Siberian coast the night a South Korean airliner was downed was on a routine mission and was unaware that the Korean plane had entered Soviet airspace or was in trouble.

title: BATTLE LINES FORM OVER BID FOR POCONOS GAMBLING
description: These were idyllic late-summer days, these last few, with a bright sun glistening off the dark lake and white golf carts at Skytop Lodge and burnishing the couples stretched beside a pool at the plush Caesars Paradise Stream resort. And everywhere, here in the four- county vacation area of the Pocono Mountains of northeastern Pennsylvania, the smiles of vacationers seemed as bright as the sun.

title: SUSPECT ARRESTED IN SLAYING OF LAWYER VISITING 'VILLAGE'
description: A Brooklyn man has been arrested and accused of driving the getaway car in the slaying Saturday afternoon of a lawyer from Philadelphia on a busy residential street in Greenwich Village.

title: No Headline
description: Lowering the New York Voltage Even if Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch weren't long-time rivals, even if they were brothers married to loving sisters, their political offices would draw them apart. Some days, the Mayor would complain that with nearly half the state's population, his city was getting short rations from Albany. Other days, the Governor would feel his Democratic brother was just unreasonably greedy.

title: Saul S. Streit Is Dead at 86; Ex-Judge and Assemblyman
description: Saul S. Streit, a former New York State Assemblyman and a former administrative judge in State Supreme Court, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86 years old.

title: Hundreds Send Money To Aid 'Migrant Mother'
description: An appeal for help for the woman who symbolized Depression poverty in a photograph entitled ''Migrant Mother'' has raised more than $15,000.

title: ISRAELI STATEMENT ON PULLBACK
description: Following is the text of the Israeli Army announcement today that it had started its pullback to southern Lebanon, as distributed by the Government press office:

title: ROCK: LOVERBOY AT THE BYRNE ARENA
description: If a computer were instructed to concoct an aural hybrid of the 10 most popular rock bands in the country, the result would probably sound a lot like Loverboy, the Vancouver-based quintet that performed at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena on Friday. The group, which has enjoyed three best- selling albums, has polished a teen- age-oriented hard-rock style that skillfully uses every cliche in the arena rock arsenal.

title: Marcy Kramer Is Wed
description: Marcy Ellen Kramer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Kramer of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to David Scott Tannenbaum, son of Elmer Tannenbaum and the late Edna Tannenbaum, also of Brooklyn. Rabbi David Halpern performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn, L.I. The bride is a department supervisor with Blue Cross- Blue Shield in New York. Her husband is a lawyer.

title: MANUFACTURING IN U.S. CALLED SOUND BY A STUDY
description: Is America's industrial base deteriorating?

title: No Headline
description: Australia II's Record 3-1

title: Helene Pavlov Wed to Harvey Zeichner, Lawyer
description: Dr. Helene Pavlov, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sylvia Pavlov of Philadelphia, was married in Manhattan yesterday to Harvey Zeichner, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Zeichner of Howard Beach, Queens. Rabbi Harlan J. Wechsler performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: SEOUL LIKELY TO SLOW STEPS TOWARD SOVIET TIES
description: In the wake of the destruction of a Korean airliner carrying 269 people last week, South Korea will pull back from recent efforts to open diplomatic channels to the Soviet Union and other Communist countries, Government officials and foreign diplomats said today.

title: ARAB PREOCCUPATION
description: To the Editor:

title: OFFICIAL PUSHERS OF POISONED HEROIN?
description: To the Editor:

title: MEDICAL PRICE RATIONALE
description: To the Editor:

title: SIGEL RETAINS GOLF TITLE
description: Jay Sigel successfully defended his United States Amateur golf title today when he scored an 8-and-7 victory over Chris Perry.

title: U.S. REQUEST REBUFFED ON ISRAELI WITHDRAWAL
description: The United States pleaded with Israel on Saturday not to go ahead with its planned withdrawal from the hills around Beirut but was rebuffed by Israeli officials, the White House said today.

title: Ilene Platz Becomes Bride Of Jonathan Cranin on L.I.
description: Ilene Platz, daughter of Gloria Geller of Canarsie, Brooklyn, and Simon Platz of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Jonathan B. Cranin, son of Dr. and Mrs. A. Norman Cranin of Hewlett Bay Park, L.I. Rabbi Martin Siegel performed the ceremony at the Cranin home.

title: CHAD REBEL SAYS HE'LL ATTACK IF THE FRENCH GET IN THE WAY
description: Goukouni Oueddei, the Chadian rebel leader, warned in an interview in northern Chad over the weekend that his forces would attack French troops in Chad if they got in his way.

title: VOTERS TO DECIDE BATTLE OVER UPSTATE CAMP
description: Amid miles of rolling woods and clear lakes in the Adirondacks, a few weed-strewn, decaying sheds and barns have become the center of a battle by preservationists that will be decided at the ballot box in November.

title: 2 MEN SLAIN AND 2 OFFICERS SHOT IN NEWARK RESTAURANT SHOOTINGS
description: Two men were killed yesterday and four people, including two Newark police officers, were wounded when gunfire erupted during an argument at a Newark restaurant, a spokesman for the police said. The injured were all reported in satisfactory condition.

title: DICK HYMAN, THE MAN WHO PUT THE DOO-WACKA-DOO IN 'ZELIG'
description: Woody Allen's counterfeit documentary ''Zelig'' tricks the eye with images that jitter and flicker like 1920's film footage. No less spectacular is the way it tricks the ear, with such unlikely material as Fanny Brice singing a song to Leonard Zelig, Josephine Baker stepping to a Zelig- inspired dance tune, a sweeping 1930's love theme from a nonexistent Hollywood biography of Zelig and straight-faced themes for doctored newsreels.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Bricktop Happy at 89

title: IN JERSEY, WILD OVER BLUE YONDER
description: Billy Smela has the inside dope on flying.

title: Virginia J. Lopez Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Virginia Jane Lopez, daughter of Martha Lopez and Delio Lopez, both of Clearwater, Fla., to Roger Morton Low took place yesterday in Poughquag, N.Y. Justice Stanley Parness of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Low of New York and Poughquag.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: AGREEMENT The Labor Day holiday recalls strife, negotiation and agreement, a time-honored order of events, not only in the field of labor but in many other overlappings of human affairs. International affairs are not much different, as New Yorkers who visit the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street (534- 1672), may observe in the treaty that ended the American Revolution and capped the negotiations between Britain and the new union, the United States of America, just 200 years ago this month.

title: Fire Ravages Coast Church
description: A fire from an electrical short today caused more than $5 million in damage to a historic downtown Catholic church, fire officials said. The blaze destroyed the roof of the five-story St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, heavily damaged the sanctuary, destroyed valuable paintings and statues and charred much of the ornate woodwork, imported from Germany in 1901. No one was in the church at the time.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It should be clear to the Syrians we don't want their forces entering the area we leave.'' - Defense Minister Moshe Arens of Israel. (1:2.)

title: IMMIGRANT BILL ALIEN TO REALITY
description: The Simpson-Mazzoli Immigration Reform and Control Act, which appears headed for passage this fall, contains a number of major reforms. Among them is an amnesty that would legalize perhaps two million to four million illegal aliens. There are also civil fines that would deter employers from hiring undocumented workers in the future. Not only is it highly questionable whether Simpson-Mazzoli could control illegal immigration but also several new features under consideration by Congress could weaken effective enforcement even further.

title: FISHING SEASON RENEWS HUNT FOR CLUES TO ALASKA MURDERS
description: After a year of chasing fruitless leads, a team of state investigators has returned to a remote fishing village in southeast Alaska to seek new clues to the identity of the murderer of seven people aboard a fishing vessel last Labor Day.

title: Hit-and-Run Auto Kills Biking Youth
description: A hit-and-run driver struck two youths who were on bicycles, killing one youth, the police said today.

title: LEADER OF POLAND'S CHURCH ASSAILS GOVERNMENT ETHICS
description: Jozef Cardinal Glemp sharply criticized the Polish authorities today as ''ethically incorrect'' in their treatment of Solidarity supporters.

title: R. B. Golum Marries Pamela Joan Ruben
description: Pamela Joan Ruben, daughter of Mr.and Mrs. Robert J. Ruben of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Bruce Golum, son of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Golum of Long Beach, Calif., by Rabbi Robert A. Rothman at the Community Synagogue of Rye.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on page 1 on Aug. 21 about a New York State law easing the restrictions on information about adoption incorrectly reported the date it was signed.

title: Dr. Steven L. Roberts Weds Hazel Dunnigan
description: Hazel Marie Dunnigan and Dr. Steven Lee Roberts were married yesterday at their new home in Huntington, L.I., by Rabbi Robert A. Raab.

title: Zimbabwe Finds Two Bodies, Believed Those of Hostages
description: Government security forces believe they have found the bodies of two white farmers kidnapped by insurgents in Matabeleland province in the past year, the national press agency reported today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: An Added Fillip For Visiting Fire Official

title: A RETREAT BY ISRAEL
description: News Analysis

title: No Headline
description: Traffic Signal UpkeepFaulted in City Report

title: Bucks and Lanier Reach Agreement
description: Coach Don Nelson of the Milwaukee Bucks says Bob Lanier's knees are ''obviously a question mark,'' but Nelson decided to take the gamble and sign the 13-year National Basketball Association veteran.

title: SHAMIR SAYS HE'LL OFFER ROLE TO LABOR PARTY
description: Yitzhak Shamir, the Likud bloc's nominee for Prime Minister, said Saturday that he would try to bring the opposition Labor Party into a government of national unity.

title: Colts Top Patriots On Fumble Play
description: Johnie Cooks, a linebacker, ran 52 yards for a touchdown with a fumble recovery on the third play of overtime today to give Baltimore a 29-23 victory over the New England Patriots, the Colts' first victory since 1981.

title: MILITIAS IN BEIRUT BATTLE FOR LAND VACATED BY ISRAEL
description: Heavy fighting erupted in the mountains overlooking the Lebanese capital today as Christian and Druse militias scrambled for positions evacuated hours earlier by Israeli troops pulling back from the Beirut area.

title: NOAH REFLECTS AFTER VICTORY
description: He was speaking softly now. Relaxed, showered and well-fed just an hour after winning a 2-hour-31-minute thriller in 4 sets at the United States Open championships, Yannick Noah of France was reflecting upon his match, his life, his sore knee and the pressures of being a black hero in a predominantly-white country.

title: U.S. SAYS SPY PLANE WAS IN THE AREA OF KOREAN AIRLINER
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials said today that, two hours before shooting down a South Korean airliner off its coast, the Soviet Union spotted a United States reconnaissance plane in the general area and apparently thought that both aircraft were American reconnaissance planes.

title: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 5, 1983 International
description: Two hours before the shooting down of the South Korean airliner in Soviet airspace, the Soviet Union had spotted a United States reconnaissance plane in the general area of the Korean plane's flight, the Reagan Administration said. The Administration said that the Russians apparently thought initially that both planes were American reconnaissance planes. But White House and State Department officials insisted that despite initial confusion among the Russians, the South Korean plane and the reconnaissance plane, an RC-135, were 1,000 miles apart and the Soviet military had ample time to discern that the plane they tracked was a commercial airliner. (Page 1, Col. 6.) A Soviet pilot might have mistaken the downed South Korean airliner for an RC-135 reconnaissance plane of the kind used by United States off the coast of the Soviet Far East, a Soviet general said. (1:4.)

title: CLOSING THE DEAL
description: SAN DIEGO

title: A Knick to Remember
description: While Dave DeBusschere was playing for the Detroit Pistons, he first heard of a Princeton basketball player, a sophomore whom they said was destined to become the Secretary of State. After DeBusschere was traded to the Knicks in December 1968 and became Bill Bradley's teammate and roommate, the projection was altered. Knick players, and opposing National Basketball Association players, began calling Bradley ''Mr. President.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Delphic Fortune Cookie

title: STUDY SAYS WORK ETHIC IS ALIVE BUT NEGLECTED
description: Most American workers want to do high-quality work, but their desire to do this is seriously undermined by management practices, according to a three-year study.

title: PORTRAITS IN CHOCOLATE
description: Most people will never see themselves in museums or on Mount Rushmore, but that's no reason to give up hope. If being cast in bronze or stone is out of the question, there's always chocolate.

title: NEW YORK WOOING TEXAS MART BUILDER
description: When Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch tried to resolve an impasse two weeks ago over the $1.5 billion plan to rebuild Times Square, their discussion turned to a man neither had met: Trammell Crow.

title: WITH FLOWERS AND CRIES OF GRIEF, JAPANESE HONOR THOSE WHO DIED
description: It was a day for chrysanthemums upon the waters.

title: RANK HOPES FOR GAINS UNDER NEW CHAIRMAN
description: Sir Patrick Meaney will be the next chairman of the Rank Organisation. His appointment, confirmed at a board meeting last week, ends eight months of pressure by the company's institutional stockholders to find someone to help Rank out of its doldrums.

title: Playwright Wins Yale Scholarship
description: David Ives has been named the recipient of the first Audrey Wood Scholarship at the Yale School of Drama. Mr. Ives, a 33-year-old native of Chicago, is a member of the class of 1984. His play ''Canvas'' was produced in New York at the Circle Repertory Company.

title: LABOR OFFICIALS LOOK AHEAD AND BACK
description: Today is Labor Day, a chance for reflection as much as celebration. David W. Dunlap of The New York Times asked five union officials in their 30's what brought them to the labor movement and what they hoped to bring to it, what - if anything - made modern union work different from that of the past.

title: Washington WatchRobert D. Hershey Jr. G.M. and Ford Fuel Standards
description: WASHINGTON THE Transportation Department is looking

title: DRUSE AND CHRISTIANS: A HISTORY OF TURMOIL
description: The battles between the Druse and the Maronite Christians are rooted in a history of fear and hatred, of massacres by each side against the other and of foreign countries ready to back one group or the other, and at times both, for their own ends.

title: Head of Charter Agency Ends Travel Talks With Russians
description: The president of the nation's largest charter travel company, which reserved the tickets of at least 13 passengers aboard the Korean airliner downed off a Soviet island last Thursday, cut off negotiations today for planned charters to the Soviet Union.

title: BOOK RECALLS BLACK WORLD WAR II TANK BATTALION
description: ''These guys were better than heroes because they weren't supposed to be able to fight, and they were treated worse than lepers. I can tell you, it took a rare sort of character to go out there and do what they did. I used to ask myself, why the hell should these guys fight? Why?''

title: SUMMER OF '83: VERY HOT, VERY GOOD FOR BUSINESS
description: As people streamed by on the boardwalk at Point Pleasant Beach, N.J., Roger Stone stood amid the jangling of change and flashing of lights in his games arcade and thanked the sunshine for the crowds.

title: Gail Naftalin Is Wed To a Social Worker
description: Gail Naftalin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Naftalin of Minneapolis, was married in Manhattan yesterday to Jerome R. C. Sachs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abram Sachs of Silver Spring, Md. Rabbi Nancy Fuchs-Kreimer performed the ceremony.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Trash and the Constitution
description: Think for a minute, please, about your trash can. Is it part of your home and castle, which the state is forbidden to search without a warrant? Or is it a depository for abandoned things, open to strangers, scavengers - and the police?

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Sports Behind Bars

title: SHELBY OF ORIOLES HELPS WIDEN LEAD
description: John Shelby had been in a mini batting slump. He had gone hitless in the previous two games and his average had fallen to .249.

title: WORLD DEBT PERIL EASES BUT PERSISTS
description: It has been a year since leaders of the international financial community gathered in Toronto and realized that Argentina and Mexico might not be the only developing countries that could have problems meeting their interest and principal payments on more than $600 billion of debt owed to foreign banks and governments.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In tennis doubles, the non-receiving member of the receiving team steps into the service box of the receiver just as the ball is about to be served. Is this an infraction? Unsportsmanlike behavior? What happens if the ball hits him on the fly?

title: Golden Gate Bridge Strike
description: Toll collectors on the the Golden Gate Bridge have walked off their jobs in a demand for a pay raise.

title: BRAVES, EXPOS MAKE GAINS
description: The National League Eastern and Western Division races tightened yesterday, as the Atlanta Braves snapped a six-game losing streak, the Montreal Expos cooled the Los Angeles Dodgers and the Pittsburgh Pirates and Philadelphia Phillies both lost.

title: AID URGED FOR DRUG INDUSTRY
description: A study issued by the National Academy of Engineering recommends that the Food and Drug Administration revise many of its controls on drugs, and urges that other Government policies be changed in order to strengthen the competitive position of the American pharmaceutical industry.

title: No Headline
description: Reagan on TV

title: Theater Piece by Schickele
description: ''Bestiary,'' a theater piece by Peter Schickele, will open the season for the group Calliope on Nov. 12 at 8 P.M. at Abraham Goodman House, 129 West 67th Street.

title: KRICKSTEIN, AN AMATEUR, BEATS GERULAITIS
description: In Aaron Krickstein's dream, he was beaten in straight sets by Vitas Gerulaitis. But yesterday, on the grandstand court at the National Tennis Center, the 16-year-old amateur came back from two sets down and again at 2-4 in the fifth set to eliminate 15th-seeded Gerulaitis and become the youngest player to reach the last 16 of men's singles in the United States Open tennis championships.

title: Books of The Times
description: CATHEDRAL. By Raymond Carver. 228

title: Voice of America Is Telling Russians of Plane Incident
description: The Voice of America is increasing broadcasts to the Soviet Union in an effort to get the story out about the downing of a South Korean airliner by a Russian warplane, a spokesman said today.

title: FIXED-RATE MORTGAGES RALLY
description: Fixed-rate mortgages, which forced some thrift institutions to the brink of insolvency and hurt many others a few years ago when interest paid to depositors soared, have made a comeback. But the recent upward trend in interest rates threatens to again reduce their numbers.

title: ACCOUNTANT IS CHOSEN FOR STANDARDS BOARD
description: Colleagues describe Raymond C. Lauver, who has been appointed to the Financial Accounting Standards Board, as an outstanding technician who likes to get his mind around problems, be they accounting or bridge.

title: SALVADORAN GUERRILLAS ATTACK NATION'S THIRD LARGEST CITY
description: In some of the heaviest fighting since the start of the three-year-old civil war, rebel forces attacked the third largest city in El Salvador during the night.

title: A LABOR DAY TOAST
description: I propose a salute this Labor Day.

title: OVETT REGAINS MARK IN 1,500
description: Steve Ovett regained his world record in the 1,500-meter run today when he was clocked at 3 minutes 30.77 seconds in an international track and field meet here.

title: REACTION TO U.S. BRINK'S TRIAL IS JUST AS MIXED AS THE VERDICT
description: Defense lawyers expressed joy, prosecutors remained silent and the judge said he was perplexed after a mixed verdict in the Federal Brink's trial in Manhattan.

title: No Headline
description: A federal judge is investigating charges that Julio Gonzalez del Solar, the president of Argentina's central bank, leaked valuable insider information on recent financial measures to eight banks, including several American ones.

title: CHILDREN, READING AND THE COMPUTER AGE
description: In an age of talking books on tape, video games, computer software and pervasive television-watching, are children being overwhelmed with too much information? Have traditional concerns about literacy been replaced by a faddish preoccupation with ''computer literacy''?

title: GIANTS ARE DEFEATED
description: It may have been nature's reminder that during the change of seasons there is a continuity to life. Or perhaps it was simply that one team could rush the passer and the other could not.

title: Israel Reported to Authorize 2 New West Bank Settlement
description: A Government committee today authorized the establishment of two new Jewish settlements in the Israeli-occupied West Bank of the Jordan River, the World Zionist Organization announced.

title: PASSERS STAND OUT IN EASTERN I-AA
description: SOME major of Division I-A football coaches might be envious of Eastern Division I-AA talent, particularly when looking at quarterbacks such as John Witkowski of Columbia, Steve Calabria of Colgate, Frank Novak of Lafayette, Rich LaBonte of Maine and Joe Potter of Brown. Even the Metropolitan New York area Division III teams have players of outstanding quality at quarterback, including Mark Casale of Montclair State and Todd Jamison of St. John's.

title: Iraq Marks Anniversary Of War With Iran
description: Iraq marked the third anniversary of its war with Iran today with a vow that it would continue fighting until a just solution to the conflict was reached.

title: COSMOS AND MANIC PLAYOFF OPPONENTS
description: The Cosmos' opponent in the first round of the North American Soccer League playoffs will be the Montreal Manic, whom the Cosmos defeated all four times the two Eastern Division rivals met in the regular season.

title: 'Music Festival' on WQXR
description: Regular programming on WQXR- FM (96.3) and AM (1560) will be pre- empted today for the station's third ''Festival of Music'' from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. Among the works played will be Tchaikovsky's Piano Concerto No. 1 in B flat minor with the pianist Claudio Arrau; Beethoven's Quartet No. 7 in F played by the Amadeus Quartet, and arias and duets sung by Luciano Pavarotti, Joan Sutherland, Mirella Freni and Katia Ricciarelli.

title: NEAR ITS END, SHUTTLE MISSION IS DECLARED SUCCESSFUL AND THE MOST TROUBLE-FREE EVER
description: As the mission of the space shuttle Challenger was drawing to a close, space agency officials said the flight not only accomplished all objectives but also was the most trouble- free orbital journey by American astronauts.

title: IN RHINO COUNTRY: A FIGHT TO SAVE HORNS OF AFRICA
description: As they climbed down from a truck that had taken them to a distant place, the men inserted ammunition into the breeches of sporting rifles. ''If you want to speak,'' their leader told a visitor, ''speak in whispers. We do not want to advertise our presence.''

title: MONDAYSPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Brewers, at Milwaukee, 2:30 P.M. Shane Rawley will seek his 15th victory as the Yankees open a four-game series.

title: UNCOUNTED IN THE 1963 MARCH ON WASHINGTON
description: To the Editor:

title: A FRUSTRATED GOSSAGE PONDERS FUTURE
description: THE Yankees use a radar gun to measure the speed of Rich Gossage's fastball, but there is no device that can measure what is in Gossage's mind. There are tons of statistics to show how surprisingly ineffective Gossage frequently has been this season, but there is no statistic that reflects the effect Gossage's mental state might have on his pitching performance.

title: No Headline
description: Bayer Chooses New Chairman LEVERKUSEN, West Germany, Sept. 4 (AP) - Hermann-Josef Strenger has been

title: Aquino's Widow Rejects Central Opposition Role
description: An opposition leader said today that the widow of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. would be asked to assume a central role in an expanded drive against the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, but Mrs. Aquino said she would decline any such post.

title: SHIFT OF POWER TO G.O.P. SEEN IN TECHNOLOGY USE
description: The growing power of political technology and the money to pay for it, and ''not some spontaneous 'shift to the right' '' are causing a realignment in American politics that helps Republicans, according to Benjamin Ginsberg, professor of political science at Cornell.

title: BEN COHEN, 'A GOOD MAN'
description: Benjamin V. Cohen, who died Aug. 16, was a rare man. He and Thomas G. Corcoran were pre-eminent among that ''contamination of mischievous cub lawyers,'' as an anti-New Deal columnist called the men at the heart of Franklin D. Roosevelt's Washington. Ben was as austere, shy and selfless as ''Tommy the Cork,'' as Roosevelt dubbed him, was ebullient and gregarious. They made a team that singlehandedly performed for the White House chores of bill-drafting, speechwriting and political strategy now done by hundreds. Tom, who turned to money-making law in 1941, died a few years ago, but Ben, who championed his friend to the very end, remained the selfless, public-spirited jurist - ''the best legal brain in Washington.''

title: TO RID MERCHANT FLEET OF 'FLOATING COFFINS WAITING TO SINK'
description: To the Editor:

title: Art of Central Park To Be in Exhibition
description: ''Artists' Views of Central Park: 1814-1914,'' a collection of paintings, drawings, prints and sculpture, will be on display from Sept. 22 to March 11 at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 76th Street.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Handy Man

title: Markets Closed Today
description: All United States and Canadian stock and commodity markets will be closed today in observance of Labor Day.

title: NADER SAYS OSHA IS SHACKLED NOW
description: Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, charged today that the Reagan Administration had undermined the Federal agency responsible for assuring a safe workplace and had made it a captive of industry.

title: TOUGH BUT RESTRAINED
description: President Reagan was exactly right when he denounced the Soviet destruction of Korean Air Lines Flight 7 as a ''horrifying act of violence.''

title: R. S. Harrison Weds Jolie Ann Bales
description: Jolie Ann Bales, daughter of Patricia Ann Bales of Seattle and Bruce Alan Bales of Tulsa, Okla., was married yesterday to Robert Steven Harrison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Norman Harrison of Oradell, N.J. Cantor Richard H. Berman performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Swedes Search for Subs
description: The Swedish Navy continued today to search for possible foreign submarines in home waters near the southern naval base of Karlskrona, a military spokesman said. But he said there had been no new indications of any intruders since three sets of depth charges were fired Saturday to try to force the suspected submarines to the surface.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:Danish Player Best Known In Europe Is Remembered

title: SOCIALISTS GATHER AMID HARD POLITICAL TIMES
description: For the Socialist Party, there have been better times.

title: Dollar Weak As Result of Fed's Report
description: The unexpected decline in the United States money supply, announced by the Federal Reserve last Friday, nudged the dollar downward in foreign-exchange trading today. Gold prices edged up.

title: COMPUTERS MASTERING SPEECH RECOGNITION
description: now the trick is to teach them to listen. Scientists and engineers have already made great strides toward achieving that goal. Machines are already being produced that recognize voices in a primitive way. And experts are confident that they will be able to build computers that will be competent to comprehend the human voice and carry out sophisticated spoken instructions.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST TUESDAY, SEPT. 6, 1983
description: The Economy The nation's savings rate has failed to respond to the Reagan Administration's sweeping reduction in taxes. Although Americans typically have saved a bit over 6 percent of their take-home pay, by last spring, despite the economic recovery, the rate had plunged to a 33-year low of 4 percent. (Page A1.)

title: BISHOP JOSEPH T. DALEY
description: Bishop Joseph T. Daley of Harrisburg died late Friday of cancer.

title: No Headline
description: Chess:Dlugy and Benjamin Share Title at the Junior Tourney

title: A 'FLEA MARKET' FOR AUTO FANCIERS
description: Terry Ehrich, an auto buff with an informal manner and easy smile, runs an $8 million-a-year magazine business. Next year, for the first time, he plans to draw up a budget.

title: ON COMMERCIALS AND KICKOFFS
description: The exigencies of television intruded on the progress of a National Football League game Sunday, raising anew the question of how much control the networks exert over the games they pay to broadcast.

title: MODELS: THEIR FACES EARN NEW FORTUNES
description: When Christie Brinkley stepped up to the podium in the Helmsley Palace's Versailles Room last week for the announcement that she and Russ Togs, a sportswear company, had agreed to produce the very first line of Christie Brinkley clothes, she did not quite resemble the fashion model who achieved immediate celebrity a few years back by appearing in a swimsuit on the cover of Sports Illustrated.

title: SIGNS OF OIL INDUSTRY REVIVAL
description: There is no sign to guide the visitor, but on the outskirts of Big Spring in the dusty West Texas oil country there is a fenced-off tract of land that is a kind of cemetery of oilmen's dreams. There lie row upon row of great steel oil and gas drilling rigs and a jumble of rusting pipe, cables, drill heads, transformers and house trailers.

title: SCOUTING
description: Getting Younger

description: Broadway Travels East

title: LESSONS ON A VINTAGE 'TIN GOOSE' LURING JETLINER PILOTS
description: When he is not flying a Boeing 737 jetliner for United Airlines, Bernard Godlove heads here to teach pilots how to fly a 54-year-old ''Tin Goose.''

title: TEXT OF U.S STATEMENT ON INTELLIGENCE PLANE
description: Following is the text of a statement read to reporters today at the White House about the presence of a United States reconnaissance plane in the vicinity of a South Korean airliner that was later downed:
