title: CARLETON ELDRIDGE JR., LAWYER
description: Carleton G. Eldridge Jr., a senior partner in the New York law firm of Coudert Brothers, died in his sleep Sunday while vacationing in St. Croix, V.I. He was 61 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: COWBOYS RALLY TO TOP REDSKINS
description: The Dallas Cowboys, who have spoiled more than one occasion for the Washington Redskins over the years, did it again tonight as they defeated last season's Super Bowl champions, 31-30, in a fiercely played game.

description: Of Art and Heat

title: No Headline
description: MARION DUPONT SCOTT

title: Isaac Asimov Novel Wins a Hugo Award
description: A novel by Isaac Asimov and a nonfiction book about his writings by James Gunn were two of the top winners of Hugo Awards, the science-fiction achievement awards.

title: WHO DECIDES IN RUSSIA?
description: The most important question provoked by the shooting down of South Korea's Boeing 747 is the relation between political and military decision makers in Moscow.

title: Bombing in West Germany
description: A bomb caused $1.1 million worth of damage to a restaurant and a doctor's office at the G"ottingen city center, the police said.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Effect of Rates, Military Surge
description: WHEN the stock market reopens today after the long Labor Day weekend, investors can look back to a week when the Dow Jones industrial average rose 23.38 points, to 1,215.45. Reflecting the holiday spirit, trading volume sank to a daily average of 66.4 million shares, marking the lowest turnover this year.

title: U.S. DELEGATE IN TASHKENT ACCUSES MOSCOW
description: The chief United States delegate to an international communications conference in the Soviet Union said today that the United States cannot excuse the Soviet downing of a Korean passenger plane. The Soviet delegate called the remark inappropriate.

title: VISIT BY GROMYKO TO PARIS DELAYED
description: France and the Soviet Union postponed the visit scheduled today by Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, just seven hours before he was to arrive in Paris, the Government announced.

title: AMERICANS SAVING LESS NOW THAN BEFORE THE '81 TAX ACT
description: Just over two years ago the Reagan Administration engineered sweeping changes in the nation's tax system and the largest tax cuts in history. The primary objective was to encourage the country to save and invest more of its income.

title: 6 YARDS IN 6 CARRIES UPSETS WOOLFOLK
description: The Giants, with two strong running backs in Butch Woolfolk and Rob Carpenter, were expected to run the ball more this year.

title: TEXTBOOK PUBLISHERS GRADED
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich went to the head of the class, but Holt, Rinehart & Winston's report card was mixed.

title: A FAILURE OF THE WESTERN POWERS TO SAVE PALESTINIAN LIVES
description: To the Editor:

title: Lomax Doubtful
description: Neil Lomax , the St. Louis Cardinals' quarterback, was listed as a doubtful starter for next Sunday's game against Dallas. Lomax's right shoulder was bruised on a tackle by Bruce Clark in Sunday's loss to the New Orleans Saints.

title: PER CAPITA INCOME UP 5% ACROSS U.S.
description: The average income of Americans rose about 5 percent last year, the Commerce Department said today.

title: WHY BETTORS RISK ALL FOR BIG WIN
description: ATLANTIC CITY FEW of the thousands of people still up at dawn on Labor Day in this resort town bothered to watch the daily miracle of the sunrise over the ocean. Most were still hunched over the gaming tables on the busiest weekend of the busiest year the casinos have ever had.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Make no mistake about it, this attack was not just against ourselves or the Republic of Korea.

title: PUBLIC HOUSING QUEST TROUBLES TOWN
description: For nearly a year, the Georgetown Housing Authority has struggled with public opposition, local zoning ordinances and stringent Federal housing rules in an effort to find a site for a 50-unit public housing project.

title: U.N. ASKS IRAN TO STOP RECRUITING CHILDREN
description: The United Nations subcommission on human rights called on Iran today to conform to international conventions and stop recruiting child soldiers for its Persian Gulf war against Iraq.

title: ONE HOPEFUL SIGN IN BEIRUT SUBURB
description: What happened today in this poor, overwhelmingly Moslem town just outside Beirut might be a step toward a settlement of Lebanon's civil war.

title: CBS Found Not Guilty Of Contempt of Court
description: CBS has been acquitted of Federal contempt of court charges stemming from its withholding of scripts from a ''60 Minutes'' broadcast about police brutality in New Orleans.

title: ANOTHER TAX APPROACH
description: The Federal budget deficit is now on the order of $200 billion, and if current conditions prevail and no corrective action is taken, it could climb to as much as $300 billion in less than five years. The prospect of continued out-of-control deficits of this magnitude is clearly intolerable. They expose the United States to serious risks of rekindled inflation, higher interest rates, a lopsided recovery and a severely crippled competitiveness in world markets. These serious consequences would, I believe, encourage proposals for more bureaucratic control mechanisms that could result in a significant loss of freedoms.

title: ANALYSTS EXPECTING STOCK RISES
description: After last year's late-summer surge in the stock market, this summer has been a discouraging one for investors in stocks. Nonetheless, there is a widespread expectation on Wall Street that the bull market has further to go, and that stock prices will resume their climb this fall.

title: No Headline
description: Allison Wins, Widening Lead

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies , at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Ron Darling makes his major league debut for the Mets and is opposed by Tony Ghelfi, who has only one previous start.

title: 4 Still Hospitalized After Shootout
description: Two police officers and two others remained hospitalized in stable condition today following a shootout in a restaurant in which two men were killed, authorities said.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Intel Corp. filed a bond offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission, through L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin and A. G. Becker Puerto Rico Inc.

title: Caesars World Names President of New Unit
description: Caesars World Inc., the big casino and hotel operator, established a new subsidiary, Caesars World Productions, at the beginning of 1983 to manage and package entertainment at company locations and elsewhere. Last week the company appointed Frank Brill the first full-time president of this operation, which will negotiate and design live and broadcast entertainment and sports events.

title: SCHOOL DAYS HAVE BEGUN IN THE STORES
description: Hester Prynne was worth about two minutes of her time, Michele Baccigalupi thought. Then Michele put aside ''The Scarlet Letter'' and forgot about the summer reading list from St. Edmund's High School in Brooklyn.

title: Poetry Center Opens Season Sept. 19
description: The Poetry Center of the 92d Street Y will open its 45th season Sept. 19 with a reading by Oriana Fallaci, an Italian journalist and author.

title: DO-GOOD PITYTHONS
description: Fund-raising telethons, such as last weekend's muscular dystrophy extravaganza, have been largely responsible for society's image of handicapped people. The picture is not always dignified.

title: BRIEFING
description: More Millionaires

title: A LIGHT WEEK FOR NEW OFFERINGS
description: Activity in the Treasury and corporate debt markets this week is likely to be confined to the trading of issues outstanding, since no offerings are scheduled for new notes or bonds.

title: SCOUTING
description: Bettors' Union

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing erbor, an article about Division I-AA football in SportsMonday yesterday incorrectly identified Fred Hill. He is the new baseball coach at Rutgers.

title: INDUSTRIAL POLICY'S OBSTACLES
description: The desire for a national industrial policy is now a ruling political passion. Presidential aspirants, political commentators, business and labor leaders and academics proclaim it as perhaps our most urgent priority, today's equivalent of the space program.

title: POLICE SEEK DRUNKEN DRIVERS AT CHECKPOINTS
description: The white sedan pulled out of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge toll plaza ?0 station on Staten Island and made a sharp right turn for an exit, but missed. With a squeal of tires, it ended up lodged on a curb.

title: The Calendar ;  Tuesday
description: After the slow rhythms of August, this is the week the pace of Washington normally begins to quicken.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Salute to Sanitation

title: WHOLE CITIES ORGANIZE TO FIGHT HEART DISEASE
description: MANKATO, Minn.

title: CITY PROPOSES HOUSING FOR DISPUTED WEST SIDE SITE
description: In an effort to resolve a two-decade- old controversy, the Koch administration is proposing that a 162-unit apartment complex be built on one of the last vacant sites in the huge West Side Urban Renewal Area. The complex would be built and maintained with both public and private funds.

title: No Headline
description: Man Is Found Shot to Death In Old Westbury Development

title: FOWLER CLASSIC ON LANGUAGE TRANSLATES TO PAPER
description: EVEN in the era of computers, word processors, video cassettes and data banks, the urge to put a sentence together sensibly, even lovingly, still engages the attention of students, teachers and professional wordsmiths. And ever since the Brothers Fowler in England and William Strunk Jr. and E. B. White in America showed that books on language need not be as dry as dictionaries, their modern successors have been busy trying to uphold the tradition.

title: COMPOSED EPIC POEMS
description: Henry Chapin, the author of a half- dozen volumes of poetry and four books on the ecology of man and the sea, died Sunday in his home in Peterborough, N.H. He was 89 years old.

title: SCANLON UPSETS MCENROE IN FOUR SETS AT OPEN
description: The tennis world has been waiting for Bill Scanlon to blossom for years. Yesterday, Scanlon did, outplaying top-seeded John McEnroe in four stimulating sets for a berth in the quarterfinals of the United States Open championships.

title: Letter: On Landmarks Save Faith, Not Buildings To the Editor:
description: You correctly identify serious problems that come with government regulation of church buildings by landmarking (editorial Aug. 28). The willingness of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission to use its law for the illegal purpose of ''spot zoning'' is only the tip of the iceberg. In the 18 years of its existence, the commission has never developed a full set of policies and procedures or defined the standards for landmarks designation beyond the vague ''special character'' cited in the landmarks law.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Hand Use and Intellect

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Hard-Times Homecoming

title: PRESIDENT SAYS SPY JET LANDED BEFORE INCIDENT
description: President Reagan said tonight that a United States reconnaissance plane passed close to a Korean passenger plane early last Thursday but landed in Alaska an hour before the Korean plane was shot down.

title: Moscow Police Arrest 4
description: Four members of a private organization called Group of Trust were seized by the Moscow police today when they went to the British Embassy to pick up a letter from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, a spokesman for the group said. Mrs. Thatcher was answering a note the group sent her in June complaining about the treatment of antinuclear demonstrators in Britain. The spokesman, Yuri Medvedkov, said the four who were arrested today were his wife, Olga, Mark Reitman, Sergei Rosenoer and Valery Godyak.

title: LABOR PARADE'S MARSHAL
description: With Sandra Feldman, the organizers of yesterday's Labor Day Parade got not only the first woman and first teacher to be grand marshal - but they also got a tough unionist in the bargain. At the age of 43, Miss Feldman is executive director of the United Federation of Teachers. She is also the secretary, the second-highest elected official, in the 70,000-member local, directly under Albert Shanker.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: WHILE most of the fashion capitals continue to sit on their hands, wiggle their ears and whistle, London keeps turning new corners with a sense of invention once called madcap. The latest fashion trend there has nothing to do with shaved heads, leather jerkins or spikes. It's being called Street Credibility, according to Tommy Nutter, who is among London's great tailors and was one of the lights that burned brightest in the 60's. Now, at age 40, he has his own shop on Savile Row.

title: China Signs Oil Pacts
description: The China National Offshore Oil Corporation said today that it had signed contracts with the Japan National Oil Corporation and with a consortium consisting of Idemitsu Oil Development, a Japanese company; the Natomas Company, an American concern, and Cluff Oil, of Britain. Since 1980, China has signed 16 contracts with 19 oil companies of eight countries for oil exploration and development. No initial investment figure was quoted for the latest deal, but under China's offshore oil contract rules the foreign partner bears all exploration costs.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: AMERICANS give the public schools a poorer rating today than they did 10 years ago. This judgment seems to ignore important indicators that show the schools are better today than they were in 1974. The present assessment emerges from the 15th annual Gallup Poll of the Public's Attitudes Toward the Public Schools, published by Phi Delta Kappa, the professional education fraternity.

title: OLDENBERG SCUPTURE HAS TOWN ON TENTERHOOKS
description: The sculptor Claes Oldenburg wants to erect a giant, orange fishing pole above a creek in this fashionable mountain town, but some local residents are far from receptive to the idea.

title: Clippers Routed
description: Terry Blocker hit two home runs and drove in six runs tonight to pace Tidewater to a 21-8 drubbing of the Columbus Clippers in the semifinal round of the International League Governor's Cup playoffs.

title: A PROBLEM AT SCHOOLS
description: News Analysis

title: PURCHASERS CITE EASING OF GROWTH
description: The economy continued to grow in August, though at a slower rate, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report yesterday. Employment and industrial production, however, registered their best performances this year.

title: AdvertisingN. R. Kleinfield Parody Of Playboy Is Planned
description: THEY did People. Then they did

title: No Headline
description: Mental Health Business as Usual New York, like other states, betrayed its mentally ill with a ''deinstitutionalization'' program, which reduced the number of patients at state mental hospitals without allocating enough money for their care in the community. As a candidate, Mario Cuomo promised to deal with the problem.

title: PUSHING FOR A NUCLEAR FREEZE
description: Late last month, with Congress out of session and with the pace of political life in the capital at a crawl, the officers of the Nuclear Freeze Campaign held a retreat. They examined the lobbying organization's goals, looked at how it was structured and discussed ways of increasing its impact.

title: DANCE: JOHANNA BOYCE
description: THE familiar and the fantastic were blended with good humor by the experimental choreographer Johanna Boyce in the performance that she presented Sunday in the outdoor ''Art on the Beach'' series on the Battery Park City Landfill.

title: INDIA SATELLITE GEAR JAMMED
description: Controllers tilted India's new communications-weather satellite today to bring its jammed solar gear in line with the sun while preparing maneuvers to get the equipment to extend properly.

title: No Headline
description: Bel Bolide Wins Del Mar Race

title: PHILIPS CLOSE TO RAISING ITS INTEREST IN GRUNDIG
description: N.V. Philips' Gloeilampenfabrieken, the giant Dutch electrical products group, is close to an agreement to increase its share of Grundig A.G., West Germany's largest home electronics company, officials of both companies said today.

title: CABANAS AT HIS BEST IN CREATIVE SOCCER
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Pope Expresses Praise For Cardinal Cooke
description: Pope John Paul II expressed his sympathy today for Terence Cardinal Cooke of New York, who has announced he is terminally ill with leukemia, and extolled him as a ''faithful pastor and servant.''

title: Aching Royals
description: The artificial turf of Royals Stadium in Kansas City, Mo., is one of the oldest and hardest in the major leagues, and now the Royals' George Brett, Frank White and Hal McRae complain that it's beginning to wear them down. ''Every morning I get out of bed I can feel the difference,'' said Brett.

title: 8 NIGERIAN ELECTION OFFICIALS BURNED TO DEATH AFTER VOTE
description: In the latest outbreak of Nigerian election violence, eight election commission officials were burned to death last week during voting for state legislatures, the police said today.

title: Mexican Rise In Oil Income
description: Mexico's oil revenues will exceed targets by 3 to 4 percent this year, Eliseo Mendoza Berrueto, the nation's Under Secretary of Energy, said here today.

title: Brock Suspended
description: The dispute between Dieter Brock , the Canadian Football League's leading quarterback, and the Winnipeg Blue Bombers took a more severe turn as the club suspended him without pay for refusing to play Sunday against the Saskatchewan Roughriders. The quarrel started last January, when Brock, twice the winner of the league's Schenley Trophy, asked to be relieved from the last three years of his five-year, $1.1 million contract so that he could finish his career with an American club.

title: Police Chief Cautions U.S. Officers to Stay Out
description: Police Chief Ray Davis, calling Federal immigration raids on illegal aliens ''wasteful and worthless,'' says Federal immigration officers are not welcome in his city.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PILOT TAPES
description: Following is a transcript, as translated from the Russian and distributed by the White House tonight, of excerpts from the radio transmissions of two Soviet pilots who were described as having participated in the downing of Korean Air Lines Flight 7 last week. All times are Greenwich Mean Time.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT REAGAN'S ADDRESS ON DOWNING OF KOREAN AIRLINER
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's speech in Washington last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Distraught Over Killing, Police Officer Resigns
description: An officer who shot and killed a 5-year- old boy found clutching a toy gun in a dark apartment has retired from the force, fearing an inability to serve as a policeman, his father said.

title: SCOUTING
description: Durable Record

title: Israeli Coalition Fails To Reach Agreement
description: Religious and economic issues today held up attempts by ministers from the Likud bloc to reach agreement with their coalition partners to form a new Government under Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir.

title: No Headline
description: L.P.G.A. Rookie Wins in Playoff

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary Saturday of Wallace Hamilton, novelist and playwright, incorrectly listed the date of a memorial service. It is Sept. 18 at 5 P.M. in the Friends Meeting House on Rutherford Place.

title: SEOUL SAYS IT WON'T RETALIATE INDEPENDENTLY
description: South Korea will not take independent retaliatory actions against the Soviet Union for shooting down a South Korean airliner last week, the Foreign Minister said today.

title: LET ALL THE DYING KEEP THEIR DIGNITY
description: To the Editor:

title: INTEREST RATE DIP EXPECTED TO FUEL A DRAMATIC RISE IN STUDENT LOANS
description: AFTER a year of severe belt tightening, college students are letting out all the eyelets again, borrowing at near record levels under the federally guaranteed loan program. And the trend in loan volume is expected to intensify as the interest rate declines slightly this month.

title: No Headline
description: Time Nutrition Section

title: BREWER PITCHERS BAFFLE YANKS
description: Both the big, slow curves of Tom Candiotti and the fastballs of Pete Ladd baffled the Yankees today as they lost, 3-1, to the Brewers and fell from second place in the American League East.

title: Bank Robber Leaves A Big Clue for Police
description: A man who the police say robbed a bank here forgot the first rule about holdups: don't leave your address behind.

title: No Headline
description: Datapoint Net Triples in Year

title: AUSTRALIA II WINS ROLE OF CHALLENGER
description: Greeted by cheers and the blaring of boat horns from the spectator fleet, Australia II crossed the finish line 3 minutes 19 seconds ahead of Britain's Victory 83 today to become the 25th challenger to the America's Cup.

title: COLUMBIA GOING BACK INTO SPACE IN NEXT MISSION WITH A CREW OF 6
description: The first space shuttle, the Columbia, is scheduled to return to service for the next flight in the American series, and the Challenger is getting a breather after three flights in five months.

title: LAKE IN POCONOS ON COMEBACK TRAIL
description: Gerald Ehrhardt and Carson Helfrich stopped to look at a sign and then continued their tour along the shore of a lake that glittered in the morning sun. It was a lake teeming with life: water sports on its broad bosom and fish below. Only a few years ago it was diagnosed as possibly dying.

title: No Headline
description: 4-A Names Executive

title: TRADERS REACT TO MONEY DATA
description: For several years the Federal Reserve has warned against predicting changes in Fed monetary policy on the basis of weekly money supply data, which it says ''are highly volatile and subject to revision.'' For just as many years traders, economists and investors have ignored the Fed's advice by treating each weekly money supply announcement as a major event.

title: KOREAN PLANE'S PILOT WAS AIR FORCE VETERAN
description: ''See you soon,'' said Chun Byung In, a 45-year-old Korean Air Lines pilot, when he left his family in Seoul on Aug. 27 for what he thought would be another routine trip.

title: INFORMERS AIDING SALVADOR REBELS
description: Attacks by rebels in the eastern part of El Salvador in the last two days indicate they used information obtained from informers within the Salvadoran Army, a Western official here said today.

title: INSTRUCTION WITHOUT INSPIRATION
description: SOMEONE, it seems, is always trying to eliminate, or at least significantly reduce, the human factor in the arts, be they visual, auditory or pedagogical.

title: 12 Hurt in Helicopter Crash
description: A helicopter crashed in a desolate area near Mount St. Helens today, slightly injuring 12 people aboard, the authorities said. No roads led to the crash site, and the last victims were airlifted from the site shortly before 3 P.M., an hour and a half after the crash, said Tom McDowell, chief of the North Country Emergency Medical Services.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Call of the Cricket

title: PlaneSafely On the Thruway
description: A single-engine plane landed safely on the southbound lanes of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway this morning, just south of Exit 21A in this Albany County town, according to the state police.

title: 'LIBERAL TRADE' URGED BY GATT ECONOMISTS
description: The international agency that monitors world trade urged governments today to promote global economic growth by allowing the market place to determine price levels undistorted by protectionism.

title: LIBYAN PLANES ARE REPORTED TO BOMB CHAD TOWN
description: Libyan warplanes bombed the Government outpost of Oum Chalouba in northeastern Chad today, a Government official said.

title: PLAN TO IGNITE UNDERGROUND COAL FOR GAS STIRS FEAR
description: A plan to ignite underground coal and capture the gases for synthetic fuel has touched off a controversy here, fanned by anger and fear over an uncontrolled mine fire at Centralia, 13 miles to the north.

title: RUSSIAN REACTION: OLD FEARS REVIVED
description: NewsAnalysis

title: 5 Peruvian Guerrillas Killed
description: Five suspected Maoist guerrillas were killed in a clash with the Peruvian police as rebels staged several attacks over the weekend, ending a three-week lull, police sources said today. They said the five guerrillas of the Shining Path movement died in a shootout as they tried to take over a village in the remote Andean province of Ayacucho, northwest of Lima.

title: PEGASUS CAPTURED BY WORLD APPEAL
description: Give a colt named World Appeal the lead on a lightning-fast race track, and he can stretch his speed for nine furlongs. He did exactly that two months ago in the Jersey Derby and duplicated that victory today with a front-running 2 1/4-length triumph in the $226,900 Pegasus Stakes on opening day at Meadowlands Race Track.

title: TEST BEING READIED TO MEASURE DEPRESSION
description: Doctors are developing a test to diagnose clinical depression, which experts believe may be caused by low levels of an easily measurable brain chemical.

title: CARDINALS CAPTURE PAIR FROM PIRATES
description: The Cardinals swept a doubleheader from the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight to move one-half game out of first place in the National League East.

title: CHRYSLER AND AUTO WORKERS AGREE ON CONTRACT EXTENSION
description: Negotiatiors for the Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers reached tentative agreement on a new labor contract today, Owen F. Bieber, the union's president reported.

title: DEMANDS IT PAY FOR JET LOSS
description: Transcript of address, page A15.

title: A Drive Against Thai Pirates Is Paying Off, U.N. Aide Says
description: A campaign in the waters off Thailand against pirates who prey on refugee boats fleeing from Vietnam is meeting with some success, a United Nations official said today.

title: No Headline
description: Holiday Market Closings

title: CONCERT: NAUMBURG
description: WITH the arrival of Labor Day, the summertime series of outdoor concerts around the city is coming to an end. One of the last was a concert Sunday night at the Damrosch Park Bandshell presented by Jens Nygaard conducting the Naumburg Orchestra. Many urban residents may feel a bit saddened at this seasonal passing, but this concert reminded a critic about why his own enthusiasms for this type of musical celebration are muted.

title: F.B.I. KEPT WATCH ON HENRY WALLACE
description: Henry A. Wallace was watched by the Federal Bureau of Investigation while he was Vice President under Franklin D. Roosevelt and Secretary of Commerce for Harry S. Truman, and also in his 1948 run for the Presidency, a newspaper has reported.

title: FRESH PRINTS FROM PRINTOUTS
description: She derives her prints from television screens, computer printouts, even cardiograms. Her shapes are simple: short dresses, sweatshirts, bulky jackets, trousers. The clothes are racy but comfortable-looking. Elisabeth de Senneville, the French ready-to- wear designer, thinks they will have considerable appeal because she contends they represent the wave of the future in fashion and because she believes American women are more open to new ideas than women elsewhere.

title: MGM Suing Taurus-Film
description: The MGM/UA Entertainment Company has filed a $960 million lawsuit that accuses a major European film distribution company of price-fixing and restraint of trade.

title: No Headline
description: People

title: Gdansk Demonstrations A Success, Walesa Says
description: Lech Walesa, founder of the Solidarity union, today described last week's pro- Solidarity demonstrations in Gdansk as a success considering what he called the scare tactics of the authorities.

title: CAP ON INTEREST GROUPS' CAMPAIGN INFLUENCE URGED ON COAST
description: A drive has begun in California to change campaign financing practices in order to blunt the influence of special-interest political action groups whose money fuels the increasingly costly races for the State Legislature.

title: CITY OPERA LIGHTING DIRECTOR
description: Gilbert V. Hemsley Jr., the production supervisor and lighting director of the New York City Opera who designed lighting for dozens of major opera, ballet, theater and televison productions, died of cancer Sunday in his Manhattan home. He was 47 years old.

title: Philippine Panel Visits Scene of Killing
description: Members of the special commission set up to investigate the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. today visited the Manila airport, where the opposition leader and his reputed assassin were killed on Aug. 21.

title: PLANE'S DOWNING MAY SHADOW TALKS
description: The subject of the downed South Korean airliner and the ensuing international uproar are expected to dominate the East-West gathering of foreign ministers at the European security conference here this week.

title: CommoditiesYla Eason Obstacle To Sugar Price Rise
description: AFTER a sleepy summer, sugar futures prices promise to sparkle, if only they can get through this month.

title: CALIFORNIA INMATES WORK WITH EMERGENCY CREWS
description: When the exclusive Malibu Colony home of Barbra Streisand was hit hard by storms last month, prison inmates quickly piled sandbags around it, protecting it from further damage.

title: JOHN GILPIN, 53, BALLET DANCER WITH LONDON FESTIVAL TROUPE
description: John Gilpin, whose career with London's Festival Ballet made him internationally known as one of Britain's leading ballet dancers, died of a heart attack in London yesterday. He was 53 years old.

title: CANADIANS SUSPEND FLIGHTS BY SOVIET JETS TO MONTREAL
description: Canada decided today to suspend all flights by the Soviet airline, Aeroflot, into Montreal for 60 days to protest last week's downing of a South Korean airliner.

title: No Headline
description: Who's Taking Care of the Kids? There are 23 million American children under 14 whose mothers work outside the house; nearly a third are under 6. Almost all the mothers, the Labor Department says, work because they need the money. So who's taking care of the kids?

title: ProtestersLeaving SenecaArmy Base
description: Members of the Women's Encampment for a Future of Peace and Justice held a quiet closing ceremony today as they prepared to end a camp established the Fourth of July to protest the deployment of nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: PIANO MAKERS LOSING GROUND TO IMPORTS
description: Now it is American piano makers that are threatened by imports.

title: 2 MARINES DIE IN ARTILLERY RAID ON BEIRUT FORCES
description: Two United States marines were killed and two others wounded in an artillery barrage at dawn today, the third day of renewed Christian-Druse fighting in Lebanon, a Marine spokesman said.

title: No Headline
description: Irish to Vote Tomorrow on Antiabortion Measure

title: CBS CLEARED OF CONTEMPT CHARGES IN POLICE CASE
description: CBS Television has been cleared of criminal contempt charges that stemmed from its refusal to submit a segment of its ''60 Minutes'' news program to a Federal judge before it was broadcast.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MR. BEDFORD AND THE MUSES. By Gail Godwin. 229 pages. Viking. $14.95.

title: SCOUTING
description: Selig Is Directed To His Back Yard

title: LABOR DAY AT LAKE GEORGE: MORE WORK WITH LESS HELP
description: Pam Orcutt fixed a smile on her face and trudged outside to wait on another table at the popular Boardwalk restaurant here. The Adirondack Community College student had been working from 11 A.M. to 4 A.M., and she said her face was getting tired from smiling.

title: Business and the LawKenneth B. Noble Investigations By Lawyers
description: WASHINGTON ADECADE ago, the Securities and Exchange Commission, concerned with reports of illegal corporate contributions to the re-election campaign of President Nixon, began asking companies to conduct internal reviews and disclose to their shareholders whether they had made improper payments.

title: 2 CHILEAN EXILES GO HOME TO A ROUSING WELCOME
description: Thousands of exuberant Chileans chanting ''The military dictatorship will fall!'' welcomed home this weekend two opposition politicians, the latest of hundreds of Chileans who have returned here in recent weeks after extended periods in forced exile.

title: 142d Philharmonic Season
description: The New York Philharmonic will open its 142d season on Wednesday, Sept. 14, at 8 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall, with a gala benefit concert conducted by Rafael Kubelik, with Rudolf Serkin, piano soloist. Mr. Kubelik will conduct Mahler's Symphony No. 1 and Mr. Serkin will perform Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 1.

title: Higher Education Hailed
description: Education Secretary T. H. Bell extolled the value of higher education today, even for workers who did not need college diplomas for their jobs. ''We may miseducate our people, but we can't overeducate them,'' he said at a George Washington University convocation for the start of the school year. Mr. Bell received an honorary doctor of public service degree at the convocation.

title: 7 Pakistani Politicians Reported Arrested
description: The police arrested seven members of the banned Pakistan People's Party today when they returned to Pakistan to lead a campaign for democracy in their native Punjab Province, airport sources said.

title: SALVADORANS STEADFAST, U.S. ENVOY SAYS
description: Richard B. Stone, the United States special Presidential envoy, said today that the Salvadoran Government is on the road to peace and democracy, and will not accept any plan to share power with the guerrillas fighting it.

title: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 6, 1983 International
description: President Reagan assailed Moscow for what he termed ''the Korean ailine massacre'' and announced new curbs on cultural, scientific and diplomatic exchanges with the Russians and new efforts to restrict Soviet civilian aviation in the West. In a television address, Mr. Reagan also called on Congress to back his military programs, particularly the MX missile. (Page A1, Column 6.) An American surveillance plane passed close to a South Korean airliner last Thursday but landed in Alaska one hour before the airliner was shot down, President Reagan said in his television address. The White House said the presence of the surveillance plane ''some 1,000 miles and two and a half hours' flight time from the scene of the shootdown'' in no way excused the attack. (A1:5.)

title: Teachers May Strike In Several Major Cities By United Press International
description: Teachers in New York City, Pittsburgh, St. Louis and Detroit threatened yesterday to strike unless they received contracts.

title: More Stores Sell Gasoline
description: The number of retail gasoline outlets fell by one-fifth nationwide between 1977 and 1982 while the number of convenience stores with gas pumps more than doubled in the same period, according to an industry newsletter.

title: KOCH CONSIDERING PLAN TO BUY WELFARE HOTELS
description: Mayor Koch is considering a plan to take over some of the 50 hotels now sheltering displaced welfare families.

title: ONE MORE STEP FOR MEDICINAL MARIJUANA
description: To the Editor:

title: POPE WARNS 25 U.S. BISHOPS ON SEX MORALS
description: Pope John Paul II repeated Roman Catholic teaching against abortion, divorce, the ordination of women, birth control, premarital sex and homosexuality today in a speech to 25 visiting United States bishops.

title: No Headline
description: Latin Debtors Seek Changes

title: PERONIST INFIGHTING CONTINUES IN THE COURTS AND THE STREETS
description: Peronist party infighting continued in the courts and on the streets today as the party sought to reconvene its stalled presidential nominating convention.

title: SERBAN, HIS 'VANYA' AND HIS CAREER
description: The vast space at La Mama Annex has been transformed into a sprawling, open-walled, multilevel house, a wood-paneled, organic environment for Andrei Serban's production of ''Uncle Vanya.'' The play, which stars Joseph Chaikin and F. Murray Abraham as Uncle Vanya and Dr. Astrov, is in previews and is scheduled to open Sept. 11.

title: MONARCH'S HORMONES YIELD SUBTLE SECRETS OF INSECT GROWTH
description: Fortunately for Dr. William Herman, monarch butterflies can be raised in the laboratory on an artificial diet. They are also sturdy enough to survive shipping from California. Otherwise, last spring's cold wet weather would have left Minnesota's monarch butterfly specialist high and dry.

title: ORGAN DAMAGE FOUND IN MICE AT LOVE CANAL
description: MEADOW voles, the field mice that live near the fenced-off Love Canal toxic dump site in Niagara Falls, N. Y., have been found to have shortened lifespans and organ damage similar to that caused by the kinds of toxic chemicals that were dumped in the canal, a four-year scientific study has revealed.

title: HONDURAN PROPOSES A TREATY
description: Foreign Minister Edgardo Paz Barnica said today that Honduras would seek a a regional treaty to cover the region's political, economic and security problems.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Bayer's New Chief Breaks Tradition

title: No Headline
description: Taxi Driver Is Slain

title: TV: 'MURDER INK' PILOT, A SERIES THAT WASN'T
description: AMONG the more convincing reasons for looking forward to a new television season is the possibility that the networks may finally have cleared their programming shelves of failed pilots. If watching the stuff that succeeded in becoming weekly series can be trying, looking at the failures can border on downright cruelty. Tonight's prime example, on CBS-TV at 8 o'clock , is ''Murder Ink.''

title: Acid Rain Study On Scandinavian Lakes
description: Leading scientists in Britain, Norway and Sweden announced today that they were starting a limited five-year study into the effects of acid rain on Scandinavian lakes.

title: One Dead as Boat HitsL.I.Causeway
description: A motorboat crashed into the pilings of a Wantagh State Parkway causeway near Jones Beach here early today, and the accident killed one man and injured two others, the Nassau County police said.

title: METS WIN ON FOSTER'S 3-RUN CLOUT IN 9TH
description: The winner of the National League East this year may well be the best of a bad lot, with four teams struggling nightly to keep themselves in the race.

title: CONTRARY TO FORM, A TRIP TO THE RANCH IS CUT SHORT
description: In vacations, as in all things, President Reagan had been determined to be different from his predecessor.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'Snuff' Is Snuffed

title: No Headline
description: Ketchum Wins Pactel Account Pacific Telephone has named

title: SHUTTLE ENDS A SUCCESSFUL MISSION WITH FLAWLESS LANDING AT NIGHT
description: The space shuttle Challenger glided out of the dark and moonless night early today to end its successful six-day, two-and-a-half-million-mile mission with a perfect touchdown here. It was the first nighttime landing by a spaceship.

title: REAGAN AVOIDS DRAMATIC IN RESPONSE TO SHOOTING
description: News Analysis

title: Anti-Chile Protests in Spain
description: About 20 people forced their way into the Chilean Consulate here and vowed to occupy the offices for 24 hours to show their opposition to Chile's military Government. In Madrid, 40 people protested in front of Chile's Consulate with placards attacking the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

title: RUSSIANS' VERSION
description: The Soviet Union said today that a Soviet fighter that fired tracer shells past a Korean Air Lines 747 did so only after the airliner had changed course and altitude over southern Sakhalin Island in such a way as to carry it over a Soviet air base.

title: Top Officers Promoted At National Presto
description: Since 1965, when Joseph H. Berney became assistant to the president of National Presto Industries Inc., a pioneer in the manufacture of small electrical appliances, he has been developing the skills that would lead him to a top spot. And last week, the 51-year-old executive was promoted from treasurer to president of the Eau Claire, Wis., company.

title: No Headline
description: Cities Service Fills No. 2 Post LOS ANGELES, Sept. 5

title: Guatemalan Army Hints 12 Were Killed by Communists
description: A Guatemalan Army bulletin said today that 12 civilians were murdered in a southern town as members of the outlawed Communist Party distributed leaflets and organized a rally there.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: ADT Co. has named Selma Tennebaum Rossen vice president of engineering and service.

title: Charlotte Curtis Reluctant Appointee; 'I want to see what they have to show me,' explains Diaz-Alejandro of Reagan's panel on Central America.
description: -ALEJANDRO, the Cuban-born economics professor, was in Corsica without a telephone when President Reagan announced his appointment to the Bipartisan Commission on Central America. Days later he heard the news, and since he hadn't sought the appointment and nobody had approached him prior to the announcement he thought it was a joke.

title: PICKPOCKETS IN CITY ADOPT NEW TACTICS
description: He was small and slender, 15 or 16 years old, and his eyes looked glazed. He seemed to stumble as he stepped off the subway train at 96th Street and Central Park West yesterday. Suddenly, he went down, his right leg apparently wedged between the train and the platform.

title: BUDDY YOUNG, EX-FOOTBALL STAR
description: Claude (Buddy) Young, who starred as a college and professional football player in the 1940's and 1950's, was killed in a car accident early Sunday morning near a small town in Texas. He was 57 years old.

title: ADVERTISING ; Travel Patterns Studied By Knapp for Clients
description: Knapp Communications, which has been periodically funding attitude studies of different consumer categories as a service to its advertisers, has just completed a national inquiry into travel patterns and beliefs. Knapp, which publishes Architectural Digest, Bon Appetit, GEO and Home, used Simmons Market Research to do the study.

title: NEW CLUE IN MYSTERY OF ALZHEIMER'S DISEASE
description: One of the mysteries of Alzheimer's disease is the presence in patients' brain cells of strange tangles of fibers, known as neurofibrillary tangles. The degree to which the brain is encumbered with these clumps of fibers correlates with the severity of dementia and mental deterioration suffered by the patient.

title: ; PROTECT THE LOCAL PHONE CUSTOMER
description: To the Editor:

title: 'HOMES OF STARS' TOURS SUE FOR ROUTES
description: A heated battle is brewing in Beverly Hills, the city proclaimed by its Chamber of Commerce as ''the most magical kingdom of them all,'' where for 50 years the star-struck have been able to board a tour bus and come within a stone's throw of the homes of such luminaries as Lucille Ball or Jimmy Stewart.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:CommercialLeaguesTaking EntriesinMetropolitanArea

title: JETS NOT RELAXING AFTER FINE OPENER
description: Dwayne Crutchfield was understandably impressed today with the Jets.

title: Business and the Law; Investigations By Lawyers
description: A DECADE ago, the Securities and Exchange Commission, concerned with reports of illegal corporate contributions to the re-election campaign of President Nixon, began asking companies to conduct internal reviews and disclose to their shareholders whether they had made improper payments.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: ALL SET This is the opera season in New York, if not quite yet in the opera houses themselves, then in the museums and kindred institutions that are vying to honor the Metropolitan Opera on its 100th birthday. The newest exhibition to take the centenary as a theme opens today at the Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street (838-6690). In the wonderfully high gallery on the main floor of these bookish precincts, an attractive and lively show, ''Designing for Opera,'' takes the visitor through the topic from the 1500's to the most recent David Hockney design, for ''Rake's Progress.''

title: OF RENTS AND BUSINESS
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Airliner's Crash Last Week Is Reported
description: A Soviet Aeroflot airliner crashed a week ago on a domestic flight as it approached Alma-Ata airport in the Kazakhstan Republic, killing all those on board, according to a local newspaper reaching Moscow today.

title: REYE'S SYNDROME SEEN OUTSIDE CITY LIMITS
description: Reye's syndrome, a mysterious and often fatal childhood disease that can cause liver failure and brain swelling, strikes rural and suburban youngsters more often than their city counterparts, a researcher has reported.

title: SPERM-BANK BABY JOY TO HIS MOTHER
description: An unmarried psychologist who gave birth after being artificially inseminated with sperm from a sperm bank to which some Nobel Prize winners had contributed says she has been happy in her son's first year.

title: No Headline
description: Sneaky, Creepy Taxes Now you see them, now you don't. With much ballyhoo, the Government enacted massive cuts in personal income taxes soon after President Reagan took office. Those cuts have now vanished. Taxes, in fact, are going up, invisibly.

title: British Printing Net Up
description: Robert Maxwell, chairman of the British Printing and Communications Corporation, said today that the company's pretax profits in the first six months of 1983 rose 53.3 percent, to $11.5 million, from $7.5 million in the period a year before. He said the increase came despite losses of $2.4 million caused by a strike at the Park Royal plant.

title: Nursing Home Worker Charged in 6 Deaths
description: A 24-year-old former nursing home kitchen worker, already in custody on charges of raping and murdering two elderly residents, was charged today with killing four other women at the home.

title: TESTING TIME IN LEBANON
description: Military Analysis

title: CHINAGLIA MISSES COSMOS' WORKOUT
description: Giorgio Chinaglia, who missed the final game of the regular season last Friday because of a business trip, was absent again today when the Cosmos held the last practice before their playoff series opener here Tuesday night against Montreal.

title: JOHN MCENROE AND HIS MONSTER
description: On the second match point, Bill Scanlon scorched a backhand return of John McEnroe's second serve down the line. As the ball skipped off the green court past the Wimbledon champion, the 16th- seeded Texan shouted with joy. So did most of the 20,701 people who had been hypnotized under a hazy, humid sun for nearly four hours yesterday by the possibility of John McEnroe being spanked in the United States Open's fourth round.

title: EX-C.I.A. MAN ACCUSES DULLES
description: A former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency who was imprisoned in China for 21 years says he might have been released in 1957 instead of 1973 had it not been for Secretary of State John Foster Dulles's ''overwhelming fear of Communism.''

title: JOBS ARE KEY ISSUE FOR CITY'S LABOR DAY MARCHERS
description: With cranes, buses, fire engines and sewing machines, New York labor paraded up Fifth Avenue yesterday.

title: Raiders to Get Jordan
description: Coach Ron Meyer of the New England Patriots confirmed yesterday that his club and the Los Angeles Raiders had all but completed the paperwork on a trade that will send Shelby Jordan , the Patriots' recalcitrant offensive tackle, and the tight end Don Hasselbeck to Los Angeles in exchange for Derrick Ramsey , a reserve tight end, and a fourth-round draft choice in 1985. The key player in the deal would appear to be Jordan, who is expected to lend significant help to a somewhat troubled Los Angeles offensive line.

title: WHEN THE I.R.S. TURNS TO 'DATA MERCHANTS'
description: To the Editor:

title: CONGRESSIONAL LEADERS DISCOUNT SIGNIFICANCE OF THE U.S. SPY PLANE
description: Congressional leaders today discounted the importance of the presence of an American reconnaissance plane in the general area where a South Korean commercial airliner was downedlast week.

title: ADVERTISING ;  Addenda
description: * HWH Enterprises has established a Chicago office, through its associaiton with Coordinators Inc., Chicago.

title: PAY LESS DRUG STORES NORTHEST reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The share earnings reflect 100 percent stock dividend paid in May.

title: Davila in Mourning
description: Admitting that his championship was a hollow one, Alberto Davila said yesterday from his home in Pomona, Calif., ''I just prayed for him, prayed for him all the time after it happened. I feel really bad; I'm in mourning with his family.''

title: STOP & SHOP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 13
description: The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid June 30.

title: CARTER'S LASTING GESTURE
description: To the Editor:

title: MEL TOMMLINSON WINS CAROLINA PRIZE
description: Mel Tomlinson, a dancer with the New York City Ballet, has won the first North Carolina Prize, a $10,000 award to a North Carolina native for outstanding work in the visual or performing arts.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF KIRKPATRICK ADDRESS ON KOREAN AIRLINER TO SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Following is a transcript of an address yesterday by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, to the Security Council, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: LODGISTIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Loan to Mexico Repaid
description: Mexico repaid a $1.85 billion bridging loan from the Bank for International Settlements promptly on Aug. 31, the bank's president, Fritz Leutwiler, said today. The international rescue of Mexico was an example of sensible central bank action, and of a country clearly improving its position by rigorous measures, he added.

title: U.N. COUNCIL HEARS A TAPE IN RUSSIAN
description: Mrs. Kirkpatrick's speech, page A15.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: SOME years ago one of the songs in a Broadway show called ''Take Me Along'' had a line to the effect that if more guests arrive, simply ''add more water to the soup.'' That may bestretching it a bit, but there are many practical ways of extending a main course using somewhat more solid materials. For example, you may add the flavor of more mushrooms or a few more bread crumbs to the cooked meat you're about to shape into a loaf.

title: POET WINS BATTLE TO REMAIN IN U.S.
description: Dennis Brutus, a black poet and political activist exiled by South Africa, was granted asylum in the United States today after a two-year battle against deportation.

title: U.A.W. PANEL APPROVES $2.42 CHRYSLER PAY RAISE
description: A tentative contract giving workers at the Chrysler Corporation a wage increase of $2.42 an hour over two years was approved today by the Chrysler Council of the United Automobile Workers.

title: A-Plant Releases Radioactive Gas
description: Radioactive gas was accidentally released into the atmosphere for 30 seconds from the Connecticut Yankee nuclear power plant today, but utility executives said there was no danger to the public.

title: PHILLIES RUIN DEBUT OF DARLING
description: On Ron Darling's first seven pitches as a big leaguer last night, he struck out Joe Morgan and Pete Rose, with a total of 40 years in the majors between them, and appeared on his way to a spectacular debut.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT BY SOVIET GOVERNMENT
description: Following is the text of the Government's statement today on the downing of the South Korean airliner, as distributed in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass:

title: Careers; Global Public Relations
description: DONALD G. DOWD, until recently vice president of corporate communications for the A. B. Dick Company, a large office equipment maker, thinks that in this age of increasing dependence on computerized information ''the professional worldwide public relations executive must understand global cultures if he or she is going to play a significant rule in future business and government decisions.''

title: SOME MARINES 'FEEL HELPLESS'
description: At 3:15 P.M. today, the call went out that no marine on the base here likes to hear. ''Into the bunkers!'' shouted a marine to his comrades. ''Condition One!''

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT BY THE STATE DEPARTMENT
description: Following is the text of a statement read at the State Department today by Lawrence S. Eagleburger, Under Secretary for Political Affairs, on the downing of the Korean Air Lines jetliner and Soviet statements about the downing:

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Coast Thrift Unit Plans Record Private Offering

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Memo From Lindsay Era Invites Memories An official city memorandum, with

title: MSR EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: HYSTER STUDIES KOHLBERG PLAN
description: The Hyster Company announced today that it is considering a financing proposal from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the investment concern, that would return Hyster to private ownership while keeping it under its current management.

title: Utah Symphony Strike Ended by 3-Year Pact
description: Musicians of the Utah Symphony voted Monday night to ratify a new three-year agreement, ending a five- day strike that was the first in its history.

title: SCOUTING
description: Waiting Game

title: BRIEFING
description: U.S.I.A. on Overtime

title: Advertising; Providing Creativity For P.& G.
description: PROCTER & GAMBLE is the country's largest national advertiser, and it probably has the most stable agency relationships on record. Despite these two winning characteristics, Roy Grace, executive creative director of Doyle Dane Bernbach's domestic operation, was relieved when the Cincinnati giant announced it was splitting with the agency last Nov. 16, ostensibly because of a product conflict in Europe.

title: No Headline
description: IT'S back-to-school time, and there are lots of new products, books and clothes for children of all ages, from the kindergarten set to teen- agers.

title: CHILE'S 210 YEARS OF MISRULE
description: A decade has passed since the Chilean military seized power in a bloody coup that overthrew President Salvador Allende Gossens and put an end to his democratic road to socialism. It has been a decade since a Chilean colonel proudly told me to come back in 10 years and ''see what we have done for Chile.'' In fact, he and his fellow officers have destroyed Chile's economy and united the people in opposition to their regime. They have proved to be incompetent as well as inhumane, sowing the seeds of their own overthrow.

title: Brazil Debt Talks Set
description: Western creditor nations will consider Brazil's request to reschedule its official debts at a three-day meeting here beginning Sept. 14, diplomatic sources said today. However, no firm agreement is expected from the meetings.

title: Broken Hill Offer
description: The Broken Hill Proprietary Company Ltd., Australia's largest company, said it had recommended that its shareholders reject the share exchange bid from Wigmores Ltd., a subsidiary of Robert Holmes A'Court's Bell Group Ltd. Broken Hill said it would give its reasons for the recommendation in formal documents responding to the Wigmores offer, which was valued at $3.5 billion at current exchange rates.

title: VATICAN EMPLOYEE APPEALS FOR NEWS OF DAUGHTER
description: A Vatican employee whose daughter was kidnapped publicly expressed his fear today that the girl was dead and begged her kidnappers to disclose her whereabouts so that ''we can pray for her, near her.''

title: TIME, COST AND BASE FOR SMALLER MISSILES UNDER VITAL DEBATE
description: A debate vital to the nation's security is going on among military experts and lawmakers over how much a network of smaller missiles, dubbed Midgetman, would cost, when it could be built and how it should be deployed.

title: Republic Airlines
description: The union representing pilots at Republic Airlines has ratified a tentative agreement calling for a 15 percent pay cut and a wage freeze requested by the airline.

title: OPERA: TWO BY MENOTTI
description: BY twilight Monday a good crowd had found its way to Washington Market Park, a pleasant patch of green in the shadow of the World Trade Center. There, around a wooden gazebo that made the park seem to belong to Dayton, Ohio, 1903, rather than to New York City, 1983, two short operas by Gian-Carlo Menotti were performed as the sun set over the Hudson River.

title: FARM HOUSE FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to July 23
COSMOS SHOCKED IN PLAYOFF OPENER
description: The Montreal Manic, who had lost all four games they played against the Cosmos in the regular season, stunned the defending champions, 4-2, tonight in the opening game of their North American Soccer League playoff series.

title: A HELPING HAND FOR SALT-FREE DIETS
description: IN the past I have written about

title: SUN CITY INDUS reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid in July.

title: RIGHETTI DEFEATED ON SIMMONS TRIPLE
description: Dave Righetti sat slumped in front of his locker, silently stripping off his socks. When words finally came, his voice was angry.

title: ALVARADO SHUTS UNIT, CUTTING 30 JOBS
description: Anthony J. Alvarado, the New York City Schools Chancellor, said yesterday that he had phased out an 11-year- old office at the Board of Education, eliminating at least 30 jobs and saving the school system $2 million.

description: THE TROUBLED CRUSADE. American Education 1945-80. By Diane Ravitch. 384 pages. Basic. $19.95.

title: No Headline
description: Robert M. Fisher, who resigned as an executive of a steel company almost 10 years ago after contracting leukemia and then devoted his time to volunteer work for other cancer victims, died yesterday at the Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. He was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: City National Gets New Chief Allan T. Abess Jr. has been

title: U.S. MAKES DENIAL ON RC-135 PLANES
description: A spokesman for the Defense Department today denied a Soviet assertion that seven reconnaissance planes flew along the Soviet coastline on the day a Soviet fighter shot down a South Korean airliner.

title: Marcos Reassures Businessmen on Stability
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos told American and local businessmen today that the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. had not impaired the Government's stability.

title: YOUNG ADOPTEES IN SEARCH OF THEIR ROOTS
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM: SENEGALESE 'JOM'
description: ''Jom'' was shown as part of the 1983 New Directors/New Film Series. Following are excerpts from a review by Janet Maslin that appeared in The New York Times last March 28. The film opens today at the Film Forum 2, 57 Watts Street.

title: Smiles Curt in Geneva As Arms Talks Restart
description: United States and Soviet negotiators exchanged polite smiles and perfunctory greetings when they met today for the start of what is expected to be a decisive round in the talks on the reduction of intermediate-range nuclear missiles.

title: Holdup Man Given 25 Years For the Robbery of 7 Banks
description: A 29-year-old Bronx man convicted of robbing seven Chase Manhattan banks within a period of four weeks was sentenced yesterday to 25 years in prison.

title: EX-GENERAL DYNAMICS AIDES INDICTED
description: A Federal grand jury sitting in Manhattan indicted two former executives of the General Dynamics Corporation yesterday on charges they accepted $2.7 million in kickbacks, part of a $5 million embezzlement scheme involving General Dynamics and the now-defunct Frigitemp Corporation.

title: Vietnam Warns U.S. On Nicaragua Conflict
description: Vietnam's Foreign Minister, Nguyen Co Thach, said today that any United States intervention against Nicaragua could lead to a conflict similar to the Vietnam War.

title: No Headline
description: One former world champion regularly advises his partners: ''Never lead a trump.'' When necessary he amends this by adding, ''except when it's right.'' But when is it right?

title: FOR PERCY, QUESTIONS ON RUNNING FOR RE-ELECTION
description: Senator Charles H. Percy had barely bitten into his lamb chop Saturday night when the telephone rang in his mother's house in Wilmette, a suburb of Chicago. ''It's the White House,'' said his 91-year-old mother, Elisabeth.

title: New Zealand Tourism Does Without Pictures
description: The most familiar feature of destination-sponsored travel advertising - glorious four-color scenery - is completely missing from the latest creation done for the New Zealand Government Tourist Office by the San Francisco office of Dailey & Associates.

title: SAGE ENERGY COMPANY reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The 1982 net includes gain of about $7.3 million from the sale of the company's gas processing business.

title: ROBERT L. JONES
description: Robert L. Jones, senior vice president, resident counsel and secretary of Gulf and Western Industries Inc., died of a heart attack last Thursday in his office in Manhattan.

title: Warsaw Says 1,472 Were Seized in Protests
description: The Government said today that 1,472 people were seized by the police during last week's Solidarity ''rioting,'' but added that support for the outlawed union was on the wane.

title: OFFICIAL POLISH KINDNESS

title: REAGAN SAYS MARINES WILL REMAIN IN BEIRUT
description: The Reagan Administration affirmed its commitment today to keeping marines in Lebanon despite the killing of two more American troops.

description: Share earnings are restated to reflect a 20 percent stock dividend paid in July.

title: SHULTZ IS IN MADRID FOR TALKS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he would talk only about the South Korean airliner and Soviet human rights violations during his scheduled meeting with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko on Thursday.

title: DRUSE TAKE KEY MOUNTAIN TOWN AFTER HEAVY FIGHTING IN LEBANON
description: Syrian- backed Druse militiamen captured a key mountain town 10 miles east of here from Christian Phalangists after heavy fighting Tuesday.

description: The Soviet Union today protested to the United States over the storming of Soviet property in Glen Cove, L.I., by demonstrators angered over the downing of the Korean passenger plane.

description: Coleco Industries formally presented today the final version of its long-awaited home computer system and said it would sell for a somewhat higher price than analysts had been estimating.

title: Ghana Reported Ready To Reopen Togo Border
description: Ghana is ready to reopen its border with Togo, which was closed a year ago to prevent smuggling and currency trafficking, the Accra radio reported today.

title: No Headline
description: New Hope for New Jersey Drivers For years New Jersey drivers have had to pay the highest auto insurance rates in the nation because of a ''no-fault'' system whose main beneficiaries are lawyers. And for more than six years, the lawyers' lobby has managed to scuttle reforms in the Legislature. This year things seem different. A reform proposal met swift approval in the Assembly yesterday and stands an excellent chance of passing the Senate.

title: CATHOLIC SCHOOLS OPEN TODAY; LAY TEACHERS CONTINUING TALKS
description: Classes in schools of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York will begin today for 130,000 pupils despite contract disputes with two unions representing most lay teachers in the schools.

description: WHILE the Fifth Avenue of high fashion and fanciful prices does not reach down to 47th Street any more, the developers of a new combination office and retail building on the site of the old Korvettes department store at 575 Fifth Avenue hope to re-create something of its atmosphere there.

title: No Headline
description: The Citizen Astronauts Lacking a space station or other heavy construction project, America's space shuttle remains a marvel of technology without a serious mission. Challenger's flawless night landing again demonstrated the craft's prowess. It completed another round of equipment tests and launched another satellite. But these only furthered the impression that the craft is underemployed, ill suited to a severely scaled-back space program.

description: Q.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF RADIO TALK OF SOVIET PILOTS INVOLVED IN DOWNING AIRLINER
description: Following is a transcript of the conversations of Soviet pilots involved in the downing of Korean Air Lines Flight 7, as made public in translation by the White House today. The United States also showed a video tape to the United Nations Security Council in which the Russian-language conversations were on the audio portion and English and Russian transcriptions were on the video part.

title: RADICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BERRY IS DENIED INJUNCTION
description: A Federal judge refused last night to issue a pretrial ruling permitting Walter Berry to play for the St. John's basketball team in the coming season.

description: An elbow injury suffered on Sunday by the New England Patriots' tight end, Don Hasselbeck , has stalled a prospective trade that would have sent Hasselbeck to the Los Angeles Raiders in exchange for the Raiders' reserve tight end, Derrick Ramsey .

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Changes Due For Hospitals
description: HOSPITAL management companies, whose profits continued to climb during the recent recession, have turned in one of the stock market's best group performances in recent years. But concern over soaring Government spending for health care now has led to significant changes in Medicare reimbursement that promise to affect all hospitals.

title: Marine's Wife to Testify In Fraternization Trial
description: A Marine corporal agreed today to testify against her estranged husband, a Marine lieutenant who is being court-martialed for courting her.

title: 23.27 GAIN PUTS DOW AT 1,238.72
description: Stock prices rose sharply yesterday, buoyed by the growing conviction that interest rates would soon decline because of slowing growth in the nation's money supply.

title: 3D SPACE SHUTTLE BEING PREPARED AS WORKERS SERVICE CHALLENGER
description: As technicians serviced the space shuttle Challenger here after its six-day flight, workers at a nearby plant were putting the finishing touches on the third shuttle, the Discovery, which is set to be rolled out next month and to begin flying next year.

title: DArofHospital
description: Dr. Arnold A. Karan, former director of the Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center, died of a heart ailment yesterday at the Booth Memorial Medical Center in Flushing, Queens. He was 81 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Teachers Strike At Scotch Plains
description: A 360-member teachers' union went on strike here today but did not delay the first day of classes for 4,400 students in the Scotch Plains- Fanwood school district, officials said.

title: VIOLENCE AND BOXING
description: He says he could tell as soon as he climbed into the boxing ring that ''another of those things'' was about to happen. The man stretched out below him was going into spasmodic contractions, and his right pupil was bigger than his left.

title: WASHINGTON HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss The latest year net includes a tax benefit of $253,000, or 20 cents a share.

title: EXECUTIVES ;  EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Telephone and Telegraph International, Basking Ridge, N.J., has appointed Robert D. Dalziel vice president-operations.

title: BRITAIN'S UNIONISTS MOVE TO THE RIGHT
description: Struggling to halt an erosion in influence and power, leaders of British trade unions today gave the conservative wing of their troubled movement control of the governing council and authorized it to talk to the Government about proposed anti-union legislation.

title: New Concerns Raised On Three Mile Island
description: The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that it had new concerns about whether operators falsified valve leak rates for the undamaged reactor at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania.

title: PEP BOYS-MANNY, MOE & JACK reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings have been restated for a 3-for-1 stock split paid in April.

title: Article 147915 -- No Title
description: The World Wildlife Fund said today that it had donated $200,000 more to China's effort to save the endangered giant panda. A joint panda preservation project started in 1980 has received $2 million from China and a total of $1 million from the fund, which says that only about a thousand pandas remain in the wild in China.

title: BIG AFGHAN CLASH REPORTED BETWEEN 2 RULING FACTIONS
description: A simmering feud between two factions in Afghanistan's ruling Communist Party erupted in gunfire last month near the city of Herat and about 100 Afghan Army and police personnel were killed or wounded, a Western diplomat said today.

title: 2 Spies for Taiwan Put to Death, China Says
description: China said it executed two men today who had been working as spies for Taiwan.

title: A. T. Cross Co.
description: The A. T. Cross Company, a manufacturer of writing instruments that is based in Lincoln, R.I., said it planned to acquire closely held Mark Cross Inc. for an undisclosed amount of cash and notes.

title: FEDERAL BUYOUT OF TIMES BEACH, MO., BEGINS
description: For 8-year-old Angela Capstick, a Government buyout of dioxin-tainted Times Beach means paved streets to roller skate on and perhaps no more nightmares about men in white protective suits. For her parents, it means an end to payments on two houses and a chance to plan for the future.

title: NEW PROGRAM IN SHELTERS STRESSES WORK ETHIC
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that, in an effort to instill ''a work ethic'' in homeless New Yorkers, his administration was requiring residents of some shelters to peform odd jobs in exchange for their room and board and a small weekly stipend.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA AND MISS SHRIVER GAIN SEMIFINALS
description: Pam Shriver has again moved into Martina Navratilova's path in the United States Open tennis championships, this time in the semifinals of women's singles.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions

title: Cosby Buys Stake In Coke Bottling
description: The Coca-Cola Company said it had sold part of its stock in the Coca-Cola Bottling Company of New York to Bill Cosby, the entertainer. Terms were not disclosed.

description: Sale of Gold By Lisbon Seen

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Lloyd's Chairman Planning to Retire

title: CITY FIRE DEPT. TO GIVE 22 OF 34 WOMEN FULL STATUS
description: Twenty-two women, the first in New York City history, will be granted full status as firefighters at the end of their probationary periods this month, the Fire Department announced yesterday.

title: ROCK: HOLDSWORTH AND I.O.U.
description: ALLAN HOLDSWORTH, who led his band, I.O.U., on Monday at the Bottom Line, belongs in the highest rank of guitar virtuosos. His solos seem impossibly fast yet clean and smooth and articulate, zooming like a silver streak.

title: West German and Norwegian Sign a Pact to Build 18 Subs
description: West Germany and Norway signed an agreement here today to build 18 conventionally powered submarines to patrol NATO's northern seaboard.

description: WEDNESDAY, SEPT. 7, 1983

description: Close to Broadway, And Trying to Get Closer

title: WALLACE HOUSE
description: Wallace House, a former New York University professor of dramatic arts, died Friday at his home in Greenwich Village after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

title: A RIVALRY IN THE MAKING: MISS SHAFFER VS. DELBELLO
description: As Lieut. Gov. Alfred B. DelBello tries to establish a role for himself in the Cuomo administration, New York's Secretary of State, Gail S. Shaffer, is emerging as a rival for political influence.

title: 2 PAY-TV SERVICES MERGE
description: Two of the nation's leading pay- television services, Showtime and The Movie Channel, have been merged into a joint venture to be owned by Viacom International, Warner Communications and Warner Amex Cable Communications, it was announced yesterday.

title: PALMER AND ORIOLES DOWN RED SOX, 8-1
description: Eddie Murray and Rick Dempsey hit two-run homers to highlight a 12-hit attack tonight as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Boston Red Sox, 8-1.

title: No Headline
description: The United States, rejecting the newest statement from Moscow on the downed South Korean airliner, charged today that the Soviet Union ''continues to lie to the world'' even while acknowledging that a Soviet fighter shot the plane down.

title: SCOUTING
description: His School Gone, Player Survives

title: U.S. ENVOY IN SALVADOR DISCOUNTS REBEL RAID
description: The new United States Ambassador to El Salvador said today that he did not see the recent guerrilla attack on the country's third largest city as a setback in efforts to reach a political settlement to the country's civil war.

title: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1983 International
description: The Soviet Union acknowledged for the first time that a South Korean airliner carrying 269 people was shot down on Sept. 1. The Soviet Government said that a Soviet fighter was ordered ''to stop the flight'' of the Boeing 747 over Sakhalin Island after the airliner failed to obey the fighter's demands that it land at a Soviet airfield. (Page A1, Column 6.) A 60-day ban on flights to Moscow in protest over the shooting down of the Korean airliner was called by leaders of a professional organization representing most of the world's commercial airline pilots. The call by the governing board of the 57,000-member International Federation of Air Line Pilots Associations could bring about ''the complete civil aviation isolation of Moscow'' by airlines operating in the non-Communist world, according to the deputy president of the organization. (A1:3-4.)

description: The Peronists, Argentina's largest political party, overwhelmingly nominated former Senate President Italo A. Luder early today as the party's presidential candidate.

Lesotho Asks for Food
description: Lesotho has asked other countries in the Commonwealth to increase their food aid to prevent mass starvation in areas of the country where drought has devastated the cattle and crops, the Tanzanian Government newspaper Daily News reported today. The request came at the opening session of a Commonwealth conference being held in northern Tanzania.

title: AN EAST GERMAN WRITER AND THE WALL OF SILENCE
description: In a small house in the woods outside East Berlin, a noted German author and former American citizen writes busily for a public that is forbidden to read his latest books.

title: GUATEMALAN ARMY REPORTED DIVIDED
description: Four weeks after the Guatemalan Defense Minister seized power, the political situation remains highly unstable, according to Guatemalans and Western diplomats.

Year-ago results have been restated.

title: HISPANIC OVERCOUNT FOUND IN CENSUS
description: According to the Census Bureau, there are 374 Hispanic people in Panola County, a sparsely settled place of small towns, farms, lakes and woods 50 miles south of Memphis.

title: Mitsui Engine
description: Mitsui & Company said it had been licensed to produce and market everywhere except in North America and Western Europe a small, direct-injection diesel engine that can run on vegetable oil. Mitsui said the engine uses 25 percent less fuel than a conventional diesel engine, does not need a radiator or fan, and is suitable for use in cars and agricultural and construction machinery. It said it had acquired the license from Elko Lizenz G.m.b.H., a West German research institute.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WINE AND SONG The City Opera strike is finally over and the Metropolitan Opera is revving up for its 100th season, but there won't be any singing at Lincoln Center until later this month. Therefore, anybody with a craving for some immediate opera - albeit on a smaller scale - may wish to head downtown tonight for an amusing alternative when the landmark Greenwich Village restaurant Asti, 13 East 12th Street, will reopen after summer refurbishment.

title: KEAN OFFERS PLAN TO IMPROVE EDUCATION
description: Warning that New Jersey's education system is producing a generation of educationally deprived students, Governor Kean today proposed broad changes that he said would attract and hold better teachers, improve classroom discipline and set higher standards for students.

description: Keeping Course

title: MARATHON OFFICE SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: TV: 'WHEN WOMEN KILL,' ON HBO
description: ''WHEN WOMEN KILL,'' a new documentary made for Home Box Office, could have been called, just as easily, and perhaps more properly, ''Why Women Kill.'' Women's victims, Lee Grant, the production's narrator, says, ''are almost always someone they once loved.'' By implication, the victims are males, most of whom, the documentary suggests, are responsible for their own deaths. In some cases, however, males persuade women to kill other people for them. The one-hour documentary will be seen at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: No Headline
description: Sounders

title: BECKWITH PARTNER GETS 25-YEAR JAIL TERM
description: Edward P. Wolfram Jr., formerly the managing partner of the now- bankrupt Bell & Beckwith stock brokerage house, was sentenced yesterday in Toledo, Ohio, to 25 years in prison for violating Federal securities laws.

description: Shearson/American Express Inc. has asked a 71-year-old man who invested his savings in tax-exempt bonds issued by the Washington Public Power Supply System to sign a letter accepting responsibility for the purchase.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: WE are not about to let a summer go by without an egg cream story. On second thought, make that two egg cream stories - they're small. Our first story comes from Craig Minor, who was walking on West 44th Street the other day when a craving for the native drink overcame him. Spotting a soda fountain, he entered and said, ''An egg cream, please.''

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: MOST wines improve with age but, alas, most people do not. Beset by a variety of infirmities and indignities, stripped of a sense of purpose and the pleasures of youth, no longer respected and sought after, many older people wonder if living to a ripe old age is worth it after all. And seeing the poor quality of life among the nation's elderly no doubt prompts many young people to live for today without regard for what it may mean to their old age.

title: AT THE OPEN, TENNIS FANS DRESS THE PART
description: YOU can spot them at the United States Open in Flushing Meadows, wearing the latest in Fila, Ellesse and other tennis togs, and padding around in thick-soled tennis shoes. A tennis neophyte might mistake them for the players. But no, they are the spectators.
