title: MOSCOW'S BEST CELLAR LIST
description: The Fourth International Book Fair is open in Moscow. As a veteran of the first two fairs, I deserve, like a war veteran, a medal of honor and a free pass to the Moscow subway. I was escorted to the first two fairs by two dozen K.G.B. agents. This made me feel like a very important and dangerous dignitary. They wouldn't let me forget that Soviet writers, unlike writers in other countries, are very well cared for by the state.

description: ''THE LAST FIGHT,'' which opens today at the National and other theaters, is a movie about boxing, set in New York and scored with a Latin beat. It stars the Latin music personalities Ruben Blades and Willie Colon as, respectively, a salsa singer-boxer and the Latin hood who sells the boxer out to the mob.

title: Dr.JohnA.SoursDiesat52; Supervised Psychiatric Unit

title: DRIVE BY N.A.A.C.P. GETS MIXED RESULTS
description: A program to demonstrate the economic power of black Americans by having them make purchases with $2 bills and Susan B. Anthony dollars has produced mixed results, according to reports from banks and merchants around the nation.

title: Economic SceneVictor R. Fuchs Divorce Rate's Fiscal Impact
description: Victor R. Fuchs is professor of economics at Stanford University and a research associate at the National Bureau of Economic Research. Leonard Silk is on special assignment. SOARING divorce rates, dramatically altering the circumstances under which millions of children are raised, have contributed to the economic problems of society. During the last 20 years 19 million children under age 18 saw their parents divorced. Despite a high remarriage rate, the rise in divorce, plus an increase in the proportion of births to unwed mothers, means one-parent homes for nearly one in four children.

title: VERMONT BREWERS GATHER FOR A CONTEST
description: The 85-degree Labor Day heat suited several dozen of Vermont's best home-brewers as they gathered here for the third annual Vermont Home-Brew Competition.

description: An 89- unit housing project that will be built for low- to middle-income families in a depressed area of Newark is ''a seed from which many other good things will happen,'' Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson said today.

title: CONRAIL'S BOXCAR PLAN
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation announced yesterday that it would cut by 20 percent the rates it charged other railroads to rent its boxcars and would pay incentives of $50 a car to customers who filled empty boxcars that moved over the Conrail system.

title: Luci Johnson Plans Marriage to Banker
description: Luci Baines Johnson said today that she was engaged to Ian Turpin, a British banker on Grand Cayman Island in the British West Indies, and was to be married late this year or in early 1984.

title: FLOWER TIME reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
WINE TALK
description: ARECENT column in this space included some highly critical remarks about several so-called hybrid wines from the Finger Lakes region of New York State. Some readers interpreted those lines as a blanket condemnation of New York wines, which they were not. Indeed, in that same judging, which took place at the School of Hotel Administration at Cornell University, there were several excellent wines. For the most part they were made from vinifera grapes, but there were a couple of hybrid whites of outstanding quality as well.

title: BIG DRUG OPERATION IN NORTH CALIFORNIA IS BROKEN UP BY U.S.
description: Federal officials announced here today that they had cut off a major drug route into San Francisco. Ten people were arrested on Federal drug smuggling charges and 134 pounds of cocaine was seized by law-enforcement officers in the past four days, the officials said.

title: Russian Vodka Barred
description: The New Hampshire Liquor Commission voted unanimously today to stop selling Russian vodka at state liquor stores. The 3-0 vote was to protest the Soviet Union's downing of a South Korean airliner last week.

title: No Headline
description: From Lies to Remedies The Soviet leaders have managed to turn one night of reckless aerial murder into a prolonged and ugly flight from responsibility. They are conceding facts that they have known for days only as the evidence shoots down their original lies. They will regret this destruction of their new leader's credibility even more than they undoubtedly regret their air force's stupidity. They should quit trying to justify the unjustifiable and purge their consciences instead by joining other nations in constructive remedial action.

title: North Sea Well Capped
description: A group including a Dow Chemical Company subsidiary has plugged and abandoned its first well in an area of the North Sea east of the Shetland Islands, Sovereign Oil and Gas P.L.C., operator of the well, said today.

title: ROBBER WOUNDS A RESTAURATER ON EAST SIDE
description: An owner of Truffles Cafe at 696 Madison Avenue, near 62d Street, was shot and critically wounded in an attempted robbery by two gunmen early yesterday.

title: U.S., Japan Plan Oil Talk
description: United States and Japanese officials will meet in Anchorage for two days of talks in the middle of this month on possible sales to Japan of Alaskan crude oil, officials of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

title: SHIRLEY PHILLIPS COWAN
description: Shirley Phillips Cowan, who served for 21 years as the director of the Lexington Houses Children's Center, a Manhattan day-care facility, died of a pulmonary obstruction Sunday at her summer home in Heritage Village in Southbury, Conn. She was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CHRISTINE CRAFT: REPORTER OR SYMBOL OR BOTH?

description: In four hours on any given Wednesday, Michael Alexander can turn 10,000 pounds of lettuce into 2,000 pounds each of melons, tomatoes, plums, radishes and English muffins.

title: Share Sold in Fiat Unit
description: Italfinanziaria Immobiliare, a unit of the Istituto Mobiliare Italiano banking group, has acquired a 10 percent stake in Comau S.p.A., a Fiat subsidiary specializing in automated production systems, Fiat said in a statement today. A United States company, Allied Bendix, already holds an interest in Comau.

title: E.E.C. Production Slips
description: Industrial production in the European Economic Community dipped four-tenths of 1 percent in June from May, and fell 1.8 percent from the period a year earlier, Eurostat reported today.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Interest Rates Rise Slightly
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday for short-term and long-term securities.

title: Pargas Ends Pact On Its Acquisition
description: Pargas Inc. said it would not be acquired by Forstmann Little & Company under terms of an agreement announced in March. Pargas added, however, that talks were continuing with Forstman Little, a private New York investment firm specializing in leveraged buyout transactions.

title: SCOPE INDUS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,737,250. c-After an extraordinary credit of $22,391,178.

title: Soviet Aide in Ottawa Says Tapes Could Be 2 Years Old
description: A Soviet Embassy official said today that tapes played by President Reagan on Monday and offered as proof that a Soviet fighter shot down a South Korean airliner could have been made two years ago.

title: THE POLITICS OF FEAR
description: The tragedy of the downed South Korean airliner is a reminder of the politics of fear. We are not likely to be told by the Soviet Union why these 269 lives were lost, for it is obviously terrified of the truth. Fear plays a larger part in the struggle for power and security than is generally realized. Throughout history in wars over religion, the dogmatic clash of dreams for eternal life, the fears and whisperings of contending theologies and personalities led to more and more conflicts and atrocities.

title: Each Alaskan to Get $386.15 From Oil Fund
description: In most states people pay income taxes and are lucky to get refunds.

title: AMTRAK'S STRATEGY FOR NEW AUTO TRAIN
description: Amtrak, the federally subsidized national passenger railroad system, thinks it can succeed where private enterprise did not. On Oct. 30, it will revive Auto Train service between Lorton, Va., outside Washington, and Sanford, Fla., near Orlando.

title: POTEMKIN, '83 STYLE
description: In just six years, the Soviet Union has unmistakably demonstrated that a totalitarian state cannot hold a legitimate international book fair.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Sports World Specials column in SportsMonday this week gave an incorrect date for the New York Knicks' ceremonies marking the retirement of Bill Bradley's uniform number. It is Saturday night, Oct. 29.

title: TO KEEP TROOPS IN LEBANON
description: The Reagan Administration needs broad national support if it is to continue to keep United States marines in the multinational force in Lebanon. Unfortunately, President Reagan has thus far not reported to the Congress under the relevant section of the War Powers Resolution. This is a mistake.

title: CAVENHAM (USA) INC reports earnings for 16 wks to July 23
description: b-Including a gain of $1,952,000 on the exchange of debentures and a tax credit of $3,263,000. c-Including a tax credit of $1,170,000.

title: CITY RETAIL SALES RISE SLIGHT 5.6%
description: For the second consecutive month, retail sales in New York City were soft in August, averaging only 5.6 percent above the depressed month a year earlier, a spot-check yesterday showed. The performance reflected a sharp slowing from the double-digit increases registered in May and June.

title: WEINBERGER ON LATIN TOUR, AFFIRMS 'BASIC' U.S. POLICIES
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger began a three-day tour of Central America today, saying he wanted to reaffirm United States policy in the region and see its problems first hand.

title: Venezuela Debt Relief
description: Venezuela will request a new three-month moratorium on the payment of about $18 billion in short-term debt owed to foreign creditors, Government sources said today.

title: PRIDE HELPED COWBOYS IN 2-D HALF RALLY
description: The Dallas Cowboys had been behind at the half before, of course, but according to their public-relations department, not by as much since the eighth game of their first year in the National Football League, 1960. In that game, the Green Bay Packers were leading, 27-0, on the way to a 41-0 victory, and the Cowboys were on their way to an 0-11-1 season.

title: A LOT RIDES ON A GOOD NAME
description: To most people, the board game Monopoly is nothing more than a pleasant diversion. But for executives at the Nestle Company and many other consumer products concerns, a lot more than $200 for passing Go has been riding on the well-known Parker Brothers game.

title: No Headline
description: Steel Output Down By 0.6% By The Associated Press Steel production fell to 1.614

title: Cities Service President Is an Exploration Man
description: For about 14 years, David A. Hentschel, executive vice president of the Cities Service Oil and Gas Corporation, has finished his day at the office with a run of six or seven miles. Now Mr. Hentschel has been promoted to a new starting line, the presidency of Cities Service, which has been owned by the Occidental Petroleum Corporation since last November.

title: ADVERTISING
description: People

title: INTERNATIONAL PILOTS' GROUP ASKS 60-DAY BAN ON FLIGHTS TO MOSCOW
description: Leaders of a professional organization representing most of the world's commercial airline pilots called on their 57,000 members today to join a 60-day ban on flights to Moscow in protest over the shooting down of a South Korean airliner by Soviet jets.

title: BECK, EX-UNIONIST, STILL BATTLING AT 89
description: The voice rasps. The ice-blue eyes flash. The small fist thumps the lectern. A harangue by Dave Beck, president of the teamsters' union 30 years ago, can still shake the rafters.

title: COOKING SCHOOLS: HOW TO CHOOSE THE RIGHT ONE
description: 2d SUB COOKLIST-A - C6 A la Bonne Cocotte, 23 Eighth Avenue,

title: THE LAFAYETTE ESCADRILLE AND ITS 'RINGERS'
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTO SALES HELD BACK BY DROP IN INVENTORIES
description: Sales for the nation's Big Three auto makers rose a slight 13.1 percent in the Aug. 21-31 period, the companies reported today, with dealers unable to fill some orders because of drastically low inventories.

title: Richardson Goes Home
description: The Nets' guard Michael Ray Richardson has been released from the Hazelton Hospital, just outside Minneapolis, where he was undergoing further treatment for depression and cocaine abuse.

title: Battery Park Chief May Be Replaced
description: While his staff searches for a new chairman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Governor Cuomo said yesterday that he wanted to replace the head of another public authority.

title: Mead Plans Fund
description: The Mead Corporation said it would begin offering Corporate Cash Management Fund Inc. as a no-load, open-end investment fund through its Mead Money Management Marketing Corporation unit. Mead said the fund's assets would be invested in high-yield adjustable-rate preferred stocks that qualify for 85 percent dividend-received tax deductions. The maximum tax rate on dividends received would be 6.9 percent, it said.

title: FIRST COMMERCIAL BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: FIGT TO PUBLIC: GUTHRIE DAYS IN NORTHWEST
description: IN May 1941, the Bonneville

title: BANK ACQUISITION IN SOUTH CAROLINA
description: The South Carolina National Corporation will acquire the First Bankshares Corporation of South Carolina in a stock transaction valued at $118 million, the companies said yesterday.

title: Half of Bad Rails On Subway Fixed
description: Almost half the 582 places in the subway system where tracks are badly worn or loose have been repaired, the acting president of the Transit Authority said yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: Basic Resources Corp. said it had completed the acquisition of R. J. Brown & Associates, a Swiss company specializing in engineering and construction management of offshore pipeline systems, for $12.8 million in cash plus additional deferred and contingent payments annually from 1984 to 1991.

title: Coastal Buyback
description: The Coastal Corporation said it would reinstitute its program to repurchase periodically up to 2 million shares of its common stock on the open market.

title: NEW RAID ON CHAD OUPOST IS REPORTED
description: Chad's Information Minister said today that a large Libyan-supported anti-Government force, backed by tanks and artillery but not by planes, had attacked a Government outpost in eastern Chad for the second time in five days.

title: IN A TINY CHAD VILLAGE, DROUGHT ECLIPSES WAR
description: In the wilting heat of afternoon, the chief of this village sat on a grass mat in the shade of a scrawny tree, shaving the head of his 5-year-old son, the youngest of 11 children.

title: RIVIERS'S ICE CREAM GUERRILLA FIGHTS ON
description: -TROPEZ, France

title: Eugene McCarthy in Hospital After Suffering Heart Attack
description: Former Senator Eugene McCarthy of Minnesota was reported in fair condition tonight at a hospital here after suffering a heart attack.

title: SCOT FRANK'S DIAL-A-FIGHT CHALLENGE
description: The neighbors in Scott Frank's hometown, Oakland, N.J., are probably not surprised. This is just a logical extension of the days when he was in high school and would hold boxing matches in the basement of his parents' home. Not only was he the matchmaker and the promoter of those Saturday afternoon main events, but Frank was also fighting in them. And, from the fistic and financial success he had, it became clear that he was going to become either a boxer of some stature or another Don King.

title: SCOUTING
description: The Good News

title: Lloyd Quits Coaching
description: Dan Lloyd , the former Giants linebacker who returned to professional football after winning a two-year battle with cancer, has left as an assistant coach at William Paterson College three weeks after he was hired. Lloyd left over the weekend by mutual agreement with Coach John Crea of William Paterson. ''Dan and I are both sorry things didn't work out,'' said Crea.

title: SYNTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The year-ago results reflect a 2-for- 1 stock split effective Feb. 19, 1982. The fiscal 1983 results reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No. 52 regarding foreign currency translations.

title: MEDICAL SCHOOL IS A TARGET AGAIN
description: The Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences, the nation's only medical school for military doctors, lies on 100 acres of tree-studded land at the Naval Medical Center in suburban Bethesda, Md. But behind the placid facade, the atmosphere is tense these days in the wake of two strong attacks on the school's programs.

title: INEXPENSIVE MANDOLINE
description: FOOD processors are marvelous for slicing and chopping large quantities of vegetables, but when it comes to more intricate work, such as making french fries, latticed potato slices (called pommes gaufrettes) or shoestring- thin julienned zucchini strips, a simple, nonmechanized device called a mandoline outperforms its electric cousins.

title: HELIX CIRCUITS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MRS. KAYE APPROVED FOR TOP COURT
description: Judith S. Kaye, saying she wanted to be judged solely on the quality of her jurisprudence, was confirmed by the Senate today as the first woman to serve on the state's highest court.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies , at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Walt Terrell, who this season has eight runs batted in and seven hits, including three home runs, tries to play the spoiler's role against the Phillies and John Denny.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar 's agent said Tuesday the free-agent center had ''basically'' agreed to a two-year contract with the Los Angeles Lakers. The details were yet to be ironed out, but Tom Collins said, ''Basically, it's done.

title: Debt Issues
description: * The European Economic Community is issuing $100 million of 10- year Eurobonds with 12 percent coupons, through Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd. The price of the bonds will be fixed by Friday between 99.5 and par.

title: Greece and U.S. Set To Sign Accord Today
description: Greece and the United States will sign a five-year defense and economic cooperation agreement here today. The accord was initialed in July after eight months of negotiations and covers the continued presence of United States bases in Greece as well as military aid.

title: HERS
description: LATELY I have been observing a cruel, almost combative hostility toward children that amounts to a new ''cult of toughness.'' I first noticed it in 1979 when the United Nations International Year of the Child - a global campaign to end poverty and provide health and human rights to all children - was attacked by a number of groups, including Americans Against Abortion, which called it ''an intense propaganda campaign to 'liberate' children from their parents.'' The suggestion was that the millions of starving children were merely rebellious little brats who deserved no help at all.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''We state: 'Soviet territory, the borders of the Soviet Union are sacred.'

title: Fruehauf Trucks
description: The Fruehauf Corporation said its Fruehauf International Ltd. division had signed a five-year license agreement with KOC Holding A.S. of Turkey, which gives KOC the right to manufacture and market a broad range of Fruehauf truck-trailer products in Turkey.

title: LANPAR TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JACKSON'S SUCCESSOR IN THE SENATE TO BE CHOSEN FROM OPEN BALLOT
description: A successor to serve the five years remaining in the term of Senator Henry M. Jackson, who died last Thursday, must be picked by Washington's voters on Nov. 8, the State Attorney General has ruled.

title: KOCH PROPOSES SHIFT IN CONEY I. HOUSING
description: Low-income workers would get preference over welfare recipients in applying for apartments at certain Coney Island housing projects under a plan proposed yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: ISRAELIS FLEXIBLE ON PULLOUT, ARENS HINTS
description: Defense Minister Moshe Arens today redefined Israel's conditions for withdrawing from Lebanon, saying that even if Syrian troops remained, the Israelis might leave the western and central sectors once the Lebanese Army or local militias could police the territory.

title: The Beaumont Darkness
description: The board that manages New York's Lincoln Center is slow to anger, but when finally aroused it is decisive. It recently stripped the center's theatrical unit, the Lincoln Center Theater Company, of its official name and deprived it of Lincoln Center funds. The board normally avoids interference with the artistic policies of its constituents, but this action hardly violates the tradition. The drama group, informally known as the Vivian Beaumont Theater - after the building it occupies - has no visible artistic policies.

title: PUEBLO INTERNATONAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-After tax credits of $266,000 for the quarter and $462,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $372,000 for the quarter and $656,000 for the 6 months. The 1982 quarter sales and net income figures include sales of $11,722,000 and net of $551,000, or 14 cents a share, for the operations that were sold. The 1982 six-month figures include sales of $21,117,000 and net income of $584,000, or 15 cents a share, for operations that were sold.

title: Egyptian Official Calls Ties With Israelis a 'Cold Peace'
description: Egypt's Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Boutros Ghali, described relations with Israel as ''cold peace'' today and said that no Egyptian minister would visit Israel in the near future.

title: G.M. to Market A Suzuki Model
description: The Suzuki Motor Company has introduced its new minicar, which it hopes to use to establish a foothold in the United States next year with the help of the General Motors Corporation.

title: AN AFTER-SCHOOL PROGRAM
description: HERE is a sampling of after school activities available in Manhattan for children of kindergarten age and up. They are open to both sexes. In some listings the activities are representative but by no means inclusive. SCHOOLS

title: Angola Rebels Report String of Successes
description: Pro-Western guerrillas fighting the Angolan Government said their forces captured 27 Spaniards, Brazilians and Portuguese in a raid Monday, according to a statement here today.

title: WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results for the latest quarter and year include operations of Tops Business Forms Inc. which was acquired in February and accounted for as a pooling of interests. The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid May 1983.

title: Police in Pakistan Break up An Anti-Government Protest
description: Policemen today used tear gas and truncheons and arrested about 60 demonstrators in breaking up an anti- Government rally by several thousand people in the southern Pakistan town of Hyderabad, opposition sources said.

title: China Oil Accord Seen
description: Britain's Cluff Oil P.L.C. is expected to sign an offshore oil exploration and development contract with China early next month, industry sources said today. It would be the first British company to perform such explorations on its own.

title: British Union Chiefs Bar Political Strikes
description: In a setback for left-wingers, Britain's labor union leaders voted today against political strikes.

title: THE SCREEN: 'REVENGE OF THE NINJA'
description: BEGINNING yesterday, anyone proffering $5 at the ticket windows of the RKO Warner Twin and some other local theaters could purchase transport to a community where the deadly medieval Japanese art of the ninja clashes with the modern methods of the Mafia - namely Salt Lake City.

title: CLARK CONSOLIDATED reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Laxalt Planning Committee For Reagan Re-Election Bid
description: Senator Paul Laxalt says he will file papers to form a re-election committee for President Reagan next month unless Mr. Reagan ''has some strong, specific objection.''

title: GOSSAGE THWARTS RALLY BY BREWERS
description: Rich Gossage faced more than the tying run at the plate when he came onto the mound tonight with no outs in the eighth inning. Hanging over him was the fact that the Yankees twice led the Brewers by seven runs and should never have been in a situation where late-inning heroics were necessary.

title: Reagan on Jewish New Year
description: President Reagan extended his greetings today to Jews celebrating the High Holy Days, which began with Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish new year, at sundown today.

title: GENERAL KINETICS reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $21,789.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK
description: WHILE many American actors are able to imitate the English, nothing seems to defeat English actors more than assuming American accents. They flatten their vowels, stretch their diphthongs and end up affecting a kind of mid-Atlantic drawl. If they are called upon to do urban speech, it invariably comes out dese-and-dose, regardless of the city or the period.

title: Hitachi and Sanyo Set Europe Plans
description: Hitachi Ltd. and the Sanyo Electric Company said they would start production of videotape recorders in Europe in October. Sanyo plans to produce the recorders at its color TV plant in Britain, while Hitachi will use a West German plant.

title: ARGUELLO FIGHTS HISTORY SECOND TIME AROUND
description: History is not on Alexis Arg"uello's side. Friday night, he will try to forget the terrible beating he took 10 months ago and challenge Aaron Pryor once again for the World Boxing Association junior welterweight title.

title: BERKSHIRE GAS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SOVIET SAYS WORLD OPINION IS ON ITS SIDE
description: The Soviet Union stood firm today in its defense of a Soviet fighter pilot's action in shooting down a South Korean airliner and maintained that world opinion and international law were strongly on its side.

title: People
description: * James E. Murphy has been appointed vice president for corporate communications at Merrill Lynch & Co.

title: PROVEN TOOL IN THE MAKING OF HOMEOWNERS
description: To the Editor:

title: BLACK IS RETIRED IN A POLICE DEATH
description: The retrial of a young black man accused of killing a Charleston County policeman and wounding another began Tuesday, with pickets outside the courtroom and an undercurrent of racial tension.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: BRIEFING
description: A Matter of Timing

title: JAPAN'S CIVIL RADAR TOO FAR AWAY TO PICK UP 747
description: The Japanese civil radar installation that is closest to the area where the South Korean airliner was shot down last week was never within range to pick up the plane on its radar scopes.

title: Required Reading; 'A Pleasant Place'
description: It is a pleasant place, despite the testimony of politicians. President Kennedy once said that Washington was a city of Southern efficiency and Northern charm. Like many things said about the capital, this was a handy way of separating the speaker from the subject. Every Presidential candidate since John Quincy Adams has pretended to an aversion to Washington. People who are running hard toward Washington find it expedient to pretend that they are running away from it, or, in fact, against it.

title: KOREAN JETLINER: WHAT IS KNOWN AND WHAT ISN'T
description: A week after a South Korean 747 airliner took off from Kennedy International Airport on a journey that was ended by a Soviet air-to-air missile, there are many unanswered questions.

title: AMEX CARVING A NEW NICHE
description: In the mid-1960's, the American Stock Exchange was the place to go for market action. At one point, trading got so heated that the president of the exchange issued a statement warning against excessive speculation in Amex stocks.

title: CONNECTICUT CHOICE OF 'PARTY POTENTATES'
description: To the Editor:

title: Maulers Pick Boisture
description: Dave Boisture , a reserve quarterback for the New Jersey Generals, was drafted by the Pittsburgh Maulers yesterday as the six expansion clubs of the United States Football League picked the final 24 players in the 144-player allocation draft.

title: ARCHITECTURE: CARNEGIE HALL RESTORATION, PHASE 1
description: THE facade of Carnegie Hall, which has changed almost constantly in its 92 years of existence, this week looks a little more the way it did in 1891. The reason is that the initial phase of a continuing $20 million restoration of the hall has just been completed, and it offers the first evidence of what architectural direction the major reconstruction of Carnegie Hall - a project that will not be finished until the building's centennial in 1991 - will take.

title: TIDES ELIMINATE CLIPPERS
description: The Tidewater Tides, the Mets' top farm club, advanced to the final round of the International League playoffs tonight with a 13-1 victory over the Columbus Clippers, the Yankee farm team that had won the league's regular-season championship.

title: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The bank is listed on the Montreal, Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: GROMYKO DEFENDS ACTIONS OF SOVIET IN PLANE INCIDENT
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union, staunchly defending his Government's actions, today repeated the Soviet contention that the United States was ultimately responsible for the loss of the Korean Air Lines Boeing 747 in Soviet airspace on Sept. 1. Speaking at a session of Eastern and Western foreign ministers here, Mr. Gromyko said Soviet borders were inviolable. He said that the South Korean airliner, which was shot down by a Soviet fighter, had been spying for the United States and that Washington had ''unleashed a wave of slander'' and ''falsehood'' over the incident.

title: FLORIDA UTILITY WILL REPLACE TRANSFORMERS MADE WITH TOXIC PCB'S
description: As a result of accidents in New York and California, the Florida Power and Light Company plans to spend more than $15 million in south Florida over five years to replace hundreds of transformers containing insulation made with toxic PCB's, the company has announced.

title: MONARCH AVALON reports earnings for Qtr to JuLY 31
Company Admits Waste Violation
description: A Long Island company has pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court to a charge of unlawful possession of first-degree hazardous waste, according to the State Environmental Conservation Department.

title: U.S. DENIES HAVING SOVIET GROUND-STATION TAPES
description: The White House said today that, contrary to earlier statements, the United States did not have any tapes of radio transmissions from Soviet ground control stations to the pilots of two Soviet fighter planes involved in the shooting down of a South Korean airliner last week.

title: AGING RELATIVES: HELP FOR FAMILIES
description: AS the country's over-65 population has grown, more and more families face a longterm responsibility for the care of their own elderly. Particularly when aged parents are disabled, the demands of providing physical, emotional and financial support can be overwhelming.

title: Things Are Up in the Air At a Noontime Workshop
description: CIn Bryant Park, 30 people looked heavenward yesterday while juggling balls, Indian clubs and beanbags.

title: SWEDISH CHARM
description: THEY came to New York for a short but busy visit. Pierre Munkeborg, above right, Christer Rosenholtz, above center, and Hans Ornback of Scandinavian Furniture borrowed an uptown space to show over 150 pieces of Swedish furniture - most of which are of pine and date from 1880 to 1900.

title: Bank Rates Are Steady
description: Interest rates by major banks for money market deposit accounts remained at the same level as last week, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.

title: STICKS AND STONES
description: A U.S. President, in response to the Soviet massacre of 61 U.S. citizens traveling under the protection of U.S. passports, has sounded off more fiercely than Theodore Roosevelt and has acted more pusillanimously than Jimmy Carter.

title: CABLE TV FRANCHISES: CHICAGO'S EXAMPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-SHERIFF'S DEPUTY DENIES INMATE TORTURES
description: A former San Jacinto County sheriff's deputy accused of taking part in the water torture of prisoners told a jury today that he never saw any such thing happen.

title: CORRECTION
description: An art review in Weekend last Friday of ''Twentieth Century Masters: The Thyssen-Bornemisza Collection'' incorrectly identified the organizer of the show. The exhibition and its tour were organized by the International Exhibitions Foundation of Washington, D.C.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: CLOTHING OF AFRICA
description: African Textiles as Clothing, American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street, 873-4225. On Sunday at 2 P.M. Sylvia A. Boone, a Yale professor of art history, will present a slide lecture on African textiles, discussing the color, texture, cut and drapery found in various regions. The lecture will be in the Kaufmann Theater on the first floor.

title: 3 DEATHS SINCE 1981 IN SAME APARTMENT SET OFF INVESTIGATION
description: Early last Friday, Sarah G. McHale, a 68-year-old widow, was suffocated by an intruder in her living room in Apartment 31 in a quiet garden apartment complex here.

title: JIFFY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to July 31
Interest Rates Drop Broadly
description: Interest rates declined in all sectors of the credit markets yesterday. Government securities dealers said there was a growing perception that money supply growth may continue to be slower than expected, thereby allowing the Federal Reserve to encourage stable to lower short-term interest rates.

title: JULY-AUGUST U.S. CURRENCY AID SMALL
description: Total intervention by the United States Government in the foreign exchange markets in late July and early August came to $254.1 million, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York disclosed yesterday.

title: THURSDAY, SEPT. 8, 1983
description: Companies

title: 12% Kaneb Issue
description: A $30 million issue of Kaneb Services Inc. adjustable rate preferred stock was offered through Salomon Brothers Inc. with an initial dividend rate of 12 percent and a price of $100 a share. After Dec. 31, the dividend on the Baa-3-rated preferred stock will be reset quarterly at a rate equal to the higher of the bond equivalent yield for 3-month Treasury bills, 10- year Treasury notes and 20-year Treasury bonds.

title: An Esmark Executive Will Manage Halston
description: A longtime executive at International Playtex, the underwear unit of Esmark Inc., has been named to head Halston Enterprises, the designer apparel maker just acquired by Esmark.

title: An Unusual Issue For Consolidated
description: The Consolidated Foods Corporation announced plans late last week for an innovative issue of convertible adjustable preferred stock with a face value of $75 million. According to John Erdman, a principal at Morgan Stanley & Company, the investment banker for the issue, the issue would be the first of its kind.

title: CHAD SAYS IT STOPPED REBELS
description: Chad's Information Minister said today that the eastern oasis area of Oum Chalouba was ''calm and effectively under Government control'' after a victory over a Libyan-supported rebel force on Tuesday.

title: Wyeth Buyer Gets 5 Years
description: Guido Frezzo, a wealthy mushroom grower, was sentenced to five years in prison and fined $20,000 Tuesday for buying three paintings stolen from the artist Andrew Wyeth. Mr. Frezzo, 52 years old, of Avondale, admitted giving two burglars a 1957 Chevrolet and $2,000 for three of 15 paintings stolen from the Wyeth estate in Chadds Ford, Pa., on March 27, 1982.

title: POSTPONE THE VISIT TO MANILA
description: For three years, Benigno S. Aquino Jr. and his family found sanctuary in our country. Americans are proud that he lived among us. We will never forget his humanity, his courage and his commitment to democracy. In life and in death, he deepened the historic bond between the United States and the Philippines.

title: Barbarity in the Ring
description: In a desperate effort to save the life of Francisco (Kiko) Bejines, the 20-year-old Mexican fighter who collapsed during a match in California last week, neurosurgeons cut out part of his brain and skull and removed a blood clot. It was a dangerous operation made necessary by a dangerous sport.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Two years ago we built a wood deck on a concrete slab below. The flooring is tongue-and-groove plywood covered with deck paint. Water keeps coming through the joints so we tried to seal the seams with epoxy. This has not done the job. The floor is still leaking and the plywood is splitting and cracking badly. Is there anything we can do? onfused about what you

title: FAILURES OF COMMON SENSE; Unlicensed
description: An appellate court in Manhattan has ruled, 3 to 2, that William R. Frye, though a distinguished journalist and lecturer, was not a ''professional'' who qualifies for the former exemption from New York's unincorporated business tax. Accountants are, and shorthand reporters, but not Mr. Frye.

title: ORGANIZE TO FIGHT PROTESTERS, PINOCHET AIDE URGES
description: As opposition leaders vowed to carry out plans for a ''day of national protest'' Thursday, Interior Minister Sergio Onofre Jarpa urged supporters of the Government to form ''mutual support groups'' to defend themselves against demonstrators.

title: Judaism and Feminism
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: STANDBY TAX PLAN RULED OUT
description: The Treasury Department's chief tax writer said today that the Reagan Administration's proposal for a contingency tax to reduce future budget deficits was ''dead for this year.''

title: Bridge: Versatile Writer on Game, George Coffin, Reaches 80
description: A man who has made many important contributions to the game but is little known to the present generation of players celebrates his 80th birthday today. He is George Sturgis Coffin of Waltham, Mass., the author of several major books and the publisher of many others.

title: JAZZ: JARRETT TRIO AT VANGUARD
description: EVERY few years, Keith Jarrett leaves behind solo piano concerts in large halls and brings a jazz group to the Village Vanguard. His current engagement there, through Sunday, with Gary Peacock on bass and Jack DeJohnette on drums, coincides with the release of an album by the trio, ''Standards.''

title: A SUPREME COURT CURB ON ITS OWN POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT reports earnings for Year to June 30
Key Rates
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: TRACKING WATER LEAKS WITH SENSORS AND SENSE
description: At first, there was only a trickle running down the street in a quiet residential neighborhood on Staten Island. Neighbors thought somebody was washing his car, but the trickle persisted, day after day, until one day it became a stream that gouged potholes in the street.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: MASSMUTUAL MTGE & RLTY INV reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The year-ago third quarter includes a gain of $74,330 and the 9 months includes a gain of $132,550 from the extinguishment of debt.

title: SEEDS FROM FAVORITES FOR NEXT YEAR
description: AS the planting season winds down, many gardeners have the same question: Is it all right to save leftover seed for next year? And what about those who save seed from family favorites for next year's crop?

title: CONNORS AND MRS. LLOYD ADVANCE
description: Don't tell Jimmy Connors that defending his United States Open title will be any easier now that the top- seeded John McEnroe has been eliminated. He just won't believe it.

title: Thrift Unit Acquisition By a Bank
description: The Federal Reserve Board, declaring an ''emergency'' situation, yesterday approved the acquisition of the Perpetual Savings and Loan Association in High Point, N.C., by the Old Stone Corporation, a Providence, R.I., bank holding company.

title: VERMONT CHILDREN IN PROSTITUTE RING
description: The police and state officials said Tuesday they had closed a child prostitution ring in Brattleboro, in southeastern Vermont. The authorities said that 10 children ranging in age from 8 to 13 years had been involved, acting on their own and not controlled by adults.

title: Problem Loans Soar at Citicorp
description: Citicorp said that nonperforming loans in its international loan portfolio have soared by 54 percent in the first half of the year, largely because of financial problems of private-sector borrowers in Latin America. The bank's nonperforming international loans - those in which interest is more than 90-days in arrears - rose to $1.7 billion for the first six months, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: THE MAN IN CHARGE OF THE AMEX
description: Arthur Levitt Jr., the 52-year-old chairman of the American Stock Exchange, has been a man of many careers. And while his current contract still has two and a half years to run, he concedes that he is not done changing hats.

title: SCHOOL LOSES TAX EXEMPTION
description: Associate Justice William J. Brennan of the Supreme Court refused today to suspend a ruling that denies tax-exempt status to a small Baptist school in Mississippi unless it actively seeks black students and teachers.

title: PUBLIC WORKS AWAITING JOBLESS TEEN-AGERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Choral Society Season
description: The New York Choral Society will open its 25th season on Oct. 29 at 8 P.M. with Verdi's ''Requiem.''

title: REAGAN BACKS LITERACY EFFORT
description: President Reagan today unveiled a largely voluntary national program aimed at wiping out illiteracy among 23 million adult Americans.

title: Iraq Foreign Ministry Official Visits Washington for Talks
description: The Under Secretary of the Iraqi Foreign Ministry met today with senior United States officials for a discussion of the Iran-Iraq war and other issues, the State Department said.

title: Basque Gunmen Kill Two
description: Gunmen killed a bar owner and a liquor salesman on Tuesday in two incidents in the Basque country. The salesman, Francisco Javier Alderdi, 49 years old, was shot by three gunmen in his car parked in front of his home here. Arturo Quintanilla, 44, owner of a bar in Hernani, near San Sebastian, was shot to death by gunmen when he was getting into his car.

title: RESTORING A LATROBE MANSION IN SUSSEX
description: DAVID PINNEGAR, the 22-year-old owner of Hammerwood ParK, near this Sussex TOWN, was marking the 219th anniversary of the birth of his house's architect last May 1 when he heard that a chunk of the Capitol in Washington had crashed to the ground. ''It was somewhat ironic,'' Mr. Pinnegar said recently. ''We were cutting chunks out of a cake made in the image of Hammerwood when we were told the news.''

title: Burger King Planning Biggest Campaign Yet
description: Elsewhere in fast food, Burger King, the newly aggressive rival of the mighty McDonald's, is preparing to mount its heaviest ad campaign ever, with plans to spend $40 million before the end of this year.

title: Ex-Im Bank Losing Official
description: Charles E. Lord, vice chairman of the Export-Import Bank, which finances foreigners' purchases of American-made goods, is resigning to join ''a major private financial institution in New York City on Oct. 3,'' the bank said today.

title: An Exception to Rule on U.D.C. Legal Fees
description: Last March, a few days after being confirmed as head of the state's Urban Development Corporation, William J. Stern attacked the agency's extensive use of outside lawyers. Some firms had billed the agency at rates as high as $225 an hour for the work of top partners.

title: Garden's Card Is Staggering
description: Wanted desperately: a light-heavyweight boxer who is licensed in New York State. Assignment: fight a 10- round bout tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden against Matthew Saad Muhammad, the former champion of the World Boxing Council. Urgently contact Harold Weston Jr., the Garden's matchmaker.

title: ISRAEL TV DROPS ROALD DAHL WORKS
description: Israel Television canceled programs of works by Roald Dahl on the ground that the British mystery writer had made ''very strong anti-Semitic'' statements in a magazine article, a spokesman said Tuesday.

title: CHRISTIANA COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $258,000 for the quarter and $709,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $182,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net income including a gain of $97,000 from discontinued operations.

title: LAWS TO BAR COMPUTER MISUSE REMIAN SCARCE
description: A third of a century after computers began their dizzying development as the central engines of American government, business and communications, the rules to prevent the misuse of computers are still murky and incomplete.

title: SILVERCREST INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: BAHAMIAN OFFICIALS DENY VESCO PAID DRUG BRIBES
description: Bahamian Government officials yesterday denied that Robert L. Vesco had paid them bribes to protect a drug- smuggling operation on a small island in the Caribbean.

title: Uganda Politician Missing
description: Three men who were traveling with an official of the ruling party were found shot to death at a village 70 miles southwest of Kampala, the newspaper Munno reported today. The official, Lazaro Bulezi, chairman of the Uganda People's Congress in Mpigi, was apparently abducted. He has been missing since Friday.

title: NICHOLS (SE) (A) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
News Analysis
description: To many diplomatic and Lebanese analysts the artillery shells falling in and near Beirut these days are tolling a kind of death knell for the hopes, kept alive for roughly a year, that the Lebanese Government of President Amin Gemayel could build a unified Lebanon. Now, for the first time since the Israelis drove into the country 15 months ago, expelled the Palestine Liberation Organization from Beirut and began to serve as a kind of police force keeping hostile Lebanese factions apart, open, full-scale sectarian warfare has erupted again.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 8, 1983
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: Irish Electorate Votes On an Abortion Ban
description: Only half of Ireland's electorate voted today on an amendment enshrining an abortion ban in the Irish Constitution.

title: GOOD SAMARITAN FOILS CAR THIEVES AND THEY KILL HIM WITH AN AUTO
description: One Bronx man was killed yesterday and another seriously injured when they were deliberately run over on a street near their homes in retaliation for preventing a group of people from stealing a car belonging to a friend, a spokesman for the police said.

title: Embassy in Teheran Bombed
description: A car bomb exploded outside the French Embassy compound in Teheran today, slightly injuring two women in an embassy vehicle, the official Iranian press agency reported.

title: WASHINGTON POST IS PICKETED
description: Members of the Newspaper Guild at The Washington Post began ''informational picketing'' today at the nation's seventh largest daily newspaper after voting to reject a proposed contract that the company called its ''final offer.''

title: Court Kills Sales-Tax Charge M
description: The state's sales-tax-evasion case against Martin Carey, younger brother of former Gov. Hugh L. Carey, was killed today by New York's highest court.

title: TEST MAY DETECT AIDS EARLY
description: A blood test that measures a rare form of the substance interferon may help doctors detect people who have early stages of AIDS disease but no outward symptoms, researchers say.

title: DODGERS WIN IN 10 ON MARSHALL SLAM
description: Mike Marshall smashed a grand slam with one out in the bottom of the 10th inning to power the Los Angeles Dodgers a 7-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight.

title: O.A.S. Affirmation on Debt
description: Representatives from 27 member nations of the Organization of American States today affirmed their ''historic acceptance of international commitments'' regarding the debt crisis confronting Latin American and Caribbean nations. Together, they owe more than $300 billion to official and private creditors around the world.

title: STATE SHOREHAM COMMISSION STRUGGLING IN A MAZE OF DATA
description: For three months, the Governor's Commission on Shoreham has held hearings, quizzed experts and struggled to make sense of the economic and safety issues involving the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Phone Complex Being Constructed
description: Construction of a 400,000-square-foot office building that will house the Central Services Organization, the technical-support company for the seven regional companies formed in the divestiture of American Telephone and Telegraph Company, began here today.

title: 2 FRENCH SOLDIERS KILLED AS SHELLS SLAM INTO BEIRUT
description: Artillery shells rained over West Beirut today, killing a French paratroop colonel and his driver. In response, the French sent two warplanes on warning flights over the city and Moslem Druse artillery positions in the nearby mountains.

title: Foster's Waiting Game
description: As long as George Foster has been recognized as one of the most powerful forces in a batter's box, he has developed the reputation for waiting until the time was right. If a few more moments are required to gather his thoughts and develop his concentration, he will step out of the box. ''It's important to me,'' he said. For the Cincinnati customers until the last two seasons, the results were worth any annoying wait.

title: No Headline
description: AN ORDERLY MAN. By Dirk Bogarde. Illustrated. 291 pages. Knopf. $14.95.

title: ATLANTIC CITY MAYOR'S CRITICS SUCCEED IN BID FOR RECALL VOTE
description: A group seeking to recall Mayor Michael J. Matthews has filed enough valid signatures to force a referendum, the City Clerk said today.

title: TENNIS'S 'SHERIFF' ENFORCES THE LAW
description: The most important person in tennis is not competing in the United States Open this week.

title: ON SCUPPING'S PLEBIAN LURE
description: All too often veteran anglers tend to zero in on a certain species when a more plebeian goal would produce both action and food. I was reminded of this recently when I returned almost empty-handed from a six-hour jaunt that involved casting a wide variety of plugs and jigs for striped bass among the Elizabeth Islands of Massachusetts.

title: AMERICANS IN ELECTRONIC ERA ARE READING AS MUCH AS EVER
description: Despite rising concern over literacy and widespread fears that television and other electronic media are undermining the influence of the written word, Americans seem to be doing as much reading as ever.

title: TCA CABLE TV reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
IF IT WERE EISENHOWER
description: When President Reagan spoke to the nation the other night about the shooting down of the Korean airliner, angrily denouncing Soviet behavior, I found myself thinking about Dwight D. Eisenhower. He would have been just as angry, I thought, but there would have been a different tone in his response: more restrained, more dignified, more convincing. Or was I just romanticizing a now-remote figure?

title: Message on Plastic Bottles Seeks to Clarify Law
description: A small sailboat made of 160 plastic bottles was on display yesterday in the patio at the Tavern on the Green. Inside was a smooth, squishy pillow stuffed with reconstituted material that had once been four plastic bottles.

title: STEWART & STEVENSON SERVICE reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: Market Place; Closed-End Bond Funds
description: FOR the first time in nine months, Thomas J. Herzfeld has taken a more positive stance toward the fixed-income market. ''We've had approximately a 50 percent correction from the bond market's highs of last winter,'' he said yesterday in explaining his rationale. And that, in turn, makes him optimistic over prospects for closed-end bond funds, which he trades actively at his firm in South Miami, Fla.

title: JETRONIC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Finkelstein Buys Chock Full Shares
description: Jerry Finkelstein, a New York financier, said that he and associates had acquired 90,000 shares of the Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation for $18.25 a share, along with a two- month option to acquire an additional 120,000 shares. The block of 210,000 shares represents about 4.2 percent of the company's outstanding shares.

title: No Headline
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Widow of Astronaut Is Dead
description: Patricia Finegan Davis, widow of Lieut. Col. Edward H. White 2d of the Air Force, the first American astronaut to walk in space, died in her home here Tuesday, a family spokesman said. Mrs. Davis, who was in her 50's and had undergone surgery to remove a tumor earlier this year, was widowed when Colonel White and two other astronauts were killed in a flash fire inside the Apollo 1 capsule in a test at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida on Jan. 27, 1967.

title: Advertising; Campaign For Dean Witter
description: BECAUSE there are specific programs of interest to investors on network radio and on cable TV, Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn has bought time on both for the new ad campaign of its client Dean Witter Reynolds.

title: Technology; TV Licensing With a Lottery
description: THE old drum from which Selective Service numbers were drawn during the Vietnam War will be used again this month in a new type of lottery - the awarding of licenses for low-power television stations.

title: POLAND ACCUSES 6 IN DEATH OF YOUTH
description: Two Polish policemen and two ambulance drivers have been charged with beating to death a youth in their custody, officials said today.

title: ALONG THE BAY OF NAPLES, TREMORS GET TO BE A HABIT
description: After almost 10 months of daily earth tremors, the 65,000 people of this town adjoining Naples are running away, camping out, being evacuated or brooding about what they should do.

title: HAZ IZOD'S ALLIGATOR PEAKED?
description: First came the alligator, then the polo player. The tiger, the dragon, the horse and the fox soon followed. ''When you start naming them,'' said Bill Van Voorhis, a J. C. Penney executive, ''there's a whole zoo of them.''

title: EXILES AND PUBLISHERS DIFFER ON MOSCOW FAIR
description: At the same moment that the Fourth International Book Fair is being held in Moscow this week, several Soviet writers-in-exile and American publishers who did not go to the Moscow Fair as a matter of principle met yesterday - but disagreed about the merits of attending or not attending this year's fair.

title: Jo Durie Leaves Outside Courts for Now; Plays Mrs. Lloyd at Open
description: She has performed in the relative privacy of the outside courts and the grandstand, her progress charted closely only by the contingent of British reporters to whom she has become, ''Our Jo.'' But for those tennis fans who are eagerly anticipating a women's final between Chris Evert Lloyd and Martina Navratilova in the United States Open, Jo Durie is just another obstacle to be crossed off the list of opponents at the appropriate time and place.

title: Friends and Foes
description: Bill Parcells of the Giants and Dan Henning of the Atlanta Falcons are not speaking to each other this week.

title: U.S. ENCOUNTERS POLITICAL SNAG IN SECURITY COUNCIL
description: The United States and its allies began drafting a Security Council resolution today condemning the destruction of the Korean airliner and quickly ran into a political problem, Western diplomats said.

title: Harper of Jets Has Surgery; Cartilage Is Removed
description: The mere mention of knee surgery, even of the arthroscopic kind, is often enough to send shivers down the brawniest of backs in the National Football League. But for Bruce Harper of the Jets, knee surgery has relieved a season's worth of worry.

title: VOLUME MERCHANDISE reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Earthquake Strikes Alaska
description: A strong earthquake rocked south- central Alaska today, causing minor damage to at least one building in Anchorage, but there were no reports of injuries. The quake, which measured 6.4 on the Richter scale, struck about 10:22 A.M. Alaska daylight time.

title: EUROPEAN PILOTS JOIN BAN ON MOSCOW
description: Thousands of commercial pilots in western Europe said today that they would join a 60-day boycott of scheduled flights to Moscow in retaliation for the Soviet Union's downing of a Korean Air Lines 747 jumbo jet.

title: 'NEW' NOVEL BY DREISER IS COMING OUT THIS FALL
description: Broke, and in the aftermath of a nervous breakdown caused by the commercial failure of his first novel, ''Sister Carrie,'' in 1904 Theodore Dreiser composed an autobiographical novel based on his humbling experiences the year before, when he worked as a day laborer for 15 cents an hour, 10 hours a day, for the New York Central Railroad.

title: 'Lady's Not for Burning' To Open Equity Season
description: ''The Lady's Not for Burning,'' the romantic comedy by Christopher Fry, will open the 41st season of the Equity Library Theater Sept. 22 at the theater's Playhouse, Riverside Drive and 103d Street.

title: REAGAN BEGINS TO WEAR A HEARING AID IN PUBLIC
description: President Reagan has begun wearing a custom-made, technologically advanced hearing aid in his right ear after experiencing increased difficulty hearing high-pitched sound.

title: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 8, 1983
description: International

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the Aug. 29 Advertising Column about Bell Atlantic misidentified two agency assignments. Lewis, Gilman will handle Bell Atlantic's mobile systems, Yellow Page promotion and local advertising for Bell of Pennsylvania and Diamond State Telephone. Ketchum Communications was assigned Bell Atlantic's telecommunications systems, corporate and financial advertising, and local advertising for the Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone companies.

title: FAILURES OF COMMON SENSE; Bridge Mugged
description: Last May, at the time of the Brooklyn Bridge's birthday bash, the Brooklyn Bridge Centennial Committee opened a sound and light show depicting the early life of the bridge. It included a narration, music, electronically produced storms - snow, thunder and lightning - and other effects.

title: Court Prohibits Ban On Homosexual Aliens
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service cannot stop homosexual aliens from entering the country without medical certification of deviation or defect, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled today.

title: AMC ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Headline
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Pershing Missile Is Tested
description: A Pershing 2 missile was successfully launched today on its next to last test flight, the Army said.

title: Ulster Guerrillas Kill Veteran Police Officer
description: Guerrillas killed Northern Ireland's second longest-serving police officer today in a predawn ambush outside his home.

title: Vermont Judge Faces Drunken Driving Charge
description: Judge John Morrissey of Superior Court, who has twice been convicted of drunken driving, has been cited again after his automobile collided with a car while traveling the wrong way on Interstate 89, the state police said today.

title: McCarthy Is Listed as 'Fair' At a Hospital in Washington
description: Eugene J. McCarthy, a former Senator and challenger for the Democratic Presidential nomination, was transferred to Georgetown University Hospital today, where he was listed in fair condition after a heart attack.

title: SCOPE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,737,250. c-After an extraordinary credit of $22,391,178.

title: Paine Webber Sets Deal for Brokerage
description: Paine Webber Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire First Mid America Inc., a brokerage firm in Lincoln, Neb., in a deal valued at between $15 million and $16 million.

title: A.T.&T. AND COLECO IN VIDEO GAME VENTURE
description: In its latest move to expand beyond telephones, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday announced a joint venture with Coleco Industries to develop a home video game service that would be delivered over telephone lines.

title: Housing Proposed For West Side Site
description: A Koch administration plan to build a 265-unit rental apartment complex on a disputed site in the Upper West Side Urban Renewal Area was presented Tuesday night at a public meeting of Community Board 7.

title: Atari Replaces Head Of Unit After 9 Months
description: Peter Wensberg has been replaced as president of Atari Inc.'s new home telecommunications division, Ataritel, just nine months after he joined the company.

title: ST. LOUIS TEACHERS' STRIKE MARS START OF SUBURB-TO-CITY BUSING PLAN
description: The transfer of white suburban pupils to inner-city St. Louis schools under a court-approved desegregation plan got off to a difficult start today as the city's teachers walked out on strike over demands for higher pay.

title: TV: PBS A 'DREAM' JAZZ BAND
description: TELEVISION has a way of being fickle. This evening, jazz, hardly a staple of the medium, is done to a marvelous turn. Meanwhile, a situation comedy, perhaps the most enduring product of the home screen, gets off to a disastrous debut.

title: BankAmerica's South Dakota Filing
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it had filed an application to open a state-chartered bank in South Dakota. Industry analysts said that, because of a new South Dakota law, the step would put BankAmerica in a position to sell insurance if existing Federal regulatory barriers are overcome.

title: ACME GENERAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split distributed on July 15.

title: STATEMENTS AT MADRID PARLEY ON KOREAN JET'S DESTRUCTION
description: Following are statements by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union and Secretary of State George P. Shultz of the United States at the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe yesterday in Madrid, covering what they said about the downing of a South Korean airliner. Mr. Gromyko's remarks are excerpts from his speech as reported by Reuters. Mr. Shultz's comments were recorded by The Associated Press. Gromyko's Statement

title: JOHN E. PFRIEM
description: John E. Pfriem, the president of The Post Publishing Company, died today in Bridgeport Hospital after a short illness.

title: ONE ALTERED TRANSCRIPT, ONE QUIET RESIGNATION
description: It was the Friday afternoon before the Labor Day weekend, one of the sleepiest news days of the year on Capitol Hill. Congress was on vacation, and the two-paragraph news release that was quietly issued by the House Committee on Government Operations barely rippled the surface of the steamy summer day.

title: NFA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
description: The 1982 figures reflect the company's first 9 months of operations. The company began operations in October 1981.

title: NATO ALLIES SEEM TO FAVOR CURB ON FLIGHTS TO MOSCOW
description: The United States and many of its allies moved today toward suspending for at least a week to 10 days air travel from their countries to the Soviet Union in response to the Soviet downing of a South Korean airliner.

title: Boarding Homes Face
description: State officials today recommended new procedures for licensing and inspecting boarding homes and the establishment of a fund to provide emergency improvements.

title: SUN CITY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid in July.

title: Illegal Raids on Legal Services
description: The Federal program of legal services for the poor is under siege again. Ronald Reagan couldn't kill it when he was Governor of California, but as President he keeps trying. Unable to persuade Congress to abolish the Legal Services Corporation, he has installed a wrecking crew to smash from within. Now a loud Senate minority seeks to tar the program with the odd charge that its lawyers have tried to ward off the Reaganite attacks.

title: BOEING GETS $640 MILLION QANTAS ORDER
description: The Boeing Company received a $640 million order yesterday from Qantas Airways, the airline owned by the Australian Government, for nine jetliners.

title: KOREA'S AMBASSADOR: 'I KNEW, I HAD A FEAR'
description: Shortly after 7:30 P.M. last Wednesday, Korea's Ambassador to the United States, Lew Byong Hion, arrived at his home off Massachusetts Avenue, unlocked the door and heard the telephone ringing. It was an official of the Foreign Ministry in Seoul.

title: Stokes Loses New Trial Bid
description: Representative Louis Stokes, Democrat of Ohio, was denied a new trial Tuesday on charges of driving while under the influence of alcohol. He said he would not appeal the ruling.

title: Pargas Merger
description: Pargas Inc., a retail and wholesale distributor of liquefied natural gas, said it had agreed to an amended merger agreement with Forstmann Little & Company valued at $144 million.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, has elected to its board Alexander M. Haig Jr., former Secretary of State.

title: S. & P. Lowers Chicago Rating
description: Chicago's credit rating was lowered yesterday by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, which cited the city's ''continuing weakened financial position.''

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS JET CONTRACT
description: In a major victory for the General Dynamics Corporation, the Turkish Ministry of Defense said yesterday that it would buy the F-16 jet fighter, made by General Dynamics, to modernize its air force. Turkish military sources said that the Government would buy some 160 planes for an estimated $4 billion over 10 years.

title: VORNADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-After tax credits of $330,000 for the quarter and $1,030,000 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $625,000 for the quarter and $1,250,000 for the 6 months.

title: Coke Sees Drop in Net
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that the ''overvalued'' dollar and currency devaluations in Latin America, a major market, would reduce the company's second-half net income by between $13 million and $15 million.

title: EDUCATIONAL COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 100 percent stock dividend paid July 21.

title: U.S. EXPECTS 3 STATES TO TOP NEW YORK POPULATION IN 2000
description: The Census Bureau said today that if current trends continued, Texas and Florida would surpass New York State in population by the year 2000.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PORTER'S PARIS

title: Warning on Steroids
description: Adolescent athletes who take anabolic steroids face even greater health risks than older athletes, according to an expert at Purdue University. Steroids taken to increase body weight and build strength can actually stunt the growth of young athletes, he said, and cause especially devastating effects in teen-age girls.

title: COOPERBIOMEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FAST LEGAL ACTION FOR A.T.&T.
description: A Federal judge agreed today to a Justice Department request that any appeal of the divestiture plan for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company bypass the United States Court of Appeals and be certified to go directly to the Supreme Court.

title: JAPANESE ARTISTRY IN CARPENTER'S TOOLS
description: ROBERT CHAMBERS, a violin maker in Volant, Pa., who studied the Stradivarius method in Cremona, Italy, uses a wooden-bodied Japanese joiner plane called the Fortune of Happiness to join the two pieces that make a violin's belly. He uses a handmade Japanese gouge with a curved blade to carve the violin's scroll and a pair of Japanese knives for the f-holes.

title: DENNY OF PHILLIES STOPS METS
description: When Mike Schmidt walloped a home run in the ninth inning for Philadelphia last night, a black cat raced out of the Phillies' dugout and almost ran in front of him on the basepath, then turned away.

title: Berry Pondering St. John's Entry
description: Walter Berry, the basketball player who is fighting the National Collegiate Athletic Association for eligibility to play at St. John's this season, will not make his final decision on whether to enroll there for this year until later this week, according to Coach Lou Carnesecca.

title: Survey Stakes Burned To Protest Navy Project
description: Protestors said Tuesday that they had torn up and burned hundreds of surveyors' stakes along a 20-mile route in Michigan's Upper Peninsula where the Navy plans to build a submarine communications system.

title: Voters in Equatorial Guinea Choose National Assembly
description: Voters in the tiny West African country of Equatorial Guinea elected a new 41- member National Assembly last week, an Equatorial Guinean Embassy spokesman said today.

title: THE PERSONAL APARTMENT: ROOMS WITH A SPECIAL VIEWPOINT
description: THEY are the apartments that defy rational description. Objects are everywhere, along with enough furniture and accessories to fill a couple of antiques shops. But something about the interiors is more intriguing than the initial impact of clutter and sheer abundance of things. These are apartments filled with memorabilia, intensely private lairs that have what many slick and newly decorated interiors lack - a vivid sense of the past, intimacy and warmth and a distinctive personal style. They are spaces the whole of which is more than the sum of their many parts.

title: McDonald & Little Gets The Bojangles' Account
description: McDonald & Little, Atlanta, which learned about the fast-food business working for regional advertising associations of McDonald's in the Southeast, has just been named agency for Bojangles', a chain with headquarters in Charlotte, N.C., that is owned by Horn & Hardart. The agency puts the billings at about $7 million, which appears to be today's magic number.

title: REALTY INCOME TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The net in the latest quarter includes gain from property sale of $342,521.

title: U.S. WEIGHING POLICY OPTIONS IN BEIRUT CLASH
description: The Reagan Administration, deeply concerned over increasing danger to the marines in Beirut, has reopened the entire question of the American military presence in Lebanon, Administration officials said today.

title: CHEMLAWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Bank of Boston
description: The Bank of Boston's plan to acquire the Casco-Northern Corporation of Portland, Me., does not meet state banking guidelines and will not be approved, Donald DeMatteis, the superintendent of the Maine Bureau of Banking, said. Mr. DeMatteis said the state's Attorney General had told him that Maine law prohibits acquisitions by out-of-state banks unless a reciprocal agreement exists. Massachusetts law, Mr. DeMatteis said, prohibits Maine banks that are owned by bank-holding companies from outside New England from acquiring Massachusetts banks. The Bank of Boston announced in March that it would acquire Casco-Northern, Maine's largest bank holding company, for $55 million.

title: Principals' Union Starts Campaign for City Schools
description: ''Give the Kids a Hand'' reads a billboard at Broadway and Houston Street (and three others around the boroughs). ''Support Public Schools.''

title: Kean to Sign Bill On Simulcasts
description: Governor Kean said today that he would sign a bill designed to avert the closing of the financially ailing Atlantic City Race Course by allowing it to take bets on horse races televised live from other tracks.

title: HOLSTERING AMERICA'S HANDGUNS
description: On June 8, 1981, the village trustees of Morton Grove, Ill., fired a shot heard 'round the world of handguns. They passed an ordinance restricting handgun ownership within village limits. Legal challenges, financed by the National Rifle Association and other pro-gun groups, were immediately filed, and the result was national attention that kept the town of 25,000 in the public eye for months. Not much has been heard from Morton Grove lately, but the silence should not be misread.

title: SEAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After tax credits of $87,000 for the quarter and $222,000 for the 9 months. c-After a tax credit reversal of $7,000. d-After a tax credit of $63,000.

title: GOODHEART-WILCOX reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Jury Interview Curbs On Journalists Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court on Tuesday affirmed the right of judges to restrict journalists from interviewing jurors after a trial about their deliberations.

title: Swiss Inflation Slows
description: Swiss consumer prices rose 1.7 percent in August from a year ago, the smallest increase since January 1979, the federal Office for Industry Trade and Labor said today. The rise came after a 2.2 percent increase in July from July 1982.

title: PROPERTY OWNERS IN A DALLAS SUBURB PREPARING TO SELL TOWN
description: The town of Buckingham, which offered a rural way of life until it was enveloped by urban sprawl from neighboring Dallas, has decided to sell out now that the price is right - $40 million.

title: BOWNE & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $159,000 for the quarter and $344,000 for the 9 months and an estimated loss of $403,000 for the quarter and 9 months on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $235,000 for the quarter and $489,000 for the 9 months. Results reflect the sale of certain assets and business of Bowne Information Systems Inc., effective Aug. l.

title: UNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Holtz's Joke Book
description: Lou Holtz, the sardonic coach of the Arkansas football team, is expecting a 1983 season dotted with more than the usual number of losses, but over the telephone yesterday he made clear that one thing he hadn't lost was his sense of humor.

title: Belgian G.N.P. Up 0.7%
description: Belgium's gross national product at constant 1975 prices rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in 1982 after a 1.2 percent fall in 1981, the National Statistics Institute said today. The institute's figure compares with earlier provisional estimates by the Bureau du Plan, a Government economic planning agency, that the gross national product would fall slightly last year.

title: O.E.C.D. Deciding On Top Economist
description: A British economist with a moderate approach to Government intervention is expected to take over the top economic job at the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

title: City Directory Shows All-Night Locations
description: What kind of a product do you suppose would restrict its TV and radio advertising to the hours between midnight and 6 A.M.?

title: 'SINGING POLICEMAN' FILES SUIT AFTER BAN ON BLACKFACE ROLE
description: Police officials violated the rights of Baltimore's ''singing cop'' when they ordered him to stop imitating Al Jolson in blackface routines because of racial tension, a lawyer argued Tuesday.

title: STOCKS SHOW MODERATE RISE
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday in continued heavy trading, following Tuesday's sharp advance. The Dow Jones industrial average finished just over four points below its record close, set in June.

title: TYLAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bayi Changes Schools
description: After a year at the University of Oklahoma, Filbert Bayi, the 30-year-old former world-record holder in the mile and the 1,500-meter run, has left the school to join the Tanzanian exclave at the University of Texas-El Paso. Bayi said he was making the move at the urging of the Tanzanian Government, which had been disappointed with the country's poor showing at the recent World Track and Field Championships and wants its top competitors to train together for next summer's Olympics.

title: BLUESKY OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including a special gain of $771,945 on the sale of marketable securities. c-Net loss.

title: 6.85% Rate Increase Is Approved for Lilco
description: The State Public Service Commission yesterday granted the Long Island Lighting Company a $43.4 million interim rate increase - $19.6 million less than the company had sought.

title: U.S. Coal Sales Review Urged
description: The chairman of an independent commission investigating Interior Secretary James G. Watt's coal leasing policies has suggested that future sales be reviewed by a council of five Cabinet members.

title: Glenn Files to Get U.S. AidFor Campaign for President
description: Senator John Glenn of Ohio on Tuesday became the fifth Democratic Presidential candidate to submit documents to the Federal Election Commission to qualify for Federal matching campaign funds.

title: Doctors Advised on Efforts In Restarting Failing Hearts
description: Trying to restart a stopped heart in a hospital patient's with chest pounding and electric shocks usually becomes useless if not successful within 30 minutes, doctors have disclosed.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
BATHROOM GADGETS MAKE LIFE EASIER
description: IT is all very well to have an overflow drain in the bathtub to prevent the absent-minded from starting a bath, forgetting it and finding a flood. However, some drains make it impossible to get the water deep enough for a good soak.

title: WEINBERGER, IN SALVADOR, HAILS ARMY GAINS
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger visited one of El Salvador's most contested areas today and came away expressing satisfaction with the progress Government troops were making in cleaning out guerrilla strongholds.

title: BROOKLYN'S TAMUD BY TELEPHONE OFFERS WISDOM IN DAILY TALKS
description: For many years, Rabbi Eli Teitelbaum dreamed of making the wisdom of the past more accessible through modern technology. Now the Talmud is just a few push buttons away, through ''Dial-a-Daf.''

title: PARLEY ASKS PALESTINIAN SELF-RULE
description: Delegates to a United Nations conference today proclaimed the right of the Palestinian people to self-determination and their ''own independent state in Palestine''.

title: WEDTECH CORP reports earnings for 6mo to June 30
AIDE LINKS BAKER TO CARTER PAPERS
description: A low-echelon aide in Ronald Reagan's 1980 Presidential campaign has told Congressional investigators that, on orders from aides to James A. Baker 3d, he made copies of materials President Carter planned to use in his debate with Mr. Reagan, according to sources familiar with the investigation.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
2 Critically Burned In Queens Fire
