description: A fire broke out in the kitchen of a Queens apartment early yesterday, critically burning two elderly men, the Fire Department reported.

title: MANILA PANEL STARTS ASSASSINATION HEARINGS
description: A five-member commission that President Ferdinand E. Marcos appointed to investigate the assassination of his chief political rival, Benigno S. Aquino Jr., opened hearings today with testimony by the police doctor who performed an autopsy.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHEN a piece of furniture accumulates a lot of blemishes, the only way to restore it is to strip it before refinishing. If the defects are minor, however, it is possible to rejuvenate a piece by touch-up or concealment combined with polishing.

title: 100,000 AT SEOUL MEMORIAL SERVICE FOR 269 VICTIMS
description: There was no private grief this morning as more than 100,000 people jammed into Seoul Stadium for a memorial service for the 269 victims from the South Korean airliner that was shot down by a Soviet fighter.

title: OLD 'NEW' PARK LAMPS
description: To the Editor:

title: FUTURE OF MANIC IN DOUBT
description: Perhaps the main motivation for the Montreal Manic in their 4-2 upset of the Cosmos on Tuesday night stemmed from the uncertainty of the team's future, according to Coach Andy Lynch.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Garry Unger, a 17-year player in the National Hockey League, who has been with the Edmonton Oilers the last three seasons, has retired and will become a television commentator with the Canadian Sports Network. Unger, 35, also played in Toronto, St. Louis, Atlanta, Los Angeles and Detroit.

title: LOCKHEED TEAM GETS SHUTTLE JOB
description: A team of companies led by the Lockheed Corporation today won a contract potentially worth billions of dollars to provide launching and landing services for future shuttle flights.

title: U.S. WILL PROTECT MARINES, BUSH WARNS
description: After an American frigate shelled Druse positions in Lebanon, Vice President Bush warned Syria and other anti-government elements in Lebanon today that the United States would protect its 1,300-man Marine peacekeeping unit around Beirut.

title: JUDGE ORDERS END TO ST. LOUIS STRIKE
description: A Federal district judge today ordered 3,800 teachers and other school workers to end the biggest of the nation's current teacher strikes because it was disrupting a court-approved desegregation plan.

title: New NEC Chip
description: The NEC Corporation said it would begin marketing next month a new battery-powered 64K dynamic random access memory chip. The new product is the world's first 64K dynamic RAM to use a complementary metal oxide semiconductor structure, an NEC spokesman said. He declined to give the chip's price.

title: Choices for the Civil Court
description: Democratic voters in two Manhattan districts will select candidates for Civil Court judge next Tuesday.

title: I.B.M. Price Cuts
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it had cut the purchase prices of its large 3083, 3081 and 3084 processing units. The discounts will range up to 14 percent for the three processors and 12 percent for most upgrades of the 3083 and 3081 units. I.B.M. said the purchase price for the smallest of the processors involved, the 3083 model Group E, had been cut to $960,000, from $1.1 million.

title: Tymshare Bid
description: The Federal Communications Commission approved the acquisition of French-owned FTC Communications Inc. by Tymshare Inc., bolstering Tymshare's efforts to enter the international communications market.

title: 4TH BEETHOVEN FESTIVAL AT ESTATE IN OYSTER BAY
description: Beethoven in the Hay Barn, Beethoven under the stars. Beethoven in a mansion and under hanging plants. Devotees of the composer can indulge themselves immoderately in grand surroundings on Long Island this weekend, but they'll have to make choices because so much will be going on at once.

title: FESTIVAL OFFERS 26 FILMS BY WOMEN
description: One film - a collaborative effort by nine German women directors - explores women's fears of nuclear disaster and how those fears affect their lives. Another is a documentary about the mass sterilization of Puerto Rican women. A third is a tribute to Thelma Hill, a black dancer.

title: SIGNS OF PRIVATE INVESTING IN HARLEM HOUSING SEEN
description: Since World War II, almost all housing development in Harlem has depended on investing government dollars. Only in recent years have community leaders been able to take steps to attract the private investment that is necessary to lift the community above the level of subsistence.

title: NEW YORK'S SIDEWALKS: A CHOICE OF TOURS
description: WALKING tours of New York have come a long way since 10 years ago, when such institutions as the Municipal Art Society, the Museum of the City of New York and the Friends of Cast Iron Architecture began to take New Yorkers on ordered routes through the city's history and architecture. Today, it is possible to spend almost any weekend scrutinizing New York from the sidewalk. There have been walks through subway tunnels and across archeological digs, and bird's-eye scannings from the tops of tall buildings. The life of such New York writers as Herman Melville may provide the tour's organizing principle - or ghosts, songs, ethnic restaurants, cemetery roll-calls or poisonous plants.

title: HE PROMISES HER JUDGESHIP
description: Alice Daniel, Governor Cuomo's counsel and the only woman among his senior advisers, resigned yesterday. Mr. Cuomo announced that he would nominate Miss Daniel to be a judge on the Court of Claims when a vacancy occurs in January.

title: CHICAGO REAL ESTATE MAN ACCUSED OF $1 MILLION PLOT TO KILLL MAYOR
description: A wealthy real estate executive has been accused of offering $1 million for the assassination of Mayor Harold Washington, the authorities announced today.

title: ARMS INDUSTRY'S HOT STOCKS
description: Relations between Washington and Moscow have grown noticeably cooler in recent days, but on Wall Street the chill has helped heat up the sluggish stocks of military contractors.

title: New Focus Inc. Picks Colarossi Griswold
description: The Colarossi Griswold agency has been tapped by New Focus Inc., a computer services company.

title: DANIEL SCHOEN
description: Daniel Schoen, president of the Kaufman Carpet Company, died Tuesday at his summer home in Mantoloking, N.J. He was 77 years old and lived in South Orange, N.J.

title: HEINZ (H. J.) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
BANKS GET SCOLDING BY REGAN
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan today criticized banks and the rest of the financial industry for the present level of interest rates.

title: SYMBOLIC SINS CAST ON WATER FOR ROSH HA-SHANAH
description: Jews gathered along the shore of Prospect Park Lake in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon and prayed for forgiveness during the Rosh ha-Shanah holiday.

title: Where Have All the Savings Gone?
description: It was the largest tax cut in the nation's history, reducing total tax liabilities $100 billion a year by 1990. It was intended, in President Reagan's words, to have a ''powerful impact on the incentives for all Americans to work, save and invest.'' But as the Government's data now reveal, the Economic Recovery Act of 1981 has had little or no effect on work or savings.

title: SHULTZ CONFRONTS GROMYKO DIRECTLY ON PLANE INCIDENT
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz held a two-hour meeting today with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko to confront him directly with the demand that the Soviet Union accept blame for the shooting down of a Korean Air Lines plane last week. Later, Mr. Shultz said the Soviet Foreign Minister's responses to him were ''totally unacceptable.''

title: Mayor Files Suit On Recall Petition
description: Mayor Michael J. Matthews filed a suit in Superior Court today challenging the validity of hundreds of signatures on a petition seeking the Mayor's recall.

title: BRIEFING
description: Stassen Is Ready

title: WEINBERGER ENDS HIS LATIN TRIP
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger ended a three-day tour of Central America today with high praise for the region's efforts to fend off Communism.

title: 23 ACCUSED BY U.S. OF SELLING HEROIN
description: Twenty-three people were accused yesterday in Federal court of participating in two New York City-based drug rings that distributed up to $1 million worth of heroin weekly in the city and in Cleveland, Pittsburgh and Detroit.

title: Vanderbilt Bars Soviet Game
description: The American tour by the Soviet national basketball team this fall is still on, according to the Amateur Basketball Association USA.

title: BROADWAY
description: Rex Harrison to do Shaw play at Circle in Square.

title: Jones Doubtful for Seahawks
description: The Jets' home opener Sunday is against the Seattle Seahawks, who have dominated the Jets since 1977, winning six consecutive games by an average margin of 23-11. The Seahawks, who under their new head coach, Chuck Knox, lost their opening game at Kansas City by 17-13, beat the Jets last season by 27-23.

title: BRITISH AIRWAYS ENDS MOSCOW RUNS
description: British Airways announced today that it was halting its four scheduled flights a week from London to Moscow beginning Friday because it did not want to force its pilots to fly against their will.

title: SAN GENNARO FESTIVAL ADDING NEW FLAVORS
description: There are more and more tacos and egg rolls among the pizzas, zeppole and torrone on Mulberry Street, but despite its increasingly international flavor, the 57th Feast of San Gennaro that began yesterday is still New York's greatest celebration of its Italian heritage.

title: POWER TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income Power Test's 33 1/3 percent interest in Alpha Portland Industries resulted in equity earnings of $457,000 for the latest quarter compared with $347,000 for the 1982 quarter and $495,000 for the latest 6 months against a loss of $424,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Irish Voters Adopt New Ban on Abortion
description: Ireland has voted an antiabortion amendment into the Constitition by a 2-to- 1 majority, but only half the electorate turned out.

title: VOLUME MERCHANDISE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
REAGAN'S RECORD ON WOMEN STILL BEING DEBATED
description: After more than a year of debate, the White House and women's groups are still in fundamental disagreement over the validity of President Reagan's contention that he has appointed more women than any of his predecessors.

title: HORSE-RIDING EVENT
description: Equestrians of all ages will take part in a two-day competition this weekend at the West Shore Stables, 52 Hughes Avenue, in the Travis section of Staten Island.

title: MALPRACTICE: IT'S PATIENTS WHO NEED PROTECTION
description: To the Editor:

title: MATTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net income

title: HOLD OFF ON EUROPEAN MISSILES
description: Late this fall, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization is scheduled to deploy the first Pershing 2 medium- range nuclear missiles in West Germany. The Social Democratic Party continues to support NATO's 1979 ''two-track'' decision - to negotiate seriously with the Soviet Union in the hope of heading off installation of the missiles, but to deploy some medium- range missiles eventually if negotiations fail. Yet we Social Democrats oppose American and West German conservatives who are exploiting this decision in ways contrary to what was intended when NATO adopted it.

title: White Tiger Dies After Bite
description: A rare white Bengal tiger died Wednesday after its tail was chewed to the bone in a freakish accident when the tail slipped into the cage of another tiger, officials of Miami's Metrozoo said.

title: Japan Tool Orders Rise
description: Machine tool orders received by 68 major Japanese engineering companies in July rose 17.5 percent from the period a year earlier, to a 16 month- high of $210 million, the Japan Machine Tool Builders Association said today. The July total was 16.1 percent higher than in June. The association attributed the sharp rise to increased exports.

title: STUDY SAYS SMILE MAY INDEED BE AN UMBRELLA
description: The folk wisdom that urges you to smile your troubles away has received new support from scientific research to be published today.

title: THE EVENING
description: JUST around the hour that the sun softened and the sound of lifeguards' whistles ceased at Jones Beach on Labor Day, Beatrice Freeman blew happily on a party noisemaker. Then, with the assistance of several friends and relatives, Mrs. Freeman began lugging an assortment of bridge tables and beach chairs from parking lot to sand. On the tables she placed paper plates, silverware, cold cuts covered with aluminum foil and, most important, a lineup of various-sized framed family photographs. The most elaborate frame contained a tinted portrait, taken 28 years ago, of Beatrice Freeman in a bridal gown gazing lovingly at Sandy Freeman.

title: EXPLORING THE POP-SOUL OF ASHFORD AND SIMPSON
description: DESCRIBING the chemistry of Ashford and Simpson, the husband-and-wife pop- soul duo who are performing at Radio City Music Hall tonight and tomorrow, people often compare them to Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers. The world they evoke on stage is a Manhattan-centered dreamscape of perpetual romance, and their ardent vocal exchanges have the rhythms of pop ballet. As in the Astaire-Rogers partnership, the man is the gentler, more ethereal sensibility. The androgynously leonine Mr. Ashford sings in a quivering emotional falsetto, while his wife is an urgent gospel belter with a cheerleader's exuberance.

title: CORRECTION
description: A photo caption in Metropolitan Report yesterday incorrectly identified a witness who testified before the Governor's Commission on Shoreham. He is Dr. Peter Kroeger, a proponent of the nuclear plant on Long Island.

title: STRIKE COSTS THE PUBLIC SHOULDN'T HAVE TO PAY
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexican Official Kidnapped
description: A high-ranking union official of the Mexican national oil monopoly was kidnapped today by two gunmen who held three people hostage until the victim arrived home, the police said. The official, Hector Garcia Hernandez, was taken from this border town this afternoon but the authorities had received no ransom demands by tonight, a police spokesman said.

title: DOG IS RULED COUPLE'S 'CHILD' IN CUSTODY CASE IN CALIFORNIA
description: After a year of bitter divorce proceedings, a judge has awarded a childless couple joint custody of their dog in accordance with California's child custody laws.

title: HUSHED PROXIES
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Workers Hurt At Navy Yard
description: A 40-foot scaffold fell over at a Brooklyn Navy Yard dry dock yesterday, injuring three workers who were on the wood-and-metal frame, authorities said.

title: A BUS TOUR THAT SHOWS HARLEM'S MANY SIDES
description: There once was a time, when Duke Ellington summoned the world to ''Take the A Train'' to Harlem, in which jazz musicians and poets, literati and cultural cognoscenti flocked to 125th Street. ''Harlem of the 1920's was presented as a great playground, America's answer to Paris,'' as the historian Gilbert Osofsky wrote. And 50 years before, the stately town houses of Sugar Hill, Striver's Row and Jumel Terrace were home to such wealthy New Yorkers as the Astors and the Baileys of Barnum & Bailey.

title: PLAYING EMILY ROEBLING IN THE YEAR OF THE BRIDGE
description: HER name is Eleanore Whitla Clinger, but on stage she is Bijou Clinger. Seated in the tiny Quaigh Theater, where she is starring in her first big New York role, as Emily Roebling in a musical called ''The Brooklyn Bridge,'' the ebullient Miss Clinger considered the question, ''Why Bijou?''

title: White House Post Filled
description: President Reagan today named Andrew Card, a former Massachusetts legislator, as his special assistant for intergovernmental affairs to act as a liaison agent between the White House and the governors. Mr. Card, 36 years old, ran for the the Republican nomination for Governor of Massachusetts in 1982 and is now vice president of a suburban Washington computer software engineering company. He replaces James Medas, who has been named a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State.

title: Samuels Weighs Good and the Bad
description: After one year on the job as the president of the North American Soccer League, Howard Samuels says, he has finally had his eyes opened. People had warned him beforehand about certain obstinate franchise owners and about the byzantine politics of the United States Soccer Federation, but, he said yesterday, ''I didn't believe them.''

title: DOLPHINS TRYING TO FILL VOIDS WITH 2 OFFENSIVE PLAYERS HURT
description: The Miami Dolphins used a familiar combination to defeat the Buffalo Bills last Sunday: A strong defense and Uwe von Schamann, whose four field goals accounted for all the points in the 12-0 victory.

title: FLOOD OF BOGUS I.D. PAPERS IMPERILS PLAN TO CURB ALIENS
description: An enormous traffic in fraudulent documents among illegal aliens in this country threatens to defeat the intention of major legislation now pending in Congress to change the immigration system, according to officials in this border state and in Washington.

title: Vesco Inquiry Is Requested
description: Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling called today for a high-level panel to investigate a report that Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, was trafficking in drugs with the help of Bahamian politicians. Mr. Pindling called the report by NBC News ''unfounded and baseless'' and asked President Reagan to initiate a Federal inquiry to determine the source of the NBC News account.

title: Key Rates
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SUNSETS BY CASSETTE AND SCENTS VIA DISK
description: In Corona del Mar, Calif., Kathy and Jeff Joseph, who live with their three children in a converted Greyhound bus, find it soothing to watch 27 fish swim around in the aquarium, which they liken to a constantly changing piece of art. In Opa-Locka, Fla., Donna McKenna, the city's Vice Mayor, says of her light show: ''It calms me down when we're having dinner or at home working on the city budget.'' And late at night in Altus, Okla., Beverly Smith finds it ''relaxing and cozy'' to sit in her living room in front of her crackling fireplace, and she is now planning to buy a waterfall.

title: DIGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $3.1 million from repurchase of debentures. c-Net income.

title: Statistics on Troublemakers
description: Almost two of every three people arrested after the Diana Ross concert in Central Park live in Brooklyn.

title: Chief's Son Moves Up To No. 2 Spot at Beker
description: One company that is making the line of succession to its top executive position clear is Beker Industries, a manufacturer of phosphate-based fertilizers. Yesterday, Erol Beker, the company's 64-year-old founder, chairman and chief executive officer, announced the promotion of his son, Erol Y. Beker, 27, to president and chief operating officer.

title: Hamsho Facing Nevada Inquiry
description: The Nevada State Athletic Commission today ordered the middleweight boxer Mustafa Hamsho and his corner to show why his license should not be suspended for his using adrenaline, an unauthorized hormone, during his 10-round decision over Wilfred Benitez.

title: Conoco Discovery
description: Conoco Inc. said it had discovered ''significant accumulations'' of high- quality crude oil in deep waters of the Gulf of Mexico off the coast of Louisiana. The discovery is in Green Canyon block 184, about 170 miles southwest of New Orleans, in water depths ranging from a little more than 850 feet to almost 2,000 feet. The block is owned equally by Conoco, the operator, and the Occidental Petroleum Corporation's Cities Service subsidiary and Getty Oil Inc.

title: SOME BASIC STRATEGIES FOR EATING AT FESTIVALS
description: Eating successfully at any one of New York's jam-packed street festivals requires a special talent, especially if the fair happens to be the dazzling extravaganza that is the San Gennaro celebration. Running until Sept. 19, this fair honoring the patron saint of Naples stretches along Mulberry Street almost half a mile from Chinatown north through Little Italy. And though carnival games and rides will line those streets, the real attraction will be the food stands.

title: HERE, THE U.S. ATTORNEY IS BOTH FEDERAL AND LOCAL
description: When a visitor slips on the steps of a monument here, the United States Attorney for the District of Columbia will defend the Government from the tourist's lawsuit. If the visitor is mugged on a trip to this city, the United States Attorney will pursue the crime and prosecute the attacker.

title: Closings by Toro
description: The Toro Company, a leading maker and marketer of lawn care and irrigation equipment, said it planned to close plants in the Minnesota communities of Willmar and Fairmont and transfer those operations to and transfer those operations to plants in Shakopee, Minn., and Tomah, Wis. ''This action is consistent with the company's two-year program to restore Toro to profitability by making the most effective use of its assets,'' said Toro's president, Kendrick B. Melrose.

title: Man Gored by Deer Dies
description: The 89-year-old owner of a mink ranch has been found gored to death by a deer in a small nature preserve he maintained near his property. The rancher, Raymond Nelson of rural Verona, died of multiple head injuries apparently caused by antlers, a coroner reported. Mr. Nelson's son, Fred, found the body in the fenced-in preserve where about 30 deer are kept and shot an 11-point buck believed responsible.

title: Fannie Mae Sets Rates for 2 Issues
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association announced an interest rate of 10 percent for $1 billion of new six- month debentures due March 12, 1984, and 11.55 percent for $700 million of three-and-a-half-year debentures due March 10, 1987. Both issues are offered at a price of 100 through various securities firms.

title: Miss Honegger Insists On Talk With Deaver
description: Barbara Honegger, the former Justice Department employee who quit after assailing White House attitudes toward women, said today she would insist on seeing the deputy White House chief of staff, Michael K. Deaver, not an aide, to discuss women's issues.

title: Movie and TV Unions Approve a 3-Year Pact
description: Members of the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, voting as a combined union, have overwhelmingly approved a three-year contract with movie and television producers.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Well Servicing Corp., Dallas, said its American Pipeline unit completed a long-term gas sales contract with Big Three Industries to supply gas to a Big Three plant near Houston.

title: A Husband's Reaction To Downing of Airliner
description: Dr. Michael Kole's wife was killed on the South Korean airliner that was shot down by the Russians, and yesterday he stood across from the United Nations to speak publicly about it.

title: TV PIONEER IN DOCUMENTARY TECHNIQUES
description: Lou Hazam, who developed many of the documentary techniques in use on television today as a writer and producer for NBC News, died Tuesday at Holy Cross Hospital in Silver Spring, Md. He was 72 years old and lived in Silver Spring.

title: CAESARS WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including income of $113,000 for the quarter and a loss of $1,787,000 for the year from discontinued operations, an extraordinary loss of $10,617,000 for the quarter and year from an exchange offer, income from minority interest of $515,000 for the quarter and $1,210,000 for the year and a tax credit of $683,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $7,832,000 from discontinued operations, income from minority interest of $512,000 and a tax credit of $3,045,000. d-Net income after a loss of $8,680,000 from discontinued operations and income from minority interest of $2,068,000.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Director's tale of passion in Paris suburb.

title: WEDTECH CORP reports earnings for 6mo to June 30
SUN ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After tax credits of $152,000 for the quarter and $598,000 for the 9 months.

title: THE OTHER U.S. DEFICIT: IDLE PEOPLE AND PLANTS
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: 49ers Rout Vikings by 48-17
description: Joe Montana threw a career-high four touchdown passes in the first half tonight to lead the San Francisco 49ers to a 48-17 victory over the Minnesota Vikings.

title: SENATOR AND A SOCIALITE MUGGED
description: Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut and Amanda Burden were robbed at gunpoint yesterday evening near Gracie Mansion while on their way to meet Mayor Koch, a spokesman for the police said.

title: MAKERS OF HEARING AIDS SEE WIDER ACCEPTANCE
description: Hearing aids have never been something that people want to be seen wearing. But when President Reagan wore one in public for the first time Wednesday, the industry that makes the devices got a boost in its long battle for public acceptance.

title: FIRE MAY UNVEIL MYSTERIES OF CUSTER
description: When Lieut. Col. George Armstrong Custer led the Seventh Cavalry along the banks of the Little Bighorn River, many of the reasons for his battlefield actions died with him and his 215 soldiers.

title: YURI, YOU HAVE MADE OUR JOB MUCH HARDER
description: Dear Yuri V. Andropov

title: Economic Scene; U.S. Gains In Technology
description: TALK has it that the United States is losing ground in the race to develop the fast-growth, high-technology industries critical to economic success. But the evidence mustered by economists tends to support the opposite thesis: That we have a longstanding comparative advantage in what ought to be called ''high-creativity'' industries.

title: Cable TV Appointment
description: The merged Showtime/The Movie Channel cable programming service has named Mike Weinblatt president and chief operating officer. Mr. Weinblatt, a longtime NBC-TV executive, had been president of Showtime Entertainment, a subsidiary of Viacom International.

title: Michigan Power Sells Revenue-Backed Bonds
description: The Michigan Public Power Agency yesterday became the first large power authority of its kind to sell bonds in the public market since mid-June. At that time, some investors abandoned the market after the Washington State Supreme Court pushed the Washington Public Power Supply System into default on $2.25 billion of bonds outstanding.

title: Barber's Special Day
description: In the precise world fo pro football, two seconds can seem like a lifetime when a man is fending off an opponent, and seven seconds can seem like an eternity. To his delight, Larry Pasquale, who coaches the special teams for the Jets, discovered that a block by Marion Barber last Sunday lasted ''at least seven seconds.''

title: 'CITY NEWS' BILL
description: ''CITY NEWS,'' written, directed and edited by David Fishelson and Zoe Zinman, is a comedy about an ambitious young editor of a New York City underground paper and his rise to fame and power by drawing a weekly cartoon about his love affair with a young woman named Daphne.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: ART: FOUR GALLERIES PRESENT GROUP EXHIBITIONS
description: SOME group shows, like those now at Davis & Langdale, 746 Madison Avenue, at 65th Street, and Schoelkopf, 825 Madison Avenue, at 69th Street, are essentially profiles of the galleries' stables. Others are composed around themes, as in ''Paintings of the 50's'' at Marilyn Pearl, 38 East 57th Street, while still others are miscellanies - for example, the collection of 19th- and 20th-century prints at Fitch- Febvrel, 5 East 57th Street.

title: REAGAN ACTS TO CLOSE DOWN AEROFLOT'S 2 OFFICES IN U.S.
description: President Reagan requested the Civil Aeronautics Board today to close the two American offices of Aeroflot, the Soviet airline, and suspend its right to sell tickets through American carriers.

title: DEUKMEJIAN SEEKS CONVICTS RELEASE
description: Gov. George Deukmejian, who was elected on a campaign platform calling for harsher treatment of criminals, is seeking to release thousands of ''nonviolent'' inmates from the state's prisons before their sentences expire because of what he calls dangerous overcrowding.

title: Connecticut Judge Limits Klan Rally
description: A Superior Court judge has granted Stratford's request for restrictions on a Ku Klux Klan rally planned for Saturday.

title: OPTIMISM ON OUTLAYS
description: Business executives are planning to cut spending for expansion and modernization this year by 2.3 percent, after adjustment for inflation, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Alf Landon, at 96, Eligible To Collect Life Insurance
description: Alf Landon's long life has paid off in dollars.

title: Caesars World Loss
description: Narrows Caesars World Inc., citing a $10 million loss from a recent share exchange offer, yesterday reported a deficit of $8.4 million in the fourth quarter ended July 31, Nonetheless, the loss was narrower than its $14.1 million loss in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Class Acts; Safe and Sorry
description: Back in June, we gave worms to contractors in New York who were storing building materials on city streets or walkways at great inconvenience or danger to pedestrians. We also held out apples to the inspectors who pursued violators, often vainly.

title: For Children Plays and Tales
description: FRACTURED FABLES, modernized fairy tales by Ann Lyon and Charles Anderson, with music by Anita Montgomery, performed by the Not Ready for Video Players, six actors and singers, Sunday at 2 P.M. at Belvedere Castle in Central Park, 79th Street, south of the Great Lawn. Free. Bring a blanket for seating. THE NIGHTINGALE, a tale by Hans Christian Andersen, will be told by Diane Wolkstein Saturday at 11 A.M. at the Hans Christian Andersen Statue, Central Park, at 72d Street near Fifth Avenue. Free.

title: THE TEACHERS' PET PROJECT
description: At first glance they can be mistaken for typical tennis fans shouting encouragement to their favorite player. But it is when they begin to move their hands like a Navy signalman waving a semaphore or when they are able to command a player's attention with a raised eyebrow or a nod of the head that it becomes apparent that they have more than a rooting interest at stake.

title: A FESTIVAL OF FESTIVALS, STARTING WITH THE VENERABLE FEAST OF SAN GENNARO
description: The Feast of San Gennaro, the oldest and grandest of New York's street fairs, will be in full swing this weekend as thousands jam the narrow lanes of Little Italy to feast on fried sausage and cannoli, to try their luck at wheels of fortune and to hear the crooning of Neapolitan balladeers. Throughout the metropolitan area this weekend the feast's progeny, in a host of ethnic and other guises, from an Irish fair in Coney Island to an Armenian festival in Manhattan, will blossom in streets and parks, enticing New Yorkers, their neighbors and visitors to the city with food, music and merriment, as if to prove that winter's chill is still far off.

title: ENGLISH SPEAKING MOUSE THRIVES IN TOKYO
description: There may be no kimonos, but there are plenty of T-shirts with messages in English. Raw fish is scarce, but not pizza or fried chicken or other exotica. The twang of the shamisen is not to be heard, but the lines form at the right, folks, for the Dixieland band. Even the fellows in the chipmunk costumes do not bow, but hold out their paws to shake children's hands.

title: STUDY FINDS LOW '82 LEVEL FOR UNEMPLOYMENT CLAIMS
description: Despite record unemployment, proportionately fewer Americans received unemployment benefits in the thick of the recession last year than in any other recession since World War II, according to a study to be published Friday by the Brookings Institution, a public policy research organization here.

title: TELECREDIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
THE RAVAGE OF RHETORIC
description: The first question American visitors ask about France these days is whether things are really as bad as they sound.

title: 2 TO SHOW THEIR ROOTS WITH DOWN-HOME MUSIC
description: WHEN rock-and-roll became America's dominant popular music, regional styles all but disappeared. With the same top-40 songs dominating the radio in New York and Atlanta and Santa Fe, bands that want to make the big time do their best to eliminate local references and local accents. But as those local accents grow increasingly rare and exotic, they are all the more prized; an unlikely coalition of traditionalists and hedonists still supports musicians who show their roots. Two of those musicians - the Memphis piano man Rosco Gordon and the Louisiana zydeco accordionist Queen Ida - will be playing irrepressible, down-home music in Manhattan clubs this weekend.

title: Bankruptcy Move In Butcher Case
description: The First Tennessee Bank of Knoxville and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation have petitioned to force the wife of the bankrupt financier C. H. Butcher Jr. into involuntary bankruptcy.

title: RAPE CHARGES DISMISSED AFTER PROSECUTION DELAY
description: Charges that a Brooklyn man raped four women and tried to rape a fifth have been dismissed by a judge who said his ruling was mandated because the Brooklyn District Attorney's office had not been ready to try the case within the required six months.

title: FINANCING VOLUME SETS MARK
description: The volume of financing throughout the nation, mostly through borrowing, soared to a record level in the second quarter, the Federal Reserve's latest study shows. The rising demand for credit, if it continues, could push up interest rates and threaten the economic recovery.

title: U.S. Backs Bank On Advisory Unit
description: In another move that weakens the barriers separating the banking and securities industries, the Comptroller of the Currency has authorized a Texas bank to operate an investment advisory service.

title: Comings and Goings
description: John McEnroe, Peter Fleming, Gene Meyer and Eliot Teltscher have been named to the United States Davis Cup team that will meet Ireland from Sept. 30 to Oct. 2. . . . Coach Foge Fazio of Pitt chose John Congemi over Chris Jelic to replace the Panthers' injured quarterback, John Cummings . . . . Steve Garvey, who has been out with an injured thumb since July 29, said he did not expect to return to the San Diego Padres' lineup this year. . . . Dane Iorg, the St. Louis Cardinal utility player who had been sidelined for a month with a wrist injury earlier in the season, broke a finger during a game against the Pittsburgh Pirates Wednesday night and will be out indefinitely. . . . Vagas Ferguson, the running back who had been dropped by the New England Patriots, signed with the Houston Oilers.

title: YANKEES DEFEAT BREWERS
description: For the second consecutive game, Rich Gossage was called on tonight with no outs in the eighth inning and the tying run at the plate. He was less effective this time, struggling in the eighth and creating another scare in the ninth, but nonetheless he preserved a 6-5 victory for Bob Shirley and the Yankees.

title: REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST OF AMERICA reports earnings for Year to June 30
LFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Net loss.

title: Habre Says the French Want to Partition Chad
description: President Hissen Habre's Government issued a strong complaint today against France for not mounting direct operations against Libyan-backed rebels, and said the French wanted to partition Chad.

title: YUGOSLAVIA DEBT PACT REPORTED
description: Yugoslavia's 600 or so Western creditor banks are ready to sign a debt restructuring package that will include $600 million in fresh loans to buoy the nation's battered economy, Frankfurt bank sources said today.

title: Legal Path Cleared
description: Ruling that a professional ballplayer does not voluntarily accept the risks of playing on a wet field, a state judge has cleared the way for Elliott Maddox, the former Yankee outfielder, to seek $10 million in damages for a knee injury he suffered when he slipped in the mud while chasing a ball at Shea Stadium in 1975. The Yankees played at Shea that year because Yankee Stadium was being renovated.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Sharon Publications to Shapiro Budrow & Associates.

title: NORTON SIMON REPORTS DEFICIT; FLUOR NET TUMBLES BY 76.9%
description: Norton Simon Inc., citing the impact of several extraordinary items, reported yesterday that it lost $38 million in its fourth fiscal quarter ended June 30 contrasted with net income of $29 million, or $1.01 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: ROCKCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: All year-earlier figures were restated to reflect the acquisition of Martin & Stern Inc. on Feb. 4.

title: Florida Prisoner Wins Stay of Execution
description: A Federal appeals court granted an indefinite stay of execution today to a man who was scheduled to die in Florida's electric chair Friday for the fatal shooting of a policeman.

title: RESTAURANT
description: Exotic cuisines at modest prices. ALTHOUGH New York restaurants are unquestionably the most expensive in the country, it is also true that the city offers the widest and most diverting assortment of inexpensive eating places. Two cases in point are the restaurants reviewed today, one Vietnamese, the other Hungarian; together they prove that it is possible to eat for about $10 to $12 a person, or even less, and still do so with style.

title: Market Place; Quickening Pace Of Bank Mergers
description: WHEN it comes to merger activity, no other industry can compare with the feverish pace set lately by the nation's banks. Most acquisitions have occurred between banks and bank holding companies within the same state. But as barriers to interstate banking crumble, mergers have expanded beyond state boundaries.

title: Man Held in Abduction Of Girl, 3, in Colorado
description: A country club groundskeeper wanted in the kidnapping of a 3-year-old girl has surrendered to the police, the authorities say.

title: Soviet Ship Leaves Florida
description: A Soviet freighter that received a bomb threat while it was docked in Jacksonville Wednesday left today after a search failed to turn up any trace of explosives, the Coast Guard said. The threat delayed the departure of the ship, the Novovolynsk, for four hours.

title: FRIDAY, SEPT. 9, 1983
description: The Economy

title: ALL ROADS LEAD TO BUSY HUDSON VALLEY WEEKEND
description: Getting there is half the fun on almost every road north of New York City into the Hudson Valley this weekend. The alfalfa fields are emerald green, amber tassels crown tall green corn plants, maturing reddening apples contrast with the green leaves of the apple trees, and farmstands are bursting with sweet corn, peppers, tomatoes, pears and apples.

title: Welcome for Tortoise
description: Jalopy, the Staten Island Zoo's tortoise on wheels, got a ticker-tape welcome home yesterday, beginning at Borough Hall in St. George. In Arizona for three months, he had undergone radiation therapy for a malignant tumor.

title: New Kodak X-Ray Films
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it planned to introduce a new family of medical X-ray films, based on its new T-grain technology.

title: ONE APPROACH TO THE SHORTAGE OF MEN IS SHARING
description: Four years ago, when Audrey Chapman announced to her friends in New Haven that she was moving to Washington for a new job, they prepared her for the worst.

title: Martin Fans
description: Ronald Gay, who is disabled and unemployed, didn't have enough money to take his family to the recent Yankees-Brewers games in Milwaukee, so he did the next-best thing. He took his three children to the Pfister Hotel so they could at least get a glimpse of the Yankee players.

title: U.S. ACID RAIN STANCE ENCOURAGES CANADIAN
description: After meeting today with William D. Ruckelshaus, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, Canada's new Environment Minister said he had found an ''encouraging'' change in the United States attitude on the acid rain problem.

title: Airlines Serving Moscow
description: Following is a list of Western European airlines and other non-Soviet bloc carriers and the flights they operate in and out of Moscow: British Airways - Four flights a week, and a weekly London- Moscow-Tokyo service. Air France - Five weekly flights and a weekly Paris-Moscow-Tokyo flight, returning via New Delhi and Moscow.

title: POPE SAID TO PLAN VIENNA CALL FOR CHURCH FREEDOM
description: Two days before Pope John Paul II begins a four-day visit to Austria, his host, Franz Cardinal K"onig of Vienna, said the Pope would deliver a call from the Austrian capital to the neighboring Communist countries calling for religious freedom and a role for the Roman Catholic Church in promoting unity between Europe's East and West.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Class Acts; Phoning Home
description: The opening of school is a time of special anxiety for parents who have found that when their children fail to appear at a New York City high school, nobody calls. Only an occasional postcard, arriving long after the truancy, informs the parent.

title: AUCTIONS
description: PAUL MELLON, the 76-year-old art collector, philanthropist and chairman of the National Gallery of Art in Washington, is selling what he describes as a ''cross-section'' of his collection of 19th- and 20th-century paintings, drawings, watercolors and sculptures. The 41 artworks, which will be auctioned Nov. 15 at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, are valued conservatively at $8 million, according to Christopher J. Burge, Christie's fine-arts specialist, who announced the sale this week. Up for bidding will be 32 paintings, four sculptures and five drawings and watercolors, most of which are from the Impressionist, Post-Impressionist and modern periods, and were purchased in the 1950's and 60's.

title: Latin Debt Discussion
description: The United States and other members of the Organization of American States agreed today to support the creation of a special committee to discuss ways of easing the foreign debt burden of Latin American and Caribbean countries.

title: 'LOTTERY!' SERIES, TENNIS AND BOXING
description: TELEVISION has a habit of repeating itself. In the 1950's, a series called ''The Millionaire'' had a run of five years, fulfilling the fantasies of viewers who watched ordinary folks suddenly coming into lots of money. Now, in this very new season, there is ''Lottery!'' The resemblance is more than coincidental. The world may change, but its basic fantasies go on forever.

title: 2 NEW FILMS FROM FRANCE
description: ''LUCK is like a butterfly,'' says the tough, doomy young heroine of ''Lucie sur Seine,'' directed by Jean- Louis Bertuccelli. ''It lives and dies too fast.'' Lucie, who can also quote Rimbaud, has been disconnected by the dreariness of life in the working- class Paris suburb where she lives with her slovenly mother, her Arabic stepfather and her adolescent half-brother, who shows porn films to his classmates for profit. Lucie is lost, lost.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advest Group Inc., Hartford, has elected to its board of directors Richard G. Dooley, executive vice president and chief investment officer of the Massachussetts Life Insurance Co., and Corine T. Norgaard, professor of accounting at the University of Connecticut.

title: MATTEL REPORTS LOSING $156.1 MILLION IN QUARTER
description: Mattel Inc., whose video game business declined sharply last spring, yesterday announced a loss of $156.1 million for the fiscal second quarter, substantially more than the company had projected.

title: Tides Win, 12-1, Lead Series, 1-0
description: Gary Rajsich hit 2 home runs and a single, drove in 4 runs and scored 3 as the Tidewater Tides trounced the Richmond Braves, 12-1, tonight and took a 1-0 lead in their three-of-five- game series for the International League playoff championship.

title: Shipyard Woes Cited by E.E.C.
description: The Commission of the European Economic Community said today that the slump in the shipbuilding industry was likely to get worse even if the world economy rebounded. Stagnant demand, falling world prices and excess capacity prevent a comeback for the industry, it said, and urged the 10 member nations of the Common Market to become more competitive.

title: Technology; Tariff Plan
description: The United States has proposed to Japan that they remove their mutual 4.2 percent tariffs on semiconductors as a way to expand semiconductor trade between the two countries, Japanese officials said today.

title: EX-GOV. EVANS NAMED TO JACKSON SENATE SEAT
description: Gov. John Spellman today appointed former Gov. Daniel J. Evans to serve temporarily in the Senate seat left vacant by the death of Henry M. Jackson.

title: LATE RALLY ENABLES DOW TO RISE BY 2.03
description: A late rally sparked by a speech by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan enabled stock prices yesterday to finish with small gains in slow trading.

title: Quick Studies
description: The Seattle Seahawks, who play the Jets at Shea Stadium this Sunday, are a young and improved team, and they may have another mark of distinction: leading the National Football League in the number of former college basketball stars who made the final 49-man roster.

title: CAESARS NEW JERSEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FLIGHT 7 AND THE MX
description: Right-wing hawks are calling President Reagan, once one of their own, ''pusillanimous'' (from the Latin pusillus, meaning ''very small,'' and animus, meaning ''soul'') in his response to the destruction of Korean Air Lines flight 7 by a Soviet fighter plane.

title: Brighter Outlooks
description: Five years after he was paralyzed from the neck down, Darryl Stingley, the former New England Patriot receiver, says he is happy to be alive and thinks you should be, too. At a Boston news conference to promote his new book, ''Happy to Be Alive,'' Stingley, who was hurt in a 1978 exhibition game when he was tackled by Jack Tatum of the Oakland Raiders, said he was still bitter about Tatum, who has never contacted him since the incident, but had been supported well by his family, friends and religious faith.

title: A QUIET SUNDAY AT LYNDHURST WITH 3,013 DOGS
description: There will be shaggy dogs and smooth-coated ones, big and little, representing 130 breeds or varieties Sunday at Lyndhurst, the national landmark overlooking the Hudson near Tarrytown, N.Y. They will be among the 3,013 dogs at the 66th Westchester Kennel Club show, the largest dog event to be held in the metropolitan area in four years.

title: TEXT OF REAGAN LETTER TO C.A.B. CHAIRMAN
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's letter today to Dan McKinnon, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, outlining new sanctions against the Soviet airline Aeroflot, as made public by the White House:

title: READING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $95,000 for the quarter and $106,000 for the 6 months and extraordinary credits of $77,000 for the quarter and $252,000 for the 6 months. The 1982 figures are restated to reflect a change to LIFO from FIFO inventory accounting at Imperial Clevite Inc., an affiliate.

title: People Express Houston Flights
description: People Express Airlines said it would begin nonstop service between Houston and Newark Oct. 1, and charge 70 percent less than competing airlines.

title: Saad Muhammad's Opponent Is Chosen
description: The program will not be the way it was originally designed, but Madison Square Garden has been able to come up with a live boxing card for its main arena tonight preceding the closed- circuit telecast of the World Boxing Association's junior welterweight title fight between Aaron Pryor and Alexis Arg"uello in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: SAVIN BUSINESS MACHINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
MANET SHOW, A NEW VISION OF THE ARTIST
description: NO one has to tell us that Edouard Manet (1832- 83) is one of the ''great'' painters of the 19th century. We think of him art-historically as a father of Impressionism, and we've seen our quota of Manet masterpieces in reproduction or in museums here and abroad - among them ''Boating,'' the photographically cropped closeup of a straw-hatted sailor and a woman in a sailboat; ''The Balcony,'' a striking group of three persons, most notably the painter Berthe Morisot, on a green-railed balcony, and ''A Bar at the Folies Berg ere,'' in which a melancholy barmaid confronts us head on, backed by a mirror that reflects a sparkling crowd of pleasure seekers. Most of us ''know'' Manet casually by his major icons, in the same way that we know other artists of historical importance - Rembrandt, Goya, Picasso - by theirs.

title: Key Soviet Official Arrives in Peking
description: The first high- ranking official of the Soviet Union to be invited here on a state visit in more than two decades arrived today for a week of talks with Chinese officials.

title: JEWELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss of $51,000 for the quarter and 6 months from discontinued operations. c-Including gains from discontinued operations of $9,000 for the quarter and $7,000 for the 6 months.

title: Soviet Embezzler Executed
description: Georgi Saakadze, director of a wool factory in Soviet Georgia, has been executed by a firing squad after being found guilty of embezzlement, according to the Tbilisi newspaper Zarya Vostoka. He was arrested in November 1981 when water-main inspectors found that pipes had been insulated with cheap fiber glass material provided by Mr. Saakadze instead of high-quality wool felt ordered and paid for. The investigation showed that he and his accomplices had been accumulating the felt and selling it off privately.

title: Reservoir Levels 8% Below Normal
description: A hot and dry summer upstate has pushed the water levels in the city's 17 reservoirs to 8 percent below normal, officials said yesterday.

title: F.B.I. FILED REPORTS OF EINSTEIN AS A SPY AND KIDNAP PLOTTER
description: A file on Albert Einstein shows the Federal Bureau of Investigation checked reports that he was behind a supposed Communist plot to take over Hollywood, the leader of a spy ring and a participant in the Lindbergh kidnapping, according to a researcher.

title: Development Loans
description: Multilateral development banks are providing more contingency and local financing to developing countries in the face of growing economic and political uncertainties, an energy adviser to the Asian Development Bank said today. The adviser, Jayanta Madhab, said the viability of development projects was increasingly unpredictable because of changes in the world economic environment, lower oil prices and inflation.

title: Reynolds Studies Sea-Land Spinoff
description: R. J. Reynolds Industries appointed a special panel today to investigate the feasibility of selling its ocean transportation operation, Sea- Land Industries Investments Inc., to its shareholders.

title: COOPER LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including income of $1,009,000 for the quarter and $1,699,000 for the 9 months from minority interest in a subsidiary.

title: MANHATTAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
LENDL AND ARIAS GAIN SEMIFINALS
description: In the 15 years since the United States tennis championships became the United States Open, the late rounds of the men's singles division have been the domain of wily veterans, players of experience and stature. But last night, a young player joined that elite group.

title: 3 Deaths May Lead To an Exhumation
description: Authorities said today that they were considering exhuming the body of the second of three women who died in a garden apartment in Montclair since November 1981.

title: DON'T BLAME ISRAEL FOR LEBANON'S TROUBLES
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTON SIMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $25,707,000 for the quarter and $18,605,000 for the year and extraordinary losses of $26,900,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net income after loss from discontinued operations of $4,508,000 and an extraordinary gain of $23,215,000 on the extinguishment of debt. d-After gain of $22,750,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $28,650,000. The net income for the latest year which after preferred dividend requirements results in a fully diluted loss per share.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from London yesterday misidentified the airline for which Robert Tweedy, the president of the International Federation of Air Line Pilots Associations, flies. He is a pilot for Aer Lingus.

title: ALL WORK AND NOW A LITTLE PLAY MAKE JAPAN FRET
description: While Americans celebrated Labor Day by taking last weekend off, Japanese were busy trying to decide whether they work too hard.

title: SOVIET BOOK FAIR STIRS CONTRASTING REACTIONS
description: The fourth Moscow International Book Fair opened here Tuesday with limited American participation but with works of Mao Zedong back on public display in the Soviet Union after an absence of two decades.

title: Lanier-Harris Accord
description: The Harris Corporation said it had reached a definitive agreement for its previously announced acquisition of Lanier Business Products Inc. Under terms of the deal, which is valued at about $378 million, Harris will issue 0.525 share of its common stock for each of the approximately 16.2 million Lanier shares outstanding. Harris, based in Melbourne, Fla., makes communication and information-processing systems. Lanier, based in Atlanta, makes office equipment, particularly word processors.

title: REAGAN PROPOSES SEX BIAS CHANGES
description: President Reagan, under criticism that he is insensitive to women's issues, proposed today to eliminate sexually discriminatory language from a number of Federal laws.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday DINAH WASHINGTON SALUTE

title: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 9, 1983
description: International

title: Merle Middleton Odgers, 83, Former President of Bucknell
description: Merle Middleton Odgers, president emeritus of Bucknell University, died Tuesday at the Oak Cove Health Center in Clearwater, Fla., after a brief illness. He was 83 years old and had lived at the Oak Cove retirement home since 1975.

title: 2 ARE REPORTED KILLED IN CHILE PROTESTS
description: Chilean riot policemen used tear gas and water cannons to break up anti-Government demonstrations today. One person was reported killed in a Santiago neighborhood and scores of protesters were injured as the police charged into crowds gathered in the downtown area. Another death was reported in Valparaiso, 80 miles west of the capital.

title: STAFF AND POLICY SHIFTS AT MUSIC HALL
description: Radio City Music Hall Productions announced yesterday that Bernard Gersten had been ''let go'' Tuesday as executive producer and vice president. Mr. Gersten was the most senior of ''less than 25 people'' who were ''let go,'' according to Mike Walker, the organization's vice president for marketing.

title: IBRAHIM ABBOUD, 82, WAS SUDAN'S LEADER FROM 1958 TO 1964
description: Gen. Ibrahim Abboud, who seized power in the Sudan in 1958 and resigned six years later under civilian pressure, died yesterday in Khartoum. He was 82 years old.

title: LET'EM TAKE STEROIDS
description: The widespread use of anabolic steroids by athletes is upsetting to many people, but it is not clear why. The misgivings appear to be based more on vague, moralistic feelings than on rational analysis.

title: President Leaving Dome Petroleum
description: William E. Richards resigned yesterday as president and director of Dome Petroleum Ltd. and its associated companies. The step clears the way for the new chairman and chief executive, 55-year-old J. Howard Macdonald, to stamp his own management style on the financially troubled group, which is based in Calgary, Alberta.

title: Solid Concepts of Art At Columbus Circle
description: Was it Stonehenge sprouting on Columbus Circle?

title: FIGHTING IN LEBANON: BALANCE OF FORCES
description: American and other intelligence officers say there is evidence that the Syrians and their allies in Lebanon have been considering their military choices in the confrontation with the multinational peacekeeping force and the regular army in Lebanon. Signal intercepts and individual reports reflect reasonable confidence, the informants said, that the current harassment of the peacekeeping force of United States marines and French, Italian and British troops can continue without punitive reaction and that the Lebanese Army will prove incapable of driving the Lebanese Moslem Druse militiamen from their present positions.

title: Continental Illinois Stock
description: The Continental Illinois Corporation's 1,750,000 shares of adjustable-rate preferred stock are being offered at $50 a share, with an initial dividend yield of 11.25 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The offering was increased from 1,250,000 shares. After Dec. 31, the dividend on the stock, which is rated A-3/BBBx, will change quarterly at one percentage point below the higher of the bond equivalent yield for 3-month bills, the yield for 10-year Treasury notes or the yield for 20-year Treasury bonds.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BLUE GUIDE NEW YORK. By Carol von Pressentin Wright. 623 pages. Ernest Benn-Norton. $22.50 (hard cover), $12.95 (paperback). NYCACCESS. By Richard Saul Wurman. 248 pages. Access Press. $11.95. NEW YORK: A Guide to the Metropolis (revised edition). By Gerard R. Wolfe. 516 pages. McGraw-Hill. $12.95.

title: U.S. ALLIES AGREE ON A REPROACH AT U.N.
description: The United States and its allies agreed on a draft resolution for the Security Council today that ''deeply deplores'' the destruction of the Korean airliner. The text, formally submitted late today, was deliberately fashioned to win the maximum number of Council votes. It did not ''condemn'' the Soviet action. Some Western diplomats predicted the document would be supported by 12 of the 15 members when the Council votes, perhaps as early as Friday.

title: SOVIET ENVOY PLEDGES TO GIVE JET DEBRIS TO JAPAN
description: The Soviet Ambassador said Thursday that his Government had found debris from the downed South Korean airliner in international waters and would turn the recovered materials and documents over to Japan, Foreign Ministry officials said.

title: Bridge: A Conservative Often Finds Defender's Role Compatible
description: Beginners who take lessons or read elementary textbooks might be forgiven for thinking that the standard for an opening bid is a fixed quantity: 13 high-card points or the equivalent.

title: OWNERS RESTRICT WORK ON SEABROOK NUCLEAR PLANT
description: Owners of the financially troubled Seabrook nuclear power plant voted today to halt virtually all work on the second of two planned reactors, raising the possibility it might be canceled.

title: BRZEZINSKI SAYS SOVIET IS DURABLE
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's national security adviser, said yesterday that he did not accept recent theories that the Soviet Union is bound to become more pluralistic and peaceful.

title: No-Contest Pleas In 14 Fire Deaths
description: A former mental patient accused of setting a tenement fire that killed 14 people pleaded no contest to arson- murder charges today as jury selection in his trial was about to begin.

title: Assets of Money Funds Increase Slightly
description: Assets of money market mutual funds climbed $13 million, to $164.9 billion, in the seven-day period that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: PHILIPPINE OPPOSITION SETS UP A UNITY PANEL
description: The leaders of more than 50 political groups opposing President Ferdinand E. Marcos today formed a coordinating committee of former senators and others to rally anti-Marcos forces nationwide.

title: Hickory Farms Goes To McCann-Erickson
description: Hickory Farms of Ohio, a chain of 560 shops in malls, will move its advertising account, expected to bill $10 million next year, to the Louisville, Ky., office of McCann-Erickson next Jan. 1.

title: U.S. SHIPS ENTER LEBANON FIGHTING SHELLING HILL SITE
description: A United States warship shelled an artillery emplacement in hills southeast of this capital today after gunners, presumed to be Moslem Druse militiamen, fired at the Beirut airport area where American Marines are based.

title: GIANTS CONCENTRATE ON PLAYING BETTER
description: Ali Haji-Sheikh, the rookie place- kicker, promises to do better in the second game of the regular season than he did in the opener. Doing better has been the theme this week for the Giants' coaches and players regarding their game Sunday against the Falcons in Atlanta.

title: FLUOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
STERLING EXTRUDER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $71,000, or 11 cents a share.

title: Old Faithful
description: In this era of sweet spots, midsize versus oversize, graphite versus wood and metal, it's a wonder that any tennis player ever finds the right racquet.

title: RATES RISE A BIT IN QUIET DAY
description: Interest rates on Treasury securities rose slightly in quiet trading yesterday. Analysts said there was no change in the economic or financial outlook to account for the negligible rise in rates.

title: No Headline
description: Lindsay Son Ordered to Serve Community for Cocaine Sale

title: DANCE: AILEY REPERTORY
description: EVERY opening of a new season by the Riverside Dance Festival at the Theater of the Riverside Church is a happy event. This is true even when a less- than-superior program, as was the case Wednesday night, begins the series.

title: Pizza Time Restructuring
description: Joseph F. Keenan, president and chief operating officer of Pizza Time Theater Inc., is resigning amid a reorganization that follows the company's first loss.

title: 20-YEAR SAGA OF LITTLE HOUSE THAT COULDN'T
description: Some say there is a 1956 Chevrolet in the basement of the empty house on Avenue M in Brooklyn. Or a terrarium. Or neither of the above.

title: Welch Wins 6th In a Row
description: Mike Marshall hit a three-run home run and Bob Welch allowed only four hits over eight innings as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Cincinnati Reds, 5-2, tonight.

title: Indictment Set in Fraud Case
description: A 62-year-old businessman accused of passing himself off as a wealthy international financier was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Manhattan. He is charged with taking part in a scheme to defraud the Small Business Administration and Barclays Bank of New York of at least $1.6 million.

title: MARION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The year-earlier results reflect accounting change for oil and gas operations.

title: More Rent Money for the Poor
description: In the wake of his dispute with Mayor Koch about the conditions in which New York houses homeless families, Governor Cuomo promises to seek a 25 percent increase in the welfare rent allowance. For 540,000 families on public assistance throughout the state, and especially for the city's homeless, that increase is long overdue.

title: WHY CON ED OUGHT NOT TO BURN COAL
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET SEEMS UNWILLING TO BAR FUTURE DOWNING
description: The Soviet Union gave a strong indication today that that it would resist Western moves to obtain guarantees that civilian airliners intruding into its airspace would not in the future be shot down.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The caption on a United Press International photograph on page one of the Times yesterday incorrectly identified American mourners at memorial service in Seoul. They were Mr. and Mrs. Joe Munder.

title: Oilfield Strike Is Ended
description: Production resumed at the Norwegian-British Statfjord oilfield in the North Sea today after a five-day strike by catering workers ended late Wednesday night.

title: 63 Demonstrators Hurt In Indian Protest
description: At least 63 people, some of them policemen, were injured today in an anti- Government demonstration by Communist supporters in the northern state of Punjab, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: Advertising; Eye Patch Lives On at Hathaway
description: WHEN the creative people at the Silverman Mower agency in Syracuse were studying the possible directions they could take their new Hathaway shirt account, they thought of the time-tested testimonial approach. But consumer research told them the man with the eye patch still had a ''residual equity.'' What to do?

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 9, 1983
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: SEAGRAM CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes $22,501,000, or 25 cents a share, for the quarter and $31,475,000, or 35 cents a share, for the 6 months, from equity in unremitted earnings of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. c-Includes $18,778,000, or 21 cents a share, for the quarter and $33,665,000, or 38 cents a share, for the 6 months, from equity in unremitted earnings of Du Pont.All amounts are in U.S. currency.

title: JOHN E. PFRIEM
description: John E. Pfriem, president of The Post Publishing Company, died Wednesday in Bridgeport Hospital after a short illness.

title: Althea Following in Landaluce's Steps
description: Five nice colts will contest the Futurity tomorrow at Belmont Park, but just like last year, the most exciting 2-year-olds this year are fillies, not colts. Once again, the filly to watch is one of the first daughters of a new stallion and she is trained by Wayne Lukas.

title: Secret Ingredient
description: Some enterprising merchants in Newport, R.I., have been turning the hot Australia II keel controversy into some cool profits. While the American and Australian crews prepare for the final 1983 America's Cup races beginning next Tuesday off that coastal resort, secret-keel merchandise is doing a brisk business on Thames Street, along the dock area.

title: REPORT SAYS OSSINING GUARD PROBABLY SPARKED UPRISING
description: Although many ''troublesome conditions'' contributed to an inmate uprising at the state prison at Ossining last January, the disturbance was probably ignited by disciplinary actions taken by a Correctional Services Department sergeant, a state report said yesterday.

title: MAYOR MAKES DRUG ARREST PART OF HIS JOB
description: Frank B. Priore, the Mayor of this Morris County community, has a penchant for police work.

title: SOFTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
4 Killed in Crash in Bavaria
description: A bus-truck collision on a Bavarian highway killed four Cypriots who held British citizenship, the police said today. More than 40 people were injured in the accident, in which a London-bound bus parked by the side of the road was rammed from behind by a truck.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I've been on this spot for 33 years. I came to America with one quarter in my pocket and I became a success.

title: ENERGY IS THE RESIDUE OF PRYOR'S ANGER
description: All that has happened recently to Aaron Pryor does not bode well for Alexis Arg"uello.

title: More Time Needed
description: Terry Bradshaw, the Pittsburgh Steelers' quarterback, who has been slowly recovering from elbow surgery, said yesterday that it might be two months before he could rejoin the team. ''I'm looking at about six to eight weeks,'' said the 34-year-old Bradshaw, who has seen no action since the start of training camp.

title: PRESLEY COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Witnesses Sought In Dodd Robbery
description: New York City detectives questioned witnesses and attempted to find others as they searched yesterday for the men who robbed at gunpoint Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut and Amanda Burden on Thursday evening two blocks from Gracie Mansion.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: OF KNIVES AND FORKS AND AMERICAN MANNERS
description: Because most American customs and rules of etiquette are drawn from those of Europe, any that differ are of special interest. How did the differences come about and what do they represent, if anything?

title: No Headline
description: In weeklong discussions at the Organization of American States meeting here, delegates from both the United States and debtor nations have arrived on common ground on the causes and dimensions of Latin America's $300 billion debt.

title: American Symphony Plans Drive on WQXR
description: The American Symphony Orchestra will conduct a subscription drive tomorrow from 9 A.M. to 2 P.M. on WQXR AM and FM.

title: U.S. STEEL PLANS LAYOFFS AND MAY CLOSE 3 PLANTS
description: The United States Steel Corporation plans to lay off 5,000 white-collar employees beginning next month, a senior executive for the nation's biggest steelmaker said yesterday.

title: New Dance Works
description: As it begins its third year, Performance Space 122, at 150 First Avenue, near Ninth Street, is putting a new policy into effect: artists in its dance, theater and performance events will also be co-producers, in effect, producing their own works. Today and tomorrow Paula Kellinger is presenting a dance program of new works in collaboration with Cathy Weis, who has made the video element.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF SOVIET OFFICIAL'S STATEMENT AND EXCERPTS FROM NEWS SESSION MARSHAL CALLS FLIGHT 7 A 'PROVOCATION PERPETRATED BY U.S. SECRET SERVICES'
description: Following are a full transcript of an opening statement and excerpts from the questions at a news conference in the Foreign Ministry Press Center in Moscow yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times. The conference was held by Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, chief of the Soviet General Staff, with Viktor Litvinsky translating from the Russian. OPENING STATEMENT

title: TYLAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Transactions
description: COLLEGE N.C.A.A. - Announced selection of the Carrier Dome at Syracuse University as the site of the 1984 national collegiate track and field indoor championships March 9-10. The meet had been held in Detroit and Pontiac, Mich., for 19 consecutive years.

title:
PATENTS;
Method for correcting Radio Signal Distortion
description: A method of distinguishing between two types of fading in radio signals, so that corrections can be made, has been invented by Peter D. Karabinis of Bell Telephone Laboratories in North Andover, Mass.

title: PARTNERS OIL reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-earlier figures are restated.

title: POP SEPTET: AIR SUPPLY AT RADIO CITY
description: The Australian septet Air Supply, heirs to the Bee Gees and to the early- 1970's soft-rock group Bread, is among the most successful groups to manufacture pop music that is the esthetic equivalent of cheap candy.

title: AFTER YEAR OF BOYCOTT, PUSH ENDORSES ANHEUSER-BUSCH PLANS
description: Operation PUSH, the organization headed by the Rev. Jesse Jackson, announced yesterday that it was endorsing a program of ''enhanced opportunities for black America'' put forward by the Anheuser-Busch Company, the brewer the civil rights group has been boycotting for the past year.

title: SOUTH AFRICA ACTS ON A CONSTITUTION
description: South Africa's white parliament completed action today on a newconstitution that would give nonwhites a role in the national Government for the first time in the country's history.

title: Saad Muhammad Wins in 10th
description: Beginning what he considers the start of a quest to regain the world light-heavyweight championship he lost in 1981, Matthew Saad Muhammad of Philadelphia stopped Larry Davis of Plainfield, N. J., in the 10th round last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: MARCADE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net income

title: Don't Slam the Housing Door
description: Nine Bronx housing groups feel that the door to possible housing help has been slammed shut. They hope at least to be considered for Federal subsidy funds that would create 600 units of low-rent housing.

title: SHUTTLE BACK AT CAPE AFTER QUICK TURNAROUND
description: The shuttle Challenger, fresh off its best space voyage yet, today rode a jumbo jet home to the Kennedy Space Center where it will be refitted for is next flight in January.

title: TRADING IS SLOW
description: Stock market prices closed moderately lower yesterday in slow trading, with some of the technology issues posting the biggest losses.

title: 2 PLANES ATTACK NICARAGUAN PORT
description: The Nicaraguan military command said today that two small planes had fired rockets at oil tanks at the Pacific port of Corinto.

title: HOLMES HAS A GOAL BEYOND PERFECTION
description: The games of chance that Larry Holmes plays do not involve money. He has been the World Boxing Council's heavyweight champion for five years, and the fortune he has earned will make retirement financially comfortable. No, the risks that Holmes takes when he gets into the ring nowadays involve his record, a perfect one so far.

title: American General Continental Stake
description: The American General Corporation reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission today that it has acquired 2,579,700 shares, or 5.1 percent, of the common shares of the Continental Corporation. American said the total amount owned includes 976,600 shares acquired on the New York Stock Exchange between June 30 and Aug. 31 at between $28.40 and $31.10 a share. Today, Continental closed at $33.25, up $1.75.

title: 4 Indicted in Death Of L.I. Jeweler
description: Four people, including two 16-year- old girls, have been indicted for the killing of Joseph Bellissimo, a jeweler who was stabbed 15 times and whose store set ablaze by robbers, authorities said today.

title: Joan E. Hewson Married To William H. Croke 2d
description: Joan E. Hewson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Hewson of New Canaan, Conn., was married in Nantucket, Mass., yesterday to William H. Croke 2d of Norwalk, Conn., son of Regis N. Croke of Valley Stream, L.I., and the late William H. Croke. The Rev. Herbert Stevens performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: Kean Signs Bill On Sentencings
description: Judges sentencing defendants convicted of crimes against the disabled or the elderly will have to take into consideration the age of the victim in determining the sentence under the terms of a new law signed here today by Governor Kean.

title: Inouye to Kissinger Panel
description: Senator Daniel K. Inouye, Democrat of Hawaii, has been named an adviser to President Reagan's commission on Central America, which is led by Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 10, 1983
description: Markets

title: AN EXTRAORDINARY EVENT IN MOSCOW
description: It was a scene for which old Moscow hands could not recall a precedent.

title: A.P. REPORTER QUITS SALVADOR AFTER DISPUTE
description: A reporter for The Associated Press left El Salvador today after the American Embassy told him his ''safety could not be assured.''

title: Queens Street Fair
description: Hollis, Queens, is a neighborhood of middle-class families in pretty houses. But through it slashes Hollis Avenue, a run-down commercial strip with a 40 percent vacancy rate.

title: ENDURING BASTION OF EXCLUSIVITY FOR 'GENTLEMEN'
description: It is Washington's oldest and most exclusive men's club, with a membership that has included such names as Elihu Root, Robert Todd Lincoln, John Hay, Henry Morgenthau Jr., Walter Lippmann, Dean Acheson, Adm. George Dewey, Paul Mellon, Henry Cabot Lodge and Henry A. Kissinger. Ten of its members have been nominated for the Presidency and six of them - Grant, Taft, Harding, Hoover and Theodore and Franklin D. Roosevelt - succeeded.

title: SOVIET SAYS ORDER TO DOWN JET CAME AT A LOCAL LEVEL
description: The chief of the Soviet General Staff, Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, said today that the decision to shoot down a Korean Air Lines 747 was made by a local commander and that it was ''not an accident or an error.''

title: Synthetic Fuels Officer Resigns
description: Jimmy Bowden, executive vice president and chief operating officer of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation, has resigned, a spokesman said today. In a statement, Mr. Bowden said that staying in the job would complicate the search for a new president to succeed Victor Schroeder, who resigned last month. Mr. Bowden will be succeeded by Leonard Axelrod. Mr. Bowden said he disagreed with the board's proposals for the management of the corporation. Mr. Schroeder resigned after some board members urged that he be replaced following charges of impropriety and mismanagement in his office. He has denied any wrongdoing.

title: No Headline
description: The Wages of Protectionism The Chrysler Corporation has negotiated a new labor contract that eliminates most of the concessions granted by its union in 1980. That is no surprise. Now that the company is again profitable, the rationale for paying Chrysler workers less than those at Ford or General Motors has evaporated. But it is a disheartening reminder that the American auto industry and the United Auto Workers do not yet understand the seriousness of their financial predicament. If Big Auto is ever again to thrive without protection from Japanese rivals, it must cut costs drastically.

title: Boxer Arrested
description: Kenny Bogner , the lightweight boxer, has been charged with theft and burglary of a beach house in Seaside Heights, N.J. Bogner, who was arrested at his home in Trenton on Wednesday and later released on his own recognizance, was accused of a burglary that occurred last July 24. The Seaside Heights police would give no details of the charges, but the boxer's father, Kenneth Bogner , said a woman who lived at the beach house had reported that a gold necklace and a bracelet had been stolen. ''He doesn't need the junk,'' said the elder Bogner, who called the charges ''ridiculous.''

title: 5 FILMS WITH POLITICAL STATEMENTS DUE IN FALL
description: Five new movies dealing with sensitive political and social issues will reach movie theaters this fall, all in an eight-week period. Their release is considered noteworthy by the film industry because in the last six years only about half a dozen Hollywood movies have addressed such highly charged issues.

title: Books of The Times
description: ANGELS. By Denis Johnson. 209 pages. Throwaway Lives Knopf. $12.95. Bored with their successes, Americans are beginning to love their failures. This is especially true in our fiction, because writers of novels and stories seem to get bored faster than other people. Everybody in Denis Johnson's ''Angels,'' for example, is a failure. It's as if we were proud of having evolved a way of life in which you can fail more absolutely, more definitively or finally, than anywhere else. Because we haven't got an ancient culture, we seem to preen ourselves on having all the latest disabilities.
