title: G.M. Denies X-Car Cover-Up
description: The General Motors Corporation has formally denied the Federal Government's charge that it failed to provide ''accurate and complete information'' on a reported brake problem in 1.1 million 1980 X-car models.

title: HOPE TAPING: LIKE 'BUYING STOLEN GOODS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Brewers 2, Tigers 1 Tigers 2, Brewers 1
description: An unearned run in the eighth inning, when the right fielder Charlie Moore misplayed Lou Whitaker's fly ball, gave Detroit the victory in the second game of a twilight-night doubleheader.

title: Zia Hints He Might Call Elections Before 1985
description: Pakistan's military ruler, Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, has hinted that he might compromise with the opposition and call general elections earlier than the promised March 1985 date.

title: PRINCIPAL POINTS IN DISPUTE BETWEEN SOVIET AND THE U.S.
description: Following are some of the major contradictions between the American version of the downing of Korean Air Lines Flight 7 and the Soviet version. Soviet accounts have changed; this is the version presented today in Moscow.

title: OIL CO-OPS CAN SAVE ON HEATING
description: EARLY fall is a time when the minds of many homeowners turn toward winter, in particular toward ways of keeping energy costs down. In recent years a growing number who use oil for heating have turned to fuel cooperatives, organizations of consumers who band together to get lower prices from suppliers.

title: Study of 30 Years of TV Finds Smoking Declined
description: A review of 30 years of television programming shows that the number of scenes of smoking has been dramatically reduced but that today there is a lot more onscreen drinking, researchers reported Wednesday.

title: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 10, 1983 International
description: International

title: TO ENLIST THE I.M.F. IN NONPROLIFERATION
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW MILITARY BUYS ITS PARTS
description: In April 1982, B. H. Aircraft, a small Long Island aviation parts manufacturer that had never done business with the military, sent the Air Force a bid to build 15,000 jet engine nozzles for $44.8 million, or $1,395 a piece. N. V. Philips, a giant Dutch conglomerate, bid $44.4 million - or $1,318 a piece - and the Defense Department announced that Philips had won the contract.

title: G.E. Furloughs
description: The General Electric Company will lay off 1,200 workers for several weeks as it adjusts to a drop in its transformer business, a company spokesman said. The spokesman, Bruce Farren, said the company needed the furloughs because there were few orders for large transformers.

title: Washington Voices Concern Over Massacres in Lebanon
description: The United States today condemned ''terrible acts of vengeance'' in the fighting between Druse and Christian militias in Lebanon.

title: ASIAN-AMERICANS SEE GROWING BIAS
description: Asian- American leaders say they are alarmed by what they regard as rising discrimination against their people. As a result, they are forming political action organizations around the country that are unifying traditionally rival ethnic groups, including Japanese, Koreans, Chinese and Vietnamese.

title: THE NAVY WILL BRING DOLLARS TO THE REGION
description: Can a person logically support both a nuclear weapons freeze and the basing of the Navy's Surface Action Group on Staten Island?

title: ARKANSAS TOWN OUSTS EX-CONVICT AS SCHOOL HEAD
description: A convicted felon whose appointment as superintendent of schools in this town of 285 people drew protests has been dismissed by the school board.

title: Author Wins Judgment for Slander
description: The psychiatrist Thomas Harris and his wife, Amy, who collaborated on the best-seller ''I'm O.K. - You're O.K.,'' will collect $150,000 in settlement of a slander suit based on a report that he had committed suicide.

title: The Cruel Sea
description: When the British yachtsman Chay Blyth leaves Manhattan in November, he'll be captaining a 65- foot trimaran called Beefeater, headed for San Francisco via Cape Horn, one of the world's most treacherous voyages.

title: START WESTWAY
description: When New York City's financial future was seriously threatened a decade ago, some members of the business community helped the city regain its economic vigor. In view of the pulling together and progress that has been achieved since then, it is ironic that, over this same period of time, Westway, one of the city's most promising public projects, has been mired in controversy. Clearly, it is time to move from planning to real progress.

title: Weinberger Accuses Soviet
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the Soviet Union was keeping other nations out of the area where a Korean airliner went down so they can manufacture evidence to show the pilot was a spy. He said in an interview on the NBC News program ''Today'' that he would advise President Reagan to keep a tough stance with Moscow for downing the plane.

title: PRODUCER PRICES UP BY 0.4% IN AUGUST
description: The Producer Price Index for finished goods, which measures the price of goods ready for sale to the final user, rose a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. Some food prices rose sharply because of drought conditions in many producing states.

title: Opera Memorabilia To Mark Met Centenary
description: Costumes, scenery and other memorabilia used in Metropolitan Opera productions in the last 100 years will be featured in an exhibition celebrating the centenary of the company, beginning Sept. 21 in the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, 111 Amsterdam Avenue, at 65th Street.

title: OUTER-SPACE PROFITS
description: President Reagan and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Administrator, James Beggs, have announced support for private business ventures in space. These opportunities deserve to be taken seriously. They are not castles in the air to distract attention from idle plants and double-digit unemployment on earth; they involve working factories whose commercial potential has been tested. Properly exploited they will help transform the nation's $100 billion investment in the space program into sustained world leadership in an area of technology with as yet unimaginable applications for commerce and manufacture.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Carl Lewis , who won three gold medals at the world track and field championships, said he would try to match the feat accomplished by Jesse Owens at the 1936 Olympics by going for four gold medals at the 1984 Games. In addition to the long jump, the 100-meter dash and the 400-meter relay, Lewis said, he plans to enter the 200-meter dash. . . . A heavyweight bout between Mike Weaver , former champion of the World Boxing Association, and Stan Ward has been postponed from next Wednesday until Sept. 30 in Los Angeles.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 13.

title: Dr. Morris Kaplan Dies at 83; Radiation Therapy Specialist
description: Dr. Morris Kaplan, a retired physician and radiation therapist, died of a ruptured aorta Tuesday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Manhattan. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Airline Smoking Ban Sought
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board plans to propose a total ban on smoking on commercial flights that last less than one or two hours.

title: CUOMO STUMPS IN EAST HARLEM FOR BOND ISSUE
description: Governor Cuomo toured East Harlem yesterday to announce job appointments and a public works project, to thank voters for electing him last year and to plead for votes for the ''Rebuild New York'' transportation bond issue on the ballot Nov. 8.

title: JOHN J. KREIDLER
description: John J. Kreidler, a labor mediator who retired earlier this year after 15 years in the New York City office of the State Mediation Board, died yesterday of a heart attack suffered while swimming in Long Island Sound.

title:
PATENTS;
Electric Sharpener For Cosmetic Pencils
description: Cosmetic pencils used for make-up around the lips and eyes sometimes get dull.

title: A POWER FAILURE AT PENN STATION HALTS 40 TRAINS
description: More than 40 trains and 32,000 New Jersey commuters and intercity riders were delayed up to three hours through the rush period last night when a power failure halted Amtrak and N.J. Transit rail service into and out of Pennsylvania Station.

title: INSPECTOR FACES FORGERY CHARGE IN I-95 COLLAPSE
description: A state bridge inspector was charged today with forgery and altering his inspection notes to make it appear that he had warned Connecticut officials about the condition of the Mianus River Bridge in Greenwich nine months before it collapsed.

title: SECOND-CLASS PATRONS
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on festivals in Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect date for the New York State Chili Cookoff. The contest takes place today at 11 A.M. at the Queens Botanical Garden.

title: Longer Hours In AM Radio
description: The Federal Communications Commission agreed today to authorize longer operating hours for an estimated 2,200 AM radio stations.

title: THE CITY;
description: Two men stole $500,000 worth of jewelry yesterday from a jeweler in the city's midtown diamond district, after binding the owner with their neckties, the police said.

title: SHULTZ ASSAILS THE RUSSIANS BUT ASKS 'SERIOUS DIALOGUE'
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz assailed the Soviet Union today over human rights and other violations and challenged it ''to undertake a serious dialogue'' to settle all outstanding issues.

title: LEBANON TRUCE TALKS UNDER WAY AS BATTLES GO ON AROUND BEIRUT
description: Another French member of the peacekeeping force was wounded by artillery fire today as intense negotiations were under way on a cease-fire.

title: reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income of $1,010 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary loss of $19,367. c-After a loss of $14,058 from discontinued operations. d-Net income including income of $25,316 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $165,579. Corrected from Saturday's editions, Sept. 3.

title: MINNESOTA FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BILINGUAL EDUCATION DIRECTOR IN CITY RESIGNS
description: The director of the New York City Board of Education's Office of Bilingual Education resigned this week, following criticism of her hiring and management practices in an audit by the City Comptroller.

title: MOST NATO ALLIES AID TO AGREE ON BAN OF SOVIET CIVILIAN FLIGHTS
description: A majority of the 16 North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies will impose a two-week ban on civilian flights to and from the Soviet Union beginning Sept. 15, NATO sources said today.

title: Carey and Koch Discuss the Jets
description: International

title: CHILE EXTENDS CURBS AFTER FOUR ARE SLAIN IN RENEWED PROTESTS
description: The Chilean Government today extended for six months the ''state of threat to internal peace,'' which allows President Augusto Pinochet to restrict freedom of assembly and to exile citizens without judicial review.

title: RIVER RESTORATION GAINS IN FLORIDA
description: South Florida water officials agreed today to begin work on setting the Kissimmee River back on its original, meandering path. They said it would be the start of the first attempt to restore a major river in the United States to its original condition.

title: SYSTEM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $576,000, or 14 cents a share, from the sale of the leasehold interest in the company's former headquarters.

title: Cram Beats Ovett In a 3:52.56 Mile
description: Steve Cram of Britain edged his countryman and arch-rival Steve Ovett by 15 hundredths of a second in a one-mile run at the Crystal Palace tonight. Competing in the Coca-Cola-International Athletes Club meet, Cram won in 3 minutes 52.56 seconds.

title: PRYOR STOPS ARG"UELLO IN 10TH
description: Aaron Pryor and Alexis Arg"uello did it again tonight. What could well be the fight of the year for the second straight year ended in much the same way their 1982 epic did, with Pryor winning by late-round knockout to retain his World Boxing Association junior welterweight title.

title: Letter: On Rail Freight The Right Track for Boxcars
description: To the Editor:

title: UNISEX 'AD HOMINEM'
description: To the Editor:

title: Military Contracts
description: The General Dynamics Corporation received a $93.9 million Army contract for 2,598 Stinger missiles and related hardware, the Defense Department said. In addition, the department said that the Air Force awarded contracts worth $43.6 million to the Raytheon Company and $39.9 million to the Hughes Aircraft Company.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday on the appointment of Daniel J. Evans to the seat of the late Senator Henry M. Jackson incorrectly listed Mr. Evans's years as Governor of Washington. He served from 1965 to 1977.

title: BONN HINTS AT A SOVIET SHIFT IN GENEVA
description: The West German Foreign Minister said today that there was a possible sign of an important new Soviet position that could lead to a breakthrough in the Geneva negotiations on reducing medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: Reagan Investment Call
description: President Reagan called today on foreign governments to reduce restrictions on investment from abroad. The 2,000-word policy declaration signaled a fresh diplomatic effort to dismantle proliferating rules that many governments impose on foreign investors.

title: Bankrupt Schools Open
description: Classrooms were open today for more than 32,000 students in the San Jose Unified School District, although it is officially bankrupt. The district filed for protection June 30 under Chapter 9 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, saying it had $1.7 million in debts that it could not pay. The law gives the district time to work out a plan to pay the money.

title: Moynihan, at Seminar, Urges Lower Dairy Price Supports
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, today called for the lowering of dairy price supports, saying the current cost of the supports amounted to ''a tax on food.''

title: PatentsStacy V. Jones Protecting Design Features
description: WASHINGTON NINETY-FIVE patents were granted this week for such things as goblets, hairbrushes, games and animal collars. They were what are known as design patents, which concern how inventions look rather than what they do.

title: CAMPANELLI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
COAST FREELANCE UNIT THRIVES ON REPORTING FOR TV
description: After years as an also-ran in the San Francisco audience ratings, KRON, the NBC television affiliate in San Francisco, decided last year to do something about its news coverage. First, a new reporting team was created, called Target 4. Then station officials called in the Center for Investigative Reporting.

title: Paul H. Blaisdell, 75; Had Role in Rationing
description: Paul H. Blaisdell, who administered the tire and gasoline rationing program for the United States as a principal officer of the Office of Price Administration in World War II, died Tuesday in his home in the village of Moody.

title: CAPITOL AIRWAYS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Owens Statue Rejected
description: A monument to the late Olympic star Jesse Owens has been barred from the courthouse lawn in Lawrence County, where Owens was born. Instead, it will be placed in a vacant lot here, the town of his birth, according to State Representative Roger Dutton, who has vowed to build a park around the statue.

title: No Headline
description: The Auctions column in Weekend yesterday referred erroneously to ''the late'' Dr. Albert Grokoest. The Times regrets the error.

title: TENNIS CHAMPIONSHIP LURES SUBWAY CROWD
description: For two weeks each September, the Flushing subway line belongs to the tennis fans - commuters with coolers and seat cushions.

title: BANKER'S NOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: CAMPBELL RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After a net charge of $1,049,000 from a loss on the transfer of shares, a loss on the sale of an investment and a gain on the issue of share capital by majority-owned companies. c-Net loss including a net gain of $232,000 from issues of share capital by majority-owned companies.

title: Lebanon Asks U.N. Meeting
description: Lebanon is asking for an urgent meeting of the Security Council to deal with the latest outbreak of violence in that country, a spokesman for the Lebanese mission to the United Nations said tonight.

title: A LANDMARKS LAW MINDFUL OF OWNER INTERSTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethiopia Frees 1,163 To Mark Anniversary
description: Ethiopia says it has freed 1,163 prisoners, including 117 who were being held for political reasons, to mark the ninth anniversary of the overthrow of Emperor Haile Selassie.

title: ONE WORLD
description: The 11th One World Festival, sponsored by the Diocese of the Armenian Church of America and the Mayor's Office of Special Events, will begin today at noon at St. Vartan Cathedral and adjacent park, Second Avenue and 35th Street. The free outdoor festival, which will continue through tommorrow evening, will include music, dancing, antiques, crafts exhibits and foods from around the world.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $2 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve System yesterday reported that the basic measure of the nation's money supply dropped by a startling $2 billion for the week ended Aug. 31, and that two broader measures of the money supply were kept well under control during August.

title: PLEASED WITH A TOWN THEY GIVE IT A MILLION
description: Every summer since 1938, Dr. Harry J. Johnson, a Manhattan internist, and his wife, Teresa, have vacationed in Madison, Conn., a town of 15,000 on Long Island Sound. ''We enjoyed living here,'' Dr. Johnson said, ''and five years ago, when I retired, we began to think of how we could help the town, something of lasting benefit.''

title: UPTURN AT NEIMAN-MARCUS
description: Neiman-Marcus, in the words of Richard C. Marcus, its chairman and chief executive officer, is ''back from the valley.''

title: TELEPORT ON STATEN I. ENVISIONED AS CITY'S LINK TO A BRIGHT FUTURE
description: It will look like a garden of giant aluminum dishes on Staten Island: 17 of them will be lined up in several rows, each dish about 25 feet across and tilted up toward the sky.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10.

title: RADIO CITY SHIFTS FOCUS TO POP MUSIC CONCERTS
description: Radio City Music Hall Productions, which announced on Thursday that it had let go ''less than 25'' people - about 20 percent of its adminstrative staff, will now concentrate on pop music events and television productions in place of theatrical shows.

title: ASBESTOS VICTIMS UNSHIELDED BY THE COURT
description: To the Editor:

title: TEKTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 20
YANKEES WIN AND TRAIL BY 4
description: The Yankees have three weeks to find themselves, 23 games to shape their season into something other than suspensions, pine-tar memories and unfulfilled potential.

title: SKS RSNBL MNHTN APT W/RMS, FLR, KTCHN
description: I moved recently from London, where four friends and myself had grudgingly parted with 150 pounds ($270) for the monthly rental of a Georgian townhouse in the newly fashionable district of Camden Town. Not surprisingly, I had some fairly misguided notions about the rental market in New York.

title: RESOURCE EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Miss Foat Loses a Round
description: A state appeals court today upheld a ruling that the right of Ginny Foat, a California feminist, to a speedy trial on charges of killing an Argentine businessman in 1965 was not violated even though prosecutors had held a warrant for her arrest since 1977. The 42-year- old former president of the California chapter of the National Organization for Women is to stand trial Oct. 11 in the slaying of Moises Chayo.

title: SAGE LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
Helen M. Fleming a Bride
description: Helen Marie Fleming, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Fleming of New Brighton, S.I., was married yesterday to Assemblyman Eric N. Vitaliano, son of Mrs. Michael L. Vitaliano of West Brighton, S.I., and the late Mr. Vitaliano. The Rev. Michael O'Herlihy performed the ceremony in St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church in New Brighton. Mrs. Vitaliano is a McDonald's manager. Mr. Vitaliano, a lawyer, was elected to the State Assembly last November to represent the 59th District on Staten Island.

title: Coral Sea Heads Home
description: A five-ship battle group led by the aircraft carrier Coral Sea has completed training operations and left today from the Caribbean coast of Central America, the Navy said. The carrier is on its way to its new home port of Norfolk, Va.

title: Greening the White House
description: Grass roots, in Washington talk, is where a politician who has been keeping his ear to the ground senses a lot of support growing.

title: VS SERVICES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
Date for Yin Concert
description: The Chinese pianist Yin Cheng- Zong will give a recital in Carnegie Hall at 8 P.M. Sept. 28. The date of the concert, which will be the pianist's North American debut, is incorrectly advertised for tomorrow evening in tomorrow's Arts and Leisure Section. Mr. Yin will perform works by Scarlatti, Mozart, Beethoven and Liszt.

title: Edna J. Frieder Wed To Stanley Rinehart
description: The marriage of Edna Julie Frieder, an assistant treasurer with the Bankers Trust Company, to Stanley M. Rinehart, a Bankers Trust vice president, took place in Manhattan yesterday. Civil Court Judge Amy H. Juviler performed the ceremony at the couple's apartment.

title: A LANDMARKS LAW MINDFUL OF OWNER INTERESTS
description: To the Editor:

title: BANNER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credis of $120,000 for the quarter and $2,850,000 for the year and a loss of $301,552 for the year from discontinued operations. c-Net loss including a tax credit of $320,000 and a loss of $636,535 from discontinued operations. d-Net income after a loss of $724,352 from discontinued operations.

title: Woody Allen Series
description: A Woody Allen retrospective is marking the 15th Film Makers of the Hamptons Festival this weekend at Guild Hall, 158 Main Street in Easthampton, L.I. Today the features will be ''Stardust Memories'' at 5 P.M. and ''Manhattan'' at 9 P.M. Tomorrow at 2:30 P.M., ''What's New Pussycat?'' Admission is $6. Information: (516) 324-4050.

title: BEST PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results include operations of Modern Merchandising Inc. as of October 1982 and Basco Inc. as of July 1982.

title: PLAYERS
description: The quarterback makes the bed, since he is the last one out in the mornings. The bride brings home the paycheck, since she is the only one making a living. A dishwasher does the dishes. The newlyweds share the other chores. ''I'm turning into a Susie Homemaker,'' said Blair Kiel, Notre Dame quarterback and part-time South Bend househusband.

title: U.S. Court Clears Way For a Georgia Execution
description: A Federal appeals court today lifted a stay of the execution of John Eldon Smith, clearing the way for the state to set a date for him to die in the electric chair.

title: OSBORNE LAYS OFF BULK OF EMPLOYEES
description: The Osborne Computer Corporation, once one of the hottest stars in the personal computer field, laid off nearly all of its nonmanagement workers and some executives today.

title: Dodgers Defeat Braves by 3-2
description: Alejandro Pena limited Atlanta to three hits over the first seven innings to help the Los Angeles Dodgers score a 3-2 victory and extend their lead over the Braves to three games in the National League West.

title: TEXSCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
MRS. PERON IS GIVEN A PARDON
description: President Reynaldo Bignone tonight pardoned former President Isabel Martinez de Peron for her conviction of misusing charity funds.

title: Abraham Wilson, 84; A Peace Fund Founder
description: Abraham Wilson, a New York lawyer who was a founder of the Fund for Peace and an organizer and former general counsel of the United World Federalists, died last Sunday of a heart ailment at his home in Newtown, Pa. He was 84 years old.

title: Still a Battler
description: Brooklyn Dodger fans remember Rex Barney as a hard-throwing right- hander of four decades ago whose career included a no-hitter against the Giants 35 years ago yesterday. They may also remember him as a battler, and this summer Barney lived up to that reputation.

title: SEIZURE OF BISCAYNE THRIFT UNIT UPSET
description: Federal regulators acted improperly in seizing the Biscayne Federal Savings and Loan Association in April and must return it to stockholders, a Federal District Court judge ruled here today.

title: 2,800 Quarters Gone, As Is Pac Man Game
description: The police thought it strange when they found that someone had broken through a window of the Orange City Bank and taken nothing but quarters - $700 worth.

title: MERRILL SEES A FALL IN EARNINGS
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it would report ''substantially lower'' earnings in the third quarter compared with the similar period last year.

title: U.S. POSTPONES VOTE IN SECURITY COUNCIL ON REBUKE TO SOVIET OVER AIRLINER
description: Faced with what could have been a political defeat, the United States and its allies today put off until Monday a vote on a Security Council resolution rebuking the Soviet Union for shooting down a Korean airliner.

title: REAGAN RESPONDS TO CONSERVATIVES
description: President Reagan responded today to conservative critics who have demanded stronger action against the Soviet Union over the shooting down of a Korean airliner by saying, ''Vengeance isn't the name of the game.''

title: MIDWEST ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The termination of the flight was not an accident or an error.'' - Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, chief of the Soviet General Staff. (1:6.)

title: EDWARD D. ROBBINS
description: Edward Denmore Robbins, a retired member of the Manhattan law firm of White & Case, died of pneumonia Wednesday at Forsyth Memorial Hospital in Winston-Salem, N.C. He was 72 years old and lived in Winston-Salem.

title: Berry Undecided
description: Walter Berry, whose eligibility to play basketball for St. John's is under dispute and in the courts, still has made no announcement as to whether he will enroll at the university for this year. But Berry has a few more days to ponder his decision, even though classes began at St. John's this week, because late registration is permitted at St. John's until next Thursday. If Berry enrolled at a junior college, he could play basketball this winter, but he would have to graduate from such a school in order to have immediate eligibility upon transferring to a Division I school, such as St. John's.

title: ZIMBABWE DEPORTING 2 JAILED WHITE OFFICERS
description: With Prime Minister Robert D. Mugabe about to arrive in the United States on a visit he hopes will repair Zimbabwe's image in the West and stimulate foreign investment, his Government today ordered the release and immediate deportation of two of six white air force officers who last week were sent back to their cells after a judge had dismissed sabotage charges against them.

title: CHILDREN'S MAGAZINES FOR A COMPUTER AGE
description: ''What in the world will our children do with the computer?'' - From an advertisement in a new family computer magazine.

title: Kemp Stays in Hospital
description: The Yankee outfielder Steve Kemp, hit in the face by a batted ball during practice Thursday at Milwaukee, was removed from the intensive-care unit at a hospital there yesterday. Though his condition was listed as excellent, he is expected to remain in the hospital a few more days. Kemp suffered a fracture of the cheekbone and damage to two teeth when he was hit by Omar Moreno's line drive. Dr. Wilbert Wiviott, a plastic surgeon, indicated that no surgery would be necessary. Dr. Herbert Giller, an ophthalmologist, was prevented by Kemp's badly swollen left eye and the existence of blood behind the eye from making a complete examination or diagnosis.

title: No Headline
description: Good Students, Good Teachers Albert Shanker, the president of the American Federation of Teachers, offers a statesmanlike suggestion for relieving the critical shortage of good teachers. He would provide college scholarships to top students who will commit themselves to at least five years of teaching.

title: FOOTLOOSE AND FANCIFUL
description: Shoes have become adventurous and innovative as summer steps toward fall. The ones shown here, seen the past week on city streets and Long Island boardwalks, are free-spirited indeed.

title: COMPENSATION IN AIRLINE CRASH
description: Survivors of the 269 people killed in the shooting down of a Korean Air Lines jetliner by the Soviet Union last week are eligible to receive up to $75,000 per casualty from the airline, and could receive substantially more if they can show in court that the airline was guilty of ''willful misconduct,'' legal experts said yesterday.

title: Chamber Opera Delays Opening Performances
description: The Chamber Opera Theater of New York has announced that financial difficulties have forced it to put off the opening of its 1983-84 season. The world premiere of Lee Hoiby's ''Italian Lesson'' and Kurt Weill's rarely heard ''He Who Says Yes,'' which were scheduled to open the company's season Sept. 14 in the Marymount Manhattan Theater, will be presented later in the season.

title: METS' SEAVER AND OROSCO TOP EXPOS, 5-4
description: Tom Seaver got some long-awaited offensive support from the Mets tonight, but victory almost slipped away from him. Only some ninth-inning relief from Jesse Orosco preserved a 5-4 triumph over the Montreal Expos.

title: Man Gets 3 Years On Arms Charge
description: A 57-year-old Queens man was sentenced to three years in prison and fined $10,000 yesterday for his conviction on conspiring to smuggle arms and ammunition to Ireland.

title: BGS SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
1 of 2 Rescued After Yacht Sinks
description: A ship rescued a man adrift at sea in a life raft for two days after his 41-foot sailboat sank, but a crewman aboard the yacht was missing, the Coast Guard said today.

title: AMERICAN BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Comserv to Adjust Earnings Figures
description: The Comserv Corporation said that because of an adjustment in accounting for software license contracts, it will restate earnings and revenues for 1982 and for the first two quarters of 1983.

title: Chadian Official Warns Of Coming Rebel Attack
description: The Government of President Hissen Habre said today that Libyan- backed rebels were preparing to attack again, while the official press increased its criticism of France for not reacting to earlier clashes.

title: Monday Movie Bumps Cosmos
description: When the Cosmos face elimination from the playoffs Monday night in Montreal, the game will not be televised live by Channel 9. Instead, the station will show a movie, and carry the Cosmos-Manic game on tape afterward, at 10:30.

title: SAN/BAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: 6 Girls Win Admission To an All-Boy School
description: The city school district must admit six female students to all-male Central High School while appeals are heard of an earlier order ending the males-only history of the school, a judge has ruled. Judge William Marutani of the Common Pleas Court signed the order Thursday.

title: St. Louis School Strikers Warned of Dismissals
description: School officals said yesterday they would dismiss the striking St. Louis teachers and hire replacements if they did not return to work Monday in the most heated of the teacher strikes that have disrupted schools for more than 200,000 pupils in seven states.

title: Competitive Spirit
description: For Paul Blanchard , a punter for the University of Minnesota, cancer is just another opponent and one he plans to beat. ''I'm used to competing, and that keeps you going,'' said Blanchard, who has undergone surgery and a debilitating series of radiation treatments for Hodgkin's disease, a form of cancer of the lymph glands, but still plans to be in uniform when the Gophers face Rice today.

title: A FORMER PRESIDENT OF RCA
description: Maurice R. Valente, an investment banker, former president of the RCA Corporation and a longtime executive with the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, died last Saturday while on vacation in Rome. He was 54 years old and lived in Franklin Lakes, N.J.

title: GASOLINE IN WELL THREATENING FAMILY
description: A family whose well water is so tainted with petroleum that it ignites has been told that officials can do nothing to help because of a quirk in the law.

title: Earl Campbell Sidelined
description: The Houston Oilers have declared Earl Campbell , their star running back, out of their game tomorrow against the Los Angeles Raiders because the knee he sprained in last Sunday's overtime loss to Green Bay has not responded to treatment. Campbell gained 123 yards and scored three touchdowns.

title: I.B.M. in Talks With Delmed
description: Delmed Inc. said it is having discussions with the International Business Machines Corporation regarding ''cooperative business relationships.''

title: National Data
description: National Data Communications Inc. said it had filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code because of continued pressure from a creditor.

title: TCA CABLE TV INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BELL PETROLEUM SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Sports of The Times; A New Jimmy in Semifinals
description: Wherever he went yesterday at the National Tennis Center, people recognized him immediately. As he strolled over to practice on a back court, voices could be heard whispering, ''That's Jimmy Arias, that's the new kid.'' For the last decade, Jimmy Connors has been the most important ''Jimmy'' in tennis. But now there's a new Jimmy who will oppose Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia today in the men's semifinals at the United States Open before Jimmy Connors goes against Bill Scanlon.

title: UNA CORP.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
202 DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title:
PATENTS;
Improved Transmission Of Television Signals
description: In the field of electrical inventions, RCA received a patent this week for improved television transmission.

title: CUSTOM ENERGY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income including income of $336,349 for the quarter and a loss of $374,008 for the year from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $853,297 from discontinued operations.

title: Trading Active In Tymshare
description: Active trading in Tymshare Inc. was attributed by analysts and traders to reports that the company was an imminent takeover target.

title: Open Invitation
description: Nobody can accuse the Playtex public relations people of not being forthright. In fact, although devotees of Emily Post and Amy Vanderbilt most certainly would throw up their hands at the breach of etiquette involved, Playtex yesterday delivered invitations that were forthright to a fault.

title: EMF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Miss Navratilova Will Meet Mrs. Lloyd; Rivalry Renewed in Open Final
description: She was still a chubby 17-year-old from Czechoslovakia when she first met Chris Evert on a tennis court. It was 1973, and Miss Evert, now Chris Evert Lloyd, gained a convincing straight-set victory over Martina Navratilova.

title: Neill on Injured
description: Reserve Bill Neill, the Giants' starting nose tackle, who has had knee problems throughout his career, is now on the injured-reserve list after twisting his left knee in practice this week. The move means that he must miss at least the next four games.

title: National Steel Sees 1983 Profit
description: The chairman of the National Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest steel producer, said yesterday that there was a good chance the company would post an operating profit for 1983.

title: CACI GROUPS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 200 percent stock dividend in April.

title: OLDENBURG SCULPTURE BACKED
description: Claes Oldenburg's $190,000 plan to build a 60-foot orange sculpture of a fishing pole has won endorsement of the Vail Town Council after a debate in which opponents decried the plan as an ''imposition'' and a sad comment on the times.

title: WOR CANCELS 2 OF ITS OLDEST PROGRAMS
description: In an attempt to attract more and younger listeners, radio station WOR has dropped two programs that for decades had been staples on the station's schedule. The station has also reshuffled the broadcast times of several other shows and changed the format of ''P.M. New York,'' a three- hour news-and-weather program whose host is John R. Gambling.

title: Key Rates
description: * Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Medical Opinions Vary
description: The running back Sherman Smith was traded to the Kansas City Chiefs by the Seattle Seahawks during the exhibition season, but the trade was nullified after Kansas City doctors had found a narrowing of Smith's spinal column and questioned whether he should be playing football. Since then, however, Smith, who had previously passed a Seahawk physical, has passed two further examinations, one by the Seahawks and one by the San Diego Chargers, which accepted him in a later trade.

title: Your Money; Life Insurance Loan Changes
description: MANY holders of whole life insurance policies have taken out loans on these policies because the interest rate on such borrowing has been lower than could be obtained elsewhere.

title: Bridge:Irritation Becomes Mother Of Invention for Ingenious
description: Some bidding situations are like mosquitoes: A constant source of irritation, needing the balm of some scientific remedy. Some experts are fertile inventors of ad hoc cures, and one of these is Fred Hamilton of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a former world champion.

title: San Francisco Museum To Open a New Unit
description: An exhibition of works by the designer Issey Miyake will open a new department of architecture and design at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art Sept. 20.

title: LAGGING HURRICANE CLEANUP IS HOUSTON'S HOTTEST ISSUE
description: When Hurricane Alicia roared through this proud city three weeks ago, it destroyed well over a billion dollars in property, left three quarters of a million people without electric power and another quarter of a million without telephones, and littered the downtown with broken glass and the rest of the city with a tangle of toppled trees and torn-off limbs.

title: CRACKER BARREL OLD COUNTRY STORE INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June.

title: The $2,001,000 Open
description: Following is a breakdown of the prize money for this year's United States Open tennis championships. The purse money listed is the same for men and women. Singles Winners Total

title: MISS HOLTZMAN DISAGREEING WITH JUDGE OVER RAPE CASE
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney's office said yesterday that a judge had erred in blaming it for many of the pretrial delays that, according to the judge, had required him to dismiss rape charges against a Brooklyn man.

title: Suicide Rate Found Up 41% In Those 15 to 24 Years Old
description: The suicide rate among young Americans has risen sharply in the past 25 years to become the third leading cause of death among people 15 to 24 years old, according to the Federal Centers for Disease Control.

title: JAPANESE RECOVER PIECES OF AIRLINER
description: Pieces of metal identified as wreckage from the Korean Air Lines 747 shot down by a Soviet fighter eight days ago have been found on a beach in northern Japan, officials reported tonight.

title: RISING COSTS HAMPERING SOME RIDERS
description: THE action in horse jumping is not taking place exclusively inside the show rings. As is the case with almost the entire horse industry, show jumping is big business, and the arena is a show floor. And the price of horses has risen greatly in recent years.

title: 3 Food Outlets Listed by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited three food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: COOKING CLASSES FOR MANY TASTES
description: AS summer fades and autumn arrives, outdoor barbecue grills are covered and the cooks return to the kitchen. As the new season approaches, Westchester residents can avail themselves of a myriad of cooking courses being offered countywide.

title: FILM
description: ''Katzelmacher'' (1969), one of the late Rainer Werner Fassbinder's first and still most arresting features, opens the comprehensive, 10-week New German Cinema Retrospective (1962-1982) that starts on Wednesday at the Film Forum 2.

title: Winner of Jackpot Hides As Cheating Is Charged
description: A world record $1.7 million slot-machine jackpot paid to a retired warehouseman has been canceled because of signs of cheating, the authorities said.

title: ARKANSAS PREVAILS
description: Derrick Thomas ran for two touchdowns, and Arkansas survived a last-play field-goal attempt today to defeat Tulsa, 17-14. The loss was the first for Tulsa (1-1) after 10 consecutive victories. Thomas, a freshman fullback, scored on 2-yard runs in the second and third quarters to give Arkansas (1-0) a 17-7 lead.

title: NEBRASKA WINS 12TH IN A ROW BY 56-20
description: Mike Rozier ran for 191 yards and four touchdowns to become Nebraska's career leading rusher today as the top-ranked Cornhuskers routed Wyoming, 56-20.

title: Cora Michalis Becomes Bride
description: Cora Candler Michalis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Fahnestock Michalis of Locust Valley, L.I., and Douglas McMillan Thomas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. Thomas of Greenwich, Conn., and Naples, Fla., were married yesterday. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley.

title: AT BOTTOM, LONG ISLAND SOUND IS A MESS
description: In the mid-1970's, the oceanographer Jacques Cousteau sailed across Long Island Sound and pronounced it ''dead.'' That was something that swimmers, boaters and fishermen knew only too well. After watching fires burn on the water and hauling home inedible catches, they were not surprised when water-quality tests read like an epitaph.

title:
DINING OUT;
INCONSPICUOUS IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: Finding The Front Porch Restaurant in Atlantic City is half the battle. In a city where huge casino signs beckon visitors to try their luck, a small restaurant on the second floor of a building about half a block from the Boardwalk attracts only those who are looking specifically for that address.

title: YES, THERE IS STILL OUTDOOR COOKING AFTER LABOR DAY
description: SOME people drain their pools and pack away their barbecue grills the week after Labor Day. But summer isn't over yet. Fresh herbs, summer vegetables and warm evenings when meals can be cooked outdoors and eaten under the trees are still in the offing. For these somewhat cooler days, fish is particularly appropriate. Steaks and small whole fish can be broiled over hot coals and served with a flavored butter or a sauce made with fresh tomatoes, sorrel or gooseberries - all still in season.

title:
GARDENING;
NEGLECTED HOSTA RETURNING TO FAVOR
description: THE versatility of many modern flowering plants is really quite remarkable. Plants considered to be adapted for use under limited circumstances but a generation ago are used successfully in a much broader variety of situations today.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE STONYWALKERS By Vivien Alcock. 151 pp. New York: Delacorte Press.

title:
ART;
A VIEW THROUGH LONDON'S VAUXHALL GARDENS
description: WITH the end of summer comes the chore of covering the plants or bringing them indoors. One can forestall the blues this brings on by vicariously exploring the effervescent public gardens of bygone days, London's Vauxhall Gardens.

title: Perkins 20-7 Winner in Alabama Debut
description: Ray Perkins made a successful debut as a college football head coach today when his Alabama team methodically beat Georgia Tech, 20-7. Thus, Alabama's Ray Perkins era oficially began, and the Paul (Bear) Bryant era more or less ended.

title: AT FORD, A QUIET REVOLUTION UNFOLDS
description: IT was the spring of 1980 when Donald E. Petersen, the newly named president of the Ford Motor Company, visited the corporate styling center to have a look at clay models of cars proposed for the future. Noticing that the designers there seemed a bit glum about what was in store for the next few years, Mr. Petersen asked if they really liked what they were presenting.

title: MILAN'S MAGIC
description: TS OFFICIAL TITLE IS THE SALONE DEL Mobile Italiano, and this is the 23d year that the furniture fair is being held in Milan, Italy. Combined with Euroluce, a lighting fair, and Eimu, an international exhibit of office furnishings, the event, which runs from Sept. 10 through Sept. 15, draws the attention of manufacturers, designers, architects and retailers in the home-furnishings field throughout the world.

title: REROUTING PROPOSED FOR DISPUTED NEW ELECTRIC LINE
description: The staff of the State Public Service Commission has recommended changes in a disputed plan for a transmission line that would carry inexpensive Canadian hydroelectric power to the New York metropolitan area.

title: A. H. Barada Married To Suzanne Schwind
description: Suzanne Kirkwood Schwind, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Edmond Moran of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Andrew Henry Barada, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Silvestre Barada 3d of New Canaan and Nantucket, Mass. The Rev. Thomas A. McGrath performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in Darien, Conn.

title: Communist Shoot-Out
description: Tribal rivalries hamper the dozens of Afghan insurgent groups but at least they refrain from attacking each other because they hate the Russians more. Moscow's puppets seem more bitterly divided, however, and last week diplomats reported a long-standing feud between two factions of the ruling Communist Party erupted in shooting near the city of Herat; about 100 soldiers and policemen were said to have been killed or wounded.

title: TRYING TO REGAIN ELEGANCE OF 20'S
description: When it was built in 1923, the Midston House, at the corner of 38th Street and Madison Avenue, was conceived as a club-style hotel, with much of its space devoted to lounges and public rooms.

title: MUSIC: MALE CHORUSES PERFORM AT LINCOLN CENTER
description: An enthusiastic crowd greeted male choruses from Chicago, Madison, Wis., and Los Angeles at the first concert of Come Out and Sing Together, which is billed as ''the first national gay choral festival.''

title: CORRECTION
description: The date of a concert by the Chinese pianist Yin Cheng-Zong, his North American debut, is incorrectly advertised in today's Arts and Leisure Section. Mr. Yin will perform at 8 P.M. Wednesday, Sept. 28.

title: JAPANESE CAREFULLY JOIN OUTCRY OVER JETLINER
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone on Saturday denounced the Soviet missile attack on a South Korean passenger airliner as ''an affront to humanity'' and said ''Japan must deal firmly with such behavior.''

title: Sandra L. Dana Becomes a Bride
description: Sandra Ladson Dana, daughter of Eleanor W. Dana of New Canaan, Conn., and Charles A. Dana Jr. of New Canaan and New York, was married yesterday to Robert James O'Donnell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Donnell of Haverford, Pa., and Newport, R.I. The Rev. Frederick S. Baldwin, assisted by the Rev. William A. Eddy Jr., performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan.

title: CONNORS, LENDL WIN
description: In what was simply a study in domination, Martina Navratilova, the most successful female tennis player over the last two years, reaffirmed her claim as the world's best by thrashing Chris Evert Lloyd yesterday to win her first United States Open championship. The scores were 6-1, 6-3 in a final that lasted just 63 minutes.

title: CABARET: DINAH WASHINGTON PORTRAIT
description: In the hierarchy of female jazz singers, Dinah Washington holds a high place, although she never gained the renown of Bessie Smith or Billie Holiday or Ella Fitzgerald, who preceded her, Sarah Vaughan, who was her contemporary, or even Betty Carter, the innovative singer who followed her. One might think that this was because she was too closely allied to the world of rhythm and blues.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
COUNTRY FAIR
description: Although it's starting off on a contemporary note - with a 10-kilometer race (10 A.M.; registration $5) - the Fourth Annual Brookhaven Town Country Fair today will have a decidedly old-fashioned look to it; after all, its theme is another nod in the direction of Suffolk's Tercentenary celebration. So, from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., the grounds of the Longwood Estate on Longwood Road in Ridge will be alive with demonstrations of spinning, weaving and blacksmithing; a Revolutionary War military encampment, historic Long Island and Indian exhibitions, folk music concerts, games and children's hayrides. Two rooms of the historic Smith Estate will also be open to the public. Everything is free.SMITHTOWN'S HERITAGE

title: A.G. Balbus Wed To Debra Chason
description: Debra Ann Chason, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Chason of Harrison, N.Y., was married yesterday to Andrew G. Balbus, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome H. Balbus of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Robert Rothman performed the ceremony at the Chason home.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Frank Gagliano, the Rutgers track coach, will become coach at Georgetown Oct. 1. He will replace Joe Lang, who has been elevated to assistant athletic director. . . . Pat O'Neil has been elected chairman of the board of the Cleveland Indians.

title: THOUSANDS DELIGHT IN MANETAT MET OPENING
description: The line began forming at 7:45 yesterday morning, two hours before tickets went on sale.

title: COAST CITY SPURNS ACTION ON ALIENS
description: Like many areas of Orange County, Santa Ana receives a large share of the hundreds of thousands of illegal aliens who cross the Mexican border 100 miles to the south each year. They now make up 25 percent of the city's population.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: LEADERS of industry and a coalition of environmentalists and labor unions are keeping an eye on Governor Kean's office these days, eagerly waiting to see whom he appoints to an 11-seat advisory council that will oversee implementation of the Worker and Community Right to Know Law.

title: COMPUTER LITERACY: ETHICS A KEY WORD
description: DICK has 10 computer programs and Jane has none. If Dick buys one more program and lends it to Jane to copy, how much software should Jane now have?

title: Lisa Ann Ross Is Wed To Producer-Director
description: Lisa Ann Ross, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert A. Ross of Hampton, N.H., was married yesterday to Abbott Kimball Andresen, son of Ann Kimball Andresen of New Canaan, Conn., and Malcolm Andresen of New York. The Rev. Duncan McQueen performed the Episcopal ceremony at Wheatleigh, an inn in Lenox, Mass.

title: PLAYLAND RECORDS RISE IN ATTENDANCE AND INCOME OVER '82
description: PLAYLAND, like some of its rides, has had its ups and downs in recent years, but according to figures released last week, the county's 279- acre amusement park in Rye ended its 1983 season ahead of last year in terms of attendance and revenue,

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a computer keypunch error, ''Tough Times Don't Last, Tough People Do!'' by Robert H. Schuller was incorrectly included in the Nonfiction Best Seller List published in today's Book Review section. The books ranked sixth through fifteenth should have been ranked one position higher and ''The F Plan Diet'' by Audrey Eyton should have been ranked fifteenth.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: The Long and Short Of Dresses for 57 Years Martha West has been a family- owned shop in White Plains for 57 years, specializing in knitwear and special-occasion long and short dresses. The main sale periods are July and December, but sale items are available beyond those periods. Sizes are 6 to 42 and 10 1/2 to 26 1/2, with custom orders possible for the hard- to-fit at no extra charge.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: HAYWORTH FUND RAISING

title: CABLE STILL PLAYS IT SAFE
description: Already recognizing the simple logistical fact that there are not enough worthwhile theatrical-release movies to fill up 24-hour schedules seven days a week, the major pay-cable organizations such as Home Box Office and Showtime have been increasingly acquiring or directly financing other kinds of programming fare. The monthly lineups now include children's shows, a smattering of sports, a good deal of comedy formats and pop-music concerts, some stage productions and, perhaps most significant as far as the film industry is concerned, original made-for-cable movies.

title: Ann G. Huntress, E. M. Lamont Jr. Are Wed on L.I.
description: Ann Greenlee Huntress, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll B. Huntress of Naples, Fla., and Edward Miner Lamont Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lamont of Laurel Hollow, L.I., were married yesterday by the Rev. T. Carlton Lee at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: THE POINT OF VIEW WAS MASCULINE
description: WILLA. The Life of Willa Cather. By Phyllis C. Robinson. Illustrated. 321 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $17.95.

title: Bruce Walton Weds Nancy Barton Motley
description: Nancy Barton Motley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Lothrop Motley Jr. of Dover and West Falmouth, Mass., was married yesterday to Bruce Hunter Walton, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Hunter Walton of Montclair, N.J., and West Hyannisport, Mass. The Rev. Deene D. Clark performed the ceremony at the Dover Congregrational Church.

title: MUSIC
description: The Chamber Opera Theater of New York, a group that has been praised in the past for its unusual productions of chamber opera, will present the world premiere of Lee Hoiby's ''The Italian Lesson'' on a double bill with Kurt Weill's ''He Who Says Yes,'' Wednesday at 8 P.M. at the Marymount Manhattan Theatre, 221 East 71st Street.

title: Dede Cummings, Designer, Weds
description: Jean Ellis Cummings, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Cummings of Providence, R.I., was married yesterday to Stephen Carmichael, son of Stacy Tobin Carmichael and Martin Carmichael, both of New York. The Rev. Virgil Brallier performed the ceremony in the New Marlborough (N.H.) Meeting House.

title: CONTROVERSY WITH RUSSIANS IN GLEN COVE FLARES ANEW
description: THE diplomatic war between Moscow and Glen Cove over beach privileges for Soviet diplomats has flared up again, with Mayor Alan M. Parente expressing concern for the safety and security of the Russians and suggesting that ''if they are unhappy, they should move out of town.''

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE gypsy moth infestation that ravaged trees throughout the northern half of New Jersey in 1981 and 1982 declined noticeably this spring and summer, and state agricultural officials say the worst is about over.

title: Ribant Team Wins
description: Dennis Ribant of Newport Beach, Calif., who pitched for the Mets from 1964 to 66, teamed with his 18-year-old daughter, Tracy, to win the father- daughter championship in the Equitable Family Tennis competition at the National Tennis Center. They defeated John and Kristen Skogstad of Atlanta, 6-3, 7-5.

title: No Headline
description: SCATTERED across Connecticut is a small circle of people, some unknown to each other, who are engaged in fighting an international radio war. The group includes a former United States Senator, James L. Buckley of Sharon; an electronics engineer from Stamford, Geza Zeigler; a Sino- Soviet specialist from Ridgefield, Jean Shalieff, and the president of RKO General Inc., Frank Shakespeare of Greenwich.

title: BIG BUCKS FOR BIG NAMES IN BUSINESS
description: Even Harry Walker can't sign everyone. ''We would give our right arm to have Paul Volcker under exclusive contract,'' acknowledged Mr. Walker, whose New York agency, Harry Walker Inc., handles about 3,000 bookings for hundreds of speakers each year.

title: OHIO NEWSPAPER FIGHTS LAW ON RETRACTIONS
description: A man identified only as ''Bill'' in an Akron newspaper article in June about wrongdoings at a race track is trying to obtain a retraction and has asked the Summit County prosecutor's legal help.

title: BERT R. HAAS
description: Bert R. Haas, a financial analyst who specialized in the construction industry, died Friday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A DEATH IN GUATEMALA STRAINS TIES WITH U.S.
description: Early one morning last February, a Guatemalan linguist disappeared. He had been working on a United States education project in his country, and was last seen being driven by soldiers into a military base in northwestern Guatemala.

title: LEBANON PEACEKEEPING SETS STAGE FOR WAR POWERS DEBATE
description: Aclassic battle is shaping up between the President and the Congress over Lebanon, where the civil war is intensifying and American marines and other peacekeeping forces are taking increasing casualties and shooting back. It is classic in that it is likely to be more over form and procedure than substance; what there is of substance is likely to be more in the nature of handwringing than of exploring alternatives to the Administration's policy of hanging in there.

title: NEW PORT OFFICIAL CALLS 'DRIVE' CRUCIAL
description: THE man who on Tuesday will be sworn in as the newest commissioner of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey attributes his success in both business and public life to drive and a dedication to succeed.

title: Hunt for Missing Sailor Ends
description: The search for a missing sailboat crewman has been suspended pending further developments, the Coast Guard said today. The crewman, Manuel Jose Rodrigues, has been missing since early Tuesday when the 41-foot sailboat Boom-Boom sank about 45 miles east of Cape May. Two Coast Guard cutters, two helicopters and an airplane had been searching for Mr. Rodriques since the boat went down.

title: Independence Vote Gains In Marshall Islands
description: With about 50 percent of the votes counted, a plebiscite in the Marshall Islands on adopting a form of limited independence from the United States was winning by 2,917 votec to 2,022.

title: Wedding in Greenwich for Gay Larkin And John T. J. Coe, a Mining Engineer
description: Gay Katherine Larkin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sylvester Patrick Larkin Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to John Taylor Johnston Coe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Eugene Coe 3d of Lawrence, L.I., and Johannesburg. The Rev. John Bishop, assisted by the Rev. Douglas Ray, performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Jersey's Medicaid Pays For a Heart Transplant
description: A 19-year-old former Newark athlete has undergone the first heart transplant paid for by New Jersey Medicaid.

title: A PORTRAIT OF THE SMELLS OF 1943
description: I DON'T know if it's a metabolic exchange my body is experiencing or simply the process of aging nostalgically. The fact of the matter is that I've been yearning for the smells of yesteryear a lot lately.

title: THE OBLIGATIONS OF A SURVIVOR
description: DO I have the right to call myself a survivor? The question has arisen often in my thoughts during the past years, yet I had no answer until recently.

title: HELPING THE NEEDY SAVE ENERGY
description: THE Cuomo Administration has created a new energy-conservation program to help New Yorkers with low to moderate incomes improve their residences.

title: ON THE DOWNING OF KOREAN AIR LINES FLIGHT 7
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SYDNEY
description: ''Well, mate, how do you like the place!'' Visitors to Sydney are always asked that question, usually by the taxi driver who takes them from Kingsford Smith Airport to the center of town. With luck, it'll be after they pass through the nondescript sprawl of outlying suburbs and had at least a glimpse of the harbor. Even then an answer really isn't necessary. Like most of the four million or so inhabitants, the cabbies are confident that Sydney is everything a major city should be. The Rocks

title: WORKERS TAKE OVER THE STORE
description: ON A RAINY NIGHT IN northeast Philadelphia, a bookkeeper and a couple of stock clerks could be seen through the plate-glass windows of the O&O Supermarket. For everyone else, the workday had ended.

title: ON THE DOWNING OF KOREAN AIR LINES FLIGHT 7
description: To the Editor:

title: THE TREES OF WARSAW
description: The anchors Mr. Rosenthal mentions in his essay may indeed be the symbols of the Gdansk shipyard, the nation, or the union of nation and church, as he suggests.

title: TENSION REPORTED TO RISE IN RURAL PHILIPPINES
description: An official who attended a quarterly meeting of Philippine provincial governors and city mayors in Manila on Friday said only 15 of 130 who normally would have been present attended the session.

title: Rosanna Agnew Becomes a Bride
description: Rosanna Elizabeth Agnew, daughter of the late Seth Marshall Agnew and the late Mary Elisabeth Edes Agnew of New York, was married yesterday to Walter Owen LaBonte Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. LaBonte of Springfield, Mass. The Rev. Harry Longley performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Siasconset (Mass.)

title:
GARDENING;
NEGLECTED HOSTA RETURNING TO FAVOR
description: THE versatility of many modern flowering plants is really quite remarkable. Plants considered to be adapted for use under limited circumstances but a generation ago are used successfully in a much broader variety of situations today.

title: WATCH THIS SPACE
description: Late last spring a community group in the Times Square area initiated an unsuccessful campaign to prevent the demolition of the old Seymour Hotel at 50 West 45th Street. The Landmarks Preservation Commission had identified the 81-year-old, 12-story brick Beaux Arts- style building as a structure it planned to consider for landmark designation, but the Seymour did not have any sort of protective status and was torn down in June to make way for a new structure.

title: MEXICAN UNIONIST IS ABDUCTED IN U.S.
description: A Mexican oil union official accused of embezzling millions of dollars was kidnapped from a Texas border town this week and returned here to face possible prosecution.

title: HYDROPOWER LOWERS RATES FOR A SMALL L.I. UTILITY
description: Dennis and Pat Farrell live in a threebedroom Cape Cod house with their three children. Their latest electric bill was $92.60.

title: State of Emergency Ends in Most of Peru
description: A state of emergency imposed on Peru was lifted today in all but three provinces in the Andes.

title: PLAN TO SWAP PRIVATE LAND FOR FEDERAL AREA STIRS EAST END
description: IN the Hamptons, where an acre in the right place can sell for well into six figures, wrangling over real estate is common enough. Nevertheless, an attempt by one of Southampton Town's biggest landowners to exchange 227 acres of wetlands and 106 acres of uplands that he owns for 45 federally owned acres, concurrently managed by the Fish and Wildlife Service of the Department of the Interior as part of the Conscience Point National Wildlife Refuge, has caused an uncommon commotion.

title: Valerie Ann Nifosi Weds
description: Valerie Ann Nifosi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Nifosi of Smoke Rise, N.J., was married in Manhattan yesterday to Matthew John Gilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger P. Gilson of Syracuse. The Rev. John Andrew performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, assisted by Msgr. John Ryan, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: WETLANDS CELEBRATING NATURE
description: DECOY CARVING has an honored and historic place in the pantheon of American crafts, and an extensive display and sale of decoys by well-known craftsmen will be one of the highlights of a new nature-oriented festival next Saturday and Sunday in southern New Jersey.

title: Barbara L. Kaul, Paul L. LeBlanc Exchange Vows
description: At the Congregational Church in New Canaan, Conn., yesterday Barbara Lee Kaul, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Winter Kaul of Rochester, was married to Paul Lanford LeBlanc, son of Mr. and Mrs. Moreland Paul LeBlanc of Darien, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles Crawford Smith.

title: 'DISCOVERING' CONFLICTS
description: ALLEN LEEPA'S statement, ''I paint to discover new conflicts,'' is amply borne out by the visual evidence in his current exhibition at the Abraham Rattner Memorial Studio in Sag Harbor, where a selection of works from the last 10 years is on view through Oct. 2. His canvases and drawings investigate conflict on two levels, the esthetic and the personal.

title: MIANUS BRIDGE NORTH OPENED TO BIG VEHICLES
description: For the first time since a section of a Connecticut Turnpike bridge collapsed here nearly 10 weeks ago, heavy vehicles were allowed today to pass over the temporary span replacing it.

title: A KEY SALVADORAN PROVINCE STILL HAS SOME TESTS TO PASS
description: Col. Jose Dionisio Hernandez drew out his collapsible pointer and tapped its tip on his map of the central province of San Vicente where he commands the 5th Brigade.

title: STORYTELLER SPINS TALES OF PIRACY OLD
description: BY her own admission, E. J. Wagner is a ''compulsive talker.'' And especially when the subject is mysterious - murder or crime or forensic medicine, the things that interest her most these days - the words pour forth like a torrent.

title: U.S. SAID TO SOFTEN STAND ON MISSILES AT GENEVA PARLEY
description: American negotiators at the Geneva talks on medium-range nuclear missiles have been empowered to make new concessions, according to Administration officials.

title: IS IT ART? CRAFT? OR JUST A VISION OF LIGHT?
description: THERE are as many attitudes toward light in images as there are artists, and maybe a few more. Some artists are possessed by something akin to a spiritual fervor to simulate a light as real as that in nature and some must create a factitious light, a vision of their minds divorced from the real world.

title: PERILS AND PROFITS OF PENSION ADVISERS
description: DAVID Booth makes it look easy. Once a successful investment consultant with the Wall Street firm of A. G. Becker, Paribas Inc., he left in 1981 and set up his own office in the second bedroom of his brownstone apartment in Brooklyn Heights. Business seemed to fall in his lap: In only 18 months, his firm, Dimensional Fund Advisors, has landed 48 corporate pension fund accounts and now manages $650 million for clients like International Business Machines, Celanese, Standard Oil of Indiana and the Retirement System of Maryland. And he still has time to take midday jogs across the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: CONNECTICUT WILL DECIDE MUNICIPAL PRIMARIES
description: Contests for mayoral nominations in Bridgeport, Stamford and Waterbury will highlight primary elections in Connecticut on Tuesday.

title: SOVIET HAS HANDED REAGAN A POWERFUL ARGUMENT FOR MX
description: With the change of season has came a change in the political climate of Washington that will affect some important legislation. The summer preoccupation with the risks of American military involvement in Central America has given way to an emotional focus on the downing of a Korean airliner by a Soviet fighter plane.

title: ADDING A VOICE TO THE CHORUS
description: AS an alumnus of the New York University Glee Club, I can vouch that no amount of concert-going quite compensates for the joy one gets in singing it oneself. While instrumentalists must function with high technical proficiency to contribute to the success of an orchestra, almost anyone who can carry a tune can hold his own in a chorus, quite literally adding a meaningful voice to some of the greatest music ever written. At least five county choirs have sent out calls for new members; you can not join them all - four of them rehearse on Tuesday evenings - but may wish to consider trying out for one.

title: Station Platform
description: The concrete platform at the New Canaan, Conn., rail station had crumbled, and was closed early in 1982 as a safety measure. The only way off the eight-car rush-hour trains for the 1,000 commuters was through two or three cars served by steel stairways to the rear of the platform, a slow process that prolonged the journey.

title: VISITING CHINA ON YOUR OWN
description: China. Most people would envision climbing the Great Wall, scouring the Forbidden City, feasting on Peking duck. I imagined being stuck on a tour bus with everyone snapping pictures. No surprises. Everything smooth. No serendipity. No more. It is now possible to go to China on one's own. One must arrange for a private guide and follow a set itinerary, but the cost is relatively low and if adventure is what one is after, it is nearly impossible to avoid.

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: BLOOD & ORCHIDS. By Norman Katkov. 503 pp. New York: Marek/St. Martin's. $15.95.

title: Swiss Valais
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Claghorn Weds Stuart W. Ferguson
description: Susan Strawbridge Claghorn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Winthrop Claghorn Jr. of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Stuart William Ferguson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Woodrow Ferguson of Newtown, Iowa. The Quaker ceremony was performed at the Friends Meeting House in Princeton.

title: GARDENING
description: THE versatility of many modern flowering plants is really quite remarkable. Plants considered to be adapted for use under limited circumstances but a generation ago are used successfully in a much broader variety of situations today.

title: Call to Enforce Drug Policies
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WHEN THE TWAIN MEET
description: I was in Taipei's ''Snake Alley'' when I realized fully that I had come far from home. A young man with more enthusiasm than a circus barker was holding forth at a staccato beat before 20 people gathered outside a small restaurant. Around him were the carcasses of dead snakes.

title: Getting Grants
description: To the Editor:

title: Micheal F. Nagi Wed To Janis Lynn Kuehn
description: Janis Lynn Kuehn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Duvier Kuehn of North Salem, N.Y., was married yesterday to Micheal Franklin Nagi, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Paul Arthur Nagi of Boston. The Rev. Clayton Lund performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: U.S. BRACES FOR ITS STIFFEST YACHTING TEST
description: The series of yacht races that will mark the 25th defense of the historic America's Cup is to start Tuesday at a buoy 7.8 miles southeast of the Brenton Reef Tower on Rhode Island Sound.

title: Ann McK. Wiser Becomes a Bride
description: Ann McKee Wiser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Forwood Cloud Wiser Jr. of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Glen Fries, son of Mr. and Mrs. George R. Fries of Lewiston, Mont. The Rev. Richard Bower performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 11, 1983
description: International

title: MIXING POWER AND DELICACY
description: WHEN the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art began to devote an annual installation to area talent several years ago, it initiated a series that would become one of the institution's most appealing programs.

title: VODKA BOYCOTT URGED
description: CONNECTICUT last week joined a widening movement to curb the purchase of Russian vodka in protest of the Soviet downing of a South Korean jetliner with 269 people on board.

title: Poetry Translations
description: To the Editor:

title: SHRINE OF THE SHOGUN
description: Much of Japan's beauty, both natural and man-made, is a subtle attraction. From bonsai trees to shoji screens, the esthetic inclination of Japan has usually been toward simplicity and miniaturization. It is little wonder that this is the case on a volcanic archipelago the size of California, crowded with people and short of space. So Japan is rarely considered a place of jolting scenic vistas or human monuments. Yet the country does have spots that, at a glance, will make jaws drop. Perhaps nowhere in Japan are more such experiences offered than in Nikko, 75 miles and a two- hour train ride north of Tokyo, owing to the handiwork of both man and nature.

title: No Headline
description: Dennis Brutus would be a ''prime target'' of South Africa if he were deported to his native Zimbabwe, and ruled the black poet could stay out of range. The granting of political asylum ended a two-year battle for Mr. Brutus, whom the Justice Department had sought to deport for ''classified'' reasons that were not disclosed. Mr. Brutus, a professor of literature at Northwestern University, has actively campaigned against apartheid and is considered largely responsible for South Africa's exclusion from the Olympics. He is not, Judge Schwartz said, ''a menace to the United States, and that is the real test.''

title: Rutgers Defeats Connecticut, 22-5
description: Rutgers defeated Connecticut, 22-5, in its season's opener at Rutgers Stadium today, and the Scarlet encountered few surprises regarding its strengths and weaknesses.

title: OKLAHOMA A WINNER BY 27-14
description: Marcus Dupree gained 138 yards in 24 carries, and Earl Johnson, a freshman, ran for 96 yards and two touchdowns to lead Oklahoma to a 27-14 victory over Stanford today.

title: HOW WE KNOW THAT THEY KNOW THAT....
description: WHEN American military forces were training to rescue the American hostages in Iran in 1980, they feared that mock landing strips and replicas of the American Embassy in Teheran being built in the United States might be detected by Soviet satellites. Defense Department officials had similar fears that prototypes of so-called Stealth aircraft, planes designed to elude radar coverage, would be spotted by cameras aboard Soviet satellites as they passed over manufacturing sites in southern California.

title: CITY LENT $19 MILLION FOR RENT TO PEOPLE ON WELFARE IN 1982
description: Edna DeJesus says she is constantly worried about her rent.

title: So Put On a Happy Face
description: Smiling may sometimes be worth it whether you want to or not. According to research by three University of California scientists, the mere act of flexing facial muscles to express happiness or other emotions can produce effects on the nervous system usually associated with such feelings.

title:
GARDENING;
NEGLECTED HOSTA RETURNING TO FAVOR
description: THE versatility of many modern flowering plants is really quite remarkable. Plants considered to be adapted for use under limited circumstances but a generation ago are used successfully in a much broader variety of situations today.

title: NEW U.S. RIGHTS AIDE BACKS WHITES FOR JOBS IN MEMPHIS
description: The new staff director of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, an appointee of President Reagan, is urging the agency to reverse itself and support the seniority rights of white firefighters over the competing job claims of blacks hired later under an affirmative action plan.

title: 17 TREES FIND A NEW HOME IN 5TH AVE. AERIE
description: Fifth Avenue got 17 new 21-story- high trees yesterday. The trees started out on the ground and were hoisted to their place in the sun by a 140-ton crane.

title: MEETING ROSS MACDONALD
description: FRANK On July 11, Ross Macdonald died at the age of 67 in Santa Barbara, Calif. From sometime in the 1960's, he was widely considered to be the best contemporary American mystery writer, bringing a new psychological and literary complexity to the genre.

title: FOR ACTRESS, PIAF IS A CURSE AND BLESSING
description: ''IT'S a blessing and it's a curse,'' Juliette Koka said of her much-acclaimed identification with Edith Piaf.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: MASS MARKET

title: Marcos Foes Band Together
description: Opponents of Philippine President Ferdinand E. Marcos rushed to organize before passions aroused by the Aug. 21 murder of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. have cooled. Leaders of more than 50 political groups last week formed a national coordinating committee of former senators and other leaders.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: NO PLACE ON EARTH. By Christa Wolf. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $6.95.) Christa Wolf, the East German novelist, essayist and scriptwriter, writes about lack of freedom, about the kind of starvation that ''springs from a deprivation of something essential, a basic nutrient of the spirit,'' in the words of our reviewer, Marilyn French, who found this tightly woven novel ''more beautiful than mournful.'' Set in 1804, it portrays an imagined meeting between two real people - the playwright and poet Heinrich von Kleist and the canoness and poet Karoline von G"underrode - who feel themselves totally alienated from the culture that surrounds them. AMERICAN POLITICS: The Promise of Disharmony. By Samuel P. Huntington. (Harvard/Belknap Press, $6.95.) Exploring the relationship between political thought and political institutions, Samuel P. Huntington, an international affairs expert at Harvard University, observes that ''the gap between political ideal and political reality is a continuing central phenomenon of American politics in a way that is not true of any other major state.'' His book makes use ofmodern survey data as well as historical materials, and our critic, Andrew Hacker, found it ambitious in range, ingenious in analysis and filled with imaginative insights.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: FICTION

title: WHEN CONGRESS MET IN PRINCETON
description: ON June 30, 1783, Charles Thomson, the Secretary of Congress, sent a letter to his wife, Hannah, describing this town, where he and the members of the Continental Congress had arrived four days earlier.

title: JUSTICE DELAYED IS NOT JUSTICE
description: IF you live in Connecticut and are injured as a result of the negligence of an automobile driver, the design of a defective product or malpractice, you have the longest trial delay in the United States.

title: A Victory Not Only for Mr. Brutus
description: Dennis Brutus, a South African poet and one of apartheid's most devastating critics, has finally won political asylum in the United States - no thanks to the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The agency fought Mr. Brutus through nine months of hearings and sought his deportation even after its case against him collapsed.
