Happily, it is last week's ruling of an immigration judge, Irving Schwartz, and not the arguments of bungling I.N.S. prosecutors, that speaks for American justice.

title: Ammonia Sulfate Spilled In a Pristine Maine River
description: About 500 pounds of ammonia sulfate spilled from a blueberry processing plant into a pristine river, critically injuring a plant worker and killing everything living in a half-mile stretch of the river, officials say.

title: AIR SHOWS GAINING, DESPITE CRITICISM
description: LEO LOUDENSLAGER and Jim Roberts, pilots on the United States Olympic aerobatic team, spun their red and blue Lasers into daring loops, dives and rolls over Sussex County Airport.

title: KNIFE CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: BALLANTINE SITE AGAIN FROTHS WITH ACTIVITY
description: PURITY, body and flavor-the three- ring symbol of the P. Ballantine & Sons Brewery in Newark - was once emblazoned on every building in the vast manufacturing complex on the bank of the Passaic River in the city's Ironbound section.

title: Bomb Sent to School Official At L.I. Home Injures His Wife
description: A mail bomb sent to the Massapequa, L.I., home of a Long Island school superintendent exploded yesterday morning, injuring Patricia Kane, the official's 46-year-old wife.

title: 2 Disinter Their Father In Search of Bank Code
description: A brother and sister were arrested Friday in Spotsylvania County on a charge of disinterring the remains of their father, who was killed five years ago by another of his children, the police said.

title: Straining at the Leashl dogfight for
description: As custody battles go, it was a real dogfight for Judi Wheatland. Mrs. Wheatland, in the throes of a divorce from her husband, Rex, sought to keep the couple's pet cockapoo (a mix of cocker spaniel and poodle) as part of the settlement. But both claimed deep attachment to the dog, Runaway, and Mrs. Wheatland declined her husband's offer of $20,000 for her share of the animal, even though she had only $15 in the bank.

title: ON THE DOWNING OF KOREAN AIR LINES FLIGHT 7
description: To the Editor:

title: IN AUSTRALIA, LIBEL SUITS ARE PUBLIC TRADITION
description: When Prime Minister Robert J. Hawke recently sued three Australian news organizations here for financial compensation, including money from the taxpayer-supported national broadcasting system, there was little surprise and not much comment.

title: BLACK CONVICTED IN RETRIAL OF KILLING WHITE OFFICER
description: A black man whose first trial for killing a white police officer ended in a hung jury was convicted today of voluntary manslaughter. The retrial had led to increased tension in this city that prides itself on its improved racial climate.

title: INCURABLE AFFLICTION: BEING A GIANTS' FAN
description: I HAVE been a dyed-in-the-wool New York Football Giants' fan for the last 26 years. Last season, I interviewed approximately 55 Giants' fans to see if I could shed some light on why they had stuck with a loser for so long. The Giants, like Sisyphus's boulder, have dashed the hopes of their faithful and, at times, fanatical fans for all but two of the last 19 years. Yet they have sold out the four stadiums in which they have played since 1963, when they were last in a championship game.

title: In Praise Of Squid
description: I AM PERSUADED THAT name and appearance have as much to do with public acceptance, or denial, of a food as do flavor and texture. I think this is true of catfish and sea urchins, among others. And it is also true of squid, one of the most delectable products of the sea.

title: Gallup Poll Says 81% Endorse School Prayer
description: An overwhelming majority of Americans favor a constitutional amendment that would permit voluntary group prayer in public schools, according to a new Gallup poll.

title: ARRAY OF SONG AND CONCERTS
description: UNLIKE the situation with instrumentalists, who must function with technical proficiency if they are to contribute to the success of an orchestra, almost anybody who can carry a tune can hold his own in a chorus and add a meaningful voice to some great music.

title: PAINTING WILL GAIN A NEW PERSPECTIVE FROM THE PAST
description: The overwhelming focus of the 1983-84 museum season is painting - not just a random smattering of old and modern masters, although there is, as usual, a cross-section of the old and the new, but a concentrated dose of the kind of painting that can throw into perspective work being done now. By the time the season is over and museumgoers have seen Manet, Gris, Kandinsky, Balthus, de Kooning and the late work of Picasso, as well as Malcolm Morley and the best young Expressionist painters from Germany, contemporary painting will not look the same.

title: Mahaffey Widens Lead To 3 Shots on a 67-201
description: John Mahaffey overcame a sputtering start today as he widened his lead in the third round of the $350,000 Bank of Boston Golf Classic.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Tigers' Berenguer Stops Brewers, 4-0
description: Juan Berenguer pitched his first major league shutout with a four-hitter, and Chet Lemon drove in two runs with a homer and a sacrifice fly as the Detroit Tigers defeated the Milwaukee Brewers, 4-0, tonight. The game was delayed by rain for 15 minutes in the third inning.

title: Jets' Plans for Hector Are Speeded Up
description: Johnny Hector reported to the Jets rookie camp last spring with an open mind, an able body and humble aspirations.

title: WALLACE'S SON SEEKS HIS OWN POLITICAL BASE
description: At the age of 31, George C. Wallace Jr. is trying to cast off the image of ''Little George'' and emerge from the shadow of his famous father.

title: BEYOND THE COST OF THE 269 LIVES
description: The destruction of Korean Air Lines flight 007 killed more than 269 innocent people. It probably eliminated any possibility of rapprochement between the United States and the Soviet Union before the 1984 Presidential elections. Now, the United States will in all likelihood have to start deploying medium- range nuclear missiles in Europe. The Kremlin will respond with ''analogous'' deployments, and escalation of superpower tensions will inevitably follow.

title: NOTRE DAME SCORES 52-6 ROUT OF PURDUE
description: Greg Bell had come dressed for a special occasion, but he had no idea how special the opening game of Notre Dame's football season would be. The junior tailback arrived at Ross-Ade Stadium in a frilly white shirt, bow tie, suspenders and jacket that would be appropriate for a wedding. He was willing to settle for a celebration on a bus ride back to South Bend.

title: Wendy Warnken a Bride
description: Wendy Warnken, daughter of Helena Warnken of Astoria, Queens, and the late Henry Warnken Jr., was married in Stratford-on-Avon, England, yesterday to Stephen Burge Johnson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Johnson of Hamilton, Ontario. The Rev. G. Dennis Spiller performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Anglican Church. The bride is associate curator of the theater collection at the Museum of the City of New York. Mr. Johnson is a doctoral candidate in theater history at New York University.

title: Columbus Day Proclamation
description: President Reagan has issued a proclamation saying that Columbus Day, Oct. 10, will be ''a day of special importance to Americans of Italian heritage.'' The President said Tuesday that Columbus Day ''is a day when all Americans should join in recognizing the great contributions of Italian-Americans to this country's cultural, scientific, athletic and commercial achievements and religious vitality.''

title: COLGATE TOPS ARMY ON LATE FIELD GOAL
description: In his first game as Army's 30th head football coach, Jim Young practiced deception and trickery today, hoping to make up with eagerness what he lacked in weight and talent against a highly regarded Colgate team.

title: FIRST COME THE BOSSES
description: IS anybody looking for a boss? What a question! Nobody goes looking for a boss, especially the bossy kind.

title: WHEAT FOR NICARAGUA (VIA THE U.S.S.R.)
description: To the Editor:

title: TRADITION REASSERTS ITSELF IN PHOTOGRAPHY
description: If one reads the oracle correctly, this is a season in which the avant-garde is pausing for breath, the traditional is filling the gap, and a new sense of optimism is taking hold in the marketplace - this last conclusion based on the number of new or newly revived galleries that will be showing photography this fall. The work of such well-known 20th-century practitioners as Jousuf Karsh, Eliot Porter and Aaron Siskind will be on view in New York, but for the first time in three years Eugene Atget's will not - the Museum of Modern Art's third annual fall Atget exhibition is opening out of town, in Houston, and won't wend its way here until 1985.

title: FALL PREVIEW 1983
description: ONE Sunday last month, the New York Times fiction best-seller list recorded a first-place tie between ''The Name of the Rose,'' a first novel by Umberto Eco, an Italian scholar of semiotics, and ''Return of the Jedi,'' a heavily illustrated storybook based on the latest movie in the ''Star Wars'' series. It is not unusual that two such very different books are popular at the same time; that's one of the reasons why publishers, who can seldom figure out what readers want, adopt the shotgun approach. According to that concept, a wise publisher will issue every type of book he can think of, because something is bound to sell.

title: Guest Observer; The Fondue Ticket P. C. VEY
description: The doorbell rang. I thought it might be the guy to fix the gutters or maybe the garbage disposal. ''Are you here to fix things?'' I asked the six men on my porch.

title: A LOOK AT TODAY'S 'AIM-AND-SHOOT' CAMERAS
description: Ideal for those who do not yet own a camera and for the occasional snapshooter who is thinking of buying a new camera, today's inexpensive ''aim-and-shoot'' cameras are easier than ever to use and almost foolproof in operation under most conditions. There are currently two types which practically dominate the market: one that gives you instant color pictures without having to send the film out to be processed, and another that uses the new disc film which furnishes you with color prints after you have sent the exposed disc to a processing laboratory.

title: Banned in Israel
description: When Israel Television last week killed a hit television show called ''Tales of the Unexpected,'' the reason was no mystery.

title: THERE WILL BE ANNIVERSARIES AND MAYBE CONTROVERSY, TOO
description: This will be a year for anniversaries in New York dance. The Joffrey Ballet will celebrate its 30th season at the City Center Theater, which itself is celebrating its 40th year. And the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater turns 25 in November.

title: 'PROTECTED PLACE' AT JONES BEACH
description: How wonderful to read the article about the summer of 1947 at Jones Beach.

title: Mayor Shares Rewards of The Work Ethic
description: Even for those without homes, it may be cheaper to buy than to rent. So it seemed to Governor Cuomo, who suggested that New York City purchase some of its 50 welfare hotels to save money and improve conditions for the nearly 2,100 displaced families sheltered in them.

title: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION PLEDGED ON BERKELEY CAMPUS
description: The University at California at Berkeley says it intends to hire 31 minority and women faculty members by 1986 after the Labor Department cited 18 ''problem areas'' in the school's affirmative action program.

title: Margaret J. Parlatore Bride of Alfred F. Kelly Jr.
description: Margaret Joan Parlatore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Parlatore of Port Chester, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Alfred Francis Kelly Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kelly of Crestwood, N.Y. The Rev. Eugene Murphy, uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church and concelebrated the nuptial mass with Msgr. Cornelius O'Brien.

title: CORRECTION
description: Jane Porcino's title at the State University at Stony Brook was given incorrectly last week. She is director of the gerontology project of the university's continuing education program.

title: News Analysis
description: The television interview today with the pilot who shot down a Korean Air Lines 747 marked another reluctant step into the public view for the Soviet armed forces, which have been perhaps the most secretive in the world. In putting its version of the incident before the world, the Kremlin has divulged unusual scraps of information about its fighter aircraft, its air and naval bases in the Far East and the command system within the armed forces. The disclosures have also revealed what appear to be disastrous miscues that point to problems in training, equipment and command procedures.

title: IN STAMFORD, A 33-LANGUAGE SERVICE
description: IT is two fires that Jeff Dexter remembers. Both struck the tenements in this city and both sent into the nighttime streets dozens of people. In one fire, most of the suddenly homeless were Haitians; in the other, most were Ecuadoreans.

title: Turks Report Pipeline Fire
description: A fire broke out Friday in a pipeline from Iraq to the Turkish Mediterranean coast, halting the flow of oil through the line, the Turkish press agency Akajans reported.

title:
ANTIQUES;
WETHERSFIELD SHOW AT PICTURESQUE SITE
description: ONE of the best things about many Connecticut outdoor shows is that they are held on picturesque sites, on the lawns and meadows surrounding handsome old homes. The Wethersfield Antiques Festival is just such a show.

title: 2 RACES HIGHLIGHT PRIMARIES IN CITY
description: Two contests over Democratic nominations for Civil Court judgeships in separate Manhattan districts are the only races involving public positions in New York City's primary next Tuesday.

title: Out of Lebanon, Slowly
description: It is no insult to the Marines to observe that they are squatting in Lebanon like dumb ducks, taking casualties for reasons that no one seems able to articulate. It is no insult to President Reagan to observe that he can't articulate their mission because he can no longer perceive it or be sure about the right moment to end it. The troops and their Commander in Chief are playing for time, hoping that the moment will nominate itself.

title: DANCE: THERESA DICKINSON AND ANN WOODHEAD
description: The program that Theresa Dickinson and Ann Woodhead presented Friday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio was one of those frustrating occasions when talented performers sincerely try to collaborate and yet are unable to produce a satisfying evening of dance.

title: POP CONCERT: LAURA BRANIGAN
description: It was more than two years ago that the chairman of Atlantic Records, Ahmet Ertegun, the man responsible for Bette Midler's recording career, ''presented'' his latest protegee, Laura Branigan, in a concert at the Bottom Line. Since that concert, at which Miss Branigan seemed to be casting about for a musical identity, the singer has had three hits - ''Gloria,'' ''Solitaire'' and ''How Am I Supposed to Live Without You?'' - that have more or less established her as an American echo of European pop singers like the women in Abba.

title: Miss Funkhouser Weds K.C. Pierce
description: Kristen Nell Funkhouser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Brane Funkhouser of Los Angeles, and Kent Chamberlaine Pierce, son of Mr. and Mrs. Scott Pierce of Rye, N.Y., were married yesterday at the Norwich (Vt.) Congregational Church.

title: SURPRISING FINALE IN BRINK'S TRIAL
description: AS might have been expected in a case that saw an attorney attempt to sway a jury by playing a saxophone solo recorded by a defendant, the Federal Brink's trial in Manhattan ended on a strange note. Last weekend's verdict left defense lawyers smiling, prosecutors speechless and Judge Kevin Thomas Duffy perplexed. ''I've never understood juries,'' he grumbled after four defendants were convicted of various charges - but not the most serious ones - and two were acquitted in a case that stemmed from the 1981 Rockland robbery, other armored-car holdups in Danbury, Conn., Inwood, L.I., and the Bronx, and the jailbreak of Black Liberation Army leader Joanne Chesimard.

title: SELF-MADE STORES
description: In recent years, a particularly strong following has emerged for certain men's specialty stores whose independent spirit has taken them beyond just good service. These are stores that project the personality and taste of the individuals who own and run them. They range from single exclusive shops to small chains, and their offerings, from avant-garde to the most classic and conservative. But it is their distinct point of view that makes them unique.

title: TRENTON: WEST COAST EXPRESSIONISM
description: A TOURING show of nonobjective watercolors, acrylics and drawings by Jack Roth is making its last stop at the State Museum in Trenton, having originated at Ramapo College last year.

title: 'JEDI' LEADS RECORD-SETTING SUMMER FILM SEASON
description: ''Return of the Jedi'' was by far the biggest Hollywood box-office winner, with nearly a quarter of a billion dollars as the summer movie season ended in a record-breaking American and Canadian gross of $1.5 billion.

title: MORE EUROPEANS PLAN BOYCOTTS OF FLIGHTS TO SOVIET
description: The British Government, Finnish and Italian pilots and Swedish air controllers announced separate boycotts of Soviet flights today to protest the shooting down of a South Korean airliner by a Soviet fighter.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: A STUDY commissioned by the New England Foundation for the Arts reveals that artists in Connecticut are less likely to need to supplement their incomes through work outside their art forms than artists elsewhere in New England.

title: McGovern News Talk Set
description: Former Senator George McGovern will announce Tuesday whether he will seek the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination, a spokesman has said. Mr. McGovern, 61 years old, became the biggest loser in a Presidential election when President Nixon beat him in 1972.

title: HEMINGWAY SET HIS OWN HOURS
description: UNANSWERABLE questions still surface at parties. ''What kind of novels do you write?''

title: A HISTORY OF A PAINFUL TIME
description: THE VIETNAM EXPERIENCE. By Clark Dougan, Edward Doyle, Samuel Lipsman, Terrence Maitland, Peter McInerney, Stephen Weiss and the editors of the Boston Publishing Company. Volume One. Setting the Stage. 191 pp. Volume Two. Passing the Torch. 208 pp. Volume Three. Raising the Stakes. 192 pp. Volume Four. America Takes Over. 192 pp. Volume Five. A Contagion of War. 192 pp. Volume Six. Nineteen Sixty-Eight. 192 pp. Illustrated. Boston: Boston Publishing Co. $16.95 each.

title: A Plan to Buy Better Teachers
description: Governor Kean told the New Jersey Legislature last week that the state must pay higher salaries to teachers if it intends to impose higher standards on students. He proposed state subsidies to guarantee an $18,500 starting salary for teachers and the establishment of a new ''master teacher'' program that would dispense $5,000 awards to those selected as outstanding.

title: Rare Cranes Will Start Migration in 3 Weeks
description: Whooping cranes begin their annual flight from Canada to Texas about Oct. 1, and biologists are planning to track them using radio transmitters.

title: WHAT IT'S LIKE IN A COCKPIT ON THE NORTH PACIFIC ROUTE
description: The radar screen tucked near Capt. William Powers's left knee aboard the Pan Am clipper Mayflower clearly showed the tip of Kamchatka Peninsula and the Kuril Islands to the right of the jet.

title: Montclair Gets Tie On a Late Fumble
description: Darin Small recovered a fumble on the Wagner 3-yard line and ran it into the end zone with 55 seconds left to give Montclair State a 20-20 tie with the Seahawks last night before 8,356 fans at Sprague Field in Upper Montclair, N. J.

title: Launching People Into Publishing
description: As hundreds of new titles pour out of the nation's publishing firms every fall, scores of new employees pour in. Over the past few years, many have come from university summer programs that give recent graduates, adults starting second careers and visitors from foreign houses training in a range of publishing skills and an overview of the publishing process - knowledge that many people who work in large, compartmentalized firms never get the chance to acquire. Three institutes are illustrative. A Pioneering Project.

title: Linda Gifford Is Married
description: Linda Shields Gifford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Cammann Gifford of Madison, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass., was married in Nantucket yesterday to Harold Edward Herrick 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herrick Jr. of Cape Vincent, N.Y. The Rev. Herbert S. Stephens performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: Chrysler's New Improved Offer
description: The Chrysler Corporation last week sweetened the pot by $135 million, and that may be enough to keep it from boiling over.

title: Hawaii Wedding For Laurie Foster
description: Laurie Foster, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Foster of Honolulu, was married there yesterday to Peter C. Brooks, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Oakley Brooks of New York and Edgartown, Mass. The Rev. Robert Midgley performed the ceremony at the Central Union Congregational Church.

title: 300 Besiege Federal Building In Antinuclear Rally on Coast
description: The police were forced to bar the doors of the Federal Building to keep out 300 chanting antinuclear protesters who smashed a cardboard likeness of an MX missile against the doors amid shouted pledges of support for four hunger strikers.

title: Maine
description: To the Editor:

title: SHOPPING BY DAWN'S EARLY LIGHT
description: HOW worthwhile is it for the collector to rise early enough to reach a country show before dawn? Can dealers be expected to summon the stamina for an all-day event after having traveled and set up the night before?

title: SATELLITES MAIN SOURCE OF PHOTO DATA FOR U.S.
description: Soviet contentions that the Boeing 747 shot down by Soviet fighters on Sept. 1 was a spy plane are scoffed at by American and NATO specialists and others who know the capacity and uses of United States reconnaissance satellites and planes.

title: Stepien's Comeback
description: During the months Ted Stepien sought to retain his ownership of the financially troubled Cleveland Cavaliers, he tried to move the National Basketball Association franchise to Toronto.

title: Coleen O'Shea, Editor, Is Wed to David Anderson
description: Coleen Margaret O'Shea, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. O'Shea of Woodcliff Lake, N.Y., and David Buell Anderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Anderson of Westport, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. James Turro performed the ceremony in the Sacred Heart Chapel of Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church in Park Ridge, N.J.

title: ON THE DOWNING OF KOREAN AIR LINES FLIGHT 7
description: To the Editor:

title: FORUM PLANNED AT PURCHASE
description: IN a new program sponsored by 11 corporations based in Westchester and in Fairfield County in Connecticut, four nationally known speakers will be coming to the Purchase campus of the State University of New York. The lecture series, entitled ''The President's Leadership Forum,'' will begin this month and continue into the spring.

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: HOLLYWOOD WIVES. By Jackie Collins. 510 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: NAMIBIANS ASSAIL GOVERNING SYSTEM
description: A Government commission says this South African territory's multilayered system of racial and ethnic governments has led to widespread mismanagement, inefficiency and corruption.

title: Ad Standards
description: To the Business Editor:

title: THE BLOCKBUSTER TAKES OVER
description: This season, more than ever, the blockbuster event will spell the difference between success or failure in prime time for the three major networks. And this season, more than ever, ABC, CBS and NBC will feel the competitive heat from cable services and ad hoc networks offering large- scale - and exclusive - productions of their own.

title: Sarah G. Potter Weds J. E. Clune
description: Sarah Gordon Potter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barrie Vernon Potter of Deep River, Conn., was married there yesterday to Jonathan Edward Clune, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Conrad Clune of Minerva, N.Y. The Rev. Joan Forsberg performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church.

title: Trump Toast
description: To the Business Editor:

title: MEIJI MODERNIZING
description: LOW CITY, HIGH CITY. Tokyo From Edo to the Earthquake. By Edward Seidensticker. Illustrated. 302 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $20.

title: THE TREES OF WARSAW
description: A. M. Rosenthal's article deserves some special attention, not only by virtue of its lengthiness and prominent place; it deserves attention, first of all, as an example of unobjective - even dishonest - writing.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: WILLIAM CARLOS WILLIAMS, who was born in Rutherford 100 years ago this coming Saturday, who lived there all his life and who practiced medicine three for over 40 years, is being hailed as ''the best American poet of the century.''

title: Q&A
description: Discordant Wedding Bells

title: TOWN LAW TESTS WATER
description: THE Town of Brookhaven recently put a new factor into its dispute with Suffolk County and the State of New York over jurisdiction in the Suffolk County pine barrens by enacting its own water-resource regulations.

title: POTENTIAL IS HARD TO IGNORE BUT ALSO HARD TO REALIZE
description: THE quickening drive by both major American political parties to win the hearts and votes of Mexican-American, Puerto Rican and other Hispanic citizens in 1984 raises two important questions: Are these groups really as fast-growing as their political leaders like to claim? And can they be motivated to flex their new political muscle?

title: MENTAL CLINICS FIND SPACE IN CHURCHES
description: SEVERAL hundred residents of the county are going to church every week, but not to attend services. Instead, they are patients at mental health clinics that now occupy unused Sunday school rooms at parish houses in about 40 churches.

title: AT 20, 'THE LEOPARD' IS FLEETER THAN EVER
description: Nearly 20 years to the day after its New York premiere, ''The Leopard,'' the late Luchino Visconti's screen adaptation of Giuseppe de Lampedusa's epic novel of Sicily at the time of the Risorgimento, has returned to New York. This time ''The Leopard'' is being shown in the Italian- language version that is called ''the original,'' although no original, single-language version of the film ever existed, and with 25 minutes of footage restored. The reappearance of this enchanting work proves that, under the right circumstances, two decades make no difference whatsoever but 25 minutes can transform a very good film into a possibly great one.

title: STADIUM'S FUTURE WEIGHED
description: THE Freeport Municipal Stadium Speedway, the only auto-racing stadium in Nassau County, may be entering its last lap on a collision course with village officials. Freeport's 10-year contract with Campi Enterprises, operator of the speedway, will expire in January.

title: Reactor Fuel Sample Moved
description: Technicians at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant retrieved the first sample of damaged radioactive fuel from the core of the inactive Unit 2 reactor Friday, officials said. The sample was taken from a bed of rubble left in the reactor core after the worst accident in the history of commercial nuclear power.

title: We Hear You, Mr. President
description: In a country that worships youth and fitness, age and its inconveniences are often treated like dirty little secrets. If people lie about their age, it is because they fear being perceived as over the hill. If they hide their infirmities, it is because they fear being perceived as less than whole. By wearing a hearing aid in public, President Reagan helps to relieve the pressure to do either.

title: A New Inning of Hardball on Capital Hill
description: Congress settles in for another burst of legislating this week, and, all in all, most members would probably rather be somewhere else. With the '84 campaign already at a full gallop, and Election Day a mere 14 months away, partisan back-shooting is certain to be rampant.

title: Miss Goodbody and E. H. Deming, Lawyers, Wed
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Atonement in Tenafly, N.J., yesterday Katharine Stevens Goodbody, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Maurice F. Goodbody of Englewood, N.J., was married to Ellsworth Huntington Deming, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Nelson Deming of Hamden, Conn. The Rev. John P. Croneberger performed the ceremony.

title: SOVIET FIGHTER PILOT'S REMARKS ON TELEVISION
description: Following are excerpts from a television interview with unidentified Soviet fighter pilots, as translated by The New York Times:

title: SENATOR DOUBTS POPE TOLD WALESA TO QUIT POLITICS
description: Senator Christopher J. Dodd, who has met Lech Walesa as well as Pope John Paul II recently, says he received the ''clear impression'' that the Pope had not placed any pressure on the Polish labor union leader to ease his political activities.

title: WESTERN NATIONS REFUSE TO WIDEN ROLE IN LEBANON
description: The United States and the other Western nations with forces in Lebanon have turned down an urgent Lebanese request that they enter the Shuf area around Beirut and try to halt the fighting there, according to Secretary of State George P. Shultz and other officials.

title: THE WEDDING OF SOLO'S KING
description: Once again, as she has for centuries, the Queen of the South Seas arrived to dance for the King of Solo. The young princes smiled and the old noblemen fretted, and a thundercloud burst, as it had to, above the Susuhunan's palace in Surakarta, central Java.

title: Miss Montgomery's 68 Gives Her 1-Shot Lead
description: Charlotte Montgomery overcame swirling winds to score a four-under- par 68 today and take a one-shot lead over LeAnn Cassaday through two rounds of the $150,000 Portland Ping golf championship.

title: ON THE DOWNING OF KOREAN AIR LINES FLIGHT 7
description: To the Editor:

title: POLICE BATTLE PROTESTERS IN CHILE
description: Riot policemen battled demonstrators tonight as tens of thousands of Chileans turned out for a funeral procession for one of eight people reported killed in anti-Government protests Thursday and Friday.

title: THE ARTISTRY OF RUTH PRAWER JHABVALA
description: IT IS LATE AFTERNOON, AND RUTH PRAWER Jhabvala sits exhausted in her small studio apartment on Manhattan's East Side. The room is sun- drenched and somewhat bare. Two straw mats lie beneath a sofa and a wooden, glass-topped coffee table. There are several chairs, a small bookcase and, beside the window overlooking the towers of midtown, a white laminated desk with a student's spiral notebook on top of it. On a good day, Mrs. Jhabvala fills four pages of the notebook with her newest novel. ''I just sit down at 10 in the morning and write until 1 and slowly it evolves,'' says the writer, a small, delicate woman with lively brown eyes and wisps of gray in her hair. ''I have no idea what's going to happen. It's never easy. I have trouble every single day.''

title: Braves Defeat Dodgers
description: Dale Murphy drove in the first of three Atlanta runs in the 10th inning tonight as the Braves beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 6-3, and cut the Dodgers' lead over the Braves in the National League West to two games.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: IT is the monthly meeting of the Westchester Stepfamily Support Group, but the people receiving the most attention are conspicuous by their absence. They are the stepchildren, the ones whom the adults here are talking about. They are the stepchildren - the ones whose approval these six articulate, seemingly well-adjusted grown-ups crave so deeply.

title: A PRODUCER-DIRECTOR-ACTOR-MEMOIRIST
description: FINAL DRESS. By John Houseman. Illustrated. 559 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: No Headline
description: THE WELL-BALANCED WARDROBE A working checklist of what aman should own to get the mostout of his clothes collection. By Ralph DiGennaro he daily dilemma of what to wear can be a source of consternation, particularly for those men whose sartorial inclinations are as haphazard as their closets. One obvious solution is organization. A poorly coordinated wardrobe can make it difficult for anyone to be well dressed. To become a serviceable wardrobe, a collection of clothes should not only contain the essential elements, but those elements should relate to each other in style, color and pattern. The paisley, foulard and club ties here, for example, can be safely paired with any of the dress shirts. The trousers, too, coordinate well with any of the casual shirts and sweaters.

title: Pirates 6, Phillies 5
description: Doug Frobel, a pinch-runner, scored from first base in the 10th inning on Milt May's line-single and a two-base throwing error by the center fielder Garry Maddox as Pittsburgh rallied to defeat Philadelphia. The Phillies fell from first place in the National League East.

title:
STAMPS;
SIXTEEN MORE FLAGS FROM THE UNITED NATIONS
description: The United Nations is issuing 16 stamps on Sept. 23 - the fourth installment in its ''Flag'' series, which is devoted to reproducing, in time, the flags of all the nations that are members of the world organization.

title: THE OWLS OF THE O.E.D.
description: In the center of Oxford, a handsome Georgian mansion in St. Giles's accommodates about 30 lexicographers and their paraphernalia - books, millions of quotations drawn from publications of every kind, computer terminals and all the rest of the equipment needed to keep the English language under surveillance. This is the headquarters of the Oxford dictionaries - from the 12 volumes of the Oxford English Dictionary, and its supplementary volumes, to the Oxford minidictionary.

title: THE SCOOP WAR'S GOURMET BATTLE
description: IN the old days, Rufky Mattus, Abe Kroll and their friends from Brownsville would get together at Murphy's candy store after work for some laughs and some Horton's ice cream and later, head to Coney Island for a hot dog at Nathan's.

title: TECHNOLOGY LINKS NATION'S LIBRARIES
description: Last fall the Pekin Community High School library in Illinois received a letter from Leningrad. A reader at the Lenin State Library wanted to borrow one of its books about karate.

title: SUFFOLK BUSES UNDER SCRUTINY
description: THE heavily subsidized bus system in Suffolk County, the subject of a campaign pledge of Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan four years ago, will come under scrutiny from two sources in the next few months.

title: Egypt Said to Have Arrested 7 Palestinians as Saboteurs
description: Authorities have arrested a group of about seven Palestinians who were sent to Cairo to carry out subversive activities, according to security sources.

title: HOW TO CONTROL SPLINTERING WHEN WORKING WITH PLYWOOD
description: ALTHOUGH plywood is a wood product that is worked much like ordinary lumber - cut, drilled, smoothed and shaped with conventional woodworking tools - it is more prone to splintering than solid lumber when you cut it with an ordinary saw, or when you have to drill holes through it.

title: STATE BOTTLE DEPOSIT LAW IN FULL EFFECT TOMORROW
description: A New York State law requiring deposits on beverage containers takes full effect tomorrow.

title: British Writers
description: To the Editor:

title: PENTHOUSES STILL THE TOPS, IF NOT ALWAYS AT THE TOP
description: FIRST there was the penthouse, an apartment surrounded by terraces on the roof of a tall building.

title: Ebbets Done
description: A State Senator had visions of a stately Ebbets Dome in Brooklyn, and in February 1982 he got the Legislature to approve $30,000 for a feasibility study of building a domed sports stadium in the borough.

title: A Nylon Cord
description: A long nylon cord had become a constitutional issue on Long Island.

title: THE NEW COMFORTABLE STYLE
description: Not only are there ever-increasing numbers of good ideas offered to men for functionaloff-duty'' dressing, but tailored clothing is now being constructed with the sortof softer shaping that allows for more comfort without a loss of style. By Ralph DiGennaro ost designers and manufacturers have historically styled their clothes within the framework of classic tailoring because that is what American men have become accustomed to wearing. But, in the last year, influenced by some of the country's best designers, American clothes have begun to prove that classic does not necessarily mean restrictive, either in styling or, perhaps more important, in fit.

title: F.C.C. OPENS INQUIRY ON 'SEX TALK' PHONE SERVICE
description: The Federal Communications Commission has agreed to open an inquiry to determine whether to ban a service that allows callers to listen to recordings of women simulating sex.

title:
NATURE WATCH MAKO SHARK;
Isurus oxyrinchus
description: Size: To 12 feet and 1,000 pounds.

title: Q AND A
description: Question: Toward the end of the year, in conjunction with a trip to Australia, we would like to spend several days in Papua New Guinea. I was able to find various tours but all of them were for periods of time longer than we wanted, and so far no one has been able to tell me what I can do and see in just four or five days. Where can we find this information? - K.L., Verona, N.J.

title: Peanut Butter
description: To the Editor:

title: Gang Reportedly Got $10,000 Meant for Ex-Chicago Mayor
description: Nearly $10,000 in campaign funds intended for former Mayor Jane M. Byrne's unsuccessful re-election drive wound up in the hands of leaders of Chicago's most notorious street gang, The Chicago Sun-Times reported in its Sunday issue.

title: Strasbourg
description: To the Editor:

title: OVERSEAS INVESTING FOR THE LITTLE GUYS
description: FOR centuries European investors have ranged far from home in pursuit of attractive opportunities. While the archetypical Belgian dentist probably owns securities from companies in six countries, Americans, by contrast, have traditionally shown relatively little interest in foreign investing because of the diversity and performance of United States securities markets.

title: IS THERE A FUTURE FOR THOSE NOT PRESENT?
description: More than 70,000 high school freshmen will be on the books when New York City's public schools open the day after tomorrow, but not necessarily in class. Nearly 40 percent of the ninth graders at the city's 109 high schools are likely to be chronically absent this year - that is, out of school more than 30 days a semester - according to Board of Education studies. And if the class of 1987 follows the pattern of recent ones, nearly half its members will not graduate.

title: GRADES AREN'T ALL AT DELBARTON SCHOOL
description: AT the beginning of each school year, the Rev. Giles Hayes shouts to all the freshmen: ''What school do you go to?''

title: PERFECTION ENDURES AMID DECAY
description: Crowded ferries on the Rangoon River practically vanish behind squalls of rain. The palms go wild. Umbrellas come out - black brollies for the laity and paper- and-bamboo hti for monks. Everybody runs for cover. It's time for tea or sleep, and after a while the sun appears, turning the pavements into mirrors for swirls of pigeons. This is Rangoon in the wet season, from May to October. Veterans call midwinter better - it is dry then and almost brisk at night. But the Burmese capital has its charms in the rain, which lets up often enough. They say the pagodas of Pagan in Upper Burma are even more unearthly than Rangoon's 368-foot-high Shwe Dagon. But you have to travel to Rangoon to get up north, and Rangoon isn't quite like going to Chicago. It's a crumbling city - nothing physical has changed much since the 1930's - and it brings out the mock-romantic in some visitors. One day in the barrel-vaulted dining room of the old Strand Hotel, a group of youngish Western tourists gathered around a spotted tablecloth to plot their next move. Tibet? The Amazon? Two men wore Panama hats. You got the feeling that they had just seen ''Raiders of the Lost Ark.''

title: JAZZ: ALIVE! ENSEMBLE AT LUSH LIFE
description: The jazz group called Alive!, which is at Lush Life, at Bleecker and Thompson Streets in Greenwich Village through today, could scarcely have chosen a more descriptive name. The vitality that it projects is vivid and is expressed in a variety of ways - in the range and adventurousness of its repertory, in the polished and exuberant energy of its ensemble playing and in the probing thoughtfulness of most of its solos.

title: Miss Thompson And Charles Rose Are Wed in Ohio
description: Maryann Thompson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Cofield Thompson of New York and Cincinnati, was married in Cincinnati yesterday to Charles Buckley Rose, son of Mr. and Mrs. George V. Rose of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. Paul R. Long Jr. performed the ceremony at the Indian Hill Episcopal- Presbyterian Church.

title: THE NEW EXILES
description: Not since the rise of the Nazis in Germany a half century ago have so many writers fled their homes as in the past decade, fled, in Daniel Bell's words, ''the languages and the voices and the streets and the air'' that are the writer's blood and bone. Fifty years ago they were escaping from Nazi totalitarianism; today it is mainly Communist totalitarianism; now, as then, the favored destination is the United States.

title: Irish Style
description: To the Business Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: FREE FOREIGN FILMS

title: Taryn N. Emmons Is Wed To John Freeman in Jersey
description: Taryn Niles Emmons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald M. Emmons of Red Bank, N.J., was married yesterday to John Halstead Freeman, son of Mr. and Mrs. David F. Freeman of Rumson, N.J. The Rev. Lionel Therriault performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Holy Communion in Fair Haven, N.J.

title: Ruth O'Neil Has Nuptials
description: Ruth Quinn O'Neil, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Louis O'Neil of Watertown, Conn., was married at St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church there yesterday to John T. Fisher Carr, son of Mrs. Alanson B. Houghton of Charleston, S.C., and the late Oscar Clark Carr Jr. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Marshall Filip, assisted by the Rev. Alanson B. Houghton, stepfather of the bridegroom and former rector of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: Gay Alden Fast Is Married to C.E. Taft
description: Gay Alden Fast, daughter of Mrs. David B. Bolton of Greenwich, Conn., and Paul A. Fast of Oxford, Conn., was married yesterday to Charles Eliot Taft, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel B. Taft of White Plains. Rabbi Richard S. Chapin performed the ceremony in his study at Temple Emanu-El in New York on the 62d wedding anniversary of the bridegroom's grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Morris Pike of White Plains.

title: BOND DEFAULT
description: To the Business Editor:

title: INSURANCE BILL HITS SMALL, BUT SIGNIFICANT, SNAG
description: THE long-awaited overhaul of the state's automobile insurance system cleared its first hurdle last week with its passage by the State Assembly, but a debate has begun over the language in one key section.

title: VOLATILITY FUELS THE ADVANCE OF JAZZ
description: These are odd, heady times for jazz. The music is as volatile as ever - plunging ahead, reexamining the past, trying cross-cultural experiments, and chasing after what may turn out in the long run to be tangents or conceptual triumphs. You might call it flux as usual.

title: PENTAGON ANALYST PROPOSING A SUBMERSIBLE NAVY
description: A Defense Department official believes the Navy's surface ships are so vulnerable that they should be replaced with submersible vessels, including submarine aircraft carriers.

title: BRITISH WRITERS
description: To the Editor:

title: WASHINGTON TO HOLD PRIMARY
description: The Washington Legislature today scheduled a special primary to avoid a free-for-all in the election to fill the seat left vacant by the death of Senator Henry M. Jackson.

title: EVIDENCE GAP SEEN ON CARTER PAPERS
description: The Justice Department is still at least a month away from concluding its inquiry into how Ronald Reagan's Presidential campaign obtained President Carter's political strategy papers in 1980, according to officials familiar with the investigation.

title: THE CHANGING FACE OF ASIA AND THE PACIFIC
description: Creeping Westernization has changed the face of Asia, adding modern skyscrapers to cities whose trademarks have been ancient stone forts and arched gates. On South Pacific islands known for serene beaches fringed with palm trees, officials have had to adopt restrictive building codes to prevent conversion to imitations of Waikiki. Fortunately, however, the coexistence of past and present manages to preserve the traditional character, at least visually, of these exotic lands. One moonlit night in Pramban in central Java I watched a classical Javanese ballet being performed on a stage so modern, with artful lighting and ingenious scenic effects, that it could have been imported from Lincoln Center. But this was an outdoor theater, and on a hill in the background, glistening in the moonlight, the phallic spire of a 1,200- year-old Hindu temple told me that I was in the historic heart of Indonesia.

title: IN NEW YORK, AN AWAKENING MAY BE OVERDUE
description: AS New York State's Commissioner of Social Services, Cesar A. Perales supervises $7.7 billion in programs for the state's neediest residents. A lawyer of Puerto Rican extraction, he commands an agency workforce of 4,700. And Mr. Perales makes decisions - most recently over minimum standards for residential hotels - that affect the quality of life in a particularly important way for New York's largely poor and working class Hispanic community of nearly two million.

title: FROM PARIS COUTURE: THE INFLUENTIAL TWO
description: THE PARIS COUTURE embodies two moods: affluence and influence. It is the minuscule world of clothes made to measure, by hand, for women able to pay $3,000, and much more, for a single garment. And not only must the client be affluent, so must the maison de couture itself. Several of the major design houses spend in the vicinity of $1 million each for these lavish presentations, held in January for spring clothes and in July for fall and winter apparel. The July showings are particularly costly because of the use of furs and of especially luxurious fabrics and embroidery.

title: HONG KONG'S STREET OF 'GREEN TEMPTATION'
description: Each morning just before 10, every day of the year, four blocks of Kowloon along Canton Road are transformed into a street lined with jade, a path called the Jade Market by Hong Kong's Western population but referred to by the Chinese as Jade Street. For a shopper it is a seductive wonderland of green temptation with more than 300 dealers sitting along Canton Road from Jordan Road to Saigon Street, under jerry-built awnings or large umbrellas, on camp chairs or on their haunches, unfolding tables, cloths or racks of red satin- backed cards all displaying jade rings, necklaces, bracelets, pendants and carvings. One man sits on a curb in front of a towel on which are piled stacks of black-green jade carvings; another perches on a padded folding chair behind a glass-covered display case filled with what he swears is nothing but the finest of deep apple-green imperial jade. A woman ambles up the street with several dozen red, white and green jade necklaces suspended from her wrist and forearm, stopping whenever someone shows interest. Children watch the jade while their parents go off for tea or some food in one of the two narrow alleys that cut through Jade Street, Ningpo Street and Nanking Street.

title: RIGHTS AND WRONGS OF POLITICAL ACTIVISM
description: Throughout his ministry, Pope John Paul II has consistently expressed a basic theme: Concern for social justice is the rightful function of the Catholic clergy, but outright political partisanship violates the vows of nuns and priests.

title: EXILES RETURN TO AUGMENT THE ANTI-PINOCHET FORCES
description: Two weeks after President Salvador Allende Gossens was overthrown by the military in September 1973, Mario Lopez fled to asylum in the Argentine Embassy. Many of his friends and colleagues were being arrested, and since he had been Mr. Allende's press secretary during the 1970 campaign, he feared for his life. Then, after four months in the embassy, Mr. Lopez was permitted to leave Chile and told he would not be allowed to return.

title: TROUBLING QUESTIONS ABOUT DIOXIN
description: THE news last June that dangerous levels of dioxin had been found on the site of the former Diamond Shamrock chemical plant in Newark, which made Agent Orange during the Vietnam War, was startling.

title: NEWPORT CALMLY CONSIDERS LIFE WITHOUT THE CUP
description: When an America's Cup yacht was towed into the harbor from its well-guarded dock Friday, so many people rushed to see it that they almost swamped a nearby floating pier where a sailboat show was being held.

title: CHRISTMAS COMES EARLY IN POP MUSIC
description: Each fall the large record companies traditionally line up a battery of superstar albums for the Christmas market. This season is no exception. In October we can expect new studio albums by the Rolling Stones, Paul McCartney, Stevie Wonder, Bob Dylan, and Lionel Richie. While no tour plans have been announced for the Stones, Mr. McCartney or Mr. Dylan, Mr. Wonder and Mr. Richie will both be performing here at Radio City Music Hall during October.

title: OLD WOUNDS OPEN IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: Although he is locked in Soledad prison, Dan White again is at the center of controversy here because he is due for parole Jan. 6, a little more than five years after he killed two political opponents, Mayor George Moscone and Supervisor Harvey Milk.

title: Miss Merrell Has Nuptials In Rochester
description: Louise Theodate Merrell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley W. Merrell of Rochester, and Thomas Snow Middleton, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Willoughby Middleton Jr. of Rochester and Nantucket, Mass., were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert M. Wainwright performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Epicopal Church in Rochester.

title: Baptist Convention Chooses To Retain Head for 17th Year
description: About 11,000 delegates to the National Baptist Convention of America have elected the Rev. James Carl Sams as the group's president for the 17th consecutive year.

title: IN BURMA, ORDINARY IS BRILLIANT
description: Maung Kown beckons a pair of visitors back into his simple pony cab at the end of a hot Burmese day of touring. Sunset nears, signaling the start of a daily pilgrimage. Settling into the bouncy rhythm and clatter of the pony's unhurried gait, the foreigners are conveyed along Pagan's dusty plain to a tall pagoda. The driver collects all footwear and sends his passengers up its warm stone steps. Once they are at the top, the light waning, the scorched brown earth begins to grow coppery. Whitewashed columns and walls take on burning hues and even plain brick is fired brilliant oranges and reds. After the sun disappears, fluorescent bars blink on at the pagoda's stupas, or towers, and the sky glows 30 minutes more in a charged but serene display. Suddenly, the seemingly tired, ancient landscape is suffused with a sense of renewed inner life.

title: COOKING CLASSES FOR ALL TASTES
description: LABOR DAY is past, and school is in session again. That goes for cooking schools, too. This fall, cooking school offerings are as varied as ever, giving would-be cooks and would-be

title: FRANK LLOYD WRIGHT IS CLEARLY THE MAN OF THE YEAR
description: Much happened on the city's architectural scene last year - the I.B.M. Building, Trump Tower and the Philip Morris headquarters were but the most conspicuous arrivals on the skyline. Such a building pace cannot continue indefinitely and, in fact, this season will provide a respite. There is a lot under construction now, but there are few buildings ready for ribbon-cutting.

title: Blood Infection Traced To a Homemade Cheese
description: A rare bacterial infection that has afflicted at least 15 residents of northern New Mexico and caused one death has been traced to a homemade cheese made from raw milk, health officials said.

title: TOPICAL ISSUES LEND SPECIAL DRAMA TO MOVIES
description: Filmmakers, perhaps taking their lead from the widely popular television docu- dramas of recent seasons, not to mention the kudos garnered by ''Gandhi'' last year, seem to be making a marked departure from the heroics and outright fantasy that have dominated movie screens of late, with the result that political issues figure unusually prominently in many upcoming films. In fact, the topics of many of this fall's major movies will be topical indeed, with dramas about an American photojournalist in Nicaragua, a woman lawyer in Israel who falls in love with a Palestinian, a band of anti-nuclear terrorists who hold a group of American officials hostage, a group of veterans who go back to Vietnam to rescue their buddies from a prison camp, and the death of a worker in a nuclear plant. These are hardly laughing matters, so it's just as well that the fall schedule also includes an unusual abundance of comic relief. Chief among the comedies are a Steve Martin movie with a screenplay by Neil Simon, and a remake of an Ernst Lubitsch classic, ''To Be or Not to Be,'' starring Anne Bancroft and Mel Brooks.

title: THE BIOLOGY OF DEPRESSION MAKES PHYSICIANS ANXIOUS
description: The National Institute of Mental Health has labeled severe depression the nation's No. 1 mental health disorder, affecting as much as 5 percent of the population at any given time. The figure is unavoidably imprecise: Depression is difficult to separate from the ailments that can mask it - alcoholism or chronic pain, for example - and from the illnesses of which it can be a symptom. The result has been an ongoing search among mental health experts for a reliable test for depression.

title: A Balloon To Freedom
description: Robert Hutyra's best-known means of locomotion in Czechoslovakia was a bicycle - until last week. Then the 38-year-old former member of the Czech national cycling team decided he and his family had had enough of the country's Communist regime and took an exotic way out.

title: NEW YORKER TO GO ON TRIAL IN MURDER OF HER FATHER
description: Jury selection is scheduled to begin here Monday in the murder trial of Frances Bernice Schreuder, a 45-year-old New Yorker accused of ordering the slaying of her father by her son.

title: L.I. Man Accused of Slaying His Friend and Man With Her
description: The Nassau County police arrested a 22- year-old Baldwin man today and charged him with murdering a woman whom he was dating and a man who was with her in the arrested man's house.

title: Question of Ethics
description: The linebacker Jim Eliopulos and the defensive back Monte Hunter were cut by the Dallas Cowboys in training camp. Whatever knowledge they have of the Cowboy tactics is in the hands of the St. Louis Cardinals, Dallas's opponent today.

title: GRANDPARENTS 'TAKE UP ARMS' TO SEE CHILDREN
description: THERE is no such thing as an ex-grandparent. The last time I saw two of my four grandchildren was 18 months ago outside a courtroom. They were waiting to go before a judge on our petition for visitation rights. The children's father, divorced from our daughter and now remarried, had opposed our request for visiting rights or any contact with the children.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: ''Webster, '' a situation comedy that will have its premiere on ABC Friday at 8:30 P.M., resembles NBC's ''Diff'rent Strokes'' - both concern white adults who adopt a black child. In ''Webster,'' Alex Karras portrays a former football player turned sportscaster, and Susan Clark plays his bride.

title: SOME TRICKY PLAYING
description: Try a few general knowledge questions about bridge: What country has the world's biggest club? What country has the biggest number of players in proportion to the total population? And which country has, in recent years, been most productive in the field of sophisticated bidding theory?

title: GREECE SAYS PACT SPELLS END TO AMERICAN BASES
description: The Greek Government has said the new military agreement with the United States means American bases will have to be disbanded after the accord ends in 1988.

title: Catherine A. Hoover Marries
description: Catherine Alice Hoover, daughter of Mrs. Borroughs Slater of New York and San Francisco and Robert Cleary Hoover of Piedmont, Calif., was married yesterday to Bartholomew Voorsanger, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Voorsanger of San Francisco. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Unitarian Church of All Souls in Manhattan.

title: AROUND THE WORLD IN 80 WAYS
description: A round-the-world trip can be a lot quicker now than in Jules Verne's day, but planning it is not necessarily easier. So many options are available by air that it can take hours of study to find the most appropriate combination of routing and price.

title: Study and Sport Just Don't Mix
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Jane R. Clark Has Nuptials In Greenwic h
description: Dr. Jane Rogers Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Clark of Manchester, N.H., was married yesterday to Dr. Jonathan Paull Gertler, son of Dr. and Mrs. Menard M. Gertler of New York and Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Thomas Niblock of the South Congregrational Church in Middletown, Conn., and Rabbi Roger Klein performed the ceremony at the Greenwich home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: THE CUFF AND OTHER 'ESSENTIALS'
description: One morning, while getting dressed for work, I looked in the mirror at the tie I was knotting and, after wondering why I felt compelled to wear the thing in the first place, I wondered, secondly, where it had come from.

title: DEDICATED, PROLIFIC AND FORGOTTEN
description: THE LIFE OF MAXWELL ANDERSON. By Alfred S. Shivers. Illustrated. 397 pp. New York: Stein & Day. $25.

title: First '84 Debates Planned
description: The first two 1984 debates among Presidential candidates will be held in Manchester, N.H., and Atlanta, according to the sponsoring League of Women Voters. The league's president, Dorothy S. Ridings, said Thursday that the Manchester debate would be held in late February for Democratic candidates in the Presidential primary there. The Atlanta debate will be held March 11.

title: Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Argovitz Sells Business
description: Jerry Argovitz, the former dentist who earned millions in agent fees representing some of the outstanding players in the National Football League, including Billy Sims of the Detroit Lions, has sold his agent business, Argovitz Clinic and Argovitz Clinic Management Division, to Jeff Prosser 's Career Sports. Argovitz had to sell the business to avoid conflicts of interests with his ownership of the new Houston Gamblers franchise of the United States Football League.

title: HAWAII'S LOW-KEY GARDEN ISLE
description: If you live, as I do, in California, Hawaii means either one of the following: that enchanting neighborhood paradise you hop over to for a long tropical weekend, or those perfectly dreadful, tacky islands you avoid as if they were Alcatraz. Until recently, I could be counted in the latter goup, staunchly convinced that Hawaii had negligible charm beyond busloads of tourists bedecked in leis and Harry Truman aloha shirts, cloying ukulele music and the grieveous ruination of shopping malls and Miami Beach skylines. Then I discovered, a while back, the island of Kauai and became an overnight zealot. It is called the Garden Isle and of the more developed islands in the Hawaiian chain - Maui, Oahu (home of Honolulu and Waikiki Beach) and the Big Island of Hawaii with its Kona Coast - Kauai is, indeed, the most gorgeous, the least built upon and hence still the most natural. In 10 years, it may, of course, succumb to condo fever, like Maui, but for now Kauai boasts a blissful quantity of unspoiled beaches, unpeopled mountains/valleys/canyons, citizens relatively untainted by too many big tourist bucks and mile upon mile of untouched beauty.

title: SUSTAINED GROWTH IN COLLEGIATE SOCCER
description: While professional soccer is experiencing a downward trend in income and fan interest in the United States, the game is continuing to progress vigorously at the college level.

title: Teachers End Two Walkouts With New Accords in Jersey
description: Two of the three teacher strikes that began in New Jersey on Tuesday have ended, and talks have been scheduled for Monday on the third, at Holy Cross Roman Catholic High School in Delran Township, in Burlington County.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: AFTER a long, quiet summer, the Suffolk County Executive's race is finally getting a little interesting.

title: AN EXILE FINDS CHILE 'STRUCK BY A PLAGUE'
description: Returning to Chile after 10 years of forced exile, I am shocked by all that has changed. I am also shocked by what remains the same.

title: LEBANON HAS YET TO MAKE PEACE WITH ITSELF
description: In the year since the Israeli invasion, the Lebanese have alternated between hopes of establishing a genuinely sovereign government and fears that sectarian hatreds, fueled from outside, would drag the country back toward anarchy. The hopes were based on the notion that the Government of President Amin Gemayel could gradually extend its authority beyond the tiny area of Beirut, helped by the presence of more than 5,000 foreign troops in restraining violent factions. But the eruption of war last week between Christian and Druse militias in the Shuf Mountains east of the capital was a brutal indication that the hopes were fragile.

title: OPERA MAY DOMINATE, BUT THE KEYNOTE IS VARIETY
description: In classical music, New York still looms large above the rest of the country, for all the vitality of the regional centers that have sprung

title: JUDGE FACES DRUNKEN DRIVING CHARGES AGAIN
description: The Vermont Judicial Conduct Board will investigate the case of a Vermont judge, twice convicted of drunken driving, who has been charged with a third such offense.

title: 'FOR EVERY ONE WE REACH THERE ARE 1,000 WE DON'T TOUCH'
description: You see them in every town and city across Latin America. By night they sleep wrapped in newspapers, stretched out in doorways, littered alleys and discarded construction tubing. During the day some shine shoes in public squares, sell gum, peanuts and candy on street corners or beg from stalled drivers at crowded intersections.

title: AN ANCIENT LANDMARK IN JAPAN AND A NEW ONE IN FRANCE
description: Osaka Castle To Celebrate 400th Birthday

title: RE-EMPLOYMENT: A BLUEPRINT
description: WITH New Jersey's unemployment rate at 8.4 percent, we have about 307,000 unemployed people in the state.

title: IRELAND EXPELS THREE RUSSIANS IN ESPIONAGE CASE
description: Two Soviet diplomats and the wife of one of them were expelled from Ireland on Friday, and today Government sources were quoted as saying the Soviet Embassy in Dublin was a ''clearing house for a major international spy ring.''

title: GET READY FOR A WEALTH OF AMERICANA
description: Antiques and decorative- arts enthusiasts - especially those interested in Americana and 20th-century styles - have a whirlwind of activities to choose from in the months ahead, judging by the antiques fair and the museum and gallery exhibitions scheduled.

title: Amanda Peek and Howard H. Phillips Wed in Rye
description: Amanda Peek, daughter of Mrs. Kenneth Locke Boren of Moraga, Calif., and Mottell Davis Peek of Port Chester, N.Y., was married yesterday to Howard Harwood Phillips, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Johnson Phillips of Memphis. The Rev. Donald W. Poole performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church in Rye, N.Y.

title: IS THE SURGE IN OIL STOCKS OVER?
description: FOR the last five months, as the ecstacy of a bull market began to die down, the stocks of the nation's oil companies, drilling equipment manufacturers, and oilfield service concerns have enjoyed a bull market of their own. And it was a welcome reversal of roles. Last year, these were the stocks that were shunned by Wall Street - sold off by large institutional investors and left to flounder throughout the fall and winter.

title: A Linesman Critically Hurt
description: A linesman at the United States Open tennis championships was listed in critical condition at Flushing Hospital yesterday after complications that began with his being hit by a ball.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Cold Water on the Recovery

title: LEGAL-AID AGENCY IN FINANCIAL BIND
description: ALTHOUGH the 14 chapters of the state's legal-aid agency have gained half a million dollars in operating finances this year, agency administrators say fewer people will be served and more turned away as rising costs neutralize additional financing.

title: JOHN VORSTER, FORMER SOUTH AFRICAN PRIME MINISTER, DIEST AT 67
description: John Vorster, former South African Prime Minister, who dominated the nation's politics in one of its most turbulent periods before resigning amid scandal, died late today. He was 67 years old.

title: IT'S TOO EARLY FOR GARDENERS TO PUT TOOLS AWAY
description: Just when gardeners thought they could wind down their activities and start putting their tools away, a major planting season confronts them. Actually fall is the best planting season for many plants. The chart shows the broad scope of possibilities.

title: Boston College Upsets Clemson
description: Coach Jack Bicknell, excited by one of the biggest comeback victories in Boston College football history, said tonight, ''There's one lesson that you learn in a game like this - never give up on Doug Flutie.''

title: 'I DIDN'T HAVE TO BE LUCKY'
description: IN her celebration on the court, Martina Navratilova could be heard saying, ''Off my back, off my back,'' referring to her inability in other years to win the United States Open women's singles championship. But yesterday she dominated Chris Evert Lloyd, 6-1, 6-3, as completely as she has dominated women's tennis for the last three years.

title: NEW MEXICO OFFERS A 'PREVIEW' OF MOBILIZATION
description: I tell a story,'' says Gov. Toney Anaya of New Mexico,

title: Shelley Williams Marries Steven Rothman on Coast
description: Shelley L. Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Williams of Santa Monica, Calif., was married in Beverly Hills, Calif., yesterday to Steven M. Rothman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Rothman of Beverly Hills.

title: DEALING WITH THE NEW RULES
description: NEWCOMERS to New York frequently take an apartment on a sublease for their first few months in the city.

title: DARING TO GREATNESS
description: AT 10:30 A.M. OF A summer Saturday, the sunshine dazzling, the temperatures kept in the 70's by a playful breeze, I stood on the center court at the Newport Casino, racquet to hand, and dreamed a dream of another me...

title: SPACESUITS, NOT SWIMSUITS, FOR YOUTH AT SCIENCE CAMP
description: For Chad Stone, the toughest part was shedding the 25-pound spacesuit.

title: Martha L. Griffin Weds A. J. Verdickt
description: Martha Lindsay Griffin and Andre Jean Verdickt were married yesterday by the Rev. James Conofrey at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Farmington, Conn.

title: Survey of Hospitals Indicates Persisting Nursing Shortage
description: A random survey of 1,200 community hospitals nationwide shows that one in three still has a nursing shortage, according to the American Hospital Association.

title: Catherine Quist Weds David Wendell
description: The marriage of Catherine Ane Quist to David Richardson Wendell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harlan L. P. Wendell of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., and Essex, Mass., took place yesterday at the home of Mrs. George Quist, mother of the bride, in Woodside, Calif. The Rev. Dr. Roger K. Smith, pastor of the Woodside Village Church (United Church of Christ), performed the ceremony.

title: ON THE DOWNING OF KOREAN AIR LINES FLIGHT 7
description: To the Editor:

title: The P-Car: Important and Different
description: BILL HOGLUND looked like something out of a comic movie. He was a frenzy of well-tailored elbows and angles, contorting his immense length to fold it behind the wheel of the little Fiat X1/9. ''Not much room,'' he said grinning, knees in the vicinity of his chin.

title: GOOD BREEDING; End of the Line
description: There are five dusky sparrows living in the avian equivalent of an old folks' home in Florida. When they die, an entire species dies with them - accidentally destroyed by an effort to control mosquitoes.

title: THE SUPERSTARS
description: Mary E. Cunningham Vice President Joseph E. Seagram

title: Panel Rules Pupil Has A Right to Pass Notes
description: A rule prohibiting note-passing among students is unconstitutional because it violates their rights to free speech, a hearing panel of the State Department of Public Instruction has ruled.

title: ART
description: Roy Shifrin's sculpture of ''Icarus,'' on permanent display in the entrance plaza of Manhattan Community College, 199 Chambers Street, next to the Hudson River, is one of the most ambitious outdoor sculptures in New York City. Thematically, the 12-by-13 foot chunk of polished bronze, set on an 18-foot pedestal, takes off from the Greek myth in which Icarus, flying with fragile, wax-bound wings, perishes because he ignored his father's advice not to fly too close to the sun. Mr. Shifrin's complex but monolithic form, which suggests among other things a man's torso, suggests Icarus's dual relation to the heavenly light.

title: Air Raid Hit Nicaragua Where It Hurt
description: Despite all the reports of Soviet bloc military equipment and MIG pilot training provided to the Sandinistas, Nicaragua's air defenses proved porous last week. Two small planes piloted by Sandinista defectors got through and bombed Managua, the capital, for the first time since the 1979 revolution. Oil storage tanks at Corinto, the country's main Pacific coast port, were rocketed by two other planes piloted by rebels apparently based in Honduras, and yet another plane was reported shot down as it attacked Sandinista troops near the Costa Rica border.

title: Strike Disrupts Desegregation
description: More than 56,000 St. Louis public school pupils were ready to go back to school last week, but their teachers weren't - not without a raise. In the biggest of dozens of opening-day school strikes around the country, 3,800 teachers and support workers stayed out in defiance of a Federal judge's threat to hold them in contempt and the school superintendent's threat to fire them.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: Who's Myopic?
description: To the Business Editor:

title: FELIX STATIONUS: ALLEY CAT THAT'S A CAR
description: WHEN I used to park my decrepit little wagon at the Tarrytown train station, which includes two vast lots, it was a cinch to slip in anonymously and join the crowd on the platform. But now I park at a quaint station upriver, where most everybody knows everybody else and what sort of car each drives. The cars invariably seem expensive and well cared for. For injecting my blighted buggy into this rarefied environment, I am being auto ostracized.

title: WOMEN'S CAREERS TOPIC OF CONFIDENCE
description: ''WE have a 6.6 percent unemployment rate in Westchester County, which is very low,'' said Camille Murphy, director of the Westchester County Office for Women. ''But women in the county have to know how to compete successfully for the available jobs.''

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: ACADEMIC RESEARCH AND BIG BUSINESS: A DELICATE BALANCE
description: HOWARD M. GOODMAN IS A brilliant molecular biologist and dedicated teacher. And, in this revolutionary era of corporate science, he has also become an astute businessman. Two and a half years ago, Goodman made a singular proposal to the officers of the West German- based Hoechst A.G., one of the world's largest chemical companies: Give me enough money to create a 100-person department of molecular biology at an American university, guarantee me 10 years of unrestricted basic research and, in exchange, I'll let you see what I do.

title: Gromyko Flies to Moscow
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko left here today for Moscow after a 24-hour visit in which he met with President Francois Mitterrand. During their two-hour talk Friday, Mr. Mitterrand denounced the Soviet downing of a South Korean civil airliner Sept. 1, said a spokesman, Michel Vauzelle. Mr. Gromyko said the two men had discussed ''bilateral, international and regional issues and nuclear weapons.''

title: Coast Man Guilty of Placing Poison in Co-Workers' Coffee
description: A former technician at a pharmaceutical research company has pleaded guilty to two counts of attempting to poison co- workers with coffee laced with a chemical.

title: Pamela Summers Marries in Jersey
description: Pamela A. Summers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar D. Summers of Oyster Bay, L.I., was married in Bedminster, N.J., yesterday to John Kean, chairman and chief executive officer of the Elizabethtown Gas Company in Elizabeth, N.J. The Rev. Robert W. Scott, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home.

title: LEASHING HIS FURY, REAGAN SURPRISES AND CALMS ALLIES
description: Paris AMERICA'S allies and friends noted with considerable relief, if some bewilderment, the striking difference last week between words and deeds in President Reagan's reaction to the Soviet destruction of the Korean passenger plane.

title: YANKEES LOSE PAIR TO ORIOLES, 8-4, 3-1
description: With only three weeks left in the season, the Yankees depserately have to take giant steps if they are to make any progress in the American League East race. Their ability to take such steps, though, is withering. Last night, in fact, they took two steps backward, losing a doubleheader to the first-place Baltimore Orioles.

title: A SHAVING PRIMER
description: he luxuries of the barbershop shave may be a fond memory for most men, but a new range of skin-treatment products seeks to bring back at least some of the old shaving pleasures. In addition, they promise added skin benefits. At the very least, the new breed of products may ease the daily travail of the morning shave.

title: WESTBURY MALL PLAN REVIVED
description: A DEVELOPER who envisions a $50 million three-story enclosed mall of more than 125 stores on what is now just a parking lot in Westbury, between Ohrbach's and Fortunoff's, says the time for his proposal has come - again.

title: IMAGES OF A MIND THINKING
description: THE CANNIBAL GALAXY. By Cynthia Ozick. 162 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95.

title: The Trees of Warsaw
description: A. M. Rosenthal is to be complimented for his realistic description of the situation in Poland immediately before the Pope's second visit (''The Trees of Warsaw: A Return to Poland,'' Aug. 7). The hope that he encountered at that time contrasted greatly with the listlessness, alienation and fear that engulfed Polish society before the Pope's first homecoming and the birth of Solidarity. My Polish emigre friends described most Poles in the late 1970's as feeling virtually hopeless, stating that they walked past each other as if afraid to confirm their fears that they were being turned into something less than human beings.

title: HOLMES HALTS OUTCLASSED FRANK IN 5TH TO KEEP TITLE
description: From the very beginning, it was apparent that the warnings that this fight would be a mismatch were correct. Larry Holmes, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, bloodied and bruised an outclassed Scott Frank repeatedly tonight until Referee Tony Perez stopped the bout at 1:28 of the fifth round with Frank bleeding from cuts over the eye and from the nose.

title: SUSHI'S ESSENCE: FIRST RICE, THEN FISH
description: To sushi aficionados - not only in New York and California but also in Tokyo - it may come as a surprise that the vinegared rice spread with wasabi (Japanese horseradish) and topped by a thick slab of raw fish is not the original sushi. Called nigiri-zushi, or sushi gripped in the hand, it celebrates the freshness and abundance of fish in the coastal areas of eastern Japan. It is also known as Edo-mae, referring to fish brought fresh from the waters off Tokyo Bay straight to the sushi eater. Just as Tokyo, or Edo, is a new city, brash and bustling, Tokyo sushi reflects the simplicity and directness associated with its popular culture, and is typically enjoyed sitting at a crowded counter.

title: LUXURIOUS AND ALTOGETHER FRENCH
description: LA COTE D'OR in the new Garden City Hotel is unlike any other luxury restaurant on the Island. It has been patterned after the finest hotel dining rooms in cosmopolitan cities around the world, a category of restaurants that has undergone a renaissance in recent years. The chef, Patrick Pinon, was formerly at La R^ecolte in the Intercontinental Hotel in Manhattan.

title: FOREIGN ISSUES ON CONGRESS'S AGENDA
description: When Congress returns on Monday, foreign policy issues seem likely to top the agenda, and two of the most pressing matters did not even exist when the lawmakers left town five weeks ago. One is the downing of a Korean jetliner by a Soviet fighter, and the other is the increasing violence in Lebanon that has killed four marines.

title: THE LASER ERA BLOSSOMS
description: It's harvest time. The barns are filling up, and somewhere in the depths of their primal nature even urbanites reverberate to this ancient rhythm of ripeness and gathering. Maybe that is why the marketeers of industrial products also choose this season to bring in their latest crop. In audio, for example, the new models are reaching the stores just now, when it is possible to glimpse the prospect before us.

title: I LOVE NEW YORK AND L.A., TOO
description: I AM NEARLY 6 feet 6 and accidentally hit my head with some regularity in New York - on low cupboards and protruding wall lights in apartments, low stairwells leading down into brownstone basements, low doorways in old basement restaurants and low signs in subways. At parties in small New York apartments, I am learning to keep my basketball elbows close to my waist, out of passing drinks and faces. I've realized that the circle my body describes here when I dance has to have a shorter radius. Accustomed to the wide aisles of Los Angeles's supermarkets, I am learning to negotiate tight New York markets and learning, too, to handle the lunch-time Manhattan crowds, though I still chafe at pedestrian traffic jams. On trains, buses and subways, I am fascinated to see New York commuters fold their morning paper into neat half- or quarter-page columns. New Yorkers are simply conditioned to occupy less space than Angelenos.

title: TO GET GRANTS, UNIVERSITIES USE APPLIED POLITICAL SCIENCE
