description: At first blush they seem like the usual pickings from the Federal tree: Long Island University obtained an extra $600,000 in Federal funds for laboratories and several other facilities. The University of Kansas won a Federal grant for research on how to train the handicapped. Columbia University was awarded $5 million for a National Chemical Research Center. Catholic University was given $5 million in Governments funds to build a vitreous state laboratory.

title: BROADWAY BETS ON THE MUSICAL-AND, AS USUAL, ON THE BRITISH
description: Broadway is changing its tune this season. Gone is the reliance of seasons past on musicals flown in from London or trucked in from Off Broadway theaters. Gone, too, is the dependence in recent years on revivals of vintage musicals that everyone knows by heart. This year, the emphasis is on brand new musicals - a trend so old-fashioned that it seems downright radical.

title: MONDALE AND GLENN VYING FOR EARLY LEAD TOWARD 1984
description: With the start of a busy schedule of preliminary events for the 1984 Democratic Presidential campaign, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and Senator John Glenn of Ohio are entering an intensified competition for the early lead in the six-candidate race.

title: SOME MUNICIPAL WHITE ELEPHANTS ARE NOW HOT PROPERTIES
description: ''Wanted - Creative Developers,'' proclaims a real estate ad in this morning's New York Times. It promises ''outstanding tax benefits'' for redeveloping ''a unique landmark building, five stories, 114,000 square feet including a basement of 59,000 square feet and a cellar. Listed on the National Register of Historic Places.''

title: Bridge Warning After the Fact?
description: Monday morning prophecy isn't very demanding. In some cases, it also isn't very legal. Connecticut authorities last week charged a state bridge inspector with forgery, saying he had altered his field notes to make it appear he had warned superiors about the need for repairs at the Mianus River Bridge nine months before it collapsed.

title: Julia Marie Dooley Bride Of Roy Andrew Peterson
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Hudson, Ohio, yesterday Julia Marie Dooley and Roy Andrew Peterson, 1983 graduates of the Rochester Institute of Technology, were married by the Rev. Richard H. Baker Jr.

title: WEST GERMAN LEADERS PESSIMISTIC ON MISSILE PACT
description: Despite expressions of public optimism, senior West German officials have for some time indicated that they are convinced that the chances for a Soviet-American accord at the Geneva talks on the limitation of medium-range arms are minimal and that the deployment of American missiles in West Germany will start in December.

title: ARTICLE I VS. ARTICLE II
description: Article I, Section 8: The Congress shall have Power . . . to declare War . . . to raise and support armies . . . to make all Laws which shall be necessary and proper for carrying into Execution the foregoing Powers . . .

title: Peronists Make A Safe Choice
description: Without their hero to knock heads together, Argentina's 3.2 million Peronists have agreed on little except their yen to regain power. In a tumultuous national convention last week, they certified their inability to choose a charismatic successor to Gen. Juan Domingo Peron, who died in 1974.

title: JUDGE DARONCO ASSUMES STATE POST
description: FOR years, Richard J. Daronco recalled last week, ''I used to wave at my friends going to the Pelham railroad station as I headed for the Hutchinson River Parkway and White Plains,'' where he was a State Supreme Court Justice.

title: STORIES OF OUR LONELINESS
description: CATHEDRAL. By Raymond Carver. 228 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95.

title: AFTER RETIREMENT, A CAREER AS AUTHOR
description: ONE day about 18 months ago, in the Syosset Public Library, a 60-year-old man picked up a Bic pen and, putting it to a sheet of lined yellow foolscap, began to write: ''I never wanted to be a detective. Hell, I'm only 16 years old. All I wanted to do was clear myself of what they said I did.''

title: ON THE DOWNING OF KOREAN AIR LINES FLIGHT 7
description: To the Editor:

title: DIOXIN PANEL HEAD FIGHTS BUREAUCRACY
description: THE fighting spirit has never left Wayne P. Wilson, a decorated combat veteran who now does battle with the Federal and state bureaucracies.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
NEW MARKETING PROGRAM FOR U.S. GOLD MEDALS
description: The United States Treasury has issued two more gold ''medallions'' in an ongoing program aimed at providing Americans with a U.S. alternative to bullion-type foreign gold coins. Eight such pieces now have been issued since the series started in 1980, and two more are scheduled for release in 1984, when the five-year program concludes.

title: VETERANS OF C.C.C. REUNITE IN FOREST
description: Some of the men who built roads, bridges and dams with the Civilian Conservation Corps have returned to the Allegheny National Forest to reminisce and inspect their works 50 years after the New Deal experiment began.

title: RIGHTS OF NURSES ON DEATH EXTENDED
description: NEW JERSEY has become the first state to let registered nurses make pronouncements of death for people who die at home, in nursing homes or in long-term care or hospice facilities.

title: A Vermont Trout Sojourn
description: THEORETICALLY at least, the time or the place was wrong. In the summer, most of the fishermen in northeastern Vermont can be found in its ponds and lakes, and not wading the easily accessible trout streams like the Willoughby and Barton Rivers.

title: HOW OLD IS OLD?
description: ''GRANDMA, are you old?'' It was only four years ago that my granddaughter put that question to my mother.

title: WHEN ANGELS TREAD AND FRIENDS FOLLOW
description: He raised his third of the $550,000 needed from 17 investors. ''My dentist, my accountant, my clients, my lawyer,'' he ticked off the list. ''I asked everyone and their mother.'' - The New York Times, March 24, 1983.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: MIDWOOD
description: ONCE a thicket in the southern part of Brooklyn, the Midwood section today is a community notable for its well-kept private homes, suburban appearance and abundant towering trees. One resident, known as the ''Tree Lady,'' has actually inventoried the more than 8,000 trees in Midwood, and neighbors often ask her advice on their care.

title: Union Chief Leaves Hospital
description: Owen F. Bieber, president of the United Automobile Workers, has been released from Henry Ford Hospital after treatment for injuries suffered in an accident at a news conference. Mr. Bieber suffered a slight concussion and pulled muscles in his neck and back when he fell from his chair at a news conference Tuesday.

title: Dr. Debra Thrall Becomes a Bride
description: At St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, yesterday Dr. Debra Ann Drashpil Thrall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alex Victor Drashpil of St. Petersburg, Fla., was married to Bertram Lippincott O'Neill Jr., son of Mr. O'Neill and Mrs. Edward Lind, both of Philadelphia. The Rev. Mary D. Glasspool performed the ceremony.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is the triumph of a conservationist mentality which recognizes that we have finite resources on this earth.'' - Assemblyman G. Oliver Koppell, co-sponsor of New York State's so-called bottle law. (42:2.)

title: YOM KIPPUR FASTS ARE TIED TO EARLY LABOR IN PREGNANCY
description: Women who fast near the end of pregnancy may go into early labor, according to doctors who call the phenomenon the ''Yom Kippur effect'' after studying Jewish women in Israel who had fasted on the holy day.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: LIFE will be a cabaret for a few hours Saturday, Sept. 24, when the Council for the Arts in Westchester holds its sixth yearly benefit affair. The event, which is expected to draw 500 people, is being referred to as ''Cabaret!'' and it includes, in addition to a formal dinner and dancing, a performance by the Broadway star Maureen McGovern.

title: Miss Nelson Has Nuptials
description: Elizabeth Louise Nelson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Nelson of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Robert Andrew Welke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Welke of Wyckoff, N.J. The Rev. Gary A. Ritts performed the ceremony at the Greenfield Congregational Church in Fairfield.

title: ADDING TO THE BASICS
description: No man's wardrobe is complete without at least one ofthe three basic business suits. But, whether gray flannel, navy pin stripe or tweed, it can be made distinctive with properly coordinated accessories.

title: REMEMBERING LOST FRIENDS
description: FRIENDS and relatives of Rebecca Scruton and Mark J. McGetrick - and some people who never knew them - have established funds in memory of the two Connecticut residents who were aboard the South Korean airliner that was shot down over the Sea of Japan by a Soviet fighter on Sept. 1.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: I FOUND the Perfect Purse at a craft fair in Vermont in 1972, or maybe in 1971; it was at my shoulder so long that it seemed to have been there always, and I clung to it long past shabbiness, well into disintegration.

title: Proper Environment For Worship
description: The pastor of the Unity Church in Hempstead advises me that they were very pleased that the Interfaith Nutrition Network received the attention it deserves (''A Gift for the Needy: Lunch'') and hope that it will inspire other Long Islanders to become involved and help feed the needy wherever and whenever they are hungry.

title: PILOT WHO SHOT DOWN KOREAN JET IS INTERVIEWED ON SOVIET TELEVISION
description: Soviet television broadcast an interview tonight with a Soviet fighter pilot who was identified as having shot down the Korean Air Lines 747 jetliner last week.

title: A DRAMA ABOUT GOD OPENS TO BRAVOS IN ITALY
description: In a break with tradition, a theater that calls itself a citadel of modern popular Christian drama has staged an accusatory play by Elie Wiesel that he considers a strong attack on Christian attitudes to Jews through the ages.

title: THE TIMELESS BOYHOOD OF AN AMERICAN HERO
description: IN THE BOTTOM CURL OF THE serpentine path, down past the piped- in stream that tumbles over the constructed waterfall, amid trimmed shrubs and freshly flowered succulents, next to the pool and Jacuzzi, and just below the triple-seater tree stump that has the ceramic owl perched on its back, it's family picnic time. The menu offered here in Anaheim, Calif., at the white lawn table under the beach umbrella, is the same as the one being grilled transcontinentally. Hamburgers. Hot dogs. ''We really out of hot-dog rolls?'' Tommy John asks.

title: Topics; Good Breeding; An Ideal Husband
description: In one-year-old Doron, Afton Blake has the perfect child. He is, she says, ''very bright . . . agile, vocal and insightful, but not in a monstrous way.''

title: A NEW BREED OF DIPLOMAT
description: TART WITH THE ODDS. Only one out of about every 50 will make it. That is the State Department's estimate of the outcome of its testing this year for new Foreign Service officers, the nation's future diplomats. More than 16,000 candidates applied for the annual exams, demonstrating anew the powerful appeal of a diplomatic career and disproving assertions that low pay, slow promotions, political appointments and boring bureaucratic routine are seriously erroding the prestige of representing the United States abroad. Many of the candidates are among the nation's brightest, their resumes heavy with graduate degrees and honors citations, their hopes high for a life of travel, challenge and service as consular officers, political and economic analysts, negotiators and, hope of hopes, as full-fledged ambassadors.

title: DROP IN TOMATO PROFITS LIKELY
description: ALTHOUGH final figures on all harvests will not be in for several weeks, New Jersey's prized tomato crop has not fared well this season, according to the state's leading experts.

title: ENVIOUS KIBITZERS
description: Have the woes of the brilliancy prize winner ever been adequately appreciated? If his combination goes through swiftly and without a hitch despite myriad hypothetical variations that all had to be calculated in advance, there will always be found one voice in the envious crowd who will denigrate it by declaring the opponent's previous move an obvious blunder that made the scintillating sequel a matter of course. It does not count that this obstreperous rival never saw the combinational possibility in the first place, and that when it was finally pointed out, it took him six hours of analysis to ascertain that it was indeed correct.

title: IRSAY HAS A ROLE AS COLTS FACE ELWAY
description: Robert Irsay, the owner of the Baltimore Colts, was pacing. Back and forth he went, from in front of the desk in the office of General Manager Ernie Accorsi, along the wall with the huge windows overlooking the practice field, to a spot in front of two big television sets. Back and forth.

title: IT'S THE SEASON OF THE ORIOLES, BASEBALL'S SEPTEMBER TEAM
description: BUB RIPKEN taught the basics. If any of his sons, Fred, Billy or Calvin Jr., wanted to learn the game, then the lesson would be simple.

title: NEWSPAPER BOXES CONCERN LITCHFIELD
description: WHEN fretting and fussing was last heard in Litchfield, a quintessential 18th-century town in Connecticut's northwest hills, it was because the Methodists had painted their white church gold with blue trim and shingled the roof in gold and brown. For a while last fall, the tricolored edifice raised eyebrows among many who viewed the building as a detraction from the town's colonial charm.

title: Bond Default
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Thomas Wed To Patricia Ann Brody
description: Patricia Ann Brody, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Selwyn Brody of White Plains, was married yesterday to Thomas Kostro, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Kostro of Forest Hills, Queens. Cantor Raymond Smolover of the Jewish Community Center in White Plains performed the ceremony at the Purchase (N.Y.) Friends Meeting House, assisted by the Rev. Lyle Young, a Roman Catholic priest,

title: CITY HOUSING ADVOCATES APPEAL FOR U.S. AID
description: A coalition of New York City housing advocates is urging that Congress pass legislation to provide substantial money for construction for the first time since President Reagan took office.

title: Rejuvenating The Parthenon
description: One of the most astonishing things about the Parthenon is simply that it has endured human folly for almost 25 centuries. Now a bit of human ingenuity is coming to the rescue, intended to protect the structure from further ravages.

title: THE CHANGING MOOD
description: The Congress is coming back from its summer vacation, but this time not just to the same humdrum problems. It faces the last session of the old year and the coming struggles of a Presidential election year under different circumstances.

title: HOW THE LAW WILL WORK AND WHAT COSTS WILL BE
description: At 12:01 A.M. tomorrow, every retail outlet in New York State that sells carbonated and naturally bubbling beverages, including beer, will be required to charge a deposit on beverage cans and bottles. Most bottles and cans sold in New York will have a nickel deposit, although on some larger containers the deposit may be more.

title: THE SEASON AHEAD
description: ANYONE who asks ''What's new?'' about the upcoming theater season is going to hear the titles of a plethora of unfamiliar plays, including ''Natter Ar Dagens Mor,'' which created a stir in Sweden and will have its American premiere at the Yale Repertory. In translation, it means ''Night Is Mother of the Day.''

title: Arg"uello Decides 'the Carnival Is Over'
description: It was over now, and Alexis Arg"uello sat on the hot canvas, his legs crossed at the ankles, his crossed arms draped over his knees, and looked up as Referee Richard Steele counted out one of the most distinguished careers in boxing.

title: SHOREHAM: A WAY OUT?
description: IN addition to the safety questions the Shoreham nuclear power plant poses, it is finally being comprehended that an operational $4 billion Shoreham plant also means economic devastation to Long Island - for both homeowners and businesses. Based on recent conversations I've had with some of the most respected financial management consulting firms in Manhattan, it is my conclusion that if the Shoreham facility is licensed for commercial operation in 1984, by 1987 present electric rates will have doubled.

title: Expos' 5th Homer Beats Mets
description: Gary Carter hit two of the Expos' five home runs tonight, but Tim Wallach got the most important one, a towering shot in the ninth inning that enabled Montreal to beat the Mets, 10-9.

title: THE TREES OF WARSAW
description: Having just returned from visiting my family in Poland, I read A. M. Rosenthal's article with great interest.

title: Jane Watts Scheerer Wed in East Hampton
description: Jane Watts Scheerer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Scheerer 2d of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and Simon Donald Parkes, son of Matthew Donald Parkes of Brent Knoll, England, and the late Lorna Parkes, were married yesterday. The Rev. Francis Creamer Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton.

title: COST OF OBSTETRIC CARE IS LINKED TO INSURANCE
description: The rising cost of malpractice insurance and an increase in the use of precautionary measures to guard against malpractice suits have driven up the cost of obstetric and gynecological care, according to a study prepared for the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.

title: THE TREES OF WARSAW
description: Mr. Rosenthal's article is so sad, true and honest that it could only be written by someone who ''felt a sense of being part of Poland.'' ''A small stone melted'' not only in the heart of this distinguished correspondent, but also in the hearts of many Polish-American readers who had the opportunity to read his excellent account. WOJCIECH WINKLER, President, Polish American Congress Inc., San Mateo, Calif.

title: OF MUSIC, NAZISM AND VIENNA OF 1945
description: To the Editor:

title: Diane Beattie McLeod Wed to John McCurdy
description: Diane Beattie McLeod, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Anderson McLeod of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and Weekapaug, R.I., was married yesterday to John Hood McCurdy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver L. McCurdy of Fort Myers, Fla. Bishop Robert B. Appleyard, the retired Episcopal Bishop of Pittsburgh, performed the ceremony at the Weekapaug Chapel.

title: LIFE WITH MAX AND SMUDGE: A CAT TALE
description: FROM our litter of kittens last fall, orphaned at five weeks, we kept two; one because he was beautiful, the other because she was not. When their mother died, Tailgate, our 3-year-old tabby, appointed himself their mentor and undertook the job of teaching the kittens the ways of catdom. A trio of cats is ample to live with.

title: SOUTH CYPRUS BOUNCES BACK FROM '74 WAR
description: For more than 400 years this was a drowsy farming village. Today it is the Mediterranean island's most popular seaside resort and a symbol of Greek Cypriot resilience.

title: POPE, IN VIENNA, STRESSES CHRISTIAN HERITAGE
description: Pope John Paul II arrived in Vienna today to join in celebrations of the third centennial of the defeat of the invading Turkish Moslem army by the united forces of Christian Europe at the gates of Vienna.

title: SOVIET SEEKS LOOPHOLES IN WIDE INDICTMENT
description: EXCEPT for the usual support from its satellites, it was the Soviet Union against the world last week and the Reagan Administration sought to keep it that way. The shooting down of Korean Airlines Flight 7 with 269 people in circumstances still unclear provoked worldwide reaction - from demonstrations to the spilling of Russian vodka - of rare intensity.

title: GUIDED WESTCHESTER'S GROWTH
description: Edwin G. Michaelian, the four-term Westchester County Executive who was identified with much of the county's postwar growth and development, died of a heart attack Friday night at a fund- raising dinner in Tarrytown. He was 77 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: GLOVES: IT'S A LONG STORY
description: There are still those women, few now, and very far between, who will not step outside unless they are wearing white gloves.

title: Debra Ann Orselet Marries
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Easton, Conn., yesterday, Debra Ann Orselet, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David K. Orselet of Easton, was married to Franklin Douglas Marsteller, son of Mrs. Henry F. Marsteller of Allentown, Pa., and the late Mr. Marsteller.

title: WILL THE PHILHARMONIC LIVE UP TO ITS ADVERTISING?
description: ''The world's most exciting orchestra,'' as the New York Philharmonic's advertisements defiantly put it, returns to action this week, beginning a season that should offer the organization adequate opportunity to prove that the phrase is more than promotional hyperbole. The season also is likely to test whatever inner resources of stability and morale the Philharmonic may possess. The Philharmonic, despite its long and illustrious history, has never been famously rich in such resources, but this year Zubin Mehta, the music director, will find himself under even more pressure than usual to keep the orchestra in a playing mood. Money, as usual, is the irritating issue.

title: DANCE
description: The National Dance Theater Company of Jamaica has been seen at the Brooklyn Academy of Music several times in the past but this week marks the unusual troupe's Manhattan debut. What sets the Jamaica company apart from so many other groups with a national flavor are its roots in a modern-dance esthetic which its founders, Rex Nettleford and Eddy Thomas, felt was totally compatible with folk themes.

title: COUNTRY NEIGHBOR LURING AWAY PROFESSIONAL OFFICES FROM NEWARK
description: ROSELAND, a community of 5,000 residents in Essex County, about 10 miles west of Newark, is fast becoming an office center for lawyers, accountants and other professionals fleeing to a pastoral setting from inner-city problems.

title: '34 Stations (And Counting)'
description: Two years ago I enjoyed ''discovering'' the remains of the old New York, Westchester & Boston railroad line, guided by a book called ''Westchester's Forgotten Railway'' (by Roger Arcara, 1962) and by my own recollection of certain odd-looking buildings and bridge abutments I had seen over the years and wondered about.

title: French in Chad Use U.S. Satellite Data
description: French forces in Chad get minute-by- minute information on Libyan military movements on Chadian soil from United States satellites over the Sahara, diplomats said today.

title: Hope Woodhouse Wed to R. J. Canty
description: Hope Bulkeley Woodhouse, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Macauley Woodhouse of Grosse Pointe, Mich., and Falmouth, Mass., was married yesterday to Richard Joseph Canty, son of Mrs. John Murray Canty of Boston and Ipswich, Mass., and the late Mr. Canty. The Rev. Robert L. Counselman, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Old Christ Church in Middletown, N.J.

title: WILTON BECKONS
description: With the intention of accommodating the office-space needs of smaller tenants, Leland R. Wilson broke ground last month for a $2 million, 21,100-square-foot building in Wilton, Conn. The site is a 1.8- acre tract at 43 Danbury Road near Route 7.

title: DRUSE BESIEGE CHRISTIANS IN MOUNTAINS OUTSIDE BEIRUT
description: Druse militiamen laid siege to Christian enclaves in the Shuf Mountains east and south of here today as efforts to achieve a cease-fire faltered on the seventh day of Lebanon's renewed civil war.

title: Albanese Building
description: To the Editor:

title: Cabanas Gets Contract
description: The Cosmos have signed Roberto Cabanas, the North American Soccer League's leading scorer, to a new long-term contract, effective next season.

title: 'Protected Place' At Jones Beach
description: Sharon Monahan's yearning for a ''protected place for people who remember the beach as a sanctuary'' (''And That's the Way It Was,'' Opinion Page, July 31) existed at Jones Beach until this summer. For years, I found a quiet, relaxing environment at parking field West End 1 - an environment devoid of loud radios and crowded conditions reminiscent of Coney Island on the Fourth of July.

title: THE TREES OF WARSAW
description: As a second-generation Polish American, born and raised in the Middle West, I want to thank A. M. Rosenthal for his moving article.

title: WHERE SALADS ARE SPECIAL
description: WHEN J. G. Cristada in Westport first opened, it was esthetically satisfying to look at, imaginative in its offerings, disorganized in its service and pricey.

title: FALCON OFFENSE TO TEST GIANTS
description: The season has just begun and the Giants are already facing a crucial contest. At Atlanta today they play the Falcons, the first of four successive opponents of playoff caliber who will define the Giants' comparative abilities and their place in the National Football League. After the Falcons come the Dallas Cowboys, Green Bay Packers and San Diego Chargers.

title: Four Shuttlelooking Like One Too Many
description: The space shuttle Challenger logged a very clean mission last week, showing that the machine itself was running about as well as could be expected. But in the aftermath of the eighth shuttle flight, attention landed once again on economic aspects of the project, which have always seemed murkier than the technical side.

title: Protesters Said to Stone Zia's Motorcade
description: A crowd protesting military rule stoned President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq's motorcade when he visited the town of Dadu in Sind Province, witnesses said.

title: COMPLICATED POET OF THE BLUES
description: LANGSTON HUGHES. Before and Beyond Harlem. By Faith Berry. 376 pp. Westport, Conn.: Lawrence Hill & Co. Cloth, $19.95.; paper, $12.95.

title: U.S. UNVEILS A NEW SYSTEM FOR SURPLUS FOOD
description: The Government has devised a new system to process surplus food for schools and institutions that officials hope will reduce bulging Government inventories while providing recipients with a greater variety of food.

title: PENNANT HOPES AND BENCH FEARS
description: No matter what happens this weekend at Yankee Stadium, Ken Singleton believes the Baltimore Orioles will be in the World Series in October. It is a reasonable expectation on a club that has not had a losing season since 1967.

title: CHILI COOKOFF: HOT WEATHER, HOTTER DISHES
description: It was a taste of Texas deep in the heart of Queens.

title: L.I. FIRMS 'HIRING' ROBOTS
description: AT Renco Electronics in Deer Park, Veronica gets the jobs nobody wants. On a typical day Veronica might pluck 4,000 electric coils off a winding machine. Veronica solders them and places each one on the other side of a table to be marked. She is learning how to coat coils with epoxy, a task as messy as the present one is repetitious. Come fall, the president of Renco, Bruce Rensing, wants to add optics so Veronica the robot can see.

title: Joanne Bronski Wed in Riverside
description: Joanne Theresa Bronski, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aloysius T. Bronski of the Bronx, and William Randolph Henrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Henrick of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Joseph Amato performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: CANDIDATES SET FOR TUESDAY VOTE
description: ''THERE'S one of the candidates now,'' John C. Mandanici said as he sat in his storefront campaign headquarters in Bridgeport one morning last week and watched John J. McNamara walk by on Main Street.

title: Aristide Joseph Tessitore, Maria C. Canale Are Wed
description: Maria C. Canale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Canale of Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday to Aristide Joseph Tessitore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Tessitore of Newtown, Conn. The Rev. Aristide Tessitore, cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Assumption Roman Catholic Church.

title: The Purloined Paper Chase
description: Congressional investigators looking into how Jimmy Carter's debate briefing papers got into Reagan aides' hands in 1980 haven't found a smoking gun, but they may have come up with a hot copying machine.

title: Margaret Yanow Wed To Robert A. Ouimette
description: Margaret Jean Yanow, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Mitchell Yanow of Ladue, Mo., was married yesterday to Robert Alan Ouimette, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred T. Ouimette of Falmouth, Mass., and Sarasota, Fla. Rabbi Joseph Rosenbloom performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Miss Jones Weds George Barrett 3d
description: Joanne Kathryn Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Farrell Jones of Port Washington, L.I., and Oak Bluffs, Mass., was married yesterday to George Fielding Barrett 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Barrett Jr. of Warren, N.J. The Rev. J. Harold Hadley performed the ceremony at the North Shore Unitarian-Universalist Society in Plandome, L.I.

title: DOLLAR POWER
description: POLITICS AND MONEY. The New Road to Corruption. By Elizabeth Drew. 165 pp. New York: Macmillan. $11.95.

title: TRYING TO GET THE WRINKLES OUT OF AVON
description: WHEN Hicks B. Waldron was a college fullback in the early 40's for the University of Michigan, his team suffered a 50-0 beating by the University of Minnesota. The next year, Mr. Waldron transferred to the Minnesota team, and it was Minnesota's turn to get walked over by Michigan, 52-6.

title: The Latest on Vesco
description: One way or another, Robert L. Vesco is determined to stay in the world of high finance, according to NBC News.

title: WHEN THE SPEAKER IS A WOMAN
description: Not long ago, a woman's place was anywhere but at the podium. ''Most of these meetings are attended by men, and men don't want to be told the facts of anything by a woman,'' one booking agent stated flatly.

title:
DINING OUT;
NEW CHINESE MENU, OLD FAVORITES
description: A DECADE ago, Hunan Village took the county by storm as one of the first places to offer Chinese regional cuisine - Sichuan-Hunanese food. The square building on lower Central Avenue has become familiar to many. Its location is about all that has remained intact, however. The building has been redecorated, and much to the pleasure of passers-by the outside walls show two pandas (perhaps a nod to Ling- Ling and Sing-Sing) cavorting and chomping bamboo. To the delight of those who stop inside, dark walls frame two glowing antique Chinese murals under a ceiling busy with red and green Oriental designs.

title: DON'T CALL ME AT ALL
description: DO you remember the comedy routine that led to a popular commercial done by a small man, with a small mustache, who delivered the line, ''Oh, you can call me Ray, or you can call me Jay. . .but ya doesn't have to call me Johnson''? That small man hit upon a subject of interest to nearly everyone and hence his popularity and the hilarity with which his single comic device, besides his small mustache, was greeted.

title: CONSERVATISM AND QUALITY COLOR THE NEW RELEASES
description: This year's recordings, taken as a whole, have a solid, often conservative, tinge to them. The most interesting of them invest quality in known commodities. Extravagances and oddities are at a minimum.

title: REAGAN SAYS RUSSIANS 'STONEWALLED THE WORLD'
description: President Reagan, warning against maintaining illusions about the morality of Soviet leaders, charged today that they had ''stonewalled the world'' after their destruction of the Korean Air Lines passenger plane.

title: A CRITIC'S LOT: SOME TRUTHS AND SOME GROSS CANARDS
description: Recently I was called for jury duty. While examining my qualifications to be a juror, the assistant district attorney apologized that the case being tried might prove to be boring - in contrast to the theater, ''which was always interesting.'' I corrected him with the information that the theater could be boring, and, being an open-minded citizen, one would make no pre-judgment about the dramatic interest of the case. I was rejected for that jury, but was subsequently considered for another impaneling. This time I was seated next to a young novelist and we agreed that we would both be challenged on the grounds that we could not tell art from reality. To our surprise, we were both chosen. The case was fascinating, far more than most recent visits to the theater. As critics may forget, there is no dramatic substitute for a real life experience.

title: Management Misses the Point?
description: Exploring the declining American work ethic has become a thriving cottage industry itself. A new study has found that a major cause of the problem isn't workers but bosses: outmoded management techniques that emphasize control rather than performance.

title: ON THE DOWNING OF KOREAN AIR LINES FLIGHT 7
description: To the Editor:

title: OF MONKS AND MARTIAL ARTS
description: The vivid frescoes seem startling in a 1,500-year-old Buddhist temple. On one wall, monks fight with feet and clenched fists in a cloistered garden. On the opposite wall, more monks spar with swords, staves, cudgels and other ancient weapons. The stones of an adjacent hall have been stamped down into 48 indentations, a legacy of centuries of practice in the martial arts that have left the floor pitted up to seven inches deep. Shaolin Monastery, nestled on the barren slopes of Song Mountain in central China's Henan Province, was the home of Chan Buddhism, a Chinese sect that gave rise of Zen Buddhism in Japan. But it is even better known as the cradle of wushu, an ancient fighting skill that has evolved into Chinese kung fu and influenced Japanese karate and Korean taekwondo.

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: CHANGES. By Danielle Steel. 348 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $15.95.

title: HUMPHREY DANCE TROUPE OF TARRYTOWN BROADENS ITS GOALS
description: A PERFORMING dance company that is Westchester's own, originating and producing its own works in the county, backed by a strong troupe of dancers and a dance studio that is rapidly becoming an institution - these are the goals of the Humphrey Dance Center of Tarrytown, which last week took several major steps to achieve them.

title: Donna B. Wheeler Marries
description: The marriage of Donna B. Wheeler, a registered nurse at Bloomingdale's, to David H. Polinger, senior vice president and assistant to the president of WPIX, took place yesterday at Club El Morocco. Rabbi Balfour Brickner performed the ceremony. The bridegroom's previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: U.S. COURT RESTRICTS DEVELOPMENT PLANS FOR WESTERN LANDS
description: A Federal district judge has issued a preliminary order to bar the Interior Department from allowing development on 1.5 million acres of Federal land in 10 Western states.

title: 'NO THANKS, I'M WALKING'
description: THE horn blares. The driver leans out the window. ''Would you like a ride?'' my friendly neighbor calls.

title: IN SEARCH OF RARE PLANTS SPECIES
description: BLACK-EYED SUSAN. Blue chicory. Queen Anne's lace. These wildflowers bloom with such freedom in fields and on roadsides, it is hard to imagine that any wild plants could be in trouble. But some are. And if Leslie J. Mehrhoff has anything to say about them, their futures will be more secure.

title: SWALE WINS FUTURITY
description: Swale and Shuttle Jet are probably not the best 2-year-olds around this year, but they have been staging a rousing rivalry. In the third meeting of their brief careers, Swale outgamed Shuttle Jet in a long stretch drive yesterday to win the $136,525 Futurity Stakes by a nose at Belmont Park.

title: BLACK RUNS UPHILL IN BALTIMORE RACE
description: ''How you doing, brother - I need your help,'' was the street appeal this weekend by William H. Murphy Jr., the 40-year-old former Baltimore Circuit Court judge who has been called the first serious black candidate for Mayor of this city, which is 60 percent black.

title: FLORIDA STATE TRIUMPHS, 40-35
description: Kelly Lowrey passed for two touchdowns and ran for three today to rally Florida State from a 14-point deficit to a 40-35 victory over Louisiana State.

title: Pennsylvania Man Arrested After 2 Die in Shooting Spree
description: A man armed with two rifles and a pistol shot five members of a family next door tonight, killing two, and then surrendered, the police said.

title: NETWORK FORMED FOR BANK MACHINES
description: BARNEY and Willie have never talked to each other. It is not a feud, it's just that they have never been introduced. But they, and seven others like them, are going to become fast friends later this year when Yankee 24 begins operations.

title: DRESSING FOR THE COLD
description: Because I had never been frostbitten before, I didn't realize that my left big toe slowly was being drained of blood. I was sitting in a heated press box at Riverfront Stadium in Cincinnati, while below me, two teams were about to play what had to be the coldest championship game in National Football League history.

title: The F.B.I. in Peace and War
description: While Vice President Henry A. Wallace was making dovish noises in the 1940's, J. Edgar Hoover was watching him like a hawk, The Des Moines Sunday Register reported last week. Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation trailed the liberal politician, opened his mail and tapped his supporters' telephones, the newspaper said.

title: SUCCESS OF THESE RINGS IS NO PUZZLE
description: FOR Jose Grant of Stamford, jewelry design is ''like flying - it has no boundaries.'' The retired pilot for T.W.A. is concerned these days with his burgeoning jewelry business, which has 50 employees.

title: PEACE ENOWMENT LEAVING NEW YORK
description: After nearly 73 years in New York City, the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace is closing its office in the city and merging with its Washington center of operations.

title: BROOKLYN FRONTIER
description: ''In terms of residential renovation in Brooklyn'' said Scott Miscione, an architect, ''this area is really a frontier.'' He was referring to Lexington Avenue between Franklin and Grand Avenues in the Clinton section, where he has been converting abandoned commercial properties into residential units for the last two years.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: FOR a Teaneck rabbi, this Rosh ha-Shanah (the Jewish New Year) was filled with an extra bundle of joy - her infant daughter. The rabbi, Deborah R. Prinz, of Temple Beth Am, a Reform congregation, gave birth in June.

title: AMERICA'S BEST
description: The most influential men's-wear designers in this countryhave managed to perfect a traditional approach whilequietly initiating changes in the way men dress. PERRY ELLIS

title: CRISIS BRINGS OUT THE WORST IN MOSCOW
description: IF Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov was lying last week, he did so with the utmost ease. As Western correspondents pushed forward with hostile questions at a news conference that was virtually unprecedented for a chief of the Soviet General Staff, he calmly reiterated Russian insistence that Korean Air Lines Flight 7 and the 269 people aboard were pawns sacrificed by American intelligence in a ''diabolic game.'' Soviet admissions that a district commander had ordered the plane shot down on Aug. 31 and that Marshal Ogarkov had known about it were obscured in a fog of denials and sidesteps.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: NORWALK BOAT SHOW

title: SOUTH KOREANS START INQUIRY
description: The Government, which says it does not know why the Korean Air Lines jetliner that was shot down by the Soviet Union last week was off course, has begun its investigation of the case.

title: PENN STATE (0-2) LOSES TO CINCINNATI, 14-3
description: The quarterback Troy Bodine led Cincinnati to two touchdowns in a period of 2 minutes 16 seconds after two second-quarter fumble recoveries for a 14-3 upset of Penn State today.

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE DARK FANTASTIC. By Stanley Ellin. 309 pp. New York: The Mysterious Press. $13.95.

title: MIDDLE WESTERN DROUGHT FORCING FARMERS TO THIN OUT CATTLE HERDS
description: The damaging effects of this year's drought have spread to the Middle West's valuable livestock.

title: HIGH-TECH DRIVE TAKES SHAPE
description: THE outline of an aggressive and detailed strategy is emerging in the Kean administration's campaign to win the competition with other states for high-technology business.

title: Power Relays Bombed North of Johannesburg
description: Bombs damaged two power stations north of Johannesburg before dawn today.

title: David Matthau Marries Suzanne Huyot in Queens
description: Suzanne Huyot, daughter of Rita S. Huyot of Stuart, Fla., and Robert Huyot of Paris and Carmel, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Matthau, son of the actor Walter Matthau of Los Angeles and the late Geri Matthau of New York. The Rev. Hosho Shiina performed the ceremony at the Nichiren Shoshu Buddhist Temple in Flushing, Queens.

title: Patricia Houlihan And Bank Officer Are Wed Upstate
description: Patricia Maureen Houlihan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Patrick Houlihan of Schenectady, N.Y., was married yesterday to Schuyler Van Rensselaer Winter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark Burritt Winter of Garden City, L.I., and Windham, N.Y.

title: Britannica to the East
description: THE ENCYCLOPAEDIA BRITANNICA signed an agreement with the People's Republic of China last year to publish an eight-volume Chinese-language edition, the first four volumes of which will come out next year. The Britannica also recently concluded a licensing agreement with Omnitrans, Inc., a computer translation firm in Palo Alto, Calif., which will translate, publish and distribute a 20-volume Arabritannica Encyclopaedia based largely on the current (15th) edition of the Britannica. It will be the first modern, comprehensive encyclopedia in Arabic.

title: THE MAN WHO BROUGHT AUSTRALIA TO AMERICA'S CUP
description: AFTER 132 years as a monopoly of the New York Yacht Club, it appears that the America's Cup may depart these shores and sail away to the Royal Perth Yacht Club in Western Australia. Indeed, Halsey Herreshoff, the navigator of the defending American yacht, Liberty warned it was ''likely'' that the Australians would capture the Cup unless their phenomenally fast Australia II were ruled to be an illegal 12-Meter because of her controversial winged keel. The Australian yacht has decisively beaten all contenders from Britain, France, Italy, Canada and two other Australian clubs in the summerlong challengers' trials off Newport, R.I.

title: BREWED IN JAPAN
description: Japan enjoys a well-deserved reputation as one of the great tea-drinking nations of the world. But coffee connoisseurs here seldom feel slighted. While tea reigns supreme as a symbol of Eastern tradition, simplicity and elegance, the preferred drink of emperors, geisha and samurai, coffee for the Japanese evokes all that is exciting and sophisticated in the West. It appears to be the drink of presidents, intellectuals and movie stars. Many Japanese genuinely like the taste of coffee, but perhaps even more like coffee for what it represents. During its 100 years in Japan, coffee has made a singular contribution to popular Japanese culture with the Japanese version of the coffee shop, known as the kissaten or kissa. It can be large or small, and serves everything from full-course dinners to ''cohee dake,'' coffee only. The kissaten can be found in virtually every Japanese city, town and hamlet - on crowded thoroughfares, tucked in alleyways, atop department stores. The Tokyo phone book alone lists more than 30,000 kissaten.

title: THE TREES OF WARSAW
description: Mr. Rosenthal's eloquent description of his identification of the ''stone'' in his heart that had prevented him from unleashing his passion for freedom when it came to Poland hopefully will serve as a catalyst for soul-searching on the part of others.

title: THE REALIGNMENT IN WORLD STEEL
description: TO an American observer, the petition for import relief filed in July had an all too familiar ring: Domestic steelmakers, squeezed by growing competition from low-priced imports, press the government to restrain foreign producers. The government, for broader political reasons, declines. The steelmakers then warn the government that its refusal will result in the most dire consequences for the domestic industry.

title: L.I. COOKING SCHOOLS SERVE A FULL MENU OF CLASS
description: THE roster of cooking schools on Long Island continues to grow. Whether you are a beginner, an accomplished amateur or a even professional wishing to widen your repertory, the myriad classes available this year offer an increasing diversity in techniques and cuisines.

title: Business Forum; The Fine Art of Corporate Motivation
description: Following are excerpts from ''High Output Management,'' by Andrew S. Grove, president of the Intel Corporatation, and published this month by Random House, New York.

title: AVIATION GROUP DEFENDS NEED FOR THIRD RUNWAY
description: AVIATION consultants to the Board of Legislators have told it that a proposal to build a third runway at the County Airport, a key element of the airport's master plan, no longer had merit and should be reconsidered.

title: BRAZIL'S POOR RAIDING FOOD STORES IN THE RIO AREA
description: Rio de Janeiro's entire police force was put in the streets on Friday to try to halt invasions of food stores by residents of the city's poor neighborhoods.

title: Recent Sales
description: Alexandria $250,000 *2*Goritz Road, 3-bedroom, 3-bath, *2*8-year-old ranch; 44 acres, stocked pond, fenced *2*pasture for horses; taxes $3,599. Hopatcong $75,000 *2*12 DeVito Trail, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*2-year-old ranch; wall-to-wall carpeting, *2*rear deck; taxes $2,271. Long Valley $102,500 *2*3 Oak Terrace, 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*17-year-old ranch; cul-de-sac location, hardwood *2*floors, 1 acre; taxes $2,118. North Bergen $126,000 *2*16 78th Street, 6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, *2*50-year-old brick 2-family; chestnut woodwork, *2*2-car garage; taxes $2,674. Succasunna $97,800 *2*15 Brent Place, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*25-year-old split level; beamed ceiling, tiled *2*foyer, central air-conditioning; taxes $1,595. Westfield $197,500 *2*512 Lenox Avenue, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*7-year-old colonial; fireplace, 2 skylights, porch; *2*taxes $3,927. OTHER AREAS Northport, L.I. $120,000 *2*100 Wells Road, 4-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*30-year-old Cape Cod; dining room with fireplace, *2*full basement, two-car garage, one acre; taxes $2,400. New Haven, Conn. $72,200 *2*174 Howard Avenue, 6-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*68-year-old colonial; leaded glass windows; *2*taxes $1,882. Ossining, N.Y. $121,000 *2*19 Somerstown Road, 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*160-year-old frame colonial; country kitchen, den, *2*parlor, 1.5 acres; taxes $3,285.

title: Latin Peace Plan Gets Approval of Officials
description: The Foreign Ministers of nine Latin American countries agreed today on a plan for peace in Central America that calls for regional negotiations, disarmament and a cutback in foreign advisers.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: A reported $2 billion drop in the money supply delighted the credit markets late last week; bond prices soared and interest rates plunged almost a third of a percentage point. Most market participants had expected a jump in the money supply of as much as $1 billion. The drop in M-1 - currency in circulation plus all check-like deposits - placed money growth within the Fed's current target range. It seemed to allay fears that the central bank would have to tighten credit and boded well for those looking for lower interest rates. ''This is the best money-supply picture we've had in the last 12 months; everything is on target,'' was the reaction of one market analyst.

title: Students March to Chant Of 'We Want Schools'
description: Angry students have taken to the streets in this coastal resort town to demand the reopening of classrooms shut when the schools ran out of money.

title: Idaho Marijuana Plot Raided
description: Camouflaged, machete-wielding narcotics agents swept through an Owyhee County cornfield Friday, destroying more than 500 marijuana plants valued at about $1 million, the authorities said. It took state, Federal and local officers four hours to chop down the plants, averaging 10 feet high, that had been randomly planted in the 10-acre corn crop, a spokesman said. He said the police were seeking at least two suspects.

title: OUTDOORS: FISHING FOR SALMON IN QUEBEC
description: CASTING a fly to Atlantic salmon - which under the best of circumstances only strike out of irritation or instinct when in their spawning rivers - is a ritual that offers scant hope for success if those streams are low and warm.

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be reported this week.

title: MACHINES WILL TRADE NICKELS FOR BEVERAGE CANS
description: The law requiring deposits on beverage containers in New York State takes full effect today, and the entrepreneurs are ready.

title: EQUIPMENT LEASING IS NOT A LOOPHOLE
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: PREMIERE BY CHING GONZALEZ
description: CHING GONZALEZ set seven dancers off on a journey in ''Flight Paths,'' a 45-minute work that he presented Saturday night at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, and it soon became clear that this was a venture into dangerous territory.

title: Italian Town Agrees To Dioxin Settlement
description: Seveso, the north Italian town that suffered severe dioxin contamination seven years ago, has decided to accept a $7 million compensation offer from the Swiss company whose factory caused the disaster.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt IssuesT* Nafco Financial Group , Naples, Fla., has filed an initial registration statement to offer $20 million of 20-year convertible subordinated debentures, through A. G. Becker Paribas. Common Stock

title: UTAH CASE REVIVES POLYGAMY DISPUTE
description: Royston Potter, discharged by a suburban Salt Lake City police force because he is a polygamist, says he took three wives as a matter of religious conviction.

title: PRIVACY VS. COMPUTERS
description: Dramatic advances in information technology that allow computerized data banks to communicate with one another have far outpaced the development of legal controls that protect individual freedom. Unless something is done, we may be heading for a time when one's ability to exercise control over personal information about oneself is, as a practical matter, a thing of the past.

title: POP: ASHFORD AND SIMPSON CONCERTS
description: ASHFORD AND SIMPSON, pop-soul music's perennial love birds, popped out of a glittering Art Deco skyscraper Saturday night at Radio City Music Hall, where they played three weekend performances. The cardboard edifice was emblematic not only of the couple's long-standing relationship with New York City but also of their latest album, ''High Rise,'' five of whose songs they performed with an eight-piece band.

title: Miss Allen Wed To Jules Feiffer
description: Jennifer Allen, a freelance writer in New York, was married yesterday to Jules Feiffer, the cartoonist and playwright. The Rev. Will D. Campbell, a Baptist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the New York home of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Davis, friends of the couple.

title: St. Louis Schools Act To Replace Strikers
description: The Board of Education placed a full-page advertisement in a local newspaper today offering permanent jobs to people who replace striking teachers.

title: COWBOYS FALL BEHIND, BUT WIN AGAIN
description: For the second straight game, the Dallas Cowboys overcame a slow start and an early deficit to win. But their 34-17 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today bore little resemblance to their dramatic 31-30 victory over the Washington Redskins last Monday night.

title: TO PROTEST THE SURVIVING SHAWNS IN OUR SOCIETY
description: To the Editor:

title: Jeffrey Wilbur Is Married to Susanne J. Behrens
description: Susanne Jennifer Behrens, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Behrens of Arlington, Va., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Mark Wilbur, son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Wilbur of Cranston, R.I. The ceremony was performed by Associate Judge Geoffrey M. Alprin of the Superior Court of the District of Columbia at the Sewall-Belmont House, a National Historic Site in Washington.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: %Baseball

title: LEAN HARVESTER IS OPTIMISTIC
description: The 24th floor executive suite at the headquarters of the International Harvester Company hardly looks like the hub of a company that is supposed to be on the mend.

title: TV: 'MACNEIL/LEHRER' IN ONE-HOUR FORMAT
description: THE good news about the ''The MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour'' is that it is still ''MacNeil/ Lehrer.'' On the other hand, this is the bad news, too.

title: Advertising; Agency And Client Relations
description: WHEN she's on the job as a vice president on the account management side at Cadwell Davis, Nancy L. Salz thinks constantly about the needs of her clients. On the weekends when there is time to let the mind wander, she thinks of other things. One weekend not long ago she thought of writing a book, and it's now in the stores, although the official publication date is Sept. 30.

title: Market Place; Resistance To Dow Highs
description: THE Dow Jones industrial average attempted last week to set a new closing high but fell short. The average rose 24.29 points, ending at 1,239.74; its record finish was 1,248.30 on June 16.

title: YANKEES FALL 7 BEHIND
description: The Yankees planned diligently and expensively all winter, then played determinedly for more than five months to ensure their presence in the September stretch drive for the American League East championship. Now, though, in the space of 24 hours, they - with help from the Baltimore Orioles - have removed themselves from that stretch drive, realistically if not mathematically.

title: Giants 3, Astros 2
description: Atlee Hammaker of the Giants struck out 14, a National League season-high, before leaving with two out in the eighth. The pinch-hitter Dave Bergman hit a two-run single and Tom O'Malley followed with a run-scoring single during a three-run ninth inning off Nolan Ryan.

title: 10 FAMILIES WORK TO BUILD OWN HOMES
description: Robert and Donna Minzak once feared they would never own a home. Now they are helping build their own neighborhood.

title: HARRIS LEADS STEELERS OVER PACKERS
description: Franco Harris ran for 118 yards and one touchdown to lead a punishing ground game today that led the Pittsburgh Steelers to a 25-21 victory over the Green Bay Packers.

title: MUGABE HAS A HELPING OF GEORGIA HOSPITALITY
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, in a stopover here this weekend, was served a large helping of Georgia hospitality.

title: No Headline
description: THE Reagan Administration, which finds itself in the middle of a long-running feud that pits 12 states against various multinational companies and foreign governments, is expected to decide this week whether to propose limiting the states' ability to use the so-called unitary method of taxation.

title: BANKING REGULATION EXAMINED
description: The staff of an Administration task group is drafting plans to consolidate most of the Government's regulation of commercial banks in a new, single Federal banking commission.

title: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, 1983
description: International

title: POPE SAYS WORLD MAY BE ENTERING 'PREWAR' PHASE
description: Pope John Paul II warned today that growing calls for peace seemed to justify the fears of some that the world was moving from a postwar to a prewar period.

title: SOME RELIEF FOR FATHER OF VICTIM
description: The father of Mary Jane Hendrie, the first victim of Flight 7 to be positively identified, expressed gratitude today that doubts about the 25-year-old woman's fate had been dispelled.

title: GREEN BERETS CHECK NUCLEAR PLANTS' SECURITY
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is using Army Green Berets to help determine whether nuclear power plants are vulnerable to attacks by saboteurs.

title: Margaret Joy Is Bride
description: Margaret Marie Joy, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Vincent A. Joy of East Rockaway, L.I., was married in Manhattan yesterday to Dr. Andrew A. Bailey Jr., son of Mrs. Bailey of Richmond and the late Mr. Bailey. The Rev. Dr. Thomas F. Pike performed the ceremony at Calvary Episcopal Church. The bride is a registered nurse at the New York University Medical Center, where Dr. Bailey is a resident in surgery.

title: CORRECTION
description: Science Times on Aug. 23 failed to credit C. P. Vick as the source of a drawing of a Soviet rocket. It also mislabeled the payload of the rocket, which was a surveillance satellite.

title: PINOCHET IS FIRM IN ANNIVERSARY SPEECH
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet commemorated the 10th anniversary of his rise to power today in a speech in which he called opposition leaders ''agents of violence'' and offered no concessions to the growing movement of protesters demanding his resignation.

title: A MODEST PROPOSAL
description: President Reagan has a problem with women that goes so deep he can't cover it up with ''cosmetic'' policies - like those proclaimed last week to purge sexually discriminatory language from Federal statutes - or dismiss it with the claim that ''our record isn't known.'' The trouble is that it is known.

title: NEW ROCHELLE SCHOOLS MOVING INTO COMPUTER AGE
description: The New Rochelle School Board voted unanimously last month to spend more than $300,000 to buy a central computer system for its 7,500 students from kindergarten through 12th grade, and it knew it was taking a big step.

title: LAWRENCE FRIED
description: Lawrence Fried, a freelance photographer whose work appeared in Newsweek, the Saturday Evening Post, and Collier's magazines, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 56 years old.

title: Boojum To Chas Conerly
description: If a textbook were written about the relationship between early pace and the outcome of six-furlong races, yesterday's running of the Boojum Handicap would illustrate the hazards of speed duels. Gold Beauty and Shimatoree, two of the faster sprinters in recent years, cooked each other for a half mile at Belmont Park yesterday and set up the Boojum for an improbable late winning charge by Chas Conerly.

title: A Guide to Resolutions
description: Now that Congress is back from its summer vacation, you had better get your hands on a copy of ''The Guide to Continuing Resolutions'' if you want to keep up.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: * Rate depicted in Long- or Short-Term Rates chart.

title: Quisenberry Ties Record
description: Dan Quisenberry tied the major league record by posting his 38th save as the Kansas City Royals gained a 3-1 triumph over the Minnesota Twins today. Willie Aikens won the game with a two-run, two-out homer in the ninth inning.

title: Cambodia Rebels Attack A Vietnamese Base
description: Cambodian rebels attacked a Vietnamese base near the Thai-Cambodian border today in a new offensive, Western military sources said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I was scared at first. I thought they were not going to let us in.

title: CONSERVATIVES GATHER TO REMEMBER GEORGIAN
description: More than 3,500 conservatives held a memorial service today for Representative Larry P. McDonald, one of 269 people killed in the downing of a Korean airliner.

title: Commodities; Eason Volatile Currency Trading
description: WHEN the dollar rocketed to record highs early last month, one trader said currency speculators in the futures market were in nirvana.

title: Bridge:Westchester Group Joins In County's Tricentennial
description: A most unusual - perhaps unique - bridge tournament will be staged next Sunday as part of the Westchester County Tricentennial celebration. It will be a Swiss team contest at the Westchester County Center in White Plains with an interesting restriction: Every team must represent a city, town or village in Westchester or, alternatively, a particular Westchester company.

title: Letter: On Shipping; Keeping a Tanker Fleet at the Ready
description: To the Editor:

title: A MOTIVE IS SOUGHT
description: An exploding mail bomb injured the wife of a Nassau County school superintendent Saturday, and the police said yesterday that they were seeking a motive and a suspect.

title: SEAS OFF JAPAN YIELDING GRIM FLIGHT 7 DEBRIS
description: After a week of reluctance, the seas north of Japan have finally begun to give up the remains of Korean Air Lines Flight 7.

title: Pole Seeks German Asylum
description: Waldemar Rzedkowski, the First Secretary at the Polish Embassy in West Germany, has asked for political asylum, Government officials said today.

title: CONNORS CAPTURES FIFTH U.S. OPEN CROWN
description: Jimmy Connors again showed Ivan Lendl what it takes to win a Grand Slam tournament with a four-set victory yesterday for his fifth United States Open men's singles title and second in succession.

title: Ford Foundation Announces 24 Grants to 2-Year Colleges
description: The Ford Foundation said yesterday it would make $25,000 grants to enrich courses at 24 two-year community colleges across the country, in hopes that more of their graduates would become academically able to transfer to four-year colleges.

title: No Headline
description: Unnatural Bonds on Natural Gas It seems unlikely that Congress will soon untangle the knot of problems that keeps natural gas unnaturally regulated. The issues are so complex, the stakes so high and the politics so charged that any deal is a long shot. But the fact remains that gas consumers, producers and pipeline companies would all be better off with a compromise. The best hope lies with an Administration-backed bill soon to be tested in the Senate.

title: FELIX BLOCH, NOBEL LAUREATE FOR PIONEER WORK IN PHYSICS
description: Felix Bloch, professor emeritus of physics at Stanford University and winner of the Nobel Prize in Physics, died Saturday after a heart attack at his home in Zurich. He was 77.

title: People
description: * Samuel Cooperstein has joined Sawdon & Bess Advertising as senior vice president, group creative director.

title: BUSINESS LEADERS LOOK AHEAD
description: Each fall, the nation's business snaps back into high gear as summer's diversions recede farther into memory. As they return to work this season, business leaders will find more than enough in the way of pressing issues to claim their attention.

title: FLORIDA STATE 2-0 DESPITE BIG POINT YIELD
description: Undefeated, untied and unable to prevent opponents from scoring lots of points, Florida State amazes even its coach, Bobby Bowden.

title: Same Script For Montclair
description: For the second year in a row, Montclair State tied Wagner in the last minute of the season opener for the two leading Division III teams in the metropolitan area.

title: COMPUTER INSTRUCTION SOARS IN NEW YORK AREA SCHOOLS
description: In an explosion of excitement comparable to that in science and mathematics at the time of Sputnik 25 years ago, public schools across the New York metropolitan area this fall are taking the plunge into computers.

title: 2 Bus Crashes in North India Kill 56 and Leave 50 Missing
description: At least 56 people were killed in two bus crashes in northern India last night and about 50 others were believed to be missing, the Press Trust of India reported today.

title: British Party Rejects Merger With Liberals
description: The Social Democrats today rejected until after the next election an outright merger with their Liberal Party partners in a centrist political alliance.

title: Economic E.E.C. Talks
description: Finance ministers from the European Economic Community agreed today to explore new ways to stabilize the world economy but rejected the idea of a major overhaul of the international financial system.

title: Chandler Scores Knockout in 10th
description: Jeff Chandler of Philadelphia knocked down Eijiro Murata of Japan five times en route to a 10th-round knockout as he successfully defended his World Boxing Association bantamweight title today.

title: OPERA: CONNECTICUT GROUP OFFERS A WEEKEND FESTIVAL
description: The Connecticut Grand Opera moved its operations to the State University of New York's Purchase campus Saturday and today. The weekend of opera and opera-related events constitutes the company's first major effort to break clear of its narrow format and limited listenership.

title: TIGERS DOWN BREWERS TO REMAIN 5 1/2 OUT
description: With the Yankees and Milwaukee Brewers slipping fast, the Detroit Tigers now appear to have the best chance of stemming the Baltimore Orioles' drive to the American League East title.

title: Union Officials' Use of Funds Reported Under U.S. Inquiry
description: Federal and internal investigations are being conducted on the use of funds in two United Automoile Workers regions, according to newspaper reports.

title: ALBANY SHOWDOWN DUE ON $1 BILLION BOND ISSUE
description: Legislators will return to Albany this week for a one-day session that will determine the shape and possibly the fate of Governor Cuomo's proposed $1.25 billion bond issue to repair New York's deteriorating roads, bridges, ports and mass-transit systems.

title: Security Bank Sale
description: The Security New York State Corporation is selling four branch offices in Batavia, Attica and Warsaw to ease approval of its planned merger with Norstar Bancorp of Albany, the bank holding company said. The offices overlap with those of Norstar's subsidiary, Liberty National Bank, and might cause regulatory problems if they were not sold, Security said. It is selling its Attica office to the Wyoming County Bank and its Warsaw office to the Bank of Castile.

title: Hot Stove in Summer
description: With pennant races in both National League divisions coming to a boil, with a simmering drive shaping up in the American League East and with the Chicago White Sox cooking with gas in the American League West, this would hardly seem the season for sitting around a hot stove talking baseball.

title: DEBERG RESCUES BRONCOS
description: The quarterback Steve DeBerg, who replaced the ineffective rookie John Elway, scored on a 2-yard run with 29 seconds remaining to give the Denver Broncos a 17-10 victory over the Baltimore Colts today.

title: PHILLIES WIN ON LEZCANO'S HIT
description: Sixto Lezcano said he was happy to leave the San Diego Padres, and yesterday the Philadelphia Phillies were happy that they obtained the outfielder in a six-player trade Sept. 1.

title: WIDOWERS AND THEIR GRIEVING
description: To mental health professionals, the face in the newspaper photographs was the classic portrait of the grieving widower: Eyes lowered, lips tightened, Menachem Begin was leaving a Cabinet meeting after announcing plans to resign as Prime Minister of Israel.

title: Required Reading The Answer: Democracy
description: The only practical long-term basis for progress is along democratic lines. Extremist solutions of the right or left are not going to prove sustainable over time. Traditional structures and social relationships are too shattered to serve as a basis for a lasting return to power of either the traditional right or a new fascism born of civil war. Meanwhile, the far left is inspiring its own rejection, its fate sealed by its own intolerance, by its commitment to armed struggle, by its attacks on the economic infrastructure and means of production and by the strategic blunder of an alliance with Communism, alien to the region and unacceptable to the United States.

title: EXPOS DEFEAT METS BY 4-0
description: Mike Torrez had trouble with doubles today. He gave up four in the fourth inning that brought in three runs and another in the fifth that drove in one run as the Montreal Expos beat the Mets, 4-0, for the third straight time.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Plans Speech To the Canadian Parliament
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher will become the first British head of government in 43 years to address a joint session of the Canadian Parliament when she visits Ottawa later this month, a Government official said Saturday.

title: SERIOUS CRIME DOWN 3% IN '82
description: The number of serious crimes reported in the United States dropped 3 percent in 1982 and the crime rate dropped 4 percent, the sharpest declines in six years, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: RAIN COMES TOO LATE TO SAVE PEANUTS AND SOYBEANS IN SOUTH
description: David Bone, his face filmed with the dust of a peanut field, stood in the shade of a tool shed and squinted grimly out into a sun that has baked the moisture from his soil, seared his hopes, and withered crops that once offered high promise for a fair return on his year's labor.

title: Nassau Girl Killed By Hit-Run Driver
description: A 20-month-old child was killed and her mother critically injured by a hit-and-run driver late Saturday as they crossed Sunrise Highway here, the Nassau County police said.

title: CABARET: 'WILD THYME' AT BALLROOM
description: ''WHERE the Wild Thyme Blows - a Shakespearean Romp,'' conceived and staged by Sandra Kazan with music to Shakespeare's lyrics by Carolyn Sloane, has barely started romping at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, when Juliet appears on her balcony murmuring her customary, ''Wherefore art thou, Romeo?'' Her far-from-customary Romeo is a chubby buffoon who is a blend of Zero Mostel and Oliver Hardy - Jason Brill - and Juliet herself is a man, Richard Ziman.

title: FED POLICY APPEARS STABLE
description: Although bond prices have risen sharply each of the last two Friday afternoons after the Federal Reserve announced unexpected declines in the nation's money supply, analysts are saying that the Fed's monetary policy may not change as swiftly as the credit markets seem to expect.

title: CITY OPERA, THE STRIKE BEHIND IT, WARMS UP FOR SEPT. 21 OPENING
description: One week after ratifying a contract that put an end to its 54-day strike on Aug. 29, the New York City Opera Orchestra returned to work last week at the New York State Theater. It rehearsed two new productions the company will present in its shortened 60-performance season.

title: AT TRICENTENNIAL FETE, STATEN ISLANDERS BROOD
description: Just a little more than 300 years ago, Capt. Christopher Billopp of New York sailed around Staten Island in a brisk 24 hours, winning a contest decreed by the Duke of York and thereby securing the island for his colony against New Jersey's competing claim.

title: FOLK-ROCK: BIG COUNTRY
description: FEW local rock events in the last year have roused higher expectations than the arrival of Big Country, the British folk-rock quartet, at the Ritz on Friday and Saturday. Fronted by the Scottish guitarists and singers Stuart Adamson and Bruce Watson, Big Country combines a raw, punkish energy with a folk traditionalism that borrows the modality, abrupt melodic phrases and dance rhythms of Scottish reels.

title: CITY LOOKS TO AGENCIES FOR HELP IN REDUCING NEGLIGENCE COSTS
description: The Koch administration, alarmed by the large number and the high cost of legal claims against the city, is moving toward a program that would hold agency heads accountable for at least some of the payments caused by their agencies' negligence.

title: A NEW U.S. TRANSCRIPT INDICATES SOVIET PILOT FIRED 'CANNON BURSTS'
description: The State Department today issued a revised transcript of a Soviet pilot's remarks that quotes him as saying he fired ''cannon bursts'' nearly six minutes before launching two missiles that shot down the South Korean airliner with 269 people aboard.

title: SALVADOR KILLERS STEP UP ACTIVITIES
description: The Archbishop of San Salvador joined political leaders today in expressing outrage at the stepped-up activities of a death squad called the Secret Anti-Communist Army.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Activision Inc., Mountain View, Calif., has named Gregory E. Fischbach a senior vice president of the company and president of Activision International Inc.

title: No Headline
description: CURT Warner doesn't want to be publicly compared to O. J. Simpson or any other great backs of professional football. He runs from the issue the same way he ran from the Jets yesterday.

title: OFFERINGS INCLUDE CHRYSLER WARRANTS This week's supply of corporate debt securities totals about $755 million, including three issues of adjustable-rate preferred stock totaling $205 million. There continues to be a paucity of new long-term issues, especially from industrial companies with the flexibility to delay borrowing until rates are lower.
description: Other corporate financings this week include today's auction of 14.4 million warrants to buy an equal number of Chrysler Corporation common shares. The warrants, which will be sold by the Treasury Department to the highest bidder, allow the holder to buy Chrysler shares at $13 each until 1990. Chrysler's stock closed Friday at $29.75 a share.

title: JURY WILL TAKE UP BLACK'S DEATH IN POLICE HANDS
description: A coroner's jury has ruled that the death of a black man in police custody was a felonious homicide, and a grand jury will consider possible charges against four white police officers.

title: SOVIET CONFIDENT FUROR WILL PASS
description: The Soviet Union said today that the American-inspired ''anti-Soviet hysteria'' over the shooting down of a Korean airliner would be short-lived and have no lasting effect on the country's ties abroad.

title: SOVIET VIEWED AS INTENT ON JUSTIFICATION AT HOME
description: The Soviet Union's refusal to accept blame for downing the Korean airliner has not only angered Administration officials but persuaded analysts here that the Kremlin cares more about justifying the actions of its armed forces to its own people and allies than about its credibility and image abroad.

title: JETS BEATEN BY 17-10
description: So many things were different yesterday when the Jets faced the Seattle Seahawks. And yet, almost inevitably, it seemed, the result was the same.

title: PENTAGON GETS TOUGH ON LATIN POLICY
description: The Reagan Administration, despite the objections of some top State Department officials, has decided to go on the attack against Congressional opposition to its Central America policy, according to senior Administration officials.

title: Esteem for Institutions Is Rated in Gallup Poll
description: While memories of Watergate may be fading, the public esteem for the country's leading institutions is no higher than it was 10 years ago and actually fell in some cases, the Gallup Poll reports.

title: 2d Trial Opens Today In Seattle Killings
description: Jury selection begins Monday in the trial of Willie Mak, one of three men charged with shooting 13 people people to cover up a holdup in a gambling club in Chinatown here.

title: LYE MAKES UP 8 SHOTS FOR FIRST VICTORY
description: Mark Lye, a seventh-year pro, rallied from an eight-stroke deficit for his first PGA Tour victory today in the $350,000 Bank of Boston Classic.

title: BUILDING-SAFETY CRACKDOWN IN NEW YORK SHOWS RESULTS
description: Six months after a crackdown began against landlords who violate four recent New York City building-safety laws, more than half the affected buildings have complied with the laws or their owners have filed plans to do so, city officials said yesterday.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WESTERNS ON WEST SIDE

title: INDICTED HAWAII UNION BODY CHIEF DEFIES KIRKLAND'S ORDER ON LEAVE
description: The president of the Hawaii A.F.L.-C.I.O., who is under Federal indictment on perjury charges, has defied an order from national headquarters and refused to take a leave of absence pending the resolution of his case.

title: NONPROFIT AGENCIES ARE TURNING TO FEES TO BALANCE BOOKS
description: Nonprofit groups are turning more to the use of fees, service charges and dues because they face increased demand for their services at a time of declining Federal support, a new study has reported.

title: THWARTED LIVES: TANGLED WEBS WOVEN FOR US
description: Most people are convinced that it happens only to them. They think that somehow they are mined with a strange magnetism that attracts every one of life's small irritations. ''Why me?'' they moan to themselves, as yet another incident occurs that reinforces their belief that they are doomed to high blood pressure.

title: 'UNEQUAL TREATIES' ARE NOT NECESSARILY ILLEGAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief of Hyster Backs Kohlberg Buyout Bid
description: William H. Kilkenny, chairman and chief executive of the Hyster Company of Portland, Ore., was surprised by the recent, unsolicited proposal of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company of New York for a leveraged buyout of his company.

title: No Word on U.S. Steel Shutdowns
description: Officials of the United Steelworkers of America said yesterday that they had no knowledge of plans reportedly being considered by the United States Steel Corporation to shut three plants currently employing more than 3,000 workers.

title: SIGN ON THE DOOR COULD SAY 'VACANCY'
description: For 10 months, International Trade Commissioners Alfred E. Eckes Jr., Paula Stern and Veronica A. Haggart had to be wary of chance meetings or even riding the elevator together. Lunch was out of the question.

title: TELLING A STORY ABOUT FAMILY LORE
description: ''The tradition of family stories is a connection that all of us in this room share,'' said the smiling young woman, ''but not everyone may be aware of it.'' She stood with her father at the front of the small room. Most of the 42 adults in the audience were strangers. They sat on conference chairs at the New York Hilton.

title: MAJOR CORPORATIONS ASK WORKERS TO PAY MORE OF HEALTH COST
description: Some of the nation's largest corporations are asking their employees to pay a bigger portion of their health-care bills than in the past. If adopted nationwide, the practice would mark a reversal of one of the most widespread and generous employee benefits in America.

title: A Serene Michael
description: If circumstances were different, Walt Michaels admitted, he would be an uncontrollable ball of tension. He knows, because last year at this time he was.

title: THE SHADOW OF FLIGHT 7 FELL ON MADRID MEETING
description: The Korean airliner crisis overwhelmed the meeting of foreign ministers here last week, changing it from what had been planned as a show of East-West accord into an acrimonious showdown.

title: A New Era in Medicare
description: The national effort to roll back hospital costs takes an important turn on Oct. 1. After that date, the hospital that treats an aging person's heart or hip no longer may submit a bill to Medicare for all the reasonable charges it can claim. Instead it will be paid a fixed fee and have to absorb any cost overruns.

title: COSMOS ARE FACING A FAMILIAR PITFALL
description: The Cosmos have a history of facing elimination in playoff quarterfinals and advancing nonetheless, but this is the first time they face elimination away from home.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: What constitutes a ringer in horseshoe pitching?

title: MOSCOW BARS 49 BOOKS OF U.S. JEWISH GROUP
description: Organizers of the American Jewish publishers' stand at the fourth Moscow International Book Fair said today that 49 of their titles had been seized by Soviet officials.

title: Shrinking the Globe
