description: In the cool, golden-domed interior of St. Vartan Cathedral on Second Avenue yesterday, a cello played refreshingly. Visitors drifted to and from the blazing-hot courtyard, filled with books and photography about Armenian life, present and past.

title: HOW DEPOSIT SYSTEM WORKS
description: These are some of the rules governing deposits on bottled and canned beverages in New York State:

title: MARGARET MEAD FESTIVAL, A WORLD VIEW OF HOW PEOPLE LIVE
description: Living in a remote valley between two mountain ranges, the isolated highland tribes of New Guinea had no knowledge that an outside world or other kinds of people existed. But in the 1930's their Stone Age culture was intruded upon for the first time with the arrival of Australian prospectors looking for gold. One of the Australians bore a camera and shot footage of the native people running in terror from the first airplane they had ever seen landing in their midst, and cringing at the sound of a record player - they thought the spirits of their dead relatives were locked up inside it, screaming to get out.

title: A GOVERNMENT ATTACK ON POLAND'S WRITERS
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, SEPT. 12, 1983
description: Companies

title: Little World Series Berth to Tidewater
description: A five-hitter by Dwight Gooden helped Tidewater, the Mets' principal farm club, to a 6-1 victory tonight over the Richmond Braves for their second consecutive International League playoff championship and a berth in the Class AAA Little World Series.

title: LEARN TO 'TALK HAWK'
description: If those who oppose United States involvement in Central America are going to present their arguments effectively, they will have to put moralism aside and learn to ''talk hawk.'' Rather than stressing the United States' complicity in the socially bred suffering of the region's poor, they must look unsentimentally at United States interests and calculate the costs of intervention. Otherwise, liberals can be made to look like naive, guilt-ridden do-gooders, incapable of handling the responsibilities of power in a world where American interests abroad are ever more vital and American power to defend them is ever more limited.

title: EX-ARMY SURGEON GENERAL Dr. Leonard D. Heaton, the retired lieutenant general who was Surgeon General of the Army under four Presidents, died of cancer Saturday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. He was 80 years old and a resident of Pinehurst, N.C.
description: As Army Surgeon General, General Heaton commanded one of the world's largest medical services and operated on many world leaders, including Gen. George Marshall, Gen. Douglas McArthur and the President of Nicaragua, Anastasio Somoza, when he was mortally wounded in 1956.

title: SPACE CENTER'S PROBLEM PIGS A TASTE TREAT AT FLORIDA JAIL
description: The wild pigs that have been giving Kennedy Space Center officials headaches are now ending up on the menu at the Brevard County Jail.

title: Clemson's End Run
description: When Clemson was placed on probation last November after the National Collegiate Athletic Association had found it guilty of a long series of recruiting violations, the most severe penalty imposed on the South Carolina school's football program was a two-year ban on television appearances.

title: LITTLE CHANCE SEEN OF CUTS IN DEFICITS
description: With Congress returning to work Monday, the economic outlook is still good. But the chances for shrinking the Government's record budget deficits are fading.

title: The Statue as Bridge
description: Back in town for the first weekend after a summer of Friday getaways, many heat-resistant strollers explored the city anew. Some discovered a curious structure surrounding William Henry Seward's statue in Madison Square Park.

title: FOUR GUNMEN KIDNAP GUATEMALA LEADER'S SISTER
description: The sister of Guatemala's new leader was kidnapped Saturday night by four gunmen, a Government communique said today.

title: CLARKS BALK FILM ON HEART IMPLANT
description: Honoring the request of Dr. Barney Clark's family, the University of Utah is refusing to release films showing the implanting of the first permanent artificial heart.

title: MEXICO CITY'S FLORA FINDING LIFE TOO FOUL TO BEAR
description: Fall has come early to the Paseo de la Reforma, the broad, winding boulevard that Mexicans often refer to fondly as their Champs-Elysees. Leaves are falling. Branches are falling. And in some cases, even trees are falling.

title: Mrs. Reagan's Mother Cited
description: Nancy Reagan accepted an award Saturday for her ailing mother, Edith Davis, for her volunteer work. Mrs. Davis, 87 years old, was honored for helping the Arizona Association for Retarded Citizens.

title: Warden Carrying Rifle Frees Hostage Guards
description: Six inmates briefly took two prison guards hostage today but gave up when confronted by the warden, who was carrying a rifle, the authorities said.

title: PLAN TO IMPROVE SCHOOLS IN MOTION IN MISSISSIPPI
description: Wanda Jean Tarvin's face beamed with excitement this week. For the first time, at the age of 11, she was going to school.

title: More Mexican Oil for Japan
description: Japanese oil officials expect to raise imports of Mexican crude oil to 160,000 barrels a day, the contracted volume under the present long-term deal, from the current 110,000 barrels, according to a spokesman for Japan's Mexican Petroleum Import Company.

title: John A. Chatzky Wed To Lucia T. Chapman
description: Lucia Tully Chapman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert G. Chapman of Denver, was married yesterday to John Andrew Chatzky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Chatzky of Scarsdale, N.Y. Cantor Raymond Smallover and the Rev. Eugene Schneider, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Linde, the brother-in-law and sister of the bridegroom, in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Emily M. Sachar Wed to Jean-Michel Wasterlain
description: Emily Martha Sachar, a business reporter for Newsday, the Long Island newspaper, was married yesterday to Jean-Michel Wasterlain, an associate investment manager with the Prudential Insurance Company's real-estate department in Newark. Rabbi Joseph Rosenbloom performed the ceremony at Whittemore House on the Washington University campus in St. Louis.

title: Ex-Officer of Cigna Joins American Can
description: The American Can Company, signaling its interest in becoming an important factor in the insurance business, has named John R. Cox, a former executive vice president of the Cigna Corporation, executive vice president of the parent company as well as deputy chairman and chief executive officer of its Associated Madison Companies, a rapidly growing financial services group.

title: JAMES WECHSLER, A COLUMNIST AND EX-EDITOR OF POST, DIES
description: James A. Wechsler, a columnist and former editor of The New York Post and a prominent voice of American liberalism for 40 years, died of cancer yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Dummy in Cell Helps Inmate Escape Prison
description: Nevada State Prison officials on Saturday mistakenly released a convict serving a 45-year term, thinking he was another inmate due for release.

title: THE DIFFERING STYLES OF THE HELMSMEN
description: WHEN John Bertrand, the skipper of Australia II, arrived at the docks a couple of minutes too late for a recent scheduled appearance on the ''Today'' show, Dennis Conner, Liberty's skipper, said jokingly, ''Hey, John, I hope you're this late on Tuesday.''

title: NEW YORKERS STAND AND WAIT TO BE FIRST
description: Karol Smith and Jennifer Twiggs, two 19-year-old sophomores at Vassar College, were up early Saturday morning. They dragged themselves to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where they got in the long, long opening-day line for the Manet retrospective.

title: DRUSE MILITIAMEN BATTERING TROOPS OF LEBANESE ARMY
description: Druse militiamen and their allies battered the Lebanese Army at the key strategic town of Suk al Gharb on Saturday night and early today, Lebanese and Western military sources said.

title: Kaunda Arrives in Bonn
description: President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia arrived in West Germany this evening for a five-day visit during which he is expected to discuss the future of South- West Africa.

title: U.S. Forces Start Trip Home After Joint Exercises in Egypt
description: The last of 5,500 American troops who have been taking part in military maneuvers with Egyptian forces headed for the port of Alexandria today on the way back to the United States.

title: TV: 'WALLS OF FIRE,' MEXICAN ARTISTS
description: REACHING back a decade or so, Channel 13 has found ''Walls of Fire,' a 90-minute documentary about the three Mexican artists of this century who came to be known as ''los tres grandes,'' the three great ones. The film, which had been nominated for an Academy Award, can be seen tonight at 10 o'clock.

title: Irish President Is in Japan
description: President Patrick J. Hillery of Ireland arrived in Japan today for a weeklong state visit. Dr. Hillery, accompanied by his wife and a small official party, arrived on a flight from Singapore.

title: NATIONAL PARK TOURISTS TANGLE WITH ANIMALS
description: This park's geysers, mountains, rivers and thousands of wild animals attract 2.5 million tourists annually. Its rules say one may look at the animals from a distance and never touch them.

title: GIANTS WIN IN OVERTIME
description: The Giants, who played so poorly in their opener last week, played inspired football today. When Scott Brunner's only intercepted pass of the day helped the Falcons tie the score with little more than 3 minutes remaining, the Giants went on to win in overtime, 16-13.

title: Yellowman Postponement
description: The concert at the Ritz by the Jamaica reggae singer Yellowman, which was scheduled for last Thursday, has been postponed until Sept. 21.

title: Business Week Has a New Campaign
description: ''Of course I'm sure, I read it in Business Week,'' is the theme of a new advertising campaign on which McGraw-Hill Publications will spend $2 million during the rest of 1983. The publisher says it is the most concentrated advertising effort in the corporation's history.

title: DODGERS SET BACK BRAVES IN 9TH, 7-6
description: Mike Marshall's two-run double tied the score, and the rookie R.J. Reynolds squeezed home Pedro Guerrero in a four-run ninth inning today, rallying the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 7-6 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

title: HANGING ON IN EL SALVADOR
description: It is barely 8 o'clock in the morning, and Phillip Hand, a tall, bearded man with an eye for bugs and worms, has already spent an hour striding along the deep furrows.

title: ; IS MOSCOW IMPORTING LIFELINE OR NOOSE?
description: To the Editor:

title: Devaluation by Zaire
description: Zaire has devalued its currency by almost 80 percent against the dollar in line with International Monetary Fund recommendations for reviving its economy.

title: No Headline
description: The U.N. Today Sept. 12, 1983 SECURITY COUNCIL

title: TRYING TO DETERMINE IF RATES ARE TOO HIGH
description: Economic Analysis

title: Begin, Ill, Is Absent From Cabinet Session
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said he felt ill today and stayed away from a regular Cabinet session, a Government spokesman announced.

title: NEW YORK AND OTHER STATES DEFY U.S. RULES FOR DISABILITY BENEFITS
description: New York and other states, eager to help people retain Social Security disability benefits, have begun to flout Federal rules for the program, and so far the Reagan Administration has taken no action to penalize them.

title: Buyer of G.& W. Unit Is Construction Expert
description: Merrill L. Nash, who last week bought the building products group from Gulf & Western Industries for $65 million, is acquiring a business in which he has spent most of his professional career.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SETTING EUROPE ABLAZE. By Douglas Dodds-Parker. 219 pages. Springwood. $12.

title: 4 Senators See Reagan At Mideast Crossroads
description: Four senators said today that President Reagan's Middle East policy had reached a crossroads, but expressed doubt Congress would order United States Marines out of Lebanon.

title: CALL YOUR OMBUDSMAN
description: To the Editor:

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA EAGER TO ACHIEVE ADDITIONAL GOALS
description: ''ANYBODY got any money?'' the young woman asked. Everyone in the group searched pockets. ''Why?'' one said. ''What do you want?''

title: Rebels Said to Launch Attack in Lesotho
description: Rebels of the Lesotho Liberation Army, helped by about 500 South African soldiers, launched an eight-hour attack on Lesotho today, the Government said.

title: FOR HOLMES, JUST ANOTHER MISMATCH
description: There have been so many opponents that there is bound to be some duplication. That is why boxing fans who watched Larry Holmes defend his World Boxing Council heavyweight championship against Scott Frank on Saturday night might have gotten a feeling they had seen this fight before. Frank, who had been portrayed as the latest Rocky Balboa, looked a lot more like another Scott LeDoux.

title: 3 SENATORS PROPOSE 2-STEP PLAN FOR CUT IN NUCLEAR WEAPONS
description: A two-step reduction in nuclear weapons by the Soviet Union and the United States was urged today by three senators involved in arms control policy.

title: Loretta Preska Weds a Fellow Lawyer
description: Loretta A. Preska, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor R. Preska of Delmar, N.Y., was married yesterday to Thomas J. Kavaler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph O. Kavaler of New York. Justice Ernst H. Rosenberger of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Water Club in New York.

title: HARD FIGHT EXPECTED ON I.M.F.
description: New infighting over money for housing, loans to Communist countries and who is responsible for the world debt problems has complicated the Administration's task of winning approval in Congress for $8.4 billion for the International Monetary Fund.

title: ECONOMIC FACTORS ENGULF SEABROOK
description: Since early 1972, when the Public Service Company of New Hampshire asked for approval to build a nuclear power plant at Seabrook, the proposal has been the source of a bitter upheaval in this tiny state.

title: Fete in Black and White
description: Men in dinner jackets ogled the penguins - ''for whom black tie was not optional,'' one guest observed - at the New York Aquarium in Coney Island on Friday night. As whales, walruses and dolphins frolicked, the Brooklyn Arts and Culture Association honored seven outstanding women.

title: STUDYING CANADA'S ECONOMY
description: A high-level inquiry into Canada's economic problems that opened here last week heard charges that the federal Government is sacrificing workers to win its battle against inflation.

title: A 99o READING FAILS TO DAUNT CENTRAL HIGH ATHLETES
description: As the temperature climbed to a high of 99 yesterday, James Rollins of Brooklyn was playing a hard and fast game of paddleball on a court shimmering in the heat in Central Park.

title: 3 DIVERS LOST AT SHIPWRECK SITES
description: A 43-year-old scuba diver from Manhattan was missing and presumed dead yesterday after he entered the wreck of a heavy cruiser sunk off the western tip of Fire Island during World War I by a German submarine, a Coast Guard spokesman said.

title: JIMMY'S PEOPLE
description: FROM the moment he appeared on center court yesterday, Jimmy Connors had the crowd in the palm of his racquet. In the evolution of the United States Open tennis championships, Jimmy Connors has emerged as the people's choice, the street corner smart guy who somehow symbolizes to New York City what this tournament has come to mean. From the courtside box seats to the top row of the National Tennis Center, the people applauded politely for Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia, perhaps out of sympathy for his haunting, hollow eyes. But they cheered and cherished the American terrier's fifth Open singles title.

title: HAPPY DRUSE SAVOR VICTORY AMID RUBBLE
description: In this part of the Shuf Mountains, the Druse are in control and they speak the language of victory.

title: Godard 'Carmen' Wins Top Award at Venice
description: Jean-Luc Godard's ''Prenom: Carmen'' won the Golden Lion for best movie today at the Venice Film Festival.

title: THE REAGAN SILENCE
description: From the moment it took office the Reagan Administration has carried on a determined campaign to deny the public information about the workings of government. The White House and the Justice Department have acted through a series of executive decisions, without getting authority from Congress for the new suppression.

title: Making Amends on 57th St.
description: Carnegie Hall is going to announce a plan, perhaps today, to ''show our appreciation'' to nearly a thousand people who were turned away from a free concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday afternoon.

title: Marc Rich Talks Go On
description: The jurisdictional dispute involving Marc Rich & Company A.G. has yet to be resolved following talks here last week, according to officials.

title: Puerto Rico Yield at 7 3/4%
description: An $80 million adjustable rate bond issue of the Puerto Rico Industrial Medical and Environmental Pollution Control Facilities Financing Authority was priced yesterday by L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin with an initial five-year yield of 7 3/4 percent at par.

title: Denunciation of Soviet Is Blocked by Greece
description: The 10 members of the European Economic Community expressed regret today over the downing of a South Korean airliner, but because of Greek objections they refrained from jointly condemning Moscow over the incident.

title: THE HABIT OF WAR
description: The headlines these days are either about people declaring, demonstrating, or even running riotous for peace, or about wars. Wars offer the greatest variety, in practically every shape, size and color.

title: JACKSON TOURS AREA OF LONDON RIOT
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, the American civil rights leader, paid a one-day visit to London today, following the traditional trail of White House aspirants on a ''fact-finding'' pilgrimage to Europe.

title: SAFETY GROUP WANTS UPSTATE NUCLEAR PLANT CLOSED
description: The Union of Concerned Scientists, a nonprofit advocacy group for nuclear safety, petitioned the Nuclear Regulatory Commission yesterday to immediately shut the James A. FitzPatrick nuclear plant in upstate New York for what it called ''a grave safety hazard.''

title: Weather May Help Liberty in Opener
description: As the late afternoon clouds darkened the horizon, almost everyone had left the dock area here, everyone except the crews of Australia II and Liberty. They continued to work on their boats with a quiet determination to make them as close to perfect as possible for their meeting Tuesday in the opening race of the 25th America's Cup defense.

title: Taiwan Production Up
description: Taiwan's industrial production index rose 23.8 percent in August compared with August 1982 and 1.9 percent compared with July, preliminary Government figures showed today. An official attributed the increase to rising production last month of integrated circuits, digital watches and clocks, and motorcycles.

title: U.S. REVEALS OUSTER OF 2 SOVIET ATTACHES WITHIN LAST MONTH
description: The State Department disclosed today that it expelled two Soviet diplomats from this country last month, charging them with espionage.

title: LANGUAGES IN EARLY STAGES
description: WHEN the opening bell rang at the 55th Street School in Milwaukee one day last week, Linda Martinez greeted her kindergarten class with the words, ''Como esta usted?''

title: Odessa, Tex., Tops List Of '82 Homicide Rates
description: Odessa, Tex., is the nation's most dangerous metropolitan area for homicides and Alaska the most dangerous state, the National Coalition to Ban Handguns reports.

title: 1,200 Italian Prisoners Declare Hunger Strike
description: More than 1,200 prisoners in four Italian jails went on a hunger strike today to demand penal reforms, especially a reduction in pretrial detention, according to the prisoners.

title: FOODARAMA SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
TO ENABLE INDIVIDUALS TO SUE NATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Cement Import Study
description: Cement from Australia and Japan is being sold in the United States for substantially less than fair market value, the Government said today.

title: The U.N. Today, Sept. 13, 1983
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: REAGAN UPGRADING LEBANON PRESENCE
description: President Reagan has authorized ''aggressive self-defense'' tactics to protect the Marines in Lebanon and is consulting with Congress on a resolution to approve a continuing American military presence there, Administration officials said today.

title: Chess: Karpov Wins by a Half Point
description: In the Hanover Tournament Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, the world champion, defeated his compatriot, the grandmaster Tamas Georgadze, in the 14th round to forge a half-point margin of victory over Georgadze in the Hanover International Tournament in West Germany.

title: DISPOSAL COST AND HAZARDS OF NUCLEAR WASTE
description: To the Editor:

title: GADGETRY IN N.F.L. COVERAGE
description: As surely as autumn brings a new

title: Lavelle Trial Is Set for Nov. 16
description: Despite arguments by Rita M. Lavelle's defense lawyers that their client was the victim of ''abuse and manipulation'' of the grand jury system, a Federal district judge today set Nov. 16 as trial date for Miss Lavelle, a former Environmental Protection Agency official.

title:
CREDIT MARKETS;
BOND PRICES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Bond prices fell sharply yesterday as a jittery market shifted its focus from a lack of follow-through buying support to profit taking and reports of a revision in money supply figures, thwarting the rally attempt that began late Friday.

title: Cannon Begins 5-Year Sentence
description: Billy Cannon, the former college and professional football star, began serving a five-year counterfeiting sentence at a minimum-security Federal prison here today.

title: Lebanon Asks U.N. Council To End a Decade of Violence
description: Lebanon's chief delegate to the United Nations appealed today to the Security Council to put an end to the ''violence, bloodshed, murder and destruction'' that he said had plagued his country for the last decade.

title: South Africa Denies Fighting With Lesotho
description: South Africa today denied that its soldiers had taken part in fighting Sunday on the border with Lesotho.

title: CONCERT: 'FIRST GAY CHORAL FESTIVAL'
description: A few months ago, a concert given by the New York City Gay Men's Chorus seemed to this reviewer to share many of the qualities of an ethnic music concert; it was a celebration of community achievements, tastes and crises. But that was a purely local event. The concert on Sunday night in Avery Fisher Hall - which brought together homosexual choruses from Chicago, Denver, Los Angeles, Seattle, Washington, Madison, Wis., Anaheim, Calif., New Orleans and New York - was an event that was at once political, ethnic, sexual and cultural.

title: GEOTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ATLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income after a charge of $132,000 related to a tax credit. c-Including a tax credit of $3.4 million. d-Including a tax credit of $1,940,000.

title: FLIGHT 7'S FINAL MOMENTS: DID IT SURVIVE 12 MINUTES?
description: A Japanese news agency quoted unidentified military officials Monday as having said that the South Korean airliner struck by a Soviet missile had fallen in ''vast spirals'' until it reached 2,000 feet and then plunged vertically into the water 12 minutes after the attack.

title: KASLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
No Headline
description: Mets Call Up Hurdle PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 12 - Clint Hurdle, an experienced utility man who played for Kansas City and Cincinnati, was acquired by the Mets today as the club sought to shore up the middle of its infield. The Mets purchased the contract of Hurdle, 26 years old, from Tidewater, its Class AAA farm club that recently won the International League championship.

title: LOCKHEED SETTLES A SEX-BIAS SUIT
description: The Lockheed California Company settled a sex discrimination lawsuit today by agreeing to hire or promote at least 2,600 women into middle-

title: Waiting for M*A*S*H
description: It's enough to drive Hawkeye into his tent for a moonshine martini.

title: UAL Sees Lower Net
description: UAL Inc., the parent company of United Airlines, said yesterday that it expects its third-quarter net income to be ''substantially less'' than for the similar period a year ago, even though it will have higher consolidated earnings from its operations. UAL earned $102.4 million, or $3.45 a share, in the third quarter a year ago, which included an extraordinary gain of $36.6 million resulting from the purchase of United Airlines notes at a discount.

title: NUGGET OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: ON TRAIL OF CANCER: DISCOVERIES REACH A CRESCENDO
description: SCIENTISTS who study biology at its most basic level are in the midst of a crescendo of new discoveries that seem to be unraveling of the mystery of the cancer process.

title: CONGRESS BEGINS PARRYING OVER DOMESTIC ISSUES ON RETURN TO WORK
description: Congress returned to work today after a five- week holiday and displayed a strong bipartisan approach on several urgent foreign policy matters. But the lawmakers plunged immediately into political disagreements over such sensitive domestic issues as higher taxes and spending for social programs.

title: CRIME RE-ENACTMENTS ON TV NEWS ARE ON RISE
description: As an increasingly popular addition to local news programs, a growing number of television stations in the United States are re-enacting unsolved crimes on the air and offering rewards to anonymous viewers who supply information that helps the police make arrests.

title: SHARK SEEN AS EVOLUTION CLUE
description: A sluggish shark with a four-foot- wide mouth, rubbery lips and tiny, nonmenacing teeth is an important clue in understanding evolution, say some of the country's leading experts on sharks.

title: 50 Die in Andes Bus Plunge
description: Fifty people were killed when a bus plunged down a ravine in the Andes Mountains 85 miles south of here today, radio reports indicated.

title: 3d Conspiracy Trial Open For 6 Carolina Nazis
description: Six American Nazis charged with conspiring to bomb Greensboro, N.C., buildings three years ago went on trial a third time today. Prosecutors pledged to keep trying ''until we get it right.''

title: GENERAL CINEMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including income of $40 million, or $2.14 a share, from the sale of Miami television station. c-Including nonrecurring income of $4.4 million, or 24 cents a share, from the sale of a radio station and gains on the conversion of exchangable debentures.

title: HMW Industries Agrees to Merger
description: HMW Industries of Stamford, Conn., which had been fighting a tender offer by the Clabir Corporation of Greenwich, Conn., said it had agreed to be acquired by a company to be organized by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, specialists in leveraged buyouts.

title: GELCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest periods reflect a provision of $10.9 million for disposal of Mexican vehicle leasing operations and a charge of $1.8 million for the early retirement of debt. Results reflect a charge of $11.3 million for the latest year and a gain of $2.9 million for the previous year from foreign currency translations.

title: Money Supply Rumor Denied
description: A rumor that there were significant errors in Friday's money supply figures swept the financial markets yesterday. By the time the Federal Reserve Board denied the rumor - which reportedly started in the Chicago metal pits and spread to both coasts within minutes - it had depressed the stock, bond and commodity markets.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report Friday in the Briefing column of the Washington Talk page gave incorrect information on obtaining the Almanac of American Politics, 1984 edition. It is available (by mail or in person) only at the Washington office of The National Journal, 1730 M Street N.W., Washington, D.C. 20036. The price is $35 for hardcover, $22.50 for paperback.

title: HOW VIOLENCE NURTURES SEPARATISM IN SRI LANKA
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 SENATORS: MORE THAN A CONTRAST IN STYLES
description: From the time Congress recessed last month until its return yesterday, New York's two Senators had remained hard at work, each in his own fashion.

title: MOSCOW SAYS PILOT TRANSCRIPT REVISION PROVES U.S. IS LYING
description: A Soviet news commentator said today that a revised transcript of exchanges between Soviet fighter pilots and their ground control ''totally shattered'' American allegations that the fighters gave no warning to a Korean Air Lines jetliner before shooting it down.

title: MERCHANDISE MART GETS THIRD CHIEF IN 38 YEARS
description: Philip E. Kelley has been named president and chief executive officer of Chicago's Merchandise Mart, one of the world's largest buildings, where wholesalers show their wares.

title: Advertising; Theatrical, General Ad Union
description: BEFORE a month is out the five principals involved in Ash/Le- Donne and Fisher/Feld should have signed the necessary papers to create Ash-LeDonne-Fisher, an ad agency with almost $50 million in billings that will combine the skills of a theatrical promotion and general advertising.

title: TEXT OF COUNCIL RESOLUTION ON DOWNING OF THE AIRLINER
description: Following is the text of the Security Council resolution on the downing of a South Korean airliner that was vetoed today by the Soviet Union:

title: ANTELOPES' HORNS REFLECT SEX ROLES
description: ALE buffaloes, elands, oryxes, gnus and gazelles use their horns on the African plains in butting or pushing matches against competitors of the same sex to establish superiority or to gain the courting rights to an attractive female. But the thinner, more graceful horns of the female animals have a more specialized function and are used mainly as a stabbing weapon to repel or injure predators, a study has revealed.

title: U.S. Aide Gets Pepsico Post
description: Max L. Friedersdorf, the 54-year-old United States Consul General in Bermuda, has been named vice president for public affairs of Pepsico Inc., effective Monday. He will deal with government relations and corporate public relations.

title: ACAPULCO Y LOS ARCOS RESTAURANTES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
'IF SOMETHING HAPPENS'
description: Even though the Baltimore Orioles have torn September off the Yankees' calendar, George Steinbrenner and Billy Martin re-exchanged their wedding vows yesterday, but the principal owner seemed to have his fingers crossed behind his back.

title: U.S. Aid Urged for Teachers
description: Albert Shanker, president of the American Federation of Teachers, proposed today that the Federal Government offer full college scholarships to top- caliber students who agree to spend five years as classroom teachers.

title: REAGAN NAMES HISPANIC WOMAN AS TREASURER OF THE UNITED STATES
description: President Reagan today nominated Katherine D. Ortega as Treasurer of the United States.

title: A Computer Line
description: Computer Designed Systems Inc. said it had introduced a line of computers as part of its ''adviser'' group of interactive computer systems.

title: MUSIC: NORTH INDIAN RAGAS
description: THE ragas sung by Sheila Dhar in the Uris Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum Sunday afternoon were refined rather than florid. Their form was known as North Indian Khayal - a word, the program noted, that means ''imagination, fancy'' in Persian; the tradition evolved out of the Indian courts of the 16th century.

title: Gallic Galas
description: A series of events with a French touch, not necessarily related, recalls last spring, when the British were coming. But there are Gallic quirks.

title: MOSCOW VETOES U.N. CRITICISM IN PLANE AFFAIR
description: The Soviet Union today vetoed a resolution by the Security Council that deplored the Russians' destruction of a South Korean airliner on Sept. 1.

title: Tigers 5, Indians 1
description: Rick Leach's two-run single keyed a three-run Detroit fourth inning.

title: 16 SINATRA ALBUMS DUE OUT AS SET
description: From 1953 to 1962, Frank Sinatra made two or three albums a year for Capitol Records, many of which have become classics. Most are still available in one form or another, but next month a definitive edition of 16 of them will be released in a boxed set that will retail for $350.

title: NEWPORT PHARMACEUTICALS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: A Nominee for F.T.C.
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate Terry Calvani, 36, a Vanderbilt University law professor, to a seven-year term on the Federal Trade Commission, replacing David Clanton, a Republican.

title: BANNER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $120,000 for the quarter and $2,850,000 for the year and a loss of $301,552 for the year from discontinued operations. c-Net loss including a tax credit of $320,000 and a loss of $636,535 from discontinued operations. d-Net income after a loss of $724,352 from discontinued operations.

title: BANK WAR LOOMS ON C.D.'S
description: Almost three weeks before the final major step in the deregulation of interest rates, competition for consumer deposits is heating up. Already, Citibank and the Dollar-Dry Dock Savings Bank are running newspaper advertisements seeking to lure deposits into accounts that will become available Oct. 1, and other banks are likely to be drawn into the fray.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TERCENTENARY

title: 2 Picasso Oils, on Loan, Stolen at Texas Museum
description: Thieves using a cinder block smashed a glass door at the Art Museum of South Texas early today and took two paintings by Picasso valued at nearly $1 million, the police said.

title: American Medical
description: The founder of American Medical Buildings Inc., ousted two weeks ago from his positions as president, chairman and chief executive officer, has sued to allow shareholders to elect a new board of directors. Joseph W. Checota, who was replaced by Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., a retired Navy admiral, said his slate of directors would include former Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. The suit, filed in Milwaukee County Circuit Court, asks for a special meeting of the board to be called for Oct. 18.

title: ASTRO-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The company was spun off from Atlan-Tol Industries on May 1.

title: VIDEOTAPES OF SLAYING SMUGGLED INTO MANILA
description: A customs examiner at Manila International Airport, going through the baggage of a Filipino arriving from Tokyo, ignored a videotape cassette labeled ''Playboy Lovers,'' as the passenger had expected he would.

title: COMPETITION KEEN AS RANGER DRILLS OPEN
description: The locker room stereo had been blaring rock-and-roll for only a few hours, and the sweat provoked by the first day of Herb Brooks's strenuous drills was still dripping when the theme of this year's Ranger training camp became clear.

title: Canadian Journalist Is Killed in Lebanon
description: Clark Todd, the London bureau chief for CTV Television Network in Canada, has died of wounds received during fighting in Lebanon, the network announced today.

title: BRIEFS
description: American Telephone and Telegraph Co. announced that four of its digital transmission services would be marketed as Accunet Digital Services.

title: EXPERTS PLAN TO ADDRESS ILLS OF BLACK FAMILY
description: Black leaders and others are to meet next year to fashion a comprehensive program addressing the problems of black American families, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced yesterday.

title: Two Join Antarctic Pact
description: Brazil and India were admitted as members of the Antarctic Treaty today and will join the 14 other member countries on Tuesday for two weeks of talks on the future of the continent. A special meeting of the treaty consultative group accepted the two countries, which have both sent scientific expeditions to the continent and intend to set up research stations, its chairman, John Rowland, said here.

title: VIETNAM BOAT PEOPLE AIDED BY 7TH FLEET
description: To the Editor:

title: McGovern Due to Announce
description: Former Senator George S. McGovern, starting months behind his rivals among Democrats and turning aside the advice of many associates, plans to announce Tuesday that he will run again for the Democratic Presidential nomination, his daughter said. He won the nomination in 1972, only to be swamped by Richard M. Nixon.

title: Generals Reported Sold for $9 Million
description: A Manhattan trial attorney said yesterday that he and three other investors had reached an agreement with Chuck Fairbanks, the team president representing the majority owner, J. Walter Duncan, to buy the New Jersey Generals of the United States Football League. Fairbanks, however, denied that the sale had been concluded.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: HERE it is the first week that everyone is back from wherever they said they had gone, and already everyone wants to know the shape of fall to come.

title: PALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
ST. LOUIS UNION ENDS 1983'S BIGGEST SCHOOL STRIKE
description: The nation's biggest school strike of the year ended today hours after the school board began hiring replacements for the striking teachers and as both sides agreed to resume talks and the teachers said they would return to work.

title: Adirondack Camps vs. Trees
description: To wealthy New York families in an earlier era, ''camp'' in the Adirondacks meant something special: a self-contained private village that combined a wilderness experience with unparalleled luxury. An excellent specimen, Camp Sagamore, is now the focus of an unusual controversy between two groups of conservationists.

title: Afghan Guerrillas Take Bazaar Areas in 3 Towns
description: Moslem guerrillas opposed to the Soviet-backed Government in Kabul have moved into three towns in eastern Afghanistan in a drive to take control of the area, guerrilla sources said today.

title: Harmon, Forte Put on Probation
description: Two former National Football League running backs, Clarence Harmon and Ike Forte, pleaded guilty today to charges of possession of cocaine were sentenced to 10 years probation by State Judge Guy Jones.

title: SOVIET CIRCUS TO LEAVE CANADA
description: Canada announced tonight that it would allow Aeroflot planes to pick up the stranded Moscow Circus in Halifax despite a 60- day Canadian ban against the Soviet airline.

title: Judge in Ohio Rape Trial Bars A.P. Photographers
description: Photographers for The Associated Press were barred today from the trial of Dr. Edward Franklin Jackson Jr. on charges of rape and burglary.

title: WITNESS CALLS BRINK'S KILLINGS JUSTIFIED
description: The only defense witness called in the Brink's murder and robbery trial testified today that members of the Black Liberation Army had staged the $1.6 million robbery and were justified in killing two policemen and a Brink's guard.

title: Howard Dietz Tribute Planned for Thursday
description: A musical tribute to the late lyricist Howard Dietz will be held Thursday at noon at the Imperial Theater, 249 West 45th Street.

title: JACOBSON STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Eastern Cutbacks
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. announced that it would cut about 575 positions in its sales and services division as part of a continuing program to reduce expenses. Many of the slots are already vacant and some of the affected workers would move into other open positions, the company said.

title: Talking Business with James Akins, oil consultant; Nervousness Over Mideast
description: In the six months since OPEC decided to lower its oil prices and limit output, the international market has stabilized. But many American oil executives have become increasingly worried about political tensions in the Middle East.

title: 64 KILLED IN BLAST AT SOUTH AFRICAN COAL MINE
description: A methane gas explosion at a coal mine in Natal Province killed 64 miners and seriously injured 4 others today.

title: NORA LOFTS, 79, AUTHOR OF HISTORICAL NOVELS
description: Nora Lofts, a prolific British writer whose historical novels and biographies were published in the United States at the rate of one a year for the last 40 years, died in her sleep Saturday at her home in Bury St. Edmunds, England. She was 79 years old and continued writing almost to the end of her life.

title: STATE INQUIRY FAULTS M.T.A. ON $2 MILLION IN LEGAL FEES
description: A New York State inquiry into outside legal fees paid by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has led to criticism of the agency for failure to require a detailed accounting of the billings.

title: DAIRY MART CONVENIENCE STORES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FOLK-ROCK: LOVE-TRACTOR
description: A ROCK instrumental often risks sounding like a song awaiting words. Yet when Love Tractor, a quartet from Athens, Ga., played a set of instrumentals and a few songs with lyrics Saturday at Danceteria, the instrumentals were convincingly complete.

title: Kohl to Tour Middle East
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl will make official visits next month to Jordan, Egypt and Saudi Arabia, the Government announced today.

title: CHART HOUSE TO BUY GOFFATHER'S PIZZA
description: Chart House Inc., the largest franchisee of Burger King restaurants, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Godfather's Pizza Inc. in an exchange of stock valued at about $306 million.

title: Starting Lineup
description: People close to major league baseball often emphasize that popular statistics, such as batting average, should not always serve as the major factor in assessing the worth of a given player. Fair enough.

title: OPERA: 'MACBETH' FROM CONNECTICUT
description: ''MACBETH'' - that raw and obdurate product of Verdi's early operatic years - has been attracting the attention of music's biggest guns recently. Peter Hall's star-crossed production had a shaky run at the Metropolitan Opera last season, and on Oct. 11, Riccardo Muti and the Philadelphia Orchestra come to Carnegie Hall with a concert version of their own.

title: CHINA SUDDENLY TAKING A TOUGHER LINE ON CRIME
description: Many common criminals have been executed in cities across China recently, and thousands of ''hooligans'' have been arrested, according to several reports reaching Peking.

title: No Headline
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about New York State's new law requiring deposits on beverage containers gave an incorrect telephone number for inquiries. The number, starting tomorrow, will be 267-9800.

title: No Headline
description: HUGGING THE SHORE. Essays and Criticism. By John Updike. 919 pages. $19.95. IN one of the essays in this sumptuous collection, John Updike speaks of Nabokov's ''ebullient creativity,'' his ''resplendent oeuvre.'' The same terms might easily be applied to Mr. Updike's own astonishing body of work. At 51, he has emerged not only as one of our finest novelists, but also as this country's one all-around man of letters. Few writers in America choose to enter the literary decathlon - preferring, for the most part, to specialize in one form, one distance, or another - but Mr. Updike has demonstrated, over the years, his ability to move from the short story to the novel, from light verse to nonfiction with fluency and grace.

title: IN CONGRESS, BITTER WORDS AND DEMAND FOR SANCTIONS
description: Senate Democratic and Republican leaders jointly introduced a resolution today ''condemning the brutal behavior'' of the Soviet Union in destroying Korean Air Lines Flight 7, but many liberals and conservatives in both houses pressed for action stronger than words.

title: BENJAMIN BARTEL, LAWYER, DIES AT 67
description: Benjamin Bartel, a lawyer who was former chairman of the board of Alexander's Inc., the department store chain, died of a heart attack early Sunday at New York Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Helmets for All
description: For years their faces have been easily recognizable to hockey fans, but now Guy Lafleur, Bob Gainey and Larry Robinson of the Montreal Canadiens will look more like everyone else on the ice.

title: HACKING THE ENGLISH LANGUAGE TO BITS AN BYTE
description: NOT even the estimable George Orwell foresaw that by the year before 1984 men would modify their language to accommodate machines. Perhaps, as some critics have said, Orwell foresaw nothing, but just reversed the last two digits of 1948 to label his polemic against the world as it then was. Whatever the case, there is nothing in ''1984'' that anticipates the dialect of Newspeak known as computerese.

title: HELDOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $347,000 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: POPE GREETS POLES LIVING IN AUSTRIA
description: Pope John Paul II met tonight in the Baroque square in front of the Charles Borromeus Church with thousands of Poles now living in Austria.

title: PRAB ROBOTS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NEW YORK BANKS ARE ASKED FOR AID TO RIOT-TORN MIAMI
description: Major New York City banks, eager to expand their business activities in Florida, were challenged yesterday by that state's Governor to help finance the economic redevelopment of the riot-devastated Liberty City area in Miami.

title: TRAVEL NOTES: WEINBERGER TALKS TO THE TROOPS...
description: Most Cabinet members dress as impeccably on the road as at home, if not more so. Pinstripe suits, silk ties and glossy wingtips are de rigueur.

title: TRADING HEAVY
description: Stock prices fell yesterday in heavy trading after an explosive early rally based on hopes of lower interest rates evaporated. Traders cited rumors, later denied, about errors in Friday's money supply figures, as well as underlying caution.

title: Abu Dhabi Loan Deal
description: The Abu Dhabi Gas Liquefaction Company and 37 international banks have signed a $500 million loan agreement to finance additional liquefied natural gas and petroleum gas storage facilities in Abu Dhabi, the National Bank of Abu Dhabi said today. Interest on the loan will be five-tenths of a percentage point above the London interbank offered rate for the first four years and 0.625 percentage point above that rate for the remaining years.

title: A LIMPING WARNER AMEX
description: When Hurricane Alicia ripped through Houston last month, it knocked out service of the city's new cable television system for a week. That was just one of a series of devastations to the Warner Amex system and, in its customers' view, the most forgivable; the other disasters have all been man-made. ''If I were God,'' said Drew Lewis, chairman and chief executive officer of Warner Amex Cable Communications, in an interview last week, ''I wouldn't have any problems.''

title: CORRESPONDENCE SCHOOL VIA COMPUTER IS PLANNED
description: The correspondence school took a tentative step into the computer age today as a one-year-old San Francisco company announced plans to create an electronic university.

title: NEW YORK CITY'S SCHOOLS OPENING WITH MORE FUNDS AND NEW HOPE
description: The new public-school year begins today in New York City, with more money to spend, expectations of more children to spend it on and a new Schools Chancellor committed to new ideas.

title: VISUAL CUES COMPENSATE FOR BLINDNESS IN ONE EYE
description: NEVER mind the athletic ability it takes to catch a pass in professional football. Consider instead just the perceptual-motor task involved. Each time a receiver makes a play, he must judge where the ball will land while both he and the ball are in motion, and he must continue to monitor his position and the changing location of the ball as the two converge on the same spot on the field.

title: PAYLESS CASHWAYS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
BORMAN'S INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Aug 13
description: b-Net income including extraordinary credits of $550,000 for the quarter and $850,000 for the 6 months.

title: Robbery Is Foiled At Grand Central
description: A man with a hatchet held up the Bowery Savings Bank branch in Grand Central Terminal at 8:35 A.M. yesterday and escaped through throngs of rush-hour commuters but dropped most of the money he had got.

title: HORIZON CORP reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Net income.

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CHARGERS DOWN CHIEFS
description: Dan Fouts drove the Chargers 80 yards in five plays tonight, passing 12 yards to Wes Chandler for the game- winning touchdown with 1 minute 45 seconds to play to beat the Kansas City Chiefs, 17-14.

title: Price They Pay: 19 Fines at Open
description: Jimmy Connors earned $120,000 for winning his fifth United States Open singles title Sunday. But $1,000 will be deducted from his check for one verbal obscenity and one visible obscenity during his four-set victory over Ivan Lendl in the final.

title: COMGEN TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are presented on an actual and not a pro forma basis.

title: LCS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid June 1.

title: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 1983
description: Companies

title: CHOICE FOR TREASURER
description: When Katherine D. Ortega learned last week that President Reagan would nominate her as Treasurer of the United States, her first act was to call her family in New Mexico.

title: YANKEES SET BACK FALTERING BREWERS
description: If the Yankees are disappointed at their forlorn position in what not long ago was the American League East race, consider the plight of the Milwaukee Brewers. In first place as recently as Aug. 25, the defending champion Brewers suffered another loss last night and now are eight games behind Baltimore.

title: Client Wants Lawyer Even If He Is a Witness
description: Mary P. Evans testified today that she wanted Robert Ritchie, a lawyer, to defend her on charges of helping a prisoner escape, although he could be called as a prosecution witness.

title: Upstate V
description: A 7-year-old boy from Camillus who died Sept. 2 was a victim of Eastern equine encephalitis, Onondaga County officials said today.

title: CHRYSLER TOP BIDS TO BUY BACK STOCK RIGHTS
description: The Federal Government yesterday reaped its reward for helping to bail out the Chrysler Corporation.

title: Geothermal Plant Planned by Dravo
description: The Dravo Corporation announced that it would begin work this fall on the nation's first commercial geothermal hot water power plant, which will use natural hot brine to produce enough electricity for 45,000 California residents. The $125 million, 47- megawatt project will be built by subsidiaries of Dravo and the Standard Oil Company of California at Heber in California's Imperial Valley, a Dravo representative, Marci Crawford, said.

title: METS MAKE OFFER TO PURCHASE JETS
description: Two major owners of the Mets have offered to buy the Jets if all other efforts fail to keep the football team from moving to New Jersey when its lease at Shea Stadium expires after this season.

title: Jets Considering Klecko for Tackle
description: After his first defeat as a head coach in the National Football League, Joe Walton adopted the same attitude today that he did after his first victory: the whole team was responsible, including the coaches.

title: MAY ENERGY PARTNERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bancal Tristate Signs Merger Pact
description: The Bancal Tristate Corporation said it had signed a definitive agreement covering its previously announced acquisition by Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. of Japan.

title: Honoring the Consuls
description: New York is ''the largest consular city in the world,'' according to the Mayor's office. And last night at Gracie Mansion, Mr. Koch was host to his biennial reception for the consuls general, currently numbering 89, and their spouses.

title: FAMILIES DESCRIBE TOLL OF ALZHEIMER'S DISEASE
description: When Dr. John Douglas French, a former neurosurgeon in Los Angeles, started coming home early from work, he would often sit at his desk, apparently exhausted, shifting papers absent-mindedly. His wife urged him to get a medical examination, and he did.

title: CITIBANK PENALIZED ON BOYCOTT
description: Citibank has agreed to pay $323,000 to settle charges that it violated export laws aimed at prohibiting American companies from cooperating with a boycott of Israel by Arab nations. The Commerce Department, which announced the agreement today, said the fine was the largest ever imposed under the anti-boycott provisions of the Export Administration Act.

title: In Training
description: Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini says that when he steps into the ring Thursday night at Madison Square Garden to defend the World Boxing Association's lightweight championship against Orlando Romero, he'll be physically and mentally tough.

title: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 1983
description: International

title: DAWKINS BECOMING A LEHMAN PARTNER
description: Maybe military discipline would help solve the financial problems of many municipalities. This might explain, at least partly, why Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. has named a retired brigadier general as its newest general partner.

title: Boeing 747 Offer
description: The Boeing Company is offering to convert 747 jetliners into super-jumbo jets by extending the aircraft's familiar hump by more than 23 feet, at a cost of $10 million to $12 million. Boeing needs 20 firm orders to start the one-time modification program, a spokesman said. The program would begin in September 1984 at the manufacturer's Everett plant, north of Seattle, where 747's and 767's are assembled.

title: MARION SADLER, EX-PRESIDENT OF AMERICAN AIRLINES
description: Marion Sadler, a former president and chief operating officer of American Airlines, died Sunday at the Tucson (Ariz.) Medical Center after a long illness. A former resident of Manhattan, he was 72 years old and lived in Tucson.

title: Bankruptcies Surge in Japan
description: Japanese corporate bankruptcies last month rose sharply, to 1,607, a record for any August, from 1,455 in July and 1,315 a year earlier, the Tokyo Commerce and Industry Research Company said today.

title: Bush Meets Moroccan King
description: Vice President Bush met King Hassan II today for talks that diplomats said concentrated on the Middle East and Morocco's war in the Western Sahara. On the first full day of his visit to Morocco, Mr. Bush spent more than an hour with the King.

title: WATT DISREGARDS HOUSE PANEL VOTE STAYING COAL SALE
description: The Reagan Administration said today that a Congressional resolution calling for postponement of a sale of coal leases was unconstitutional and that it would be ignored.

title: PHILADELPHIA SCHOOL ADMITS WOMEN
description: While news photographers snapped pictures and fellow students let out an occasional catcall, six young women today became the first of their sex to register at Central High School, the oldest and most distinguished public secondary school in this city.

title: Mothers Day
description: Phyllis Diller gave a baby shower yesterday for Marilyn Michaels, the comedian, and a lot of pregnant friends showed up at the Manhattan Market Restaurant, on Second Avenue. Not surprisingly, the talk centered around waistlines, shrinking and expanding.

title: WEST AND EAST GERMANY IMPROVE TIES
description: West Germany and East Germany have recently taken steps to improve their relations in what officials here see as an attempt to avoid East-West tensions after the deployment of United States medium- range missiles in Western Europe.

title: U.S. LIKELY TO ACT TO BAN A PESTICIDE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is likely to propose a partial ban within the next two weeks on ethylene dibromide, a widely used pesticide strongly suspected of causing cancer, agency officials said today.

title: Aroma Disk System Hitting the Marketplace
description: There is a lot of talk around - in certain circles at least - about a new appliance that is finding its way into the marketplace from Environmental Fragrance Technologies, subsidiary of Charles of the Ritz, which is a subsidiary of the Squibb Corporation.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Gene Mauch , the much-traveled major league skipper, has turned down a chance to return to the Montreal Expos as an administrative aide to General Manager John McHale . . . . Sebastian Coe of Britain, one of the world's outstanding middle-distance runners, says he will not compete in any major track and field meets before the Olympic Games next year. He is recovering from a glandular illness that hindered his performances this year.

title: REFORMS SOUGHTS IN BRIDGE TESTS BY CONNECTICUT
description: The Connecticut Department of Transportation, concluding a six-week internal investigation following the collapse of the Mianus River bridge in Greenwich, recommended today sweeping changes in the way the state inspected its bridges.

title: RELIEF REACHES TRAPPED SHUF VILLAGE
description: The first International Red Cross relief convoy got through today to this besieged Shuf Mountains village, where tens of thousands of Christian refugees are short of food and medicine - and fearful of the encircling Druse militia.

title: THE SPLENDID CAVE IN ALTAMIRA SUFFERS FROM ITS POPULARITY
description: THE polychrome paintings on the ceiling of Altamira Cave were so well preserved when they were discovered 100 years ago near this town on Spain's northern coast that few people could accept the notion that they were created by prehistoric people.

title: SOVIET PIANIST SEEKS 'REFUGE' IN SPAIN, AFTER QUITTING TOUR
description: Aleksandr Toradze, the 24-year-old prize-winning Soviet pianist who dropped from sight last month during a tour, has asked for ''refuge'' in Spain, Foreign Ministry sources said today. They said that could be a first step toward seeking political asylum in Spain or another country, such as the United States.

title: Improvement Sought
description: The officiating crews for the Pacific-10 Conference will work United States Football League games next season in a move aimed at improving officiating in the league. ''We are most aware that the quality of officiating must improve,'' Commissioner Chet Simmons of the U.S.F.L. said in a statement. He added that all officials who worked the league's first season are being evaluated and ''only those whose performances were satisfactory will be rehired for the 1984 season.''

title: TOUGHER CONSTRUCTION RULES APPROVED BY COUNCIL PANEL
description: A bill approved yesterday by a City Council committee would allow city buildings officials to stop construction work at sites where sidewalk sheds did not extend 20 feet beyond the building or when the sheds were removed before exterior work was finished.

title: NOW, THE RIGHT HEM LENGTH IS WHAT YOU WANT
description: The millenium has apparently arrived, but not too many people have noticed.

title: Pilot of Experimental Plane Dies as Wife Narrates Flight
description: A stunt pilot demonstrating an experimental Italian aircraft died Sunday when the wings snapped off the plane as his wife was describing his maneuvers over a public address system, officials said.

title: ADVERTISING;Accounts
description: * Canon Mills Inc. to Peter Rogers Associates.

title: Market Place; Phoenix Fund: High-Risk Mix
description: THE Phoenix Fund, Merrill Lynch's mutual fund that invests in what it calls ''troubled'' companies, expanded holdings of common stocks during its latest quarter. Prominent names among portfolio additions included Ford and Texas Instruments.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The public look at education and the ferment of debate in a variety of public arenas is really healthy.

title: NEW CHOICE IN TV: VIDEO COMPONENTS
description: Those shopping for new television sets these days are increasingly confronted with another choice: video component systems, television's answer to stereo components systems.

title: A ROOKIE FUMBLES HIS BIG CHANCE
description: Bill Bates is another of those free agents, like Everson Walls and Mike Downs, who as a rookie found a job in the secondary of the Dallas Cowboys. Bates, from Tennessee, attracted attention on Sunday when he intercepted his first pass in the National Football League and came within 5 yards of scoring his first touchdown. Instead he had his first fumble.

title: Dozens of Chileans Injured in Protests
description: Dozens of people were injured Sunday night when residents of Santiago's slums took to the streets for the fourth straight day, hours after President Augusto Pinochet formally marked his 10th anniversary in power.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Beker Industries, Greenwich, Conn., has elected to its board Paul Hallingby Jr., a general partner of Bear, Stearns & Co.

title: DENNY OF PHILLIES STOPS METS BY 2-1
description: Ron Darling came up with a new and costly flaw tonight in his second start as a Met. He hit three batters and one of them scored as the Phillies beat the Mets by 2-1 and bounced back into first place in the National League East race. The Phillies took a half- game lead over the Expos, who lost to the Cubs.

title: SCIENTISTS TRY TO STOP DECAY OF MONITOR'S ANCHOR
description: Scientists plan to use electric current to remove corrosion from a 1,450-pound anchor recovered from the wreck of the Monitor, the Civil War ironclad.

title: T.W.A. IN SHIFT ON TICKETS
description: In a step that could keep many ''in- plant'' corporate travel departments operating as usual, Trans World Airlines yesterday reversed itself and said it would continue to pay a 3 percent commission on airline tickets issued by those departments.

title: EAGLE CLOTHES INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $2,743,000. c-Including a tax credit of $1,430,000.

title: Jacob Young Married To Kathleen Beckett
description: The marriage of Kathleen Beckett, a copywriter at Vogue magazine, to Jacob Young, an associate editor of the international edition of Newsweek, took place yesterday. The Rev. John Farren performed the ceremony at St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church.

title: 5 Shot at California School
description: Five students were shot and wounded while standing in a crowd at lunch time outside Manuel Dominguez High School.

title: RIVAL BID FOR NORTHWEST DOESN'T DETER ALLEN INC.
description: Allen & Company Inc. refused yesterday to retreat from its $575 million deal to buy the Northwest Energy Corporation, even though the Williams Companies raised the ante to what could amount to $875 million.

title: GIANTS LOSE ANOTHER RECEIVER TO INJURY
description: The Giants, who lost one wide receiver to injury two weeks ago, lost another today when Johnny Perkins was placed on injured reserve with a chipped and sprained left ankle.

title: ARRIVAL OF THE CONQUEROR
description: For the last four years, wherever the sport of squash racquets has taken Jahangir Khan, an independent film producer has usually been close behind, recording moments for the story of Khan's life. The name Jahangir (ja-hon-GEER) means ''conqueror of the world.'' The name Khan, in the last three decades, has come to symbolize dominance in the sport, and the family's youngest champion has done nothing to change that.

title: New Ad Day Begins For Florist Transworld
description: Despite a single 30-second TV spot that appeared during ''60 Minutes'' on the CBS-TV Network Sept. 4, the people at Florist Transworld Delivery, or F.T.D., consider that their newest advertising effort really got started yesterday morning with commercials appearing during each of the three early morning network news shows.

title: FINANCIER IS CHARGED WITH A SLAYING IN SOHO
description: The 32-year-old president and part owner of a New York investment banking concern was arrested yesterday and charged with fatally shooting a Jersey City man on a SoHo street last Tuesday evening after a dispute over a minor traffic accident.

title: KISSINGERS ARE MOVING IN BUT BLUEBERRIES ARE GOING
description: Henry A. Kissinger and his wife, Nancy, have bought a farm here as a weekend and summer retreat, complete with a pond, tennis court, swimming pool and part of a five-acre blueberry plantation.

title: ROPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $43,000 and gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $1,424,000. The 1982 quarter and year share earnings have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective July 12, 1983.

title: CONNORS'S VICTORY PUTS NO. 1 IN DOUBT
description: The United States Open again established Jimmy Connors as No. 1 in the hearts of New Yorkers and Martina Navratilova as the No. 1 women's player, but the top spot in men's tennis for 1983 remains unresolved.

title: A.B.T., OUT OF MONEY, SEEKS $2 MILLION LOAN AND CONSIDERS STAFF CHANGES
description: The American Ballet Theater, one of this country's foremost ballet troupes, is caught in a financial squeeze that has left the company in turmoil and that could lead to the resignation of two of its top officials.

title: Angels Suspend Foli
description: The California Angels suspended Tim Foli , one of their shortstops, for an indefinite period. The club's only explanation came from Manager John McNamara , who said that Foli had been disciplined for ''failure to be in uniform after the rain delay'' during Saturday night's game in Chicago against the White Sox.

title: PUBLIC SUBSIDIES FOR RICH STUDENTS
description: At a time when welfare, food stamps and other props for the poor have been under vigorous challenge, it seems strange that the college expenses of high-income families should be underwritten by taxpayers. Yet that is precisely what is happening in the nation's public universities, to the detriment of private universities, students and the taxpayers who are footing the bill for our ill-conceived educational policy.

title: ATLAN-TOL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net loss. Results for the latest periods include nonoperating income of $1.4 million. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split on July 11, 1983.

title: COURT UPHOLDS FEE USED TO TRIM MILK OUTPUT
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld the Federal Government's 50-cent fee on milk production, imposed in an effort to cut milk surpluses and help pay for price supports.

title: Open Heart, Open House
description: Frances Gibson of East Elmhurst, Queens, took eight friends from her Queen Esther and Silver Leaf Clubs with her to the Kew Gardens office of Borough President Donald R. Manes yesterday. There - ''feeling like the Queen of England,'' she said later - she was awarded certificates of appreciation by the city and the borough.

title: Earthquake in Serbia
description: An earthquake struck seven villages in the Kopaonik mountain region of Serbia on Saturday, leaving 200 people homeless, the Politika newspaper reported today. No deaths were reported in the quake, which measured 5.3 on the Richter scale, but it was estimated that 1,200 buildings and dwellings were damaged in the region about 100 miles south of here, the report said.

title: Ruthven and Cubs Halt Expos by 8-0; Baseball
description: Dick Ruthven pitched a four-hitter today, and Keith Moreland drove in two runs and had two key hits in a seven-run sixth-inning rally as the Chicago Cubs beat the Montreal Expos, 8-0.

title: CAN DOCTORS LEARN WARMTH?
description: LEADING American medical professors and physicians are moving to correct what they regard as a serious problem in their profession: a lack of compassion in the treatment of patients.

title: Saints' Rogers Hurt
description: George Rogers , the New Orleans Saints' star running back, has suffered strained ligaments in his right knee and may be out of action for as many as four games. Coach Bum Phillips said yesterday that Rogers's knee was ''awfully sore'' and that although it was ''not like something you'll have to operate on,'' Rogers would be out anywhere from one to four weeks.

title: Minnesota Bonds Aid Home Loans
description: A $30 Minnesota Housing Finance Agency bond was tentatively priced by Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc with yields ranging from 6.50 percent to 10 percent.

title: NEW TAPES SHOW KOREAN AIRLINER WAS EXPERIENCING RADIO TROUBLE
description: Tapes made public by the Government today showed Korean Air Lines Flight 7 had radio troubles that forced it to relay two vital position reports to traffic controllers back in Alaska.

title: Victor Technologies
description: Victor Technologies Inc., a Scotts Valley, Calif.-based computer manufacturer, announced yesterday that it had laid off 350 people, primarily manufacturing workers, from its headquarters staff.

title: MOLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Key Rates
description: * Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: DEMOCRATS HEAR ASKEW EXPLAIN VIEWS AT FORUM
description: Former Gov. Reubin Askew of Florida appeared at a Presidential forum here tonight, becoming the first of four Democratic Presidential contenders scheduled to campaign in New York this week in an effort to win the second largest delegation to next year's Democratic National Convention.

title: ESPEY MANUFACTURING & ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CAPITAL GALLERY TO SHOW 43 VERSAILLLES PORTRAITS
description: While the Palace of Versailles in France is closed for renovation, the National Portrait Gallery here will put on display 43 of the palace's best portraits depicting the leaders of three centuries of monarchy and republic.

title: Japan-China Talks
description: About 10 Japanese petrochemical companies will open talks next Monday with the China National Chemicals Import and Export Corporation in Peking to fix prices of Chinese naphtha for shipment to Japan in the fourth quarter, industry sources said today.

title: Shift at Ford Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company's assembly plant in Hapeville, Ga., has begun production of the midsized 1984 Ford LTD and Mercury Marquis. The plant has been building Ford Thunderbirds since Jan. 31, and will continue its Thunderbird production at a lower rate, dropping from 50 units an hour to 31 an hour. A company spokesman said Ford is considering adding the Mercury Cougar to the plant's production by the end of the year.

title: REAGAN'S RIGHTS STANCE CALLED AKIN TO KING'S
description: William Bradford Reynolds, an Assistant Attorney General, said today that the civil rights policies of the Reagan Administration were fully consistent with the views espoused by former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: PRUDENTIAL BANK HIRES EXPORT-IMPORT OFFICIAL
description: Charles E. Lord, vice chairman of the Export-Import Bank of the United States, is going back into private banking after five years in Government jobs - and he is landing in the midst of changes sweeping the financial services industry.

title: CORN CROP PUT AT HALF OF '82 TOTAL
description: The worst drought in nearly 50 years has reduced this year's corn and soybean crops, the principal livestock feeds, to levels far below the record 1982 harvest, the Agriculture Department's Crop Reporting Board said today. The corn crop will be one-half less than last year's yield, and soybeans will be one-third less.

title: MIRACLE CURES SELDOM WORK IN SCHOOL REFORM
description: IN her forthcoming book, ''The Troubled Crusade,'' Diane

title: Si Quiere Promover English
description: The trouble with much ''bilingual'' education is that it isn't bilingual. Too often it's a program to teach children math, social studies and science in their native language without any genuine effort to help them function in English as soon as possible.

title: The Productive Fungus
description: A fungus that lives symbiotically on the roots of wheat helps produce crop yields that are twice as large as those produced by wheat that is uninfected by the fungus, scientists at the United States Department of Agriculture Research Service in Lincoln, Neb., have discovered. The fungi have a network of microscopic filaments that penetrate plant roots and act as an extension of the root system, enabling the roots to take up additional nutrients and moisture from the soil.

title: COMMUNICATIONS CORP OF AMER.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: METROCARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including tax gains of $5,000 for the quarter and $9,000 for the 6 months.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Early European travelers in Africa described ''ants with mandibles capable of crushing a rat.'' Are there really ants that can do this?

title: DECLINE IN AUTOPSIES RAISES CONCERNS
description: IT is the final operation. It is one that can be done in any hospital, one that provides the most

title: Bridge: Exploits of Italian Blue Team Compiled by Pietro Forquet
description: If in the 1960's the cognoscenti had been asked to vote for the world's best players virtually everyone would have put Pietro Forquet of Italy in first or second position: Some would have given the edge to his regular partner, Benito Garozzo.

title: Osborne, Financially Shaky, Seeks Investor
description: The Osborne Computer Corporation, which laid off all but 80 of its employees last Friday, is scrambling to find a new source of investment or a possible acquirer to stave off financial failure.

title: 2,000 U.S. MARINES ARRIVE OFF BEIRUT AS FIGHTING RAGES
description: A new contingent of 2,000 United States marines arrived off Lebanon today. Hours later, three more marines ashore were wounded when their positions at the Beirut airport were shelled again.

title: AMERICAN SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
N.F.L. Steroid Use
description: Commissioner Pete Rozelle says that a National Football League study conducted recently found that there was not heavy use of anabolic steroids for nonmedical purposes among players. Rozelle, speaking in Chicago, said steroid use had been approved by the league when it is prescribed by physicians.

title: RULING ISRAELI COALITION RALLIES ROUND SHAMIR
description: Leaders of Israel's governing coalition announced tonight that after 10 days of back-room bargaining, all factions had signed an agreement to form a new government with Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir as the next Prime Minister.

title: ...AND SHULTZ JOUSTS WITH GROMYKO
description: As he was talking to reporters on the way back to Washington on Friday, Secretary of State George P. Shultz ruminated about his two-hour session the day before in Madrid with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union. ''It was a very tough meeting,'' he said, ''to put it mildly.''

title: ELLMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Berry Now Student At a Junior College
description: St. John's has lost Walter Berry, its highly touted basketball prospect, for at least one year.

title: U.N. CHIEF'S REPORT IS PESSIMISTIC
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar today deplored the continuing frustration of the United Nations in its efforts to settle conflicts between nations.

title: BankAmerica Will Sell $100 Million Note Issue
description: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it would sell $100 million of 11 3/8 percent notes due Sept. 15, 1986.

title: PEKING'S STATUS AS ATOMIC POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: THE NEWEST MEMBER OF THE CLUB
description: Daniel J. Evans had been a United States Senator for less than 30 minutes, but already the title seemed to come easily to old friends and the several dozen Republican colleagues who dropped by a Senate reception this afternoon to welcome the newest member.

title: SOUTH KOREA'S AIRLINE AND ITS PILOTS HAVE REPUTATION OF BEING AGGRESSIVE
description: Korean Air Lines, whose off-course 747 carrying 269 people was shot down by the Soviet Union, has a mixed reputation among aviation officials, industry executives and pilots.

title: Queens Man Slain; 2 Boys, 16, Held
description: A Queens man was shot and killed yesterday on a street near his home when he refused to hand over a large portable radio to two 16-year-old boys, the police said.

title: A GALA AT SAKS OPENS SEASON
description: It was the opening salvo of the fall and winter social season, coming on the heels of weather that seemed like midsummer. More than 600 people paid $125 to attend the black-tie dinner at Saks Fifth Avenue last night that introduced the clothes of five leading fashion designers and supported five different charities.

title: VIRGIL CONNER
description: Virgil Conner, one of the oldest people ever to receive a doctorate degree from a university in the United States, has died.

title: U.S. Ambassador to Denmark Is Decorated by Government
description: John L. Loeb Jr., the departing United States Ambassador to Denmark, was decorated yesterday with one of that country's highest awards, the Grand Cross of the Order of Danneborg, in recognition of his efforts to strengthen Danish-American relations, the United States Information Service reported from Copenhagen.

title: KOCH IN THREAT NOT TO TESTIFY AT POLICE-BRUTALITY HEARING
description: Mayor Koch threatened yesterday not to attend a Congressional subcommittee hearing on charges of police brutality against black New Yorkers next week unless the hearing is held in a building he finds acceptable.

title: REAGAN SEEKS JOINT RESEARCH
description: President Reagan asked Congress today to modify antitrust, patent and copyright law to encourage joint research and development ventures by corporations.

title: TRAVELODGE INERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
HYTEK INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $35,000 for the latest first quarter and $53,240 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: CRESTBROOK FOREST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Pirates 7, Cardinals 5
description: Brian Harper delivered a two-run pinch single in the sixth as Pittsburgh rallied from a three-run, first-inning deficit.

title: THE MAKING OF AN ENDANGERED SPECIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Step-Up Seen In World Oil
description: Worldwide oil production is ''virtually certain'' to increase during the second half of 1983 after a three-year decline, the Oil and Gas Journal reported today in its current issue.

title: Authority List Revised
description: The daily list of tax-exempt authority bonds has been revised. Twenty of the more actively traded issues in the municipal bond market were added; an equal number of issues that have recently shown few daily changes have been deleted.

title: STANDING UP, SHELLING OUT
description: The McCarthy Hoax
