title: SOVIET ORDERS U.S. VICE CONSUL EXPELLED AS A SPY
description: The Soviet Union today ordered the expulsion on spying charges of an American diplomat serving at the consulate general in Leningrad.

title: ANDERSEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for 3-for-2 stock split in June.

title: No Headline
description: ''General public perceptions are that an aerospace job is a 'man's job,' '' said A. Thomas Hunt, the lawyer who negotiated the agreement. ''Hopefully, this decree will become a model.''

title: Charlotte Curtis The Woes of Gardening
description: THEY dream of Green Mansions, Hidcote, Sissinghurst and Giverny, frowzy antique roses, wildflowers and the rest. Yet despite money and hard labor, often their own, their successes are limited. They are country flower gardeners, and after a lushly beautiful spring, this was not one of their great summers.

title: Australian Trade Gains
description: Australia's balance of payments surplus widened in August, to $391 million, from $117 million in July. The balance of payments had a $446 million deficit a year earlier, the Statistics Bureau said today.

title: Buyer Found For Permian
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said it had agreed to sell substantially all the assets of its Permian Corporation unit to the First City Financial Corporation of Vancouver, British Columbia, in a deal worth about $375 million. First City Financial will pay $275 million in cash, a note for $50 million and cash from the sale of existing crude oil inventories valued between $50 million and $60 million.

title: THE RISKY GRAIN DEAL
description: Along with the tragic personal suffering and national affront, the downing of the Korean Air Lines 747 may offer one advantage - a chance to reconsider the consequences of the new United States-Soviet grain sales agreement.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Ratings

title: Not as He Saw Them
description: Coach Ed Biles of the Houston Oilers said he planned to call the National Football League office to complain about the ''magic crew'' of officials who made numerous ''mystery calls'' in the Oilers' loss to the Rams on Sunday.

title: ON NICARAGUA'S JEWS
description: The Reagan Administration has produced a new skeleton from the Nicaraguan closet - anti-Semitism.

title: DISENCHANTMENT GROWING AT JERSEY DEMOCRATS' CONVENTION
description: Signs of a growing disenchantment with the field of Democratic Presidential candidates were visible today as New Jersey Democrats opened a two-day convention.

title: COSMOS OUSTED IN PLAYOFFS
description: The Cosmos' season came to an abrupt end tonight when the Montreal Manic posted a 1-0 victory in a disputed shootout and eliminated the defending champions from the North American Soccer League playoffs.

title: Coast Thrift Unit Fights Acquisition
description: The Beverly Hills Savings and Loan Association said its board of directors had voted to oppose the application of Paul Amir for California regulatory approval of his proposed acquisition of ''effective control'' of the association.

title: ZIMBABWE KEEPING BAN ON NEWSMEN
description: As the Government here continues to bar entry to foreign correspondents based in South Africa, other southern African nations that supported such exclusions in principle are shying away from them in practice.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Cuomo in Chinatown

title: Western Electric
description: The Western Electric Company said it would phase out its Indianapolis telephone plant by 1986 as part of an economy drive. The plant, built in 1949, produces Trimline, Touch- A-Matic, Design Line and other telephone sets and modular telephone components.

title: ONE OF FOUR ON ANTINUCLEAR FAST TAKES BROTH, FIRST IN 39 DAYS
description: Weak, dehydrated and with failing vision after 39 days of taking only water, one of the four Oakland antinuclear fasters decided to end her fast today after her doctor expressed ''deep concern'' for her physical well-being.

title: Compucorp Bid
description: Compucorp,, said it had executed a letter of intent with Litton Industries to allow it to acquire Monroe Systems for Business, a Litton subsidiary, for undisclosed terms. Both Compucorp, which is based in Santa Monica, Calif., and Monroe, based in Morris Plains, N.J., manufacture and sell business systems and office automation equipment. Monroe, which employs more than 3,700, sells business computers, office copiers, accounting machines and electronic calculators.

title: Japan Machine Orders
description: Japanese machinery orders, excluding shipping, fell 30.2 percent in July, to a seasonally adjusted $2.02 billion, from $2.89 billion in June, the Economic Planning Agency said today.

title: Sharon Urges Rescue Of Trapped Christians
description: Former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon tonight urged the Israeli Government to prepare a military operation to rescue nearly 50,000 Lebanese Christian civilians trapped in the Druse-encircled town of Deir al Qamar.

title: DRUSE MOUNT HEAVY ATTACKS NEAR BEIRUT
description: Syrian-backed Druse militiamen today attacked Lebanese Army troops on a ridge near here from three directions in heavy fighting aimed at breaking through to link up with other anti-Government units closer to the capital.

title: BOTH SIDES AT BRINK'S TRIAL MAKE FINAL ARGUMENTS
description: Final arguments were made in the Brink's trial today. The defense said the $1.6 million robbery and triple murder was an act of armed revolution, and the prosecution called the crime ''barbarism.''

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: The Police Blotter
description: A Bronx teen-ager was arrested yesterday and charged with the murder of a 2-year-old neighbor, killed when he was thrown from the roof of a building. The suspect, Danny Jenkins, 17, was arrested at midnight in his apartment at 725 Fox Street and charged with killing Alexis Castro, who lived in the same building.

title: MONTAGUE H. HACKETT
description: Montague H. Hackett, an advertising executive whose clients included the sponsors of programs that introduced Bing Crosby, Fred Astaire, Eddie Duchin, Bert Lahr and other entertainers to national radio in the early 30's, died of a heart attack last Thursday at White Plains Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Former Player Killed in Shootout
description: A former Indiana University football player may have been ''suffering from some illness that affected his brain'' before he fired a shot at the police Monday and was in turn fatally shot by them, according to the Monroe County coroner.

title: Woman and 2 Sons Slain
description: A woman and her two young sons were shot to death Monday night in their home in Hamilton Township.

title: 2d Autopsy Scheduled On Body of Black Farmer
description: The family of a black farmer who died while being arrested by four white policemen agreed today to have his body exhumed for a second autopsy, and the Justice Department said it might investigate whether his civil rights had been violated.

title: SOVIET DESCRIBES OUSTER OF COUPLE
description: The Soviet press gave unusually detailed accounts today of the apprehension of an American couple whose expulsion on spying charges was announced Monday.

title: CON-ED'S COAL PLAN IS NO HEALTH THREAT
description: To the Editor:

title: HELP REUNITE LEBANON
description: Until now, the marines in Lebanon have been primarily a peacekeeping force. Theirs has been an uphill mission, to say the least, but it is time we took on an even harder assignment - the active shoring up of the Government of Lebanon. More specifically, we must help it begin to reunite the country by backing up its efforts to take control of the Shuf Mountains, southeast of Beirut.

title: Q&A
description: Q. One of my children refused a fried egg that had a blood spot on the yolk. What is it?

title: L LURIA & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
Danelo Signs With the Bills
description: Joe Danelo, the veteran place-kicker who was beaten out by the rookie Ali

title: Gold Coin Minted For the Olympics
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, in ceremonies at the United States Bullion Depository here, minted the first United States gold coin in 50 years today.

title: REAGAN TO LET MARINES GIVE SOME AID TO LEBANESE ARMY AND EUROPEAN PEACE FORCES
description: The Reagan Administration announced today that the Marines in Lebanon were now authorized to call on American naval and air power not only to defend themselves but to assist other Western forces and, in certain circumstances, the Lebanese Army.

title: CLABIR SWEETENS HMW OFFER
description: The Clabir Corporation, in a renewed effort to move further into the military business, yesterday sweetened its offer to buy control of HMW Industries, a manufacturer of artillery fuses, arming devices and other weaponry.

title: TO TUGMAN THIS COOK IS 'THE BEST'
description: ''HEY, is Gilroy over there?'' The shouted question came sailing from the pilothouse of a tugboat in the city's Lower Harbor as it passed another tug called the McAllister Brothers.

title: Careers; Outlook For Civil Engineers
description: ALL across the country, there is talk about decay of the infrastructure - defined broadly as bridges, highways, railroads and airports, dams and reservoirs, flood control projects, underground pipes and sewage systems, and hazardous waste facilities.

title: SPANISH VINTNER SEEKS BIGGER U.S. SALE
description: ''THERE is much less prejudice in the United States against Spanish wines than there is in France and some parts of Europe,'' said Manuel Raventos Artes while rattling along in a minitrain through the seemingly endless wine cellar of Codorniu, the Spanish maker of sparkling wine.

title: 2 Ex-K.G.B. Officials Given New Soviet Posts
description: Two former officials of the K.G.B., the Soviet security agency, have been named Deputy Interior Ministers as part of Yuri V. Andropov's effort to give the K.G.B. more power in the national police force.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The nation that dramatically and boldly led the world into the age of technology is failing to provide its own children with the intellectual tools needed for the 21st century.'' - The National Science Board Commission on Precollege Education in Mathematics, Science and Technology. (D27:2.)

title: HOUSE APPROVES FUND INCREASES IN 10 PROGRAMS
description: The House of Representatives moved today to reverse some of the domestic spending cuts enacted in the first year of the Reagan Administration by passing legislation that would increase authorizations for 10 education and health programs by $1.6 billion.

title: WELLS FARGO GUARD ACCUSED OF STEALING $7 MILLION IN CASH
description: An armed security guard for the Wells Fargo Armored Service Corporation bound and apparently drugged two co-workers at a company garage here late Monday night and fled with $7 million in cash, the police said today.

title: Rangers Sign Larouche
description: The Rangers yesterday announced the signing of Pierre Larouche, the offensively talented center who had become a free agent without compensation after refusing to sign a termination contract with the Hartford Whalers. Larouche reported to the Rangers' training camp at Playland in Rye, N.Y., yesterday and joined the rest of the players in the two-a-day training sessions.

title: Economic Scene; The Questions For Politicians
description: THE most important factor affecting the state of the economy now and for the next few years is probably the 1984 Presidential election. Conversely, the most important factor affecting the election is the economy. Modifying John Keats's famous equation of beauty and truth, one might even say: Politics is economics, economics politics, that is all ye know on earth, and all ye need to know.

title: A Pro Outlook
description: John Robinson, who became accustomed to winning football games as head coach for seven years at the University of Southern California, is off on the right track in the National Football League, having won his first two games as the coach of the Los Angeles Rams.

title: BALTIMORE MAYOR EASILY WINS PRIMARY BID FOR FOURTH TERM
description: Mayor William Donald Schaefer easily won renomination to a fourth term today, winning a Democratic primary victory over William H. Murphy Jr., a former state judge who was the first black candidate to mount a strong challenge for Mayor in the history of this predominantly black city.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Darkness: Temporary and Permanent
description: Not all news out of the Aug. 10 garment district blackout was bad.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: ELVIS COSTELLO, who is widely regarded as the most important singer-songwriter to come out of the English new wave, finally has his very first American hit. ''Everyday I Write the Book,'' from his ninth album, ''Punch the Clock,'' is No. 48 on Billboard's Hot 100 and climbing. The song, which plays off the Monotones' 1958 doo-wop hit ''Book of Love,'' is an irresistible compendium of allusive pop hooks and verbal sharpshooting.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tim Foli, the ailing California Angel shortstop who was suspended for being out of uniform after he took a shower and put on his street clothes during a 93-minute, ninth-inning rain delay in Chicago on Saturday, was reinstated yesterday. A team spokesman, Tom Seeberg, said Foli had apologized ''to the proper parties'' and had acknowledged ''that he was wrong.''

title: THE GARRULOUS SILENCE SOMEWHERE IN THE COT SWOLDS
description: The English are said to be a taciturn race, and our adventures in the dining rooms of country inns confirmed it. Wherever we stayed - the King's Arms, the Plowman's Legs, the Squire's Kidneys - silence in the dining room was intense.

title: Wrestlers Soviet-Bound
description: The United States' boycott of the 1980 Olympics cost him a trip to Moscow. But now Dan Gable, the Iowa wrestling coach, who also coaches the American national team, is heading for the Soviet Union despite the furor over that country's shooting down of a Korean passenger plane.

title: Police in Milan Report Arrest Of Three Terrorist Suspects
description: The police have arrested three suspected right- wing terrorists in a raid on a downtown cafe, police spokesmen said today.

title: U.S. to Shun Energy Parley
description: The United States today abruptly canceled its participation in a three-day energy conference to be held in New Delhi next week because of the Indian Government's refusal to grant visas to Israeli delegates.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: Ayala to Face Charge in Texas
description: Tony Ayala Jr., the former junior- middleweight contender who is serving a 35-year sentence in New Jersey for a rape conviction last April, was en route to San Antonio today to face charges that he violated probation imposed here for a 1978 assault.

title: Osborne Sued By Creditors
description: The Osborne Computer Corporation, the faltering pioneer of the portable computer industry, is being sued in a California state court by two computer companies, Testology Inc. and PH Components Inc., that claim that Osbourne owes them more than $4.5 million.

title: CITY PUTS PRESSURE ON JETS
description: City officials, frustrated and annoyed at the silence of the Jets' principal owner, appeared to increase their pressure on him yesterday, saying that they would try to bring another National Football League team to Shea Stadium if he does not meet with them by early next week.

title: Robert E. Weintraub, Economist for Congress
description: Robert E. Weintraub, senior economist for the Joint Economic Committee of Congress and a monetarist economist in Washington for many years, died here Monday morning. He was 58 years old.

title: RESOURCES EQUIPMENT CAPIAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss c-Net income

title: NORTHWEST ENERGY: BOESKY BUYS STAKE
description: An investment group led by Ivan F. Boesky has purchased 5.8 percent of the Northwest Energy Company of Salt Lake City in a $32.2 million deal, documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission indicate.

title: BEAUMONT SEEKS TRUCE WITH LINCOLN CENTER
description: The board of the Vivian Beaumont Theater, at a meeting late Monday afternoon, tendered an olive branch to the Lincoln Center board. At the same time, the Beaumont board retained Peter Fleming of the law firm of Curtis Mallet-Prevost Colt and Mosle to look after its interests. But behind the public announcement of peace proposals were resentments uttered by two members of the board.

title: IMMUNO NUCLEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: No Headline
description: A Tulsa minister said Monday his congregation had donated more than $1.5 million in one day as a ''pure sacrifice'' for a new church auditorium. The Rev. Marvin Phillips said a huge crowd showed up at the Garnett Church of Christ in Tulsa Sunday and donated cash, cars, jewelry and houses.

title: METS FOIL PHILLIES
description: Mike Fitzgerald hit a home run in his first major league plate appearance, and Darryl Strawberry drove in three runs tonight as the Mets defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-1.

title: HOW 2 AREAS KEEP CRIME RATE LOW
description: Although miles apart in geography and atmosphere, the two areas share one distinction: Last week a report sponsored by Figgie International, a Cleveland-based company, using some objective statistics and some subjective observation, described both neighborhoods as among the safest in the United States. Here is a look at Ridgewood and Belmont and their residents.

title: SHULTZ TELLS SENATE REPRISALS AGAINST SOVIET WOULD REQUIRE SUPPORT
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz told the Senate today that the United States would not invoke sanctions against the Soviet Union unless it received the international support needed to make the sanctions effective, according to senators who attended a closed, two-hour session.

title: PETRIE STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
GULF ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $170,000. c-Net loss.

title: NO GAME TODAY
description: Walt Michaels would have killed for weather like this in the Jets' sodden loss to Miami last January. Ernie Banks would have taken one look at the blue skies and said ''Let's play two.'' Bowie Kuhn would have tossed away his thermal underwear and sat in his skivvies on a World Series day like yesterday.

title: United Bars In-Plant' Fees
description: United Airlines said yesterday that it would not follow Trans World Airlines in continuing to pay 3 percent commissions to ''in-plant'' corporate travel departments, putting in doubt that the commissions would continue. United, which stopped paying the commissions on Monday, added that it would stick to its Aug. 10 decision to eliminate commissions to in-plant travel agencies that write about $1 billion in tickets annually.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: SOMETIMES the ideas in this space are for special-occasion dishes. Though the criterion for cooking time remains within our standard boundary of one hour for preparation, the ingredients tend to be a bit more costly.

title: TRADING SLOWS
description: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday in much slower trading. The dull session followed Monday's dramatic turnabout, which saw the market end lower after posting sharp gains early in the session.

title: Ford Says It's Closing Steel Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company today notified the 850 nonunion employees of its Rouge Steel subsidiary that the big mill would be closed, possibly within a year, because the company had been unable to reach agreement on concessions with the 3,500 unionized workers there.

title: Nicaragua Accuses U.S. Of Role in Air Attacks
description: Nicaragua accused the United States Central Intelligence Agency today of waging ''indiscriminate terrorism'' to overthrow the Sandinista Government.

title: Phibro Divides Chief's Office
description: John H. Gutfreund has been named co-chief executive officer of Phibro-Salomon Inc., the commodity and securities firm. Mr. Gutfreund will share the post with David Tendler, who has been chief executive. Both remain co-chairmen. The New York-based firm also announced that it was forming a holding company in a corporate reorganization.

title: New Commodity Rules
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission approved new regulations today that allow an exchange to trade two options on futures contracts, two options on physical commodities or one option on a futures contract and one option on a physical commodity. Current rules provide for the trading of one option on a futures contract and one on option on a physical commodity.

title: Key Rates
description: * Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Article 163926 -- No Title
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority and its subsidiaries have paid some of the country's largest law firms about $4 million so far this year for legal work, ranging from labor negotiations to bond sales to litigation.

title: JOB SAFETY HEAD IS CRITICIZED IN REFUSING RULE ON PESTICIDE
description: The chairman of a House subcommittee charged today that the director of the Occupational Safety and Health Commission had ignored advice from his own staff in declining to take emergency action to protect workers from the pesticide ethylene dibromide.

title: NATIONAL TECHNICAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $194,000 for the quarter and $225,000 for the 6 months.

title: BRIEFING;Some Sort of Record
description: When the Federal Government makes a useful change, however modest, it is worth noting, perhaps even celebrating. Congress returned to Capitol Hill from vacation Monday, and the resulting Congressional Record the next day carried, for the first time ever, the date of the session it recorded as well as its title and volume number printed on its spine, where it could be read on a shelf or in a file drawer.

title: SOVIET SAYS 747 USED 'TRICKS' LIKE SPY PLANE
description: The Soviet armed forces added new details today to earlier assertions that the South Korean airliner shot down by a Soviet jet fighter was spying.

title: PARAQUAT SPRAYING IS BLOCKED
description: A Federal district judge temporarily blocked the Drug Enforcement Administration today from spraying the herbicide paraquat to eradicate illegal marijuana fields growing on Federal lands.

title: AMERICAN BUILDING MAINTENANCE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
GRIFFIN TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-1 stock split approved on June 22.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge:A 'Solid' Suit May Be Weak When Reality of Play Starts

title: No Site Picked Yet ForPolice
description: An aide to the House Subcommittee on Criminal Justice said yesterday that no site had been selected yet for its New York City hearing next Monday on allegations of police brutality against black and Hispanic New Yorkers.

title: DUTCHMAN ELECTED LEADER OF JESUITS
description: The Jesuits today elected a Dutch specialist on the Middle East, the Rev. Peter-Hans Kolvenbach, to head the order.

title: Top Yield Is 9 7/8% For Revenue Issue
description: A $61.1 million issue of Hillsborough County, Fla., refunding utility revenue bonds was priced tentatively with a maximum yield of 9 7/8 percent for bonds due in 2011, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: FROM OVEN TO TABLE
description: NOW that autumn is near, thoughts turn again to seasonal fare such as roasts, stews and casserole dishes. Whenever I cook a roast, a chicken or a duck, I prefer to serve it whole right from the oven rather than carve it in the kitchen.

title: FILM: 'KOYAANISQATSI,' ESSAY ON U.S.
description: ''Koyaanisqatsi'' was shown as part of the 1982 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby that appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 4, 1982. The film opens today at the 57th Street Playhouse.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Test of Speed On Wall Street
description: Wall Street, better known for contributing to heart attacks than preventing them, will be the site of part of today's race to benefit the New York Heart Association. Fifteen hundred runners, many of them Wall Streeters, will run a five-kilometer course after work.

title: No Headline
description: COLD HEAVEN. By Brian Moore. 265 pages. William Abrahams/Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $14.95.

title: SOUTHLAND OFFICIAL IN BRIBE PLEA
description: A vice president of the Southland Corporation, which runs the nationwide 7-Eleven convenience-store chain, pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiring to bribe New York State tax officials to fix sales tax cases involving the chain.

title: SBE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Khan Tops Talbott
description: Jahangir Khan, the world's foremost squash racquets player, defeated Mark Talbott, who is ranked first in North America, in their first match of the Chivas Regal International Challenge yesterday. The scores in the exhibition at the Lincoln Squash Club were 9-4, 9-3, 9-2.

title: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 14, 1983
description: The Economy

title: Statue of Owens Now a Possibility
description: Lawrence County officials who had initially rejected a monument in memory of Jesse Owens, prompting accusations of racism, reversed their decision Monday, the 69th anniversary of the Olympic star's birth.

title: Sallie Mae Arranging Sale of 6 Million Shares
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, also known as Sallie Mae, yesterday announced some details of its first public stock offering.

title: WINE TALK
description: THOUGH the Yellow Rose of Texas may never be replaced by the purple grape, the Lone Star State has every intention of making it in the wine world. Thirteen commercial wineries are in operation and the University of Texas is in the ninth year of an experimental program to determine what grapes will grow well and where.

title: POPE AVOIDS POLITICS ON VISIT TO AUSTRIA
description: Pope John Paul II ended his four-day visit to Austria today with a pilgrimage to Maria Zell, the country's most revered sanctuary of the Virgin Mary. He returned to Rome in the evening.

title: SCHOLARS QUESTION SALE OF WRIGHT DRAWINGS
description: An exhibition and potential sale of 100 drawings from the archives of the Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation in Scottsdale, Ariz., which is to begin Friday, has raised questions from numerous scholars and architectural historians.

title: 'RESTLESS' MCGOVERN RENEWS QUEST FOR PRESIDENCY
description: George McGovern, who got only 17 electoral votes in his unsuccessful bid to unseat President Nixon in 1972, announced today before a cheering college audience that he would seek the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination on a platform of ''realism and common sense.''

title: WHAT MAKES THEM RUN
description: Watching George McGovern hop on the Presidential merry-go-round again makes you wonder what makes them run. After all, George didn't have a very merry ride the last time; but the older they get, the harder they try.

title: ARMY'S ENGINEERS TO STUDY WESTWAY FOR 2 MORE YEARS
description: The Army Corps of Engineers said yesterday that it needed at least two years to assess the impact of the Westway on striped bass in the Hudson River before it could consider granting the project a permit.

title: Market Place; Positive Views About Merck
description: AT the start of this month, Merck & Company temporarily suspended overseas sales of its new measured-release form of an anti-arthritis drug in response to reports of unexpected side effects to the medicine. That announcement also produced a reaction in Merck's stock, which fell 4 5/8 points, to 91 3/4, on Sept. 1.

title: Inquiry Set On Pan Am
description: A five-member commission will investigate the withdrawal of United States track and field athletes from last month's Pan American Games in Caracas, Venezuela, The Athletics Congress said today.

title: FLORIDA COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $969,000 for the quarter and $1,445,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $243,000 for the quarter and $438,000 for the 6 months.

title: Judge Decides In N.F.L.'s Favor
description: A Federal judge has thrown out much of a lawsuit in which the Los Angeles Raiders accused the National Football League of obstructing justice during last year's trial of the Raiders' antitrust case against the N.F.L.

title: FRANCOISE DE LA RENTA, EDITOR, LAUDED BY KISSINGER AT MASS
description: Several hundred friends and colleagues of Fran,coise de la Renta attended a memorial mass last night at St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church for the editor and hostess who died of cancer in June.

title: Shift in House's Seats By End of 80's Is Seen
description: New Census Bureau projections on population shifts by the end of this decade indicate that New York will lose five seats in the House of Representatives and Texas and Florida will each gain four seats, according to American Demographics Magazine.

title: Strauss Play to Open Season at City Stage
description: ''Big and Little/Scenes,'' a play by Botho Strauss, will open the 17th season of the City Stage Company on Oct. 6 at the company's theater, 136 East 13th Street.

title: WAXMAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MARTINELLI IS VICTOR IN YONKERS PRIMARY BY NARROW MARGIN
description: Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli of Yonkers won a bitter Republican primary yesterday in his bid for re-election, narrowly defeating Carl A. Calvi, a county legislator.

title: SAUSAGE MAKING TODAY: SUBTLE, ELEGANT TASTES
description: COMBINE a passion for handmade foods, a curiosity about modern adaptations of old recipes and an insatiable desire for something new and you have a revival in the art of sausage making. That is what is taking place in home kitchens as well as in small shops and at fancy restaurants, where the butchers and chefs, disappointed with the quality and variety of the commercially prepared sausages, are making their own. Not just variations on old familiar themes - pork or veal with sage or coriander, garlic and black pepper, but also updated versions of the kinds of sausages no one has made in 50 or 100 years.

title: SCIENCE PANEL PROPOSES SPECIAL SCHOOL NETWORK
description: A network of ''exemplary'' schools specializing in mathematics and science, 1,000 at the elementary level and 1,000 at the secondary level, was proposed today by a high-level Government panel.

title: INITIO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 6
description: b-Including capital gains of $101,000 for the quarter and $160,000 for the 6 months and a gain of $166,000 for the quarter and 6 months from the settlement of litigations.

title: REAGAN AND MUGABE EXPLORE DISAGREEMENTS
description: President Reagan and Prime Minister Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe held their first meeting today and declared that their disagreements on dealings with South Africa and on other matters would not hinder their friendship.

title: PLANS PROGRESSING FOR A 60-STORY WALL STREET TOWER
description: Plans are moving ahead for the construction of a 60-story office tower at 60 Wall Street, the 52,000-square- foot parcel of land in the heart of the financial district that, despite its considerable value, has stood vacant for more than two years.

title: Asner Foes to Urge Boycott of Union Vote
description: Charlton Heston and other foes of Edward Asner, president of the Screen Actors Guild, said yesterday that they would not put up a candidate to oppose Mr. Asner's re-election but that they would call for a boycott of balloting, which is to begin Oct. 11.

title: MARSHALL B. WEITMAN
description: Marshall B. Weitman, president of the Whitemarsh Realty Company of Greenwich, Conn., died of hepatitis Sunday at Greenwich Hospital.

title: R. H. Macy Earnings Up 29.8%
description: R. H. Macy & Company reported yesterday that earnings jumped 29.8 percent in its fiscal fourth quarter, ended July 30, as sales increased 16.8 percent.

title: IN DEFENSE OF THE RIGHT TO BE OFFENSIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: CONDUCTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-After a charge of $450,000 from the writeoff of obsolete assets.

title: WATT VS. PETERSON
description: Most editorial comment on the running argument between Interior Secretary James G. Watt and Russell W. Peterson, president of the National Audubon Society, totally misses the critical point of the exchange. The issue is not whether Mr. Watt or Mr. Peterson would better manage public land but rather that they are prisoners of their public positions as political decision- makers.

title: HOFMANN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
4 IN FAMILY HURT IN THE EXPLOSION OF TRANSFORMER
description: A 23-month-old girl and her 12-year- old brother were critically burned yesterday and their mother and grandmother were also injured when an explosion in an undergound Consolidated Edison electrical transformer sent 15- foot-high flames shooting up through a sidewalk grating in front of a supermarket in Corona, Queens.

title: Henderson Passes 100
description: Rickey Henderson of the A's stole his 99th, 100th and 101st bases of the season during Oakland's 6-5 victory over Texas. The A's outfielder, who set a major league record with 130 steals last year, is the only player to achieve at least 100 steals three times. Henderson stole 100 bases in 1980.

title: Westphal to Join Suns
description: Paul Westphal , who was released by the Knicks after being named the league's comeback player of the year last season, has agreed to a two-year contract with the Phoenix Suns, Jerry Colangelo , the team's general manager, said , ''The document is not signed, but Paul and I worked out everything today and we have a handshake on the deal.'' Westphal, 32, started at guard for the Suns for five seasons, during which he averaged more than 20 points, until he was traded in 1980 to the SuperSonics. He then signed with the Knicks in March 1982 as a free agent.

title: REACTIONS TO KREMLIN: HOW IT SEES ITSELF AND THE WORLD
description: Unlike Afghanistan, Poland or the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev, the downing of a Korean Air Lines 747 presented the Kremlin with a crisis for which it had no explanation or rationale worked out in advance. Soviet leaders were forced to respond fast, and their reflexes - their claims, evasions, charges and disclosures - may have revealed more about their system than about what led to the decision to destroy a civilian airliner, resulting in the deaths of 269 people.

title: Letter: On Mental Health Mr. Cuomo Defends His Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a pretax loss of $405,000 for the quarter and 6 months on the discontinuing of notes and gains of $114,000 for the quarter and $254,000 for the 6 months on the early extinguishment of debt. c-Net income including pretax gains of $444,000 for the quarter and $6,024,000 for the 6 months on the sale of property, a gain of $2,038,000 for the quarter and 6 months on the early extinguishment of debt and a tax credit of $2.4 million for the quarter and 6 months. The company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption with the Thursday Sports listing on Sept. 1 incorrectly described the origins of the national men's tennis championships. They began in Newport, R.I., in 1881 and moved to Forest Hills in 1915.

title: Moon Conviction IsUpheldbyCourt
description: The conviction of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon for tax fraud and conspiracy to obstruct justice was upheld yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 14, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: HARRISON CULTRA, NOTED INTERIOR DESIGNER, 42
description: Harrison Cultra, an interior designer and decorator for many prominent clients, died Sunday at New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 42 years old and lived in Manhattan and Germantown, N.Y.

title: Spinners Play Tonight
description: The Spinners, a British folk group, will give a free concert today at 7:30 P.M. at the South Street Seaport, Fulton Street, between Front and Water Streets. The group, which was formed 25 years ago, is on a tour of maritime museums around the country. The concert goes on rain or shine.

title: Norwegian Local Voting Shows Swing to Left
description: Results from Norway's local elections showed a swing to the left today and an apparent rejection of the national coalition Government's austerity policy.

title: Belgian Rail Strike Spreads To the Rapid Transit System
description: A nationwide rail strike spread to the rapid transit system and post offices today, and the country braced for a general strike Thursday by 900,000 public employees angered by the Government's austerity program.

title: GLENN OUTPOLLS MONDALE AT JERSEY PARTY MEETING
description: Senator John Glenn of Ohio finished first for the Democratic Presidential nomination in a straw poll today of delegates to the New Jersey party's convention. Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale of Minnesota finished second, and the state party chairman, James F. Maloney, declared the race in New Jersey a two-way contest.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: AT one time or another almost everyone cooks or makes a stab at cooking. The results may vary, but no matter how the food turns out, there is one constant in the operation. A certain number of dishes, gadgets, and pots and pans get dirty; a certain amount of sugar and flour gets dribbled on counters; drops of sauce coagulate on the stove, and eggs slither around, occasionally showing their independence by rolling off and splattering on the floor. In short, it is very possible for even the most organized and tidy person to end up with a kitchen that looks as if a cyclone has roared through it.

title: TEXAS ATTORNEY GENERAL INDICTED FOR BRIBERY
description: Texas Attorney General Jim Mattox was indicted today on a felony charge of commercial bribery. The indictment involved a purported threat to destroy the bond business of a Houston law firm if the firm pursued inquiries into his campaign finances.

title: COMPREHENSIVE CARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
PEERLESS MFG CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AT THE CHAD FRONT: WAR IN AN ANCIENT WASTELAND
description: This remote desert crossroads does not look like a prize worthy of the worry of diplomats in Paris and Washington or the lives of soldiers from half a dozen countries.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: SOVIET DIRECTOR CHARGES HARASSMENT IN LONDON
description: Yuri Lyubimov, the Russian director, complained today that he had been harassed and threatened by an official of the Soviet Embassy here who warned him against making disparaging remarks in the Western press about artistic interference back home.

title: The Good, the Best and the Border
description: Hey, bud, you want some fake identification? It's not hard to find. In Texas, one forger provided whole ID packets, including Social Security card and birth certificate, for $75. If that's all an illegal alien needs to stay in this country, no wonder there are so many of them. Indeed, there's such a wave of false papers that some people now suggest surrendering to the illegal tide.

title: Dr. Gordon Derner, 68, Dies
description: Psychology Dean at Adelphi

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: ''A sign of the times,'' observes Sol Zatt, who was riding in a cab in Manhattan when an urgent message came over the radio: ''No. 18, call your broker.''

title: Boxing Twins Score
description: Elias and Erick Madrid, California's 20-year-old boxing twins, scored twin knockouts over another pair of boxing brothers Monday night to capture the Pacific Coast lightweight and junior-lightweight titles. Elias, who weighed in at 133 3/4 pounds, knocked out 25-year-old Willie Daw of Vinton, La., in the third round of their bout in Northridge, Calif., and Erick, 128 1/2 pounds, knocked out 23-year-old Elvis Daw in the fourth round. Elias's record is now 13-0 with 11 knockouts, and Erick's is 12-0 with 10 knockouts.

title: FOR KINSEY INSTITUTE, NEW RESEARCH EFFORTS
description: THIRTY years ago today, when universities could still court ridicule and political reprisals for sponsoring research about human sexuality, the Alfred C. Kinsey Institute of Indiana University published ''Sexual Behavior in the Human Female,'' an 860-page book that documented America's changing views on sexual conduct and enhanced the effort to establish sex research as a legitimate field of scholarly inquiry.

title: Cosmos' Protest Denied
description: The North American Soccer League

title: Alaska Pipeline Approval Sought
description: A group that includes two former Alaska Governors said it would seek Congressional approval to build a $26.6 billion all-Alaska pipeline to move natural gas from the state's North Slope oil fields to a tidewater port on Cook Inlet for shipment to potential markets in the Far East.

title: DIVERSIFIED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Becker Group Gets General Manager
description: Michael J. Kugler, chairman of Merrill Lynch Government Securities Inc., has been named general manager of the fixed-income group at A. G. Becker Paribas Inc., the securities and investment banking firm. He has also been named a managing director of the firm.

title: Court Declines to Stay St. Louis Busing Plan
description: A Federal appeals court refused today to delay implementation of the nation's most comprehensive voluntary desegregation plan.

title: Ford to Raise '84 Prices About 2.3%
description: The Ford Motor Company, following the lead of the General Motors Corporation, announced that it is increasing the prices of its 1984 models an average 2.3 percent, or $254, putting the price of the average Ford auto at $11,200.

title: Advertising; 'Peanut' Campaign Awaited
description: IF anyone's heart leapt with anticipation of revelation at the sight of

title: COMCOA INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Short Night's Work Likely for Mancini
description: The crowd, apparently a fair-sized one, will be coming to see Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden. According to one of the few American experts on Orlando Romero of Peru, Mancini's undefeated but suspect challenger, the crowd will not be kept long.

title: RISE IN INSTALLMENT DEBT DURING JULY SET RECORD
description: In July, consumers took on a record $4.84 billion more in installment debt than they paid off, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: FAMILIAR FOG PROVIDES RELIEF TO SWELTERING SAN FRANCISCO
description: Dawn's early light was a happy time today around San Francisco Bay because it revealed a heavy finger of fog that drifted in through the Golden Gate overnight. The fog promised, and delivered, relief from the record heat of the last few days that roasted a city ill-equipped for hot weather.

title: CHRYSLER WORKERS APPROVE PACT WITH $2.42 RAISE
description: Workers at the Chrysler Corporation today approved by a substantial margin a new 21- month labor contract with the company that includes a pay increase of $2.42 an hour.

title: BRAZIL TO MEET BANKERS
description: Brazil will begin negotiations Friday with its commercial bank creditors to sort out its financial requirements for the rest of this year and 1984, Finance Minister Ernane Galveas told a news conference yesterday in New York.

title: Quisenberry Sets Mark
description: Dan Quisenberry, the Kansas City reliever, set a major league record for saves in a season when he recorded his 39th tonight as the Royals beat the California Angels, 4-3.

title: COOKE TO RECEIVE RITE OF ANOINTING OF SICK
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke, who is suffering from terminal leukemia, has asked his aides to administer the sacrament of the Anointing of the Sick on Monday, the Archdiocese of New York announced yesterday.

title: Computer Plan Attracts Former Timex Leader
description: Robert F. Weltzien, a former chairman of the Timex Corporation, has been named chief executive of a company that plans to produce a portable computer.

title: R.K. Gottshall, Former Chief Of Atlas Chemical, Dies at 71
description: Ralph K. Gottshall, former president and chairman of Atlas Chemical Industries in Wilmington, Del., died of liver disease Sunday in the Wilmington Medical Center. He was 77 years old and lived in Wilmington, Del.

title: TV: PREVIEW OF SATURDAY CARTOONS
description: WHERE are your children on Saturday mornings? It is possible they are staring at the tube. Cartoons on television are almost as ubiquitous as the news, although Saturday mornings are their very own. Children as young as 2 and 3, the National Institute of Mental Health says, may spend a lot of time looking at television, and they may continue to do so until they have reached their teens. Their viewing drops off a bit then, but in the meantime they have seen a great many cartoons.

title: MORTGAGE-BOND SHIFT STUDIED
description: The Senate Finance Committee opened hearings today on an alternative to the very popular mortgage subsidy bonds. Supporters said it could save the Treasury about $600 million.

title: Officer at Booz, Allen Going to Venture Unit
description: John Roach has resigned as a vice president and director of Booz, Allen & Hamilton Inc. to become president and chief executive officer of Braxton Enterprises, a venture capital entity formed by George Bennett, chairman of Braxton Inc.

title: Gold Traders Check Files
description: The Alderdice brothers have been allowed out of their jail cells to begin poring over the financial records of their bankrupt gold and silver trading company in an effort to clear themselves of fraud charges.

title: NEUTROGENA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Devils Will Emphasize Youth
description: A new locker room, a new weight room, a spacious new lounge with a large-screen television - all these facilities have been added to the Devils' training center at Ice World in Totowa, N.J., and the Devils' players are smiling over the changes.

title: JACLYN INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 4 percent stock dividend paid in June.

title: CITY'S TOP LEASING OFFICIAL ACCUSED OF EXTORTING BRIBES
description: New York City's director of lease negotiations was arrested yesterday by Federal authorities and charged with trying to extort more than $500,000 from a landlord in return for lining up city agencies as tenants.

title: Guatemala Rejects Talks With Terrorist Group
description: Guatemala's new leader, Gen. Oscar Mejia Victores, rejected pleas today to negotiate the release of his kidnapped sister, and police officials said they had new leads in the case.

title: Manville Gains a Delay
description: The United States Bankruptcy Court extended the Manville Corporation's right to present a plan for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act until Oct. 17.

title: U.S.'S AMERICAN AIRLINES SUIT BARRED
description: A Federal judge has dismissed a suit brought by the Justice Department that charged Robert L. Crandall, the president of American Airlines, with attempting to engage in ''collusive monopolization'' with its competitor, the Braniff International Corporation.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OVER THERE

title: REACTOR CLEANUP AT 3 MILE ISLAND IN FOUND IMPROPER
description: Investigators for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission charged today that the companies involved in cleaning up the Three Mile Island nuclear reactor had circumvented proper procedures and adopted cleanup techniques of questionable safety.

title: THRIFT UNIT WILL TEST INVESTORS
description: One of the largest thrift institutions in the country, the Philadelphia Saving Fund Society, will announce an initial public offering today that could serve as a barometer of Wall Street's enthusiasm for the thrift industry.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: N.B.A. Puts Off Referee's Camp
description: The first tangible inkling of labor problems that could affect the start of the pro basketball season came yesterday with word that a weeklong training camp for referees that was to have begun next Sunday at Westbury, L.I., had been postponed until Oct. 2.

title: Presentations Made To Buckingham Corp.
description: The Buckingham Corporation last week listened to presentations from five agencies interested in handling its advertising for its Scotch, vodka, liqueur and wines.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Acton Corp., Acton, Mass., said it had sold a California cable television system with 2,200 basic subscribers to Falcon Communications, a limited partnership based in California, for $5 million.

title: PROLER INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31

EXCERPTS FROM THE ADDRESS BY SENATOR GLENN ABOUT MIDDLE EASTERN ISSUES Following are excerpts from a speech by Senator John Glenn to a meeting of the Foreign Policy Association yesterday at the Hilton Hotel:
description: The time has come for Arab leaders to face some simple facts. The first of these is that Israel's right to exist is neither open to doubt nor open to question. She is one of our strongest friends and surest allies. Our morality and our national security alike demand that we protect and defend her. So let us say it clearly and let us say it frankly. America's commitment to a free and independent Israel will never fail and never falter. Not for an hour. Not for a minute. Not for an instant.

title: MOBILE PHONE AS OPTION SET ON SOME '84 BUICKS
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it would offer mobile telephones as options in some 1984-model Buick cars. The phones, which will be supplied by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, are the first to be offered by an auto maker as an option, according to the two companies.

title: SELIGMAN & LATZ INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: The Mutual Bank Fiction
description: Shall the proposed amendment to Section Three of Article X of the Constitution, to remove restrictions upon the issuance of capital stock by savings banks and by institutions for savings . . .

title: STAGE: CHILDREN OF 60'S IN WEEKEND REUNION
description: EARLY on in Kathleen Tolan's ''Weekend Near Madison,'' a new play about aging moonchildren of the 1960's, a blocked painter named Jim (Randle Mell) explains his views about art. For art to be vital, he says, it must be ''raw'' and ''without skin'': an artist must create because he has no choice, because his work simply ''had to be done.'' Curiously enough, it is exactly this urgency that proves to be missing from the play that follows. There are patches of lively writing in ''A Weekend Near Madison,'' but the evening seems methodical, not deeply felt. It's a novice playwright's exercise - a paint-by-numbers portrait of its subject, rather than a heated creation.

title: CONSTITUTIONS, THE GOOD AND THE BAD
description: The writing of constitutions is one of the world's growth industries. Of the 160 existing national constitutions, 101 have been established since 1970. This week, the American Enterprise Institute, a Washington-based think tank, has brought together the drafters of many of the non-Communist world's constitutions for a weeklong conference on the art of constitution writing.

title: Hotel Check-In Computerized
description: The Hyatt Hotels Corporation today introduced a computer terminal that allows guests to check in and out of its hotels by using a credit card. ''Response from our guests has been very positive,'' Pat Foley, Hyatt Hotels president, told a news conference.

title: DEREGULATION PERIL TO THRIFT UNITS SEEN
description: The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board told Congress today that an Administration proposal for deregulating the banking industry could threaten the recovery of the nation's thrift industry.

title: A GUATEMALAN DEFECTOR SINGLES OUT CORRUPTION
description: Carrying two Guatemalan passports, a bundle of frayed papers that he says document corruption in the Guatemalan military and a small satchel of clothes, Capt. Erwin Guerra Morales deserted his army and his country the last week in June.

title: FETUS VACCINATIONS REPORTED
description: A fetus can be vaccinated against tetanus by inoculating the mother in pregnancy, a hospital research team said today.

title: U.S. SAYS KILLING OF AQUINO HURT MANILA'S IMAGE
description: State Department officials said today that the assassination of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. had ''beclouded the reputation'' of the Philippine Government and that many Filipinos ''suspect the complicity'' of elements of their own Government in the slaying.

title: With Season Over, Mazzei Seeks Aid
description: The elimination of the Cosmos from the North American Soccer League playoffs here Monday night prompted Coach Julio Mazzei to repeat that the league's most glamorous team was getting older and needed a facelift.

title: Borrowing Needs Reduced
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan confirmed yesterday that economic recovery had helped reduce the Treasury's borrowing needs for the quarter ending Dec. 31. He estimated that the Treasury would need to raise $45 billion to $50 billion of new cash during the quarter, down from the $60 billion to $65 billion projected by Treasury officials last July.

title: REAGAN DIRECTIVE ON SECRECY CRITICIZED BY EX-CARTER AIDE
description: Lloyd Cutler, who was the senior White House counselor to President Carter, criticized the Reagan Administration today for seeking to censor books on national security by former policy-making officials of the Government.

title: Stop the 'Legal' Holdups
description: To a New York bar or bodega owner, the message is menacingly clear. The man on the phone says he represents the police and he needs a contribution for officers' widows and orphans.

title: Operating Net in Japan
description: Operating income of Japanese companies rose 3.3 percent in the second quarter of 1983 compared with the period a year earlier, after a 2.7 percent decline in the first quarter, the Finance Ministry said today.

description: Jeruchem Gorelick, 73, Taught at Yeshiva U. Seminary

title: U.S. HAD NOTICED ACTIVITY BY SOVIET
description: American intelligence agencies were aware of heightened Soviet air-defense activity off the Siberian coast an hour before a Korean airliner was shot down in the area, but did not understand the significance of the Soviet actions until after the airliner had been attacked, senior intelligence officials said today.

title: Out of Sight
description: Largely because the rest of the American League's Western Division has been mired in a six-team slump for much of the season, the Chicago White Sox are now within reach of a record or two.

title: Namath to Make Debut On Broadway in 'Caine'
description: Joe Namath will make his Broadway debut Tuesday in the revival of Herman Wouk's ''Caine Mutiny Court-Martial'' at Circle in the Square. Mr. Namath will be playing the role of Lieutenant Maryk, the officer who is on trial for seizing command of a naval vessel from his superior, Captain Queeg.

title: MACY, R H, & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: The share earnings for both year- earlier periods have been restated for the 3-for-2 stock split of the common shares distributed on April 1, 1983.

title: Cheerleader Injured
description: Zema Williams, a used-car salesman who dresses in Indian garb with a full war bonnet for Washington Redskin games, has become a popular cheerleader at R.F.K. Stadium. But when Williams took his act to Philadelphia on Sunday for the Redskins' victory over the Eagles, he was not well received by some fans.

title: UP BY 5 1/2
description: Bill Swaggerty, pitching in relief in only his second major league game, earned his first victory, and Gary Roenicke belted a grand slam as the Baltimore Orioles took a 7-1 decision from the Boston Red Sox and a doubleheader sweep tonight.

title: John Emmerling Inc. Gains New Business
description: John Emmerling, head of the agency of the same name, plus ''Inc.,'' was all abubble with new- business news yesterday. One was brand new, and two others were additions.

title: Army Tries Ads
description: To promote ticket sales for home games at Michie Stadium, the athletic department at Army tried a week of 30-second promotional ads on two television stations in the Albany area during the final week of August.

title: CRITICS ASSAIL SILENCE LAW FOR SCHOOLS
description: The first two witnesses in a Federal trial on the constitutionality of New Jersey's moment- of-silence law contended today that the statute was educationally unsound and religiously improper and that it would lead to disruptions in the classroom.

description: Following is a list of non-Soviet bloc airlines that have canceled flights to the Soviet Union in response to the downing of a South Korean airliner, and of those that are still flying:

title: SAMUEL C. FEUERSTEIN, 90, NEW
description: Samuel C. Feuerstein, a New England textile manufacturer who was prominent in Hebrew education, died Friday in Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 90 years old and lived in Brookline, Mass.

title: AS SCHOOL BELLS RING, A DAY OF BEGINNINGS AND MEMORIES OF THINGS PAST
description: It was the first day of public school yesterday, a day of rituals and promise for nearly a million children all over the city. At Public School 58, an elementary school in the heart of Brooklyn, it began as it had for the last 26 years, as an event embraced by the neighborhood.

description: People who've won a $1 million or more from the state lottery don't seem to have much else in common.

description: The Reagan Administration, saying that unemployment was ''likely to remain high,'' today endorsed an 18- month extension of the Federal supplemental unemployment benefits program, which expires at the end of the month.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ONE calm August morning while my father in-law was fishing alone in a rowboat on a Minnesota lake that he had known since boyhood, he apparently fell into the water and drowned. His body was not found until three days later, when the funeral and burial were quickly arranged by a family half dumbstruck with grief and half relieved that the days of anguished uncertainty were at last over.

title: OPENER PUT OFF IN CUP SERIES
description: Severe wind shifts across a sparkling sea caused the opening race in the 25th America's Cup defense to be abandoned today. The first race in the four-of-seven-race series is now scheduled to begin at noon on Wednesday.

description: If the Yankees and the Milwaukee Brewers had a more realistic chance of catching the Baltimore Orioles, the two games they have played at Yankee Stadium this week would have glowed with the excitement and the intensity of a World Series.

description: American Health Magazine, which made its debut in March 1981 with Owen J. Lipstein as publisher and T. George Harris as editor, will go into the black on an issue-by-issue basis with the November/December issue now on the presses.

title: Retail Sales Down 1.4% In August
description: Sales by retailers fell 1.4 percent last month, the biggest drop since June 1982, mostly because of a sharp decrease for auto dealers, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: EXPOS WIN AND REGAIN LEAD
description: Bob James earned his first major-league victory, allowing only one hit in four and one-third innings of relief pitching to lead the Montreal Expos to a 5-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

title: INDIANA REACTOR MAY END ERA
description: On a bluff overlooking the Ohio River near the small farming community of Madison in southern Indiana, the Marble Hill nuclear power project is less than half completed and all but overwhelmed by increasing costs and growing uncertainty over how to finance them.

title: DROP MIDEAST 'EVENHANDEDNESS,' GLENN SAYS
description: The United States should stop trying to be evenhanded in the Middle East and give Israel its unequivocal support, Senator John Glenn said yesterday.

title: Adman Faults U.S. Creativity
description: The creative reputation of United States agencies in Europe has been deteriorating rapidly for a decade, a French agency head charged here yesterday.

title: Goalie's Slow Rise to N.H.L.
description: Unlike most Canadian youngsters, particularly those who eventually play in the National Hockey League, Kelly Hrudey didn't spend his grammar school days playing hooky for hockey.

title: Houston Voters Approve Building of Toll Roads
description: A $900 million bond issue to build three toll roads to untangle freeway traffic won easy approval today in a countywide election.

title: A LAVISH SALUTE TO FRANCE OPENS
description: FOR Bloomingdale's, retail diplomacy has become a way of life. In the last five years the store has staged six major storewide promotions tied to the importation of products, art and atmosphere from other countries. Today, after promotions for India, China, Israel, Ireland and the Philippines, Bloomingdale's is kicking off its newest effort, F^ete de France. ''It is,'' said Marvin S. Traub, chairman of the store, ''the largest and greatest promotion we have ever done.''

title: AEROSONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CROSS-BORDER POLLUTION VEXES U.S. AND MEXICO
description: For much of last week, a large cement factory just across the Mexican border in Juarez was filling the air with almost 60 tons of dust pollution a day. And as happens often here, much of it drifted over this Texas city, which has one of the worst air pollution problems in the country.

title: ARMEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
McCormick Oil
description: The McCormick Oil and Gas Company said that its board had approved a reorganization plan involving a transfer of substantially all of the company's assets to a new limited partnership, McCormick Oil and Gas Partnership. The company's assets will be exchanged for units of limited partnership interest, which will be publicly traded. McCormick, based in Houston, said the reorganization plan, which now requires shareholder approval, is part of a plan to phase out its oil and gas exploration activities.

title: Florida Utility's $125 Million Sale
description: The Florida Power and Light Company's $125 million of 12 7/8 percent bonds were offered at a price of 99.81 to yield 12.9 percent to maturity in 2013, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: WHEN THE REAL BICENTENNIAL COMES ALONG
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alpha Industries, Woburn, Mass., has elected Robert M. Goldwasser a corporate vice president.

title: TRAK AUTO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: All sales figures exclude sales of Trak Auto West.

title: ART: 'VIENNA 1900,' THEME AT EDINBURGH
description: The Edinburgh International Festival is not an enterprise as to which I shall feign to be objective. Ever since the festival was first held in the late summer of 1947 - Rudolf Bing was its original director - it has been something that I hate to miss. Simply to be in this great, gaunt city is one of the firmest of metropolitan pleasures. To have the best of music, the best of theater and the best of art heaped into one's lap - morning, noon and night - is to rebecome the archetypal small boy in the archetypal candy store. After close on 30 such festivals, I approach each new one with an undiminished excitement.

title: Koch Gets a Degree For Equanimity During Fire
description: Smoke from a small electrical fire poured into Carnegie Hall in June as Mayor Koch was about to speak at the Polytechnic Institute of New York commencement. In burning-deck stance, he stayed on stage until the last of 2,800 peeple had filed out and then joined them outside until the ceremony could continue.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TEN YEARS LATER Whatever the other achievements of the Richard M. Nixon Administration, it has indisputably fostered the dramatic arts. Few other Presidencies have spawned so many post-Administration productions, most of them small and satirical, but then there is always ''All the President's Men,'' a big book and a big movie. Ten years have passed since Watergate investigation days and, uncoincidentally, this anniversary sets the stage for several shows.

title: The Stakes in Beirut
description: Keeping Lebanon stitched together is a desirable American diplomatic objective but it is not a vital national interest. If that distinction can be preserved, President Reagan's show of aerial force may help to protect the Marines there without incurring foolish new military commitments. If Congress endorses their deployment without pushing the President to exaggerate the stakes, it can hold him to account and also assist his diplomacy.

title: U.S. AND SAUDIS PRESS SYRIA TO AGREE TO LEBANON TRUCE
description: Saudi Arabian and American negotiators pressed Syria tonight to agree to a cease-fire between Syrian-backed Druse militiamen and Lebanese Army troops fighting for control of mountains overlooking Beirut.

title: T.W.A. WILL CUT 3,500 EMPLOYEES
description: Trans World Airlines said yesterday that it would cut its work force by 3,500 employees by the end of 1983 through a combination of furloughs, leaves and attrition, in an attempt to stem its continuing losses.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: WHAT THE WAR POWERS RESOLUTION SAYS
description: Congress passed the War Powers Resolution in 1973 over a Presidential veto. It was a reaction to the Vietnam War and was intended to control Presidential discretion in introducing American troops into hostilities abroad. It has been opposed by every President since then. The deaths of five marines in Lebanon since President Reagan sent them there has raised the issue of whether Congress should now have the opportunity of voting on their continued presence in Lebanon. Here are excerpts from the resolution. Purpose and Policy

title: OPTICAL RADIATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
TRADING IS SLOWER
description: Stock prices ended mostly with small gains yesterday in slower trading. The largest movers were issues that responded to specific news developments.

title: H R S INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes a special gain of $1,607,688. c-Year-ago results were not available because the company changed to a March 31 year.

title: LIBERTY BEATS AUSTRALIA II IN AMERICA'S CUP OPENER
description: Tenaciously using his yacht's sails to block the challenger's wind, Dennis Conner drove Liberty past Australia II midway on the 24.3-mile course and went on to win the opening race in the America's Cup yacht racing series today by 1 minute 10 seconds.

title: THE SHYEST OF SPRING FLOWERING BULBS
description: DAFFODILS and tulips are not the only bulbs that flower in spring. Imagine a garden blooming with glory of the snow, winter aconites, snowflakes, snowdrops, squills and stars of Bethlehem.

title: PERVASIVE HEALTH IMPLICATIONS OF MEDICARE'S FINANCIAL CRISIS
description: To the Editor:

title: Godfather's Pizza Finds Home at Chart House
description: Godfather's Pizza has grown from one pizza place in Omaha to 800 outlets during the last 10 years, and the company's founder has had an even more meteoric rise. Today, it is William M. Theisen, 38-year-old multimillionaire, member of the board of Creighton University, Airport Authority chairman and philanthropist.

title: New Job for Ex-D'Arcy Chairman
description: Out of the Madison Avenue limelight for the last 18 months, John de Garmo, former chairman of D'Arcy-MacManus Masius/ New York, has reappeared as director of strategic planning at Margeotes/Fertitta & Weiss, a 10-year-old agency with a client list of quality names.

title: SCREEN: 'HEAT AND DUST,' SET IN INDIA
description: ''India changes a person,'' someone says in ''Heat and Dust,'' just as other travelers from the West have been saying in fiction about India for the last 100 or so years. What makes the old line so poignant in this fine new film is the understanding that the changes wrought by India aren't necessarily accidental, involuntary or even very mysterious. Instead, they've been sought out by generations of tourists, some less heedless than others, who, as often as not, are infatuated by an idea of India long before they set foot on the subcontinent.

title: NO DIGNITY FOR KILLERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Southland Trial Delayed
description: A Federal judge yesterday postponed until Nov. 14 the trial of the Southland Corporation, one of the nation's largest retailers, on a charge that it conspired to bribe New York State tax officials to fix sales-tax cases involving its 7-Eleven convenience-store chain.

title: A SHOW OF WOODEN CARVINGS, GOOD FOR A SMILE
description: Roy Superior, a Yale-trained artist, recently turned to woodcarving and whittling for relaxation. His wooden sculpture pieces, which can best be described as fantasy machines and improbable inventions, are currently at the Heller Gallery as part of a two- person show on view through Oct. 2.

title: Body of Diver Found in Warship
description: The body of a 43-year-old Manhattan scuba diver was recovered yesterday from the wreckage of a heavy cruiser that was sunk 10 miles off Fire Island during War War I by a German submarine, a Coast Guard spokesman said.

title: INVITING WAR
description: Even if the ''first use'' of nuclear weapons is not to NATO's advantage, does not the threat of such use help deter a Soviet nuclear attack and would not the removal of the threat increase the risk of war?

title: KOCH IS ANGRY AND WON'T ATTEND
description: The chairman of a House subcommittee said yesterday that next Monday's hearing on allegations of police brutality against black New Yorkers would be held in a state armory in Harlem. Mayor Koch immediately responded that he would not attend.

title: PLASTIC COMPOUND MAY BE REVIEWED
description: A major inquiry is expected to be authorized Thursday by the Consumer Product Safety Commission into the potential health hazard posed by an animal carcinogen found in most pliable plastic products, including many plastic products used by infants.

title: Times Co., Warner in TV Pact
description: The New York Times Company and Warner Communications Inc. said yesterday that they had formed a joint venture to produce and distribute informational programming for cable television.

title: Robert Kennedy Begins Drug-Abuse Treatment
description: Robert Kennedy Jr. disclosed today that he was under hospital treatment for drug abuse.

title: G.M. Sees Car Sales Rising
description: In his first sales forecast in almost three years, Roger B. Smith, the chairman of the General Motors Corporation, predicted today that 13.5 million cars and trucks would be sold in the United States during the 1984 model year, a 15 percent improvement over the 1983 model year.

title: MGIC IS MORTGAGE PIONEER
description: The MGIC Investment Corporation has had a rough year, but the company has long been a leader in the home mortgage insurance business.

title: Chrysler to Pay Preferred Dividends
description: The Chrysler Corporation, in a move that would eliminate the last obstacle to its paying a common stock dividend, said today that it would pay $116.9 million in current and past dividends on its $2.75 cumulative preferred stock.

title: KILLING OF WITNESS IN INQUIRY ATTRIBUTED TO 'POLITICAL' TIES
description: A witness in a Federal investigation was slain last year to protect a ''political connection,'' a prosecutor in State Supreme Court in the Bronx said yesterday.

title: KIT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: THE WEEK THE CIRCUS HAD TO STAY IN TOWN
description: The 10 lions, three elephants, 10 dogs and 50 men, women and children of the stranded Hermanos Suarez Circo simply could not be booked into the Bee County Jail.

title: Marshall Islands Vote Backs Independence
description: Nearly 60 percent of the Marshall Islands' 8,000 voters approved an agreement to end 36 years of United States rule, nearly complete returns showed today.

title: U.S. NAVY PRESSING SALVAGE EFFORT TO RECOVER DEBRIS NEAR SAKHALIN
description: The United States Navy has undertaken an urgent effort to recover wreckage of the South Korean airliner shot down by a Soviet fighter, with priority assigned to finding the plane's two crash-resistant data recorders, the Defense Department said today.

title: Chinese Airport Collision Kills 10 and Injures 21
description: A domestic airliner carrying 100 passengers collided with a military plane just before taking off from the southern city of Guilin today, killing 10 people, the official New China News Agency reported.

title: NEW BAN, OLD LID
description: Close Encounter, 1930

title: U.S. OFFICIAL ASSERTS TEACHERS SHOULD BE EXPERT IN SUBJECTS
description: A leading education official in the Reagan Administration has issued a call for states to require that all prospective teachers have ''degrees or demonstrable expertise in the subjects they plan to teach.''

title: ART VERSUS HEALTH CARE, A QUESTION OF PRIORITIES
description: For the past 50 years, various Government agencies have earmarked a small portion of their construction funds for artwork in public places, often a mural in a lobby or a statue in a courtyard.

title: SHUBERT CONSIDERS OFFER TO OPERATE THE MARQUIS
description: The Shubert Organization, the largest theater owner on Broadway, has now been offered the chance to operate the Marquis Theater, the first to be built on Broadway in more than a decade, according to the Marquis's owners.

title: THOR ENERGY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $26,000 for the quarter and $54,000 for the 6 months.

title: BRITISH APPROVE SOTHEBY SALE TO ALFRED TAUBMAN TO U.
description: The British Government today removed the last official obstacle to the $125 million purchase of Sotheby Parke Bernet, the international auction house, by Alfred Taubman, an American multimillionaire.

title: DANCE: JAMAICA TROUPE
description: THE National Dance Theater Company of Jamaica is no stranger to New York shores but oddly, this unusual company had never performed in Manhattan until last night when it opened a run through Sunday at the City Center.

title: TORO CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $466,000. c-Net loss.

title: NORTH HILLS ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings reflect several stock splits including a 3-for-2 stock split effective Aug. 5.

title: Continental Offers A Stock Plan
description: Continental Airlines, in a move to win further concessions from its workers, announced a stock plan that would allow its 12,000 employees to own up to 12 million shares of stock, or 35 percent of outstanding common.

title: FIANCEE OF $7 MILLION ROBBERY SUSPECT IS ARRESTED
description: The fiancee of a Wells Fargo security guard accused of stealing $7 million in cash from a company depot here Monday was charged tonight with hindering the prosecution, the police announced.

title: PLANE UNRELATED TO ARMS TALKS, MOSCOW ASSERTS
description: A senior Soviet official said today that it was ''wishful thinking'' for the West to hope that outrage over the shooting down of a South Korean airliner would prompt the Kremlin to make concessions in medium-range missile talks in Geneva.

title: Bridge: An Unusual No-Trump Bid Won Attention in Honolulu
description: If a partnership has a 4-4 fit in a major suit, it is virtually automatic to play game in that suit rather than no- trump. Even world champions have trouble diagnosing the rare situations in which no-trump is preferable.

title: TV: NEW 'WOMAN TO WOMAN' SERIES
description: ''WOMAN TO WOMAN,'' a new syndicated series being offered in the New York City area by WABC-TV on Mondays through Fridays at 10:30 A.M., is certainly a step in the right direction for daytime commercial television.

title: COMPUSCAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $193,000. c-Includes a gain of $296,000 from the extinguishment of debt and a tax credit of $460,000.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: IF walkways slope enough so that they are hazardous when wet, snowy or icy, weatherproof outdoor steps are the best remedy. Outdoor steps may also be needed to make it easier to reach raised decks, porches or patios or to move between levels in graded areas.

title: KENAI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Reject the Poison Gas Ploy
description: The House has a chance today to rebuke a backstage legislative maneuver and avoid a dangerous competition in a loathsome weapon: poison gas. But to do so, it has to take the unheard-of step of rejecting a House-Senate conference report on the entire $200 billion defense authorization for 1984.

title: Quaker Oats Gets A New Chairman
description: The Quaker Oats Company, the big marketer of food, pet foods and toys, announced yesterday that its chairman, Robert D. Stuart Jr., would step down Nov. 9 at the company's annual meeting.

title: BANK RATES OFF SLIGHTLY Interest rates on money market deposit accounts declined slightly nationwide in the seven-day period ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.
description: The Monitor's nationwide average this week, based on a survey of 50 large institutions in the five largest United States markets, was 8.65 percent. Last week, it was 8.67 percent, the same as the previous week.

title: West Berlin Honors Owens
description: The West Berlin Senate has decided to name a major thoroughfare in honor of Jesse Owens, the American who starred in track at the 1936 Olympics in Berlin. The wide street leading to the Olympic Stadium will be renamed Jesse Owens Avenue.

title: AMFESCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid June 12.

title: 512K CHIP DEVELOPED BY I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday an experimental version of a new computer memory chip that has twice the capacity of any chip yet reported: a 512K-bit dynamic random access memory chip that stores 524,288 bits of information.

title: 230 Fine At Foodshow
description: The DDL Foodshow on Columbus Avenue opened in a blaze of publicity less than a year ago. Now the Health Department has found seven code violations, slapped a $230 fine on the elegant establishment and warned that it might be closed down if the violations were not corrected before Sept. 26.

title: FOR $8.77, A PRESIDENTIAL THANK YOU
description: It turns out that President Reagan has his own sort of social safety net. It was extended by a Californian he has never met named Ronald E. Roseveare, a man who accidentally received the electric bill for Mr. Reagan's ranch, and chose to pay it.

title: PROBATION OFFICER IN MONTANA DISMISSED OVER HIRING FRAUD
