description: A Lewis and Clark County probation officer has been dismissed after it was found that he had contracted to stay married to a veteran for 30 days to receive the state's absolute hiring preference for veterans and their families.

title: Market Place Bright Outlook For Chemicals
description: CHEMICAL stocks, benefiting from a variety of factors, have traded lately at their best prices in years. On Monday, for example, Dow Chemical and E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the nation's largest chemical producer, reached new highs since 1981. Somewhat earlier, American Cyanamid and Monsanto sold at record prices.

title: Cuomo Sees Difficulties On Westway
description: Governor Cuomo said today that it was possible that New York could end up with neither the Westway project nor Federal funds for mass transit.

title: TEXT OF CONGRESS'S RESOLUTION ON KOREAN JET
description: Following is the text of Congress's joint resolution on the Soviet Union's downing of the South Korean airliner. The House approved the resolution today by a vote of 416 to 0, and the Senate was expected to vote on it Thursday.

title: COMMUNICATIONS & CABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company is 80 percent-owned by the Cenvill Development Corp.

title: MORTGAGE GROWTH INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes gains of $403,000, or 12 cents a share, and $354,000, or 12 cents a share, for the latest and year-earlier periods, respectively, from the sale of real estate investments.

title: GARDEN PARTY FOR MANCINI
description: They have raised themselves two flights above the harsh realities of the streets of New York, but it's still a long way to the top. So when a world champion comes around to the crowded gym on 42d Street where young boxers train and wait for a break, it rekindles the faith that dreams are made of.

title: Thomas B. Schlesinger Dies; Was Official at Williamsburg
description: Thomas B. Schlesinger, director of news services of the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation in Williamsburg, Va., died of complications Monday after a brain aneurism at Williamsburg Community Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in Williamsburg.

title: Detective Faces Charges in Assault
description: A detective was suspended without pay yesterday on charges that he assaulted a bystander who made a derogatory remark as police officers were fired on in the Bronx on Aug. 20.

title: CLERIC IN JERSEY OPPOSES STATUTE ON PUPIL SILENCE
description: A leader of the Baptist church in New Jersey testified in Federal District Court today that the state's minute-of-silence law would inevitably lead to prayer in the public schools.

title: NEWCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed May 10.

title: BIG THREE AUTO SALES CLIMB 20%
description: The nation's Big Three automobile manufacturers reported today that sales for the first 10 days of September were up 20 percent from very weak sales in the same period a year ago. Analysts expressed optimism for the the fourth quarter and for 1984.

title: Boesky Buys Into HMW Industries
description: A group led by the Ivan F. Boesky Corporation, an investment banking concern based in New York City, has acquired 9.76 percent of HMW Industries' 1.6 million common shares outstanding, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In the filing, Boesky said the shares were purchased from Katy Industries on Aug. 24 for $38 a share and were purchassed for risk arbitrage and investment purposes.

title: SOVIET RETALIATES OVER AIRLINE CURBS
description: With most Western air links to Moscow due to be cut off Thursday, the Soviet Government retaliated today by refusing to accept air tickets issued in the United States and by branding the boycott a new chapter in Washington's ''anti- Soviet psychosis.''

title: DWG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: STAMPEDE INTERNATIONAL RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $168,297 for the latest year and $1,205,550 for the earlier year primarily from the public offering of the company's Thermodynetics Inc. unit.

title: Twins to Be Host To All-Star Game
description: The Minnesota Twins, who last played host to the annual All-Star Game in 1965, will do so again in 1985, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn announced yesterday. The 1985 game will be held in the Twins' new home, the Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome. The 1984 game is scheduled for Candlestick Park in San Francisco.

title: STATE JURY FINDS 3 RADICALS GUILTY IN BRINK'S KILLINGS
description: Three radicals who said they were fighting for black liberation were convicted here today of murdering two policemen and a Brink's guard and stealing $1.6 million from an armored car in Rockland County nearly two years ago.

title: Toro Company Reports Profit
description: The Toro Company, citing the successful introduction of several new products, yesterday announced earnings of $320,000 in its fourth fiscal quarter ended July 29, in contrast to a loss of $100,000 in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. The Minneapolis-based producer of lawn and maintenance, irrigation, and snow removal equipment said that sales in the latest three months rose 6.7 percent, to $54.1 million, from $50.7 million.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 15, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: MUSIC: RUDOLF SERKIN PERFORMS BEETHOVEN
description: TO open each season, the New York Philharmonic traditionally puts on a gala benefit concert for the orchestra's pension fund, with the aid of a universally admired soloist, if possible. Last night the attraction for a richly turned out audience was an old favorite, Rudolf Serkin, playing Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 1 in C under the baton of Rafael Kubelik.

title: TOPPS CHEWING GUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
A JOLT TO MEDIA GENERAL IMAGE
description: Media General presents itself as a straight-arrow place where all employees and executives must subscribe yearly to the publishing, broadcasting and newsprint company's written code of business ethics.

title: NEW YORK WARNED ON U.S. ROAD FUNDS
description: New York State must change its laws by Oct. 1 to allow heavier trailer trucks on interstate highways or it will lose $750 million in Federal highway money, transportation officials said today.

title: Israeli Slain in Hamburg
description: A gunman shot an Israeli businessman in the back Tuesday night as he approached the front door of his home, killing him instantly, the police said today. The dead man was identified as Efi Halpern, 46 years old.

title: FORMER REAGAN WORKER REFUSES TO UNDERGO HYPNOSIS IN INQUIRY
description: An aide in Ronald Reagan's 1980 campaign has refused a request by Federal investigators that she be hypnotized to help her recall an incident in which campaign materials prepared for President Carter may have been delivered to Reagan workers.

title: Hard-Hat Hero
description: All of a sudden the horns went off on Rhode Island Sound and boats started cruising closer and closer to the slender 12- Meter yacht. It was like New Year's Eve on Main Street, except for the surging wakes that splashed from boat to boat.

title: PLANNED PARENTHOOD DELETED FROM FEDERAL CHARITY DRIVE
description: The Federal Office of Personnel Management today ousted Planned Parenthood from its annual Federal employee charity drive, handing anti-abortion groups a major victory.

title: BALANCE COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BALDWIN TO SELL MGIC UNIT
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation, under pressure from regulators to generate cash, said yesterday that it would put its MGIC Investment Corporation up for sale.

title: CENVILL DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
THE PRIDE OF PEOPLE'S POLAND: ITS PRINCELY STEEDS
description: In People's Poland, Arabian horses are still aristocrats.

title: SERVAMATIC SOLAR SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: UNIVERSAL MONEY CENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss. Results for the latest quarter and 6 months include costs and expenses of $107,600 for the quarter and $223,300 for the 6 months from the company's foreign subsidiary, Universal Money Centers PLC.

title: ULTRASYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
KILLEARN PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Jersey Educator Named
description: Dr. Robert E. Boose, Superintendent of Schools of Mercer County in New Jersey, has been nominated by Gov. Joseph E. Brennan to become Education Commissioner of Maine. Dr. Boose, 37 years old, would succeed Harold Raynolds Jr., who has become Commissioner of Education in Alaska. Dr. Boose, whose nomination must be approved by the State Senate, said he hoped to start work here in November.

title: MARTHA MCSTEEN, CAREER OFFICER, MADE ACTING SOCIAL SECURITY HEAD
description: Margaret M. Heckler, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, today named Martha A. McSteen, a career civil servant, as acting head of the Social Security Administration.

title: FALL RETAIL SALES OFF TO SLOW START
description: Fall apparel sales, often a barometer of the all-important Christmas season, have gotten off to a slow start. Consumer interest in colder-weather clothing has been hurt by hot temperatures in recent weeks, merchants say, resulting in reduced shopper traffic through apparel departments.

title: AMERICAN CENTURY TRUST reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After tax credits of $2,416,000 for the latest year and $1,599,000 for the earlier year.

title: Bush, in Algiers, Says U.S. Respects True Nonalignment
description: Vice President Bush said today that the United States respected genuine nonalignment but rejected the idea of a ''natural alliance'' between nations that espouse nonalignment and the Eastern bloc.

title: GROUPS SEEK TO HALT RELEASE OF BACTERIA WITH ALTERED GENES
description: Environmental advocates have filed suit against the National Institutes of Health to invalidate the agency's approval of the first release of genetically altered bacteria into the open environment.

title: B.B.D.O. Departure
description: Richard B. White, after 29 years with Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, the last seven as an executive vice president, will leave the agency at the end of the year to pursue the long-contemplated second career. He is 53 years old and is also chairman of the executive committee of B.B.D.O. Inc. and a member of its board.

title: MCNAMARA CALLS ON NATO TO RENOUNCE NUCLEAR ARMS
description: Former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara said today that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization should renounce the use of nuclear weapons, which he said ''serve no military purpose whatsoever,'' and rely solely on nonnuclear forces to deter a conventional Soviet attack against Western Europe.

title: WITH BEGIN ILL, LEVY BECOMES THE ACTING PREMIER OF ISRAEL
description: Deputy Prime Minister David Levy took over as acting leader of Israel today in place of Prime Minister Menachem Begin, who is ailing. The 70-year-old Mr. Begin, who has announced his intention to quit but has not yet formally resigned, has not left his official residence for a week. ''The Prime Minister does not feel well, that is not a secret,'' said Mr. Levy, 45 years old, who recently unsuccessfully challenged Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir to succeed Mr. Begin as head of the Herut Party. Mr. Levy took over as acting Prime Minister, but Mr. Shamir was expected eventually to replace Mr. Begin in the top job. Mr. Levy said authority was transferred to him to act as Prime Minister under Israeli law. The law states that when a prime minister is unable to fulfill his duties or is outside the country, the deputy prime minister takes over.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
TABLES THAT FOLD AWAY WHEN THE MEAL IS OVER
description: FOR PEOPLE with limited floor space there are some ingenious tables available that fold away to practically nothing when not in use and open up to become useful working and eating surfaces.

title: 6 DEMOCRATIC CANDIDATES AFFIRM THEIR COMMITMENT TO ISRAEL
description: Responding to questions from Mayor Koch, six candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination have affirmed their commitment to Israel. The candidates also agreed that the Federal Government should assume at least some additional responsibility for financing health and welfare programs in the United States.

title: Ballet Hispanico Debut
description: Two world premieres will mark the Oct. 4 debut of the Ballet Hispanico at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street.

title: Time Inc. Cable Magazine Fate
description: The fate of Time Inc.'s newest magazine entry, TV-Cable Week, is expected to be decided today at the company's regular monthly board meeting, sources at Time said. Time officials declined to say whether the magazine was on the agenda.

title: ARMY OFFICIAL CALLS WESTWAY DELAY UNAVOIDABLE
description: Col. Fletcher H. Griffis of the Army Corps of Engineers spent last weekend in his study on Governors Island poring over books on marine biology and stacks of staff reports. The colonel, the corps's engineer for the New York district, was trying to refute a scientific recommendation that further studies be made on striped bass in the Hudson River.

title: No Headline
description: PERPETUAL MOTION. By Graeme Gibson. 283 pages. St. Martin's Press. $12.95.

title: Soviet Contests Are Called Off
description: An exhibition game between the United States Olympic hockey team and the Soviet national team, scheduled for Joe Louis Arena Dec. 5, was canceled today in protest of the destruction of a South Korean airliner.

title: TRANSNET CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
UNITY BUYING SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $885,148 from the final sale of the Camarillo, Calif., property during June. c-Net loss.

title: STRUGGLE OVER FATE OF A WRIGHT HOUSE
description: FOR residents of Highland Park, Ill., the presence of a Frank Lloyd Wright house in the neighborhood has become as much of a nuisance as a visual delight. The 1902 Willits House, considered by architectural historians to be Wright's first prairie-style dwelling, has been for sale for three years.

title: WHY ARE WE IN LEBANON
description: A Lebanese Moslem who prospered in the construction business, Rafiq Hariri, launched a charitable project near his home town of Sidon: a $300 million hospital and college. Last spring Phalangist Christian militiamen visited the site. At gunpoint they took bulldozers, tractors, trucks and other equipment. Phalangist leaders made clear that Mr. Hariri was suspect because of his religion and his business activities in Saudi Arabia.

title: COAST DEMOCRATS SPURN G.O.P. DEAL
description: The California Legislature wound down its most partisan session in years today amid signs that both Democrats and Republicans expect the State Supreme Court to block the scheduled Dec. 13 statewide vote on a legislative redistricting plan.

title: THE CRIMINAL STIGMA OF FINGERPRINTING CHILDREN
description: To the Editor:

title: Utility to Cut Rates By 6.6% More
description: The Public Service Electric and Gas Company agreed today to decrease its natural-gas rates $13.1 million more than a $74.2 million reduction already pending before the State Board of Public Utilities.

title: THEATER: NEW SERBAN 'UNCLE VANYA'
description: THE people who inhabit the country estate of ''Uncle Vanya'' can run and run, but no matter where they run, they can't escape. What they face at every turn are the ruins of their aspirations, the crushing ordinariness of existence, the heedless march of time. As the estate's owner puts it, the place is as imprisoning as a labyrinth - and that's just what Santo Loquasto has designed as a set for Andrei Serban's new production of Chekhov's play at the La Mama Annex.

title: ; WHAT AN INDUSTRIAL POLICY REALLY MEANS
description: To the Editor:

title: HERS
description: THE membership committee of a business and professional club was considering what object might make an attractive bonus for new members. I suggested a canvas bag. ''Men won't carry it'' was the immediate consensus. At first I pushed my point. ''Plenty of men carry Channel 13 bags,'' I argued. But even as I spoke, my mind's eye had trouble visualizing great numbers of men with bags in hand, while the image of women carrying all manner of totes was an easy one to conjure. I retired my suggestion and have since given a lot of thought to why it is that women - in Simone de Beauvoir's words, ''the second sex'' - are also ''the schlepper sex.''

title: TURKISH TRIBUNAL IS TOLD OF PRISON HUNGER STRIKE
description: Inmates of a military prison in this eastern Turkish city have told a military tribunal that at least 100 prisoners have been engaged in a hunger strike since Sept. 2 in protest against ill treatment.

title: WHEELCHAIRS IN CITY'S SUBWAYS AND THE COST OF REDOING STATIONS
description: The New York City subway system has 465 stations, 6,400 passenger cars and what seem like a million stairs. It is the stairs that keep people in wheelchairs from using the stations, boarding the trains and getting around the city underground.

title: DART DRUG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $8,300,000, or $4.97 a share, from the sale of assets.

title: HAMILTON GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a $400,000 special loss provision on guarantee of bank loans of Mexican companies and a $325,000 tax credit. c-Net loss

title: Bank Lacking Insurance Fails
description: An unregulated, uninsured bank in this southeastern Iowa town has been closed by the state because of bad loans, most of them made to drought-stricken farmers.

title: HARVEY GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-After loss from discontinued operations of $686,000. c-Net loss after loss from discontinued operations of $767,000.

title: BRIEFING
description: The President and Elmer

title: U.S. Won't Stop Movie Venture
description: The Government said it would not try to halt an effort by Home Box Office Inc., CBS Inc. and Columbia Picture Industries to team up on the production and licensing of movies.

title: Problems for Cowboys
description: Ticket sales to Dallas Cowboy home games have been lagging, and, according to the team's president, Tex Schramm , it's all because of fan disenchantment resulting from last season's strike and a series of off-season published reports linking Dallas players to drug use. ''The strike and the drugs turned a lot of people off,'' said Schramm, who still has 5,000 tickets available for the home opener against the Giants on Sunday. . . . Meanwhile, on the field, the Cowboy coach, Tom Landry , has some special worries of his own this week - the disappointing play of the Cowboy special teams.

title: WHAT AN INDUSTRIAL POLICY REALLY MEANS
description: To the Editor:

title: ALBERT BRADLEY, EX-CHAIRMAN OF GENERAL MOTORS, DIES AT 92
description: Albert Bradley, a former chairman of the General Motors Corporation who played a key role in the early development of the company's operations overseas, died Sunday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 92 years old.

title: PROFITING FROM MISTAKES
description: THE name on the windows is OOPS, and the acronym stands for Originals on Permanent Sale. But what's an OOPS? ''An OOPS is a showroom sample, discontinued or overstocked piece of furniture, something with slight or severe damage, a canceled order, an item that came in the wrong size or color, or the result of a computer or typist's error,'' explained Dinah Martin, above, who has just opened a 3,200-square-foot space, designed by Gregory Turpan, on La Guardia Place, near Bleecker Street.

title: CON ED IS PERMITTED TO BURN COAL IN CITY
description: New York State yesterday approved a Consolidated Edison Company application to burn coal at two generating plants in the city that now use oil.

title: TERRA COTTA ADDS COLOR TO CITY BUILDINGS
description: THERE is more and more talk of color in architecture and there is more and more talk of ornament in architecture - both of these elements yearned for, it would seem, as means of giving the buildings we make today something of the elan of the architecture of the past. If one material has always seemed able to yield both color and ornament - and, indeed, has been absolutely crucial to the architecture of the last hundred years - it is terra cotta, that baked clay that can be molded and fired into almost anything.

title: REITMAN'S (CANADA) LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Arms Sale to Egypt
description: The Department of Defense told Congress today that it planned to sell Egypt 16 ship-launched Harpoon missiles, two training missiles and associated parts and equipment for $40 million.

title: Japan Industrial Output
description: Japan's July industrial production index, base 1980, was revised upward to 103.8, seasonally adjusted, from a preliminary 103.6, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

title: REAGAN ASSURES ITALY ON MISSILE PACT
description: In a letter made public today by Prime Minister Bettino Craxi's office, President Reagan assured Italy of his continuing ''deep commitment'' to reach an accord with the Soviet Union on limiting medium- range nuclear missiles despite the shooting down of the South Korean airliner.

title: TAX RISES PROPOSED IN FRANCE
description: France's Socialist administration today proposed a surcharge of up to 8 percent on high-income taxpayers plus an increase in other taxes and social security charges, and it said the country faces another year of austerity.

title: BEADS LINK BAHAMAS ISLAND TO COLUMBUS TRIP
description: Beads and other ancient European-made items found by American archeologists could be the long-awaited proof that Columbus made his 1492 landing in the New World on the Bahamian island of San Salvador.

title: Australian Incentives
description: The Australian Government plans to encourage high-risk technological ventures with federal tax incentives, the Industry and Commerce Minister, John Button, said today.

title: Althea Captures Del Mar Futurity
description: The 2-year-old filly Althea jumped ahead early and ran away from a field of four colts in posting a 6 1/2- length victory today in the $229,615 Del Mar Futurity.

title: Navy Captain Removed From Admiral's List
description: The top officer of the Navy's Tidewater medical facility has been relieved of his duties and denied promotion to rear admiral because of investigations into his administration at two Navy hospitals, the Navy said today.

title: Waiting for a Grade
description: Although he is still waiting for a key grade, Arkansas basketball officials said they were confident that their top freshman prospect, Kenny Hutchinson , would be academically eligible to play for the Razorbacks this winter. Hutchinson, who starred for Martin Luther King High School in New York City, maintained the 2.0 high school average the National Collegiate Athletic Association requires for freshman athletic eligibility, according to Coach Eddie Sutton , but he still needs a high school diploma. The coach said the diploma had been held up pending the grading of a New York Regents competence test that Hutchinson took in August.

title: UPSTARTS OF THE ROAD
description: A swarm of vans buzzes up and down Boulevard East on the west bank of the Hudson River during morning rush hours, darting in and out of traffic, scooting past buses and whisking away Manhattan- bound commuters before the lumbering buses can get to them.

title: L.I.AideIsSuggested For a U.D.C. Agency
description: Governor Cuomo today recommended the appointment of the Town Supervisor of Huntington, L.I., Kenneth C. Butterfield, to head a subsidiary of the Urban Development Corporation.

title: ISRAEL AFTER BEGIN
description: Israel needs an election.

title: HOME COMPUTERS; A STUDY OF EFFECTS
description: ARE home computers placing greater strain on American families? Or has the arrival of computers in the home ushered in an era of togetherness for Mom, Dad and the little ones and opened up a new world of electronic family fun?

title: Fight Against Apartheid
description: Arthur Ashe and Harry Belafonte, with other athletes and performing artists, urged their colleagues yesterday to join a newly organized boycott of South Africa to protest apartheid.

title: Reds Sign Soto
description: Mario Soto has signed a five-year contract that will make him the highest paid Cincinnati Reds player in the team's history.

title: Domingo Rewarded For His Effort
description: San Francisco came to New York yesterday. A representative of Mayor Dianne Feinstein, Charlotte Mailliard, had come to declare Placido Domingo Day there and gave the tenor the key to San Francisco - all at a ceremony at the Hotel Pierre.

title: ROYAL PALM BEACH COLONY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Memorial for Buddy Young
description: A memorial service for Claude (Buddy) Young, the former football star killed in an automobile accident Sept. 4, will be held at 11 A.M. next Tuesday at Christ Church, 520 Park Avenue, near 60th Street, the National Football League said yesterday. The funeral for Mr. Young, who was the league's director of player relations, was in Chicago last week.

title: LADD FINDS CONSISTENCY AFTER GLORY
description: Nearly a year after Peter Ladd helped the Milwaukee Brewers reach the World Series and made Cumberland County Jail in Maine one of the most famous prisons in the country, there is hardly any aspect of his baseball career that has remained unchanged. His team, his weight, his success, all of them have gone up and down. One thing has been consistent.

title: CONCERT: 10 PIANOS
description: THE composer Wendy Chambers delights in good-natured spectacle. Her massive works are one part music, one part conceptual art and one part shrewd public relations. On Tuesday night, Miss Chambers presented her latest extravaganza, ''10 Grand,'' on the north plaza of Lincoln Center.

title: Zoeller, on a 63, Leads Vegas Golf
description: Fuzzy Zoeller shot a nine-under-par 63 and took a one-stroke lead today after the first round of the new $700,000 Las Vegas Pro-Celebrity Classic over the Showboat Country Club course, one of four desert layouts being used for the five-day, 90-hole event.

title: JAZZ: THREE SINGERS AT FAT TUESDAY'S
description: THE triple-layered jazz vocal program that brings together Sheila Jordan, Helen Merrill and Shirley Horn at Fat Tuesday's, Third Avenue at 17th Street, through Sunday, is an unusual opportunity to sample three of the more prominent contemporary jazz singers in close conjunction.

title: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 15, 1983
description: Companies

title: TRAFALGAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Includes depreciation and amortization of $691,000 for the latest quarter and $824,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: PRESIDENT PRESSED TO SEEK APPROVAL FOR MARINES' ROLE
description: Senate Democrats called on President Reagan today to acknowledge that the War Powers Resolution had been set off by attacks on the United States marines in Lebanon and to ask for Congressional approval for keeping the marines there.

title: C H B FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
Boating Family
description: Three generations of Kalibats will be vitally concerned with the outcome of the Class 5 division of the $50,000 Chrysler Laser Classic 200 powerboat races in the waters around New York on Sept. 24.

title: GYM EQUIPMENT FITS IN A HOME
description: THE windowed dining room of Robert E. Dorf's 173-year-old brownstone in Greenwich Village recently developed a dual personality. One half, with cozy fireside, remains the place in which meals are served. However, the other, where a large shiny machine looking something like a high-tech Jungle Gym stands, has been transformed into a sophisticated home exercise center.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Ampal-American Israel Corp. has elected Ephraim Reiner chairman following the resignation of Jacob Levinson.

title: DEMOCRATS PUSH JOBS LEGISLATION
description: Democratic leaders joined today in an attempt to generate backing for a bill they say would create a half-million jobs within 45 days.

title: OPEC Study Of Price Pact
description: The monitoring committee of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is to meet here Thursday to assess how recent increases in production by the group are affecting its six-month-old price agreement and output quotas.

title: 2 Women Slain In Family Quarrel
description: A Queens man shot and killed his wife and mother-in-law with a shotgun after a domestic quarrel in their home at 119-22 233d Street shortly before 7 o'clock last night, the police said.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Mesa in a Bid To KN Energy
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company announced that it had bought, in a private transaction, 3.9 percent of the shares of Denver-based KN Energy Inc., and had offered to acquire all the rest of KN's outstanding common through a tax-free exchange that would give KN holders 3.5 Mesa shares for each KN share.

title: Key Rates
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: EL CHICO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
description: b-Some year-ago figures are not available because the company was a unit of Anheuser-Busch Cos. at that time.

title: Thrift Unit Issue Is Oversubscribed
description: The Philadelphia Saving Fund Society, one of the nation's largest thrift institutions, said yesterday that its initial public offering of 30,252,159 shares, priced at $11.25 a share, was sold out. Underwriters were led by Salomon Brothers.

title: BRIEFS
description: American Syn-Fuels Inc., Federalsburg, Md., said it had agreed in principle to acquire an ethanol manufacturing facility from Bardestown Fuel Alcohol Co., Bardestown, Ky., which is operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Treasury Issues Ebb Again
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds declined for the third consecutive day, and losses in that time have more than eliminated the sharp price gains that occurred late last Friday after the Federal Reserve announced a $2 billion decline in the nation's basic money supply.

title: Technology; Making Tasks In Factory Fit
description: THE need to keep busy in the American factory is considered fundamental by most workers and managers. An idle person or machine is equated with loss of output, productivity and profit. And a great pile of partly completed orders is a symbol of industriousness akin to the belching smokestack of yesteryear.

title: SARGENT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $527,000.

title: INTERMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Airline Finds Defects In 747 Emergency Rafts
description: United Airlines will restrict its Boeing 747s from flying over water, beginning immediately, because of problems discovered in the use of emergency life rafts, the airline announced today.

title: Mortgage Certificates Attract Pension Funds
description: The nation's largest-ever securities offering, $1.5 billion in mortgage participation certificates issued by the Los Angeles-based Financial Corporation of America, quickly sold out yesterday through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation and Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: 3d Man Gets Term In Killing of Black
description: A 20-year-old Brooklyn man was sentenced yesterday to three to nine years in prison for assault and other charges arising from the fatal beating of a black transit worker by a white group on a Brooklyn street last year.

title: BASING A DESK ON A PAIR OF FILE CABINETS
description: WHEN not studying in bed or on the floor, students have been known to work at a desk, especially if it's roomy, well-lighted and their own. It need not be a bulky, ready-made desk when a wood slab over file cabinets will meet the scholar's needs. The lines are clean, the size is adjustable and the entire system is simple to disassemble for moving.

title: PACESETTING COMPUTER MAKER FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: The Osborne Computer Corporation, the upstart that introduced the briefcase-sized portable computer, announced yesterday that it had filed for bankruptcy. It was the first in what analysts said could become a series of failures in the heavily competitive personal-computer industry.

title: Wildflowers Blooming In Heart of Brooklyn
description: It's intended as New York's wildflower garden but for 20 years it was simply what could be called a tanglewood. Yesterday, however, visitors to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden were able to stroll on log-bordered trails through its newly opened local flora section, a 2.5-acre sampling of the ecology within a 100-mile radius of the city.

title: Minor to Major
description: A lot of minor leaguers have been called up to the majors in the last couple of weeks, but when the high-flying Chicago White Sox called up six regular players from their Denver farm club, one minor league owner didn't think the move was done to improve Chicago's chances to clinch the American League West championship. According to A. Ray Smith, the owner of the Louisville Redbirds of the American Association, the call-up was done ''deliberately'' to undermine one of Smith's pet projects, the new Class AAA World Series round- robin that begins tonight among the champions of the American Association (Denver), the International League (Tidewater) and the Pacific Coast League (Portland).

title: PRESIDENT ACCUSES SOVIET ON '62 PACT
description: President Reagan contended today that the Soviet Union and Cuba had repeatedly violated a 1962 agreement that ended the Cuban missile crisis by continuing to ship ''offensive weapons'' into the American hemisphere.

title: QUANEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: WORKSHOPS ON CARPENTRY AND FURNITURE MAKING
description: Beginning this month, several workshops on home carpentry and repairs and furniture making are being offered in Manhattan. Apartment Carpentry. A 10-session workshop will teach basic skills to enable participants to complete projects at home. Sessions will cover putting up shelves, hanging pictures on plaster or brick walls, installing draperies and constructing bookcases.

title: A Way Out of the Civil Rights Feud
description: President Reagan has been battling civil rights groups for more than a year about his power to replace members of the Civil Rights Commission. That power isn't spelled out in law and Senator Arlen Specter, the Pennsylvania Republican, offers a sound compromise to end the feuding.

title: CALENDAR: KILIMS FROM THE UKRAINE
description: Ukrainian Kilims Exhibition , the Ukrainian Museum, 203 Second Avenue at 12th Street, 212-228-0110. Beginning Saturday, tapestries made between World Wars I and II, when Ukrainian artists and weavers were reviving the traditional nomadic craft, will be on display. Included are 15 handwoven kilims of hemp, linen, wool and cotton with geometric patterns and plant motifs. The exhibition also includes a kilim from the 1870's.

title: Jerseyan Named For U.S.Judgeship
description: President Reagan today nominated Maryanne Trump Barry, the first assistant United States attorney for New Jersey, to be a district judge in Trenton.

title: RULING BACKS PRIVATE POWER
description: A Federal agency, in a major reversal of policy involving ownership of hundreds of hydroelectric plants, decided today that private, investor-owned utilities should generally be allowed to keep billions of dollars worth of facilities they have built and operated for decades.

title: 6 ARE NAMED BY THE TIMES TO NEW POSITIONS AS EDITORS
description: Promotions and assignment changes in the news department of The New York Times were announced yesterday by A. M. Rosenthal, the executive editor.

title: LEASES FOR U.S. COAL ATTRACT FEW BIDDERS IN MONTANA AUCTION
description: The Interior Department's auction of Federal coal mining leases, undertaken by Interior Secretary James G. Watt in defiance of a House Committee resolution, was held here today, but four-fifths of the coal tonnage failed to attract bids.

title: Annual Meeting Now Important
description: The National Football League's annual fall meeting, scheduled for Oct. 5 and 6 in New York, is normally a routine affair. In some years, the executives from the 28 teams don't even stay in town for the second day.

title: CHILE CANCELS POLITICAL DISCUSSION PROGRAM ON TV
description: Only hours before a television station was to present a new program of political discussion on Tuesday, the Government prohibited the broadcast.

title: DOCTOR CURBED BY HOSPITAL HE HELPED FOUND
description: A 74- year-old doctor who still travels the scrubby ranch land of west Texas making house calls has been barred from the emergency room of the hospital he helped found.

title: Army Women Prevail On Earrings on Duty
description: The Army has decided that women in uniform may wear earrings as long as they are not gaudy and ''fit snugly against the ear.''

title: EX-SHERIFF GUILTY IN TORTURE CASE
description: James C. Parker, 47 years old, the former sheriff of San Jacinto County, and two of his deputies, John Glover, 65, and Carl Lee, 63, were convicted today of conspiring to violate the rights of prisoners by subjecting them to water torture.

title: Portuguese Leader Off for U.S.
description: President Antonio Ramalho Eanes left today for a six-day visit to the United States, the first such trip by a Portuguese head of state.

title: 'Clinically Dead' Man Lives
description: A 57-year-old golfer diagnosed ''clinically dead'' when he was struck so hard by lightning that his nylon socks melted was revived by paramedics who struggled to save him for 40 minutes, officials said today. The man, Joseph M. Burke of West Palm Beach, was in poor condition today at John F. Kennedy Memorial Hospital in nearby Atlantis.

title: Unity Liquidation
description: The Unity Buying Service Company, a mail order company based in Hicksville, L.I., said that its board had adopted a plan to liquidate the company and distribute all the cash generated to its shareholders. Unity said that it intends to make a public offering of substantially all the shares of its Mail Marketing and Fulfillment subsidiary and a similar offering or a private sale of another subsidiary, Beautiful Visions Inc. It also said it would sell off its factory buying club, its distribution complex in Georgia and its remaining assets.

title: Q&A
description: Q. One room in our 80-year-old house has an embossed tin ceiling with several coats of paint on it. In many small spots the paint is peeling, but we are afraid that scraping will harm the raised pattern, and stripping all the paint off seems an insurmountable task. Also, we have been told that stripping will result in ''flash rusting.'' What is the best way to prepare this ceiling for repainting?

title: U.S. URGED ISRAEL TO ATTACK DRUSE POSITIONS
description: The United States asked Israel, on behalf of the Lebanese Government, to use its military forces, including air power, to attack Druse positions in the Shuf Mountains about a week ago, Administration officials and diplomats said today. The Israelis refused, they said.

title: U.S. to Delay Spraying Chemical on Marijuana
description: The Reagan Administration has agreed to stop spraying marijuana with paraquat, a weed killer, for the rest of the growing season, a Justice Department official said today.

title: NORDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $53,000 for the latest quarter and $243,000 for the year- earlier period. c-After income from discontinued operations of $39,000 for the latest period and $62,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: U.S. TO REPLACE ENVOY TO BRITAIN
description: The United States Ambassador to Britain, John J. Louis Jr., was informed by Washington today that he was being replaced after 30 months in a diplomatic assignment that is regarded as a plum.

title: George L. Roehr Dead; Principal at Newspaper
description: George L. Roehr, a principal owner of the parent company of The Press and The Sunday Press of Atlantic City, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Lincoln, Mass. He was 52 years old.

title: CHANGES APPARENT AT E.P.A.
description: There seems to be a new look to the way the Environmental Protection Agency perceives and approaches the nation's hazardous waste problem since William D. Ruckelshaus took over the embattled agency nearly six months ago.

title: BIOTECH CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for As of June 30
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: Article 166931 -- No Title
description: A $1 million program to provide support for five neighborhood community organizations here was announced today. It will be financed by the Ford Foundation, two Pittsburgh philanthropies and the City of Pittsburgh.

title: ACCORD ON A SALE DENIED BY GENERALS
description: J. Walter Duncan, principal owner of the New Jersey Generals, said today no agreement has been reached with the New York lawyer who claims he has arrived at a tentative agreement to purchase the club.

title: USING SUBTITLES WITH LIVE OPERA
description: THEY'VE been doing it in films for many years, and more recently in televised opera. Subtitles in English are thus nothing new. But now the New York City Opera is bringing the concept of subtitles to actual performances at the State Theater.

title: Troops in El Salvador Retake Strategic Town
description: The army retook the strategic southeastern town of Jucuaran today, ending a weeklong fight with rebels, officials said.

title: BankAmerica
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, in what it says is the first multibrand approach to marketing traveler's checks, said it would soon offer its 30,000 sellers worldwide Visa and Mastercard traveler's checks in addition to its own BankAmerica traveler's checks. In announcing the new program, James B. Wiesler, head of BankAmerica's retail banking division, said, ''This expanded product line will strengthen BankAmerica's position as one of the largest issuers of traveler's checks in the world.''

title: JETS REPLACE BLINKA AS STARTER
description: It had been Stan Blinka's proudest boast: He had started at middle linebacker in every game he had been a Jet, except for a one-game suspension.

title: Broken Hill Rejects Bid
description: The board of the Broken Hill Proprietary Company today urged rejection of an offer from Wigmores Ltd.

title: Advertising; Sponsor's Role Set For G.M.
description: DESPITE the fact that it is the country's third-largest national advertiser, the General Motors Corporation has never sponsored a television show itself. Various divisions, such as Chevrolet, yes. But the whole company, never.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Joe Namath, the former Jets' quarterback, entered a not-guilty plea yesterday in Beverly Hills, Calif., to a charge of drunken driving. Namath was arrested Aug. 20 in West Hollywood. Namath did not appear at the arraignment in Municipal Court, but his attorney, John Gaines , entered the plea and a pretrial hearing was set for Oct. 20.

title: WHAT SOUTHERN GUILT?
description: Birmingham, Ala., where the 16th Street Baptist Church was bombed 20 years ago today, is being revisited. In most such civil rights retrospectives, a black elected official or an interracial gathering is marveled over, and headlines declare progress. The ''buts'' of black unemployment and racial voting patterns can't dampen the upbeat message: The sinners have repented. The four black girls bombed at the church did not die in vain.

title: PROVOCATIVE NEW FURNITURE DESIGNS FROM THE MILAN FAIR
description: With designs that ran the spectrum from the silly to the sensitive, from the classical to the brash, the 23d Salone del Mobile Italiano once again proved true to its reputation for originality and inventiveness. The giant six-day furniture show, which included both Euroluce, a lighting show, and Eimu, an office furniture display, began here a week earlier than usual, and many of the Milanese were just getting back from their summer vacations as it opened on Saturday. While some visitors saw the event as marking a year of austerity in Italy - a period of reflection for designers in a time of recession - there were still plenty of lively new designs.

title: SOMETHING FOR EVERYONE AT BOAT SHOW
description: Whether you are a millionaire yachtsman or an occasional angler who would like an inflatable boat that could be tucked away in the closet of your apartment, Norwalk's 1983 International Boat Show - which opens today and continues through Sunday - has something to titillate your imagination.

title: French Prices Rise
description: French retail prices rose five-tenths to six-tenths of 1 percent in August after an increase of nine-tenths of 1 percent in July, the Statistics Institute said today. The figures show that for the 12 months to August prices rose 9.6 to 9.7 percent after a rise of 9.4 percent for the 12 months to July.

title: INVENTORIES ROSE 0.2% IN JULY
description: Inventories held by United States businesses rose two-tenths of 1 percent in July as sales fell for only the second time this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: MARINE ROLE IN LEBANON: NEW OPTIONS AND RISKS
description: Military Analysis

title: BOSTON POLICE TROUBLES RISE IN DISPUTE OVER '75 SLAYING
description: The Boston Police Department is embroiled in a major controversy, including the threat of a police strike, as an outgrowth of a 1975 incident in which two officers killed a black man.

title: Gallup Poll Reports Decline In Mondale Lead Over Glenn
description: Walter F. Mondale's lead over Senator John Glenn for the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination dropped by seven percentage points from June to August, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: EATON VANCE INVESTORS FUND INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Chamber Music at the Y Will Open 10th Season
description: The 10th season of ''Chamber Music at the Y'' opens on Oct. 25 at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, with a program featuring Schubert's Octet and Weber's Clarinet Quintet in B flat major.

title: MARIJUANA'S DRAWBACKS IN TREATING GLAUCOMA
description: To the Editor:

title: Yugoslavs Get Rest of Loan
description: Yugoslavia has received the last $200 million of a $500 million bridging loan granted by the Bank for International Settlements last March, a bank spokesman said today. The first $300 million, which was backed by guarantees from major Western central banks, was disbursed several months ago.

title: Kicking Bounces
description: At this time of year in the National Football League, for every player who receives good news there is another who receives bad.

title: SCIENTIFIC SOFTWARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Dollar Bonds Little Changed
description: - Fixed-interest dollar bonds traded in a narrow range today as investors remained fearful of the possibility of a large rise in the United States money supply.

title: Soviet River Captain Sentenced to 10 Years
description: A 10-year prison sentence has been passed by a Soviet court on the captain of a river liner that struck a railroad bridge with the loss of more than 100 lives last June 5, the newspaper Sovetskaya Rossiya reported today.

title: Deposit Survey Puts Compliance at 82%
description: More than 80 percent of the beverage containers examined immediately after New York State's new deposit law went into effect Monday carried proper refund labels, according to a survey by the New York Public Interest Research Group.

title: MEXICO SET TO REVAMP TROUBLED AUTO INDUSTRY
description: The Mexican Government today announced a major reorganization of its troubled automobile industry intended to reduce reliance on imports and achieve ''internationally competitive scales'' of production.

title: ARGENTINA FACES SHOWDOWN
description: A provincial judge, a politically cowed military and the ire of foreign bankers are all part of an international tug-of-war that threatens to put Argentina into default Thursday.

title: Jersey Penalizing 14 School Districts
description: Fourteen school districts that allowed seniors to graduate this summer before they had completed the required 180 days in class will be penalized $2,545 for every day of noncompliance, it was announced today.

title: TWO NEW POLITICAL ANTAGONISTS EMERGING IN CHILE
description: Chile's new Interior Minister, who is 63 years old, is locked in a political struggle with a 29-year-old labor leader who was imprisoned Friday on charges of defaming the Government.

title: Deficits Hurt, Feldstein Says
description: Underscoring his dispute with Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, President Reagan's chief White House economist said today that huge Government budget deficits were driving up interest rates and ''doing very substantial damage'' to American industry.

title: Transactions
description: AUTO RACING

title: ADVANCE CIRCUITS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-Net loss. c-Net income.

title: HOUSE CONDEMNS SOVIET IN 416-0 VOTE
description: In a rare display of bipartisan unity, the House voted 416 to 0 today to condemn the Soviet destruction of Korean Air Lines Flight 007 as ''one of the most infamous and reprehensible acts in history.''

title: U. OF TEXAS REACHES 100 RIDING HIGH
description: The University of Texas, a once provincial school that has gained a reputation as a major intellectual center, threw a huge party today for its 100th birthday with a convocation, marching bands, barbecue and an eight-foot-tall orange-and- white birthday cake shaped like the university tower.

title: ANIXTER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ANOTHER LOOK AT THE SYSTEM AND STRATEGY
description: To the Editor:

title: Planned Parenthood Regains Status in U.S. Charity Drive
description: Federal District Judge Joyce Green temporarily reinstated the Planned Parenthood Federation to the Federal charitable campaign today, and Government lawyers then suggested they would fight the case no further.

title: AS A COMPUTER MARKET FRAYS
description: The declaration of bankruptcy by the Osborne Computer Corporation was the first spectacular failure in a shakeout in the personal computer industry that is bound to hit many others, according to analysts and executives.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Upset By Lisa Bonder
description: Top- seeded Chris Evert Lloyd, beaten by Martina Navratilova in the final at the United States Open last Saturday, failed to find her game today and was upset by Lisa Bonder, a 17-year-old American, in the second round of the Queen's International tennis tournament. The scores were 7-5, 4-6, 6-4.

title: A Swami Flies Over The Berlin Wall
description: An Indian swami carrying purple chrysanthemums flew his motorized kite over the Berlin wall to East Germany today ''to prove that love and flowers can overcome barriers better than bombs.''

title: ALEXANDER NAMES HEAD FOR TROUBLED HOWDEN
description: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., the big insurance broker, announced yesterday that it had named Richard M. Page to head its troubled London subsidiary, the Alexander Howden Group.

title: SENATE DEMOCRATS SET TO FORCE ISSUE OVER WAR POWERS
description: Senate Democrats moved tonight to force President Reagan to seek authorization under the War Powers Resolution to keep marines in Lebanon. The action came after the failure of repeated attempts earlier in the day to work out a compromise with the White House.

title: MISS AMERICA AND 2 NEW ABC SERIES
description: LOVE it or leave it, ''The Miss America Pageant'' rolls on as one of television's perennial blockbusters. The 56th annual event will be carried live from Atlantic City tomorrow evening at 10 o'clock on Channel 4. Once again, the finalists can be seen in a variety of evening gowns, swimsuits and talent displays. The gimmick this year will be the reunion of 30 former Miss Americas, including Lee Meriwether, who won in 1955, the first year the pageant was carried on television. Gary Collins will serve as host, singing ''She's Our Miss America'' as the winner strolls, no doubt tearfully, down the runway. ABC Introduces Two New Series

title: THE VERY LATEST IN BOMBS AND ROCKETS AND RADARS AND RADIOS AND
description: ''May I help you, sir?'' the smiling salesman asked, moving enthusiastically toward the browser who was bent over the floor model, peering intently.

title: LOUISE BROOKS RETURNS IN 2 CLASSICS
description: The German cinema of the 1920's was responsible for some of the great silent-film classics. It was also responsible, at least indirectly, for ending the career of one of America's great silent stars - Louise Brooks.

title: U.S. TELEPHONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: FRENCH EXPECTED TO SELL IRAQ JETS
description: France has decided to go forward with plans to supply Iraq with jet fighters that Western experts fear may intensify the Iran- Iraq war, French and Arab sources said today.

title: I.B.M. INTRODUCES GLENDALE COMPUTER
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday introduced the first of its long-awaited series of midsized computers at prices that industry analysts said would increase pressures on competitors that are already suffering from smaller profit margins.

title: 3D AVENUE FESTIVAL SET
description: More than a million people are expected to throng a milelong stretch of Third Avenue on Sunday in the eighth frolic of eating, shopping and entertainment that is formally known as the Third Avenue Street Festival.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The mastery of English is the first and most essential goal of education.

title: FOREST CITY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PHILS TIED FOR FIRST AFTER LOSS TO EXPOS
description: Before the Montreal Expos played the Philadelphia Phillies tonight, their catcher, Gary Carter, declared, ''We have to win tonight or else we are in trouble.''

title: S.E.C. Alters Oil Rules
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted revised rules today allowing oil and gas producers using the full-cost accounting method to delay amortizing costs of operations where energy reserves are still unknown. The S.E.C. staff said the effect of the rule change would be to permit companies to show lower expenses and higher profits from a given discovery in the early years of its development, although reported expenses would be increased in the later years of the project's life, lowering profits at that time.

title: TRAVELERS STRANDED IN SOVIET SEEK NEW WAYS HOME
description: Travelers from around the world lined up at ticket offices here today in search of new routes home as Western restrictions on flights in and out of the Soviet Union went into full effect.

title: People
description: * Arthur X. Tuohy appointed a senior vice president of Benton & Bowles.

title: Ring Computers
description: The computer age came to the boxing ring, or at least to the edge of it, at Madison Square Garden last night for a card that featured Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini's defense of the World Boxing Association's lightweight title.

title: DOLE IS SAID TO SUPPORT A $12 BILLION TAX BILL
description: The chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Bob Dole of Kansas, has decided to move ahead on a token tax increase that would raise about $12 billion over three years, Congressional staff members said tonight.

title: 16 Injured in Ammonia Blast
description: An ammonia tank exploded at an ice plant today, injuring 16 people, two critically, the authorities said.

title: FRIENDLY FROST INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
AFGHANS EXPEL 2 U.S. DIPLOMATS
description: The State Department said today that the United States Embassy in Kabul was told two American diplomats were being expelled on charges of spying.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES Insurance, AAA Rating Reduce Hospital's Costs
description: The Hollywood Presbyterian Hospital Center, a nonprofit hospital in Los Angeles, became the first hospital to sell bonds insured by a unit of the Crum & Forster insurance group.

title: Poland Bars Sending Of Underground Texts
description: The Ministry of Communications today issued an order forbidding telex users, including foreign correspondents, from transmitting Solidarity underground statements.

title: Ex-WNYC Head Returning to Post
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that Mary Perot Nichols had been named director of WNYC, the municipal radio and television system.

title: QUESTIONS REMAIN AFTER USA TODAY'S FIRST YEAR
description: USA Today, a nationally distributed general-interest newspaper that has been loudly mocked and quietly mimicked, marked its first birthday yesterday, turning aside industry questions about whether its financial losses imperiled its future.

title: HUNT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Dome Names President
description: Dome Petroleum has appointed John Beddome as president to succeed W. E. Richards, who resigned last week. The appointment of Mr. Beddome, 53, puts a new two-man team at the top of the financially troubled oil and gas group, which for more than a year has been negotiating with its Canadian and American lenders to reschedule its $6.3 billion (Canadian) debt.

title: SELF-REFUTING CHARGES
description: To the Editor:

title: MARCUS CORP reports earnings for 12 wks Aug 18
EAGLE-PICHER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
BY THE YARD, FRANCO IS FIRST
description: If a yard is a yard is a yard, Franco Harris has surpassed Jim Brown as the leading rusher in National Football League history.

title: AN AILING BEGIN SUBMITS HIS FORMAL RESIGNATION
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin submitted his formal resignation today to President Chaim Herzog, setting in motion the process of choosing a new Prime Minister and a new Government.

title: 1,400 PAY MUSICAL TRIBUTE TO HOWARD DIETZ
description: Friends, admirers and family of Howard Dietz filled the 1,452-seat Imperial Theater on West 45th Street yesterday afternoon for a musical tribute to the lyricist, who died July 30 at the age of 86.

title: Mottram 'Fed Up'
description: Buster Mottram, Britain's top- ranked player, said he was giving up big-time tennis, though he would continue to lead Britain's Davis Cup team and play in smaller tournaments. The 28-year-old Mottram said that he was ''fed up with the hassle'' of chasing computer points and that he had had enough of the grind.

title: MCGUIRE IS INCEASING STAFF OF COMPLAINT REVIEW PANEL
description: Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire has agreed to increase the staff of the Civilian Complaint Review Board by almost 25 percent to reduce a backlog of cases, the board's executive director said yesterday.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Problem With Timing

title: MONSTER POWER IN 'STRANGE INVADERS'
description: ''STRANGE INVADERS,'' which opens today at Loews State and other theaters, is a tasteful monster movie with a terrible secret: it eats other movies.

title: A NEW LOOK AT LEBANON
description: The crisis in Lebanon has reached a turning point and requires a full new policy review.

title: PARK WORKERS REMOVING FELLED TREES IN THE BRONX
description: Enormous tree trunks, some as large as seven feet in diameter, are lying on the ground in Crotona Park in the Bronx. Broken branches dangle precariously from the tops of trees.

title: American and Japanese Share the Kreisler Prize
description: An American and a Japanese shared top place today in Austria's Fritz Kreisler violin competition, an event that attracts some of the best young violinists in the world.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Friday HOUND AND HORN AND ART

title: PRICE CUTS EXPECTED AT APPLE
description: Apple Computer Inc. will cut by 18 percent the price of its new Lisa computer in an attempt to stimulate lagging sales of the innovative but expensive machine, industry sources said yesterday.

title: Prices Up in O.E.C.D.
description: Consumer prices in the 24 nations that make up the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development rose four- tenths of 1 percent in July after an increase of three-tenths of 1 percent in June, the O.E.C.D. said today.

title: BURLINGTON COAT FACTORY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: TELESPHERE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income The results for the 6 months and second quarter include interest income of $617,000 and $539,000, respectively, compared to $273,000 and $215,000 in the year-earlier 6 months and quarter, respectively.

title: NATO'S USELESS NUKES
description: As early as l955, an exercise called ''Carte Blanche'' simulated the use of 335 tactical nuclear weapons in a European war, with 80 percent of the warheads detonated in West Germany - as would be likely in the event of a Soviet invasion.

title: U.S. Prison for Broker
description: The Federal Bureau of Prisons has ordered Edward P. Wolfram Jr., a former official of the bankrupt Bell & Beckwith stock brokerage, to serve his 25-year sentence for stock fraud in stricter security than the trial judge recommended. Mr. Wolfram was sentenced last week in United States District Court to serve the sentence in a minimum security prison. But prison officials, who make the assignments, ordered Mr. Wolfram to report Sept. 30 to the Federal penitentiary at Tallahassee, Fla.

title: EXCERPTS FROM CARNEGIE FOUNDATION'S REPORT ON U.S. PUBLIC HIGH SCHOOLS
description: Following are excerpts from ''High School: A Report on Secondary Education in America,'' released here today by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching:

title: EAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
AT THE MOVIES
description: 'Pandora' star delighted that Lulu's back.

title: Reagan, in Note, Says Begin Was 'a Source of Inspiration'
description: President Reagan said today that Prime Minister Menachem Begin ''has been a source of inspiration'' and wished him well in his retirement.

title: Albert F. Hegenberger, An Aviation Pioneer
description: Albert F. Hegenberger, an aviation pioneer who made the first nonstop flight from California to Hawaii, has died at a nursing home at the age 87.

title: COGENIC ENERGY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: AEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: POP/JAZZ
description: FADS come and go in pop music, but the basics change far more slowly. For the last quarter-century in black pop, two styles have grown up side by side - funk and vocal-group music. This weekend's Budweiser Superfest will present one concert of each style at Madison Square Garden, with Rick James and the Stone City Band headlining a funk concert tonight and the O'Jays topping a vocal-group bill tomorrow. Both shows will begin at 7:30 and continue until 1 A.M.

title: Sri Lanka Lifts Curfew
description: The Government said today that it was lifting a night curfew enforced since ethnic violence broke out in July between the majority Sinhalese and the minority Tamils.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: HINDERLITER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: POLL FINDS COUNTRY CONFUSED ON JET DOWNING
description: Americans are displaying a mood of frustration and contradiction over the Soviet downing of the South Korean airliner on Sept. 1, a New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows.

title: BARCO OF CALIFORNIA (CO) (O) reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
FLICKINGER, S M, CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Cancer's Link to Diet Examined by Scientist
description: Natural poisons, including some that cause cancer, may be 10,000 times as common in the human diet as man- made pesticides, a University of California biochemist said in a scientific paper to be published Friday.

title: Westway in a Fishy Net
description: What questions can Army Engineers ask the striped bass in New York harbor that the fish will answer in two years? That's the added time the Corps unreasonably asks before it will pronounce the piscatorial effect of filling in 200 acres of the Hudson River to accommodate the Westway Interstate Highway.

title: PRESSURE GROWING TO REMOVE MARTIN
description: Strong dissatisfaction with Billy Martin among members of the Yankees and his apparent failure to produce a pennant this year have led George Steinbrenner to seriously consider ending Chapter III of the manager's tenure, sources close to the club said yesterday.

title: DANCE: THE GLENN LUND COMPANY
description: THE Glenn Lund Dance Company presented a fast-paced program on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater. Yet all its lively dancing was to no avail because of the vague choreography of its directors, Laura Glenn and Gary Lund.

title: Sabo Takes Met P.G.A.
description: Ed Sabo of the Country Club of Fairfield, playing in his final Izod Metropolitan P.G.A. Championship, shot a three- over-par 73 today to win the 54-hole tournament with a 212.

title: PACT ON SPENDING BOND ISSUE MONEY IS VOTED IN ALBANY
description: The State Legislature ratified a plan tonight for spending the money from a proposed $1.25 billion bond issue to rebuild and expand highways, roads and bridges.

title: Credibility Gap
description: When he was convicted of assaulting a woman in San Antonio in 1978, he was just 15 years old, he had a clean record, and his promise to reform was so moving that the judge suspended the youth's 10-year sentence and placed him on probation. When the young man came back to court yesterday to plead guilty to violating that probation, his promise to reform was just as fervent, but the judge had heard it before.

title: MANCINI A WINNER BY KNOCKOUT IN 9TH
description: In boxing's version of chicken- counting, it helps to know how to duck. A news conference was called for next Monday morning to announce Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini's next fight, even before the 22-year-old World Boxing Association lightweight champion began last night's title defense against Orlando Romero.

title: A Record Gap In Payments
description: The broadest measure of United States foreign trade showed a record deficit of $9.7 billion in this year's second quarter, according to Government figures released today, and Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige predicted that the deficit for all 1983 would be a record $30 billion, Last year's deficit was $11.2 billion. In its report, the Commerce Department attributed the huge shortfall mainly to a widening in the deficit for trade in merchandise as exports declined and the United States stepped up imports of a ''broad range of commodities.'' Today's report on the nation's balance of payments includes trade in services and the balance on various other financial transactions as well as trade in oil, manufactured goods, farm produce and other merchandise.

title: Key Rates
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Coleco Test Delay
description: Testing on Coleco Industries' new Adam home computer printer has been delayed until today or early next week, the Federal Communications Commission said.

title: NU-TECH INDUSTRY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
A Million Times
description: A high-spirited bunch of song writers, each with one or more tunes broadcast over a million times, gathered at the Helmsley Palace Hotel yesterday for their annual awards. More than 500 songs had reached this status before another 52 were added last year, according to Broadcast Music Inc., which protects songwriters' performance rights and gives the awards.

title: STAGE: 'GALAS,' NEW PLAY BY RIDICULOUS COMPANY
description: HAVING spent the past few seasons impersonating neurotic middle-aged men, Charles Ludlam has decided to jump into women's clothes again. But not just any woman's clothes. In ''Galas,'' his new play at the Ridiculous Theatrical Company, Mr. Ludlam has wrapped himself in the extravagant gowns and furs of Maria Magdalena Galas - a larger- than-life opera diva whose dramatic singing career is matched only by her tumultuous offstage adventures with the rich and mighty Greek shipping tycoon Aristotle Plato Socrates Odysseus (known to his friends as ''Soc'').

title: TIME INC. TO ABANDON ITS TV-CABLE MAGAZINE
description: TV-Cable Week, the ambitious television-listings venture that Time Inc. began only five months ago, will cease publication with the Sept. 25 issue, Time announced yesterday.

title: CRANSTON ASSERTS U.S. IS VIOLATING O.A.S. CHARTER BY AIDING REBELS
description: In a broad attack on Reagan Administration policy in Latin America, Senator Alan Cranston accused the Administration yesterday of violating the charter of the Organization of American States by providing funds for the ''covert war'' in Nicaragua.

title: Schedule Debate
description: For several years, teams in the American League have been playing what is called a ''balanced schedule'' - that is, a team plays virtually the same number of games against clubs in the other division as it does against clubs in its own division. A curious way, some people believe, to determine divisional titles.

title: NU-MED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $36,000.

title: DELTA QUEEN STEAMBOAT CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss includes a loss of $896,000 from the after-tax effect of an accounting change.

title: U.S. Sugar Offers $68 for Each Share
description: The United States Sugar Corporation, the nation's largest producer of raw cane sugar, said yesterday that it would make a cash tender offer for up to 3.6 million of its 4.9 million outstanding shares, at $68 a share, to turn a ''substantial portion'' of the company over to its employees.

title: U.S.-Japan Farm Talks
description: The United States and Japan today ended two days of farm trade talks here, apparently still far apart on American demands that Japan ease its quotas on beef and citrus imports.

title: ALLIES PRESSING U.S. ON I.M.F. BILL
description: Western Europe and Japan have told the Reagan Administration that they will block a $6 billion emergency loan to the International Monetary Fund because they want to put more pressure on Congress to approve an $8.4 billion increase in the United States contribution to the I.M.F.

title: FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The year-ago share earnings was restated to reflect 3-for-2 stock split effective Feb. 25, 1983.

title: FROM BILLY BARNES TO MABEL MERCER WITH LOVE
description: CERTAIN pop voices crystallize a particular ambience and sensibility with an intensity that can transport an audience back into a world that exists more in memory than in fact. Billy Barnes, the pianist and singer who was Mabel Mercer's accompanist from 1965 to 1972, is such a voice. Listening to him play and sing at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, where his affectionate tribute, ''To Mabel Mercer With Love,'' has been extended through tomorrow, one can practically scent the twilight air of Manhattan in the early 1960's and imagine mingling with the cafe society that embraced Miss Mercer as its queen of pop musical manners.

title: Indians' Move Possible
description: The Cleveland Indians, whose principal owner, F.J. (Steve) O'Neill, died last month, will be sold ''to the right buyer,'' but ''a sincere effort'' will be made to keep the club in Cleveland, according to a trustee of a charitable corporation that is to receive O'Neill's 60 percent interest in the club. However, the trustee, O'Neill's nephew, Patrick O'Neill, warned that the club might be moved if new Cleveland buyers could not be found.

title: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 16, 1983
description: International

title: Soaked Business Card Of U.S. Victim Found
description: The Japanese police said yesterday that searchers combing the shores of Hokkaido Island had recovered a business card belonging to one of the 61 Americans aboard the South Korean airliner shot down by a Soviet fighter two weeks ago.

title: Orioles Halted; Lead at 5
description: Wade Boggs, the major league's batting leader, highlighted a 15-hit attack with a double and two singles tonight as the Boston Red Sox defeated Baltimore, 7-1, snapping the Orioles' six-game winning streak. The loss trimmed Baltimore's American League East lead over idle Detroit to five games.

title: America's Cup Reigns Over Tranquil Scene
description: The object of all the excitement in Newport, the America's Cup itself, sits through it all, a trifle forbiddingly, on West 44th Street at the New York Yacht Club.

title: ; ANOTHER LOOK AT THE SOVIET SYSTEM AND STRATEGY
description: To the Editor:

title: STUDY ASKS TIGHTER CURRICULUMS
description: The Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching today called for significant changes in American high schools, beginning with tightened curriculums and the improvement of salaries and working conditions for teachers.

title: Reagan Praises Paterson Principal
description: President Reagan called the principal of Eastside High School in Paterson today to commend him for his tough approach to discipline.

title: WHERE TO FIND THE APPLES
description: Following is a list of pick-it-yourself apple orchards open this weekend compiled by The New York Times, the Department of Agriculture and Markets of New York, and the Cooperative Extension Service of New Jersey: Connecticut Hartford County: Bell Town Orchards, South Glastonbury, (203) 633-2789; Minor's Farm, Bristol, (203) 589-0861. Litchfield County: Hallock Orchards, Washington Depot, (203) 868-2244; Terekook Farm, New Preston, (203) 868-2648. New Haven County: Bishop's Orchard, Northford, (203) 484-9801; Joseph Flynn, Northford, (203) 484-0220; Bishop Farms, Cheshire, (203) 272-8243; Hickory Hill Orchards, Cheshire, (203) 272-3824; Ives Orchards, Wallingford, (203) 634-0825; C. O. Young & Sons, Wallingford, (203) 269-3865.

description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLISHING: REVERSAL OF RULING TROUBLES AUTHORS
description: IN a decision hailed by book publishers but questioned by the Authors League, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit unanimously reversed a lower court decision that Prentice- Hall failed properly to advertise and to promote one of its books, ''Du Pont: Behind the Nylon Curtain,'' by Gerard Colb Zilg.

title: Wang Stock Deal
description: Wang Laboratories Inc. said it had sold 530,800 shares it owned of Tymshare Inc. stock and said it had canceled its previously announced plans to acquire more than $15 million worth of the stock. The shares sold, which represented about 4.3 percent of Tymshare stock, were worth about $10 million, Wang said. Analysts had suspected that Wang was interested in taking over Tymshare.

title: GOLDEN WEST HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-New loss.

title: Dressing for the Occasion, With a Bit of Help
description: A New York-bound executive from the West Coast, trying to make it in time for Wednesday's opening concert of the New York Philharmonic, was changing into his tuxedo on the plane when he made a discovery: no cuff links and no shirt studs.

title: College to Honor Reagan
description: President Reagan, who will attend a fund-raising reception and dinner next Tuesday for Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, will also receive an honorary degree from the University of South Carolina, the White House said today. The degree will be granted to honor the President's efforts in focusing attention on education, Larry Speakes, the spokesman, said.

title: Economic Scene; Industry Policy: Is It Desirable?
description: ARE the Democrats chasing a lemon in their quest for something called an ''industrial policy?'' Some leading Democratic Party economists and intellectuals think so.

title: APPLE FANCIERS TAKE TO THE ORCHARDS
description: The pick-it-yourself apple season starts this weekend in parts of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut near the metropolitan area, with a crop that is described as good in taste but variable in color.

title: BILL APPROVED TO PERMIT BIGGER TRUCKS ON ROADS
description: The State Legislature this evening passed a measure to permit heavier trailer trucks on New York roads in an attempt to avert the possible loss of $750 million in Federal highway funds.

title: Advertising; Parental Guilt and Computers
description: TROUBLED Texas Instruments, having scrapped a short-lived ad campaign that replaced price promotion with product promotion, is now borrowing a page from the encyclopedia salesan's guide and is using the time-tested parental guilt ploy.

title: PROTEST FILED
description: Under cloudless skies on a golden afternoon on Rhode Island Sound, Liberty defeated the challenger, Australia II, in the second race of the America's Cup series by 1 minute 33 seconds today. But all was not golden ashore as Australia II filed a protest against Liberty.

title: MANY JETS DISLIKE AN ARTIFICIAL SURFACE
description: Even now, more than a month after their last exhibition game at Giants Stadium, many of the Jets remain injured and they blame the artificial turf at that stadium and other stadiums.

title: Mayor of West Berlin Meets With Leader of East Germany
description: Mayor Richard von Weizs"acker said today that Erich Honecker, the East German leader, indicated willingness in a meeting today to relax money exchange rules for visiting Westerners.

title: HOW POLL WAS CONDUCTED
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Sept. 14 with 705 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.

title: TWENTY-FIRST CENTURY DISTRIBUTORS reports earnings for Year to June 30
CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday on a sale of Federal coal mining leases in Billings, Mont., gave an incorrect total for the bids made by mining companies. They totaled $911,800.

title: HOUSE APPROVES BILL ENDING MORATORIUM ON CHEMICAL ARMS
description: The House of Representatives today approved and sent to President Reagan a 1984 military bill that would end a 15- year United States moratorium on production of chemical arms by authorizing a new form of nerve gas weapons.

title: LEVINE GETS NEW TITLE
description: The Metropolitan Opera yesterday announced the appointment of James Levine as artistic director of the company, a position that gives him greater artistic control than anyone in the company's history except for its general managers.

title: READERS' GUIDE TO SUNDAY'S BOOK FAIR AND ON FIFTH AVE.
description: ONE of the few things that will be difficult to do at the fifth ''New York Is Book Country'' Fair on Sunday is read.
