What will be far easier, at the 174 booths set up by publishers, booksellers and related organizations, will be to have a horoscope printed by computer (at Booth 70), to count the words in a Wordsworth poem (Booth 168), to get fingerprinted (24), to meet Peter Rabbit (54) or Edward Gorey (133), to buy a reconstruction of a seventh-century Irish game (136), to have your name written as a Chinese ideogram (22) or to say hello to the Wicked Witch of the West (139).

title: Zoeller in Tie for Lead
description: Fuzzy Zoeller shot a 2-under-par 70 and was tied with Wayne Levi for the second-round lead today in the new Las Vegas Pro-Celebrity Classic, the first American golf tournament to offer more than $1 million in total prize money. Zoeller, the first-round leader, and Levi each finished 36 holes with 133's. The tournament is being played on four courses.

title: MACNEAL-SCHWENDLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ART: A WORLD OF MENACE FROM AVIGDOR ARKIHA
description: THERE are no clean well lighted places in the paintings of Avigdor Arikha. His immediate, physical images of people and objects are a cry of claustrophobia and danger. No person or thing is what it appears to be. Sunflowers seem disoriented by the sun; cherries and peaches are as edible as grenades; a cozy library contains a chair that is too small, a lamp that is too low and books that seem as much a surrounding army as a battalion of friends. This is the world as a small child might experience it, where everything seems inscrutable and all- powerful and nothing is safe.

title: AUTOMATIC SALUTING OF BUDGET BALANCING
description: A number of in- telligent people have observed that America has been living with what were once considered intolerable budget deficits and that lightening has not struck - not yet, at least. They are not saying that the emperor, the balanced budget, has no clothes but that it is unclear what clothes he is wearing. For this, they will be called Keynesian, irresponsible or worse. But they are right to ask what difference budget deficits make, and raising the question is the first step toward an important improvement in economic policy.

title: REAGAN'S IMPOTENT OPPONENTS
description: During two and a half years of Reagan-dominated politics, we have witnessed a remakable passivity and timidity from opposition political leaders. Not only have they allowed President Reagan and his team to assault and injure vast segments of the body politic, but, even more important, they have allowed him to set the terms of the political debate.

title: RIO GRANDE DRILLING reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: TEXAS ENERGIES INC O) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
MEGADATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
RECITAL: KOSTER PLAYS GUITAR
description: DENNIS KOSTER is a performer who seems happiest as a recitalist when he finds occasion to draw torrents of notes from his guitar. Appearing at Goodman House on Wednesday night, he divided his program between flamenco and classical music, the former represented by works of Sabicas, Escudero and Mr. Koster himself, the latter consisting of Bach's Partita in E, pieces by Villa-Lobos and Mr. Koster's guitar adaptation of the Allegro Vivace from Kodaly's Sonata for Unaccompanied Cello (Op. 8).

title: Comings and Goings
description: Chuck Williams, a defensive lineman who had been Pittburgh's top freshman prospect this year, will sit out this season because of recent knee surgery. . . .Bubby Brister, Tulane's starting quarterback, who was replaced during the school's first two games this season by Jon English, the son of Tulane's coach, Wally English, has quit the football team, withdrawn from school and plans to enroll in another school.

title: New Chief Chosen At R.J. Reynolds
description: The cloudy succession picture at R. J. Reynolds Industries cleared yesterday with the announcement that J. Tylee Wilson had been elected chief executive.

title: MARCOS FOE QUITS ASSEMBLY AND DENOUNCES COLLEAGUES
description: The head of a coalition of 12 opposition parties resigned from the National Assembly today with a speech denouncing its members as puppets of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: WHY KUHN STRUCK OUT
description: Major league baseball's search for a commissioner to replace Bowie K. Kuhn has spawned debate on the need to restructure the leagues' administration. Most of the comments, which assume that the commissioner is an independent actor who fashions and administers policy, miss the central point. Baseball's prosperity cannot be determined by the personal characteristics and qualifications of the commissioner.

title: WESTERN STEER-MOM 'N' POP'S reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 12
TRAFFIC SNARLED BY ELDERLY MAN IN WHEELCHAIR
description: An 83- year-old man looking for a library took a wrong turn in his wheelchair and found himself ''a living target,'' rolling along at under five miles an hour on a busy interstate highway.

title: No Headline
description: ELECTRONIC LIFE. How to Think About Computers. By Michael Crichton. 209 pages. Knopf. $12.95. RELAX. You have nothing to fear from computers. This is the basic message of ''Electronic Life,'' the latest book by the multiform Michael Crichton, who in his various guises as science-fiction writer, historical novelist and medical investigator, has given us such books as ''The Andromeda Strain,'' ''The Terminal Man,'' ''The Great Train Robbery'' and ''Five Patients.''

title: MITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $1,281,000.

title: SOVIET BASKETBALL TOUR OF U.S. CANCELED
description: The strained relations between the United States and the Soviet Union, resulting from the downing of a South Korean airliner by a Soviet fighter plane two weeks ago, yesterday further disrupted scheduled athletic events between the two countries.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''IN my day,'' Florence Vander Kemp said at a party where she was the guest of honor, ''one never held a party before the first of October. Now it's so different.''

title: Kach Is Nimble After a Fumble
description: Mayor Koch, who is in the forefront of efforts to keep the Jets from moving to New Jersey, freely admits that he is not a sports fan and thus isn't very familiar with football. Somewhere along the line, though, the Mayor has learned how to run something that looks a lot like a reverse.

title: NATIONAL BERYLLIA CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
THEATER: 'BUSBYMUSIC'
description: GERALD BUSBY'S composition ''Parallel'' is subtitled ''Suite for Two Harpsichords, Dancer and Gymnast on Parallel Bars,'' and that is almost what it was when it was performed as part of the show ''Busbymusic,'' which is at Theater Guinevere, 15 West 28th Street, through Sunday.

title: MISS HOLTZMAN WINS AN APPEAL IN SCHUMER CASE
description: The State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn could investigate accusations of election misconduct by Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn and, if warranted, prosecute the case.

title: GEORGIA' POULTRY CROP HURT BY HEAT
description: In the heart of this city, where it is against the law to use anything but fingers to eat fried chicken, stands a symbol. It is a bronze statue of a rooster raised on a 25-foot marble monument above a grassy triangle called the Georgia Poultry Park.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Topics 'All Things Counter'; Vending in Peverse
description: During debate over New York's can- and bottle-return bill, grocers complained about the extra work it would inflict - collecting and sorting the containers and handing out all those nickel deposits. Technology has come to their rescue.

title: SOME SYNAGOGUES WELCOME UNAFFILIATED ON THE HOLIDAYS
description: The Hebrew Institute of Riverdale, an Orthodox synagogue in the Bronx, plans to open its doors again tomorrow, on Yom Kippur, for special services for newcomers.

title: CANAL-RANDOLPH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to JuLY 31
Trading Light In Eurobonds
description: Fixed-interest dollar bonds fell in early trading today, but rose in the afternoon to close largely unchanged from late trading on Wednesday. Dealers said trading activity was very light.

title: CARPENTER READY FOR COWBOYS
description: If the Giants are to upset the Cowboys Sunday in Dallas, they must get another big running game from Rob Carpenter.

title: U.S. Steel Imports
description: A top Commerce Department official said today that the Reagan Administration may file unfair trade charges to stop the United States Steel Corporation from importing millions of tons of British steel. Lionel H. Olmer, Under Secretary for International Trade, told a House panel that the U.S. Steel-British Steel Corporation deal threatened a trade agreement reached last October that limited 10 categories of steel imports entering United States markets.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective. Corrections, also on this page, continue to deal with factual errors.

title: Money Funds Show Decline
description: Assets of money market mutual funds dropped $806 million, to $164.07 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Belgian Civil Servants Protest Austerity Plan
description: Civil servants across Belgium went on strike today to protest a Government austerity plan. The wildcat walkout halted or sharply curtailed services ranging from public transport to weather reports.

title: A.B.T. BACKS DIRECTORS
description: The board of American Ballet Theater yesterday reaffirmed its confidence in the policies of Mikhail Baryshnikov, the company's artistic director, and announced that Herman Krawitz would remain in his post of executive director. It added that the troupe's season would continue as scheduled.

title: Turkish Columnist Jailed
description: An Istanbul military court today sentenced Metin Toker, a columnist of the newspaper Milliyet, to three years' imprisonment, military officials said. They said Mr. Toker had been convicted of violating a decree in an Aug. 15 article on the new electoral law. Milliyet was closed for nearly two weeks during the investigation.

title: ETHIOPIA AFFIRMS ITS OPEN DIPLOMACY
description: To the Editor:

title: Nuclear Protesters Sentenced to Work
description: Twelve antinuclear protesters have been found guilty of trespassing and sentenced to work 20 hours for charitable causes in a case stemming from a protest July 27 at Griffiss Air Force Base in Rome, N.Y.

title: Dr Pepper Stock Scores Big Gain
description: Stock of the Dr Pepper Company surged $2.375 in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to end the day at $16 a share. Traders credited the spurt to the disclosure that the big bottling company had retained the Wall Street firm of Lazard Fr eres to give it financial advice that could range from possible joint ventures and refinancing to outright sale.

title: AUCTIONS
description: Ornithopter up for sale.

title: Bridge: The Season Starts and Ends In Double Knockout Events
description: This is the season in which the protracted double knockout team events popular in the metropolitan area die and are born again: Play begins each fall and continues for almost a full year.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American States Insurance, Indianapolis, said it would acquire all the outstanding shares of its subsidiary, American States Life Insurance Co., that it does not currently own, for about $29.5 million.

title: Suspect Charged In L.I. Slaying
description: The Nassau County police announced yesterday that a 23-year-old Connecticut man had been arrested and charged in the Aug. 30 slaying of a 20-year-old woman in her home in North New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: Connors Gains
description: In his first match since winning the United States Open last Sunday, Jimmy Connors defeated Tony Giammalva, 6-4, 6-4, in the first round of the Paine-Webber Classic on Wednesday night.

title: ART: WHITNEY PRESENTS A GRAVES RETROSPECTIVE
description: GROWING up in the Pacific Northwest, Morris Graves always stepped to the tune of a different drummer. As a sickly child with a love for flowers, he spent hours designing rock gardens in his mind and later, as a young proto- hippie, he dropped out of high school to embark for the Orient by ship. ''In Japan I at once had the feeling that this was the right way to do everything,'' he later said, and his feeling for Asian religion and philosophy has always imbued his work. Closely allied with the visionary, Asian-influenced group of Northwest artists led by the late Mark Tobey, Graves has produced a mystical art in which spiritual states are expressed by elemental symbols - birds, flowers, pine trees, the sea - as well as by Buddhist motifs.

title: FOTOMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: OPPENHEIMER & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Browns Defeat Bengals
description: Brian Sipe passed for 201 yards and threw his eighth touchdown pass of the season as the Cleveland Browns defeated the Cincinnati Bengals, 17-7, tonight. It was the Bengals third straight loss.

title: Mr. Watt's Fire Sale in Coal
description: Guess who gave a party to which nobody came? Ignoring the advice of the General Accounting Office and defying the will of a House committee, Interior Secretary James Watt insisted on selling 540 million tons of federally owned coal this week. Bids came for just one-fifth of the properties and the sums offered won't pay the costs of preparing the tracts for lease.

title: President Adds a Title In Dayton-Hudson Shift
description: A new chief executive was announced yesterday for the Dayton Hudson Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest general merchandise retailer, with 1,052 stores and sales approaching $6 billion annually.

title: OPEC Limit To Remain
description: An OPEC committee said today that because increased flows of crude oil in recent weeks were eroding oil prices, it would recommend no change in the organization's production controls and price levels.

title: BY SCAASI, DRAMA FOR FALL EVENINGS
description: The satin dress with the navy bodice and the full cocoa skirt is certainly one of the most beautiful evening designs of the fall season, its somewhat offbeat sober colors complemented by a huge stole in purple and blue. The black and white dress with life-size faces picked out in rhinestones is one of the most amusing, and the multicolor print with the vivid abstract pattern outlined in jewels is dazzling.

title: ARGENTINA TRIES TO AVOID DEFAULTING
description: President Reynaldo Bignone today studied a change in the nation's bankruptcy law proposed in a last-ditch effort to satisfy Argentina's foreign bankers.

title: At the Keyboard, The Book You Want
description: The Bobst Library at New York University christened its new computerized library catalogue yesterday, calling it ''Bobcat,'' and three distinguished writers were on hand for the occasion.

title: All in a Day
description: There was good news for the Williams family and from the Williams family yesterday.

title: THE 2 BRINK'S TRIALS
description: The Brink's robbery and murders in October 1981 have so far spawned two trials in two different places with two widely varying verdicts. The verdicts were the result of different charges against different defendants, different evidence, different juries and vastly different legal strategies. After barely three hours of deliberations, a state court jury in Goshen, N.Y., this week convicted three Brink's defendants of the full range of charges brought against them: three counts of second-degree murder and four of first- degree armed robbery.

title: A GATHERING OF CABINET DEMOCRATS
description: They matriculated in different years, so last night's gathering of ''old grads'' wasn't exactly a class reunion. Rather, the guests were alumni of one of the tougher institutions of learning: the Cabinet of the United States.

title: METRO AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income. The 1982 figures were restated to reflect the merger of an affiliated company.

title: KETTERING INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The latest quarter includes results of American Display Corporation acquired April 30.

title: CALIFORNIA COURT BARS VOTE ON G.O.P. DISTRICTING PLAN
description: Californians will not vote on a Republican- sponsored reapportionment plan, the State Supreme Court ruled today, the first time in 35 years the court took a voter-initiated measure off the ballot.

title: REST OF PARKCHESTER'S TENANTS GET CONVERSION PLAN
description: Harry B. Helmsley dropped the other shoe at Parkchester last week, presenting tenants of its east, west and south quadrants with a preliminary offering plan for conversion to a condominium.

title: Settlement Close
description: Leonard Tose, the owner of the Philadelphia Eagles, is under a court order to negotiate with a group of investors seeking to buy the club. But, according to his lawyer, Tose may be close to reaching an out-of-court settlement with the group, and the settlement might allow him to retain his 99 percent interest in the team.

title: Rejection Seen For Mesa Bid
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company's bid for KN Energy is expected to be rejected, some oil industry analysts say, but Mesa and its aggressive chairman, T. Boone Pickens Jr., are expected to profit by driving up the price of KN's shares and then selling them back to KN. Analysts say that Mesa's offer also could make KN a takeover target for another, friendlier company.

title: METS DEFEND CARDS ON FOSTER HOMER
description: The Mets reached up from sixth place last night and picked off the St. Louis Cardinals, 6-4, further scrambling the four-way race in the National League's East and depressing the Cardinals' chances of winning it.

title: CITY ARTS GROUPS GIVEN $8.3 MILLION
description: Cultural groups in New York City received $8.3 million in challenge grants yesterday from the National Endowment for the Arts, more than three times the $2.3 million given last year.

title: Esoteric Japanese and new American.
description: ONE of the best kept secrets of the Japanese community in New York is Chikubu, a small, neat restaurant on 62d Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues. Japanese customers outnumber others by 20 to 1, which means that the esoteric food served at Chikubu will have the strongest appeal to the most serious converts to Japanese cooking. Certainly, the cramped quarters of its casual interior are not exactly conducive to gracious dining. And because most staff members speak only the most rudimentary English, the service is awkward and frustrating.

title: TO SHAME ITS FELONS, CHINAP UTS THEM ON PARADE
description: More than two dozen convicted criminals, their hair cut short, their heads bowed, were driven slowly through the streets of this big port city today.

title: S.E.C. Accord With McGoff
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has settled charges against John McGoff, a newspaper publisher accused of trying to buy American newspapers with secret funds from South Africa.

title: Life and Death for the Smiths
description: Supporters of capital punishment keep saying that it's now possible to impose it without arbitrariness, and the Supreme Court has signaled its impatience with legal delays that have swelled the death- row population to 1,200.

title: 3 FUNNY WAYS TO START THIS SEASON
description: COMEDY is back in town. The standup comics have returned from working the summer resorts and cruise ships, the ensembles and improvisational groups have reunited after visiting with their mothers, the comedy clubs are open again, and the season begins in fine style with three extraordinarily funny, but very different attractions this weekend.

title: SANCTIONS REJECTED
description: The Senate unanimously approved a House-passed resolution today ''condemning the Soviet criminal destruction of the Korean civilian airliner,'' after rejecting conservatives' efforts to recommend specific sanctions.

title: DOW DROPS TO 1,215.04, OFF 14.43
description: Stock prices tumbled yesterday amid continued investor pessimism about interest rates and the general anticipation that money supply figures to be released today will reverse the recent declining trend.

title: BROADWAY
description: A new, enlarged Tuscaloosa' heads for the Music Box.

title: WAR-GENERATED DEFICITS ARE NO GAUGE FOR ECONOMIC FORECASTS
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 AIRPORTS CLOSED TO RUSSIANS
description: The Governors of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that Soviet planes carrying Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko and other Soviet delegates to the opening of the United Nations next week will be denied permission to land at Kennedy and Newark International Airports.

title: Tuition Rise Voted In Connecticut
description: The University of Connecticut trustees acted today to increase tuition, fees and room charges for the 1984-85 school year. The cost for in-state students living at the campus in Storrs would rise by 3.7 percent, to about $3,730 per year.

title: PHILARMONIC: RAFAEL KUBELIK CONDUCTS SCHUMAN
description: RAFAEL KUBELIK, the Czechoslovak conductor, is in town to help the New York Philharmonic open its new season, and following Wednesday's gala benefit for the orchestra's pension fund, he returned to Avery Fisher Hall last night to begin the Philharmonic's real business of the year, - its subscription concerts. There were two symphonies, one by Beethoven and the other by William Schuman.

title: ANOTHER LOOK AT THE SOVIET SYSTEM AND STRATEGY
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD AIR AGENCY MEETS ON DISASTER
description: The United States and other Western nations today demanded an international investigation of the Soviet downing of a South Korean airliner on Sept. 1 and tighter controls on military action against civilian flights.

title: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 16, 1983
description: The Economy

title: IF THIS IS WASHINGTON, IT MUST BE 'HISPANIC WEEK'
description: In proclaiming this as Hispanic Heritage Week, President Reagan has cast forth a Republican dragnet for that important voting group and left few appeals untried from what lately might be termed his Casa Blanca command post.

title: SPAIN DISMISSES A GENERAL FOR DFEENDING PLOTTERS
description: A senior general who expressed certain opinions unpopular with the Government in a magazine interview is losing his command of one of the country's nine military regions.

title: ECONOMICS PROFESSOR AT YALE
description: William J. Fellner, Sterling Professor Emeritus of Economics at Yale University and a leading expert on monetary theory and inflation, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Washington. He was 77 years old.

title: MCCORMICK & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
20 Years for Father Of Slain Jersey Boy
description: A 21-year-old man convicted of aggravated manslaughter in the beating death of his 3-year-old son was sentenced today to 20 years in prison with a minimum of 10 years before he would be eligible for parole.

title: BOAT PARTIES LIGHT UP DUSK ON LONG ISLAND
description: Albert Lerner said it was ''just like a backyard barbecue,'' but it wasn't. There was no grill, no charcoal and no hamburgers. And it took place not in a backyard, but in waters that the novelist F. Scott Fitzgerald once called a ''great wet barnyard'' off Long Island Sound.

title: UNITS OF 4 CITY AGENCIES TO BE MOVED TO QUEENS
description: Parts of four city agencies, involving at least 800 employees, will be moving their offices from Manhattan to Queens under an agreement announced yesterday by Mayor Koch and other city officials.

title: Topics 'All Things Counter'; Back From the Brink
description: There was a time when Sisquoc, the first California condor bred in captivity, was, if not cute, presentable. His body was all white fluff, his head and neck bright yellow.

title: Federal Buyout Begins In Dioxin-Tainted City
description: The buyout of property owners in this dioxin-contaminated city began today, the Government said.

title: YOM KIPPUR GIVES COUPLE BUSIEST TIME
description: For Lee Friedlander and Joy Levitt, the busy High Holy Days from Rosh ha-Shanah to Yom Kippur underscore the central conflict of their marriage.

title: PSYCHOLOGIST DEFENDS MINUTE OF SILENCE IN SCHOOLS
description: A psychologist who studied the effect of a moment of silence in a New Mexico school system testified today that he had found no coercion for prayer or religious activity.

title: Pass and Sims at Gate
description: The Village Gate (475-5120), Bleecker and Thompson Streets, will present the guitarist Joe Pass, playing solos, and the tenor saxophonist Zoot Sims and a quartet tonight and tomorrow. Shows begin at 9 and 11 P.M. There is an $8 cover and a one- drink minimum.

title: Willie Bobo, Drummer Who Led Latin Bands
description: Willie Bobo, the singer and drummer who called his blend of jazz and Latin rhythms ''the sound a Latin cat in Harlem would dig,'' died of cancer here today. He was 49 years old.

title: 1 POTATO 2 INC reports earnings for 12wks to Aug 17
BANK'S FAILURE DAZES A TOWN
description: The green blinds were drawn today on the ground floor of the three-story red brick Exchange Bank. Inside, dozens of clerks and accountants sifted through stacks of papers as they ran their fingers nonstop across a battery of adding machines. A burly sheriff's deputy guarded the door.

title: Horse Racing; 'Extras' of the Breeders Cup Program
description: The Breeders Cup has become synonymous with a series of six races scheduled to be run on one day in November 1984 at Hollywood Park, with $10 million in purses up for grabs. But that is only half the purpose and scope of the Cup program.

title: JACKSON APOLOGIZES TO QUEEN
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson apologized today for ''any error of judgment or interpretation'' in disclosing what he said were Queen Beatrix's views on planned missile deployment by the North Atlantic alliance.

title: CHEEZEM DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
2 YOUTHS ACCUSED OF 4 ROBBERIES
description: Two youths were charged yesterday with four robberies, and the Queens District Attorney said they might be responsible for 30 robberies and a rape in the borough this summer.

title: UNITED DIVERSIFIED reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Brazil Reaches Pact on a Loan
description: Brazil and the International Monetary Fund signed a letter of intent today that should clear the way for the payment of the second installment of a $4.4 billion, eight- year loan to Brazil.

title: WAR-GENERATED DEFIICITS ARE NO GUAGE FOR ECONOMIC FORECASTS
description: To the Editor:

title: SALE SET FOR MANUSCRIPT VALUED AT $3.5 MILLION
description: The 12th-century Gospels of Henry the Lion, said to be the most important Western medieval manuscript to appear on the art market in the 20th century, will be auctioned Dec. 6 by Sotheby Park Bernet.

title: G.M.-LABOR SPIRIT: PRESENT AND PAST
description: The sitdown strikers of 1937 would have found it all a little hard to believe.

title: TWO 0-2 TEAMS FACE BIG TESTS AT HOME
description: With 14 more games to play, any National Football League team that began the season with two straight losses should have enough time to straighten out and contend for a playoff position.

title: U.S. OUTPUT ROSE 0.9% IN AUGUST
description: Production by American factories and mines grew by an estimated nine- tenths of 1 percent in August, the ninth straight monthly advance, the Federal Reserve Board said yesterday. The growth was the smallest since February but still falls within the range economists expect to see in a normal recovery.

title: Italian Films
description: Casa Italiana of Columbia University opens its fall-winter season of screenings of Italian films with a free showing of ''Bread and Chocolate,'' the 1978 work of Franco Brusati, tonight at 7. Sunday at 3 P.M. will be ''The Garden of the Finzi-Contini'' (1971), directed by Vittorio De Sica (contribution, $3).

title: MARSHALL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $32,000. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in June.

title: KOCH PROPOSES AUTOMATIC AID FOR DEVELOPERS
description: Tax incentives for industrial and commercial development would be granted automatically in New York City outside Manhattan's two major business districts under a plan announced yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about Governor Cuomo's visit to Washington misstated the position of the New York Congressional delegation on the state's proposed transportation bond issue. The bond issue has received bipartisan support, but the delegation as a whole has taken no position on it.

title: Market PlaceRobert J. Cole Fresh Interest In Oil Concern
description: LAST April, when Delo Caspary, a Texas investor, began a proxy fight to win control of the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company, the company's stock traded on the New York Stock Exchange at $29.50.

title: Treasury Yields Rise a Bit; Prices Cut By Dealers
description: Yields of most Treasury notes and bonds rose slightly yesterday as securities dealers cut prices to levels they hoped would attract more investor demand at next week's auctions of 4- , 7 and 20-year Treasury issues.

title: STAGE: 'BASEMENT TAPES'
description: WHILE it might serve as a 15-minute - or at most an 18-and-a-half-minute - interlude on ''Saturday Night Live,'' Erik Brogger's ''Basement Tapes'' offers a meager two hours of theater. As political satire, the show at the Top of the Gate is both tired and too late.

title: MAN WHO STOLE $7 MIILION MAY HAVE HAD ACCOMPLICE
description: The Wells Fargo security guard accused of stealing $7 million in cash from a company depot here Monday night may have had someone with him at the scene, according to sworn statements made public today by the police.

title: Funds Approved To Aid Homeless
description: The Board of Estimate voted unanimously yesterday for a $28 million program that will renovate city- owned buildings for use by homeless New Yorkers and provide jobs for 450 chronically unemployed workers.

title: BEGIN'S ERA IN ISRAELI POLITICS: A PEEIOD OF HISTORIC CHANGE
description: When Menachem Begin became Prime Minister in 1977, ousting the Labor Party from government for the first time since the founding of modern Israel, many political analysts saw his election as an aberration, an odd detour from which Israeli politics would rapidly regain its old, well-worn path.

title: Birth in Automobile Causes a Traffic Jam
description: A Chinese-speaking motorist caused a rush-hour traffic jam on the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway yesterday hile flagging down drivers to help his wife deliver their baby.

title: LEBANON'S JETS ATTACK MILITIA NEAR KEY TOWN
description: American and Saudi mediators shuttled between Beirut, Damascus and Cyprus today, trying to arrange a cease-fire between the Lebanese Army and Syrian-backed Druse militiamen. But Lebanese officials said obstacles to a final agreement remained.

title: Chrysler Pension
description: The Chrysler Corporation has made a $270 million annual payment to its pension fund, pension fund sources said.

title: Bottom Line Twin Bill
description: Junior Walker and the All-Stars and the Marvelettes, two bands that made Motown soul hits in the 1960's, will share a bill Sunday and Monday at the Bottom Line (228-7880), 15 West Fourth Street, at Mercer Street. Shows begin at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $10.

title: SWANTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
White Sox Clinch a Title Tie
description: The Chicago White Sox clinched a tie for the American League Western Division title tonight by defeating the Seattle Mariners, 7-0.

title: Rev. Joseph Tinnelly Is Dead; Former St. John's Law Dean
description: The Rev. Joseph T. Tinnelly, chaplain and former dean of the St. John's University School of Law, died of a liver infection Thursday at St. Catherine's Infirmary in Philadephia. He was 71 years old.

title: LEVI STRAUSS & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Coping at Camp
description: Billy Smith, the veteran goalie, reported to an Islander training camp for the 12th time this week and met it with the same verve as in the past.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Personal Health column in The Living Section on Wednesday incorrectly described the usual means of paying autopsy costs. They are usually paid by the hospital or the medical examiner's office.

title: M.T.A. OFFERS 1% PAY INCENTIVE TO SPEED SUBWAY TRACK REPAIRS
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has offered a 1 percent ''incentive'' raise to members of the management of the Transit Authority if they can meet an accelerated goal for the system's subway track repair program.

title: Portuguese-U.S. Talks
description: President Antonio Ramalho Eanes of Portugal met with Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger today for talks on the American air base in the Azores and increased military aid to Portugal.

title: 10.67 RISE PUTS DOW AT 1,225.71
description: Stock prices rose sharply yesterday, with blue-chip, transportation and technology stocks fueling the increase.

title: Steroid Tests Urged
description: Track coaches in the Southwest Conference have approved a resolution urging the National Collegiate Athletic Association to institute spot drug tests in order to curb the use of anabolic steroids, drugs that led to the disqualification of several athletes at the Pan American Games last month. Southern Methodist's coach, Ted McLaughlin , said he thought such a plan ''would stop steroid use tomorrow'' and would be ''the only way to stop it.'' Before the resolution can be presented as a formal proposal to the N.C.A.A. it must be approved by the conference's athletic directors, who meet next week, and by faculty representatives.

title: LEVI STRAUSS NET UP 43.4% IN PERIOD
description: Levi Strauss & Company, citing strong advances in its domestic operations, reported yesterday that earnings in its fiscal third quarter rose 43.4 percent, while sales increased 6.2 percent.

title: COMPUTER TERMINAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: 2 Bond Issues Advance in Jersey
description: The State Legislature moved closer today to placing on the November ballot two bond issues that would provide a total of $185 million for beach protection and bridge repairs.

title: U.S. Fights Manville Suit
description: The Justice Department asked a Federal judge today to dismiss a lawsuit by the Manville Corporation seeking to recover money from the Government for $1 million in payments to 50 asbestos workers.

title: ROBERT KENNEDY JR. FACES CHARGE OF HEROIN POSSESSION IN S. DAKOTA
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. was charged with heroin possession today, two days after he announced he was seeking treatment for a drug problem he said he was ''determined to beat.''

title: COGENIC ENERGY SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: WOMEN'S BAR OFFERS AGENDA FOR ACTION
description: To the Editor:

title: SKYLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a net gain of $175,000 from the sale of an idle plant.

title: ROBERT C. DENNIS
description: Robert C. Dennis, who created more than 500 scripts for such television series as ''Charlie's Angels,'' ''Hawaii Five-0'' and ''Dragnet,'' died of cancer Wednesday at his Hollywood home.

title: Senator Starts Fund for Kin
description: A $1 million fund for families of the 61 United States passengers killed in the shooting down of a Korean airliner has been started by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York.Today the Senator asked the Internal Revenue Service to grant tax-exempt status to the fund so that contributions would be tax-deductible.

title: Kaiser Sale Talks Continue
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said yesterday that it had been discussing the possible sale of the company with several groups, including individuals in Tulsa, Okla., but stressed that no offers had been received. Talks have been held with various unidentified companies, as well as groups of individuals, Montye Male, a spokesman for Kaiser, said.

title: ALBANY SAMPLER: A PLACE 'TO SMUDGE YOUR SOUL'
description: These are some passages about the city of William Kennedy's life and work from his forthcoming book, ''O, Albany!'':

title: Jewish Settler Pardoned In Hebron Shooting
description: President Chaim Herzog pardoned a Jewish settler from the occupied West Bank who had been convicted and sentenced to a year in jail for shooting into an Arab house in Hebron, injuring a 5-year-old girl with flying glass, the Israeli radio reported today.

title: Use of Artificial Heart Is Reported Criticized
description: Some members of an institutional board reviewing the University of Utah's artificial heart program have criticized the implanting of an artificial heart in Dr. Barney B. Clark, according to confidential minutes of a meeting of the board last June.

title: Animals Saved From Cult's Rites
description: A farmyard menagerie packed into an apartment in a Manhattan housing project was saved yesterday from becoming a cult sacrifice, A.S.P.C.A. officials said.

title: Former Nun Got AIDS In Haiti, Doctors Find
description: A former nun who died after contracting acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, apparently contracted the illness in Haiti in the 1970's, two Canadian doctors have reported.

title: Surge of Interest
description: Leonard Panaggio, the press officer for the America's Cup races, is keenly aware of how interest in that competition has swelled over the years.

title: AID FOR CITY CITED
description: Mayor Koch, with Governor Cuomo at his side, said yesterday that New York City would get an ''acceptable'' share of money from a proposed $1.25 billion bond issue and that he would campaign for its passage this fall.

title: Imagic Layoffs
description: Imagic Inc., a once fast-growing maker of video game software, has laid off 40 of its 170 employees and said it expected more layoffs next week. The company, which is privately held, is being hurt by the shakeout in the video game and home computer business. Margaret Davis, a company spokesman, said Imagic is reaching agreements to sell off its excess inventory to raise cash, but said the company is not filing for bankruptcy protection.

title: No Headline
description: Peter Martins Knighted By Queen of Denmark Queen Margrethe II of Denmark has made Peter Martins of the New York City Ballet a Knight of the Order of Dannebrog, according to an official announcement from the royal palace. The City Ballet is on a visit to Copenhagen.

title: Army Tests New Rations
description: The Army is testing new freeze-dried field rations on 100 infantrymen to determine the long-term effects. The soldiers seem to agree that they are better than the standard canned C-rations, said an Army spokesman, Glenn Exum. The only complaint, he said, is that the portions are too small.

title: HOSPITAL COSTS: COUNTING BEDS IS NO ANSWER
description: To the Editor:

title: A Weir Retrospective
description: A retrospective of works by J. Alden Weir, an American impressionist, will open Oct. 13 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82d Street. The exhibition features about 100 works and is drawn from acquisitions at the Met and other museums as well as private collections. It will be on view through next January.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If you fail, the role of legitimacy will be disrupted and the state of Lebanon will fail, and partition and dismemberment will prevail.'' - Gen. Ibrahim Tannous of the Lebanese Army, exhorting his troops. (1:6.)

title: Nature in a Former Mine
description: Most New Yorkers have seen more of the former product of the 250- acre Clay Pit Ponds State Park around their neighborhoods than they have seen of the Staten Island preserve itself.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $5.5 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve System reported yesterday that the basic measure of the nation's money supply rose $5.5 billion in the financial week that ended Sept. 7.

title: The Last of the Tripuckas
description: Already, a little more than a week into the new semester, three windows on the sixth floor of Edmonds Hall are becoming a landmark on the Boston College campus. Three neon lights, the kind that usually advertise beer from tavern windows, welcome passersby to a good time. Inside the desks of one of the residents, two tap handles are just waiting to be attached to a keg. A bar has been built in the living room. Inflatable plastic beer bottles are decorations, the happy result of having a father who runs a successful beer distributorship.

title: Tom Mix Festival Attracting Thousands
description: Thousands of fans of the old westerns, many in boots and spurs, gathered here Thursday to honor Tom Mix, the late ''King of the Cowboys,'' who kissed the horse and not the heroine to exemplify a straight-shooter's life.

title: PHILS WIN ON WILD PITCH IN 13
description: The Philadelphia Phillies and the St. Louis Cardinals played into the 13th inning before a winner was declared tonight in one of the more unusual chapters in the complicated race in the National League East.

title: MUSIC: BAROQUE VIOLINIST
description: Evan Johnson is clearly not a violinist looking for easy popular success. Instead of immersing himself and his audiences in familiar works of Beethoven, Brahms, Bruch and the like, he concentrates on the music of Baroque masters.

title: Bush Says U.S. Respects Yugoslavia's Position
description: Vice President Bush said at a state dinner in his honor in Belgrade today that the United States respected Yugoslavia's espousal of nonalignment and its resistance against attempts to limit its independence.

title: TEXAS GENERAL RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $19,000. c-After net from discontinued operations of $472,000.

title: PERIL IN FRAGMENTING MENTAL HEALTH CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: JAMAICAN DANCE TROUPE PROUD OF CARIBBEAN LORE
description: Dancers surged across the stage in a humid rehearsal auditorium of the City Center. Perspiration glistened around the faces, necks and shoulders of bodies otherwise covered by leg warmers, sweatshirts and similar attire.

title: TELERAM COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After tax credits of $139,000 for the quarter and $179,000 for the 9 months.

title: VOTERS VS. LEGISLATURES: BALLOT ISSUES INCREASING
description: Want to end nuclear war, start a space program, get tougher on crooks, cut taxes or reapportion electoral districts? In California, you pass a petition or, more likely, you hire someone to do it for you.

title: Frederick B. Shroyer, Critic; Worked With Dorothy Parker
description: Frederick B. Shroyer, a literary critic who worked with Dorothy Parker on a highly acclaimed short- story anthology, has died of a heart attack at the age of 66.

title: New Jobless Claims Declined For First Week of September
description: New claims for state unemployment benefits declined to 409,000 in the first week in September, the Labor Department reported Thursday.

title: Jersey's Colleges Get Strike Threat
description: The American Federation of Teachers said today that teachers and staff members would strike at nine state colleges unless they were offered a better contract by Oct. 4.

title: ARTISTS' RIGHTS
description: At long last, statutory recognition has been extended in America to the classical European doctrine of droit moral, or moral right, whereby a creator retains a legally protected interest in the treatment of his or her work of art after parting with ownership.

title: TEAMSTERS REJECT CONCESSIONS PLAN
description: Members of the teamsters' union today overwhelmingly rejected a proposal by the union's president, Jackie Presser, that would have drastically reduced wages of union drivers rehired after April 1.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: Aluminum Blast Injures 10
description: A mold at the Carolina Billets manufacturing plant exploded today as molten scrap aluminum was being poured into a cast, showering the molten aluminum on 10 workers. Seven of the workers were burned critically.

title: NETWORKS INTENSIFY BATTLE FOR 6 A.M. NEW VIEWERS
description: ''Are you awake yet?'' asked Connie Chung, the anchor of ''NBC News at Sunrise'' as she ended a broadcast recently. The question elicited laughter from the technicians in the studio - an acknowledgement that even the people who produce the programs sometimes find early- morning news a groggy affair.

title: BIRD CALLS
description: These September weekends (weekdays, too) are marked by extremely heavy air traffic, most of it southbound and none of it subject to holding patterns or control towers. This is the migration season for birds and sometimes a skyward glance can pleasure the eye with a vision winging over the city on this most ancient of creature movement.

title: Harris Bankcorp Seeks 4 Banks
description: Harris Bankcorp, involved in talks about its own acquisition by a banking company, said it had signed letters of intent to acquire four Chicago- area banks for $38.6 million.

title: MITRAL MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: Judge Rules Out Law Restricting Electroshock
description: In a brief order issued late Thursday, Judge Winton McKibben of Alameda County Superior Court in Oakland, Calif., struck down a city ordinance banning the use of electroshock therapy in the city of Berkeley.

title: Xerox Settles Charges
description: The Xerox Corporation agreed to have its export privileges to most Arab countries cut for six months and to pay a $17,000 fine to settle charges that it violated a law banning cooperation with the Arab boycott of Israel, the Government said today. Xerox said its acceptance of the penalties did not constitute an admission of guilt.

title: MAKING PRODUCTS TAMPER-RESISTANT
description: Companies that make over-the- counter drugs and other consumer products are still struggling to cope with the packaging worries that began with the contamination of Tylenol capsules last year, resulting in the death of seven people.

title: AMERICANS CURB WAYS GROMYKO CAN FLY TO U.N.
description: The United States told the Soviet Union today that if Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko wanted to fly in a Soviet plane to attend the United Nations General Assembly session in New York next week, he would not be able to use an Aeroflot plane and he would have to land at a military airfield.

title: Eligibility Case
description: A Louisiana judge ruled yesterday that Jon English , a Tulane quarterback, can continue to play at least until Oct. 4, when further arguments are scheduled on a suit challenging the transfer rule of the National Collegiate Athletic Association. The N.C.A.A. said it would appeal the ruling.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 30.

title: Soviet-Chinese Talks End on a Warm Note
description: The Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister ended a week's visit today and left for the Soviet Union, declaring that a ''new channel of contact'' had been established between Moscow and Peking after 20 years of hostility.

title: TYLENOL'S RAPID COMEBACK
description: No one may ever know who or why. But for the maker of the popular red and white capsules, at least, it is almost as if nothing ever happened.

title: Title Bout Hurts Mancini's Prestige
description: Perhaps Orlando Romero was not as bad as expected. But Ray Mancini was not as good.

title: Rooting Through Bones
description: Down to Fulham Palace on the bank of the Thames to look up an antique relative on a Sunday afternoon. He is there all right, bedded in a sarcophagus right behind the church, as he should be, having died 260 years ago.

title: Connors Upset By Sandy Mayer
description: Sandy Mayer upset Jimmy Connors, 6-4, 7-5, tonight and advanced to the semifinals of a $200,000 Grand Prix tennis tournament.

title: JACKSON, IN BERLIN, BIDS REAGAN MEET ANDROPOV
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson stood on a makeshift wooden platform overlooking the Berlin wall today and called upon President Reagan to meet with Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, to seek an agreement limiting nuclear weapons in Europe.

title: Gold Wins a Delay In Molesting Case
description: The preliminary hearing scheduled yesterday in Nashville into charges of aggravated rape against Eugene Gold, the former Brooklyn District Attorney, was postponed until Oct. 20.

title: NOTED BLACK AREA'S RENEWAL DEBATED
description: To most people, it is still Sweet Auburn, a nearly eight-block-long area east of downtown Atlanta that was once the social and economic magnet for blacks throughout the segregated South.

title:
PATENTS;
Unit Counts Neutrons In Nuclear Reactors
description: A unit to measure the quantity of neutrons, and thus the fission rate, at selected points in a nuclear reactor's core was patented this week for the Department of Energy.

title: Error-Prone Mets Defeated by Cubs; Cubs 7 Mets 4
description: The Mets made three errors in one inning last night and paid the price with a 7-4 loss to the Chicago Cubs. But the real story of their downfall was Rick Reuschel, the refugee from the Yankees, who came back to New York with the Cubs and pitched his first victory in the big leagues in two years.

title: Letter: On Energy High-Tech Uranium, in Small Steps To the Editor:
description: Your editorial of Aug. 24 ''Why Build a Uranium Pyramid?'' offers three solutions to the serious problems facing the Department of Energy's uranium enrichment program. Each proposed solution - (1) delaying the completion of the Gas Centrifuge Enrichment Plant (G.C.E.P.) until some advanced centrifuge technology is available; (2) canceling the G.C.E.P. project in favor of deploying the advanced isotope separation process (when it becomes available), and (3) leaving the entire enrichment enterprise to private industry - needs to be examined more closely.

title: 2 Killed Crossing Route 17 in Jersey
description: Two persons traveling to New York State for their vacation were killed as they tried to cross busy Route 17 on foot to get to a diner on Mountainside Avenue here, according to the police.

title: CHOCK FULL O'NUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $481,000 for the quarter and $788,000 for the year and tax credits of $14,000 for the quarter and $950,000 for the year. c-Net loss after a loss of $210,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary charge of $117,000. d-After a loss of $591,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $2,150,000.

title: 7 TEXAS CITIES ARE IN TOP 20 IN MURDER PER CAPITA
description: It started as a typical if not exactly friendly Saturday night poker game in a quiet neighborhood on the west side of Odessa, a bustling boom town of slightly more than 90,000 people in the heart of West Texas's oil-rich Permian Basin.

title: A DUBIOUS CARROT
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS SEEKS GENERAL'S NOTES
description: A Federal court in Washington, acting at the request of CBS, issued a subpoena yesterday for the questionnaires that a retired United States Army general used to prepare a book on Vietnam.

title: AMAREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company has been operating under Chaper 11 of the bankruptcy code since last year.

title: Yastrzemski Ties Aaron
description: Carl Yastrzemski tied Hank Aaron tonight as the most durable player in major league history.

title: Toyota Price Rise
description: Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. said it would raise 1984 car and truck prices an average of 2.9 percent, or $254, from 1983 prices.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: DOMINGO'S OPENING AT MET IN DOUBT
description: There are doubts at the Metropolitan Opera as to whether Placido Domingo, the great Spanish tenor, will actually sing at the house's gala centennial opening on Sept. 26.

title: MIAMI OFFICER CONVICTED IN SLAYING OF BLACK MAN
description: An all-white circuit court jury today found a white police officer guilty of manslaughter in the shooting death of a black man earlier this year.

title: MARTIN DENIES YANKS ARE DISCONTENTED
description: Billy Martin insisted today that there was no mutiny among his players and coaches, and that to suggest otherwise was a ''well-designed plot'' by reporters to cost him his job as Yankee manager.

title: ANTITRUST 'DICED'
description: A class action lawsuit alleging anticompetitive sales practices by Cuisinarts Inc. demonstrates how thoroughly antitrust policy has been chopped and diced from its original, presumably pro-consumer, intent.

title: Jets' Leahy May Be Out
description: A pulled back muscle may keep the Jets' place-kicker, Pat Leahy, out of Sunday's game against the New England Patriots at Foxboro, Mass. Leahy was placed on the ''questionable'' list today, meaning that his chances of playing were considered only 50-50, and Chuck Ramsey was alerted to the possibility that he might have to add place-kicking to his own punting duties.

title: FLEXING BRAVE
description: To the Editor:

title: WASHINGTON STATE LOSES SEX BIAS SUIT
description: The State of Washington violated the Civil Rights Act of 1964 by failing to pay women wages comparable to those of men, Federal District Judge Jack Tanner ruled today.

title: BATTLING TO STEM BLACK LAYOFF TIDE
description: Five years ago, black civil servants banded together in an organization to fight discrimination on the job. Now that studies show blacks suffering disproportionate layoffs under the Reagan Administration, the organization is fighting simply to hold onto jobs.

title: OF COURSE
description: A single phrase is dangerously close to destroying the remnants of logic and eloquence in America.

title: DAVID JAMISON CARLYLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss of $196,646 for the quarter and 9 months from discontinued operations.

title: Punter Released
description: The Detroit Lions released Tom Skladany, the free-agent punter who had reported today to the team for the first time this season. The Lions thus gave up the right to compensation if he should sign with another club, said General Manager Russ Thomas.

title: Air Travel Fee Backed
description: American Airlines yesterday became the latest carrier to announce that it would continue to pay a 3 percent commission on airline tickets issued by ''in-plant'' corporate travel departments. The step may enable such departments to continue to operate as they have in the past.

title: REVIEWING THE POLICE
description: The Congressional inquiry held - and prematurely curtailed - in July in New York City on allegations of police brutality was met with suspicion and resentment by the police and citizens. Some citizens asserted that the police regularly abuse blacks and Hispanics. Police representatives asserted that police officers were more abused than abusive. And Mayor Koch said that the Police Department's code on the use of deadly force is a model for the entire nation. What is the truth?

title: TWO PARTIES WOO VOTES OF HISPANIC AMERICANS
description: While President Reagan extolled the patriotism of the nation's Hispanic war heroes Thursday, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, was praising the Congressional Hispanic Caucus's courage in opposing Republican policies that he said ''are holding Hispanics back.''

title: CONWED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
The Rerun War
description: There's a war being fought over ''M*A*S*H,'' and it's not with North Korea. It's a war for control of syndicated reruns, between the television networks and the producers and movie studios that provide most of their programming. The networks have been barred from syndications since 1970, by Government decree. Now the Federal Communications Commission proposes to give them at least a piece of the syndication pie.

title:
Patents;
Improving On Electric Motor Unit
description: WASHINGTON AN electrical device patented for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has money-saving potential for private users. The unit, an improved power factor controller, senses the current and voltage of an operating electric motor and reduces the power input to what is actually needed to run it.

title: BRIEFING
description: At Loggerheads on Arms

title: C.I.A. REPEATS ITS DENIAL THAT PLANE HAD U.S. ESPIONAGE ROLE
description: The Central Intelligence Agency repeated yesterday its stand that the South Korean airliner shot down by a Soviet fighter on Sept. 1 was not on an intelligence mission for the agency.

title: Rezone for Poor, Mahwah Is Told
description: The Bergen County township of Mahwah was ordered today to change its zoning to provide 699 low- and moderate-income housing units as a result of the State Supreme Court's Mount Laurel II decision of last January.

title: CBS REALIGNS OFFICERS IN BROADCASTING UNITS
description: CBS Inc. announced a realignment of the top management of its broadcasting operations yesterday, elevating the presidents of CBS News and CBS Sports to new corporate positions with expanded duties.

title: LIST OF PROJECTS TO BE FINANCED BY THE PROPOSED $1.25 BILLION BOND ; ISSUE
description: Following is a breakdown, by region, of the projects to be paid for by the $1.25 billion ''Rebuild New York'' bond issue if it is approved by voters in November.

title: 6 U.S. Nazis Convicted In a Firebombing Plot
description: Six American Nazis who said they were only ''going along'' with an undercover Federal agent were convicted Friday in their third trial on charges of conspiracy to firebomb parts of Greensboro three years ago.

title: Coast Lawyer Denies Guilt In Case Involving Sex Tapes
description: Robert K. Steinberg today pleaded not guilty to charges that he falsely reported the theft of videotapes he said showed sex acts involving Alfred Bloomingdale; his mistress, Vicki Morgan, and top Government officials.

title: SALVADORAN LEFTIST IS DENIED U.S. VISA
description: The State Department refused today to permit one of the top two leaders of El Salvador's leftist coalition of political and guerrilla groups to enter the United States to talk to members of Congress and to address two forums on Central America.

title: NO SHIFT TO ATLANTA SEEN FOR CITY GARMENT SALES
description: Last month's three-day power failure in New York City's garment district helped generate large attendance increases at the Atlanta Apparel Mart, but those increases did not translate into significant sales gains for most vendors, industry executives say.

title: Miss Whitworth Leads by 2
description: Kathy Whitworth shot a 2-under-par 70 in swirling winds today to hold a two-shot lead after two rounds of the Safeco Classic women's golf tournament.

title: COUNTRYWIDE CREDIT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
BARYSHNIKOV OFFERED TO QUIT, BUT A.B.T. BOARD SAID NO
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov offered to resign as artistic director of the American Ballet Theater in a letter made known to members of its board at a meeting Thursday.

title: PUBLIC RADIO BOARD TRIMS '84 BUDGET 30%
description: The board of directors of National Public Radio has adopted a new budget of $18.76 million, down roughly 30 percent from the current $26.6 million budget that almost drove the organization into bankruptcy.

title: CHALLENGE TO FEMINISM OR JUST BAD MANNERS?
description: To the Editor:

title: Aspartame Use
description: The Dr Pepper Company said it would begin using G. D. Searle & Company's aspartame as a sweetening agent in its low-calorie soft drinks, including Sugar Free Dr Pepper and Canada Dry ginger ale, before the end of the year. The company said it would use a blend of aspartame and saccharin in its drinks, but would begin test-marketing a product sweetened exclusively with aspartame before the end of the year.

title: Haitian Asylum Cases To Proceed One by One
description: A Federal judge's ruling has cleared the way for deportation of more than 1,700 Haitian refugees freed from Federal detention centers, lawyers for the Haitians said today.

title: Rouge Steel Talks
description: The Rouge Steel Company, a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company, and the United Automobile Workers union have resumed discussions on a new labor contract, just two days after the company said it would have to close the steelworks because of high labor costs. A Ford spokesman confirmed that the talks had resumed, but the U.A.W. officials would not comment on what was being discussed.

title: THE FORK: ON THE OTHER HAND...
description: The difference between American and European eating habits in the use of the fork was the subject of last week's De Gustibus, and it evoked a few possible explanations from readers. Americans follow what is called the zigzag custom, meaning that they hold forks in the left hand while cutting food with the knife in the right hand, but then switch the fork to the right hand to eat. Europeans cut food as we do, but then convey food to the mouth with the fork still in the left hand.

title: NOBILITY HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net income

title: AMADAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses of $748,000 for the quarter and $933,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations. c-Net income after losses of $126,000 for the quarter and $236,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations.

title: Key Rates
description: * Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Anna J. Bernard Dies; A White Plains Lawyer
description: Anna J. Bernard, the first black woman to be admitted to the New York State Bar Association, died Wednesday at her home in White Plains. She was 83 years old.

title: Log Cabin Razing Assailed
description: A group of preservationists say they are outraged that a hospital sent a bulldozer out at night to level the city's oldest building, a 176-year-old log cabin. ''It's inconceivable to us that they would have done this,'' John Claridge of the Erie County Historical Society said Thursday. The Hamot Medical Center, which bought the property for a development it declined to discuss, said it had the house razed because it feared the Erie County Council would condemn the property.

title: Coping With Allergies
description: Some came sniffling and scratching. Others came to help their children. What they heard was that allergy sufferers can find relief, mostly through controlling their environments.

title: AIR FORCE ASSESSES MX BASING IMPACT
description: Basing the MX missiles in southeastern Wyoming and western Nebraska will create social and economic problems for the area, but, according to an Air Force study made public today, none of them are likely to be insurmountable.

title: ARCTIC THEORY ON ANIMAL ORIGINS ADVANCED
description: The hypothesis that ancestors of such plants and animals as the giant sequioa, alligators, horses and lemurs appeared on the fringes of the Arctic Ocean millions of years before they did so at lower latitudes has been advanced by the directors of two leading natural history museums and two other specialists.

title: Marijuana Found Aboard Freighter
description: At least 20 tons of marijuana was discovered today on a freighter that had been found adrift in the Atlantic Ocean earlier this week, Coast Guard officials said.

title: Beverley Nichols Dies; Briton Wrote 50 Books
description: Beverley Nichols, a best-selling writer who confessed in his memoirs that he tried three times to kill his alcoholic father, died Thursday, friends reported. He was 85 years old.

title: CITY SEEKING TO BLOCK U.S. RULES ON VERIFYING INCOME FOR SCHOOL LUNCH AID
description: New York and four other cities have filed a class-action suit against the Department of Agriculture, seeking to block new Federal regulations that require them to verify the incomes of families with children applying for free or reduced-price school meals.

title: PRODUCTION SET FOR NEW G.M. MOTORS
description: The General Motors Corporation will begin production Dec. q of its new downsized luxury models, eventually creating 14,000 to 15,000 new jobs, F. James McDonald, G.M.'s president, said today.

title: LABATT, JOHN, LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Books of The Times
description: EASE MY SORROWS. A Memoir by Lev Odyssey of a Believer Kopelev. Translated from the Russian

title: Symbol of Depression Dies at the Age of 79
description: Florence Thompson, the ''Migrant Mother'' whose weary, beaten face stares from one of the most famous photographs of the Great Depression, died today at the age of 79, a nurse reported.

title: Police Chief Guilty Of Misconduct
description: The Freehold Borough Police Chief was convicted today of one count of misconduct in office for allowing a sergeant to tamper with evidence in a drunken-driving case involving the son of a borough official.

title: TOUGH PRINCIPAL TAMES A ROUGH JERSEY SCHOOL
description: last year, he found that much of what had been said and written about the school was true.

title: DEMOCRATS AGREE TO JOIN G.O.P. IN DRAFTING A $12 BILLION TAX BILL
description: The Democratic leadership in the House of Representatives has decided to cooperate with the Senate Republican leadership in the writing of a relatively small $12 billion tax package this fall.

title: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 17, 1983
description: International

title: 19,798 RECEIVED JOBS FOR SUMMER IN CIVIC PROGRAM
description: A private program to find summer jobs for poor youths said yesterday that it had put 19,798 youngsters to work this summer, 4,000 more than last year.

title: Your Money; Various Taxes On Municipals
description: MANY investors in municipal bonds who buy them primarily for their exemption from Federal taxes are unaware that such bonds are nevertheless taxable in other ways.

title: THE WAGES OF BEING A CARING MOTHER
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Team Welcome
description: The wave of protest that followed the downing of a South Korean airliner has forced the cancellation of the Soviet national basketball team's American tour, as well as a Soviet hockey team's games at Detroit and Philadelphia this winter. But the Soviet women's volleyball team will still be welcome at a four-nation tournament set for the Long Beach Arena in California, according to the event's promoter.

title: CHILEAN LAWYER SAYS HE'LL PRESS THE LETELIER CASE
description: A lawyer who represents the family of Orlando Letelier, a Chilean diplomat who was killed in the United States, said this week that he intended to begin new efforts to prosecute Chilean officials implicated in the crime.

title: PLANNING FOR SOLAR ENERGY
description: ALTHOUGH really cold weather

title: Hartford National
description: The Hartford National Corporation said it would acquire Firstbancorp Inc. of New Haven, in a deal that would create the second-biggest bank by assets in the state. If approved by stockholders and Government regulators, the merger would create a bank with $5.252 billion in assets and 167 branch offices, second only to the CBT Corporation, with assets of $5.276 billion.

title: Bridge:Shanghai Tourney Was Run Byersatile
description: When an international tournament is over, it can be measured by various standards.

title: LLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
No Headline
description: Let the City Council Look Up Falling meteors have not hit New York, but falling construction cranes and bits of masonry have been a deadly danger. The City Council's buildings committee proposes to reduce construction perils with new controls that the full Council should approve.

title: Actor Becomes U.S. Citizen
description: Arnold Schwarzenegger, the actor and body builder, became a naturalized American citizen today, realizing a childhood dream along with 2,000 other people in a ceremony at the Shrine Auditorium. He came in the United States in 1969 from Graz, Austria, to study weight training and body building and has since appeared in more than half a dozen films, most recently ''Conan, The Barbarian.''

title: CLABIR RAISES OFFER FOR HMW SHARES
description: The Clabir Corporation announced yesterday that it was raising the price it is prepared to pay for shares of HMW Industries to $43 a share, from $42 a share, and increasing the number of shares it is seeking to one million, from 700,000.

title: SUIT IN A HINCKLEY CASE IS DISMISSED
description: A Federal district judge has dismissed a $14 million lawsuit against the former psychiatrist of John W. Hinckley Jr., who shot President Reagan two years ago, lawyers for the psychiatrist say.

title: Devils Win by 6-4 In an Exhibition
description: The New Jersey Devils, with seven rookies in their lineup, defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 6-4, in their first exhibition at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight before a crowd of 5,485.

title: 'SMOKEY PART 3' OPENS
description: The already skimpy running time of ''Smokey and the Bandit, Part 3,'' which opened yesterday at the RKO Warner I theater, is padded by an opening montage of earlier ''Smokey'' scenes, including shots of Burt Reynolds lounging in a zebra- print hammock. He is grinning, as well he might, because he has been able to sit out ''Part 3'' altogether.

title: Shirk Still Waits For a Phone Call
description: Gary Shirk is 33 years old, and no team has called to offer him a job since the Detroit Lions gave him a quick look after the Giants, opting for younger and speedier tight ends, cut him last month. But, after nine seasons as a pro football player, he feels he still has a couple of good ones left.

title: Bandits File Suit
description: The Tampa Bay Bandits and John Bassett , their owner, filed a damage suit against the San Diego Chargers yesterday, contending that the Chargers had engaged in illegal interference of a contractual relationship when they tried to lure away the Bandit running back Gary Anderson . The amount of damages sought by Tampa Bay was not disclosed, but officials of the United States Football League said they had been told that a 21-page complaint filed in a Florida court asserted that the Chargers' efforts to sign Anderson reflected ''one of the most sordid examples of overreaching misbehavior in the history of American professional sports.''

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 28.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Quotation of the Day in some editions yesterday was incorrectly attributed. It was from a study by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching entitled ''High School: A Report on Secondary Education in America.''

title: Cuomo Endorses Reid for Executive
description: Governor Cuomo endorsed Ogden R. Reid, a former Representative for six terms, for Westchester County Executive Thursday night.

title: JURY DISALLOWS PROTEST IN CUP
description: The international jury ruled in favor of Liberty today in the protest lodged by Australia II after Thursday's second race in the United States' 25th defense of the America's Cup. The decision means that Liberty retained its victory and its 2-0 lead in the best four-of- seven-race series.

title: BEER PRICES SOAR UNDER NY. DEPOSIT LAW
description: Since the New York State law requiring deposits on beverage containers went into full effect last Monday, consumers are finding their choice of beers, soft drinks and sparkling waters significantly reduced. And among the beverage varieties left, there are fewer in glass bottles and more in cans and plastic containers.

title: TEXAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31

PATENTS;
New Chip Design
description: A new design for an integrated circuit chip has been invented for use in telephone switching centers. The new chip converts analog telephone signals, which resemble waving lines, into digital signals, or strings of pulses. The inventor, M. R. Dwarakanath, assigned patent 4,404,544 to Bell Telephone Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J.

title: WHITE HOUSE WARNS A WAR POWERS FIGHT HURTS U.S. INTERESTS
description: The White House warned today that attempts to require President Reagan to get Congressional approval for keeping United States marines in Lebanon would send an ''extremely dangerous'' signal to the Middle East and the Soviet Union.

title: B.P. Block Goes on Sale
description: The British Government put some of its stake in the British Petroleum Company on sale today as part of its fight to control inflation and sustain national economic recovery.

title: EUROPEANS DEBATE WAYS TO SPUR THEIR LAGGING ECONOMIC UPTURN
description: Helped by declining inflation and the strength of the American recovery, the economies of Western Europe are finally starting to pick up after the deepest recession since the 1930's, but only slightly.

title: Thousands of Filipinos Protest Against Marcos
description: Tens of thousands of office workers joined a protest against the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos today in Manila's financial center.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article, headline and picture caption in Weekend yesterday misidentified the pianist-singer at Michael's Pub. He is Buddy Barnes.

title:
PATENTS;
Novelty Doll
description: A patent for a doll with extendable fingernails and toenails was granted this week to Josephine and Jeanne M. Blanco of Akron, Ohio.

title: STAYING ALIVE AT THE TRACK
description: ''Awake, earthling,'' the men from outer space will say when they beam into my living room some night after I have fallen asleep with the Racing Form on my head. ''We have traveled the width of the galaxy to question you about an activity on your planet that our computers do not understand. We believe it is called horse racing.''

title: QUICK RULING PROMISED ON MINUTE-OF-SILENCE LAW
description: Testimony ended today in the trial of the constitutionality of a New Jersey law requiring a one-minute period of silence for ''contemplation or introspection'' in schools across the state, and a Federal District judge said he would hand down his decision within 30 days.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The expansion Houston Gamblers of the United States Football League have signed the defensive back Donald Dykes, a former Jet, San Diego Charger and Tampa Bay Buccaneer. . . . Greg Holmes, the Utah tennis star who upset Guillermo Vilas at the United States Open before being eliminated by Eliot Teltscher, said he was turning professional. . . . Ted Turner , owner of the Atlanata Braves, confirmed last night that Brett Butler , the Braves' starting left fielder, would be sent to Cleveland after the season to complete the trade that brought the pitcher Len Barker to Atlanta.

title: Factory Use Rises
description: Spurred by hot summer weather and by revived demand for big cars, United States factories, mines and utilities raised their August operating rates to 76.7 percent of capacity, the highest in almost two years, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Policeman Revives Man Suing Him in Courtroom
description: Police Sgt. Peter Aydelotte rushed across the courtroom late Thursday to administer mouth-to- mouth resuscitation to a stricken man suing him for the death of his son.

title: News Analysis; WAR POWERS DISPUTE
description: The political stalemate over keeping American marines in Lebanon springs from a determined effort by Congressional leaders to establish an important legal precedent that President Reagan wants to avoid. ''There's almost perfect unanimity on policy and the mission of the marines,'' said one White House official. ''It's all a question of institutional pride, but it has big foreign policy implications.''

title: Hearing, and Listening, on Police
description: To New York's Mayor Koch, the important question about Monday's Congressional hearing on police brutality is its location. To hold it in the ''cavernous'' Harlem armory, he says, risks creating a circus. That misses the central point.

title: GERIATRIC & MEDICAL CENTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
ROGUES OF THE PAST HAUNT AN AUTHOR'S ALBANY
description: William Kennedy walked through his Albany, surrounded by ghosts.

title:
PATENTS;
Printing Process
description: A novel printing process patented this week can be used on curved metal or glass surfaces. RCA, which received patent 4,403,547, uses the method to print identification on the glass support rods for electron guns in its color television tubes. Steven C. Forberger, an RCA employee in Lancaster, Pa., is the inventor.

title: BANKING'S CREDIT CARD LURES
description: With the bank credit card market saturated after 15 years, participants in the battle for customers have come to rely on one main weapon: marketing ingenuity.

title: DART DRUG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $8.3 million.

title: The Greening of the City
description: To try to make New York City

title: Osborne to Get $600,000 Loan
description: The Osborne Computer Corporation, which sought protection from its creditors on Tuesday under the Federal Bankruptcy Code in the face of $45 million in debts, has won a Federal judge's approval for up to $600,000 in emergency loan money to stay afloat while it seeks added funds, it was disclosed today. United States Bankruptcy Judge Cameron W. Wolfe approved the loan on Thursday.

title: A WHITNEY GALA FOR MORRIS GRAVES
description: A party at the Whitney Museum of American Art honored the painter Morris Graves, and what made it such a special occasion was that Mr. Graves attended.

title: MICROS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 25
description: b-Net loss

title: EXPERTS FEAR ARGENTINA IS PLANNING A-BOMB
description: Intelligence specialists and nuclear experts are increasingly concerned that Argentina is developing the ability to build nuclear weapons and may actually be planning to build a nuclear bomb.

title: BAY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $1,320,000 for the latest first quarter and $160,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: U.N.'S CIVIL AVIATION PANEL CONDEMNS SOVIET DOWNING
description: The governing council of the International Civil Aviation Organization voted overwhelmingly today for a resolution ''deeply deploring'' the Soviet downing of a South Korean airliner and demanding a full investigation.

title: Bert Bacharach Dead; Columnist and Author
description: Bert Bacharach, a former fashion editor, syndicated newspaper columnist and author, died Thursday at Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness associated with a heart ailment. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Williams In Dispute With Nets
description: Buck Williams, the Nets' all-star power forward, is hinting that he will not attend training camp later this month if he and the team cannot reach agreement on renegotiation of his contract, which has four years to run.
