title: ZIMBABE'S SOCIALISM CAN BE ELASTIC
description: Among the ideologically significant events to take place here was the announcement Thursday that the ruling party was preparing a printed guide to socialism and the name change of a fast-food restaurant from Comrade Kebab to Mr. Kebab.

title: OLD FASHION FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
LEBANESE ATTACK DRUSE AND P.L.O. IN THE MOUNTAINS
description: The Lebanese Army, supported by five fighter-bombers, opened a broad offensive today against Syrian-backed Druse militiamen and Palestinian guerrillas trying to seize control of mountain ridges overlooking Beirut, Western and Lebanese military sources said.

title: WARM SPELL DELAYS NEW YORK MCINTOSH HARVEST
description: Rod Dressel stood in a 50-acre orchard here with 5,000 apple trees, their boughs laden with ripening fruit. Across the Wallkill Valley, where other orchards grow, were the craggy cliffs of the Shawangunk Mountains to the west.

title: Crying Foul Over Fish
description: Westway, New York's longest running road show, will apparently be in previews for at least two more years. The Army Corps of Engineers announced last week that it will take a minimum of two winters to conduct environmental tests on Westway's impact on the striped bass that spawn in the Hudson River.

title: ULSTER TEAM IS SEEKING U.S. INVESTMENT
description: A delegation representing four political parties that are bitterly opposed to one another headed for the United States today on a mission aimed at attracting new investments for this beleagured British province.

title: UPKEEP OF BRIDGES SCRUTINIZED
description: -foot section of a Connecticut Turnpike bridge fell into the Mianus River in

title: RELIGIOUS LEADERS DECRY ARSON
description: -day Jewish High Holy Day period that ended at sundown yesterday decrying last month's arson fires at two synagogues and a rabbi's house in West Hartford.

title: Teaching Children Self-Protection
description: Re: Georganne Fiumara's ''Anyone Could Have Taken Him'' (Opinion Page):

title: Nurturing Creative Energy
description: A mother who leads her child through a series of steps with the goal of learning to appreciate fine art is not nurturing creativity; she is merely manipulating her child (''Nurturing Creative Energy,'' by Fred Rogers, Aug. 21). That her strategy is benevolent makes the act acceptable, but it is not a gesture to be mistaken for fostering discovery or independence.

title: REACTIONS TO 'THE ROSENBERG FILE'
description: The Book Review has received an unusual number of letters about Alan M. Dershowitz' review of ''The Rosenberg File'' and Walter Goodman's essay ''The Rosenberg Cause'' (Aug. 14). A sampling follows. Given the interest in the issue and the fact that several of the letters criticize the book as well as the review, we invited Ronald Radosh and Joyce Milton, the authors of ''The Rosenberg File,'' to comment, along with Mr. Dershowitz.

title: Industrial Policy
description: To the Business Editor:

title: LEAVE IT TO THE MARINES?
description: President Reagan's latest problem is that while he is the Commander in Chief of the armed forces as specified in the Constitution, he is not the chief commander on Capitol Hill. His troops are neither in nor out of the civil wars in Lebanon and Central America, and he can't be sure how long he can keep them in or when the Congress will order them out.

title: LITERARY MANAGER AIDS THE HARTMAN
description: EVEN though the past season was the most successful yet for the Hartman Theater in Stamford, its artistic director, Edwin Sherin, found himself early in the season with new plays that needed work. Mr. Sherin handled that task largely by himself.

title: Cynthia Gummere Marries
description: Cynthia Clark Gummere, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Gummere of Glastonbury, Conn., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Schradeick Grinnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. David B. Grinnell of Ashburnham, Mass. The Rev. Arthur C. Weil performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of Christ in Hartford. The bride's father is president and chief executive officer of the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company in Hartford. Mr. Grinnell's father is director of external affairs for the Cushing Academy in Ashburnham.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Tainted Cleanup At Reactor, Report Says The crippled nuclear reactor at Three Mile Island continues to generate controversy in greater amounts than it ever produced electricity. Last week, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission charged that the companies trying to clean up the radioactive mess have used improper techniques.

title: REAGAN ASSERTS DOWNING OF JET ISOLATES MOSCOW
description: President Reagan said today that the downing of the South Korean airliner had produced ''a fundamental and long overdue reappraisal'' of the Soviet Union in countries around the world and had isolated Moscow in world affairs.

title: Adrienne A. Marsh Weds
description: At St. Peter's Lutheran Church in Manhattan yesterday Adrienne Allen Marsh, daughter of Nancy F. Singstad of Delray Beach, Fla., and James S. Marsh of Boca Raton, Fla., was married to Ronald F. Bentien, a vice president of the New York and Foreign Securities Corporation. The Rev. Charles Thorne performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Fred G. Bentien of Manhasset, L.I. His previous marriage ended in divorce, as did the bride's.

title: WHERE SOME SEE A FOREST OTHERS SEE A TREE FACTORY
description: In a case that attracted worldwide attention in the spring, 15 residents of Nova Scotia's Cape Breton Island, including lobstermen and Indian chiefs, sued to stop a pulp and paper company from spraying forestry herbicides tainted with dioxins near their homes. Last week, Judge D. Merlin Nunn ruled in favor of the company, finding that the spray was not dangerous in the quantities used.

title: PROGRAM AIDS THE HEARING IMPAIRED
description: ABOUT 6 percent of Connecticut's population, some 180,000 people, is hearing impaired, state officials say. But West Hartford is the only school system in the state that provides academic programs for adults who are deaf or hearing-impaired.

title: Peter Emmett Lewine Weds Deborah Gobble
description: Deborah Ellen Gobble, a newswriter for WABC-TV, and Peter Emmett Lewine, an assignment editor for ABC News, both of New York, were married yesterday in Wilmette, Ill. The Rev. Robert Lee performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church.

title: KEAN BACKS PLAN ON LICENSING OF TEACHERS
description: TO IMPROVE the quality of beginning teachers, Dr. Saul Cooperman, the state's Commissioner of Education, has introduced a plan to radically change the way they are trained and certified, and Governor Kean made an unusual visit to a state Board of Education meeting to endorse the plan.

title: ARCHDIOCESE'S BROADCASTER GETS A NEW ASSIGNMENT
description: AFTER 15 years behind the microphone and before the cameras, the director of the Office of Radio and Television of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Hartford is being assigned to other duties by Archbishop John F. Whealon, effective Sept. 30.

title: MUCH ADO ABOUT THE JAPANESE
description: I find it hard to distinguish between rags put in the Goodwill bin and current Japanese styles. Issey Miyake et al. may be on the ''cutting edge'' of fashion with their ''cut- outs'' - four sleeves and outside drapes. Let's hope this trend in fashion is ephemeral. JOAN MARY MACEY, Binghamton, N.Y.

title:
ART;
DOES VIDEO MEDIUM HAVE A FUTURE? STAY TUNED
description: FOR years now, video has been the coming art medium - with artists experimenting on tapes played over television monitor screens. One reason video art has never quite arrived is that most of it is dull, duller than anything on commercial television. And the snowy screen can never hold the eye the way a richly painted surface can.

title: Aide to Mrs. Reagan Named
description: Wendy D. Weber has been appointed an assistant press secretary in the office of Nancy Reagan, it was announced Friday. Miss Weber, who began work in the White House on Sept. 6, had been a public school teacher in Anaheim, Calif. She is a resident of northern Virginia.

title:
DINING OUT;
IRONBOUND LURE SHIFTS NORTHWARD
description: YOU ENTER the parking lot through elaborate wrought-iron gates and alight beside an illuminated fountain in front of a glass and brick building that resembles a ski lodge. Once inside, a glance at the copper-hooded bar and the three spacious dining rooms, each with its florid decor, and it is obvious that Meson Madrid is not the typical little Iberian restaurant found in Newark's Ironbound section.

title: FIRST JOB, FIRST SEARCH FOR A CITY APARTMENT
description: VICTORIA FELDMAN had hoped for her own bedroom, but she shares a studio apartment and sleeps on a sofa bed.

title: U.S. Won't Appeal Granting Of Asylum to South African
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service has announced that it will not appeal a judge's decision granting political asylum to Dennis Brutus, the exiled South African poet and activist.

title: 'CONFESSION' CITED IN WITNESS'S DEATH
description: In a cellblock at the Rikers Island jail last autumn, two inmates reportedly talked about organized crime, a Federal investigation and murder.

title: MORE THAN COMICAL
description: The cartoon, it would seem, has found recognition as a legitimate art form - that is to say, an indigenous 20th- century American folk art. This might come as a surprise to many of the originators of cartoons. By way of illustration, a 1968 Walt Kelly sketch shows a crow happening upon the dormant, coiled figure of Snavely the Snake, resembling a spiraling abstract objet d'art . ''Op Art!,'' the crow exclaims. ''Wash your language, pal!,'' the tongue- twisted Snavely retorts.

title: FASHION PROFILE
description: BEING RALPH LAUREN IS EXHILARATING, stimulating, ultimately gratifying, to be sure, but not as glamorous as one might expect. He is rich and enjoys being so, but he is often unable to enjoy the accessories his riches have brought him. He has won every award the fashion industry can give but he remains beset by doubts about his abilities and the judgment of some critics that his work is too derivative.

title: A SPIRITUAL QUID PRO QUO
description: COLD HEAVEN By Brian Moore 265 pp New York: A William Abrahams Book/Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $14.95

title: A PERSONAL JOURNEY INTO THE ISLAND'S HISTORY
description: WE have all studied history in school. We spent long, often boring hours half asleep with texts of Roman conquerers and bearded explorers. We were interested in part, but, in the main, we found it all a strange and twisted fairy tale with little meaning or inspiration to our lives.

title: REACTIONS TO 'THE ROSENBERG FILE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking to Leap
description: The 1983 National Football League season is still young, but when there's a rival league around it's never too early to start contract negotiations for 1984. And for four Dallas Cowboys - two regulars and two leading reserves - now is as good a time as any.

title: Most of Alaska to Go Under One Time Zone
description: Transportation Secretary Elizabeth H. Dole ordered changes Friday that will put most of Alaska in the same time zone and end years of confusion and communication problems in the state.

title: CHINA LISTS 3 OBSTACLES TO CLOSER SOVIET RELATIONS
description: China's Foreign Minister indicated today after a week of talks with the Soviet Union that Soviet military forces on China's frontiers were still ''subjects of major disagreement.''

title: BEJART BELIEVES IN BALLET AS THEATER
description: ''You can be a la mode for two, maybe three years,'' says Maurice Bejart, director of the Brussels-based - and often controversial - Ballet of the 20th Century. Tuesday evening, the iconoclastic 56-year-old choreographer leads his troupe back to New York for its seventh American visit since 1971, beginning a three-week engagement at City Center. ''We've been performing successfully - for all types of people - for more than 20 years,'' he adds proudly.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace misidentified the quarterly journal it publishes. It is Foreign Policy.

title: A 'Credibility Gap'
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WALKMAN SHRINKS
description: Engineers fondly speak of ''a new generation'' whenever a radical design change is adopted in a product. This usage of the word ''generation'' has lately spread into audio, denoting new and presumably better ways of doing things.

title: Pakistan
description: To the Editor: I would like to express my appreciation of Clifford D. May's article ''Hard Traveling on the Way to Shangri-la: The High Road Through Pakistan'' (Travel, July 24). It brought back many fond memories of my own experiences in Pakistan.

title: WHAT THE U.N. ACCORD SAYS
description: Congress approved the Headquarters Agreement with the United Nations on Aug. 4, 1947, and President Truman signed it four days later. It included an annex spelling out American obligations to diplomats going to the United Nations. The American decisions Friday not to let Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union arrive on an Aeroflot plane and to require that he land at a military airfield if he used a special plane have raised the issue of whether the United States has violated the agreement. Here are Sections 11, 12 and 17 of the annex, which bear on the issue.

title: USING COMPANY CASH FOR COLLEGE COSTS
description: The high cost of financing a college education remains a major concern for middle-class families, but a little publicized court decision may pave the way for owners of small, closely held corporations and incorporated professionals such as doctors and lawyers to claim a corporate tax deduction for their youngsters' college costs. The vehicle for this financial sleight-of-hand was an ''educational benefit trust'' set up by a four-doctor professional corporation to pay the future college expenses of its employees' children. It made annual contributions to the trust out of pretax profits and planned to disburse the funds to the colleges attended by the children. The trust was established at a local bank and an unrelated employee benefits consultant served as trustee. Every employee of the corporation - not just its physician shareholders - was eligible for tuition payments. They could receive up to $4,000 annually per child between the age of 18 and 29 who enrolled in an undergraduate or graduate program at an accredited college or university. Each child qualified for up to four years of benefits and there were no restrictions on eligibility; benefits were payable without regard to grades or need. But all benefits would end if the parent left the corporation for reasons other than retirement or disability. The forfeited amount would not revert to the corporation or shareholders, but would be reapplied to the trust to trim future contributions. The corporation - Greensboro Pathology Associates, based in Greensboro, N.C. - said that the educational benefit plan was necessary to attract and retain high-caliber employees, and each year it deducted its contributions to the trust as a business expense.

title: NEW HEALTH BOARD SOUGHT ON POLLUTION
description: BEDFORD WORRIED about the discovery that 14 private wells were polluted, residents of this community have urged municipal officials to ignore the County Health Department and set up a Town Board of Health to help solve the problem.

title: HIGH SCHOOL APTITUTE TEST SCORES HOLDING STEADY
description: The scores of the nation's high school seniors on the Scholastic Aptitude Test increased a point on the mathematics section and declined a point on the verbal section this year, keeping the combined average score on the two-part examination at 893, according to the College Board.

title: THE ENDURING RELEVANCE OF MARTIN LUTHER 500 YEARS AFTER HIS BIRTH
description: Jaroslav Pelikan is Sterling Professor of History at Yale University. His latest book, ''Reformation of Church and Dogma (1300 to 1700),'' will be published later this year. By Jaroslav Pelikan, THE MOST EXCITING AND MOST CONTROVERSIAL figure in Christian thought today is probably a man who was born 500 hundred years ago. Martin Luther had beliefs about devils and witches that even fundamentalists regard as excessively literal. He advocated obedience to government in a way that democrats find offensive. He spoke about the Pope and about Jews in language that even his most fervent apologists cannot really defend. He could be stubborn and cantankerous and something of a bully. And yet . . . . And yet, in every generation since his own, Luther has been a source of insight and inspiration to his enemies no less than to his followers. This year, everybody seems to be celebrating the anniversary of his birth, on Nov. 10, 1483, in Eisleben, Saxony, now part of the German Democratic Republic. Officially Marxist though it is, East Germany, which had previously regarded him as an enemy of peasant revolts, has now decided to accent such positive aspects of Luther's legacy as the encouragement of his work ethic and has invested millions of marks in refurbishing the churches, monasteries and theological libraries associated with the history of Luther's Reformation. Calling the Wartburg Castle, where Luther hid from his persecutors, a ''landmark of German history,'' Erich Honecker, the East German Communist leader, earlier this year said that visits to it by East Germans would strengthen their ''feelings of nationality and homeland.''

title: How Ice-Cream Shop Got Its Name
description: ''Dr. Mike'' is alive and well and living in Weston. My name is Dr. Michael S. Burnham and Dr. Mike's Ice Cream Shop was named after me.

title: CRIME
description: Arnold Landon, the central character in A GATHERING OF GHOSTS by Roy Lewis (St. Martin's, $10.95), is a quiet, not particularly well educated man, perfectly happy in the work he is doing. He is an investigator for the planning commission in a small English locality, and as such he often gets out into the field, advising the commission about the pros and cons of land development. Should ''progress'' come to old farm land, turning the fields into shopping centers and entertainment pavilions? Or are there factors that decree the land must remain as it is?

title: More Memories Of Jones Beach
description: About the way it was at Jones Beach (Opinion Page, July 31, and subsequent Letters to the Editor), both Sharon Monahan and Barbara Paltrow have made my heart ring.

title: IT'S ABOUT TIME MEDICARE HEARD THE MESSAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford Son Faces Court
description: Jack Ford, a son of former President Gerald R. Ford, pleaded not guilty Friday to driving under the influence of alcohol Aug. 16. Jack Ford, 31 years old, a political commentator for a San Diego television station and a former publisher of The Del Mar Press, faces a pretrial hearing Nov. 1 in Municipal Court here, said Julie Whitaker, a San Diego County Deputy District Attorney.

title: DOCTORS, OPERATING
description: INVASIVE PROCEDURES, A Year in the World of Two Surgeons. By Mark Kramer. 213 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $13.95.

title: DAM IMPERILS HISTORIC HOMES
description: WEST MILFORD PRESERVATIONISTS are trying to raise the $200,000 needed to move three historic homes before the Monksville Reservoir project floods them and threatens the remains of iron furnaces used in the Revolutionary and Civil Wars.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER
description: In years past someone with a spirit of adventure but little money could sign on as a deckhand or cook and in return sail before the mast to a foreign port. Today it is still possible to work your way across the country or across the ocean - and with a great deal more comfort and style.

title: Sailing for Profit
description: Greg Brazier of East Islip, L.I., was a college administrator in 1979 when he began to build a schooner in his spare time. Last year his 70-foot, two-masted vessel was certified by the Coast Guard as fit for passenger and cargo service - the first such certification of a sailboat in the United States since the 1940's.

title: BIDS OPEN FOR SEAT OF HENRY JACKSON
description: A special election campaign that could be pivotal in determining control of the United States Senate in 1985 began across Washington today.

title: NEW ANTI-JEWISH ARSON ATTACK IN WEST HARTFORD
description: The home of a Connecticut state legislator was set on fire yesterday in what the police said was the fourth recent arson attack against the large Jewish population in West Hartford.

title: Tremor Jolts Philippines
description: A mild earthquake hit the northern province of Ilocos Norte today, one month after a much stronger quake killed 14 people in the same area. There were no reports of injuries or serious damage in today's earthquake, which seismologists said was an aftershock of the Aug. 17 tremor. A measurement of today's quake on the Richter scale was not immediately available, officials said.

title: JET INCIDENT ADDS INSIGHTS ABOUT RUSSIAN MILITARY
description: When the Korean Air Lines Boeing 747 flew into Soviet airspace about 90 minutes before dawn on Sept. 1, it set off alarms in an network of radar tracking stations, ground-to-air missile batteries and fighter squadrons that are kept permanently on a near-war footing.

title:
ART;
A GIFT FOR MAKING THE COMMONPLACE SEEM SPECIAL
description: SOME artists have a way of making even the most commonplace objects seem somehow special, or of injecting a note of magic into prosaic scenes. Some can make us look at a familiar character or subject with a fresh eye, and this is the gift shared by both the young artists now exhibiting at Gallery North in Setauket.

title: JUDGE TO HEAR MOVE FOR RECALL OF THE MAYOR OF ATLANTIC CITY
description: ATLANTIC CITY A NUMBERS game in which the Mayor's office in this gambling-casino resort is at stake will move tomorrow before Judge Philip A. Gruccio of Superior Court.

title:
STAMPS;
COMMEMORATIVES HONOR FOUR GREAT INVENTORS
description: Four men whose inventions in the fields of electricity and electronics did much to create the world of today - although their visions for the future are still awaiting attainment - are appearing on a setenant block of four commemoratives being issued Wednesday in Washington, D.C.

title: Kay Rittenhouse Becomes a Bride
description: Katherine Scott Rittenhouse, daughter of David Charles Rittenhouse and Mrs. Conrad Latimer Hoover of Wilmington, Del., was married there yesterday to Timothy James McDonald, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce J. McDonald of Albany. The Rev. James R. Bennett 3d performed the ceremony at Westminster Presbyterian Church.

title: REACTIONS VARY ON DOWNING OF FLIGHT 7
description: REACTIONS to the Soviet downing of a Korean passenger airliner continued throughout Connecticut last week in varied ways, ranging from voluntary boycotts of Russian vodka to calls from peace organizations for increased negotiations with the Soviet Union.

title: AT THE BOX OFFICE, SUMMER HAS A SPLIT PERSONALITY
description: Some questions at the end of summer: Is it a reflection of American taste or of the releasing policies of American movie companies that this summer's 10 top-grossing films include nothing but fantasies, adventures, disco-beat romances and comedies aimed principally at the teen- age trade? That not one straight drama made the list of even the top 15 moneymakers is not surprising since scarcely any straight dramas were released.

title: 'WIENER WAR' INQUIRY LEADS TO INDICTMENT OF 12 IN JERSEY
description: Undercover agents posed as hot dog vendors to investigate allegations of underworld infiltration of the lucrative pushcart business in this casino resort, the state police said this week as they announced the indictment of 12 men.

title: Ruth Ehinger Married To Richard Alexander
description: Ruth Ellen Ehinger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Ehinger of Summit, N.J., was married there yesterday to Richard James Alexander, son of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Alexander of Glendale, Wis. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Strain at the Calvary Episcopal Church.

title: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 18, 1983
description: International

title: WHAT PUT THE 'FLEA' IN A MARKET?
description: WHILE new flea markets seem to be opening every day, attracting more and more shoppers, confusion about their origin and even their definition persists.

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN HOUSE PLANTS GO INDOORS AGAIN
description: IT is time once again to bring the

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN SMALL BUSINESS;
IN SEARCH OF ETHICS
description: What should business schools be teaching students who aspire to run their own businesses?

title: Union Hunger Striker Moved To Infirmary by Jail in Chile
description: The jailed leader of Chile's copperworkers, who has been on a hunger strike for a week, was transferred to a prison infirmary Friday after his blood pressure fell, a spokesman for his union said.

title: Zoeller Leads by Six In Celebrity Classic
description: Fuzzy Zoeller established a commanding six-stroke lead today with a 64 in the fourth round of the Las Vegas Pro-Celebrity Classic, a new PGA Tour event billed as the world's richest golf tournament.

title: CHILLY NIGHT AT SHEA
description: It is said that the humorist Will Rogers never met anybody he didn't like. Some people feel that way about baseball games. Take Friday night's game between the Mets and the Cubs, for one pilgrim the last chance to see a baseball game for its own sake, before the pennant races and the championship games take precedence.

title: OLD STARS HELP NEW COACHES
description: Any estimate of what to expect in New Jersey football this season should focus on the return of Craig Heyward of Passaic and Mike Morgan of Bergen Catholic in Oradell, the state's top scorers last year.

title: ENTREPRENEURSHIP: WHAT IS IT?
description: Defining entrepreneurship has become a subject of hot debate in academic circles but the repercussions are likely to be felt beyond university walls. At stake are not just such matters as how entrepreneurship should be taught in business schools and approached in research, but more important, what role it should have in the formulation of tax and lending policies.

title: SCRIPTS ON THE MENU
description: WHY would a man who has owned a successful printing and graphics business for 20 years choose to open a Chinese restaurant?

title: HOW LEADERSHIP IS CHANGING
description: THERE has been much discussion in the media recently about what has been described as the erosion of legislative leadership. What those who subscribe to this theory fail to consider is the basic change in the nature of the issues under consideration at the state level, and the new style of leadership that is required to function effectively within the newly aligned parameters.

title: Soviet Delegates Due By Plane Via Mexico
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko is not coming to the General Assembly session that opens Tuesday, but other members of the Soviet delegation are expected to arrive as scheduled, United Nations officials said today.

title: AGENCY IS SELLING FEDERAL HOUSING
description: The Reagan Administration is making an aggressive effort to sell apartment buildings owned by the Government, including many units intended for low-income families, and has reduced Federal holdings to the lowest point in 10 years.

title: RAY WILLIAMS BACK WITH KNICKS
description: Ray Williams, the flashy, high-scoring guard who led the Knicks to the playoffs in 1981 and then did the same for the Nets in 1982, has been reacquired by the Knicks from Kansas City, the team that had acquired him from the Nets a year ago.

title: Votes in Congress;  Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: Barbara B. Moore Marries G. H. Hayes Jr., a Lawyer
description: Barbara Brooke Moore and Gordon H. Hayes Jr. were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Cape May, N.J., by the Rev. Gilbert Horn, assisted by the Rev. Cass Shaw.

title: St. Kitts-Nevis to Gain Independence Tomorrow
description: The Caribbean twin-island state of St. Kitts-Nevis will become an independent nation Monday.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: It's All Aboard For a Golf Tour In the Far East

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Bargain Hunters On the Road Again Bargain hunters willing to leave the Y.W.C.A. in White Plains at 7:30 A.M. September 28 for a bus and train trip to New Jersey's discount outlets in Flemington are scheduled to return by 6 P.M. Y.W.C.A. members can register for $40, nonmembers for $50.

title: FARMERS WEIGH EFFECTS OF DROUGHT
description: EVEN with temperatures climbing above 90 degrees into September and no measurable rainfall since June, this year's farm harvest on the East End is expected to be a mixed bag.

title: A SUIT THAT FAILED
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC:BUNGO'S HILIFE BAND
description: Bungo's African-American Hilife Band sounded more African than American in its first set Thursday at Sounds of Brazil. Highlife, the dance music from the west coast of Africa, mixes European instruments and local rhythms in a light, loping groove.

title: FILMING 'THE LAST DAYS OF POMPEII' AS A SERIES WITH A BANG-UP FINALE
description: Pompeii has come to Pinewood Film Studios. Wander round the back lot and you see a giant, polystyrene replica of Vesuvius, 50 feet high and 150 feet wide, with thickly forested slopes at the foot of the volcano. Turn the corner and you are in the Forum, dominated by the temple of Isis crowned with gold gryphons and containing a statue of the Egyptian goddess looking like Elizabeth Taylor. Step off the Forum and you are in a Pompeiian shopping street with chariot-rutted track and stalls selling fruit, vegetables, leather goods. And, quit the sunlight to enter the studios, and you find a banquet going on complete with erotic floorshow bringing to the mind the heady days of Cecil B. De Mille.

title: C. L. Stanwich Wed To Victoria Lasseter
description: Victoria Lasseter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Karl Reynolds Lasseter Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Christopher Lawrence Stanwich, son of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence Stanwich of Wellesley Hills, Mass. The Rev. Robert Stewart MacLennan performed the ceremony at the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church.

title: Frogs' Tongues
description: Using microcomputers, high-speed movie cameras and a technique called synchronized electromyography, a Michigan University professor and a colleague disproved an old hypothesis that the tongues of frogs work like a crossbow when they feed on insects. The tongue of the common frog Bufo marinus works like a catapult, they reported in June 1982.

title: Foxes, Chickens and Hunger
description: If you are President of the United States, what do you do when people are going hungry?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm afraid some of them are going to have to die before we can get people's attention.'' - Stephen Gold, a lawyer for homeless former welfare clients in Pennsylvania. (20:1.)

title: Florida Puts 60-Day Ban On the Pesticide EDB
description: Florida banned the use of the pesticide ethylene dibromide, or EDB, as a soil fumigant for at least 60 days Friday, but it decided not to extend the ban on another pesticide, Temik.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: CONSTRUCTION of Greenport's long awaited new municipal dock that replaces the old Long Island Rail Road dock is nearly completed, though how the dock will be used - and by whom - remains unclear.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: HAROLD LLOYD, The Man on the Clock. By Tom Dardis. Illustrated. 357 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $19.75.

title: HIS SCHOLARLY VOICE WILL BE MISSED
description: The death of Sir Nikolaus Pevsner on Aug. 18, at the age of 81, took from architectural scholarship one of its gentlest and most powerful presences. Few writers in this or any century have been so earnest, so energetic and so utterly uncorruptible, and fewer still have so influenced the fields they studied. It is no exaggeration to say that both the history of art and the history of architecture perceived by the 20th century have been filtered through Sir Nikolaus's lens.

title: Miss Whitworth Leads Tournament by 3 Shots
description: Kathy Whitworth shot par 72 today, but it was good enough to give her a three-shot lead after three rounds in a $175,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: Why Connors Is So Popular
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NO CASE FOR U.N. INTERVENTION IN CHAD
description: To the Editor:

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Not VeryCharitable

title: Craig Maginness Weds Ellen Reath, a Lawyer
description: Ellen Watkins Reath, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry T. Reath of the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Craig Richard Maginness, son of Mr. and Mrs. George P. Maginness of Kinnelon, N.J. The Rev. Mary D. Glasspool performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Philadelphia.

title: SCULPTURE KEPT THEM GUESSING
description: WHEN Howard Rosenthal, a sculptor, was preparing to show his latest creation in a small farming community outside Riverhead, he was afraid his Manhattan friends might be too lazy to attend.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
DON'T PUNISH THE RICH: THEY MAKE JOBS
description: WHERE do jobs come from? We answered last week that they come simply from those who hire - from bosses. We also considered society's attitude toward bosses; and because bosses who succeed tend to do well financially, this includes society's attitude toward the rich.

title: 37 Flee Belgian Jail
description: Thirty-seven prisoners escaped from Tournai Jail here during the night while guards were on strike, the police said today. The strike was part of a national stoppage by public service workers.

title: Amy Patterson Becomes a Bride
description: Amy Patterson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Patterson of Durham, Conn., was married yesterday to Bruce Cunningham Baird, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry W. Baird of Wynnewood, Pa. The Rev. Robert K. Fell performed the Congregational ceremony at the United Churches of Durham, assisted by the Rev. Allan House O'Neil of St. John's Episcopal Church in West Hartford, Conn.

title: POWER OF THE PRESS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWARK'S MULTIMILLION-DOLLAR SOLUTION
description: For several decades many of downtown Newark's greengrocers, butchers and fishmongers have been doing business along a stretch of Mulberry Street known informally as the Mulberry Street market. But as the city's long-term urban renewal project, the Gateway complex, moved closer to Mulberry Street, it seemed for a time that these food merchants would be forced out.

title: HANDSOME SETTING IN STAMFORD
description: IT was late December last year when we first visited Aux Beaux Jardins, the wood-paneled

title: ; THE PRIMARY CONCERN IS PARTY ACCOUNTABILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Hops and Jumps On Democratic Campaign Train
description: Hops and JumpsOn DemocraticCampaign TrainThe political bells proved irresistable to one semi-retired fire horse last week. As some of the six announced Democratic Presidential aspirants challenged White House policy in Central America and the Middle East, George S. McGovern added his name to their number.

title: LONG TRIAL'S END NEAR FOR JURORS IN COAST KILLINGS
description: Four days a week, for nearly two years, seven women and five men have taken their places in a jury box in the Los Angeles County Criminal Courts Building.

title: Sharon Olds Receives Lamont Poetry Award
description: The Academy of American Poets has chosen Sharon Olds's ''The Dead and the Living'' as the 1983 Lamont Poetry Selection.

title: OLD AND NEW ACTS IGNITE A FOLK-ROCK COMEBACK
description: For a long stretch of the 1970's, folk-rock was distinctly unfashionable. It was the music of self-consciously poetic songwriters who had switched to electric guitars without taking off their fingerpicks, and of slick pop producers who would add strumming and dewy-eyed metaphors to the same old songs. With its wishy-washy rhythm sections and sad-eyed, clean-cut singers, folk-rock was always closer to pop than to either folk or rock.

title: OUR VEGETARIAN FAMILY
description: LIVING with a teenager is never dull, as all parents know. But living with a teen-ager who declared one day that from here on in she is a vegetarian added a new dimension to family life.

title: ST. JOHN ON THE RUN
description: A look at the two divisions that make up the Catholic High School Football League: Long Island Division:

title: INSTITUTE TO STUDY WOMEN'S ISSUES
description: SCHOLARS with a special interest in topics concerning women now have a forum in which to meet their peers and exchange ideas - the Women's Research Institute of the Hartford College for Women. The institute is one of 28 in the United States and is the only one in Connecticut.

title: HOW ALCOHOLICS AFFECT THEIR CHILDREN
description: ''ONE is the child of an alcoholic for a lifetime,'' says Claudia Black, a leader in the evaluation and treatment of the children of alcoholics. ''I treat children from 3 on up. The oldest adult child is 74. His guilt is part of his life.''

title: A STRONG LATE-NIGHT CONTENDER WEIGHS IN
description: Just when it looked as if late-night television entertainment, post-Johnny Carson (whenever that may be), might be monopolized by the manic vulgarity of Joan Rivers, along comes an amiable guy with the improbable show-biz name of Alan Thicke. He is the star of the too-cutely titled ''Thicke of the Night,'' a daily show being syndicated by none other than Fred Silverman, former president of NBC and programming whiz-kid-in-residence at the other two networks. The 90-minute program is being carried in the New York area, Monday through Friday, on WNEW/Channel 5 at 11:30 P.M., thereby running quite intentionally up against such competition as Mr. Carson's ''Tonight'' show, Ted Koppel's ''Nightline'' news report, old movies and television series, as well as the first half of ''Late Night With David Letterman.''

title: AN OUTSPOKEN EAST GERMAN POET
description: EVENING LIGHT, By Stephan Hermlin. Translated by Paul F. Dvorak. 119 pp. San Francisco: Fjord Press. Paper, $6.95.

title: Feminist's Ex-Mate Shifting
description: The ex-husband of Ginny Foat, the former head of the California chapter of the National Organization for Women who is accused of murdering an Argentine businessman 18 years ago, will testify against her, officials said today. The former husband, John Sidote, who is serving a 25-year prison term for murder in Carson City, Nev., asserted last month that prosecutors here had coerced him into agreeing to testify against Mrs. Foat. Mr. Sidote is the state's key witness.

title: CARDINAL MEDEIROS OF BOSTON DIES AFTER CORONARY BYPASS OPERATION
description: Humberto Cardinal Medeiros, spiritual leader of Boston's Roman Catholics, died this morning, a day after he underwent emergency heart surgery, a church official said.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: The revival of interest in tap dancing and early show dancing has sparked a new focus on the art of the many black dancers who were foremost in the field. One of the leading historians in this area is Ernest Smith, whose collection of films has been the highlight of recent conferences on black dance.

title: NASSAU'S PENNY TAX STORY: TO BE CON'T?
description: THE penny sales tax increase that went into effect in Nassau County last June has been producing more than $5 million a month in additional revenue - income that the county may find too hard to give up.

title: OSBORNE'S COLLAPSE SOBERS THE INDUSTRY
description: With orders evaporating , creditors knocking at its doors and $45 million in debt, the Osborne Computer Company sought shelter by filing for corporate reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act. The development was just another in a woeful string of losses and dismissals that had sobered the high- flying personal computer industry in recent months. Osborne was once a golden boy of the industry. Founded by a brash British entrepreneur, Adam Osborne, the company pioneered the low-cost portable computer and packaged software. But competition from other portable computer makers plus ill-timed product announcements this year left Osborne with almost no cash flow. As a competitor said, ''One of the big hitters just hit the dust.''

title: Kinard Developing Slowly for Giants
description: When the Giants play the Dallas Cowboys today in Irving, Tex., their safety situation will be the same as it has been for the four exhibition and first two regular-season games.

title: OUTDOORSNelson Bryant Bitter Fight on Striped Bass
description: NEARLY everyone concerned with the welfare of the striped bass agrees that East Coast populations are depleted, but there is conflict, as recently demonstrated in Rhode Island, over how to deal with the problem.

title: REID UGES AUTO BUREAU SHIFT
description: AWAR against drugs,'' linking increased law enforcement with enhanced educational efforts, was begun last week by county government officials who cited a rising use of cocaine, especially among younger children.

title: Elizabeth Muran Becomes a Bride
description: -Ann Muran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Van Muran of Brookville and Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Jefferson Alison 4th, son of Mrs. Carlyle J. Coash of Old Brookville and Mr. Alison 3d of Dunlap, Ill. The Rev. Jack Hascup performed the ceremony in the Garden City (L.I.) Community Church.

title: Melanie Miller and Craig Reilly, Lawyers, Marry
description: At the Lewinsville Presbyterian Church in McLean, Va., yesterday Melanie Blair Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee D. Miller of McLean, was married to Craig Crandall Reilly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald D. Reilly of Greenwich, Conn., and Vero Beach, Fla. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Pierson Barker 2d, uncle of the bride.

title: IN HOT PURSUIT OF THE TRIVIAL ON THE BENCH
description: Professors at the University of Chicago Law School are known to savor a good intellectual scrap. The topic of their latest debate: Who was the most insignificant justice ever to sit on the United States Supreme Court?

title: GIVE CHILDREN THE VERY BEST OF EDUCATIONS
description: MERIT increases for teachers? The arguments for and against continue to roil. On a sanity scale they range from the prekindergarten to the graduate-school level. Two of my least-favorite arguments appeared in separate articles in this newspaper. In one, a pundit bemoaned the fact that because teachers can only be judged by their students' success, judging teachers would put too much strain on the children. He easily ignored the strain on the children of an inferior education. In the second article, a teacher said that he had been teaching the same way for 20 years. If Scholastic Aptitude Test scores have gone down, he argued, it wasn't his fault, it was because of ''societal factors'' - television, divorce, drugs, etc. In his book, only the kids should adjust to changing times.

title: RUTGERS 42-22 LOSER TO BOSTON COLLEGE
description: Boston College routed Rutgers, 42-22, tonight at Giants Stadium and demonstrated that it had more than 5 feet 9 inches and 175 pounds of quarterback.

title: Jacques Kayaloff, 85, Is Dead; Ex-Head of Louis Dreyfus Co.
description: Jacques Kayaloff, a former president of the Louis Dreyfus Corporation, a commodities concern in New York, died Wednesday after a long illness. He was 85 years old and a longtime resident of Manhattan.

title: Kansas Kicker Gets 21 Points
description: Bruce Kallmeyer of Kansas set a National Collegiate Athletic Association single-game scoring record for kickers with 5 field goals and 6 extra points today in the 57-6 victory over Wichita State.

title: LEBANON'S TROUBLES SURPASS OUR SOLUTIONS
description: The best way to get a firm fix on the Lebanese crisis is to imagine that the aircraft carrier Eisenhower, by a surgical strike, could wipe out all the foreign interlopers - Syrian, Israeli and Palestinian - and then in a splendidly limited nuclear paroxysm take out the two superpowers but leave Lebanon intact. Does anyone believe this would end the war between the Christian Maronites and the Moslem Druse - or any other of Lebanon's multitudinous and enthusiastic conflicts?

title: U.N. URGED TO HELP ARRANGE ETHIOPIA TRUCE
description: Fourteen religious and lay leaders in the United States have asked the Secretary General of the United Nations to help arrange a cease-fire in Ethiopia so relief supplies can reach famine- stricken areas.

title: No Headline
description: Jim Mattox on a felony charge of commercial bribery. Mr. Mattox allegedly threatened to ruin the municipal bond business of Fulbright & Jaworski, the law firm defending Mobil Corporation in a suit in which the State of Texas is a plaintiff. The indictment said Mr. Mattox was trying to stop the law firm from questioning his sister about a 1982 loan to Mr. Mattox's campaign fund. The firm contended the circumstances of the $125,000 loan would show a political connection between Mr. Mattox and the judge hearing the Mobil suit, in which a rancher and the state are suing for $2 billion in disputed oil and gas royalties.

title: CASINOS IN JERSEY CATCHING UP TO LAS VEGAS
description: The nine casinos here are completing a banner summer in revenues, prompting projections by analysts that Atlantic City casino income will surpass that of Las Vegas, Nev., next year and remain ahead in the future.

title: FIRST NIGHTS AT THE MET
description: PAGE 78 BOX ON FANCIULLA HEAD IS OUTSIDE TYPE

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: LORE OF THE LURES

title: SCHOOL PANEL LINKS MMERIT PAY TO THE PROGRESS OF STUDENTS
description: A suburban school board whose district has been called an ''academic graveyard'' is planning to withhold merit pay from administrators unless their students start showing progress.

title: A FILM FESTIVAL WITH AN AMERICAN ACCENT
description: When he was an English major at the University of Michigan, Lawrence Kasdan knew exactly what he wanted to do when he got out into the real world. He wanted to be a film director. Between studying and going to the occasional demonstration - this was the 60's, after all - he spent a lot of time going to the movies and writing scripts, and like most of his friends, he assumed that everything would work out. Those were the heady days, remember, when everything seemed possible; and for a generation convinced of its ability to effect durable social and political change, the prospect of leading ''a full and satisfying creative life'' seemed a small thing to take for granted.

title: NEW RESTRICTIONS ON DRIVING IRK 16- AND 17-YEAR-OLDS IN SUFFOLK
description: ON a final summer's outing to the Robert Moses State Park beach the weekend before school opened, a group of Suffolk County teen-agers loaded the car and jokingly warned their 17- year-old driver to ''watch out for cops'' on the Northern State Parkway heading home.

title: OBLIGATION, FASCINATION AND INTRIGUE
description: MR. BEDFORD AND THE MUSES, By Gail Godwin. 229 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $14.95.

title: SCHOLASTIC AIMS AND POLITICAL BATTLES
description: I went to Brooklyn's Erasmus Hall High School

title: food
description: ONE OF THE BEST indexes of the increased sophistication of the public palate is the discovery that one doesn't have to travel to a specialty food shop for an item generally considered arcane.

title: WORLDS THAT DWINDLE AND CHANGE
description: ABOUT MY TABLE & Other Stories. By Nicholas Delbanco.203 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $11.95. PARIAH

title: A WARDROBE FOR STARTING OUT
description: Having read Michael Korda's article, in which he expresses his preference for dark suits, dark ties, black socks and black shoes - with the minor exception of a dark red tie (color of blood?) - as well as for men carrying briefcases (to fill them up with Transylvanian soil?), but his abhorrence of sharpened pencils in the breast pocket (wooden stakes?) and of people's looking into their interlocutors' eyes (fear of mirrors?), I feel that he should direct and limit his expertise to vampires, rather than to businessmen. JUSTIN P. LIUBA, Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: OHIO STATE UPSETS OKLAHOMA
description: Mike Tomczak passed for two touchdowns to the tight end John Frank for an early lead and Ohio State held on in searing heat today to upset Oklahoma, 24-14.

title: Tentative Pact Reached At Ford Rouge Plant
description: The United Automobile Workers and the Ford Motor Company have reached a tentative agreement on a contract, apparently containing concessions that Ford said were needed to keep the auto industry's last steel mill open.

title: Beth Ann Kennedy to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Kennedy of Needham, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Beth Ann Kennedy, to Joseph Michael Bucceri, son of Dr. Jeanne Richardson Bucceri of New York and the late Dr. Michael J. Bucceri. A January wedding is planned.

title: Catherine Bedell, Aide At White House, Wed
description: Catherine Bedell, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Rowland Holbrook Smith Bedell of Bethesda and Church Hill, Md., was married yesterday to Nicholas Peter Rollick Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Rollick of Woodstock, Ill. The Rev. Jan P. Lookingbill performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Lutheran Church in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: FATHERS AND SONS
description: KATHRYN YINGLING-HINZ HE FATHER son relationship - to ring a change on Dr. Johnson - is like taking a dive into an empty pool: The remarkable thing is not that the project can sometimes be negotiated gracefully but that it can ever be survived at all. Especially as the sons grow into manhood themselves. It is a tribute to the indestructibility of human nature that males can spend some 18 years in a paternal presence that is by turns mute and explosive, tyrannical and charming, aloof and meddling, heartless and sentimental, omnipotent and fragile - and still not have to be carried out feet first.

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN HOUSE PLANTS GO INDOORS AGAIN
description: IT is time once again to bring the house plants back indoors after their outdoor summer vacation.

title: LITTLE RAILROADS THAT THINK THEY CAN
description: WITH just 43.3 miles of track, a few dozen cars and only 13 employees, the Pocono Northeast Railway doesn't look like a railroad that counts for much. Most of the time, the line seems to go largely unnoticed here, except perhaps when a crossing signal is broken and the traffic on Market Street can't pass.

title: EARFULS, EYEFULS; September Trophies
description: Brooklyn's Atlantic Avenue, lined with plumbing concerns, auto body shops and tinned-up tenements, is one of the city's least bucolic drags. Yet when fall arrives, it's the gateway to a weekly pastoral pilgrimage.

title: WILL OF IRON VEINS OF COAL
description: A legislative veto intended to protect Western coal lands last week got an executive brushoff from Interior Secretary James G. Watt, who then found himself on the receiving end of a judicial brushoff.

title: A Bit of Cable-TV History
description: In 1952, the late Barney Balaban, then president of Paramount Pictures Corporation, formed a subsidiary company, called International Telemeter, to exhibit current motion pictures in the home via a home box office (''Home Box Office Moves In on Hollywood,'' by Robert Lindsey, June 12). The initial field test of the Telemeter box office was launched in Palm Springs, Calif., on a 600-home system, in November 1953, with the premiere of a Paramount motion picture, ''Forever Female,'' starring Ginger Rogers and Paul Douglas.

title: CUOMO NAMES 17 TO INSURANCE INVESTMENTS PANEL
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday named 17 New Yorkers to the temporary state commission established under the new law that liberalized investment rules for life insurance companies in the state.

title: CRIME DRIVE SEEN AFFECTING THE STATE
description: NEWARK THE Federal Bureau of Investigation drive against organized crime in the New York metropolitan area will have ''a profound impact'' on organized- crime operations in New Jersey, according to W. Hunt Dumont, the United States Attorney for New Jersey.

title: COOKING CLASSES AVAILABLE FOR NOVICES AND EXPERTS
description: AUTUMN signals the reopening of the varied cooking schools in New Jersey. Courses range from how to select and cook seafood to how to concoct elaborate desserts. And dim sum, it seems, is everywhere.

title: GUITAR AT TULLY HALL BY ROMERO
description: The guitarist Angel Romero is an artist of unfailing musicality, capable of taking the gentle miniatures of composers such as Francisco Tarrega, Joaquin Turina and Gaspar Sanz and imbuing them with epic connotations. His playing is virtuosic but inevitably dignified; one never feels that he is out to impress with flashy display.

title: TAKING SOME TIME TO MAKE FAMILY, HOME AND CAR SAFE
description: MY children have a clear view of society. There are the people who are out to get you, and there are the people who are out to protect you from the people who are out to get you. I am not happy with this delineation but how could they feel otherwise? From the time they were born, they have seen me scrubbing the lettuce and washing the pajamas before wearing. How could I hide from them the facts of the poisons lurking everywhere?

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: BAY HEAD ON THESE early fall days, when tide and weather cooperate to calm the usually choppy surf, the ocean caresses the sandy shore instead of punishing it, and bathers marvel at the clarity of the light jade-green water.

title: AN EXILED SOVIET SCHOLAR
description: EASE MY SORROWS, A Memoir. By Lev Kopelev. Translated by Antonina W. Bouis. Illustrated. 256 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95 *RED ARMY officer and scholar of German literature, Communist Party member and Jew, Lev Kopelev was imprisoned by his Government at the end of World War II for protesting against the looting, rape and murder of German civilians by Soviet soldiers. He was charged with the crime of ''bourgeois humanism.'' When he was sent to the gulag, his dossier was stamped ''TO BE PRESERVED FOREVER,'' a phrase he employed to fine purpose as the title of his book on his wartime experiences.

title: 'HIGH TECH' IS NO JOBS PANACEA, EXPERTS SAY
description: Communities and regions beset by unemployment and a cloudy economic future because of the loss of manufacturing jobs are working diligently to attract companies involved in high technology. But the strategy is unlikely to solve long-term economic problems, according to experts in labor and the workplace.

title: HIGH-TECH DRIVE LOOKS TO ACADEME
description: UNIVERSITIES are expected to provide the infrastructure for the emerging partnership between academia and industry that will, it is hoped, guide New Jersey into an economy based on high technology.

title: Eric Stevens Wed To
description: Amy Clarke Cuddy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Herbert Cuddy of West Hartford and Lakeville, Conn., was married yesterday to Eric Eugene Stevens, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl E. Stevens of Cumberland, R.I. The Rev. Charles A. Bevan Jr. performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Salisbury, Conn.

title: KREMLIN DECIDES GROMYKO WON'T GO TO U.N. ASSEMBLY
description: The Soviet Union today canceled plans for Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko to attend the United Nations General Assembly. It said the United States had not guaranteed his safety or the proper handling of his official plane.

title: Texas Routs Auburn by 20-7
description: Unconcerned by predictions that it was headed for a confrontation with Auburn's best team since the Pat Sullivan-Perry Beasley days of the early 1970's, a big, menacing Texas Longhorn team made all the big plays and shut down Auburn's wishbone offense today in a 20-7 victory that shocked a sellout crowd at Auburn's Jordan- Hare Stadium.

title: About Ancient Man - And Woman
description: At risk of beating a dead Eohippus (dawn horse), I write to take exception to the generic use of ''man'' and ''he'' in the article on early Long Island inhabitants (''Tracing Long Island Life 3,000 Years Ago,'' Aug. 21).

title: John C. McIntire, Mary K. Novotny Wed at Princeton
description: Mary Kathleen Novotny, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas William Novotny of Potomac, Md., was married yesterday to John Charles McIntire, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lee McIntire of Glenside, Pa., formerly of Havana. The Rev. Francis J. McGuire, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: IN WILTON, THE ISSUE IS LIQUOR
description: IT happens every day, said Frank Lombardi. A prospective customer walks into John's Best Pizza Restaurant on Route 7, learns that the only beverages sold there are nonalcoholic, and instantly turns around and leaves without ordering anything.

title: THE MET MAKES ROOM FOR THE 20TH CENTURY
description: There's an interesting sidebar - if you can call it that - to the Department of 20th-Century Art's just-opened show of recent acquisitions at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Right outside the department's galleries the new Southwest wing - the final element in the museum's 1970 master plan - is rising atop the Met's parking garage. To be shared by 20th-century art with the Department of European Sculpture and Decorative Arts, the new building, when it opens in the winter of 1985-86, will give 20th Century 37,500 square feet of gallery space for its classic modern and contemporary works, 12,500 square feet more than the existing Whitney Museum.

title: A Cloudy Dawn In Jerusalem
description: Menachem Begin formally resigned as Prime Minister last week, opening an uncertain and possibly unstable period in Israeli politics.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Dance Preview article last Sunday, the dates for the New York engagement of the Joffrey Ballet were incorrect.

title: BAT-DOR CELEBRATES ISRAEL IN DANCE
description: ''We are an Israeli company not only because most of our dancers are Israelis and some of the works we perform are by Israeli choreographers but because we live, work and perform in Israel,'' says Jeannette Ordman. She has the authority to say this, for she has been the artistic director and principal dancer of the Bat-Dor (''Contemporary'') Dance Company since it was formed 15 years ago. Tomorrow night, the Israeli troupe will open an engagement at the Joyce Theater that is to run through Oct. 2.

title: PARENTS ASK JUDGE TO LET THEIR COMATOSE SON DIE
description: The parents of a comatose Long Island college student have asked a judge to have their son disconnected from life-sustaining equipment that has kept him alive for the last 10 days. Officials of Brunswick Hospital in Amityville had refused to do so without a court order.

title:
DINING OUT;
VEGETABLES FROM CLASSIC RECIPES
description: WITHIN the range of restaurants that specialize - in steak, fish, hamburgers, fried chicken and pizza, for example - from time to time a new one that offers less pedestrian fare crops up. Minutes north of Nyack, Toujours Prete has put together a winning combination, one that seems to be gaining popularity. This restaurant specializes in vegetarian cuisine and seafood.

title: THE TESTING OF MARTIN FELDSTEIN
description: WASHINGTON THE rumors began the moment Ronald Reagan won the election and they spread as the President-elect kept putting off the choice of chairman of his Council of Economic Advisers. Surely, the press and much of the academic community speculated, he would turn to Martin S. Feldstein, the 40-year-old Harvard professor who was president of the respected National Bureau of Economic Research. Mr. Feldstein was the best known of the younger generation of conservative economists that had emerged in the wake of the Democrats' failure to stem inflation or generate steady growth.

title: JUDGE ORDERS A GIRL TREATED FOR CANCER, BUT RULING IS STAYED
description: A juvenile court judge tonight ordered medical treatment for a 12-year-old fundamentalist preacher's daughter who has a rare bone cancer, but minutes later an appeals judge temporarily blocked the order.

title: THE STRANGE ROAD TO A SOVIET PIANIST'S DEFECTION
description: Aleksandr Toradze, a 31-year-old Soviet pianist who defected while on a concert tour of northern Spain, is being held at an undisclosed location under the protection of the Spanish Government.

title: Diner Dissents On Restaurant Review
description: I read with amazement the recent review of La Zarzuela restaurant by Florence Fabricant, with whom I have disagreed in the past and with whom I definitely disagree in this instance.

title: GENTLE ILLUMINATIONS
description: ''THERE in the absurdities or pathos of the private imbroglio has been my story,'' V. S. Pritchett once wrote, ''the drama has lain in the sight of (people) floundering amid their own words, and performing strange strokes as they swim about, with no visible shores, in their own lives.'' A talented critic as well as one of the finest living writers of short stories, Mr. Pritchett sums up his own approach to the art of fiction with his usual concision. Comic in design, moral in vision, Mr. Pritchett's short stories are grounded in and preoccupied with the individual life. Noisy public events rarely intrude in his work; for him, more than enough drama is to be found in the inner lives of his characters; and taken together, those characters - so richly endowed with fantasies and illusions - make up a populous and distinctive fictional world.

title: SCHOOL OPENS YEAR AFTER FIRE
description: MONROE WHEN Patrick Walsh was about to start his 16th year as principal of Monroe Elementary School a year ago, he had never imagined that he would soon be chauffeuring tardy pupils to school. But for that matter, he had hardly imagined that his school would be virtually destroyed by flames.

title: Martha Jacobsen, W. A. Durkin 3d Married in Jersey
description: Martha Bradstreet Jacobsen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Jacobsen of Madison, N.J., and William Austin Durkin 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Durkin Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church in Madison by the Rev. Hayward L. Levy, assisted by the Rev. Vincent O'Connor, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: IT'S TOUGH TO SUBLET IN A CO-OP
description: IF you're thinking about buying a cooperative apartment and subletting it for the income, proceed with caution and examine the proprietary lease closely.

title: TAXES,LAYOFFS AND RACISM PUT FRENCH IN MOROSE MOOD
description: Back in the soft wash of reflected Gaullist glory, President Georges Pompidou said something about wanting to turn France into a Sweden with sunshine. These days, President Francois Mitterrand is fulfilling the least appealing part of the promise: new measures announced last week appear to make Frenchmen the highest-taxed people in the world after the Swedes and Norwegians.

title: Rockland's Realignment
description: After nearly seven years of negotiations, officials from Westchester (Section I) and Rockland (Section IX) completed a realignment plan this summer that will temporarily end interdivisional competition between small and large schools in Rockland County.

title: WASHINGTON OVERCOMES MICHIGAN, 25-24
description: Steve Pelluer passed 7 yards to Mark Pattison for a touchdown with 34 seconds to play and then completed a 2-point conversion pass to Larry Michael as Washington overcame a two-touchdown deficit in the final quarter to edge Michigan, 25-24, today.

title: SUNNY'S HALO WINS IN A ROMP
description: Laffit Pincay Jr. kept Sunny's Halo near the early pace and then drew off to score an impressive 10-length victory today in the $500,000 Louisiana Super Derby at Louisiana Downs.

title: LOUISVILLE 31, ARMY 7
description: -Dean May completed 16 of 35 passes for 217 yards, including touchdowns of 15, 18 and 19 yards. Two of his touchdowns came before halftime when Louisville led by 21-7.

title: Soviet Strengthens Its Fleet In Far East, Thai Official Says
description: The Soviet Union has strengthened its Far East fleet and deployed its biggest assault ship in the region, a senior Thai official said today.

title: White Sox Clinch West Title
description: Harold Baines knocked in the winning run with a sacrifice fly in the ninth inning as the Chicago White Sox beat the Seattle Mariners, 4-3, tonight and clinched their first American League West Division championship.

title: LEBANESE FLEEING FIGHTING SEEK ISRAEL'SHELP
description: Thousands of Lebanese who have fled south from fighting in the Shuf Mountains near Beirut have stopped in the Israeli-controlled area of Sidon to wait for a cease- fire or have continued into Israel.

title: CITY HALL SAYS LIFE IN NEW YORK IS IMPROVING
description: The Koch administration says it is doing a pretty good job of running the sprawling city bureaucracy, and it has offered as evidence a two-inch-thick document that features its achievements.

title: LEBANESE CHRISTIANS FEAR RESULTS OF DEFEAT IN SHUF
description: The three men gathered on the patio of the Lagon Yacht Club were the picture of prosperity and contentment.

title: THE PUSH TO REBUILD WILL LEAVE NO STONE UNTURNED
description: It's not a pretty word - infrastructure - and it's not the kind of issue that ignites the passion of voters. Yet Gov. Cuomo has embraced an ambitious plan to rebuild the state's highways, bridges and ports and has now launched an equally ambitious effort to get the rest of New York to share his enthusiasm.

title: MANY TREATS FOR THOSE WHO PLAN AHEAD
description: IT may seem a little odd to plan your concertgoing activities six or more months in advance, but a number of chamber music societies in the county operate on a closed-subscription system, meaning that few if any seats are available for last-minute door sales.

title: AS THE STAKES GO UP, SYRIA'S CARDS WILL BE TOUGH TO BEAT
description: BEIRUT, LEBANON SINCE the onset of the most recent Lebanese crisis, analysts and diplomats have been debating whether the fighting is a ''civil war'' or a ''foreign invasion.'' In truth, it's a little of both, a foreign invasion made possible and abetted by civil conflict between Lebanese.

title: THREE AMERICAN POETS
description: JOHN YAU is a clever poet. From a poem called ''Parallel Lives'': But now - as evening drops its newspaper onto the porch - I must leave them.

title: Conn. Learns By Experience
description: A six-week investigation concluded last week that state inspectors could not have been expected to detect the signs of stress that led to the collapse in June of Connecticut's Mianus River bridge. Nevertheless, the Transportation Department said it would revamp procedures to insure a better early warning system.

title: N. Elizabeth Gregg Weds C. W. Wolf, a Bank Aide
description: N. Elizabeth Gregg and Christian William Wolf were married yesterday by the Rev. Rudolf N. Moore in the chapel of St. David's (Radnor) Episcopal Church in Wayne, Pa.

title: MISSION: TO SOLVE MYSTERY IN THE DEEP
description: EVERY morning since early August, the smooth waters of Port Jefferson Harbor have been faintly rippled by the quiet wake of the charter boat Lady Barbara heading out to mid-Long Island Sound. If the mission of the men and women on board this boat is successful, these ripples will spread out and add yet another link to connect America's maritime history with the present.

title: A 'LOST' MOVIE SCORE TO BE HEARD
description: The list of important composers who have contributed scores to motion pictures is a distinguished one that includes the names of Ralph Vaughan Williams, William Walton, Benjamin Britten, Darius Milhaud, Virgil Thomson, and many others. One of the more prolific among this number was Dimitri Shostakovich, who scored more than 30 films between 1929 and 1971.

title: BEST SELLERS FICTION
description: 113 POLAND, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Seven centuries of history in fictional form.

title: NONIMPERIAL PRESIDENCY
description: THE DIARY OF JAMES C. HAGERTY Eisenhower in Mid-Course, 1954-1955. Edited by Robert H. Ferrell. Illustrated, 269 pp. Bloomington:

title: WHY THE JETS WILL MOVE
description: IN the commotion and emotion over where the Jets will play next season, the basic factors have been overlooked. By moving to Giants Stadium, the Jets' franchise would earn millions of dollars more than it would at Shea, and the team will be on display in the National Football League's best stadium without much travel inconvenience to most of its season-ticket holders.

title: Correction
description: An item in The Westchester Journal last Sunday incorrectly named the site of a benefit scheduled by the Council for the Arts in Westchester. It will be held Sept. 24 at Arrowwood, a new conference center in Rye Brook.

title: NEW MEXICO MOSQUE FOCUS OF SMALL COLONY OF MOSLEMS
description: The 2,260-square-foot adobe mosque is hidden among the juniper trees and scrub bushes that dot the rolling hills of northern New Mexico.

title: LANDLORD'S APPROVAL IS CRUCIAL
description: MANY tenants in rent-controlled or-stabilized apartments in New York City are spending their own money to improve their apartments. They reason that, since affordable rental housing is hard to find, they may have to stay put for a quite a while and they may as well spend what is needed to make themselves more comfortable.

title: CALIFORNIA CITY UPHELD ON VOTE TO INCORPORATE
description: A judge has upheld a bitterly contested election in which the residents of East Palo Alto decided, by a 15-vote margin out of 3,549 votes cast, to incorporate as a city.

title: HEADLINERS Flowers and Powers
description: Love can lift mankind above worldly troubles, according to

title: GETTING ONE'S MAIL CAN BE A REAL TRIP
description: WHEN my children were very young, one of their favorite books was ''Flat Stanley.'' Stanley, flattened when his bulletin board fell onto his bed, found that one of the advantages of being freakishly flat was that his mother could slip him into an envelope and mail him to friends and relatives he wished to visit. Were I to be flattened, I could spend my life traveling with my mail - and getting to places I'd never even planned to visit!

title: A ROCOCO HIDEAWAY IN FRANCE
description: To The Editor:

title: THE MODERN TRANSLATOR
description: Although the number of translations published in this country has been declining for a decade, some first-rate ones have appeared in the last few years, work from a dozen languages and from such difficult writers as Rilke, Edmond Jab es, Jacques Derrida, Max Frisch, Shusaku Endo and E. M. Cioran. There have also been some fine new translations of classics, not only from the European languages, but from Sanskrit, Farsi, Chinese, Greek and Latin. One might be excused for hoping for another golden age of translation.

title: STUDY PREDICTS RISE IN 2-INCOME HOMES
description: The study, called Plan 2000 and published by the Insurance Information Institute, estimates that only 25 percent of all married couples now have both partners permanently committed to the work force.

title: SUICIDAL BEHAVIOR ON RISE AMONG TEEN-AGERS
description: THE very last thing Richard Duvall did in his brief life was take a piece of rope and hang himself from a tree. He was born in February of 1964 and he died last September, months after his graduation from high school.

title: Much Ado About The Japanese
description: Carrie Donovan's article ''Much Ado About the Japanese'' (July 31) points out what fashion should be all about today - change to the fast lane, to keep up with today's world.

title: CHAMBER ENSEMBLE STRIVES FOR INTIMACY
description: TO capture the intensity of the musical moment is one stated aim of The Wall Street Chamber Players, an eight-member ensemble that will open its season with a ''living room'' concert featuring the works of Prokofieff, Mozart, and Mendelssohn.

title: Rebecca Moe Is Married To Jonathan Kay on L.I.
description: Rebecca Moe, daughter of Jennifer Leana Moe of New Canaan, Conn., and Point O' Woods, L.I., and Erik Moe, was married yesterday to Jonathan Evans Kay, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stuart Andrew Kay of New Canaan. The Rev. Guthrie T. Speers Jr., assisted by the Rev. Alfred H. Whisler, performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Point O' Woods Church.

title: SUCCESSFUL BLACKS IN LOS ANGELES PLAN TO ASSIST WELFARE FAMILIES
description: A group of black professionals has announced plans to provide financial support and free services to poor black families for a year in an attempt to ''break the cycle of poverty.''

title: Mary-Kate McLaughlin Bride of Thomas Tendy
description: -Kate McLaughlin and Thomas Tendy, staff members of the public affairs office of the Metro- North Commuter Railroad Company in New York, were married yesterday at St. Benedict Joseph Labre Roman Catholic Church in Richmond Hill, Queens, by the Rev. John J. Condon.

title: LAUTENBERG OFFERS BILL TO AID COMPUTER TRAINING IN SCHOOLS
description: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, who became a millionaire by founding what became the nation's largest data-processing company, introduced legislation this week to provide Federal funds for computer education in public schools across the country.

title: Chile Counts The Years
description: Chile last week commemorated the 10th anniversary of Gen. Augusto Pinochet's regime with more demonstrations, violence and a promise by the General to remain in power for six years more. As he dismissed opponents as ''agents of violence'' living on ''outdated slogans and unrealistic proposals,'' Santiago slum residents battled police in barricaded streets they claimed were ''liberated from the dictatorship.''

title: U.S. WARSHIPS FIRE ON LEBANON AREA HELD BY DAMASCUS
description: Two United States warships bombarded anti- Government artillery positions deep inside Syrian- controlled areas of Lebanon today. The Syrians responded with a threat to retaliate against American forces if their positions were attacked.

title: U.S.SEEKS TO PRESERVE SHIP SUNK IN PEARL HARBOUR ATTACK
description: Divers have begun charting the twisted wreckage of the U.S.S. Arizona in Pearl Harbor, hoping to find ways to preserve the monument and perhaps answer some historical questions.

title: The Influence of William Clark
description: After reading Steven Weisman's article ''The Influence of William Clark'' (Aug. 14), I can only be worried about the country's future.

title: DON'T COUNT ECONOMIC RIGHTS AS CIVIL RIGHTS, SOME ARGUE
description: Do civil rights include economic rights? Does a commitment to civil rights require more Federal spending on social welfare programs designed to enhance economic opportunities for blacks and other minorities?

title: AIRPORT STUDY CITES ECONOMIC BENEFITS
description: MORE than a quarter of a billion dollars of the county's economy last year can be traced to the Westchester County Airport, according to a new study released last week by the County Chamber of Commerce.

title: Death of Singer's Wife Linked to Methadone
description: The amount of methadone in the body of Shawn Michelle Lewis, wife of the rock singer Jerry Lee Lewis, was ''10 times the starting therapeutic dose'' of the synthetic drug, a prosecutor says.

title: Topics Earfuls, Eyefuls
description: Misfire

title: NONCOMMERCIAL FILM SERIES ROLL AGAIN
description: AS autumn approaches, there is a flurry of activity in the darker recesses of some of the county's colleges, libraries and smaller theaters. In tiny back rooms, projectionists will soon begin threading reel after reel of myriad old and new, foreign and domestic, commercial and noncommericial films. A variety of alternative film- viewing possibilities are about to make their debuts.

title: CUSTOMS AND COSTUMES
description: he Metropolitan will be exhibiting 36 costumes, ranging from Jean De Reszke's Otello in 1892 to Leonard Warren's Rigoletto in 1951. Caruso's famous clown suit from ''Pagliacci'' will be there along with Ezio Pinza's resplendent Boris Godunov. Costumes for De Reszke and Beniamino Gigli, Carmela Ponselle and Lily Pons, Kirsten Flagstad and Lillian Nordica, and many more, are also represented.

title: BATTLE OVER CHILD LEADS TO INQUIRIES
description: JERSEY CITY THE case of a woman on welfare battling the state's Division of Youth and Family Services for the return of her 7-year-old son has taken a new turn with a report that the child's health has deteriorated.

title: WOULD CHEKHOV HAVE EMBRACED THIS 'VANYA'?
description: A key - some would say the key - moment of modern drama comes at the end of ''Waiting for Godot.'' Estragon, the more disconsolate of Samuel Beckett's two tramps, removes his string belt in order to hang himself; and his pants promptly fall down to his knees or, if the costume department has its measurements right, his ankles. Was there ever a more telling metaphor for poor bumbling man's not-infrequent feelings of helplessness, futility and sheer silliness in a world stripped of faith?

title: REMEMBRANCE OF INVESTMENTS PAST
description: ''IRAN into Henri de Rothschild

title: WINE
description: WINE BARS are all the rage. Everyone - well, everyone who drinks wine - loves them. They offer wine by the glass, cold cuts - which they call charcuterie - and the companionship of people who share one's, er, values.

title: Execution of Murderer By Georgia Is Delayed
description: The State of Georgia may not execute John Eldon Smith on Wednesday, Justice Lewis Powell of the United States Supreme Court decided today.

title: 4 ARE MISSING IN DITCHING OFF L.I.
description: A single-engine plane carrying four members of a Long Island family apparently ran out of fuel and crashed into the Atlantic Ocean near Jones Beach last night.

title: Guest Observer
description: The Mark of Zorro KEITH BENDIS

title: MANY ARE THE TRIOS AND MANY ARE THEIR VIRTUES
description: Sometimes lost among Franz Joseph Haydn's incredibly vast output are the trios, a form which, like the symphonies and string quartets, he raised to the heights of musical expression. Along with the 100-plus symphonies, the 83 quartets, the 60-odd piano sonatas, the dozen or so masses, the two oratorios and at least 15 major stage works, are some 200 trios for various combinations of instruments.

title: Sharon Lockhart, John Carter Wed
description: Sharon Lorinda Lockhart, daughter of the late Chauncenella Lockhart Henry and the late Earl Henry, both of New York, was married yesterday to John W. Carter, son of Judge Robert L. Carter of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York and the late Mrs. Carter. The Rev. M. Moran Weston, the bride's godfather and rector emeritus of St. Philip's Episcopal Church in New York, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: WYOMING PROSPECTS
description: When John Colter, trapper, mountain man and first non-Indian to enter Wyoming, spent the winter of 1807 in the areas now known as Jackson Hole and Cody, a new era began in America. Raw, hard and magnificent, Wyoming was the Wild West. Not much seems to have changed.

title: Saint-Gaudens
description: To the Editor: The article ''Touring the Saint-Gaudens Sculpture Park'' by Noel Perrin (Travel, July 24) de

title: Catherine V. Blake and Michael E. Gilson Marry
