description: Catherine Victoria Blake, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Blake of Port Richmond Center, Staten Island, was married yesterday to Michael Edwin Gilson, son of Janet French Gilson of Long Beach, Calif., and the late Arnold Moore Gilson. The Rev. Norman Catir performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (the Little Church Around the Corner).

title: POINTERS ON DEVELOPING A PERSONAL STYLE
description: Apersonal style in photography does not develop magically. It is not a quality - like blond hair or a cleft chin - that some have and others don't. It requires strong motivation and commitment in order to develop, so Sunday photographers who dig out their cameras twice a year to record a holiday celebration or vacation trip cannot expect to develop style.

title: OPENING THE GATES TO CHARLESTON
description: In some ways Charleston hasn't changed.

title: A CENTURY OF OFFSTAGE LIFE AT THE METROPOLITAN OPERA
description: Bernard Holland is a New York Times music critic. By Bernard Holland PERA HOUSES MEASURE THEIR histories in sensory experience, not fact. They are, in the end, what our ears and eyes remember of them - accumulated layers of voices heard and spectacles seen, ringing, then fading, across the years. The Metropolitan Opera, which will celebrate its 100th birthday next month, cannot reinvoke the flavor of its first performance - Gounod's ''Faust'' on Oct. 22, 1883 - nor can it bring back the voices of Caruso, Flagstad, Ponselle and De Reszke, who sang there in the years that followed.

title: TWO ONE-ROOM SCHOOLHOUSES ARE GETTING PUT TO NEW USE
description: ''THE children who come here are always so amazed,'' said Madeline Schaeffer, coordinator of the educational program at the Marble School House, a one-room school maintained by the Eastchester Historical Society. ''They will say to me, 'Where's the gym and where's the art room and where's the music room?' It's difficult for them to understand that one teacher taught all of that.''

title: PRIMARY RESULTS YIELD SOME SURPRISES
description: THE final hurdles before the November elections were cleared last week by scores of Westchester political candidates seeking their parties' endorsements. In some cases, the results were surprising, even stunning.

title: THE INFLUENCE OF WILLIAM CLARK
description: Once again, the press is reporting conflicts within the nation's foreign-policy organization.

title: HEADLINERS Artists and Cages
description: It takes an artful politician to survive the politics of art in Moscow, and

title: Worst Location For Tennis
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: DR. WALTER LANGER, FOUNDER OF EVYAN PERFUME CONCERN
description: Baron Walter Langer von Langendorff, the Austrian-born chemist who founded Evyan Perfumes Inc. and created its White Shoulders fragrance, died Wednesday in his suite at the Hotel Pierre. He was in his mid-70s.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: On any given week New York can muster up an approximation of a non-stop jazz piano festival, what with the number of jazz piano rooms such as the Knickerbocker Saloon, Zinno's and the Carnegie Tavern and places that house resident pianists such as Barbara Carroll at Bemelmans Bar or Junior Mance at the Village Gate on Sundays and Mondays.

title: U.S. VULNERABILITY TO OIL CUTOFF SEEN
description: The United States will become increasingly vulnerable to any cutoff of oil from the Persian Gulf, and the Reagan Administration's policies for meeting that threat are ''a calculated risk,'' according to a study by a nonpartisan Congressional organization.

title: IS FIRST BLACK MISS AMERICA
description: Miss New York, Vanessa Williams, tonight was chosen Miss America 1984 and became the first black woman to win the title in the 62-year history of the pageant.

title: THE REGION
description: 'War' Is Not aDefense, Brink'sJurors DecideWhat to the defendants - Kuwasi Balagoon, David J. Gilbert and Judith A. Clark - was the justifiable ''expropriation'' of funds for revolutionary activities was murder and robbery to a jury in Goshen, N.Y., last week. The three radicals, who frequently boycotted their 10-week trial, were absent from the courtroom when the panel pronounced them guilty on all 21 counts arising from the $1.6 million Brink's armored-car holdup two years ago in Rockland County. ''We are at war and have no respect for the laws, the verdict, or the sentence,'' the defendants said through a spokesman, adding they would forego an appeal but continue their efforts to overthrow the ''U.S. empire.''

title: Honor MacLean Is the Bride of Alan J. Waitkus
description: The marriage of Honor Lawrence MacLean, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm O. MacLean of Lawrence, L.I., to Alan James Waitkus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Justin Waitkus of Denver, took place yesterday. The Rev. Earle Pratt performed the ceremnony at Trinity-St.

title: INTEREST IN GARBAGE OFFERS RICHES TO FINDER OF JEWELS
description: Within days, Eric DeWild may become a college-bound millionaire. Or he may still be a 16-year-old with a penchant for picking through the neighbors' trash.

title: CANADIAN OLYMPIC SITE RUNS INTO PROBLEMS
description: In January 1982 local promotors convinced the International Olympic Committee to hold the 1988 Winter Olympics in and around Calgary. It was Canada's first successful bid for the Winter Games in seven tries. In retrospect, that seems like the easy part.

title: 2 More British Carriers Off to Mediterranean
description: Two British aircraft carriers, Hermes and Illustrious, sailed today for the eastern Mediterranean Sea, but the Defense Ministry said the deployment was not related to the fighting in Lebanon.

title: HOW 2 GOVERNORS REACHED DECISION
description: The decision to bar Soviet diplomatic flights from New York's main commercial airports was made by the Governors of New York and New Jersey Thursday against the wishes of the State Department, according to Governor Cuomo and other officials who were involved.

title: PROTESTANTS INCREASE USE OF BUSINESSLIKE REVIEWS OF MINISTERS
description: On some Sundays this year the Rev. Ian Stirrat will enter the pulpit of Sun Valley Presbyterian Church here knowing that members of the congregation are likely to be filling out forms rating him on his preaching.

title: Bates Motel Has Iowa Roots
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: TOKYO IS CAREFULLY ANGRY AT THE LACK OF 'SINCERITY'
description: No official will make the point publicly, if only because it would be in questionable taste, but the Soviet downing of Korean Air Lines Flight 7 may turn into an unexpected boon for the conservative Government of Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone. He has long advocated increased defense spending and the airliner incident is likely to make it easier for him to present his case to Parliament and the public. Most Japanese, their postwar pacifism fading, have already come to accept a stronger military as an unavoidable fact of life. Some even consider it desirable. After a century of friction and occasional war with Russia, Japanese tend not to need their arms twisted to perceive a menace from across the Sea of Japan.

title: Of Leisure And Religion
description: The article ''Around Card Tables, an Old World Discussion is Revived'' (Long Island Weekly, Aug. 21) is most interesting and enlightening.

title: NOTRE DAME IS UPSET BY 28-23
description: Phil Parker's second interception set up Dave Yarema's third touchdown pass as Michigan State defeated Notre Dame, 28-23, today.

title: Milk Production Lag Seen
description: Steady increases in milk production will slow down late this year and output may fall slightly beginning next year, the Agriculture Department predicts. August was the 52d consecutive month in which milk production surpassed levels of the same month the previous year, the department reported Thursday.

title: Paula M. Alduino Becomes a Bride
description: Paula Marie Alduino, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Alduino of Boston, was married yesterday to John Arthur Sutherland Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sutherland of Winchester and Chilmark, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Walter B. Davis in the First Congregational Church in Winchester.

title: A Writer Is Wed To Miss Whitney
description: Elizabeth Whitney, daughter of Mrs. Edward Abbott Neiley of Southport, Conn., and David Whitney of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to Richard Wylly Stevenson, son of Mrs. C. O'Leary Stevenson of Fairfield, Conn., and Richard Stevenson of New York. The marriage was performed by the Rev. Edward Prevost at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Fairfield.

title: A FRENCH PREVIEW
description: One of the favorites in the world championship due to begin next Sunday in Stockholm will be France, which scored a runaway victory in the European Championships in Wiesbaden, Germany, two months ago. The French have snatched narrow victories against United States teams twice in the past three years and will hope to do so again.

title: FRESH CORIANDER: THE 'NEW' HERB ON THE BLOCK
description: YOU might call fresh coriander a ''new'' herb. Its pungently aromatic properties have long been appreciated in Hispanic and Oriental cuisines but only recently has it become an ingredient in American and even French cooking. It adds a distinctive flavor to seafood, poultry, egg and vegetable dishes.

title: REAGAN'S CAMPAIGN ADVISERS SAY HE WOULD FACE TOUGH RACE IN '84
description: A month before the planned formation of a committee to re-elect President Reagan, his advisers agree that if he decides to run he will face serious political problems winning a second term next year.

title: Union Sq. Beauty
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT IKE WAS LIKE
description: EISENHOWER, Volume One. Soldier, General of the Army, President-Elect, 1890-1952. By Stephen E. Ambrose. Illustrated: 637 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $22.95.

title: MARTHA GRAHAM PROTESTS
description: The rare artist who can change the course of an entire art form and actually create a new one is an exception to the norm. In most countries, that genius would be granted the conditions most conducive to furtherance of his or her creativity and the preservation of that art. He or she would, in effect, gain the support of a grateful nation.

title: FILIPINOS FORM AQUINO GROUP
description: JERSEY CITY ACLOSE FRIEND and political ally of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the slain Filipino opposition leader, has begun a movement in the United States to support a nonviolent struggle by Mr. Aquino's Liberal Party.

title: Sarah Eustis Kelly Marries
description: At St. Timothy's Episcopal Church in Fairfield, Conn., yesterday, Sarah Eustis Kelly, daughter of Col. John J. Kelly, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Kelly, was married to Andrew deWitt Vigneron, son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Vigneron. Both families are of Fairfield. The Rev. Edward S. Prevost performed the ceremony.

title: 4 Cosmos All-Stars
description: The Cosmos were eliminated in the first round of the North American Soccer League playoffs, but they finished first in the point standing in the regular season, and now four of their players have been selected for the league's all-star team by a poll of league players. They are Roberto Cabanas , the forward who was the league's top scorer; Vladislav Bogicevic , midfielder, and two defenders, Franz Beckenbauer and Andranik Eskandarian.

title: Lisa Farlie Is Married
description: Elisabeth Anne Farlie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Newman Farlie Jr. of Upper Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday to Frederick George Bannerot 4th, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Bannerot 3d of Charleston, W. Va. The ceremony was performed at St. Cassian's Roman Catholic Church in Upper Montclair by Bishop Wilburn C. Campbell, retired bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of West Virginia, assisted by the bridegroom's father and Msgr.

title: CANCER TREATMENT CLOSER TO HOME
description: IN February 1976, Florence Puff,

title: A COUP FOR CINEMA CLUB
description: IT began three summers ago at the State University of New York at Purchase, where Marilyn Ackerman, who lives in Harrison, and Beth Kochen, of Scarsdale, met while taking a film course. As were many of the students enrolled, they were incurable buffs who immersed themselves in films and argued about cinema for hours.

title: VICTORIAN EVENT SET IN CAPE MAY
description: CAPE MAY FOR 10 years, the long Columbus Day weekend in Cape May has been known as Victorian Weekend, one that attracts many Victoriana enthusiasts. Sponsored by the Mid-Atlantic Center for the Arts, this year's Victorian Weekend in the only National Historic Landmark City in New Jersey will take place from Friday afternoon, Oct. 7, through Oct. 10.

title: LUCKIEST WIDOW IN THE WEST
description: THE PEACOCKS OF BABOQUIVARI By Erma J. Fisk. Illustrated by Louise Russell. 284 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Co. $14.95.

title: IOWA DEFEATS PENN STATE, 42-34
description: Penn State today became only the second major college football team in history to open with three straight defeats after being named the top team for the previous season.

title: INDICTMENTS END YEAR'S HUNT IN MURDER OF OHIO POSTMASTER
description: Village residents, still mourning the killing of their postmaster a year ago, are hailing the efforts of a postal inspector whose long investigation has led to two murder indictments.

title: SOVIET'S DEFENSES CALLED INFLEXIBLE
description: The Air Force's Chief of Staff says that evidence gathered from the Soviet downing of a South Korean passenger plane on Sept. 1 shows that Soviet air defenses are inflexible.

title: LAWS IN U.S. CALLED INADEQUATE TO BLOCK ABUSE OF COMPUTERS
description: An auxiliary policeman in Orange, Conn., was investigated last spring by authorities who suspected he was using the Police Department computer to check records for his full-time employer. But the suspect was never charged with a crime, prosecutors said, because he violated no Connecticut law.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
INDUSTRY ORGANIZES TO COMBAT FEDERAL CONTROLS
description: Buyers and sellers of coins and precious metals have a major new ally in Washington, a trade association called the Industry Council for Tangible Assets - ''ICTA'' for short. Its purpose is to counter a growing and worrisome trend toward federal intrusion into the tangible-assets business.

title: Salt Lake City
description: To the Editor: I was glad to see the article, ''What's Doing in Salt Lake City'' (Travel, July 31) with the reference to the ''This Is the Place Monument'' and ''The Seagull Monument,'' and I am sure that your readers will be interested to know that both monuments are by Mahonri Mackintosh Young (1877-1957), who was a grandson of Brigham Young. MAHONRI SHARP YOUNG, Water Mill, L.I.

title: '83 Cross-Country Outlook
description: Christine Curtin of Mepham High in Bellmore, L.I., returns for the 1983 season as the nation's leading female runner, having won the Kinney National Cross-Country Championships last December in Orlando, Fla.

title: WILLIAM CARLOS WILLIAMS'S RHYTHM OF IDEAS
description: Scholars and admirers of William Carlos Williams, whom many consider the most characteristically American of modern poets, gathered recently at a three-day conference at the University of Maine in Orono to commemorate his birth 100 years ago yesterday. Coming from widely scattered parts of the world, the participants (many of them distinguished poets themselves) heard speeches by Allen Ginsberg, M. L. Rosenthal, Robert Creeley, Paul Mariani, Kenneth Burke, Williams's two sons and the meeting's organizer, Carroll Terrell, among others. But the last word was had by the Williams expert Hugh Kenner, who in the lecture printed below illuminated one of the poet's major contributions.

title: DIRECTOR'S RESIGNATION STIRS GUILD HALL
description: SIXTEEN months after she became director of Guild Hall - and on the heels of the East Hampton cultural center's most successful summer season in years - Annabelle Hebert has resigned. Citing ''basic policy differences with the current administration,'' Miss Hebert has announced that she will leave her job on March 1.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SEARINGTOWN THE boys didn't want to go to summer camp. They had been deprived, they complained, when they learned we were going overseas. So we took them to Europe.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: OUR MARVELOUS NATIVE TONGUE, The Life and Times of the English Language. By Robert Claiborne. 339 pp. New York: Times Books.

title: LAW RESTRICTS ASSESSMENTS ON NEW CONDOMINIUMS
description: WITH the blessing of the New York State Legislature, assessments are being established on newly built condominiums in Manhattan at a low fraction of their value in the sales market.

title: REDISCOVERING 200 YEARS OF DUTCH FOLK LIFE
description: Restored and re-created villages as open-air museums began to appear in Europe, as part of the rediscovery of folk life and vernacular architecture, early in the 20th century. They are intended to preserve and bring together structures of various sorts that might otherwise have been destroyed and to present in an attractive manner the remnants of the culture and daily living of homogeneous areas of a century or two ago.

title: BATTLE FOR LEBANON: THE P.L.O. RE-EMERGES
description: MilitaryAnalysis

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN HOUSE PLANTS GO INDOORS AGAIN
description: IT is time once again to bring the house plants back indoors after their outdoor summer vacation.

title: TOPICS
description: IT didn't take long after watching ''The Hamptons'' on ABC. I began to show an unusual interest in the word ''mystique.'' The dictionary defines mystique as a complex of transcendental or semimystical beliefs and attitudes directed toward or developing around an object. East Hampton storekeepers are more direct and basic: they define the word as cash in the drawer. Mystique has a dollar value. It bought ''The Hamptons.''

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
 ALL'S FAIRS
description: With summer almost officially over, can fall festivals be far behind? Of course not, and this week on the Island folks who relish the fair circuit have plenty to sample. In Riverhead today, at the Shinnecock building of Suffolk Community College, the local agricultural community will celebrate with the Fall Harvest Festival, offering demonstrations and lectures on home wine-making and salad, vegetable and seafood preparation. There will also be concerts and an auction of Long Island produce. The festival is from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. Everything, including tasting of the culinary products, is free, except for what you buy from vendors.

title: PERIL SEEN IN CLEANUP DELAYS AT THREE MILE ISLAND
description: A member of the outside safety advisory board appointed to advise on cleaning up the disabled Three Mile Island nuclear reactor has warned that delays are generating hazards to public health and safety. He cited the possibility of ''a major event that can do great harm.''

title: SOVIET SUB SEARCHING FOR AIRLINER
description: Soviet vessels searching for debris from the downed Korean airliner in the Sea of Japan put a 20-foot yellow submarine into the water today, then retrieved it and marked the area with red buoys, a Japanese official said.

title: Q&A A Lone Tenant's Rights Question:
description: I live in a nine-unit building in which the new owner has vacated all the apartments except mine and one occupied by a 77-year-old woman. Both of our apartments are covered by rent control. If this aged woman dies, what would my rights be as the only tenant in this building? . . . E.S.K., Manhattan

title: JAZZ:BARBARA CARROLL, SINGER
description: When Barbara Carroll moved into the Bemelmans Bar of the Carlyle Hotel, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, five years ago, she was primarily a jazz pianist who occasionally sang. Now, starting her sixth year in the room, she is apt to sing almost as much as she plays, and she has developed a repertory that reflects a singer's interest as much as it does a jazz pianist's.

title: CONNECTICUT'S EMERGING BLACK VOTE
description: When Harold Washington was elected Mayor of Chicago this spring after a campaign marred by racial invective, Mayor Thirman L. Milner of Hartford sent him a telegram. ''Welcome to the brotherhood of mayors,'' it began. He was welcoming Mr. Washington to another brotherhood as well - of black mayors, of which Connecticut may soon be better represented.

title: WHAT CITY OPERA NEED NOW IS SUCCESS ON THE STAGE
description: The New York City Opera strike is over, and it's time to look forward, not backward. The truncated but still promising 1983 season will finally get under way Wednesday night with a new production of Massenet's ''Cendrillon,'' complete with projected English-language ''sur-titles'' above the stage. This will be followed just eight days later by what looks to be a lavishly cast new staging by Andrei Serban of Handel's ''Alcina.'' Several of the company's better productions are in the fall repertory, along with many of its most talented young singers.

title: SEOUL SETTING A QUICK PACE ON '88 GAMES
description: The first flurry of excitement is long gone. Now, nearly two years after this city captured the prize it so sorely wanted, it has settled into the unglamorous chore of actually getting ready to be host for the 1988 Olympic Games.

title: ANOTHER 1914?
description: The ghastly affair of the South Korean airliner had all the markings of events that so often have provoked world disasters: the combination of the accidental and the inevitable - like the shooting of an Austrian archduke at Sarajevo in 1914.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Calendars to the contrary, summer hasn't ended yet. Or so it seems with two free outdoor concerts scheduled Sunday - at, unfortunately, overlapping times.

title: MARY TODD DALE
description: Mary Todd Dale, the wife of Edwin L. Dale Jr. of the Office of Management and Budget, died at Sibley Hospital Friday of complications after surgery for cancer.

title: CONTEMPT RULING IN A BRINK'S CASE
description: A defense lawyer faces sentencing for his ''clearly contemptuous'' conduct in the recent Brink's trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE 96th annual State Fair at Great Adventure Theme Park in Jackson Township (it moved to the Ocean County park after the fairgrounds site in Hamilton Township was sold in 1981) winds up today after having brought together a mix of past and present.

title: No Headline
description: Meredyth M. Hull, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip G. Hull of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to H. Brooks Smith, son of H. Hanford Smith Jr. of New York and Nantucket, Mass., and the late Mrs. Smith. The Rev. Richard F. Brondyke, associate minister of the Central Presbyterian Church of Huntington, L.I., performed the ceremony at the church, assisted by the Rev. Ross M. Wright, assistant minister of Grace Episcopal Church in New York.

title: No Headline
description: Kathy Gertler Betrothed

title: ATOMS FOR ARGIES
description: The Argentines may be busily building themselves an atomic bomb. With such a weapon, Argentina would be able to deal with Great Britain on the Falkland Islands as a nuclear equal, as well as menace Chile in the dispute over islands at the tip of South America.

title: A LITTLE TEXAS IN DANBURY
description: TWO floors above Main Street in midtown Danbury, a visitor is instantly taken to another place. In the office of Mark Rothbaum & Associates, the photographs and gold records of the country-pop singer Willie Nelson seem to transport one into the hospitality of Mr. Nelson's Texan-styled outdoor concerts, which he calls ''picnics.''

title: AFTER OCEAN PRIZE, A NEW COURSE
description: ''IWAS shocked,'' said Akira Okubo of Stony Brook. Early this year, Dr. Okubo, an oceanographer who is a professor of physical ecology at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, stood holding a letter from the Oceanographic Society of Japan.

title: HIGHER RISKS SEEN IN NEW E.P.A. RULES
description: New rules proposed by the Environmental Protection Agency to govern two environmental hazards would permit greater health risks than past Presidential administrations considered acceptable, according to agency officials.

title: 7 S the Bronx Reinstated
description: The Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development has decided to reinstate the applications of seven nonprofit organizations for grants to build 600 apartments for the elderly and the handicapped in the Bronx.

title: ROY ANDRIES DE GROOT, WINE AND FOOD CRITIC
description: Roy Andries de Groot, a wine and food critic recognized for both his culinary knowledge and his elegant writing style, died Friday in his Greenwich Village apartment of a self-inflicted gunshot wound. He was 73 years old.

title: JAPANESE AUTO LEADS FUEL EFFICIENCY RATINGS
description: The 1984 Honda Civic coupe is the most fuel-efficient automobile sold in the United States and the first gasoline- powered car to get the top rating in six years, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Last year's box-office success of ''An Officer and a Gentleman,'' said Jerry Ludwig, ''had a lot to do with giving them (NBC) the courage to put the thing on the air.'' Mr. Ludwig was referring to ''For Love and Honor,'' a new dramatic series about men and women involved in peacetime military service in a paratrooper battalion. Mr. Ludwig, supervising producer, said that ''as an idea'' his show was in the works before ''An Officer and a Gentleman'' became a screen hit. The series stars Cliff Potts, Yaphet Kotto, Shelley Smith and Rachel Ticotin. It begins with a two-hour movie that will be shown on Friday at 9 P.M. and will thereafter be seen Fridays at 10 P.M.

title:
GARDENING;
WHEN HOUSE PLANTS GO INDOORS AGAIN
description: IT is time once again to bring the house plants back indoors after their outdoor summer vacation.

title: ELUSIVE DISEASE IS KILLING OFF GIRAFFE HERD AT BALTIMORE ZOO
description: A wasting disease has wiped out most of the Baltimore Zoo's prized herd of Angolan giraffes, and scientists are at a loss to stop it.

title: Spain Fires A General
description: Spain's Socialist Government usually walks warily in fields where the rightist-oriented military tread. But last week, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez's cabinet evidently felt it was time for toughness and bounced a senior officer who had defended colleagues now in prison for an abortive coup in February 1981.

title: THE REGION
description: ContemplatingThe Constitution

title: INTEREST REKINDLED IN RECYCLING PLANT
description: TO drivers along the Meadowbrook Parkway, it is apparent that the paint on the tall, twin, steel gray stacks is chipping away. From the Stewart Avenue side, it's obvious the building's corrugated metal siding is fighting a losing battle with rust.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: FAMILY INSTALLMENTS: Memories of Growing Up Hispanic. By Edward Rivera. (Penguin, $5.95.) A graceful, powerful family saga by a Puerto Rican writer who grew up in New York's barrio, ''Family Installments'' uses fictional names, but our critic, Phillip Lopate, noted that its strongest sections seem to derive from memory rather than imagination. Major characters include Papi (''a masterpiece''), his wife Mami, their older son Tego and their younger son Santos, who narrates the story and emerges as ''a subtle, ironic and educated observer.'' The book soars, Mr. Lopate said. THE SILMARILLION. By J. R. R. Tolkien. (Houghton Mifflin, $7.95.) Tolkien's chronicle of all that happened in his imaginary kingdoms of towers, dwarfs, elves and men before ''The Lord of the Rings'' takes the form of a collection of legends that features some particularly memorable devil figures. Reviewing the book in 1977, John Gardner said, ''What is finally most moving is not the individual legends but the total vision, the eccentric heroism of Tolkien's attempt . . . to rejuvenate the medieval Christian way of seeing and feeling, although - as all his legends reiterate - we can no longer see clearly . . . and our main feeling is now tragic dread.''

title: 'TIDE OF MEDIOCRITY' MAY NOT BE RISING AS FAST AS IT SEEMS
description: The National Commission on Excellence in Education issued a much-publicized report in April lamenting the ''rising tide of mediocrity'' in American education. Ernest L. Boyer, a former United States Commissioner of Education, suggests, ''What we have is a rising tide of school reports.''

title: FEDERAL MORTGAGE TAX-CREDIT BILL RAISES CONCERNS
description: STATE mortgage-agency officials in the

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
WHO'S TO SAY WHAT THEY ARE WORTH?
description: IF rhetoric were fact, tax-free

title: Iraqi Says His Country Wants Peace With Iran
description: President Saddam Hussein said in an interview published today that Iraq wanted peace and good relations with Iran based on justice, mutual respect and noninterference in each other's internal affairs.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
BEYOND HIGH TECH, HIGH TOUCH
description: THE radio program is known as ''The Women's Line,'' and the first voice one hears is that of Aretha Franklin, singing a popular old ballad. ''When she gets weary,'' the recording croons, ''try a little tenderness.''

title: Shorter Trying Again
description: He's won his share of marathon medals, including the gold at the 1972 Olympics, but Frank Shorter has never won the New York Marathon. But he hasn't given up either.

title: STAGE: MUSICAL SET IN NEW ORLEANS
description: ''Basin Street,'' the new musical at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater, reduces the rich Storyville environment and history to theatrical cliches. The show borrows stereotypes from other musicals and romantic fiction, beginning with ''The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas.'' In this case, a 1917 version of Moral Majority is trying to close the brothels of New Orleans, and this is the background for a tale of star- crossed lovers.

title: 1,000 Political Prisoners Released by Pakistan
description: Pakistan's military rulers freed more than 1,000 political prisoners today on the eve of the Moslem festival of Eid al-Adha, the Feast of Sacrifice.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Long GoodbyeFor Pesticide Ten years after animal tests warned that the pesticide ethylene dibromide is a potent carcinogen, Environmental Protection Agency officials said last week that the substance might soon be banned, at least partially. Given the extraordinary magnitude of health risk from exposure to EDB, however, the Government's response seemed cool.

title: Getting Tough With Congress on Central America
description: If the United States fails to achieve peace and democracy in Central America, it will be largely the fault of Congress. So contended a ''fed- up'' Reagan Administration last week as it appeared to drop its efforts at persuasion and geared to battle for the appropriations to support military and covert operations the Administration says are essential to American aims. As delivered by Under Secretary of Defense Fred C. Ikle, the fighting words to Congress also sounded to Democrats like preparation for the Republican election campaign next year.

title: THE PRIVATE SIDE OF LANDRY BELIES HIS PUBLIC IMAGE
description: TOM LANDRY'S birthday is high $1 Sept. 11, which means in most years he celebrates it during the football season. Usually, it's just another day at the office or in the stadium coaching the Dallas Cowboys. But a few birthdays ago, several of his players wanted to do something special, make it a day he would long remember.

title: Brown Edges Yale
description: Brown and Yale played football on equal terms today, but the Bruins prevailed, 26-24, on the strength of the running and passing of Joe Potter, the quarterback, and an interception by Scott Schultz, a defensive back.

title: STATE CONSIDERS CONSUMER BOARD
description: The Public Service Commission said this week that, at Governor Cuomo's request, it would soon consider regulations to help establish an independent consumer group to oppose increases in utility rates.

title: THE ADAM FAMILY'S EDINBURGH
description: In Greyfriars Cemetery there is a Latin GARRY WILLS is Henry R. Luce Professor of American Culture at Northwestern University and the author of ''Lead Time: A Journalist's Education'' (Doubleday). inscription Dr. Johnson helped compose, calling the place a ''forlorn lawn''

title: On Language; The Case For Malediction
description: Apple Computer ran an advertisement in various magazines early this year about the writing of a tricky business letter. The first draft of the letter began with the promising salutation ''Dear Mush-for-Brains.'' But by the final version, the magic of word processing had transformed it, in effect, to ''Dear Valued Colleague.'' The change may be good for business, but it is bad for the language, not to mention the blood.

title: Debora Lynn Jones Marries Obie Benz
description: Debora Lynn Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jon Rex Jones of Albany, Tex., and Allan Oberly Benz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Benz of Ridgewood, N.J., were married yesterday in Albany. The Rev. Dr. William Tucker of the Disciples of Christ Church, who is chancellor of Texas Christian University and uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: COLLEGE INTERVIEWS: NOT FOR STUDENTS ONLY
description: AUTUMN means migrations: birds to the South, older folks to Florida and thousands of Long Island high school seniors - their parents in tow - off to the college interview circuit. The Boston-Washington-Deep South trip has become to this generation of high school students what panty raids, cutting classes and mononucleosis were to their parents.

title: FLIGHT 7 VICTIMS REMEMBERED
description: NEW MILFORD LATE last month, Dr. Jong Jin Lim, a medical researcher in the ophthalmology department at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York, received word that his mother had died in South Korea. He and a brother, a resident of New York City, booked the first available flight to South Korea to be with another brother and his family.

title: CABARETL:'OLIO' BY THACKER
description: Russ Thacker has been playing jaunty, smiling, red-haired juveniles in musicals for a dozen years, although as he points out in the cabaret performance ''Olio,'' which he is now doing Tuesday nights at Don't Tell Mama, 343 West 46th Street, most of them ran for only one night or one week, when they managed to open at all.

title: IT'S OFFICIAL: FAIRFIELD IS RICH
description: AMARKETING survey of the lifestyles of Fairfield County residents has turned up data that confirm what many people already thought - that the county is affluent, well educated, and fond of martinis. The exception is Bridgeport, whose residents do not fare as well in economic comparisons.

title: TO RESCUE PUBLIC RADIO
description: When a few classmates and I started a college radio station in 1939, we sought a high standard in cultural, informational and entertainment programming - a vision enlarged these days by National Public Radio. Unhappily, N.P.R. was almost destroyed recently by bankruptcy.

title: S. L. Akers Wed In Pelham Manor To Miss Bancroft
description: The marriage of Gertrude Storey Bancroft, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Bancroft of Bronxville, N.Y., and Great Cranberry Island, Me., to Stephen Linn Akers, son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Akers of Shallotte, N.C., took place yesterday. The Rev. John M. Deason performed the ceremony at the Huguenot Memorial Church in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: UCONN-TORRINGTON OPENS IN REPRIEVE
description: ALTHOUGH the University of Connecticut's Torrington branch was threatened with closure until midsummer, 75 freshmen and 90 sophomores began classes there on Sept. 1.

title: A VOICE OUT OF AFRICA
description: Jason Berry is the author of ''Amazing Grace: With Charles Evers in Mississippi'' and co-author of ''Up From the Cradle of Jazz'' to be published next spring. By Jason Berry,

title: DECIDING WHO MAKES FOREIGN POLICY
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski, who headed the National Security Council under President Carter, is author of the book ''Power and Principle.'' This article has been adapted from a recent speech before the National Press Club. By Zbigniew Brzezinski If one thing should have been made clear by George P. Shultz's current stewardship as Secretary of State, it is that the besetting problem of who makes foreign policy is not the product of a conflict of personalities. The issue, as posed in recent years, is whether primacy in the area belongs in the State Department or in the National Security Council (N.S.C.). When Henry Kissinger headed the N.S.C. in the Nixon White House, it was alleged to be his ego and his taste for the Machiavellian that kept the Secretary of State, William P. Rogers, out of the center of things. When I occupied the same White House post under President Carter, it was said that my instinct for the jugular gave the N.S.C. an excessive share of foreign-policy initiatives, at the expense of Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance. Yet in Mr. Shultz and the current N.S.C. chief, William P. Clark, we have two men who, to all appearances, enjoy a relationship untroubled by ego trips in either direction. Indeed, Mr.Clark is generally perceived as not deeply involved in the complex substance of key foreign issues. Nonetheless, in recent months, the press has noted that influence has been gravitating away from the experienced Mr. Shultz to the able but relatively inexpert Mr. Clark.

title: PHILS STAY TIED FOR FIRST PLACE
description: The Philadelphia Phillies, using a revised lineup for the 17th time in 17 September games, cast perhaps the most damaging stone in the path of the St. Louis Cardinals to another World Series championship. The Phillies defeated the Cardinals this afternoon, 4-1, as John Denny, their candidate for the Cy Young Award, allowed just six singles. The Cardinals registered only three outs on fly balls.

title: Church in Conflict
description: In November 1977 they were front- page news - two Lutheran churches on Long Island that were using Hebrew liturgy in their Sunday morning services and, as a result, were threatened with suspension by the American Lutheran Church.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: Peculiar Fish
description: There was no dispute about the weight. Both bass brought in by the brothers John and Archie Wade clearly qualified for the top two prizes at the bass tournament on Lake Wright Patman near Texarkana, Tex.

title: RUSH TO CLIMB ARARAT GIVES A TOWN A LIFT
description: Townspeople here say they cannot recall any comparable rush to climb Mount Ararat, that great volcanic cone that dominates the frontiers of eastern Turkey, Soviet Armenia and Iran.

title: 2.5 Million Moslem Pilgrims
description: A total of 2.5 million Moslems made the pilgrimage to the shrines in Mecca and Medina this year, the official Saudi Press Agency reported today. This was an increase of 24 percent over 1982, the agency said.

title: FIGHTING CITY HALL
description: It did not charm Eric Witkin, a 35-year-old partner in the law firm of Poletti, Freidin, Prashker & Gartner, when he learned that the city had reassessed at 60 percent of the sale price the 10-apartment building he and his wife bought last November.

title: Lilies
description: To the Editor: Lilies, ''England's Paradise for Bibliophiles'' (Travel, July 17), is indeed a collector's paradise. Over the years I continue to be carried away by its treasures.

title: Q&A
description: Question: Our family has had a longstanding desire to find a country inn or resort within six hours or less by train from New York City; we also want the inn or resort to offer sleigh rides and scenery but we are not interested in skiing. How can we find one to go to this winter? - B.T., Holmdel, N.J.

title: TV Ads by Teacher Union
description: The National Education Association says it is spending $1.5 million to broadcast television commericials this month urging support for public schools. The teachers' union said Thursday that its 30-second commercials would appear 128 times on ABC-TV and NBC-TV, primarily on morning and evening news programs.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: GOING VEGETARIAN A Guide for Teenagers: By Sada Fretz. Illustrated by Eric Fretz. 278 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. ($11.50.(Ages 12 and Up)

title: EX-LAWYER JAILED FOR FRAUD SCHEME
description: A former lawyer from Brooklyn has been sentenced to two to six years in prison for grand larceny despite recommendations by Federal and local prosecutors that he be placed on probation. The prosecutors said he had become an ''extremely valuable'' informant in inquiries into two organized- crime murders.

title: ALMOST LIKE BEING IN NORTH ITALY
description: OF the scores of restaurants on the Island that claim to be northern Italian, none interpret this currently fashionable cuisine as well, as intelligently or as authentically as L'Orsa Minore in East Hampton. It may even be one of the best northern Italian restaurants in the entire New York metropolitan area.

title: ST. JOHN'S UPSETS WAGNER
description: Todd Jamison accounted for five touchdowns, three passing and two rushing, to lead St. John's to a 35-29 upset of Wagner yesterday afternoon at Redmen Stadium in Jamaica, Queens.

title: REAL-ESTATE MYSTERIES
description: BEFORE coming to Connecticut, Mark Twain had discovered a rich vein of humor in the changing geography of the frontier. As wilderness gave way to territory and territory gave way to state, place names in the West became comically confusing.

title: Rosemary Walsh and Stephen Osborn Wed on L.I.
description: Rosemary Walsh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew C. Walsh of Manhasset, L.I., and Stephen L. Osborn, son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Keith Osborn of Cheyenne, Wyo., were married yesterday. Msgr. John J. Weist performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset.

title: Miss Moseley Is Wed to K. B. Wiss Jr.
description: Elizabeth Wood Moseley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Boswell Moseley of Litchfield, Conn., and Kenneth Bertrand Wiss Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wiss of Pinehurst, N.C., were married yesterday. The Rev. David F. Gurniak performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Litchfield.

title: Lori Howard Has Nuptials
description: Lori Howard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry S. Howard of Carefree, Ariz., and Ripon, Quebec, was married yesterday to Peter Gerard Thomas, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Thomas Jr. of Northvale, N.J. The Rev. Frederick M. Jelly performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: ACHES AMID THE PAINS OF GROWTH IN ZIMBABWE
description: During the 14-year struggle to topple the all-white regime of Rhodesia, black Zimbabwe nationalists in exile would often argue that since their country would be the last in Africa (besides South-West Africa) to attain self rule, they had an opportunity to avoid the mistakes of older African states.

title: 'BLACK COFFEE' GIVES A TASTE OF CHRISTIE
description: THERE is an Agatha Christie watch on Long Island. The flags are being raised in East Farmingdale to alert fans that a rarely performed Christie mystery play, ''Black Coffee,'' is being presented by the Arena Players Repertory Theater.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN MEXICO CITY
description: RICHARD J. MEISLIN is chief of the Mexico City bureau of The Times.

title: Nebraska Gets 780 Yards to Win, 84-13
description: The running back Mike Rozier and the wingback Irving Fryar each scored 3 touchdowns and contributed 426 of the 780 total yards as Nebraska overwhelmed Minnesota, 84-13, tonight.

title: JOBLESS MAN, IN DOCTOR RUSE, MAKES TWO HOSPITALS HOME
description: An unemployed construction worker who posed as a doctor in two Denver hospitals for more than two months says he did it ''just to survive.''

title: Nine Poles Fly to West Berlin Pursued by Soviet Warplanes
description: Nine Poles seeking asylum took a rented plane and, with Soviet warplanes in pursuit, flew over East Germany today and landed at a United States air base in West Berlin.

title: PERMANENT BAN ON URANIUM EXPLORATION IS SOUGHT IN JERSEY
description: Although two giant oil companies have called off their search for uranium in the hills surrounding this Passaic County community, residents are renewing their battle to make sure such mining never takes place.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Auto Restraints on Tokyo

title: 2 Appointed by Reagan
description: President Reagan has named Richard Montoya of New Mexico as Assistant Secretary of the Interior for Territorial and International Affairs and Maria Lucia Johnson, identified by the White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, as ''a black Republican from Alaska,'' as vice chairman of the Merit Systems Protection Board.

title: GRAMBLING VICTORIOUS IN STADIUM
description: Coach Eddie Robinson of Grambling State University moved a victory closer last night to tying Bear Bryant's college coaching record for career victories as the Tigers easily defeated Morgan State, 33-0, in the 16th annual Whitney Young benefit game at Yankee Stadium.

title: Debate on Programs For the Gifted
description: The recent article ''Classes for Gifted at Issue'' scanned only the tip of an iceberg that has been immersed in a sea of controversy since World War I. The subject of gifted classification, identification procedures and programming is one the ''authorities'' in the field don't agree on any more than do parents or school personnel. All have their ''experts'' to quote, statistics to flaunt, experiences to relate and programs to compare.

title: VIENNA'S GRAND HOTEL FOR MUSIC LOVERS
description: A couple of years ago, a plane from Budapest to Prague on which I was traveling was diverted to Vienna because of bad weather. Congratulating myself on my good luck, I hailed a cab and asked to go to the Imperial, my favorite among all of Europe's grand hotels, hoping that they would have a free room. They did, they made no complaint about my decidedly proletarian Eastern European working clothes, and the concierge on duty, who knew my weakness for opera, called out to me as I signed in that there was a particularly festive performance of ''Fidelio'' that night, starting in about 20 minutes. Were there any tickets? ''Go upstairs and change,'' he replied, ''and I'll see what I can do. But everyone you ever heard of is in the cast, so it's been sold out for a month.''

title: INDIANS EDGE YANKS IN 9TH, 7-6
description: The Yankees will find it harder to pretend they are still in a pennant race after Rich Gossage allowed a ninth-inning hit that gave the Indians a 7-6 victory tonight and dropped the Yankees eight games behind the Orioles.

title: Manila's Former Leader Makes Plea to U.S.
description: Former President Diosdado Macapagal said today that the United States could influence the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos to hold free elections in the Philippines.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: NUTLEY
description: A CENTURY ago a magazine editor living in what is now known as Nutley Town urged his friend Samuel L. Clemens to pay him a visit. ''There isn't much that is prettier than this end of New Jersey,'' he wrote. ''It is all upland, tumbling into shallow valleys and bright sunny reaches along the Passaic River, and hillsides white as snow with daisies, and everywhere trees.''

title: Dying Wind Stops Australia II's Bid
description: Liberty was saved from a crushing defeat by Australia II today in the third race of the America's Cup series when the fading breeze caused the time limit to expire before the yachts finished.

title: GENERALS STILL CALL THE TUNE IN POLAND
description: Two months after the official lifting of martial law, the generals are still running Poland.

title: EYES ON E. ISLIP AND BELLPORT
description: Four scholastic football teams - all of which had 10-0 records last year - were named by the New York State Sportswriters Association as the best in the state. Two were from Long Island - East Islip and Bellport. The other two were Liverpool, from the Syracuse area, and Shenendehowa, from the Albany district.

title: REACTIONS TO 'THE ROSENBERG FILE'
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Strength Through Series

title: U.S. FUNDS SOUGHT IN FLORIDA TO SAVE IMPERILED SPARROW
description: Fewer than 100 Florida grasshopper sparrows are left along the Kissimmee Prairie, but wildlife officials say there is still time to save the species if they can get Federal funds.

title: DAUGHERTY EXHIBIT IN WESTPORT
description: THE art of James H. Daugherty is turning up all over. It figured in the Whitney Museum's 1978 survey of Synchromism, a movement devoted to the expression of form by color that, in America, was the first manifestation of abstraction, and it played a part in a recent show at New Jersey's Montclair Art Museum about A. B. Frost, a painter who is best known for his Br'er Rabbit illustrations.

title: An Editor's Favorite
description: ''BLUE HIGHWAYS'' by William Least Heat Moon is still on the best seller list after seven months, is that rare book that is both a popular and critical success.

title: HOW AND WHY CAULKING IS A HOUSE'S ALL-WEATHER FRIEND
description: ALTHOUGH most homeowners have long been aware of the need for caulking around window frames and door frames, many do not realize that caulking is just as important in many other places around the outside of the house - where open joints, seams and cracks create an opening that will allow heat to escape in the winter, and moisture, cold drafts or even insects to enter all year round.

title: SOME STRENGTHS SHIFT IN CITY
description: Lehman went undefeated in Bronx- Manhattan division play last season, but Coach Carmin Coasanto lost all but four starters and will probably have to pass more often to take pressure off an inexperienced offensive line. Truman and Kennedy, who have key personnel returning from last year, could finish 1, 2 in the Bronx- Manhattan division of the Public Schools Athletic League.

title: HE EARNED HIS PRIZES
description: Had there been an additional prize for the most special prizes won at the 1983 United States Invitational Championship in Greenville, Pa., Nick DeFirmian, a 26-year- old Oakland, Calif., international master, would have taken it.

title: No Headline
description: To Persist With Arms Control President Reagan's decision not to let the Soviet attack on a Korean airliner disrupt arms control talks was a courageous rebuff to some of his conservative allies. New evidence of Soviet paranoia only strengthens the case for curbing the arms race and maintaining a stable military balance. The question now is whether the aim is talk or agreement. For real progress, the President has to seek difficult compromises.

title: MAMEDE WINS
description: -Fernando Mamede of Portugal ran the fastest 5,000-meter in the world this year, with a time of 13 minutes and 8.54 seconds today at the Tokyo National Stadium. The world record is 13:00.42, set by Dave Moorcroft of Britain in July 1982 at Oslo.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: A MONTH ago, one might have described Paul McEntyre as a Democrat in Republican clothing, or perhaps a ''closet Democrat.''

title: Serena Jardine Bride Of Joseph D. Fenton
description: Serena Anne Jardine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Stuart Jardine of Folsom, Calif., was married yesterday to Joseph Daniel Fenton, son of Dr. and Mrs. William D. Fenton of Millville, N.J. The Rev. Otto W. Immel performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Glassboro, N.J.

title: Florida Train
description: To the Editor: My wife and I recently decided to travel to Florida by train. The ticket agent sold me a Slumber coach round-trip ticket for $604 (two persons) and stated that an additional $300 for a bedroom was not worth the money. Here are some observations.

title: 14 Mexicans Die When Gas Ignites Inside a Family Van
description: Fourteen people, including six children, died after leaking gas fumes ignited inside the family van, turning it into a fireball, a Red Cross paramedic said.

title: ARGENTINA OFFERED PERONISM WITHOUT PERON
description: Early warning of a new front in El Salvador's terrorist war against civilians has reached the secluded campus of the University of Central America. The Secret Anti-Communist Army, known by its Spanish initials E.S.A, planted bombs two weeks ago at the home of Italo Lopez Vallecillos, a professor, and in a Jesuit residence owned by the university. E.S.A. last week advised Mr. Lopez and the Jesuits that its ''guns are pointed constantly at traitors of the people.''

title: WHAT, THEN, IS THE HOT LINE FOR?
description: To the Editor:

title: HEADLINERS Foxes and Chickens
description: Everything had to be the best'' for

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN SMALL BUSINESS;
THE COURTSHIP IN WASHINGTON
description: Small business has never been more important in Washington.

title: A Correction
description: A photograph in the Week in Review of Sept. 30 was incorrectly identified. It showed the Theseion at the Agora in Athens.

title: ALTERNATIVES TO LITIGATION
description: A FUNDAMENTAL requirement of a democratic society is a system of justice that is accessible, fair and reasonably efficient and one, moreover, that resolves disputes in a way that builds confidence in the political system that embraces it.

title: Senior Citizens And Transportation
description: ''It seems to me,'' as Heywood Broun would so aptly put it, an infringement on the rights of Nassau County senior citizens when it comes to public transportation in both Suffolk County and New York City.

title: PRESSURE AND PRIDE IN A PENNANT RACE
description: With only two weeks remaining in the major league baseball regular season, pressure and ceremony intermingle. For some it is a time of magic numbers and scoreboard watching; for others it is a time of nostalgia, and for still others it is a time of expectations for the season to come.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE SECOND CUCKOO, Edited and introduced by Kenneth Gregory. 322 pp. Winchester, Mass.: Allen & Unwin. $14.50.

title: SALISBURY PLANS ITS FESTIVAL
description: SALISBURY is a tiny township tucked away in the Taconic Mountains region. It was settled in 1720 by men and women who, while staying just within Connecticut's boundaries, managed to get as far away from the rest of the colony as possible. Nestled in the beautiful lake and hill country west of the Housatonic, Salisbury in the 19th century became a favorite resort for summer vacationers.

title: Article 171714 -- No Title
description: The American Civil Liberties Union has challenged an $80,000 legal bill from the Justice Department to the family of Viola Gregg Liuzzo, the civil rights worker shot to death in Alabama in 1965.

title: DAM AT TROUT FISHERY OPPOSED
description: CONNECTICUT and Trout Unlimited, a national conservation group, have joined forces to oppose construction of a power- generating dam that would affect about four miles of recreational water on the Shetucket River.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
THIS SHOW IS A WALK DOWN MEMORY LANE
description: For a frequenter of the New York photography gallery scene - since, well, since the scene began with the opening of the Witkin Gallery in 1969 - a visit to the exhibition now at the Witkin Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, is a trip down memory lane. The exhibition, which will be at the gallery through Oct. 15, is entitled ''Seven Great Photographers,'' but it could just as well have been entitled ''Golden Oldies,'' for it is filled with work that was already recognized as ''great'' when photography first began to be shown and sold as art.

title: South Africa Bars Timerman
description: Jacobo Timerman, who was jailed for two years without trial by Argentina, has been refused a visa to visit South Africa where he was scheduled to give a series of lectures, a South African Embassy spokesman said Friday. Mr. Timerman, who is currently writing in Spain, had applied for a visa to visit South Africa at its embassy in Madrid, but immigration officials in Pretoria turned him down.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: McNeil and Jets Must Avoid Fumbles
description: Because he knows that Freeman McNeil has a gift that defies analysis, Bobby Hammond, the coach of the Jet running backs, will not warn McNeil about holding on to the ball today at Foxboro, Mass., against the New England Patriots.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: SUIT CHALLENGES NEW YONKERS COUNCIL
description: YONKERS TWO black men who had just sued this city were talking on the steps of City Hall here last week about the meaning of Yonkers elections for people with black skin or Spanish accents.

title: IN PRAISE OF CRAFTSMANSHIP
description: S A RULE, barns are exceptionally forthright buildings, devoid of the signs of misguided pride that so often mar more ''important'' structures. Presumably, this natural grace is what makes the prospect of living in a converted barn so universally appealing. And yet, too often, barns are renovated with such a vengeance that their innocence gets lost in a tangle of slick skylights and cute ''country'' decor.

title: PRIVATE SECURITY PATROLS ON RISE IN CITY'S MIDDLE-CLASS AREAS
description: Frank Zuccaro steps out of his patrol car, gun at his side, but without the badge of a New York City police officer. For the people who live along his beat in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn, however, the absence of the silver shield does not matter.

title: Victoria von Gontard Is Wed
description: Victoria von Gontard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adalbert von Gontard Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Spyros Solon Skouras Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Skouras of Greenwich, Conn., and New York. The ceremony was performed at the von Gontard home by Bishop Theodore E. McCarrick of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Metuchen, N.J., assisted by Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan of the Church of St. Michael the Archangel in Greenwich.

title: FAMILY REUNIONS ABOUND
description: If the Smith brothers, Danny and Jimmy, can help Deerfield Academy to another successful season, they will make their father a happy man. Jim Smith is Deerfield football coach. Danny and Jimmy are his fourth and fifth sons to play for him at the Massachusetts school.

title: Tampon Use Linked to Risk Of Recurrent Vaginal Ulcers
description: Some women using tampons risk developing recurrent vaginal and cervical ulcers, doctors say in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: HIGH RISES, FACE TO FACE
description: Two high-rise apartment houses, one a condominium and the other a rental, are going up on opposite sides of Third Avenue in the block between 81st and 82d Streets. Together, they are adding 210 new apartments on the avenue, which is experiencing a new wave of residential construction.

title: WELFARE CUTOFF SWELLING PHILADELPHIA'S HOMELESS
description: Willie is one of the defeated.

title: THE GOOD THAT MEN DO LIVES ON, THE BAD IS BURIED
description: Grow old along with me! The best is yet to be, The last of life, for which the first

title: THE INFLUENCE OF WILLIAM CLARK
description: We Easterners are far too involved with a concern for knowledge and expertise.

title: CUBS HIT OROSCO HARD AND WIN BY 7-6
description: A revolting thing happened to Ron Darling yesterday, just when he had his first victory in the big leagues in sight: Jesse Orosco, the ace of the Mets' bullpen, surrendered one run in the eighth inning and three in the ninth and lost the game to the Chicago Cubs, 7-6.

title: U.S. TELLS OF HOPE OVER GRAIN DEALS
description: The worst drought in 50 years is removing burdensome surpluses of corn and soybeans, but American exporters will still meet their sales commitments and the nation will fulfill food aid commitments in the next 12 months, Agriculture Department officials said today.

title: EARLY TO PLANT-EARLY TO FLOWER;
description: Two of the loveliest flowers of early spring have appealing names: snowdrops and snowflakes. These tiny bulbs are on sale at garden centers in fall and should be planted in the ground soon.

title: Around the Island On a Yacht
description: ''L.I. Yacht Race Yields Adventure'' (Aug. 7) was a good story, although it avoided mentioning the Richmond County Yacht Club and the Sea Cliff Yacht Club. The Around Long Island Regatta is planned by the Sea Cliff Yacht Club and supported by the Richmond County Yacht Club.

title: GRAIN IS NOT RUSSIA'S ROOT ECONOMIC BLOCK
description: To the Editor:

title: UNION OIL'S TENACIOUS CHIEF WATCHES A DREAM COME TRUE
description: THE lobby of the Union Oil Company of California's headquarters here is filled with plaques, paintings and mementos celebrating great moments in the company's past - most of it in the last 15 years and most of it starring Fred L. Hartley, chairman and president.

title: DO LOWER STATISTICS MEAN LESS CRIME?
description: Two Justice Department studies released this month show unexpected declines in the national crime rate last year, but no one appears to be rushing to celebrate or to claim credit for breaking the rising curve of previous years.

title: NEEDS OF CHILDREN EXAMINED
description: EAST BRUNSWICK DR. ANNA MAYER speaks softly, and there is still a hint of her Louisiana childhood in her voice. But there is nothing soft about her determination to see that New Jersey's children are properly taken care of.

title: PROGRAM ON WILLIAMS WILL BEGIN TODAY
description: RUTHERFORD TO MARK the 100th anniversary of the birth of William Carlos Williams - the physician-poet who lived and worked here - the William Carlos Williams Center for the Performing Arts is holding a celebration today through Thursday.

title: Alice Martin Weds J. Bruce Whelihan
description: Alice Anne Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John McKenzie Martin of Wilmington, Del., was married there yesterday to J. Bruce Whelihan, son of Mrs. George D. Beck of Philadelphia and the late John F. Whelihan Jr. The Rev. Robert McLeod Smith performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: DONATING WIGS TO CANCER PATIENTS
description: Since 1942 Edith Imre has been in the business of designing wigs for some of the best-known and most beautiful women in Manhattan. But not long ago she said: ''I decided I had had enough of department store buyers, enough of fashion, enough of rich people. I was at a point in my life where I wanted to do something for people.''

title: THE ZEAL OF A MAN OF LETTERS
description: HUGGING THE SHORE

title: Anne Louise Howard Wed in Capital To Dennis Chavez Tristani, a Banker
description: Anne Louise Howard, daughter of Frances Humphrey Howard of Arlington, Va. and the late Dr. I. Ray Howard, a surgeon, was married in Washington yesterday to Dennis Chavez Tristani, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jorge E. Tristani of San Juan, P.R. The bride is the niece of the late Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey. The bridegroom is the grandson of the late Senator Dennis Chavez of New Mexico.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: OUT ON A LIMB By Shirley MacLaine. 372 pp. New York. Bantam Books. $15.95

title: ILLEGAL ACTS AGAINST ILLEGAL ALIENS
description: ''THE TARNISHED DOOR'' is drawn from the reporting on illegal aliens for which John Crewdson won a Pulitzer Prize in 1981 when he was on the staff of The New York Times. The book's subject is compelling - the ideal of the United States as a blend of all the world's people, assailed anew by ethnic, religious and class prejudices, by racism, xenophobia and American workers who fear for their jobs.

title: FRIEND AND FOE CITE REAGAN'S 'MASTERFUL' USE OF INCUMBECY
description: President Reagan had no need for his hearing aid to absorb the good vibrations of one of the rites of incumbency last week as a ballroom full of Republican loyalists stood and shouted pleas of ''Four more years! Four more years!''

title: The U.S. Army and El Salvador
description: In ''The Odds in El Salvador'' (July 24), Lydia Chavez writes that American military advisers agree that victory will require ''a consistent, long-term and larger American assistance program.'' Yet the chief of the United States military mission, rotated home when ''his 15-month tour of duty ended,'' ''spoke for attribution before leaving only because he soon would be gone,'' and other advisers ''have various periods of time left.''

title: SAILING THE COAST OF MAINE
description: Sailing Down East in Maine for the first time is like traveling backward in time. The rocky headlands and islands composed of granite, sculptured, scoured out, chiseled by glaciers, bear few marks of civilization. The place names remind us that it was the French who first explored and settled there, that it was the home of the Penobscot and Passamaquoddy Indians.

title: PLAYING THE PRESIDENTIAL SLOTS
description: ATLANTIC CITY GAMBLING was not the only game in town here last week. Politics in some of its manifestations was played with enthusiasm from the gambling casinos and the Boardwalk to City Hall.

title: It's No Longer Political Poison
description: The 15-year moratorium on the production of nerve gas by the United States went up in smoke last week. Prodded by outrage at the Soviet Union, the House easily passed a $187.5 billion military authorization bill for the coming fiscal year containing $114.6 million for a new generation of poison gas weapons.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Artists very often run in families, and such was the case with the Duyckincks, the Peales and the Weirs, three dynasties whose contributions to American art range over three centuries. And the good idea of showing what they produced, by way of exploring how each clan affected the esthetic outlook of its members, has resulted in ''Three American Families: A Tradition of Artistic Pursuit,'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris (through Oct. 26).

title: Robert Ely Weds Alice F. Moulton
description: Alice Fairchild Moulton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Richard Moulton of Lake Forest, Ill., was married there yesterday to Robert Monteith Ely, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Ingraham Ely of New Haven and Amagansett, L.I. The Rev. Paul Hewett performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit. The couple has assumed the surname Moulton-Ely.

title: 4 Food Outlets Listed by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited four food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: HISTORY AND HOSPITALITY
description: CECILY DEEGAN McMILLAN lives in Frogmore, S.C., and is writing a biography of Elizabeth Sherman Cameron.

title: BEN KINGSLEY LEAPS FROM 'GANDHI' TO 'KEAN'
description: Ben Kingsley was in India filming ''Gandhi'' in 1980 when a script was delivered to his home near Stratford- on-Avon. ''I've written this play for you,'' the author wrote in a note. The play was a one-character vehicle about Edmund Kean, the brilliant 19th-century British actor regarded as one of the greatest Shakespearean actors of all time. Coleridge, for example, said that to see Kean act was ''to read Shakespeare by flashes of lightning.''

title: NO TRUCE YET FOR REAGAN IN CONGRESS OR LEBANON
description: WASHINGTON FOR the Reagan Administration, the Lebanese crisis now seems virtually insoluble. The Administration last week was trying simultaneously to negotiate a military cease-fire in Lebanon and a truce with Congress in a basic struggle over foreign policy. Neither achievement appears likely.

title: FEAR OF CONTAMINATION STILL IMPEDES MUSEUM
description: Nearly two months after health complaints from employees led to an extensive cleanup of the Herbert F. Johnson Museum at Cornell University, the arcane subject of diethylamino ethanol contamination there continues to haunt the school.

title: A $4.98 CONCESSION THAT TRACK ATHLETES DESERVE
description: THE electronic finish timing devices used at track meets these

title: No Headline
description: A Wardrobe for Starting Out

title: Miss Walker Is the Bride Of a Broker
description: Hilary Magnus Walker, daughter of Mrs. John Hone Bartol and Alexander David Walker Jr., both of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Winchester Fitch Hotchkiss Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hotchkiss of Bernardsville, N.J. The Rev. Richard F. Van Wely performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: HARVARD TOPS COLUMBIA, 43-14
description: John Witkowski, holder of 31 Columbia, Ivy and national football records, knows just how Atlas must have felt. And Witkowski was only trying to carry the Columbia football team, not the world.

title: DEMOCRATS SEEK SOCIAL GAINS AMID FRUSTRATION
description: When Congress returned to Capitol Hill last week at the end of its holiday, the first order of business in the House of Representatives was a bill raising spending levels for 10 education and health programs. The House later approved $200 million in aid for workers who lost their jobs because of foreign competition. This week the Democratic leadership has scheduled debate on spending $5 billion on thousands of public service jobs.

title: G.O.P. Derailed In California
description: Christmas won't come a little early for California Republicans after all, under a ruling last week by the State Supreme Court.

title: A QUAKING JAPAN GETS READY FOR THE BIG ONE
description: By the end of last week, this city was still standing. That surprised some people. Prophets of doom had been announcing that Tokyo and the surrounding region would crumble.

title: U.S. Olympic Hockey Team Faces a Tough Task
description: Those few startling days came spinning out of the blue in February 1980, when the United States Olympic hockey team entranced the nation by beating the Soviet team and winning the gold medal. In the exuberant aftermath, Americans who had paid no attention to Olympic hockey until then turned to each other to ask, ''Who

title: AT U.N., SOME STILL HOPE FOR A REVERSAL
description: Several United Nations officials said today that the Soviet decision not to send Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko to the General Assembly was not final and that they hoped differences between American and Soviet officials could be resolved.

title: ;  Generating Bosses
description: To the Business Editor:

title: 'IT'S TIME TO OPEN THE BAY'
description: BUDDY BURNETT sipped lemonade on the front porch of his home on Flying Point Road near Water Mill and pointed to a small dock nestled in the lush eelgrass that surrounds Mecox Bay.

title: ALLIGATORS WEREN'T THE ONLY OBSTACLES TO 'CROSS CREEK'
description: Stephen Farber writes frequently about film. Of all the arts, writing must be the least photogenic, which could help to explain why Hollywood has produced so many ridiculous movies about writers. Connoisseurs of bad movies remember Merle Oberon as Georges Sand in ''A Song to Remember,'' Gregory Peck as F. Scott Fitzgerald in ''Beloved Infidel'' or George Hamilton as Moss Hart in ''Act I.''

title: F.H. Babcock 3d, Miss Landis Wed
description: Miriam Manning Landis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Wilder Landis Jr. of Sharon, Conn., was married there yesterday to Frederick Howard Babcock 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Bodine Babcock of Millbrook, N.Y., and New York. The Rev. Frederick B. Stimson, assisted by the Rev. Gilbert S. Larsen, performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: TULANE RALLY STUNS FLORIDA STATE, 34-28
description: Jon English passed 15 yards for a touchdown to the flanker Wayne Smith, and Tony Wood kicked field goals of 39 and 40 yards to lead a second-half rally that gave Tulane a 34-28 upset of Florida State today.

title: Syracuse Defeats Northwestern, 35-0
description: The sophomore quarterback Todd Norley completed 11 of 14 passes for two touchdowns and 197 yards tonight as Syracuse beat Northwestern, 35-0.

title: WORLD BANK SAYS AFRICA IS CREATING A CRISIS
description: A World Bank study says that despite billions of dollars in recent international aid to Africa, the region faces a ''deepening crisis'' that is largely the result of domestic policies set by African nations themselves.

title: Dutch Leaving Lebanon
description: The Netherlands plans to go ahead by Oct. 1 with previously announced plans to withdraw its 800 troops from the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon, Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers said Friday night.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: WHEELCHAIR MEET

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: BECAUSE at first it didn't succeed, the county's Public Utility Agency is trying again to produce a power-line agreement with the Consolidated Edison Company that will satisfy County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke .

title: TACTICS OF A MAVERICK MONEY MANAGER
description: SHORTLY after the start of stock market

title: BRING FAIR PLAY TO TAXING OF 'PERKS'
description: THE notion of taxing fringe benefits arouses instant opposition

title: 'HALF TAMBOURINE' A SUCCESS
description: ''HEY, Mr. Tambourine Man, play a song for me . . .'' For thousands of years it has been a traditional symbol of sound, the ancient instrument the tambourine. Of Near Eastern origin, it dates to prehistoric times and throughout the years it has surfaced in a number of civilizations - the Egyptians and the Syrians, the Chinese, Peruvians and Greenlanders. Always the same basic design and shape, it was a narrow wooden circle about 10 inches in diameter, often covered with skin, and sometimes filled with pebbles or surrounded by bells or jangles.

title: REACTIONS TO 'THE ROSENBERG FILE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Gene Mauch, who quit as manager of the California Angels after the 1982 season after guiding the Angels to the American League West championship but losing in the playoffs to the Milwaukee Brewers, has rejoined the club as director of player personnel. . . . Bruce Kison , the Angels' leading pitcher, will undergo surgery later this month to remove a disk from his back. . . . He seems to have recovered from his rotator cuff injury, but now Pete Vuckovich , the Milwaukee Brewers' right-hander, has pulled a hamstring muscle in his right leg and is out for the season. . . . Rod Foster , the U.C.L.A. guard who was the Phoenix Suns' top draft choice, has signed a three-year contract.

title: NAT WEST DOES THE UNEXPECTED
description: FOR many years, the National Bank of North America was a somewhat scruffy amalgamation of small Long Island and garment-center banks - the result of almost two dozen mergers.

title: An Easy Win In Baltimore
description: Baltimore's Democratic mayoral primary last week shaped up as a sort of precedential election. In the heaviest turnout in a decade, voters nominated William Donald Schaefer to become the city's first four-term Mayor and turned back William H. Murphy Jr.'s bid to become the city's first black Mayor.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: Slugging It Out but Also Stepping Back

title: Susan A. Gibbons Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald L. Gibbons of Avon, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Ann Gibbons, to James Timothy Cronin, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Cronin of Mattapoisett, Mass..

title: STAGE: CABAARET MUSICAL
description: To transcend routine television parody, musical comedy nostalgia must embrace more than the cliches of the past. It should also illuminate cardboard conventions and stick-figure characters with an enthusiasm for the nuances of show-business detritus.

title: BIG BUSINESS IN SPACE
description: WHEN THE COUNTDOWN NEARS

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Jesuits ChooseA Dutchman

title: CITY SCHOOLS STILL HAVE 300 OPENINGS FOR TEACHERS
description: New York City's schools will still have 300 teacher vacancies when they open tomorrow for the second week of the academic year, according to officials.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Aug. 28 about proposals to protect grizzly bears misstated a 1982 estimate of grizzlies in Yellowstone National Park and adjacent national forests. The estimate, by Roland Wauer, director of natural resource management for the National Park Service, was 187.

title: BELMONT TURF RACE TO FIRST APPROACH
description: First Approach waited and waited while Sabin and Geraldine's Store raced each other into defeat, then swooped past the tiring leaders to score an easy three-length victory in the $113,600 Flower Bowl Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: YALE'S NUCLEAR 'EMPEROR' TO GROW EVEN MORE
description: TWO stories below Whitney Street in New Haven stands the world's first tandem electrostatic accelerator - a nuclear research facility that works somewhat like a huge microscope, allowing scientists to peer into the nucleus of an atom and enabling them to explore its behavior and rearrange its structure.

title: AN AMERICAN SOPRANO ADDS THE MET TO HER ROSTER
description: To be in the presence of the soprano Jessye Norman is to know the meaning of physical grandeur. Imposingly tall and heroic in size, Miss Norman offers the image of the diva as larger-than-life symbol - an emblematic figure whose dramatic appearance on the operatic stage gives import and substance to even the most tenuous aside.

title: Correction
description: In the article ''Fall Preview 1983'' (Sept. 11) the publication date of the late William Goyen's ''The House of Breath'' was given incorrectly. The novel was published in 1950.

title: FIRST SYNTHETIC CHROMOSOME REPORTED MADE
description: Scientists have assembled complex structures of genetic material that are described by the journal Nature as the first synthetic chromosome.

title: No Headline
description: Johnny Bench got goosebumps at his Riverfront Stadium farewell tonight and gave a few to the sellout crowd before the Cincinnati Reds lost to the Houston Astros, 4-3.

title: Iran Renews Threat To Halt Oil Exports
description: Iran today renewed its threat to stop all oil exports from the Persian Gulf if its own shipments were interrupted by Iraqi attacks.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: HOPES OF CHANGE IN CITY SCHOOLS
description: Not since the late 1950's, when Sputnik was launched, has American education come in for as much scrutiny as it is getting today - and educators in New York City are loving it.

title: Hugh Dryfoos, Official O >TO>
description: Hugh Dryfoos, former vice president in charge of sales for the Paper Novelty Manufacturing Company of New York City and Stamford, Conn., a producer of Christmas decorations, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 64 years old.

title: HIGH-TECH WILL HURT WOMEN
description: It has become a national credo: Economic salvation lies in high-tech - computers, micro- electronics, satellite communications and robotics. Corporate leaders affirm it, politicians promote it, the media popularize it.
