But for wage-earning women - nearly half the workforce - technological innovation means diminished requirements for skills, reduced opportunities for mobility, the loss of jobs and greater vulnerability to union-busting.

title: PAKISTANI DIES AS AFGHAN JETS ARE REPORTED TO RAID VILLAGE
description: Seven Afghan Air Force fighter-jets bombed a Pakistani border village today, killing at least one person and injuring another, the Government said.

title: BIG ROLE IN SOVIET COMPUTERS LAID TO ROSENBERG ASSOCIATE
description: A Harvard researcher has uncovered evidence indicating that a long-missing associate of Julius Rosenberg, who was executed 30 years ago after he and his wife were convicted of espionage, assumed a new identity in the Soviet Union and played a key role in the development of Soviet military computers.

title: A Sporting Venture
description: In his 40 years as a wholesale food distributor, visiting hundreds of bars and restaurants in the New York area, Pete Raso got to see his share of sports hangouts, but none of them quite measured up to the vision that took shape in his mind's eye of what a real sports bar could be.

title: DIPLOMATS WARY ON GROMYKO MOVE
description: Ambivalence, requests for anonymity and reluctance to comment were the reactions yesterday of some United Nations diplomats who were asked to discuss the cancellation of a trip to the United Nations by the Soviet Foreign Minister and the legality of the decision to bar Soviet diplomatic flights from New York's main commercial airports.

title: 'We're Struttin' Too Much'
description: FOR half an hour after the Jets' embarrassing 23-13 loss to the New England Patriots yesterday, Joe Klecko sat on a long table in the trainer's room, his back against the wall, his right leg stretched out straight. By the time he emerged and walked to the shower room, almost all his teammates had dressed and boarded the chartered buses outside. Soon he was toweling himself at his locker. In the past, win or lose, Joe Klecko had never really sounded off about the Jets, but now he spoke with the leadership to be expected of an all-pro of his stature.

title: Shea in Plea to Jet Owner
description: William Shea stood at home plate in Shea Stadium yesterday afternoon and made a public appeal to Leon Hess, owner of the Jets, not to move the football team to New Jersey.

title: STRAWBERRY BEGINS TO FULFILL HIS PROMISE
description: TOM SEAVER, who won 16 games as a rookie 18 years ago, sat on the stool in front of his locker in Shea Stadium reading a list of performances by some famous rookies. He was dazzled.

title: Deukmejian Asks U.S. To Act on Killings
description: Gov. George Deukmejian of California has asked the United States Justice Department to use the Federal civil rights law to prosecute Dan White.

title: Soiree Steeped in History
description: Tyrannosaurus Rex, 18 feet tall rampant, and three of his fellow dinosaurs will preside over a ''dinosoiree'' at the American Museum of Natural History - just like the birthday-party fantasy of many a New York youngster.

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the planned release dates for major economic indicators to be reported this week.

title: Moon Spirit Wins at Belmont
description: Angel Penna Jr. is known as an unusually patient trainer with 3-year-olds, waiting for them to blossom in the fall instead of wearing them out in the spring, and he has been proving lately that patience pays off. In the last few weeks, the trainer has brought back A Phenomenon, who won the Jim Dandy and the Jerome Handicap, and yesterday he set out Moon Spirit to score a half-length victory over Win in the $88,500 Lawrence Realization at Belmont Park.

title: ADVERTISING
description: The D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius New York office won the $10 million in Buckingham Corporation business on Friday, and that, according to Alvin Hampel, chairman here, pushes the office over the $100 million billings mark. It is the sixth piece of new business won in the last seven months.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Banco de Ponce has elected Joseph Wiscovitch vice president.

title: Field Hockey Patron
description: Dick Kazmaier's name on the 1951 Heisman Trophy marked the end of an era. A Princeton man, Kazmaier was the last Ivy League player to win college football's grandest prize, and he also was the last Heisman winner not to pursue a professional career. He went straight to Harvard Business School.

title: TOWN'S LIFEBLOOD PLANT MAY BE BIGGEST HAZARD
description: For almost a century this tiny town of 1,800 people in the foothills of the Rockies has been sustained by an American Smelting and Refining Company lead smelting plant. But new environmental tests show that the same smelter that has given life to the town has been spreading a coating of hazardous lead dust on the community.

title: ISRAEL'S SETTLEMENT RIGHT IS 'UNASSAILABLE'
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Coal by Pipe or Politics The nation's railroads fought hard for the right to compete on equal terms with trucks and barges. Now, unfortunately, they're fighting just as hard to stop pipelines from competing with railroads in moving coal. The House has a chance this week to say no to the railroads - and yes to the consumer's right to transportation at the lowest possible cost.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: * Rate depicted in Long- or Short-Term Rates chart.

title: Reports Warn of Dangers of U.S. Oil Policy
description: The United States is likely to rely increasingly on oil from the Persian Gulf region in the 1980's, and the Reagan Administration's relaxation of precautions could seriously damage the economy in another embargo, a report to Congress said today.

title: Deirdre M. Twomey Weds G. P. Cipriano
description: Deirdre Mary Twomey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Neil Francis Twomey of Wyckoff, N.J., was married there yesterday to Guy Peter Cipriano, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. Cipriano of Millburn, N.J. The Rev. Dr. John G. Pisarcik, chaplain of the St. Francis Health Resort in Denville, N.J., performed the ceremony at St. Elizabeth's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Eagles Spoil Elway Homecoming, 13-10
description: After playing the first two games of the regular season on the road and winning them, the Denver Broncos and their prized rookie quarterback, John Elway, returned today to Mile High Stadium and a wildly-enthusiatic crowd of 74,202 fans.

title: ROCK AT RITZ: MITCH RYDER COMES BACK
description: WHAT with Bruce Springsteen's unearthing Gary U.S. Bonds and Elton John's resurrecting Neil Sedaka, the notion of pop stars honoring their influences by bringing them back into the spotlight has become something of a tradition in the last decade. Recently, under the aegis of John Cougar, the 38-year-old Detroit-based rock-and-roll singer Mitch Ryder has returned to recording with a likable up-tempo album, ''Never Kick a Sleeping Dog.''

title: STATIONS THAT TIME AND TRAINS HAVE PASSED BY
description: Through the grimy windows of an IRT Lexington Avenue subway train, a shadowy image - an ''18'' in ornate bas relief - suddenly appears, ghostlike, along the murky fringes of the train's yellow light. The local train has just left the 23d Street station, and 14th Street is next on the line.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1983
description: International

title: Commodities; Why Grain And Bean Prices Fell
description: THE adage ''buy on anticipation and sell on the news'' worked with a vengeance in the soybean and corn markets last week, according to Conrad Leslie, the crop forecaster, and other analysts.

title: Addendum
description: People magazine increasing advertising page rates 5 percent, effective with the Jan. 9 issue.

title: Grey, Creamer Finalists For KIS's Photo Unit
description: The United States arm of KIS Instant Services of Grenoble, France, is looking for an agency to handle its photo division and is planning to spend $2 million during the rest of this year.

title: U.S.A. GREEN PARTY COMES TO WASHINGTON AND BACKS MONDALE
description: Emerald cities, their tarred rooftops covered with flower and vegetable gardens cultivated by urban man tilling soil on tenements and high-rise buildings.

title: GRAIN SALES TO SOVIET INCREASING
description: The Soviet Union has bought more grain from the United States - 250,000 metric tons of wheat and 125,000 tons of corn - for delivery in 1983-84 under terms of a long-term agreement signed last month, according to the Agriculture Department.

title: Daniela Wittman Is Married to Richard L. Amdur
description: Daniela Wittmann, daughter of Marie Wittmann of London and Norrkoping, Sweden, and the late Ervin Wittmann, formerly of Brno, Czechoslovakia, was married yesterday to Richard L. Amdur, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Amdur of Brooklyn Heights and East Atlantic Beach, L.I. The ceremony was performed at the Kane Street Synagogue in Brooklyn by Rabbi Jonathan Ginsberg, assisted by Rabbi Israel Mowshowitz, rabbi emeritus of the Hillcrest Jewish Center in Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: Celebrations in Chicago
description: Manager Tony LaRussa poked his head out the White Sox dugout, looked at the sun and threw a towel over his head, after a night of celebration of Chicago's clinching of the American League West title.

title: Washington Watch; Coal Slurry Bill Gains in House
description: WASHINGTON SUPPORTERS of legislation to guarantee rights-of-way for coal-slurry pipelines have been disappointed many times since the first bill was offered during the Kennedy Administration. But this may be the week when it finally clears the House of Representatives, which last Thursday sent it to the floor on a 7-5 vote by the Rules Committee.

title: 3 DIE AS BLAZE SWEEPS 4 FIRE I. HOUSES
description: A fire swept through four houses in the Fire Island enclave of Point O'Woods early yesterday, killing three people, including the chairman of Barnard College's history department and her husband, a psychiatrist.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I was chosen because I was qualified for the position. The fact that I was black was not a factor.

title: Tennessee Bank Fails
description: The Warren County Bank was declared insolvent and closed Friday because of excessive loan losses, marking the 12th failure of of a financial institution in Tennessee this year, officials said.

title: A COLLISION OF COURSES
description: SOMETHING'S got to be done about yacht racing. Up to yesterday, the America's Cup races had been called off twice in five days for lack of wind. That simply will not do in this modern age.

title: MEXICO TRIES TO HELP ITS LETHARGIC FILM INDUSTRY
description: The lethargic pulse of Mexico's movie industry can be taken each morning in the newspapers.

title: CHILEAN'S BID FOR A COMEBACK
description: For a man who presided over the most spectacular financial collapse in Chilean history, who is caught in a tangle of lawsuits and who owes hundreds of millions of dollars to foreign and domestic banks, Javier Vial seems remarkably relaxed and self-confident.

title: The Calendar; Monday
description: President Reagan starts his week by honoring executive women in Government in a Rose Garden ceremony at 11:30 A.M.

title: ORIOLES TRIUMPH
description: The Orioles, overcoming a 7-0 deficit, scored a 10-9 victory today over the Brewers, handing Milwaukee its ninth straight loss.

title: British Pocket TV
description: Sinclair Research of Britain has introduced a pocket television set with a 2-inch-square screen that will cost about $119.

title: PHILS WIN, TAKE FIRST ALONE
description: In defeat the St. Louis Cardinals slouched in front of their lockers and spoke listlessly of the need for a miracle. In victory the Philadelphia Phillies adjourned to the players' lounge, where they raised their fists in cheer as the Pirate-Expo game unfolded on a large television screen.

title: Ogilvy and Grey Benefit From Beecham's Move
description: Ogilvy & Mather and Grey Advertising, both American corporations, were the major beneficiaries of an agency consolidation in Britain by the Beecham Group, a worldwide packaged goods company that markets household products, toiletries, foods and pharmaceuticals.

title: A POLICY REVEALED
description: Now we know. By its own declaration, the Reagan Administration seeks ''military victory'' rather than a negotiated settlement in El Salvador. And it aims to ''prevent consolidation of a Sandinista regime in Nicaragua'' rather than merely to interdict whatever arms that country supplies to the Salvadoran guerrillas.

title: QUESTIONS PERSIST IN SEX CASE INVOLVING CHILDREN IN VERMONT
description: A sense of strained normalcy is returning to this town of 12,000 people a week after local officials announced that they had broken a prostitution ring run by children. But confusion remains about what actually happened.

title: Port Authority Job For William S. Doyle
description: William S. Doyle, who was deputy state commerce commissioner and takes credit for the ''I Love New York'' campaign, just as former Governor Hugh L. Carey does, has just won an assignment for his agency, William S. Doyle & Company, from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Investor Program Curbed by Court
description: A New Hampshire man has been charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission with fraudulently offering to investors promissory notes paying a minimum of 50 percent interest per year.

title: BASS CONTESTS' SPONSOR SAYS LARGER PRIZES LURE CHEATERS
description: Fishermen used to enter bass tournaments for trophies and glory, but a sponsor of the events in Texas says today's rising prize money has brought cheating by anglers who smuggle in large fish and claim thousands of dollars.

title: NICARAGUAN REBEL TO SEEK MONEY IN U.S.
description: The guerrilla leader Eden Pastora Gomez plans to visit the United States on a campaign to gain support and money for his fight against the Nicaraguan Government, aides of Mr. Pastora said today.

title: New York Cultural Groups Get 22 Challenge Grants
description: ''We're bursting our municipal buttons with pride,'' Bess Myerson, the Cultural Affairs Commissioner, said exuberantly. ''It's as though all our children were accepted at medical school.''

title: Fare From Everywhere
description: On a summery Sunday of lively, strolling crowds in Greenwich Village, one of the livelier places around town yesterday was the Manhattan Developmental Center's secluded courtyard at Barrow and Greenwich Streets.

title: Florence Still Debates Return of Dante's Bones
description: It is 662 years since Dante died, but Florence is still divided about whether his bones belong in Ravenna or in the city from which he was exiled.

title: LEBANON FIGHTING WIDENS AS MILITIA SHELLS AN AIR BASE
description: The fighting in Lebanon widened today, with anti-Government militiamen shelling the Lebanese Air Force base in the north of the country.

title: MRS. THATCHER CRITICIZES EUROPE ON FLIGHT 007
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, in her first public statement on the Soviet Union's downing of the Korean airliner, has criticized her Common Market and NATO allies for what she called their failure to fully censure the Russians for their actions.

title: 7 DEMOCRATS VISIT NEW YORK SEEKING VOTES FOR PRESIDENCY
description: The Presidential campaign in New York State is under way, with seven Democratic Presidential candidates campaigning extensively here this month.

title: MUSIC: 'BRIDGE' BY LEVICK
description: HUGH LEVICK and the Imago Ensemble, in calling their concert last Wednesday night ''The Bridge,'' were referring in part to its setting, in the Anchorage of the Brooklyn Bridge. The 50-foot-high barrel-vaulted brick ceilings also gave the music a resonance, which in quiet moments was echoed by the bridge's familiar traffic hum.

title: PRICES PAID INCH UP FOR STEEL SHEET
description: The 7 percent increase in list prices for steel sheet that most major producers put into effect Sept. 1 has pushed up prices from their depressed levels, although industry analysts agree that the actual change has been far less than the rise of $35 to $40 a ton that was announced.

title: SEAHAWKS UPSET CHARGERS BY 34-31
description: Steve Largent caught touchdown passes of 41 and 5 yards from Jim Zorn and the rookie Curt Warner rushed for 109 yards as the Seattle Seahawks defeated the San Diego Chargers, 34-31, today.

title: Japan Export Curb Opposed
description: Takashi Ishihara, president of the Japan Automobile Manufacturers' Association, opposes extending the three-year voluntary restraint on car exports to the United States when it expires next March.

title: LIBERTIES UNIT FACES DISCORD AND A DEFICIT
description: For the past 25 years free speech, equal protection and the due process of law have been the top concerns of the New York Civil Liberties Union. In recent months, however, a new set of issues has dominated its docket, topped by acute financial problems and prolonged internal discord.

title: CONCERT: O'JAYS TOP POP-SOUL BILL
description: MAINSTREAM pop-soul music, emphasizing mature, ballad-oriented singers, was the focus of the final program of the Budweiser Superfest at Madison Square Garden on Saturday. Opening with the Hispanic pop-soul singer Angela Bofill, the program also featured the pop-funk group Lakeside, duets by Roberta Flack and Donny Hathaway, and sets by two venerable pop-soul vocal groups, the Whispers, and the O'Jays.

title: VOLUNTEER EXECUTIVES FIND JOBS MAKE TOUGH DEMANDS
description: Richard Ravitch gets death threats because of his job. Elliott Willensky loses friends. In his work, Martin E. Segal worries about too many details. Thomas M. Macioce wishes he could see more of his wife.

title: No Headline
description: LOCAL KNOWLEDGE. Further Essays in Interpretive Anthropology. By Clifford Geertz. 244 pages. Basic Books. $18.50.

title: Carla Lowenheim Becomes a Bride
description: Carla Lowenheim, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Lowenheim of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Peter A. Weinberg, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Weinberg of New York. Rabbi Irwin C. Lowenheim, the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at the Garden Jewish Center in Flushing, Queens.

title: Maura Harway, WNET Official, Weds a Lawyer
description: The marriage of Maura L. Harway to William Mark took place yesterday in the Terrace Restaurant in Manhattan. The ceremony was performed by Judge Rena K. Uviller of the New York State Court of Claims.

title: Busy Alaskan Seeking Gas Markets in Orient
description: Walter J. Hickel, a hotel owner, shopping center developer and politician who has helped shape Alaska's economy over the last 40 years, is busily preparing for his latest endeavor: a $26.6 billion pipeline from Prudhoe Bay to Kenai to carry Alaska's abundant natural gas to market.

title: PIRATE STREAK ENDS AS EXPOS WIN, 5-2
description: The Pirates were toppled out of their first-place tie and saw their six-game winning streak ended yesterday when the Expos defeated them by 5-2 at Pittsburgh.

title: CAIRO DAY OF ATONEMENT: 10 MEN ARE HARD TO FIND
description: Michael Salem, a 21-year-old Egyptian Jew, entered the nearly empty Shaar ha-Shamayim Synagogue early Saturday morning to pray.

title: Search Ended Off L.I. For 4 in Ditched Plane
description: The Coast Guard abandoned its search yesterday for the four occupants of a single-engine plane that apparently went down in the Atlantic Saturday evening three miles off Jones Beach, L.I.

title: E.E.C. Steel Talks Set
description: Foreign ministers from the 10 nations in the European Economic Community are to meet here Monday to discuss the lack of progress in talks with Washington over lifting American curbs on imports of high-quality steel.

title: Bush Stresses U.S. Seeks Arms Cuts
description: Vice President Bush, on the first day of a two-day visit to Rumania, today stressed what he called the United States commitment to nuclear arms reduction.

title: Los Angeles Schools Facing Teacher Strike
description: Negotiators for teachers and the Board of Education resumed contract talks today in the nation's second largest school district, but a union spokesman gave no indication of progress before Monday's scheduled strike vote.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Fighting Hunger
description: The Yankee and Met players won't be playing each other in the World Series this year, but Yankee fans will have a special opportunity on Sunday to establish their superiority over Met supporters.

title: Youth Kills Officer and Self
description: Daniel Edward Mitchell, a 17-year-old arrested for traffic violations, took a pistol from an officer and sprayed part of a police station with bullets today, killing Patrolman Bill Smelley and wounding Assistant Chief Larry Boyd before killing himself, the authorities said. Officials said Mr. Boyd was hospitalized and in good condition. A witness, Garth Dooley, said Mr. Mitchell stepped back from an office in the station before firing back inside.

title: ARAFAT CONFIMS SHUF COMBAT ROLE
description: Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, confirmed today that Palestinians from his group were in the Shuf Mountains supporting the Druse militia forces that have been fighting Christian militia units and the Lebanese Army.

title: News Analysis
description: Cesar Chavez, who led the successful battle to establish America's first farm workers' union, is moving in several directions in an effort to transform his union into a broader-based political force. At the annual convention of the United Farm Workers last week in Fresno, Calif., Mr. Chavez told reporters that he had formed what he calls a ''Chicano lobby'' to help Democratic candidates and had ordered computerized direct- mail equipment to help spread a political message to members and supporters. He also indicated that the union was interested in representing the needs of urban Hispanic Californians as well as farm workers, its traditional constituency.

title: AIR CURBS' EFFECT DISCOUNTED
description: Americans traveling to the Soviet Union will not be greatly affected by transportation sanctions growing out of the Russians' downing of the Korean Air Lines 747 on Sept. 1, according to the chairman of a newly formed group of American tour operators.

title: INNOVATIVE ZONING PLAN COULD AID THEATERS
description: After more than a year of debate, a committee established to find ways to preserve Broadway's 44 legitimate theaters is about to vote on a novel zoning plan that proponents believe could profoundly affect the future of the New York theater and the West Side of Manhattan.

title: Barnett Bank Offer
description: Florida Coast Banks Inc., Pompano Beach, said Friday that it had received an unsolicited merger proposal from Barnett Banks of Florida Inc. and has called a meeting of its directors this week to consider the offer, which is valued at approximately $55 million. The proposal calls for every two shares of Florida Coast Banks to be exchanged for one share of a new issue of 8 percent preferred stock of Barnett Banks.

title: CLERC BOWS TO ARIAS
description: Jimmy Arias defeated his nemesis, Jose-Luis Clerc, by 6-2, 2-6, 6-0 in the final of the $100,000 Sicilian Open tennis tournament today.

title: RICH'S IS CHANGING TO COUNTER A RIVAL
description: When the Atlanta school system went bankrupt during the Depression, Rich's, a major retailer here, redeemed teachers' paychecks.

title: IT'S THE SMALLER BUSINESSES THAT NEED HELP
description: To the Editor:

title: FRIENDS THE 'OUT' AND 'INS'
description: THE subject was sailing, but you get seasick by the seashore. The topic was tennis, but you think Navratilova is another Russian ballet star. The theme was cuisine, but canned spaghetti sauce is your gourmet delight. Well, don't wilt by the water or cower by the courts. Standing outside of ''in'' things may not be noble and it doesn't make you right, but it's no great dishonor either.

title: Utility Officials Reassure Neighbors of Power Unit
description: It will be several days before investigators can safely enter a highly radioactive building at the Rancho Seco nuclear power plant, where a steam generator leaked a ''tiny amount'' of radiation into the atmosphere, officials said.

title: TV: GEORGE BURNS'S 80 STAGE YEARS
description: ANY reason is a good reason for watching George Burns in action, and tonight at 9:30, Channel 4 comes up with still another excuse for a special. It is called ''George Burns Celebrates 80 Years in Show Business.'' The comedian got his start in vaudeville at the startling, but in those days not uncommon, age of 7. As he smilingly warns at the end of the program: ''I'm going to stay in show business until I'm the only one left.''

title: CROWDS AT 5TH AVE. BOOK FAIR SEE ORIGAMI, CARTOONISTS AND WRITERS
description: Thousands of New Yorkers and visitors turned Fifth Avenue into a book-browsers' delight yesterday at the fifth ''New York Is Book Country'' fair. The bright sun not only warmed the strollers, but it also complemented the hundreds of yellow balloons that floated above most of the 175 booths set up by publishers.

title: SAM ERVIN, COUNTRY LAWYER, FEELS 'PRETTY GOOD'
description: His eyebrows no longer bob like corks on a stormy sea.

title: TREASURY ISSUES DOMINATE SCHEDULE THIS WEEK
description: Treasury auctions of notes and bonds totaling $14.25 billion dominate this week's calendar of debt financings.

title: ARGENTINE BATTLES THE POLITICAL POWERS
description: Raul Alfonsin, a leading candidate in next month's presidential elections, has accused Argentina's military rulers of corruption and of murdering thousands of people who disappeared during the army's ''dirty war'' against terrorism in the 1970's.

title: ROBERTSON CASE STIRS ANGER
description: The Yankee players responded with outrage today to the news that the team planned to levy a heavy fine on Andre Robertson for having been out at 5 A.M. on the day of the automobile accident in which the shortstop's neck was broken.

title: ADDABBO IS LEADER IN RAISING OF FUNDS IN NEW YORK REGION
description: Representative Joseph P. Addabbo, a Queens Democrat and the chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee on defense, raised more money in the first six months of this year than any other Representative elected in 1982 in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Zoeller Holds On to Score 4-Shot Victory
description: Fuzzy Zoeller, saving his worst round of the tournament for the final day, squandered an eight-stroke lead today but held on to win the $750,000 Las Vegas Celebrity Pro-Am and take over the money-winning lead on the PGA Tour.

title: No Headline
description: A FEW days ago, while on a fishing trip with my grandson Morgan, I learned that something of the child lurks within me still. Morgan Child, who will be 4 years old in February, suggested such an excursion after learning that my granddaughter Lucy, who is a few months older, and I had gone on a white perch expedition that had been transformed into a picnic when we couldn't locate the fish.

title: New Microprinter
description: Texas Instruments Inc. has introduced a ''two-in-one'' microprinter called the Omni 800XTXM Model 855.

title: Bridge: Two From Italian Blue Team Are Getting Together Again
description: Observers at the Bermuda Bowl world team championships, beginning next Sunday in Stockholm, will be watching with interest the performance of two great veterans of the Italian Blue Team. Giorgio Belladonna and Benito Garozzo are the two top players in world rankings and have won many world team titles, but they have not played together since 1975, when they came from behind to win in Bermuda after a foot-tapping furore involving two of their teammates.

title: Westinghouse Sells Operation
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has sold its computer numerical control operations, based in Orlando, Fla., to three executives. Terms were not disclosed.

title: LOSS HURTS NOTRE DAME, BUT FAUST REMAINS HOPEFUL
description: ''PEAKS and valleys, right?'' a home-team fan said to a friend as they headed for the exit last Saturday at Notre Dame Stadium.

title: Kennedys Gather on the Cape To See Sydney Lawford Wed
description: The Kennedy family spent the weekend celebrating the marriage of Sydney Lawford, daughter of Patricia Kennedy and Peter Lawford.

title: FLOUTING THE LAW
description: In the growing struggle between Congress and the White House over the War Powers Resolution, few have noticed a curious and important fact. President Reagan has so far offered no defense - not in fact, not in law - for his failure to follow the rules in Lebanon.

title: FARM UNIONS IN SALVADOR FACING BATTLE TO PRESERVE LAND PROGRAM
description: Farm workers' unions in El Salvador will face a major test of strength in the next few weeks when the Constituent Assembly considers three articles of a draft constitution that deal with the country's land redistribution program.

title: TO FIRST BLACK MISS AMERICA, VICTORY IS A MEANS TO AN END
description: It was never Vanessa Williams's dream to become Miss America - she wanted to be a Broadway star. She entered the contest only after a local pageant official saw her perform in a college show, and only after a professional play in which she was supposed to perform was canceled.

title: Donald F. Leslie Wed To Charlotte I. Skolnik
description: Charlotte Iris Skolnik, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Skolnik of Valley Stream, L.I., was married yesterday to Donald Frederick Leslie, son of Elizabeth B. Leslie of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Robert E. Leslie of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Rabbi Robert Rothman performed the ceremony at the Shenorock Shore Club in Rye, N.Y.

title: F.A.A. CHIEF SAYS JET WAS BEYOND U.S. RADAR
description: Government officials said yesterday that United States military radar could track airliners flying from Alaska to Japan and Korea for a much greater distance than civilian radar, but they said that the South Korean jumbo jet shot down by a Soviet fighter Sept. 1 had gone beyond the range of United States military radar a good way before it strayed over Soviet territory.

title: Fine Lines Between Church and State
description: Although self-styled moral majorities thunder for a constitutional amendment allowing prayer in public schools, the sharpest conflicts over religious liberty now concern silent symbols. In New Jersey, a Federal judge is hearing evidence about whether a required ''minute of silence'' in school amounts to state-sponsored prayer. And the Supreme Court will consider next month whether Pawtucket, R.I., may sponsor a Nativity scene in an otherwise commercial Christmas display.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: South Africa Austerity
description: South Africa will introduce anti-inflation measures to back up its fiscal and monetary policy, Prime Minister P. W. Botha said today. He said said South Africa's inflation rate, running at 12 percent in July, higher than in major industralized nations, had to be brought closer to that of the country's trading partners if its manufacturing industry was to become more competitive.

title: Robert D. Loomis Weds Miss Mills
description: Hilary Paterson Mills, daughter of Mrs. Chester Kerr of New Haven and Ted Mills of East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert D. Loomis, son the late Mr. and Mrs. Kline Loomis of Plain City, Ohio. The ceremony was performed at the home of Mr. and Mrs. George Mittendorf in Wainscott, L.I., by the Rev. Fanny Ericson of the Riverside Church in Manhattan.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Player A, preparing to return a ball in a tennis match, is distracted by Player B, who stamps his feet and swings his hands. Player A contends the point is his because he has been hindered. Is he correct? Under Rule 21, if Player B deliberately hinders his opponent, Player A gets the point. If the hindrance is involuntary, that is, Player B did not intend to distract Player A, then the point is replayed. It is a judgment call that must be settled by the players, if there is no official.

title: Lisa Gubernick, Journalist, And Paul Fishleder Marry
description: Lisa Rebecca Gubernick, daughter of Mrs. Reuben Gubernick of Los Angeles and the late Mr. Gubernick, was married yesterday to Paul Seth Fishleder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eli Fishleder of Teaneck, N.J. Justice Leroy B. Kellam of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the home of the bride and bridegroom in Manhattan.

title: DETROIT STRESSING STYLE FOR '84
description: The nation's automobile manufacturers seem confident that affluent customers are returning in large numbers as the recession fades. What is more, these buyers may be ready to trade in their fuel-efficient subcompact cars for more powerful and luxurious models. So Detroit is gearing up for the 1984 model year with a new emphasis on performance and styling, rather than mileage and price.

title: PACKERS TOP RAMS IN FINAL SECOND
description: Capitalizing on a turnover by the Los Angeles Rams' rookie running back Eric Dickerson, Jan Stenerud kicked a 36-yard field goal with one second left in the game today to lift the Green Bay Packers to a 27-24 victory.

title: Budget Car Rental
description: Budget Rent-A-Car said it would begin offering for rent Lincoln Town Cars equipped with a cellular mobile telephone supplied by Motorola Inc. The cars will be offered at two Chicago airports beginning Oct. 4, and the company, in an announcement Friday, said it hoped to offer the option on 16,000 Lincolns at airports around the country as licensing for other cellular radio systems is approved.

title: AUTO SAFETY DOESN'T DEPEND ON AIRBAGS ALONE
description: To the Editor:

title: French Joblessness Rise
description: French unemployment in August rose one-tenth of 1 percent, to 2,035,400, from 2,033,100 in July, according to the Labor Ministry. The figures are adjusted for seasonal variation.

title: AN ANESTHETIST, CARDIAC ARREST AND AN INQUIRY
description: When Abraham Asante walked in to the Walson Army Community Hospital looking for work as an anesthesiologist last June, his credentials were impressive: courses at Yale and Columbia, medical licenses in both Connecticut and Indiana, even a stint at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital during which he assisted a brain surgeon.

title: Yanks Split Doubleheader
description: Dave Winfield continued his assault on the last-place Cleveland Indians today, going 7 for 8 with 2 home runs in a doubleheader split. For the three-game series, when the Yankees won only once, Winfield was 10 for 13, with 4 homers, 6 runs batted in and 8 runs scored.

title: NANTUCKET JEWS FORM CONGREGATION
description: It seemed to Sarah Levine that there should be some record of what was happening here, that the genesis should not be lost. And so, in the early summer, feeling self-conscious but with a sense of history, she put a plain legal pad before her and wrote:

title: Split Over Radio Marti
description: This is only the second time in 50 years that a Republican President has had a Republican majority in the Senate, and you might think that mutual gratitude would promote a harmonious working relationship. Some days you would be wrong.

title: Williams and KN Put on Credit List
description: The Williams Companies and KN Energy Inc., both involved in takeover attempts, have been added to Standard & Poor's Creditwatch list. Williams has entered a takeover battle for the Northwest Energy Company, with a stock tender offer that is valued between $740 million and $880 million.

title: AUSTRALIA II SETS A RECORD IN VICTORY
description: Australia II defeated Liberty today in the third race of the America's Cup series by 3 minutes 14 seconds, the largest margin of victory of a challenger over a defender in cup history.

title: NEW PRICE STRATEGY FOR GRAND UNION
description: The large green and white signs hanging above the check-out counters at the East 86th Street store proclaim that Grand Union is changing. Along the aisles, the ''was and is'' price tags attached to the products prove it.

title: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1983
description: The Economy

title: NO-FAULT MEDICAL MALPRACTICE SYSTEM?
description: To the Editor:

title: EASTERN BLOC LOSING MARKETS
description: Eastern European nations, badly in need of export revenue to repay their $73.5 billion debt, are losing the battle for markets in industrialized Western nations to aggressive competitors from the developing nations of Asia and Latin America, according to experts attending a conference here on East-West economic ties.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: READING George Rose, recently a star of ''Pirates of Penzance'' on Broadway and the very model of a modern major actor, is marking an anniversary at 6 P.M. today in the Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53d Street (621-0613). It was one year ago that Mr. Rose inaugurated the Theater in the Library series for the New York Public Library with a reading at the 58th Street branch.

title: New Angles on Art
description: Thinking ahead, the eight-year-old First Women's Bank created as much unbroken wall space as possible and installed track lighting when it opened on 57th Street, just east of Park Avenue, in a neighborhood of art galleries. Three years ago it hired Wendell Walker as art consultant and part-time curator.

title: COLOR PENN STATE (0-3) BLUE
description: SUZANNE E. TALLICHET is a graduate student at Penn State who, like many other fans of the Nittany Lions, had enough of losing after Penn State dropped its first two games this season. She wrote a letter to the editor of The Daily Collegian, the student newspaper, and her message was printed in last Tuesday's edition.

title: Market Place; Group Rotation And Moods
description: GROUP rotation continued to be the name of the game last week in the stock market. The Dow Jones industrial average, meanwhile, finished at 1,225.71, down 14.03 points.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about the Kinsey Institute for Research in Sex, Gender and Reproduction misidentified the institute's director. She is June Machover Reinisch.

title: A New Career
description: ''It is na-ow post time.''

title: UTILITIES TRY TO CURB GROWTH
description: A survey of the nation's major utilities has found ''a virtual stampede'' of efforts to control load growth.

title: ISRAELI LABOR COALITION TO REPLACE BEGIN
description: A delegation from the opposition Labor Party coalition urged today that the ''historic opportunity'' created by the resignation of Prime Minister Menachem Begin be used to set up an alternative Government that will ''lift the country out of the economic, social, security and political morass.''

title: SEARCH FOR NEW BOND FUTURES
description: When bond dealers are faced with large offerings, their natural inclination is to reduce prices and raise yields in order to attract buyers.

title: Challenge to P. & G. Ad Leads to Modification
description: The question of whether a can of Duncan Hines Creamy Frosting contained enough icing to cover the cake that appeared with it in a Compton print ad was but one of the weighty matters resolved in August by the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus.

title: SNIPER IN BRONX KILLS 1, HURTS 1 ON EXPRESSWAY
description: A 37-year-old Queens woman riding in a car on a highway in the Bronx was shot and killed yesterday afternoon by a sniper who also wounded a teen-aged youth in another car at the same spot shortly afterward. The police said the killer apparently had selected his victims at random.

title: FOR A MARSHALL PLAN II
description: Private banks have shown the way. The governments of the rich democracies should follow suit, stepping in where the banks have left off with loans and aid to the developing world.

title: People
description: * Michael Feldman and John W. Stokes have been elected senior vice presidents of Young & Rubicam USA.

title: POLITICAL ACTION GROUPS' GIFTS FOCUS ON NEW AREAS IN HOUSE
description: The flow of money from political action committees to members of the House has focused recently on members of two panels that deal with the merchant marine and public works, according to reports filed with the Federal Election Commission.

title: DR. Ernest R. Deprospo
description: Dr. Ernest R. Deprospo Jr., the director of graduate programs at Rutgers University's School of Communication, Information and Library Studies, died of cancer Friday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 45 years old and lived in East Brunswick, N.J.

title: DANCE: 'USAGE,' SATIRICAL SKETCHES
description: ONE can be on the side of the angels and still seem foolish. This melancholy conclusion was prompted by ''Usage,'' a multimedia theater-piece that C.M.P. Productions offered Saturday night at the New York University Tisch School of the Arts.

title: Dancer Gets Simplicity; Venet Wins 2 Accounts
description: Dancer Fitzgerald Sample and Venet Advertising both came up with new business last week.

title: IRVING BERLIN IS BACK ON THE POP CHARTS
description: Irving Berlin is back in the pop top 10.

title: Advertising; New Effort To Verify TV Ad Use
description: AS an agency media director, Robert P. Engelke was well aware of the difficulty in getting verifications from television and radio stations that clients' advertising had run as requested. And the station affidavits that his people had to rely on were frequently not satisfactory.

title: Gail E. Meyer Marries S. J. Asarch, a Lawyer
description: Gail Ellen Meyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur I. Meyer of Harrison, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Steven J. Asarch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Asarch of New York and Delray Beach, Fla. Rabbi Burt Siegel performed the ceremony at the Rye Town Hilton.

title: BLACK LEADERS PRAISE CHOICE OF FIRST BLACK MISS AMERICA
description: Black leaders today applauded the crowning of the first black Miss America, and one of them called the selection a sign that ''inherent racism in America must be diluting itself.''

title: Hispanic Voter Effort Is a Success in Miami
description: An eight-hour musical show designed to attract potential Hispanic voters ended late Saturday night with 1,350 people signing up to vote, a record for one-day voter registration efforts in Florida. The majority of the newly registered voters listed themselves as Republicans.

title: No Headline
description: The U.N. Today Sept. 19, 1983 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: China Crash Toll Rises to 11
description: An 11th person has died as the result of Wednesday's collision of a Chinese military plane and a domestic airliner in Guilin, the official press agency Xinhua reported today.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO BAR 5 NICARAGUANS
description: The State Department has denied entry into the United States of a five-member group of Nicaraguans who had planned to speak here, according to one of the organizations sponsoring their scheduled appearance.

title: CUBS COMPLETE SWEEP OF METS
description: The Mets' bullpen, for months the strength of the team, failed in the ninth inning yesterday for the second straight game. And, for the second straight game, the Chicago Cubs rallied to beat the Mets.

title: Letter: On Nuclear Power Give Up On Shoreham
description: To the Editor:

title: New Chairman Outlines Dunkin' Donuts Goals
description: Robert M. Rosenberg, 45, has been named chairman of Dunkin' Donuts Inc., succeeding his father, William, 67, who founded the chain in 1950.

title: PHILIPPINE ARMY WILL INVESTIGATE AQUINO SLAYING
description: The commander of the Philippine armed forces has ordered a separate military investigation into the shooting of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., killed at Manila International Airport last month on his return from self-exile in the United States.

title: Michael Tierney Weds Susan Elizabeth Ryder
description: Susan Elizabeth Ryder, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Richard E. Ryder Jr. of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Michael Paul Tierney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Tierney of Bethesda, Md. The ceremony was performed at the First Congregational Church, United Church of Christ, by the bride's father, senior minister of the church, and the Rev. William J. Byron, president of the Catholic University of America.

title: Mears Sets Mark For Indy Cars
description: Rick Mears, driving the fastest Indy-car race in history, ended a yearlong victory drought today by capturing the Detroit News Grand Prix race at Michigan International Speedway.

title: Crop Forecaster Is Market Maverick
description: When the Government issued its crop estimates last week, most accounts noted that the predictions for corn and soybeans were about the same as those made a week earlier by Conrad Leslie.

title: GIFTED 3-YEAR-OLDS GO TO CLASS AT COLUMBIA
description: It was the first part of the first day in a very special classroom at Teachers College at Columbia University, and 11 3-year-old children found to be of superior intelligence were getting used to the routine of being in a new kind of school. The prepared curriculum - spatial relationships, the structure and functions of the body and other subjects that go far beyond reading - would come later.

title: Swiss Intercept Airliner
description: Two Swiss Air Force planes intercepted a Bulgarian civilian airliner today that had entered Swiss airspace without notification. An air force spokesman said an F-15 jet fighter and a Mirage reconnaissance jet intercepted the Bulgarian TU-134 airliner.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Says India Does Not Have the Bomb
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said today that India does not possess the atomic bomb but is going ahead with a nuclear development program for peaceful purposes.

title: No Headline
description: The Drug War Is More Than Local Waging a determined battle against the drug trade on city streets is only a partial response to the urban heroin epidemic. Ultimately it's an international problem, since the same drugs that blight American cities are important, if illicit, cash crops to foreign farmers.

title: Poles Offer Own Version Of Hijacking Incident
description: The Government said today that a Polish taxi driver hijacked a light plane to West Berlin, an account differing substantially from the version reported by Western authorities a day earlier.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SEE CRISIS WITH SOVIET LASTING INTO 1984
description: The cancellation of Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko's trip to New York has fortified the view of some Administration officials that Soviet-American relations are now so frozen that they may not thaw until after next year's Presidential elections.

title: LENDERS TO 3D WORLD: GROWING ROLE
description: Anonymous civil servants fanning out across the globe from well-appointed buildings three blocks from the White House are playing a crucial role in managing the economic lives of three-quarters of the world's population.

title: L.I. Man and Son Are Injured As Sailboat Engine Explodes
description: A Long Island man and his son were seriously injured today when their sailboat's auxiliary engine exploded at a dock here as they tried to start it, the Nassau County police said.

title: RECITAL: MICHAEL HABERKORN
description: THE best moments of the pianist Michael Haberkorn's Saturday night concert at the newly remodeled Carnegie Recital Hall came with an earnest and poetic transversal of Arnold Sch"onberg's ''Drei Klavierst"ucke'' (Op. 11). Unlike most pianists, who exaggerate Sch"onberg's ''wrong'' notes with misguided zeal, Mr. Haberkorn played these fascinating intermezzos with an admirable attention to linear continuity.

title: TRIBE WHERE HARMONY RULES
description: As families go they are not exactly the sort of folks who used to live next door on ''Ozzie and Harriet.'' In these families as many as 18 relatives live in the same house, and contact among them is intense. Yet the degree of family harmony is remarkable: squabbling is virtually unknown and family members display an extraordinary degree of caring for one another.

title: 3 Killed on Matterhorn
description: An avalanche swept away a roped party of American climbers on the 14,690-foot Matterhorn, killing three and leaving a fourth missing and presumed dead, the Swiss police said today. The climbers' identities were not revealed, but rescue workers say they think the climbers were United States military personnel stationed in West Germany. The party had been missing since Thursday.

title: IT'S THE SMALLER BUSINESSES THAT NEED HELP
description: To the Editor:

title: Michael A. Bontempo Dies; Ex-Newark Councilman, 82
description: Michael A. Bontempo, a former Newark Councilman, died Wednesday at his home in Port St. Lucie, Fla.

title: GIANTS ARE BEATEN
description: The Jets reached depths of frustration today that teams expected to make the playoffs are not supposed to experience.

title: Nearly 400 Reported Killed In Monsoon Flooding in India
description: Monsoon rains have killed nearly 400 people and submerged hundreds of villages in five Indian states since the start of this month, the Press Trust of India reported today.

title: Wagner and More Wagner
description: When Channel 13 broadcast the Pierre Boulez-Patrice Chereau production of Wagner's ''Ring'' last spring, the mail - and some reviews - bristled with criticism, saying the impact was spread over a five-month period.

title: NEWEST WING AT MET COMPLETES FIRST PHASE
description: The new $25 million southwest wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, above the museum garage on the 79th Street side of the building, adjacent to the Michael C. Rockefeller Wing, has reached the end of its first phase of construction.

title: Miami Trade Shifts to Imports
description: The decline in sales of United States goods abroad is turning some Miami exporters into importers.

title: John Manson, Commissioner Of Correction in Connecticut
description: John R. Manson, Connecticut's Commissioner of Correction, died Saturday night, apparently of a heart attack, at St. Mary's Hospital in Waterbury, Conn. He was 54 years old and lived in Cheshire, Conn.

title: Turnpike Crash Injures 16
description: Sixteen people were injured early today when a Greyhound bus and a car crashed into a tractor-trailer truck that overturned on the Pennsylvania Turnpike near here after its driver dozed off, the state police said. The truck driver, the bus driver, and a bus passenger were hospitalized in serious condition. Five passengers in the car and eight bus passengers were treated for minor injuries.

title: Snoopy Art Is Curbed After Schools Protest
description: Responding to complaints from educators, Hallmark Cards has agreed to stop making posters that depict Snoopy commenting that he would rather party than study at certain high schools.

title: U.S. AIDE SUGGESTS MEMBERS TAKE THE U.N. ELSEWHERE IF DISSATISFIED
description: An American delegate to the United Nations encouraged members today to consider removing the organization from New York if they thought the United States was failing in its obligations as host country.

title: TV: TWO NEW COMEDIES
description: Whimsy, of the sort once found in ''The Flying Nun'' or ''I Dream of Jeannie,'' is what is being marketed in ''Just Our Luck,'' the situation comedy beginning tonight on ABC- TV.

title: MARC RICH INDICTED IN VAST TAX EVASION CASE
description: Marc Rich, one of the world's leading commodity traders, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges that he and a partner had evaded $48 million in income taxes. Prosecutors said it was the biggest tax- fraud indictment in history.

title: DATATRON INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
BUSH PRAISES HUNGARY ON RIGHTS
description: Vice President Bush praised Budapest's human rights record today and said the United States wanted better relations with all East European countries.

title: A SOLITARY SCIENTIST PROBES AMAZONIA
description: THE setting in the Cuyabena Nature Reserve in Ecuador is a biologist's paradise: more than 500 species of birds, spiny palms that are the center of a self-contained ecosystem, vines like the ones Tarzan swung on, jumping piranhas, blind river dolphins, elusive manatees, quicksilver squirrel monkeys, iridescent- blue morpho butterflies, indefatigable leaf- cutting ants, 400-pound fish, frogs, snakes, lizards, turtles, wild pigs, giant rodents, jaguars and prehistoric caimans that fill the night air with plaintive territorial grunts.

title: House Passes Insider Curb
description: The House voted today to increase the Securities and Exchange Commission's powers over unscrupulous people using inside information for personal gain in financial markets.

title: TV SPORTS
description: His reputation was made in radio, in which a sports announcer is not so much a personality as he is a voice. And from the time he began broadcasting the Knick and Ranger games in the mid-1960's, Marv Albert has always had a distinctive voice, marked by a raspy tone and breathless pace that conveys the excitement and rush one gets from the roar of a fast-approaching train. It is a voice that has captured the fancy of New Yorkers, among them the fans who mimic Albert's definitive ''Yessss!'' the trademark he uses to punctuate a basket.

title: Police Perspectives
description: As hearings on charges of police brutality began in a Harlem armory yesterday, 34 community affairs police officers voiced their own complaints in mid-Manhattan.

title: French Aerospace Unit
description: Societe Nationale Industrielle Aerospatiale, the French state-owned aerospace company, today reported a one-third rise in sales in the first half of this year to 11.4 billion francs - about $1.42 billlion. The company also disclosed a substantial drop in its order book, which it said partly reflected the international economic recession. Orders on hand on June 30 were down 10 percent to 45 billion francs - about $5.6 billion - from a year earlier.

title: U.S. Says Number of People On Probation Has Increased
description: One of every 200 adult Americans was on probation in 1982, the Justice Department says.

title: Business and the Law; Effect of Curb On U.S. Cases
description: WHEN it comes to dealing with tax cheats, antitrust violators and others who commit such Federal crimes as overcharging the Government or failing to pay back student loans, the Federal Government may now have to choose between getting its money and getting its prey.

title: Broken Hill Financing For G.E.'s Coal Assets
description: Broken Hill Financing For G.E.'s Coal Assets

title: Hearing on Girl With Cancer Postponed Until Tomorrow
description: A state appeals court today delayed a hearing on whether a 12-year-old girl who, a lawyer said, ''believes with all her heart that God will save her,'' should be allowed to refuse medical treatment for bone cancer.

title: ETHICS COMPONENT FOR COMPUTER PROGRAM
description: To the Editor:

title: THE U.N. AND THE CITY: OBLIGATION, OPPORTUNITY AND IRRITATION
description: With mutual suspicion, misunderstandings and occasional hostility, the United Nations and its host, New York City, have pursued an elusive goal of peaceful coexistence for 37 years. By all accounts, the results have been a mix of love, hate, tolerance and indifference.

title: STAGE: SHELLEY HIRSCH, SINGER
description: Shelley Hirsch is an extraordinarily versatile vocalist, combining an unerring sense of pitch, expertise in pops and classical material, with a remarkable glossary of moans, whines, gurgles and squeals. She is not yet a very accomplished composer, however, and ''The Beach Is Her Home,'' a performance piece presented Sunday night at the Battery Park Landfill by Art On the Beach, seemed a misuse of her talents.

title: ON THE SEA OF JAPAN, 20 SHIPS COMB FOR THE WRECKAGE
description: Off the coast of this port, strong with the smell of the sea and the fish-packing plants, a race is on for who can unlock some of the mysteries of Korean Air Lines Flight 007.

title: Victim Foils Kidnappers
description: A businessman abducted at gunpoint and held for two days in an extortion scheme escaped Saturday by rolling out the back of a moving truck, the police said. The businessman, Jack Ching Lee, owner of the Yee Sing Chong market and the First Public Savings & Loan Association, was treated at California Hospital Medical Center for exhaustion, cuts and bruises and was released. His abductors escaped.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why don't different varieties of birds crossbreed when obviously dogs of varying breeds do?

title: PROMOTING RIGHTS...
description: For months, the controversy provoked by the President's nomination of three Democrats to the Civil Rights Commission has fueled debate over quotas and race-based and group-oriented preferential policies. As a nominee, I have expressed opposition to quota- ridden affirmative-action programs and to any form of preference based solely on race. I disagree with the commission's tendency to become an advocate by actively favoring certain funding levels, spending priorities and other issues of social policy properly left to Congress and the President. And I disagree with its perception of the role of discrimination in our society.

title: ACF, ICAHN TARGET, PREPARES NEXT STEP
description: Carl C. Icahn reported yesterday that he held 13.5 percent of ACF Industries and intended to seek control of the company.

title: Fight Put Off On Power Plan
description: Backers of a measure to help bail out the Washington Public Power Supply System temporarily abandoned their fight today, ending a two-month Senate deadlock on a $7.8 billion spending bill for the Interior Department and related agencies. The impasse was broken when Senator James A. McClure, Republican of Idaho, announced that he was withdrawing his amendment to help finance two power system nuclear plants in the face of a threatened filibuster.

title: RICK KUHN ASKS TERM REDUCTION
description: Rick Kuhn, the 28-year-old former Boston College basketball player who is serving a 10-year prison term for participating in a point-shaving conspiracy, has asked the sentencing judge to reduce the term.

title: Pact for MacMillan
description: Billy MacMillan of the New Jersey Devils, one of four men in the National Hockey League to hold both the titles of general manager and coach, signed a multiyear contract yesterday. MacMillan, who came to the Devils when the Colorado Rockies' franchise was moved to New Jersey for last season, had been working without a contract.

title: BY FABRICE, A TOAST TO GLITTER
description: His isn't a household name just yet, like Calvin Klein's and Christian Dior's, but he's on his way. Next week, Fabrice Simon - he pronounces Simon the French way, when he uses it at all - will be the guest designer at the black-tie dinner benefiting Girls' Town of Italy. For a decade one of New York's big fashion parties, it has in previous years honored Albert Capraro, Mary McFadden and Michaele Vollbracht of New York; Irene Galitzine, Valentino, Gianni Versace and Basile of Italy, and Zandra Rhodes of London. Fabrice, as he prefers to be known, was born in Haiti. His beaded dresses have been the toast of New York for three years.

title: TURNOVER INCREASES
description: Stock prices made a broad advance yesterday in more active trading, with the railroad and technology issues scoring the best gains for the second consecutive session.

title: ART OF GIVING CORPORATE GIFTS
description: There is a lot more to gift giving than meets the pocketbook. So says Dr. Kathleen Reardon, an assistant professor of communication sciences at the University of Connecticut.

title: HOLLINGS SAYS GLENN HAS BACKED REAGAN ON ECONOMIC POLICY
description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings charged tonight that Senator John Glenn, a competitor for the Democratic Presidential nomination, had voted for much of President Reagan's economic program.

title: ASA LTD reports earnings for As of Aug 31
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: Advertising; Ad Film On Internal Regulation
description: THE missing ingredient in advertising's noble experiment in self-regulation - a way of telling the public about its existence - might have made its appearance at last.

title: PLANNING MEMOS STRESS U.S. SHOW OF ARMED FORCE
description: Deputy Secretary of Defense Paul Thayer has ordered the armed forces to plan for expanded operations in Central America and has placed new emphasis on projecting American military power to the Persian Gulf, according to Defense Department memorandums.

title: RHODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31

PERSONAL COMPUTERS;
TURNING THE SCREEN INTO A DRAWING BOARD
description: SIX or seven years ago a gentleman in New Jersey, whose name I no longer recall, sent out to budding computer hobbyists across the land samples of a new product called ''digital foam.'' Resembling pieces of used inner tube from a DC-3, this foam had the remarkable property of being able to convert information from our world directly into binary data - that is, into a code made up of a series of ones and zeros - used by modern computers.

title: The First Law of War
description: An unnecessary debate about the war-making powers of the President and Congress is creating a misleading impression: Americans are not divided about the role of the Marines in Lebanon. Only if President Reagan persists in evading a Congressional vote of support for their deployment will he invite resistance and send the ''wrong signal'' that he says he dreads.

title: Hilton Video Plan
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced plans for a network of 35 public video teleconferencing rooms that will be linked by A.T.& T.'s video teleconferencing service. The rooms, to be available in Hilton hotels by the end of 1984, will use A.T.& T.'s Accunet Reserved 1.5 Service, formerly called High Speed Switched Digital Service.

title: AMADAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $748,000 for the quarter and $933,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $126,000 for the quarter and $236,000 for the 6 months.

title: MADLOCK KEEPS HIS SPIRITS UP
description: Mad Dog Madlock - born Bill Madlock Jr. - was sitting in the hotel lobby in New York yesterday afternoon and, in jeans and designer polo shirt, looking very unmenacing.

title: Slow the Truck Steamroller
description: New York will have no choice but to obey if Congress insists that Federal highways be opened to the huge, road-hogging trucks with tandem trailers. Congress has the raw power to insist: witness Connecticut's futile lawsuit to keep the double trucks off its interstates. Power is not wisdom, however. Congress has acted indiscriminately in rolling over legitimate state and local traffic and safety concerns.

title: SAFECARD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Anti-Cigarette Ads
description: The Office of Smoking and Health of the Department of Health and Human Services has reassigned its public service advertising account to the Clinton E. Frank Company, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies. One of its sister companies is McCann-Erickson, which does advertising for R. J. Reynolds's Camel cigarettes. The Frank shop, in a display of negative attitudes, has created a TV commercial in which a group of dancers demonstrates its new step, the Cigarette Mash, featuring partially smoked cigarettes underfoot.

title: THE MEADOWLANDS MAKES ITS MOVE
description: The screaming began at the sixteenth pole and continued through the photo-finish and two replays on the closed-circuit television monitors. Horseplayers everywhere use a combination of body English and profane English to cheer on their choices, but this din was more typical of a roller-derby than a race- track clubhouse.

title: MISSOURI RESEARCH LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss of $21,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Jets Seeking Answers Amid Poor Start; Were Hurt on Ground
description: Calmly, Joe Walton told his players today that with a 1-2 record their season was in danger of collapsing.

title: New Year to Bring Higher Prices in Poland
description: Poland announced today that food prices would rise by 30 to 40 percent in 1984.

title: RADIOACTIVITY FOUND IN BEES
description: Some insects in this Government- built town where nuclear warhead parts are produced are contaminated with radiation, researchers said Monday.

title: MEASUREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: b-Net loss

title: CORRECTION
description: A listing in the The Guide last Sunday for a concert of William Zucker's work gave an incorrect date. The recital will be given at 8 P.M. today at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: TRADING OIL IN A 'DAISY CHAIN'
description: One of the principal charges contained in the indictment announced yesterday against Marc Rich, the international commodities trader, is that companies that he controlled conspired to violate Federal laws covering the pricing and allocation of domestically produced crude oil. These laws, enacted in 1973, were gradually phased out in the late 1970's and ended in January 1981.

title: DIVIDING THE COSTS OF POLICING STRIKES
description: To the Editor:

title: Alka Seltzer's New Agency
description: Miles Laboratories is switching its Alka Seltzer antacid tablets to McCann-Erickson from Wells Rich Greene, where it has been for 13 years. But W.R.G. is keeping the Alka Seltzer Plus cold remedy.

title: APPLIED CIRCUIT TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Title to Tides
description: Helped by two unearned runs, Denver defeated Portland tonight, 5-4, giving the Tidewater Tides the Triple A world series.

title: JOHN VERNON BUTLER, 77, DEAN AT ST. JOHN THE DIVINE IN 60'S
description: The Rev. John Vernon Butler, former dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and rector of Trinity Parish in Manhattan from 1966 to 1971, died yesterday at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 77 years old.

title: FIRST CITY PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $300,000 for the quarter and $1.9 million for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $1,090,000 for the quarter and $2,007,000 for the 6 months.

title: Sony's Profits Down by 43.9%
description: The Sony Corporation said today that rising sales competition and an unfavorable exchange rate for the yen had helped to cause third-quarter profits to fall by 43.9 percent from the period last year.

title: Key Rates
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: LEADER IN FRENCH JOURNALISM
description: Charles Henri Gombault, a major figure in modern French journalism, died in Paris today at the age of 76, his family announced.

title: METS SET BACK PIRATES IN 10TH
description: A scrappy Mets team with nothing to lose tied the Pirates with two runs in the bottom of the ninth and went on to beat them, 5-4, in the 10th inning at Shea Stadium last night.

title: IF THE QUESTION IS MILITARY, ASK NUNN
description: On the Senate floor the older men cluster around the slight, dapper figure with oversize spectacles, a pinstripe suit, glistening loafers and a soft Georgia drawl.

title: MRS. MARCOS TELLS WHY SHE WANTS OUT
description: Imelda R. Marcos said today that her recently announced decision to quit politics next year was spurred by opposition suggestions that she might have been implicated in the killing of former Senator Benigno S. Aquino Jr. last month.

title: THE MARINES IN LEBANON: A YEAR OF CHANGING ROLE
description: Following is a chronology of the use of Marine forces in Lebanon: Aug. 20, 1982 - President Reagan orders 800 marines to participate in three-nation force, with French and Italian forces, to insure order during evacuation of Palestinian and Syrian fighters from Beirut after Israeli siege of the city. Sept. 10, 1982 - Marines depart after last guerrillas leave.

title: LEGISLATURE ON COAST SHELVES COMMUNITY COLLEGE TUITIONS
description: In final action in its 1983 session, the California Legislature shelved Gov. George Deukmejian's proposal to charge tuition at community colleges, but gave him most of what he had requested to relieve overcrowding in the state prisons.

title: Official at Pacific Light Hangs On to His Dam
description: David F. Bolender, president of electric operations at the Pacific Light and Power Company, is in Europe this week to meet potential investors, and he will have good news. The Merwin Dam and other hydroelectric facilities that form the power base for his shareholder-owned utility at last appear to be safely his.

title: MAKING 4-YEAR-OLDS WORK
description: THE school bells that are welcoming 5-year-olds to the beginning of their formal education in public schools around the country this fall could be ringing for increasing numbers of 4-year-olds in coming years.

title: SONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The share earnings are per Depositary Share (each Depositary Share represents one share of common stock.) The U.S. dollar amounts are translated from yen at the rate of 243 yen equals $1.00, the Tokyo foreign exchange rate as of Sept. 12.

title: COLLINS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Housing Bonds For Alabama
description: A $100 million issue of A-1/ AA-rated Alabama Housing Finance Authority mortgage revenue bonds was tentatively priced by a Goldman, Sachs & Company group with a maximum yield of 10 3/8 percent for bonds due in 2005.

title: 14 CATHOLIC BISHOPS SAY MX THREATENS WORLD
description: A group of 14 Roman Catholic bishops, citing the American bishops' recent pastoral statement on war and peace, today called production of the MX missile system unjustified and a threat to the future of the world.

title: SCIENTISTS, COMMEMORATING DNA, DISCUSS FUNCTION OF 'REVERSE TWIST
description: DNA that twists ''the wrong way'' may play a role in the regulation of genes and the cancer process, a scientist said here today.

title: U.S. WARSHIPS FIRE IN DIRECT SUPPORT OF LEBANESE ARMY
description: Two United States Navy ships off Beirut fired dozens of shells today in support of Lebanese Army units defending the town of Suk al Gharb on a ridge overlooking Beirut. It was the first direct military support of the Lebanese Army by United States forces.

title: ELECTRO-NUCLEONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $161,000 in each year.

title: Trial of Socialite In Father's Death Begins
description: The son of a New York socialite testified today that he killed his grandfather five years ago because ''my mother asked me to'' so she could ''inherit a great deal of money very quickly.''

title: Nigeria Cites I.M.F. Accord
description: Nigeria has reached a preliminary agreement with the International Monetary Fund on a three-year extended financing facility for more than $2 billion, Finance Minister Victor Masi said today.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Cardinal's Thanks

title: N.C.A.A. Study Set
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's plan to set minimum college admissions standards for athletes - a proposal that some black educators say would be unfair because standardized test scores would be racially and culturally biased - will be studied extensively, Gwen Norrell, vice president of N.C.A.A.'s Division I, said yesterday. She made the statement at a news conference to unveil a research effort from which the N.C.A.A. will try to determine whether the charges have merit. She indicated that the plan may undergo considerable changes before it takes effect in August 1986.

title: EDWIN T. SEXTON Jr.
description: Edwin T. Sexton Jr. of Silver Spring, Md., a Washington consultant and a former Republican National Committee official, died after suffering a heart attack Friday.

title: TYPICALLY, LEBANON STRATEGY DELEGATES AUTHORITY
description: Modern military communications have become so swift and global that they have put an American President in the position, if he chooses, to call the shots on a distant battlefield from his armchair in the Oval Office or from the Situation Room in the White House basement.

title: TRANQUILIZERS ARE AN IMPORTANT OPTION FOR TREATING ANXIETY
description: To the Editor:

title: GREEK EX-LEADER DEPLORES POLICY ON PLANE DOWNING AND MISSILES
description: Former Prime Minister George Rallis said today that Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's Government had jeopardized national interests in the name of ''an independent and proud'' foreign policy.

title: LEAD BY 2 GAMES
description: Joe Morgan celebrated his 40th birthday with four hits, including two home runs and four runs batted in, as the Philadelphia Phillies rallied to beat the Chicago Cubs, 7-6, tonight.

title: A Replay of Sorts
description: Kyle Burns, a 13-year-old, seventh- grade student in Justin, Tex., has decided to repeat the grade so that when he graduates from Northwest High School, he will be 19 years old and perhaps more physically qualified to win a football scholarship to Texas A&M. Under the rules of Texas's University Interscholastic League, Burns can not be stopped from repeating the seventh grade, since it is the wish of his father, Clay.

title: News Analysis
description: American involvement in the Lebanese crisis took a significant new turn today when the United States Navy began firing its guns not to defend American soldiers under attack but to support the operations of a Lebanese Army unit. Today's naval bombardment by two American ships in support of Lebanese soldiers trying to hold onto their positions in the mountaintop village of Suk al Gharb marked the first time American forces had acted under the new rules of engagement given them by President Reagan last Tuesday.

title: INCONSISTENCIES FOUND IN ENFORCING AIR ACT
description: The Federal courts have assumed great responsibility for enforcing the Clean Air Act, but their intervention has produced inconsistent pollution standards and policies, a study has concluded.

title: Soviet Delegation Flies To U.N. From Brussels
description: A 61-member Soviet delegation to the United Nations General Assembly arrived yesterday at New York's Kennedy International Airport aboard a Belgian airliner, officials said.

title: MUTUAL REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The net income results were before gain on sale of real estate.

title: ON BILINGUAL EDUCATION, REAGAN IS MOVING BACKWARD
description: To the Editor:

title: PLANTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
White Sox Streak Ended
description: Tom Brunansky hit a two-run homer in the eighth inning tonight to give the Minnesota Twins a 7-5 victory over the White Sox, breaking Chicago's 17-game home winning streak. Brunansky, who had four runs batted in, broke a 5-5 deadlock with his 25th homer of the year, scoring Mickey Hatcher, who had singled with two outs.

title: BRINGING CHURCH TO THE JOB
description: Michael West is not a steelworker, nor is he a British Steel Corporation executive. But nobody blinks an eye when he wanders through the company's Rotherham Steel Works northeast of this sprawling industrial city, pausing to chat with anyone who cares to speak to him.

title: Chess: 3 Players Tie for First Place In a Tournament in Norway
description: The Gjovik International Tournament in Norway ended in a tie for first place among the grandmasters John Nunn of Britain, Andras Adorjan of Hungary and Walter Browne of Berkeley, Calif. Each scored 6-3 in the 10-player round robin. FINAL STANDINGS Player W.L.D.Pts. Nunn3066Adorjan4146Browne4146Miles3155 1/2Agdestein4325Spassky1174 1/2Ftacnik2254 1/2Karlsson1353 1/2Helmers0452 1/2Ogaard0631 1/2

title: CHANGES PROPOSED IN AIR NAVIGATION
description: The head of the Air Line Pilots Association suggested to a House panel today that a more foolproof system ought to be developed to make sure traffic-control centers on shore know the precise position of planes on oceanic routes.

title: Giants May Put Taylor Inside
description: The Giants, confronted with injuries that have sidelined Harry Carson and Joe McLaughlin, may have found a new inside linebacker today.

title: MEGADATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Bids Accepted For B.P. Stock
description: The Bank of England began accepting bids today for the 130 million shares of the British Petroleum Company that the Government is selling in a drive to raise more than $750 million.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: VERMILION OLDIES VISITING CITY HALL
description: It is unusual enough to find in the City Hall rotunda a couple of freshly painted antique fire-alarm posts - blazing in vivid vermilion against the muted, marble setting - but the surprises continue upstairs.

title: DUNLOP IN TALKS ON SALE
description: Dunlop, Britain's largest tire manufacturing company, said today that it is negotiating to sell all of its tire-making interests in Britain and West Germany to Sumitomo Rubber Industries.

title: Acid Spill Forces School Evacuation
description: About 1,200 students were forced to leave Massapequa High School today after acid spilled in a chemistry classroom, sending fumes throughout the school and causing breathing problems for two chemistry teachers.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Big Bite Inc., Columbus, Ohio, has appointed Charles L. Rioux as chief executive officer and operating officer and Richard A. Stimmel as chairman, following the resignation of Nicholas C. Maraitis as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: MINDEN OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
VACU-DRY CO reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: LARGER TRIUMPH, LARGER LOSS; Committing Journalism
description: Costa Rica has a law against practicing journalism without a license. It's a crime for anyone who lives there to work as a newspaper reporter without Government permission, which in turn depends upon having a degree from a particular university.

title: LUTHERANS AND CATHOLICS IN U.S. AGREE ON KEY SALVATION DOCTRINE
description: American Roman Catholic and Lutheran theologians are preparing to announce agreement on the major religious issue that divided Lutherans and Roman Catholics nearly 500 years ago.

title: I.M.F. Loan Alternative
description: The International Monetary Fund may have to borrow in the financial markets if Congress votes against an $8.4 billion contribution to the agency, Federal Reserve Board sources said today.

title: CHEMICAL, ISELIN PUSH DEBT TALKS
description: The Chemical Bank yesterday intensified its efforts to obtain repayment of a $25 million delinquent loan to a garment company that has been accused by another major commercial banking organization of having committed a $15 million fraud.

title: WILDERNESS EXPERIENCE reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $72,200 from the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $21,700 for the quarter and $60,000 for the 9 months.

title: HOUSE INQUIRY LEADER SAYS REAGAN SOUGHT '80 PAPERS
description: The chairman of a Congressional investigation into the conduct of the 1980 Presidential campaign said today that investigators had uncovered evidence indicating ''an organized effort'' by Ronald Reagan's campaign to obtain materials from the Carter White House.

title: UNITED-OVERTON CORP reports earnings for 13wks to July 30
