description: b-Net loss These results include figures from the discontinued operation of the leased department segment that United-Overton Corp. sold as of Jan. 29, 1983.

title: PHYSICISTS COMPETE FOR THE BIGGEST PROJECT OF ALL
description: PUT simply, the project would be the biggest endeavor in the history of pure science, a colossus that would rival the building of the pyramids and the construction of the Panama Canal.

title: Tax Breaks In Eurobonds
description: The Administration strongly favors pending legislation designed to give American companies greater access to foreign capital by making it simpler for them to borrow on the Eurobond market, a senior official said today.

title: NEW CORNELL UNIT PROVIDING GERM-FREE CALVES TO AID RESEARCH
description: IT was an unusual birth. The cow, with a huge plastic germ-free bubble taped to her body, gave birth by Caesarean section.

title: General Cinema Forms Office of the Chairman
description: The General Cinema Corporation, the nation's largest movie theater operator and a leading independent soft drink bottler, has established an office of the chairman, consisting of four senior executives.

title: FISH FARMING BRINGS WATER AND FERTILIZER TO THE ARID WEST
description: IN a shallow river valley surrounded by extinct volcanoes, smoke trees and salt cedar, large tropical fish swim in irrigation canals that have taken on a dual purpose in this arid farming community in southwestern Arizona.

title: LARGER TRIUMPH, LARGER LOSS; American Beauty
description: John Keats wrote that ''beauty is truth, truth beauty - that is all ye know on earth, and all ye need to know.'' But is that all we need to know about Vanessa Williams, the new Miss America? For the black 20-year- old college student from New York to be chosen as the most beautiful woman in the country tells a new truth about social values in America.

title: Gates Learjet Deal
description: The Gates Learjet Corporation said it would hire some 2,200 new workers to build 80 two-engine model 35A jet aircraft for the Air Force under a series of contracts that could exceed $440 million. The Air Force also obtained an option for 20 additional planes, to be used by the Military Aircraft Command to replace an aging fleet of transport aircraft, officials said. Engines for the 35A aircraft will be made by the Garrett Corporation in Phoenix.

title: Court Reinstates Sears Indictment
description: A Federal grand jury indictment charging Sears, Roebuck & Company with Customs fraud in importing televisions from Japan was reinstated today by a Federal appeals court.

title: FEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CHAD EQUATION: FRANCE PLUS LIBYA EQUALS DIVISION
description: On a carpet in the sand at Kalait, an isolated outpost of the Chadian Army 500 miles northwest of the capital, a small group of soldiers was sitting around a campfire, nibbling on chunks of camel meat and talking about the war.

title: President Addresses Women
description: President Reagan today challenged critics to stop ''talking in generalities'' and examine his record of placing women in top Government posts.

title: PETROX INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes an expense item of $120,900 for costs related to the proposed merger of the company with the American Pacific Corp. c-Net income

title: Khomeini Issues Threat Clearly Aimed at Paris
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini said today that Iran would cut off oil supplies to any country that helped Iraq to block Iranian oil shipments.

title: EARTH SAID TO BE IN 'ICEHOUSE'
description: DESPITE the long hot summer, some scientists insist that the earth is now going through what they say, comparatively speaking, is an Icehouse Age.

title: CONGREGATION PRAYS TO KEEP A CHURCH
description: Members of the congregation regard it as an altogether unforgivable thing to be doing to one's flock: their pastor is selling the church.

title: BATTLE OVER CRUDE OIL FUTURES
description: For the first time since 1974, when gold futures were introduced, a New York futures exchange has beaten a Chicago exchange at trading the same new commodity contract. This year, in the first five months of competition, the New York Mercantile Exchange has leaped ahead of the Chicago Board of Trade to become the No. 1 trader in crude oil futures.

title: More Protection
description: In 1975, Chris Thompson of West Seattle High School suffered an injury in a football game that left him paralyzed. He brought suit against the school and won a judgment of $6.5 million in 1981. That judgment is still on appeal.

title: PANEL TO STUDY VIOLENCE IN FAMILY ANNOUNCED BY REAGAN AND SMITH
description: Attorney General William French Smith today announced the formation of a task force on family violence to study such problems as spouse and child abuse and mistreatment of the elderly.

title: Conrail Accords
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation announced that it had reached agreements on boxcar use with two more railroads, the Burlington Northern and the Bay Colony.

title: Case on Dairy Claims Is Sent Back to State
description: The State Department of Agriculture and Markets today was ordered to reconsider millions of dollars in payments it had planned to give dairy farmers in the wake of financial troubles at the Glen and Mohawk Milk Association of Fultonville.

title: MICRODYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Ethel Beane, Who Survived Titanic Sinking, Dead at 90
description: Ethel Beane, who survived the sinking of the liner Titanic in 1912, died over the weekend in a Rochester nursing home. She was 90 years old.

title: ...SABOTAGING RIGHTS
description: President Reagan's campaign to compromise the independence of the United States Civil Rights Commission is expected to reach a climax Thursday with a Senate vote on the confirmation of his nominees to replace the three remaining critics of Administration civil rights policies. If Mr. Reagan succeeds, only Jill Ruckelshaus, wife of William Ruckelshaus, the Environmental Protection Agency's Administrator, would remain of the six commissioners in place in 1980. If the President has his way, the commission will be dominated by commissioners who were appointed because they support the President's retrograde civil rights policies.

title: Chile to Buy British Ship
description: The Chilean Navy is negotiating to buy the British Royal Navy's 5,440-ton destroyer Antrim, the Defense Ministry said today.

title: DANCE: BAT-DOR TROUPE OF ISRAEL IN 3 PREMIERES
description: THE Bat-Dor Dance Company of Israel, which made its United States debut in 1979 at the Brooklyn Academy, has now returned for a two-week run, this time at the Joyce Theater in Manhattan.

title: D'Amato Backing Bid by O'Rourke
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato endorsed Andrew P. O'Rourke today for election to a full term as Westchester County Executive, calling him a man of ''integrity and character.''

title: OPEC Export Forecast
description: Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries expect their oil exports will total 22.1 million barrels a day in 1985, the same level as in 1980, Mohammed Memouni, head of OPEC's energy forecasting section, said today. He told an energy conference here that exports could rise to 24.3 million barrels a day in 1990. OPEC currently limits its members' output to 17.5 million barrels a day.

title: TEACHERS STRIKE 11 HIGH SCHOOLS IN ARCHDIOCESE
description: Lay teachers at 11 Roman Catholic high schools run by the Archdiocese of New York went on strike yesterday. A spokesman for the archdiocese, the Rev. Peter Finn, said classes for the 11,000 students were continuing as normally as possible.

title: Mancini Signs
description: After knocking out Orlando Romero, the top challenger to his World Boxing Association lightweight crown, last Thursday night, Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini signed yesterday oppose Bobby Chacon in late November or early December.

title: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 20, 1983
description: International

title: Comings and Goings
description: John Davidson, who retired as the Rangers' goalie during the summer after 10 N.H.L. seasons, will join Jim Gordon and Phil Esposito on the Madison Square Garden Network broadcast crew as a color analyst. Davidson will do all the Ranger home games on cable TV, and some away games on WOR-TV. . . . Jimmy Connors has withdrawn from the $265,000 event in San Francisco because of a painful bone spur in his right foot.

title: Article 177199 -- No Title
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation announced late yesterday that it had received a leveraged buyout offer from a group of investors headed by J. A. Frates of Tulsa, Okla. Its value is estimated at $324.9 million.

title: Awards for Fun and Profit
description: THE corporate giants are at it again, preparing to honor one another at a string of benefits that have become a painless and productive way to raise charity money while massaging powerful egos. Tonight Rand V. Araskog, chairman of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, becomes the humanitarian of the hour at the Retinitis Pigmentosa Foundation's blast at the newly refurbished Waldorf-Astoria.

title: Itel's New Look
description: The Itel Corporation has emerged from 32 months of reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws, a third of its former size. The new Itel will be devoted to leasing containers and boxcars instead of computers, its mainstay in 1978 when it had 7,000 employees and earned $21.5 million on revenues of $660.6 million.

title: PENTAGON'S REPORT DOUBTS VALUE OF COSTLY TANK DETECTION SYSTEM
description: A costly new system designed to enable NATO pilots to locate and destroy Soviet tanks at night and in bad weather is unreliable and vulnerable to countermeasures, according to a Pentagon report published today.

title: Kramer Lost For Season
description: Tommy Kramer, the Minnesota Viking quarterback who injured his right knee in Sunday's 19-16 overtime victory over Tampa Bay, had surgery today and will be out for the season. Kramer suffered a complete tear of the inside ligament of the right knee when he was tackled out of bounds by the cornerback Mike Washington.

title: MANOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
Wertmuller on Broadway
description: Thwarted in 1980 by a shortage of money from the American producer, Lina Wertmuller's play ''Love and Magic in Mama's Kitchen'' is finally coming to Broadway next spring. Yesterday Miss Wertmuller paused during auditions to talk about it - describing it as a sort of Italian ''Sweeney Todd'' about Leonarda Cianciulli, who boiled her victims and made soap of them.

title: EDUCATOR CALLS FOR REFORM, NOT PANIC
description: ''THE HIGH SCHOOL,'' the latest report on public education, does not sound a general alarm to man the life boats against the rising tide of mediocrity. By not (for once) declaring a national emergency, the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, which issued the report last week, takes a calculated risk: Will the public, used to hyperbole, respond to a report that points not to apocalypse but to opportunities for reform?

title: Glenmore Consolidation
description: The New York office of the Dallas-based Bloom Agency is benefiting by about $3 million in billings from a decision by Glenmore Distilleries Company to consolidate its advertising. That was not such good news for Garfield-Linn & Company, Chicago, which is the loser. The brands are Yellowstone Straight and Mellow Mash bourbon whiskies, Mr. Boston flavored brandies, Five Star brandies and flavored schnapps, Mardarin Napoleon liqueur, Desmond and Duff Scotch and Torre de Conte Asti Spumante.

title: POP VOCALIST: MARI WILSON
description: ONE rarely encounters pop satire as perfect as that practiced by Mari Wilson, the 26- year-old English singer who performed at the Ritz on Saturday with an 11-member troupe of musician-comedians called the Wilsations.

title: Northwest Energy
description: Ivan F. Boesky, the Wall Street arbitrager, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that companies he controlled had increased their stake in the Northwest Energy Company to more than 1.5 million shares, or 8.2 percent of the total. Northwest has agreed to a leveraged buyout by Allen & Company at $31 a share but has since received an offer of $39 a share from the Williams Companies. If Allen were to be outbid, it has the right to buy 3.34 million shares at $31, giving it a profit of $26.7 million.

title: Theory Is Advanced On Manipulated Jackpot
description: A gang of sophisticated cheaters breached two locked doors on a slot machine to gain access to a microprocessor board, setting up a record $1.7 million jackpot at Harrah's Casino in Lake Tahoe, the machine's manufacturer said today.

title: JEWEL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 13
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,200,000 from the previously announced sale of its Mass Feeding Corp. subsidiary.

title: THEATER: 2 SAM SHEPARD PIECES OPEN AT LA MAMA
description: Fans of the two full-bodied Sam Shepard plays in New York right now, ''True West'' and ''Fool for Love,'' may well be thrown by the two Shepard pieces that have arrived at La Mama. The pieces - fragments might be a better term - are titled ''Superstitions'' and ''The Sad Lament of Pecos Bill on the Eve of Killing His Wife.'' As performed by the Overtone Theater, a musical-theater performance-group from San Francisco, they have about as much to do with Mr. Shepard's major efforts as light beer has to do with Jack Daniels.

title: TAUBMAN FORMS COMPANY TO OPERATE SOTHEBY'S
description: Alfred Taubman, the Detroit financier, moved closer today to acquiring Sotheby Parke Bernet and announced the formation of a new company that would operate the fine arts and antiques auction house on both sides of the Atlantic.

title: RHODE ISLAND GOVERNOR DROPS RE-ELECTION BID
description: The announcement by Gov. J. Joseph Garrahy of Rhode Island that he will not seek re-election may be good news for both Democrats and Republicans in Rhode Island.

title: ENNIS BUSINESS FORMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June.

title: COWBOY BLITZ CHANGES A GAME
description: The Dallas Cowboys broke open Sunday's close game against the Giants when Dextor Clinkscale, the strong safety, intercepted a pass and returned it 68 yards for a touchdown in the fourth quarter.

title: Switch at Playboy
description: To replace Henry W. Marks, who hopped over to Rolling Stone to be associate publisher, Playboy magazine is bringing in Charles H. Stentiford, 43, who was a vice president of CBS Consumer Publications, serving as publisher of World Tennis and Audio magazine. Before joining those magazines he had served for nine years at Woman's Day, which is considerably different from Playboy.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 20, 1983
description: International

title: The Guns of Odessa
description: ''When guns are outlawed, only outlaws will have guns'' reads the gun lobbyists' bumper sticker, and they may have a point. Stolen guns are an important part of the criminal arsenal. But does that mean stricter controls on guns would have negligible effect on public safety?

title: Niland Sentenced
description: John Niland, the former Dallas Cowboy guard who pleaded guilty to two counts of possession of cocaine, was sentenced to 10 years of probation yesterday by a Texas state district court judge in Dallas. Explaining Judge Roland T. Scales 's decision, Mrs. Bobby Emory, the court's chief clerk, said: ''In this procedure, the judge accepted the defendant's guilty plea and then placed him on probation. If he violates the probation, Judge Scales would then be free to assess him any punishment.''

title: Murdock to Sell Shares
description: David H. Murdock, who had been expected to join the Detroit industrialists in acquiring Sotheby's, said in Los Angeles that he intended to tender his 763,000 shares, which is 6.8 percent of the stock, to Mr. Taubman. ''I feel there are currently enough investors in the purchase of Sotheby's,'' said the Los Angeles investor who was the top shareholder in Sotheby's until a year ago. Mr. Murdock's stock is worth $8 million and was purchased for about half that sum.

title: St. Kitts-Nevis Is Born As a Sovereign Nation
description: The world's newest nation celebrated its first day of independence today by receiving foreign dignitaries with bands, choirs and oratory.

title: BARCO OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for Qtr to July 2
GUEST SUPPLY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NO PLACE TO DIE: PROBLEM IN NURSING CARE
description: Her husband visits daily to brush her hair, her son to talk about the grandchild she has never met. They show her photographs and stroke her hands. They talk about the rosebush behind the house and how the neighbor's tomatoes these days are just ripe for picking.

title: SCIENTIFIC LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
No Headline
description: SCENES FROM PROVINCIAL LIFE and SCENES FROM METROPOLITAN LIFE. By William Cooper. 422 pages. Dutton. $17.95.

title: AID FOR GERMAN SHIPYARDS
description: Officials of four North German states today approved $22.4 million of financial aid for West Germany's ailing shipyards. They predicted that it would assure the yards of orders totaling $486 million over the next two years.

title: SYSTEMATICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
VALUE LINE INVESTMENT SURVEY reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The latest quarter results included capital gains of $928,000, or 9 cents a share. The year-ago figures represent the results of the Investment Information and Advisory publication and Investment Management activities of Arnold Bernhard & Co., which was transferred to the company as of Oct. 31, 1982, as part of a corporate reorganization.

title: POLICE BRUTALITY CHARGED AT FORUM
description: Presenting statistics and emotional personal accounts, dozens of people testified yesterday at a Congressional hearing in Harlem into allegations of police brutality against black and Hispanic New Yorkers.

title: MILK KILLS A PARASITE
description: AN intestinal parasite that frequently infects children is killed by a component of human milk, according to a study reported in the Sept. 23 issue of the journal Science. While the authors say human milk ''may play a protective role'' in infants exposed to the parasite, it is not known whether those raised on mother's milk have a lower incidence of such infections.

title: DOROTHY BERRY
description: Dorothy Berry, a retired brigadier in the Salvation Army who was an early leader in New York City in the rehabilitation of women who were drug addicts, died Sept. 10 at her home in Hebron, Ky. She was 82 years old.

title: COAST COMMUNITY COLLEGES FACE PROTEST ON RIGHTS
description: Charging that California's community colleges have become a ''two-year college ghetto,'' lawyers representing black and Hispanic students have petitioned the three public college and university systems to make it easier for minority students to transfer to four-year institutions.

title: German G.N.P. Rises
description: The Deutsche Bundesbank said today that the pace of West Germany's economic recovery doubled in the second quarter from first quarter and returned production to levels last seen in 1981. In its September report, the central bank said that seasonally and price-adjusted gross national product rose 1.5 percent in the second quarter from the preceding quarter, and was up 2 percent from the fourth quarter last year. It cited improved domestic demand, which increased manufacturing growth.

title: ; EHTICS COMPONENT FOR COMPUTER PROGRAM
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Michigan is selling $500 million of 6.15 percent notes due in about a year at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Citibank. Early yesterday, the notes were tentatively priced at 6 1/4 percent, but strong investor demand enabled underwriters to reduce the yield by a tenth of a percentage point.

title: RAYCOMM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss

title: A MADRID PLAN FOR AIDING RELIGIONS BACKFIRES
description: Acting on the theory that all religions should be treated equally, the Spanish Government is planning to end direct state subsidies to the dominant Roman Catholic Church. But the method it has chosen has raised the ire of Jews and Protestants.

title: ROHR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Unitary Tax Opposed
description: Britain today urged its partners in the European Economic Community to lobby President Reagan to change United States tax laws that could cost the 10 nations millions of dollars a year. A British Foreign Office minister, Malcolm Rifkind, told reporters the so-called unitary tax system could lead to double taxation. The system allows a state with a multinational company based within its borders to charge taxes on the company's worldwide profits, diplomats said.

title: DAN RATHER HEARD ON TV IN PROFANITY
description: A new daily television magazine program began its nationwide run yesterday with a report featuring a videotape of Dan Rather, anchor of the ''CBS Evening News,'' uttering a harsh four-letter profanity to the correspondent who prepared the report.

title: SOCAL PLANS TO PULL OUT OF EUROPE
description: The Standard Oil Company of California said yesterday that it was discussing the sale of all or part of its oil refining and marketing operations in Europe with Texaco Inc., among others. Socal said it expected a preliminary agreement this week.

title: Jets' Status Reviewed
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he had exchanged letters with Leon Hess, the owner of the Jets, over the weekend and yesterday regarding whether the team would play its games in New Jersey next year or sign a new lease for Shea Stadium.

title: BELLEVUE PSYCHIATRIC: TALES OF DESPAIR
description: THE 45-year-old man tried to hold back his tears as he sat in the Bellevue psychiatric emergency interview room. He was telling a doctor why he had suddenly started shouting in a Manhattan church earlier that day. The priest had called the police to take him away after he refused to leave.

title: HOLLY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Farming by the Slice
description: A new method of planting crops is being tested by the United States Department of Agriculture in the hope of helping protect the nation's farmlands against erosion, a problem considered to be the most serious currently facing American agriculture. Recent studies indicate that wind and rain annually strip four to eight tons of topsoil per acre from the country's croplands.

title: DIRTY WORK FIRST
description: To the Editor:

title: Searle Sweetener Expands Its Market
description: G. D. Searle & Company said yesterday that Pepsico Inc., the Dr Pepper Company and the Seven-Up Company had agreed to use Searle's protein-based, low-calorie sweetener aspartame in their diet soft drinks. A spokesman for Seven-Up, however, said that the company had ''no comment'' on the announcement.

title: Remembering Dayan
description: Moshe Dayan, the Israeli soldier and statesman, died two years ago, and yesterday some friends and admirers gathered at the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, on East 46th Street, to pay tribute to him.

title: DENIAL URGED ON OIL GEAR FOR SOVIET
description: An interagency advisory group on export policy, in an apparent reaction to the shooting down of a Korean airliner, has recommended that the Administration deny an export license sought by a Hughes Tool Company subsidiary to sell $40 million worth of oil exploration equipment to the Soviet Union.

title: AUGUST STARTS IN HOUSING UP
description: Construction of new homes rose to the highest level in four and a half years last month, defying a widely held assumption among economists and Reagan Administration officials that high interest rates had begun to slow the economy.

title: TROVE OF JUDAICA PRESERVED BY NAZIS TO TOUR U.S.
description: A landmark exhibit of centuries of Jewish artistic and historical objects, which were preserved by Nazi Germany to create a ''museum of an extinct race,'' is to appear in New York City next year as part of a nationwide tour, the Smithsonian Institution announced today.

title: REPORTED ON EUROPE FOR NEARLY 50 YEARS
description: Virginia Cowles, an American debutante who became a noted foreign correspondent and author, was killed last Saturday in an automobile accident in France. She was 68 years old.

title: Mexican Oil Exports
description: Mexico plans to hold down oil exports despite signs of improved demand and its edge over members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, which remain bound by quotas agreed to at a meeting last March, a senior Mexican industry official said today.

title: OFFICIALS DISCLOSE BALDWIN UNIT PLAN
description: The insurance commissioners of Arkansas and Indiana yesterday released the tentative details of their reorganization plan for the insurance subsidiaries of the Baldwin-United Corporation.

title: ROCK: RICK JAMES PERFORMS
description: Friday's Budweiser Superfest show at Madison Square Garden brought four hours of syncopated funk rhythms and heavy-breathing lyrics.

title: DEADLINE FOR CONSENSUS
description: The aftermath of the destroyed Korean airliner exploded the gathering pressure from ultraconservatives on President Reagan to veer harder right.

title: Polish-Americans Join Jews in Call Amity
description: Simon Wiesenthal, the director of the Jewish Documentation Center in Vienna, and two other prominent Jews, and three Polish-Americans have issued a statement calling for a reconciliation between Poles and Jews.

title: No Headline
description: Southeast Banking In a Buyout Plan

title: New Leg Problem Sidelines Rogers
description: For George Rogers, the New Orleans Saints' running back who set a National Football League rushing record for a rookie with 1,674 yards in 1981, the leg injury he suffered Sept. 11 against the Los Angeles Rams was exceptionally frustrating. He suffered strained ligaments in his right knee when he was tackled by Jack Youngblood.

title: EDITOR, HIS WIFE AND SON SLAIN
description: The bodies of the editorial page editor of The News-Sentinel, his wife and their 11-year-old son, victims of what was described as a ''brutal, sadistic slaughter,'' were found in their home here today after the editor failed to report to work. A 2-year-old daughter who spent more than 48 hours with the bodies was found alive.

title: D.F.S. Executive to Fill Kenyon & Eckhardt Job
description: Lawrence J. Flink, a 49-year-old executive vice president at Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, the package goods advertising powerhouse, is moving over to Kenyon & Eckhardt Advertising, where he will have the same rank but will fill a new job that puts him in charge of both the New York and Boston offices, as director of the eastern region.

title: Mailgram Contract Set for Revision
description: The Western Union Corporation said that its principal subsidiary, the Western Union Telegraph Company, and the United States Postal Service had agreed to terminate the existing contract for provision of Mailgram service, effective Sept. 1, 1987.

title: RAIDERS DEFEAT DOLPHINS
description: The Los Angeles Raiders improved upon two areas of domination tonight, as they defeated the defending American Conference champions, the Miami Dolphins, 27-14, in the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum.

title: MURDER OF WITNESS LINKED TO EFFORT TO BLOCK INQUIRY
description: A Bronx jury heard testimony yesterday that Nat Masselli, a witness in the Federal investigation of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan, was slain last year to prevent him and his father from cooperating with the inquiry.

title: Mobil Names Head Of Its Refining Unit
description: Paul J. Hoenmans, who joined the Mobil Oil Corporation as an engineer in Saskatchewan 29 years ago, has been named president of the marketing and refining division.

title: FARADAY LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss of $80,556 from discontinued operations.

title: Clare McLean Is Dead at 90; Widow of Ex-A.P. President
description: Clare McLean, widow of Robert McLean, former president of The Associated Press and former chairman of The Bulletin in Philadelphia and The Santa Barbara News- Press in California, died Sunday. She was 90 years old.

title: BRIDGE INSPECTOR GIVEN PROBATION
description: A state bridge inspector accused of forgery and altering his inspection notes after the collapse of the Mianus River bridge in Greenwich was placed on one year's probation today and ordered to perform 150 hours of community service.

title: SOVIET CITES ROLE OF U.S. SATELLITE
description: The Soviet press said today that the route of Korean Air Lines Flight 007 on Sept. 1 was ''strictly synchronized'' with passes of an American reconnaissance satellite.

title: GUIDRY IS BEATEN IN BID FOR NO. 20
description: Pitching for the first time since 1978 with a chance to reach the 20-victory plateau, Ron Guidry encountered two problems tonight: home runs and Bob Stanley.

title: CITY CENTER PICKS CHAIRMAN
description: Alton G. Marshall, chairman of the governing board of the City Center of Music and Drama, has resigned from that post and will be succeeded by Martin J. Oppenheimer, the former vice chairman.

title: NICARAGUANS FIGHT REBELS IN EAST
description: Government soldiers today battled rebels trying to seize three provinces in eastern Nicaragua, a military commander said.

title: Tom Meyer Resigns
description: The University of Illinois-Chicago basketball coach, Tom Meyer, who fended off a player revolt and attempted dismissal last spring, resigned yesterday. Lawyers representing Meyer and the university met to sign a settlement, reportedly giving Meyer $100,000 plus one year's salary of $35,000 in exchange for his dropping a $1 million damage suit against U.I.C. Meyer's senior assistant, Willie Little, was named acting head coach for 1983-84.

title: Man Fights a Mob To Rescue a Woman
description: An unarmed motorist driving home fought his way through an angry mob of up to 100 men and rescued a young woman who was attacked after a traffic accident, the police said today.

title: SOUTHERN HOSPITALITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Market Place; Connecticut's Phone Venture
description: THE reorganization of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, due next Jan. 1, has dominated Wall Street's interest in the vast communications industry this year. Meanwhile, a much smaller company that enjoys a connection with A.T.& T. has been kicking up its heels in the stock market.

title: Teen-Age and Minimum Wage Assailed
description: Congress should reject legislative proposals for a ''subminimum'' hourly wage for teen-agers because of a possible loss of adult jobs, a report commissioned by an arm of the United States Chamber of Commerce recommended today.

title: HEWLETT-PACKARD OFFERS A NEW OFFICE COMPUTER
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, seeking to enter the mainstream of the personal computer market, yesterday introduced a $4,000 desktop computer and a plan to get its machine on retailers' shelves.

title: Bridge: A Character in Wodehouse Gave a Tip That Still Helps
description: One of the many memorable characters of P. G. Wodehouse - Psmith - would sometimes warn his friends against confusing the improbable with the impossible. If West had heeded this maxim on the diagramed deal he would have been as silent as the initial letter in Psmith's name.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co.'s consumer products subsidiary announced that in conjunction with the Machine Tool Finance Corp. of Bridgewater, N.J., it had established a lease/purchase program for A.T.& T.'s videotex and teletext customers.

title: COOK UNITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 13
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $672,000 for the quarter and $1,244,000 for the 6 months and an extraordinary credit of $523,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: DOMINGO 'ALMOST' SURE TO OPEN MET
description: Placido Domingo said yesterday that although he had asked two months ago to be released from his role in the Metropolitan Opera's production of Berlioz's ''Les Troyens,'' opening the centennial season on Sept. 26, he is now ''almost convinced'' that he will do four of the six performances originally scheduled for him.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''If in the judicious determination of the members of the United Nations, they feel that they are not welcome and that they are not being treated with the hostly consideration that is their due, then the United States strongly encourages such member states seriously to consider removing themselves and this organization from the soil of the United States.

title: AN INDUSTRY FINDS GOLD IN GOLDFISH, AS NEW PET FOOD
description: They were cultivated as a science by China's Sung Dynasty. Louis XV gave them to his mistress as a love token. P. T. Barnum promoted them as freaks. And today there are more of them in the United States than there are people.

title: AUDIENCE IN ARMORY IS ORDERLY
description: Sadie Winslow, a member of Community Board 9 in Harlem, said yesterday that she had attended the Congressional hearing on July 18 into allegations of police brutality in the city. She had found it ''well conducted'' and even poignant in spite of the cramped quarters and disruptions at the Harlem State Office Building.

title: LITTLE PRINCE PRODUCTIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TO HELP BUSINESS ADHERE TO IMMIGRATION LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: LIBERTY MAY GAIN MORE FROM WIND
description: While Liberty's crew relaxed and its skipper, Dennis Conner, played golf during today's day off from racing, the crew of the challenger, Australia II, spent a few hours testing sails before resting up for Tuesday's fourth race in this 25th America's Cup series.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 20, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: STUDY TIES COCAINE USE TO THEFT
description: A national survey among cocaine users has confirmed that cocaine is addictive, a health official says.

title: BEELINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
description: b-Net loss after extraordinary losses of $237,000 for the quarter and $601,000 for the year.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SIGHT AND SOUND

title: COSTA RICA COOLS TO NICARAGUA REBELS
description: Apparently fearful of being drawn into the Nicaraguan conflict, the Costa Rican Government has moved against anti-Sandinistas who have been preparing armed attacks on Nicaragua from its territory.

title: SMITHSONIAN TO KEEP MEETINGS PRIVATE
description: The regents of the federally owned Smithsonian Institution, a collection of a dozen museums here, today rejected a request that their meetings be opened to the public and the press.

title: EVERYBODY'S BUDDY
description: In the hours after the dessert dishes had been cleared away by the waiters at the football dinner in the midtown hotel ballroom, too many speeches had been too long. Now, his head barely above the lectern, Buddy Young identified himself as representing the N.A.A.L.P., which woke up his half-dozing listeners who confused the initials with those of another organization.

title: MAKER OF AIRLINE'S LIFE RAFTS TRIES TO FIND EXTENT OF LEAKS
description: The manufacturer of emergency life rafts used on some Boeing 747 airplanes said yesterday it was trying to determine if the excessive rate of leakage found by United Air Lines was a problem with all of its life rafts or just the ones sold to United.

title: 4 on Ditched Plane Still Being Sought
description: The Nassau County police resumed searching this morning for a Long Island man, his wife and two daughters who are feared dead in a plane crash in the Atlantic Ocean off Jones Beach.

title: AGRICULTURE DEPARTMENT TO INVESTIGATE A MEAT PLANT IN DENVER
description: The Agriculture Department said today that it would investigate charges of rats, filth and ''stomach-turning'' conditions at a meat-packing plant that sells beef for school lunch programs.

title: L.I. Seeks Power From Canada
description: The Long Island Association, a group of 2,500 Long Island businesses and education and labor groups called on the Public Service Commission today to approve construction of a 200-mile- long power line that would bring cheaper Canadian hydroelectric power to the Island.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: IT was no week to slouch. There were no fewer than a dozen dinners, fashion shows, openings and outings, including a dinner for Kenzo at Le Zinc; a dinner for Luciano Soprani, who showed his Basile collection at Barneys, and Alice Mason's dinner for Francesca and Peter Tufo, where Barbara Walters grew impatient when the conversation and the service ran dry. Finally, she turned to her dinner partners and said, ''Look, you're both my friends, but do we have to talk to each other all night?''

title: Ogilvy & Mather Forms Public Relations Unit
description: Ogilvy & Mather, a major worldwide advertising agency that began to move aggressively into the public relations field in 1980 when O. & M. Public Relations was set up under Yustin Wallrapp, has formed a new unit to encompass all of its activities in that area and brought in a new man to run it.

title: ENCHANTED VILLAGE reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Comparable year-ago figures were unavailable as the company made its initial public offering last month.

title: Signal Stock Sale
description: The Signal Companies said it had agreed to sell all of its Diamond Shamrock Inc. common stock in a public offering that will result in proceeds of $164 million.

title: MOREHOUSE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in August.

title: RATES FALL
description: The Federal Reserve supplied funds to the banking system for the third consecutive trading day yesterday and touched off an intense debate in the credit markets about whether the central bank is easing monetary policy and thereby encouraging lower short- term interest rates.

title: No Headline
description: In an attempt to mollify trade unions, the French Government announced today that it had raised to 6 percent from 5 percent its goal for average wage increases next year.

title: A Gunman in Harlem Kills 2 and Wounds 3
description: A man who invaded an apartment in the Harlem building where he lived shot five people yesterday, killing two of them and critically wounding a third, the police said.

title: LOVELADY, IKE, INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes a full cost pool writedown of $2,730,000. c-Net income. The year-ago results have been adjusted for a change to the full cost method of accounting from the successful effort method of accounting in October 1982.

title: Greyhound Loses Bid For Fare Rise in State
description: The State Department of Transportation has rejected a Greyhound Bus Lines request to raise fares by 40 percent on routes within New York State.

title: MARINES IN LEBANON-MISSION IMPOSSIBLE
description: As an Israeli journalist, I have little to add to the political debate about the proper limits to the United States' role in the Middle East. What I do know from my country's bitter experience in Lebanon is that the military task that the United States has taken on is almost certainly an impossible one. Neither the marines nor the American aircraft carriers standing off the coast can hope to solve the military problem in Lebanon.

title: ACCORD ON WILLIAMS BID
description: The Williams Companies will announce an agreement today with Allen & Company Inc. that will clear the way for Williams to go ahead with an offer to buy the Northwest Energy Company, Wall Street sources said last night.

title: Reagan Plans to See The Press Next Week
description: President Reagan is preparing to hold a nationally broadcast news conference - his first in two months - in the middle of next week, White House aides said today.

title: AZTEC MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

title: V.A. Modifies Revival Policy
description: A new rule allows Veterans Administration doctors, at the request of a dying patient, to bar resuscitation or the use of extraordinary life-saving methods, an agency official said today.

title: MORE CHURCHES JOIN IN OFFERING SANCTUARY FOR LATIN REFUGEES
description: Since churches began declaring themselves sanctuaries for Central American refugees more than a year ago, an estimated 20,000 to 30,000 church members have taken the risk of defying United States immigration laws, according to leaders of the sanctuary movement.

title: PREMIER INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
ECONOMISTS EXPECT SMALLER 1983 DEFICIT
description: This year's Federal budget deficit will fall somewhat below the $210 billion level most Government and private economists had been expecting only two months ago, the economists say.

title: STENERUD STAYS ON AT 40
description: It was the second week of August in the middle of training camp at Green Bay, Wis., a time that makes some veterans feel much older than they are and others feel much younger.

title: 3 DIE AS CEMEMT TRUCK CRUSHES CAR
description: A 23-year-old Connecticut woman and her two children were killed yesterday afternoon when a cement truck veered across 10th Avenue in midtown and crashed into their parked car. The truck driver, after being given a sobriety test, was charged with three counts of second-degree murder and driving while impaired.

title: Florida Bank Bid
description: Directors of Florida Coast Banks Inc. today rejected an unsolicited takeover bid from Barnett Banks of Florida Inc. Barnett, the state's largest bank holding company with assets of $8.4 billion, Friday offered $22 a share in cash and stock for Florida Coast, which has its headquarters in Pompano Beach and reports assets of $562 million. Florida Coast said its board found Barnett's offer ''inadequate'' and ''not in the best interest of shareholders and customers.'' But Florida Coast directors ''authorized management to explore all appropriate alternatives.''

title: Expos 10, Cardinals 1
description: Bill Gullickson pitched a six-hitter and drove in two runs, including the first run of the game with his first career home run to send Montreal on to victory.

title: Orphan Gets $1 Million In Jewels He Found
description: With the signing of court documents today, a 16-year-old orphan here became the owner of more than $1 million in jewels he had found lying by railroad tracks near his home.

title: DOW RISES BY 15.25, TO NEW HIGH
description: Increasing hopes of lower interest rates sent the Dow Jones industrial average up 15.25 points yesterday, to a closing record of 1,249.19, in accelerated trading.

title: LOBBYING INTENSIFIES ON F.C.C.'S TV RULES
description: Hollywood producers and their adversaries, the three major commercial television networks, have intensified their lobbying in Washington to influence the Federal Communications Commission as it considers a dramatic change in its 13-year-old rules barring the networks from controlling the distribution of reruns of prime-time television shows and from making a profit on such sales.

title: U.S. HALTS SCHOOL-BOUND BEEF
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block ordered an immediate halt today to all distribution of ground beef processed by two companies for the school lunch program.

title: FORD MIGHT SUE TO BAR TOYOTA-G.M. VENTURE
description: A top official of the Ford Motor Company said today that Ford might join with other domestic auto companies in filing an antitrust suit to block the proposed joint venture between the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation.

title: 4 OFFICERS DISMISSED FROM FORCE FOR BEHAVIOR IN MARIJUANA CASE
description: Four veteran New York City police officers were dismissed yesterday after a departmental trial that found they had improperly confiscated marijuana and money from a Harlem apartment and ''wrongfully'' failed to arrest the occupants of the apartment.

title: EX-CELL-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,100,000, or 22 cents a share, from the sale of property and $2,700,000, or 19 cents a share, from the liquidation of LIFO inventories. c-Includes a gain of $6,000,000, or 40 cents a share, from the liquidation of LIFO inventories and a charge of $3,700,000 for costs of a plant closing and the consolidation of some manufacturing units, and for a reduction in the carrying value of related assets. LIFO inventory liquidation increased net income by $900,000, or 6 cents a share, in the latest quarter and by $1,500,000, or 10 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter.

title: Ames's New President Is Target Stores Official
description: Ames Department Stores Inc. has named an executive of the Target Stores division of the Dayton-Hudson Corporation as its new president and chief operating officer.

title: EATING SPICY FOOD: WHAT ARE THE EFFECTS?
description: THOUGH much is suspected, relatively little is known about the health effects of peppery foods. In general, hot, spicy foods are stimulants. They stimulate the circulation and raise body temperature. If you are living in a hot climate, the increase in body temperature can make you feel cooler by diminishing the difference between you and the surrounding air and by inducing sweating, which cools the body when the perspiration evaporates.

title: FILM: 'EDUCATING RITA,' SCHOOL DAYS
description: THE title character in ''Educating Rita'' is a housewife who yearns so mightily for knowledge that she embarks on a tutorial program, soon becoming the favored protege of a boozy English professor.

title: BALLET: BEJART OFFERS 'EROS THANATOS'
description: MAURICE BEJART'S Ballet of the Twentieth Century from Brussels opened a three-week run at the City Center last night with a recyling of his past choreography that, curiously, seemed to improve on the original in most cases.

title: Minority Caucus Alters Tactics for Ending Runoff
description: A shift in tactics to abolish the runoff primary, which most politicians see as a move against Mayor Koch, is planned by the Legislature's Black and Puerto Rican Caucus.

title: Kaiser Rejects Tulsa Group's Bid
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said yesterday that its board had rejected the proposal made Monday by an investor group led by J. A. Frates of Tulsa, Okla., to acquire the company.

title: Kissinger on Jet Downing
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that the shooting down of a Korean passenger jet by the Soviet Union ''while reprehensible, is something one can understand as a mixup.'' He said at a news conference that the shooting could have occurred ''through a collection of misunderstandings, accidents, bureaucratic mixups in which the various commanders decided they would never be able to explain to Moscow why they let a plane that had wandered over their territory go.''

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: S.E.C. Recognizes A Rating Firm
description: McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei Inc., a firm specializing in fixed income research, announced that it had obtained clearance from the Securities and Exchange Commission and is now a ''nationally recognized statistical rating organization.''

title: MAYOR MAY GO TO 2D HEARING ON POLICE ISSUE
description: Mayor Koch responded with a maybe yesterday to an invitation to testify at another hearing by the House Subcommittee on Criminal Justice into charges of police brutality against black and Hispanic New Yorkers.

title: James Baldwin Has Attack
description: James Baldwin, whose novels of racial stuggle brought him literary acclaim in the 1960's, was in satisfactory condition today after apparently suffering a heart attack. Mr. Baldwin became ill on his way to teach his first writing class at Hampshire College, officials at the school said. A spokesman said, ''It was a mild heart attack.''

title: CONAGRA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
A PILOT'S VIEW ON ENTERING SOVIET AIRSPACE
description: To the Editor:

title: FRENCH PLAN TO REVAMP THE ELECTRONICS SECTOR
description: The French Government today announced a major restructuring of the country's recently nationalized electronics and telecommunications industry in an effort to stem heavy losses, increase exports and keep France in the forefront of modern technology.

title: DEPTHS OF FLATTERY
description: England still has a long way to go in its effort to achieve satisfactory Americanization. True, the tea bag is now triumphant everywhere. Thirty years ago, it was sneered at everywhere from Penzance to Blackpool as a barbaric American absurdity. Londoners who had been to America and actually seen tea bags giggled when recounting the spectacle.

title: FILM: 'CROSS CREEK,' A WRITER'S LIFE
description: THE rural life imagined by Martin Ritt, in films like ''Norma Rae'' and ''Conrack'' and ''Sounder'' and now ''Cross Creek,'' doesn't have much to do with rural life as anyone else knows it. But it has its own sort of power and integrity, Hollywood-style. In their simple log cabins decorated with carefully selected antiques, living in remote swamps that somehow produce florist-caliber house plants, Mr. Ritt's characters live out bucolic fantasies that might, in the hands of any less dedicated director, seem pure hokum. Somehow, Mr. Ritt manages to use this very artificiality in the service of an optimism that is very much his own.

title: 7 Charged in Heat Deaths Of 4 Chicago Patients
description: The deaths of four elderly patients in a July heat wave has led to involuntary manslaughter indictments against seven people involved in operating a nursing home.

title: STANLEY G. FALK
description: Stanley G. Falk, former senior partner of the Buffalo law firm of Falk & Siemer, died Saturday at Buffalo General Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Buffalo.

title: EX-LEGAL AID OFFICIALS ACCUSED OF FUND ABUSE
description: Officials of the Federal Legal Services Corporation and its local affiliates used Federal funds in violation of legal restrictions in early 1981 in rallying political opposition to President Reagan's legislative program, the General Accounting Office concluded this week.

title: AMERICA'S CENSORS- THE LEFT
description: This year, the 50th anniversary of Nazi book- burning in Berlin, is a good time to re-examine censorship and to ask, Who are the real censors in America?

title: FEDERAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Philadelphia Man Pleads Guilty in Testa Slaying
description: A South Philadelphia man pleaded guilty today to first-degree death of reputed organized crime leader, Philip Testa.

title: 3 CENTER FIELDERS
description: ''Listen to this,'' Marvell Wynne said, cocking his head toward the multilingual cacophony of the Pittsburgh Pirate clubhouse. ''Listen to these guys.'' The sounds yesterday morning included Dave Parker's grousing, ''Hey, man, lend me five dollars''; the splat of playing cards smacked down, and assorted snarls, threats and insults muttered in varying dialects of Spanish and English.

title: Transfer Problem
description: It was one of those cellar-to-contender trades, in which the lagging Cleveland Indians sent Len Barker to the Atlanta Braves on Aug. 28 in exchange for three players ''to be named later.'' That way, the Braves got some immediate pitching help in their race with the Los Angeles Dodgers for the division title, but were not required to give up any players until after the season.

title: MONTEFUSCO, GOSSAGE STOP RED SOX, 3-2
description: John Montefusco, the man the Yankees belatedly found to be their right-handed starting pitcher, made another pitch for a free agent contract from George Steinbrenner tonight. Rich Gossage, who is expected to decline such a contract, helped make Montefusco's latest pitch successful.

title: BIG BOARD'S JUMP INTO OPTIONS
description: Tonight the New York Stock Exchange is throwing a gala coming out party, and it is the talk of Wall Street.

title: U.S. BATTLESHIP STEAMS TO JOIN FLEET OFF BEIRUT
description: The battleship New Jersey entered the Mediterranean yesterday on its way to join the carrier Eisenhower and other United States ships off Lebanon, Defense Department sources reported.

title: UMET PROPERTIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After gains on sale of real estate of $765,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $801,000, or 9 cents a share, for the 9 months and tax credits of $989,000, or 11 cents a share, and $1,554,000, or 18 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-After tax credits of $213,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,574,000, or 18 cents a share, for the 9 months. d-After gain on sale of real estate of $670,000, or 8 cents a share.

title: CONGRESS AND REAGAN BACK COMPROMISE ON WAR POWERS KEEPING MARINES IN LEBANON
description: Congressional leaders from both parties and President Reagan agreed today on a compromise resolution that would authorize the continued deployment of American marines in Lebanon for an additional 18 months under the War Powers Resolution.

title: POLITICAL AIDES URGE REAGAN TO BACK SPACE STATION
description: President Reagan is reported to be under pressure from his political strategists to endorse a major new space endeavor, the orbiting space station, as a tactical move against Senator John Glenn, the former astronaut who could be Mr. Reagan's Democratic opponent in the next election.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Monday about Jews in Egypt gave an incorrect birthplace for the Biblical prophet Jeremiah. According to citations from the Old Testament he was born in a village near Jerusalem.

title: DOMINGO SINGS IN 'TROYENS' REHEARSAL
description: Placido Domingo took part yesterday in a dress rehearsal of Berlioz's ''Troyens'' and is planning to sing in the Metropolitan Opera performance of the production, which will open the Met's centennial season on Monday night.

title: LLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Family Interest
description: Bob Herb, the coach of the Oakmont (Va.) High School football team, usually has two astute football observers in the stands at his team's games.

title: Advertising; S.I.'s Big Olympics Preview
description: WHEN Sports Illustrated celebrates its 30th anniversary next year, its publisher should be Robert L. Miller, at 34 years old the 10th and youngest the magazine has had.

title: GUIDE TO CITY'S WINE COURSES
description: NEARLY 40 wine courses are being offered at 10 schools in New York this year, ranging from the most basic to the most advanced available in America outside the universities.

title: WHY BANK INTEREST CONTINUES TO BE HIGH
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFING
description: Central America Bound

title: CONSUL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $65,000.

title: 11 Accused of Trying To Topple Polish Rulers
description: Eleven dissidents, including seven Solidarity members, have been charged with trying to overthrow the Communist system, the Government said today. Four of the cases could be punished by hanging.

title: T.W.A. Executive Gets Braniff Airways Post
description: Braniff Airways Inc. named William D. Slattery president and chief operating officer, and he said the new airline will be operating by March 1.

title: 'GARAGE SALE' OF EMBEZZLER'S GOODS
description: A grand piano, a log splitter, designer clothes and more than 500 other items - most of them bought by a Federal employee who embezzled over $558,000 from the Government - are available at a Justice Department ''garage sale.''

title: BOOK ON ISRAEL DISCONTINUED AFTER DISPUTE
description: The State University of New York Press has discontinued a textbook on the Middle East, and a pro-Arab group is taking the credit.

title: U.S. Fellowships Are Planned For Third-World Journalists
description: A program to bring young journalists from third-world countries to the United States for five months of practical experience with news organizations in this country was announced yesterday by the Alfred Friendly Foundation.

title: ROSWELL MILLER JR.
description: Roswell Miller Jr., a retired civil engineer and real-estate executive, died Monday at the Sharon (Conn.) Hospital.

title: IN THE DRUSE HILLS, A BURST OF ANGER IS DIRECTED AT U.S.
description: Automatic rifles were piled in an untidy stack in a corner of the Druse militia command post here today as three young men huddled over a radio, directing efforts to capture the nearby town of Suk al Gharb from Lebanese Army soldiers. They were also talking about what it was like to be fired at by the United States Navy.

title: SCOUTING;O'Brien's Future
description: Will Larry O'Brien, who is 66 years old, remain as the commissioner of the National Basketball Association at the expiration of his contract on Feb. 1?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In my district, there is not a sense we should be involved there.

title: U.S. SAID TO WEIGH ARMS CONCESSIONS
description: President Reagan has told allied leaders that the United States is prepared to be more flexible in seeking an accord with the Soviet Union on limiting medium-range missiles despite the rift over the shooting down of the South Korean airliner, American officials said today.

title: AGENCY GETS PLAN TO SCRAP 116 PROPOSED RULES PROTECTING WORKERS
description: The Labor Department's Occupational Safety and Health Administration has before it a staff memorandum proposing to revoke 116 rules suggested by previous Administrations to protect workers from toxic substances, agency and Congressional sources disclosed today.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS, SEIZING POLITICAL INITIATIVE, PRESS FOR $3.5 BILLION JOB BILL
description: Democrats, seizing the initiative on a political issue that may figure prominently in next year's elections, are pushing a $3.5 billion jobs bill through the House of Representatives.

title: Broad Shifts Made At Hanover Bank
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company announced a series of senior management changes yesterday, including the naming of two new vice chairmen.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FATAL VISION. By Joe McGinniss. 663 pages. Putnam. $17.95.

title: PETROLEUM HELICOPTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Caracas Asks Debt Delay
description: Finance Minister Arturo Sosa said yesterday that Venezuela was seeking a third moratorium on repayments of capital on its foreign debt of $35 billion. Venezuela has asked for two moratoriums of 90 days each from its 400 international creditor banks.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE 57th Street crosstown bus rolled westward carrying a dozen passengers, all but one of them obviously New Yorkers. The exception was Steve Kavalgian, who is new to the city and does not yet know our ways. Otherwise he would have done what everyone else did when sounds of chirping were heard from the back of bus - which is to say, nothing. Instead Mr. Kavalgian exhibited bad form by turning and staring and saying to a friend in the next seat, ''There's a bird on this bus.''

title: TIGERS ROUT ORIOLES
description: The Tigers scored 11 runs in the first inning tonight, getting 10 consecutive hits to tie a major league record, and went on to rout the Baltimore Orioles, 14-1, in a game called by rain after five innings.

title: AMERICAN SPORTS ADVISORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SIX LATERALS CREATE TIME, IF NOT YARDS
description: On the final play of Sunday's game between the Green Bay Packers and the Los Angeles Rams, both sides had in mind the conclusion of last season's college contest between California and Stanford. That was the game in which California scored the winning touchdown through a series of lateral passes on a kickoff return after time had run out.

title: Tose Keeps Eagles
description: Leonard Tose, owner of the Philadelphia Eagles, has paid $1.75 million as part of a settlement that enables him to retain ownership of the club and avoid litigation over a $42 million sale.

title: Emmett Dedmon, 65; Led 2 Chicago Papers
description: Emmett Dedmon, former vice president and editorial director of The Chicago Sun-Times and The Chicago Daily News, died of cancer Sunday at the University of Chicago Hospitals. He was 65 years old.

title: 2 Rangers in Fight
description: It was a victory flight home after the Texas Rangers beat the California Angels on Sunday, but not all the Rangers were celebrating. A fistfight broke out between Mickey Rivers and Mike Richardt. Manager Doug Rader quickly broke up the fracas, a club spokesman said.

title: Coleco Delays Adam Shipments
description: Coleco Industries said that it will not begin shipments of its Adam home computer until mid-October because of the need to do further testing.

title: Income Up Only 0.2% In August
description: Americans' personal income rose a modest two-tenths of 1 percent last month as the telephone workers' strike limited wage gains and damage from Hurricane Alicia cut rental income in Texas, the Government said today.

title: PARK ELECTROCHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Salvator Cufari Dead at 82; Long a Reputed Crime Chief
description: Salvatore Cufari, a reputed organized crime boss who got his start running liquor in Prohibition and later gave thousands of dollars to orphanages and a convent, died Saturday after a long illness.

title: PENTAGON FANTASIES
description: As the House proved last week with the passage of a new $187.5 billion defense authorization bill, military realities rarely have much to do with deliberations over the defense budget. The Pentagon and its allies prefer to focus the debate on what they divine as Soviet intentions rather than the Kremlin's actual capabilities.

title: Salomon Filing
description: Salomon Brothers Mortgage Securities Inc. said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a $500 million offering of bonds collateralized by mortgage passthrough certificates of the Government National Mortgage Association. Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. expects to market a similar issue of G.N.M.A.-collateralized bonds totaling $500 million in the near future.

title: SOVIET IS SAID TO HAMPER SEARCH
description: The Defense Department's chief spokesman said today that American ships had heard signals from one of the two flight recorders on the Korean airliner shot down in the Sea of Japan but had been unable so far to recover them.

title: WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
COASTAL INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
State Urges Speed In Westway Study
description: New York State has called on the Army Corps of Engineers to expedite its study of the effects that the Westway project would have on fish in the Hudson River.

title: Feldstein Rate View
description: President Reagan's chief economic adviser, Martin S. Feldstein, said today that he expected no significant change in interest-rate levels in coming months, a view somewhat at odds with that of Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, who has been arguing that they would move downward for at least the rest of 1983. ''I don't see any reason to expect any major movement,'' Mr. Feldstein told the Mortgage Bankers Association of America.

title: NAHAMA & WEAGANT ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
MARCOS DECLARES HE WON'T STEP ASIDE
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he had no intention of resigning despite the suspicions aroused by the assassination of his major political opponent.

title: Needham, Harper Wins Ramada Hotel Account
description: Needham, Harper & Steers, Chicago, has emerged triumphant in the struggle for the advertising account of the Ramada Hotel Group, which spent $7 million last year.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DIAMOND CORNER

title: Where to Put the Trough?
description: They huffed and they puffed and they put the trough down in front of City Hall. But that's not where it was supposed to go.

title: NEW TROUBLE-SHOOTER FOR LEBANON: REGINALD BARTHOLOMEW
description: As a student at Dartmouth College in the late 1950's, Reginald Bartholomew starred on stage in both Greek tragedies and high comedies. Friends say that this kind of versatility might well stand him in good stead as President Reagan's newly designated ambassador to Lebanon. Mr. Bartholomew, who was nominated to the post today, has had difficult assignments before. In 1980, he negotiated the agreement for an American military base in Somalia. Just recently, he negotiated an agreement to keep American military bases in Greece.

title: Honduran Army Kills An American Priest
description: A Roman Catholic priest from St. Louis, Mo., and a leftist guerrilla leader were killed during an operation by Honduran Government forces against rebels in the eastern highlands, an army spokesman said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption Friday in the Metropolitan Report incorrectly identified one New York assemblyman in a group of legislators. He was Kemp Hannon.

title: German Yard Gets QE2 Job
description: The Cunard Steam-Ship Company drew harsh protests today for its announcement that its flagship, the Queen Elizabeth 2, will go to a West German shipyard for its annual refitting this fall.

title: FOR GLENN, 'THE RIGHT STUFF' SEEMS TO BE RIGHT
description: Senator John Glenn, like almost everyone else involved in the Democratic Presidential race, has been wondering what impact the new movie ''The Right Stuff'' might have on his campaign.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN KNIGHT IS BACK IN FRAY
description: In the eyes of his admirers in the white electorate, Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha was a dauntless paladin who swashbuckled out into a hostile world to do rhetorical battle with anyone who sullied his country's name.

title:
Real Estate;
The Offices In Seaport District
description: DESPITE rain-tight roofs, leveled floors, shiny elevators and easily opened double-hung windows, there can be no doubt that the 35,000 square feet of office space now being leased in the South Street Seaport is in former warehouses erected in the first half of the 19th century.

title: REAGAN SAYS JET'S DOWNING VINDICATES POLICY
description: President Reagan, criticizing past American leaders for ''lectures on our inordinate fear of Communism,'' today portrayed the Soviet Union's destruction of a South Korean passenger jetliner as a sobering argument for the MX missile and other military programs.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATION OF BOSTON MOB YIELDS INDICTMENTS AGAINST 7 MEN
description: A Federal grand jury returned indictments today against seven men in the climax of a three-year investigation of organized crime by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: ECKERD, JACK, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
LA QUINTA MOTOR INNS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes gains from the sale of motor inns of $1,809,000 for the latest quarter and $1,236,000 for the year- ago quarter.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: Retirees Putting On the Gloves Again
description: It must be the Scott Frank syndrome. The New Jersey club fighter gets a $350,000 title shot against Larry Holmes, and heavyweights come out of retirement in search of one more big payday. First it was 38-year-old Jerry Quarry. Now 33-year-old Duane Bobick is considering ending a four-year retirement.

title: BRIEFS
description: Commodore Corp. announced that it had terminated discussions about the acquisition of All American of Ashburn Inc., a closely held mobile home maker that filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code last month.

title: SAME RIFLE WAS USED IN SNIPINGS UPTOWN AND IN BRONX, POLICE SAY
description: Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire said yesterday that the same weapon that was used to kill a woman and wound a Yeshiva University High School student Sunday was used in several attacks near the school last June.

title: FRESHMEN INELIGIBILITY IS URGED
description: A select committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association recommended major changes today, including making freshmen ineligible for football and basketball, and requiring schools to issue yearly ''report cards'' on how their athletes perform in the classroom.

title: Ed McGah, 84, Helped Found Raiders' Pro Football Team
description: Ed McGah, a founder of the Los Angeles Raiders of the National Football league and one of its two managing general partners, died late Saturday night in Cedars of Sinai Medical Center after a long illness. He was 84 years old.

title: A FABLE OF OUR TIME
description: Once upon a time there were two clumsy giants who had the power to destroy one another and blow up the world, but were just canny enough to know that this wasn't a very good idea.

title: AT HUB OF PLANE SEARCH, TOWN YEARNS FOR PEACE
description: Having drawn an unusual amount of attention because of Soviet and American search operations in nearby international waters, Wakkanai wishes everyone would go away. It wants to get back to normal.

title: MANNING TRADED TO VIKINGS
description: The Minnesota Vikings, seeking immediate help after a season-ending injury to the quarterback Tommy Kramer, obtained the quarterback Archie Manning and the tight end Dave Casper from the Houston Oilers today for two 1984 draft choices.

title: The Food at 59th and Lex
description: The food halls at Bloomingdale's have taken a new name and a new look; they are sleeker, more organized and better stocked. The store has introduced 240 private-label products under the name Le Gourmet, which have been put on the shelves just in time for the store's salute to France.

title: PNEUMO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Crown for a Castle
description: ''The finest castle of its class in New York City,'' Henry J. Stern, the Parks Commissioner, called it yesterday, when the restored Belvedere Castle won an award from the Landmarks Conservancy.

title: TEXT OF PROPOSED RESOLUTION FOR APPLYING THE WAR POWERS ACT TO LEBANON
description: Following is the text of the proposed joint resolution approved today by the White House and Congressional leaders on applying the War Powers Act to the presence of the Marines in Lebanon: Joint Resolution

title: OIL SANDS PROJECT WINS CONCESSIONS
description: Imperial Oil Ltd. won new incentives today to restart its oil sands project in Cold Lake, Alberta.

title: Texas Instruments Sales
description: Texas Instruments Inc. failed to meet sales goals for home computers this summer, and its chairman warned that without a substantial improvement the company faced ''significant'' losses on the year. Mark Shepherd Jr., in a speech at a San Francisco investment conference, said Texas Instruments' home computer estimated sales were ''below plan levels'' in July and August.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: F.D.A. IS REASSESSING 'SUGAR-FREE' LABELING
description: Gums and candies called ''sugar-free'' or ''sugarless'' by their producers may lose the right to call themselves by those terms. The Food and Drug Administration is reassessing its policy of permitting products containing the sugar substitutes sorbitol, mannitol and xylitol to label themselves in that manner.

title: SCOUTING;84-13 Victory Is Embarrassing
description: Tom Osborne, the coach of the No. 1-rated college football team, the University of Nebraska, was slightly embarrassed about his Cornhuskers' 84-13 pounding of the Minnesota Gophers last Saturday in Minneapolis.

title: BURT LEE
description: Burt Lee, retired president of the Paper Novelty Manufacturing Company of New York City and Stamford, Conn., died of cancer Monday at White Plains Hospital. He was 67 years old and a former resident of White Plains.

title: Brett's Backache
description: George Brett, the Kansas City Royals' third baseman, will undergo a bone scan today to determine the extent of a spinal defect that has kept him out of the lineup with back pains. According to the club's trainer, Mickey Cobb, X-rays taken Monday by the team's physician, Dr. Paul Meyer, found an abnormal space between two vertebrae, apparently a congenital defect. Cobb said the problem should not keep him from playing.

title: BOOK FAIR BOYCOTT HURTS THE WRONG PEOPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Swedish Acquisition
description: Axel Johnson Ore and Metals AB, a unit of the family-held Axel Johnson Group of shipping, trading and construction companies, said today that it had acquired the trading company GGI Metal and Chemicals G.m.b.H. of West Germany. The Axel Johnson Group said GGI Metals and Chemicals would be renamed Axel Johnson Ore and Metals G.m.b.H. The acquisition price was not disclosed. The West German company is an international trader in ores and metals, specializing in ferroalloys for the European market.

title: 2 U.S. WARSHIPS AGAIN BOMBARD ARTILLERY BATTERIES OUTSIDE BEIRUT
description: For a second day, two American warships bombarded anti-Government artillery and missile batteries in mountains southeast of Beirut today.

title: SUBSTITUTE FOR STOCKPOT
description: WELL-PREPARED stock is the fuel that makes fine French cooking soar, so a quality stockpot is an essential piece of equipment. When I worked in restaurants in France and the United States we had stockpots of 30-quart capacity or more that simmered around the clock. They were so heavy that it took two men to lift them onto the range. The best pots had spigots at the bottom so that reduced stock could be strained out.

title: ALL OVER TOWN, THE CULINARY HEAT IS ON
description: AT Tanjore, an Indian restaurant at First Avenue and 66th Street, when a customer asks for chicken vindaloo, a hot and spicy dish from the southwestern state of Goa, the owner asks how he would like it prepared: hot, very hot, extra hot, dynamite or double dynamite.

title: CAROL HOLTER
description: Carol Holter, a former commissioner of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service in New York City, died of pneumonia on Sept. 1 at Emerson Hospital in Concord, Mass.

title: TESTING THE BAROMETER OF NATIONAL OUTRAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: BEIRUT INSURANCE RULING FAVORS HOLIDAY INNS
description: In the first American ruling of its kind, a Federal judge in New York yesterday found that an all risk insurance policy held by Holiday Inns Inc. covers claims arising out of fighting in Lebanon in 1975 and 1976.

title: GENERAL MAGNAPLATE CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
ART'S WAY MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
CORRECTION
description: An illustration in yesterday's Science Times showing the relative sizes of particle accelerators was incorrectly labeled. The dimensions in the centers of the accelerators' rings referred to their circumferences.

title: Brouillard Is Chosen By Texas American
description: Texas American Bankshares, a Fort Worth-based bank holding company with 26 banks throughout the state, has retained Brouillard Communications as its ad agency.

title: TYPES OF CHILIES
description: THE most obvious quality of different chilies, whether fresh or dried, is how hot they are. However, once you have cooked with chilies for a while, subtle taste differences emerge as well. As a general rule, fresh hot chilies impart more flavor than dried ones. Also, it is the seeds that are the hottest, so over time one will learn to adjust the number of seeds used in a recipe. Those with little experience eating hot foods might best begin by experimenting with few or no seeds.

title: Market Place; How Fertilizer Group Is Doing
description: AFTER a two-year slump, fertilizer issues are one of the best-performing groups in the stock market. Standard & Poor's index of four fertilizer stocks, in fact, has increased 55 percent so far in 1983. Meanwhile, brokerage house comments on shares of fertilizer producers, along with recommendations on other farm-related stocks, have generally been favorable.

title: LOEWE LEATHER ARRIVES
description: SHINY, smooth leather coats with a satiny patina alternated with supple suede styles for both men and women. They were more suggestive of wooded country estates and limousines than of motorcycles.

title: AUGUST'S HEAT BROKE RECORDS FOR THE NATION
description: The Government's weather experts said today that August was the hottest month on record for the United States and one of the driest.

title: 2 JUDGES FACE POLITICAL OUSTER
description: In a break with tradition, two State Supreme Court justices with 20 years on the bench were denied renomination last night at a Bronx Democratic judicial district convention controlled by Stanley M. Friedman, the Bronx Democratic chairman.

title: INTER-AMERICAN THEATER SET
description: The Americas Society/Center for Inter-American Relations began its new theater program last night at a black-tie dinner with David Rockefeller, chairman of the organization, as host at the society's headquarters at 680 Park Avenue.

title: INTEREST RATES DOWN SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates declined modestly in all maturities yesterday as market participants continued to be encouraged by a lower rate for overnight bank loans, which some have interpeted as a sign that the Federal Reserve has adapted a slightly easier monetary policy.

title: Economic Scene; And Policies Did Gyre . . .
description: THE British economist D. H. Robertson published a little book in 1922 called ''Money'' that made him famous because of his use of quotations from Lewis Carroll's ''Alice'' books as chapter headings.

title: Bonn Steel Complaint
description: West Germany will file a complaint at the Court of Justice of the European Economic Community against the authorization of steel industry subsidies in France, Britain, Italy and Belgium, the Economics Ministry announced today. A ministry statement said the action violated the Common Market's subsidy code of conduct and the objective of reducing steel subsidies.

title: LIBRARIES WARNED OF THIEVERY
description: A book by Copernicus, the 16th century astronomer, was stolen from a Chicago library.

title: T.W.U. Seeks 1% Rise in Pay Over-Accelerated Track Work
description: The Transport Workers Union has asked for the same 1 percent raise for its members that was proposed last week for the nonunion management of the Transit Authority.

title: WAYS OF PUTTING OUT THE FIRE
description: IT has happened to everyone at one time or another. You order a dish in an Oriental or Mexican restaurant, one of those specials with a little red asterisk next to it, and in a foolhardy show of bravado, ask the waiter, ''Make it really hot, please.'' The dish arrives looking innocent enough, so you blithely dig in.

title: Shamir Gains Majority In Israeli Parliament
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir found enough supporters to gain a parliamentary majority today.

title: BOEING 767 SALE TO EGYPT REPORTED
description: Egypt has agreed in principle to purchase as many as five 767 jetliners from the Boeing Company, industry sources said today.

title: Carson of Giants Has Operation
description: Harry Carson, the all-pro inside linebacker for the Giants, underwent arthroscopic surgery today to repair cartilage and a ligament in his left knee.
