title: DOWNING OF JET HAS TANGLED SOVIET-U.S. SPORTS EXCHANGE
description: The downing of a South Korean jetliner three weeks ago has led to confusion and disarray in the athletic exchange programs between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: MAJOR HEROIN RING BROKEN, FEDERAL OFFICIALS SAY
description: Federal authorities said yesterday that they had smashed a major drug importation and distribution ring with the arrest of seven people and the seizure of more than 59 pounds of heroin with an estimated street value of $65 million.

title: Accounts
description: * Carowinds regional theme park, owned by Taft Broadcasting, to W. B. Doner & Company, Southfield, Mich.

title: Rangers, Up by 5-0, Hold Off Devils, 5-3
description: The Rangers took a five-goal lead tonight and held on to defeat the Devils, 5-3, in a preseason game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: CONNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 21
description: Revenue figures are restated due to the discontinuation of Petco operations.

title: ANDROPOV APPEALS TO BONN LEGISLATION ON MISSILES
description: Yuri V. Andropov appealed to West German legislators today to resist the deployment of new American medium-range missiles.

title: Reagan May Visit Cooke on Weekend
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke, who has leukemia, may receive a visit this weekend from President Reagan, according to archdiocesan and White House officials.

title: RAX RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for 14wks to July 30
description: The year-ago periods consisted of 16 weeks for the quarter and 52 weeks for the year.

title: Time to Practice
description: It might be wise for pitchers on the Chicago White Sox, the champions of the American League's Western Division, and the Baltimore Orioles, who have just about nailed down the Eastern Division title, to start taking batting practice in earnest.

title: GENERAL ASSEMBLY OPENS AT THE U.N.
description: The 38th annual meeting of the General Assembly opened here today amid concern by delegates that Soviet-American conflict may dominate the debate.

title: ROCKEFELLER CENTER: A 'JEWEL' BUT IS ALL OF IT A LANDMARK?
description: It's a ''jewel'' and an ''elegant jigsaw puzzle,'' a ''town square'' that is ''part of the action.'' But is it a landmark?

title: VICTOR TO LAY OFF 500 IN SALES FORCE
description: Victor Technologies Inc., with $11.1 million in second-quarter losses, said today that it would lay off 500 members of its sales force, bringing the total number of Victor job cuts in recent weeks to dce, bringing the total number of Victor job cuts in recent weeks to The manufacturer of desktop business computers also said it expected third-quarter losses to be of ''similar magnitude'' to the deficits of the previous three months. Victor was cautious about the possibility for a profit in the fourth quarter, citing it as a ''goal'' rather than an expectation.

title: SENATORS REJECT FREEZE PROPOSAL
description: The Senate Foreign Relations committee voted today, 10 to 7, to reject a resolution urging a mutual and verifiable freeze of nuclear weapons with the Soviet Union but sent the measure to the Senate floor for a vote.

title: ARO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a charge of $507,000 to adjust pension costs and for a one- time retirement plan. Year-ago results are restated.

title: DEMOCRATS URGE STEPS TO PREVENT NUCLEAR WARFARE
description: Democratic leaders expressed ''general support'' today for a pastoral letter by the Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States that opposes nuclear war.

title: How to Police the Police In ''Nobody Knows My Name,''
description: James Baldwin wrote that the very presence of the police in Harlem ''is an insult, and it would be, even if they spent their entire day feeding gumdrops to children.'' In his view, the police behaved like occupying soldiers in a hostile country.

title: GROWTH REALTY COS reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a writedown of $4,416,362 on the company's investment in a Laredo, Tex., shopping center and an extraordinary credit of $3,067,754 resulting from the forgiveness of interest as a result of refinancing its credit agreement.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1. Dual-Use Sportswear A cotton fleece jump suit is part of an active sportswear line designed by Alice Blaine for Everlust, which makes boxers's gear. There are also sweatshirts, rip-stop nylon pants, combination sweatshirt-leotards, shorts and even a boxer's robe. Many of these have dual uses: they may be worn for dress up. For exmple, the jump suit, which comes in gray, black or white, could go to work or a party with a change of footwear. It is $50 on the fifth floor at Saks Fifth Avenue. 2. Designs From Quilts Baby shirts need not always be plain white or pastels. Why not print them with brightly colored designs taken from antique quilts? That's just what a company named Storks by Saraberry has done. The flowerpot and bird motif in red and green is adapted from a 19th century American applique quilt. There is also a repeat of red baskets and a Pennsylvania Dutch-inspired shoofly design in blue. The shirts come with red or blue long johns; $21 to $24 a set in 12- to 24-month sizes. In the Museum of American Folk Art shops at 55 West 53d Street and 610 Fifth Avenue (Rockefeller Center Promenade). 3. Gloves for Evening Evening gloves of wool jersey come trimmed with rhinestones or bugle beads. The are a simple and inexpensive way to dress up a jersey chemise or woolen suit. Since color has become important in gloves, these come in red, cobalt blue, burgundy, russet, mustard, gray and taupe as well as black.

title: OH, TO BE IN (BLANK) NOW THAT FALL'S NEAR
description: YOU might call them weekender extenders. They are the people who rent summer houses in resort areas such as the Berkshires, Fire Island and the Hamptons. They used to pack up and trek back to the city on Labor Day, but nowadays, more and more of them are extending their leases into September and even October.

title: DEWEY ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DUAL-LITE INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $163,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net loss after a loss of $1,311,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $800,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: EFFORT FAILS ON PHONE LEGISLATION
description: The Senate Commerce Committee, in a preliminary setback for its chairman, Bob Packwood, today failed to draft legislation aimed at curbing a rapid increase in local telephone rates that is expected to hit American consumers and businesses in the next few years.

title: Anger Is Not a Policy
description: Anyone can become angry - that is easy; but to be angry with the right person, to the right degree, at the right time, for the right purpose and in the right way - that is not easy. ARISTOTLE

title: Land Sale Spares Blueberry Patch
description: One of the largest and oldest blueberry patches in northwestern Connecticut, which many had feared would be closed since the sale last week of land in the area to Nancy and Henry A. Kissinger, will be transplanted to a nearby private school and remain open to the public, the principal of the school said today.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 21, 1983
description: International

title: Continental Air
description: Continental Airlines officials said they hade been unable to reach agreement with two union groups on details of a cost-cutting plan aimed at restoring the airline to profitability.

title: Mexican Quintuplets Born
description: A Mexican woman who had taken a fertility drug gave birth to quintuplets Monday at the University of California-San Diego Medical Center. The parents, Alberto Garcin, 32 years old, and his wife, Lorenza, 26, are from Guadalajara. The mother and babies were in ''excellent'' condition, hospital officials said.

title: Joint Venture Is Approved
description: The Justice Department today granted antitrust immunity to a joint venture being formed by eight small companies that plan to pool their resources to compete for research and development and production contracts in electronics, lasers and other high-technology lines.

title: JUSTICE RELEASES A RIKERS INMATE BELIEVED RAPED
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday set free a 36-year-old Queens man who the judge said was raped by inmates soon after he arrived at the House of Detention for Men at Rikers Island eight months ago.

title: No Indictments Issued on Royals
description: A Federal grand jury that had been expected to be briefed by a United States attorney on a cocaine investigation involving members of the Kansas City Royals issued no indictments before being excused today.

title: THEATER: 'THE ARBOR,' FROM BRITAIN
description: WHEN very young writers snare our attention, it's not always because of what little they do know but because of the great deal that they don't know. They speak their hearts and minds directly, without regard for the conventions of craft or the self-consciousness of art.

title: AIR OF TENSION AT PETROVEN
description: By any measure, the last 12 months have been difficult ones for Petroleos de Venezuela. The state-owned oil company is one of Latin America's largest business concerns, and its 40,000 employees generate $15 billion a year, more than 90 percent of the country's foreign exchange earnings.

title: Allies Said to Approve Plan
description: A NATO committee has approved new American proposals for the medium- range missile talks with the Soviet Union in Geneva, Bonn Government sources said today.

title: COMPUTERCRAFT INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Ohio Seeks to Bar Trucks Carrying Nuclear Waste
description: The planned shipment of 144 truckloads of high-level nuclear waste across northern Ohio should not be allowed pending a review by the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commissiom, State Attorney General Anthony Celebrezze told the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today.

title: West Point Building F
description: The cornerstone for a $5.5 million Jewish chapel - the first in the history of the United States Military Academy - was set in place today at ceremonies praising the role of Jews in the nation's military.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Cyanamid Co., Wayne, N.J., has created four new international operating divisions and named four presidents: John H. Taylor, agricultural; William G. Paxton, chemicals; James Plumpton, Formica products, and Rolf H. Henel, medical products.

title: Panel Rejects Build U.S.' Bill
description: The House Ways and Means Committee, questioning whether the reviving auto industry needs a ''build American'' bill, rejected legislation today that would require large amounts of United States-made parts in imported cars. Despite the vote, the plan - the latest in a series of so-called domestic content bills introduced in Congress - could still reach the floor.

title: Learning About Computers, Bit by Bit
description: ''This is a floppy disk,'' said Eric E. Vogt, president of Micro Mentor, holding one aloft. ''Do not pour coffee or wine on it.''

title: Capitol Air Stake Bought
description: Capitol Air Inc. has a pair of new owners, and a spokesman said yesterday that they are hopeful of turning the ailing airline around.

title: EVEN IN BRONZE, FRANCO IS NOT EASY TO PUT ASIDE
description: ''Franco Falls in Valencia After 12 Hours of Fighting'' screamed the front-page headline in a Madrid newspaper last week. It was eye-catching, and only a bit misleading.

title: Biafran Hero Wins Nigerian Senate Seat
description: A judge has declared Odumegwu Ojukwu, the former Biafran secessionist leader, the winner of a Senate seat in Nigeria, ruling that the initial election results were fraudulent.

title: Yusuf Dadoo Dies in Britain; South African Indian Leader
description: Dr. Yusuf Dadoo, a leader of the South African Indian minority and of the banned Communist Party, has died in Britain after 23 years of exile, the African National Congress said today. He was 74 years old.

title: The Clinch River Rathole
description: Can it be, at long last, that someone has driven a stake through the heart of the Clinch River breeder reactor? Yes, but only if Congress is willing to listen to its own analysts and only if it has the courage to write off a bad investment.

title: Ideal Basic Sale
description: Ideal Basic Industries of Denver says it will sell its Knoxville, Tenn., cement plant for about $50 million.

title: MARC RICH MAY FACE NEW CHARGES
description: Marc Rich and Pincus Green, the multimillionaire commodity traders indicted Monday for evading a record $48 million in taxes, may face additional charges of tax evasion and obstruction of justice as the grand jury investigation of their dealings continues, Federal prosecutors said yesterday.

title: LIBERTY WINS TO TAKE A 3-1 LEAD IN AMERICA'S CUP
description: Liberty grabbed the lead at the start and never lost control today as it defeated Australia II by 43 seconds and gave the United States a 3-1 advantage in the 25th America's Cup series.

title: MONDALE URGES U.S. SUPPORT OF MARINES IN LEBANON 'TO HILT'
description: Walter F. Mondale asserted yesterday that the United States should refuse to accept Syrian control of Lebanon and should support ''to the hilt'' the Marines' peacekeeping force in Lebanon.

title: BEATTY IS ACCUSED OF TAX EVASION AND CONFLICT OF INTEREST BY STATE
description: Former State Senator Vander L. Beatty of Brooklyn was indicted yesterday on tax-evasion, conflict-of-interest and other state charges.

title: ENERGY OIL INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
WINE GRAPES GAIN L.I. FOOTHOLD
description: The sign on the field along Route 48 on the North Fork of Long Island makes no bones about it: ''For sale,'' it says - ''Suitable for horses or grapes.'' For the moment, at least, the grapes seem to be ahead by a couple of lengths.

title: SCREEN: 'EL BRUTO,' A 1952 MELODRAMA BY BUNUEL
description: ''EL BRUTO,'' which opens today at the Public Theater, will be a treat for students of the great Luis Bunuel, who died in July at the age of 83. The Mexican film was made in 1952 when Bunuel, for the first time in his life, was busy earning a decent living by turning out popular comedies and melodramas for Latin American audiences and, occasionally, making films of real distinction. ''El Bruto'' is not one of these, but it was bracketed by a couple that are, ''Los Olvidados'' (1950) and ''The Adventures of Robinson Crusoe'' (1952).

title: Real Estate Ownership In a Tax-Exempt Fund
description: The Tax-Exempt Equity Fund, the first bond fund to offer investors tax- exempt interest income plus an ownership interest in real estate, is being marketed through more than 50 investment banking firms led by Lowe & Associates Inc., based in Worthington, Ohio.

title: Ex-Guard Wins Harassment Case
description: The State Department of Correctional Services was ordered today to pay $10,000 in damages to a former female state prison guard who said she had been sexually harassed while on the job.

title: Strike Talks in Belgium
description: The Belgian Government called urgent talks with public-sector trade-union leaders today as a wave of strikes by Government workers over national economic policies entered a crucial phase.

title: AID TO NICARAGUA REBELS BACKED
description: The Reagan Administration told the Senate Intelligence Committee today that it planned to continue covert military aid to the Nicaraguan insurgents until the Sandinista Government stopped giving military support to the rebels in El Salvador, according to participants in the meeting.

title: JAZZ: ISHMAEL REED SONGS
description: AMONG American writers, Ishmael Reed is probably the one whose sensibility is closest to jazz. His tone is colloquial; his ideas are wild-eyed and improvisational yet rooted in down-home wisdom. ''Conjure,'' a concert Monday at the Public Theater of music based on Mr. Reed's poems and prose, was an ambitious program, but it turned out to be less than the sum of its parts.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 21, 1983
description: Markets Stock prices surged to a new closing record as hopes of lower interest rates continued to spread among investors. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 15.25 points, to 1,249.19. Turnover on the Big Board climbed to 103.5 million shares, and analysts noted that institutional buying was heavy. (Page D1.)

title: ARMY READY TO DEPLOY PERSHING AS TESTS END
description: The Army has ''successfully'' completed its testing schedule for the Pershing 2 medium-range nuclear missile, an Army spokesman said today. He said the Army was receiving components of production missiles and expected to deploy the first missiles in West Germany on schedule in December.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: MENUS are inspired by many things. Sometimes I want to re-create the foods of my childhood. Sometimes I take my ideas from my professional training or from dishes I have had in restaurants or at a friend's table. Sometimes I cook simply out of the sheer pleasure of inventing a new dish.

title: ACF Industries Planning Sale
description: ACF Industries said yesterday, after a special board meeting, that it would try to sell the company through a so-called leveraged buyout or, failing that, to ''study the possible sale'' of all or part of the company. ACF, the nation's largest freight car manufacturer, released the statement a day after Carl C. Icahn, the Wall Street executive, told the Securities and Exchange Commission that he held 13.5 percent of the company and intended to seek control. Mr. Icahn, who has since increased his stake in the company to at least 18 percent, told the Government agency that he had lined up $100 million in bank credits to help finance the deal.

title: SEYMOUR KRAWITZ, PRESS AIDE IN FILMS AND THEATER, DIES
description: Seymour Krawitz, a theatrical and film press representative, died yesterday of cancer at his home in Manhattan. He was 59 years old.

title: SENATE VOTES 6-MONTH DELAY OF WATT'S COAL-LEASING PLAN
description: The Senate voted today to stop Interior Secretary James G. Watt from selling Federal coal leases for six months to allow time for a study of the Secretary's leasing practices to be completed.

title: 1,500 Inmates Stay In Cells at Attica
description: About 1,500 inmates at the state prison here are refusing to leave their cells, the spokesman for the State Department of Correctional Services said this afternoon.

title: Fluor Is Ill With Cancer
description: J. Robert Fluor, chairman and chief executive of the Fluor Corporation, the engineering and construction company, is undergoing radiation treatment for cancer. Mr. Fluor, 61 years old, said Monday that a malignant tumor was found in his chest last month while he was undergoing treatment for bronchitis. He said that neither his corporate workload nor the operations of his company had been affected by his illness.

title: Never Mind
description: The pitcher Steve Carlton has changed his mind about breaking his 4-year-old silence after he wins his 300th game.

title: Inflation Rate In Canada
description: Canada's annual inflation rate held steady at 5.5 percent in August for the second consecutive month, the Government agency Statistics Canada reported today.

title: ESPRIT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago figures because the company proposed its initial public offering on Aug. 18.

title: Pirates Win on 2-Hitter
description: When the Atlanta Braves called Larry McWilliams into the club office a year ago in June, he thought it was to tell him he was starting on the mound. Instead, he was told he had been traded to the Pirates.

title: ONLY GOVERNMENT CAN ABRIDGE PRESS FREEDOM
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 21, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: AM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $5,249,000 for the quarter and year, a loss from estimated settlement of rejected real estate and other leases related to reorganization proceedings of $1,378,000 for the quarter and year, and income from discontinued operations of $142,000 for the quarter. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $22,276,000 for the quarter and $43,584,000 for the year. The company is listed on the Pacific, Boston, Midwest, and Philadelphia stock exchanges.

title: UTILITY ASKS RICKOVER TO EXAMINE MANAGEMENT OF THREE MILE ISLAND
description: Hyman G. Rickover, retired admiral who became known as the father of the nuclear Navy, is examining the undamaged Unit 1 nuclear reactor at Three Mile Island at the request of General Public Utilities, operator of the two nuclear reactors there.

title: LEADERSHIP ROLE A 'LOVE-HATE' AFFAIR
description: ''People don't realize it, but being a leader is hard work,'' Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who is minority leader, told a luncheon meeting with reporters last Thursday. ''Not everyone wants the job.''

title: PAY 'N PAK STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
TV: ABC OPENS NEW 'HOTEL' SERIES
description: ''HOTEL,'' a new series making its debut on ABC-TV tonight at 9 o'clock as a two-hour movie, is a beached ''Love Boat.'' Instead of the weekly guest stars walking up a gangplank, they will pull up in taxis and limousines before the elegant facade of a San Francisco hotel called the St. Gregory (actually the Fairmont). The rest of the action takes place mostly on Los Angeles sets bearing an elegant resemblance to fashionable ocean liners of yesteryear.

title: SHOREHAM GIVEN TENTATIVE APPROVAL
description: A Federal licensing panel cleared the way today for the Long Island Lighting Company to begin low-level operation of its Shoreham nuclear power plant, once it completes repairs on backup diesel generators.

title: ONE MAN'S TAX SHELTER IS ANOTHER MAN'S HOME
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Q. My grandmother, who is 90 years old, says that the word brunch is a recent addition to the language, unheard of in her childhood. Do you know its origins?

title: Key Rates
description: * Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FORT WAYNE AREA DAZED BY KILLINGS
description: The fatal bludgeoning of a newspaper editor, his wife and their 11-year-old son and the sexual molestation of their 2-year-old daughter have unleashed deep feelings of fear and vulnerability here.

title: Study Faults City Onto Children
description: A private study released yesterday said that Federal budget cuts had seriously reduced services to children in New York City and that the city had failed to restore the money in areas where it could have.

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
U.S. Steel Plans 4,000 Job Cuts
description: After two weeks of rumors, the United States Steel Corporation officially announced that it would dismiss 4,000, or approximately one-fourth, of its white-collar employees in steel and related jobs.

title: OHIO-SEALY MATTRESS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The 1983 earnings include income from litigation with licensor. The year-earlier earnings include a net gain of $343,000, or 4 cents a share, for the sale of its investment licensor. The 1982 figures are also adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split in April and a 3-for-2 stock split in July.

title: Careers; Acquiring Expertise In Benefits
description: HEALTH CARE management has grown in importance as corporations try to get better control over employee health costs.

title: Stars Plan Celebration At Duffy Square Today
description: The Theater Development Fund will celebrate its 15th birthday at noon today with a star-studded salute at the TKTS booth in Duffy Square at Broadway and 47th Street.

title: Bridge: Silence Is Indeed Golden If Your Partner Is Asleep
description: There is a great deal to be said for letting sleeping partners lie: If the player on the opposite side of the table takes a quiet nap while he is dummy, do not disturb him. He will not make any critical comments about your play, and he will awake refreshed for the next deal.

title: BEEFSTEAK CHARLIE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 6
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,200,000.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: NO one, in or out of jazz, commands the baritone saxophone like Hamiet Bluiett. With Charles Mingus and Sam Rivers, he played rip-snorting solos that would go deep into the blues, then suddenly zoom into the stratosphere. And as a member of the World Saxophone Quartet, he now anchors the group's chords or soars above them.

title: Keenan Approved for Bench
description: The nomination of John F. Keenan as United States judge for the Southern District of New York was approved by the Senate today. Mr. Keenan, who was recommended for the post by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, was criminal-justice coordinator in the Koch administration and a special prosecutor of corruption in New York. He was chairman of the Offtrack Betting Corporation from 1979 to 1982.

title: KREISLER MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $17,000 on the retirement of debt. c-Includes a gain of $82,000 on the retirement of debt and a tax credit of $551,000.

title: MORGAN IS 4 FOR 5 AS PHILS WIN
description: Joe Morgan, who has eight hits in his last 10 times at bat, went 4 for 5 and drove in three runs to pace Philadelphia in an 8-5 victory over the Chicago Cubs today and keep the Phillies two games in front in the National League's Eastern Division race.

title: Safety for Boxers
description: Ringside doctors in Illinois will soon have the power to interrupt fights to examine fighters and order the fights stopped to to prevent further injury. Under legislation that has been signed by Gov. James R. Thompson, the doctors will get the new power on Jan. 1. That is also the date California doctors get the right to stop a bout because of injury or a fighter's physical condition.

title: ETERNAL QUEST FOR PERFECT CHEESEBURGER
description: ONE of the problems of looking for important things like Noah's Ark is that someday you might actually find it. What do you do then? That is why, ever since I discovered the difference between mustard and ketchup, I have dedicated myself to the search for the Perfect Cheeseburger. It is satisfying, fulfilling and cheap, and it justifies all sorts of overindulgence that might otherwise have to be avoided.

title: Fiat Earns $390 Million 495:TURIN, Italy, Sept. 21
description: Fiat S.p.A., Italy's largest auto maker, said today that it earned 624 billion lire, or about $390 million at current exchange rates, in the first half of 1983. Fiat did not release earnings figures for the comparable 1982 period, but reported for the first time that it earned 137 billion lire, or about $95.9 million at prevailing exchange rates, for all of 1982.

title: MERRILL LYNCH UNIT PROMOTES 2 OFFICERS Merrill Lynch Government Securities Inc., the fixed-income trading division of Merrill Lynch & Company, has promoted Howard A. Shallcross to chairman and chief executive officer and Daniel T. Napoli to president.
description: Their promotions follow the resignation of Michael J. Kugler, who was chairman of the division when he left earlier this month for the fixed-income group of A. G. Becker Paribas Inc. Mr. Shallcross, 38 years old, had been president and chief executive officer of the division, while Mr. Napoli, 34, had served as executive vice president.

title: Thousands Join Vigil For Argentine Missing
description: Thousands of protesters held a 24-hour vigil outside the national palace today to demand the military regime account for the more than 6,000 people who vanished during antileftist repression in the 1970's.

title: BANK RATES DECLINE SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates on bank money market deposit accounts declined slightly, both nationwide and in the New York area, in the week ended Wednesday, The Bank Rate Monitor said yesterday.

title: CANADA OUSTS 2 SOVIET DIPLOMATS
description: Canada expelled two Soviet diplomats last week for trying to steal top-secret high technology, a Foreign Office spokesman said today.

title: THE LUXURY OF FENDI FURS AND DE RIBES STYLES
description: MANY of the avent-garde architects who once paid no more homage to regional buildings than to stop their car to take a 35-millimeter slide - ''charming,'' they said - have, during the last decade, turned their thinking around. The traditional houses that have been familiar to millions of Americans have become an increasingly strong and serious influence for architects once trained to design crisp, machine-inspired buildings.

title: HONDURAS NOW SAYS EXHAUSTION KILLED U.S. PRIEST REPORTED SLAIN
description: A Honduran military spokesman said today that a Jesuit priest who had joined leftist guerrillas died of exhaustion while trying to flee Honduran troops. But the Jesuit superior of Honduras said he doubted the official version and termed it full of ''loopholes.''

title: Technology Moving Data From A to B
description: IN the movie ''War Games,'' the young hero connects his home computer to a Defense Department computer by dialing the telephone, waiting for a high-pitched sound and then sticking the telephone handset into a box with two cups on it. The box is perhaps the most familiar type of modem, a device for allowing two computers to communicate over telephone lines.

title: A RATE CUT IN A.T.&T. TOLL CALLS
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would cut long-distance telephone rates by $1.75 billion a year, or about 10 percent, on Jan. 1.

title: Osborne Is Sued By 26 Investors
description: The Osborne Computer Corporation has been sued by 26 investors who contend they were duped by the company's assurances about its financial status and future.

title: Killer of Actress Guilty Of Manslaughter Charge
description: The spurned companion of Dominique Dunne, an actress, was convicted today on a reduced charge of voluntary manslaughter for strangling the young woman last October.

title: CANADIAN BEERS MOVING SOUTH
description: To Americans, Canada is towering pine trees, majestic mountains and stalwart Mounties. At least that's the way Canadian beer makers see it, and they say it all adds up to big beer sales.

title: 3 Dolphins Fined
description: Coach Don Shula of the Miami Dolphins fined three rookie linemen - Steve Moorman , Mike Charles and Charles Benson - $500 each for what the team described as ''drug involvement'' on a day off early in this summer's training camp. Shula would not give details, but both Charles and Benson described the incident as a one-time use of marijuana.

title: CAROLINA TOWN SEEKS A SECEDE FROM COUNTY
description: To get from here to the Williamsburg County seat in Kingstree, local residents have to drive 25 miles on a two- lane road that cuts through dense stands of loblolly pines, twists through the Indiantown Swamp and crosses sandy fields of yellow-green tobacco.

title: R E I T OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
REAGAN REAFFIRMS A PHILIPPINE VISIT
description: President Reagan said today that there were no plans to cancel his November trip to the Philippines ''at this point,'' despite the growing opposition to the regime of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 22, 1983
description: International

title: Reynolds Predictions
description: R. J. Reynolds Industries said it expects its Heublein acquisition will cost the company about 8 cents a share in the third quarter ended Sept. 30. However, the company said that 1983 year-end operating earnings should exceed 1982 operating earnings of $6.96 a share.

title: Kaiser Steel Bids
description: A group of Tulsa investors, whose bid to acquire the Kaiser Steel Corporation was rejected, said they plan to submit a second offer soon.

title: Quagmire, Here We Come
description: As the Reagan Administration slips this country deeper and deeper into the fighting in Lebanon, anyone who wonders whether there are dangers in that process ought to have a look at an important new book. It is ''Vietnam: A History,'' by Stanley Karnow.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: STRINGERS

title: OPEL SALES CHIEF PICKED AS OLDSMOBILE PLANNER
description: John O. Grettenberger, director of sales for the General Motors Corporation's European operations, has returned to the United States to become the first director of product strategic and business planning at the Oldsmobile division in Lansing, Mich. In his new position, Mr. Grettenberger will be responsible for coordinating all Oldsmobile planning activities.

title: No Headline
description: Paranoia, American Style For narrow, unimpressive reasons, the State Department has declared the United States closed to Ruben Zamora, a Salvadoran leftist. Though he has been a visitor before, and only recently met in Colombia with President Reagan's envoy, Mr. Zamora has now been barred from addressing two forums on Central America. And this exclusion is justified by the same officials who regularly upbraid the Soviet Union for its fear of alien influences.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHEN adding electrical outlets or wiring for a light fixture or an appliance, it's best not to use extension cords, which can be both ugly and unsafe. The traditional solution has been to chop holes for the new wiring in walls and ceilings, which usually requires a professional electrician.

title: Aaron's Ring Found
description: Hank Aaron says he is ''absolutely thrilled'' to learn that he will get back the $6,000 diamond ring commemorating his 715th home run, the homer that broke Babe Ruth's career record.

title: OUTDOORS
description: Easy L.I. Canoeing

title: Charges Reduced In Truck Crash
description: Charges of second-degree murder against the driver of a cement truck that crashed into a parked car Tuesday on 10th Avenue at 49th Street killing a 23-year-old woman and her two children were reduced yesterday to criminally negligent homicide.

title: Chock Full Stake
description: Members of a shareholders committee of Chock Full o'Nuts have increased their holding of the company from about 17.5 percent, to 23 percent, a spokesman for the group said.

title: Construction Worker Killed
description: A large portion of a concrete and brick wall at the Willard Hotel collapsed today, killing a construction worker in the 11th floor ballroom of the structure, which is being renovated.

title: UMET PROPERTIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes gains from the sale of real estate of $765,000 for the quarter and $801,000 for the 9 months, and extraordinary tax credits of $989,000 for the quarter and $1,554,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $213,000 for the quarter and $1,574,000 for the 9 months, and a gain from the sale of real estate of $670,000 for the 9 months.

title: 'SWEATSHOP' COMMUTING STIRS AMERICAN CAN TO MOVE AGAIN
description: William S. Woodside, the chairman of the American Can Company, said today at a gathering of Westchester County officials that housing and commuting problems had been a major factor in a decision by his company to move its headquarters from Greenwich, Conn., to a smaller site in the Westchester-Fairfield, Conn., area.

title: 2 CRIME CASES SHAKE WEST HARTFORD
description: ''A lot of people feel we're like 'Kojak' and will solve these cases in an hour,'' Francis Reynolds, the West Hartford Police Chief, was explaining to a visitor today.

title: French Chemical Gains
description: Output for the French chemical industry in the first half of 1983 rose 3 percent and sales increased about 12 percent, the French Chemical Industry Association said today. A survey of 22 French chemical companies showed that the rise was largely a result of exports, which increased 17.8 percent in the period.

title: G.M. Plans Import Of Japanese Cars
description: The General Motors Corporation has informed the Reagan Administration that it plans to import thousands of Japanese cars starting in 1984 but is not lobbying to lift import restraints on Japanese autos, a company spokesman said.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

title: DETROIT'S CHALLENGE: CALIFORNIA
description: Carroll Shelby, the one-time racing driver turned auto designer, put his cowboy boots up on the desk at the Chrysler Shelby Performance Center here and analyzed what went wrong for the American auto industry in California.

title: Hunt Given Chance In Giants' Defense
description: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants, though affirming that Byron Hunt would replace the injured Harry Carson in the lineup for next Monday night's game, said today that he would not disclose exactly how the defense would be realigned.

title: THIS IS ARMS CONTROL?
description: The attitudes that threaten to prevail in Congress today are similar to those that gripped European and American leaders at the turn of the 20th century. The peace movement was strong during that period, just as it is today. The political elite sang of disarmament. Yet these leaders had no intention of denying themselves the freedom to build all the arms they desired.

title: TRANSFER OF U.N. A TOPIC IN MOSCOW
description: The suitability of the United States as the host country for United Nations headquarters has been a theme in Soviet press commentaries this week on the cancellation of Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko's trip to the General Assembly.

title: City Plans to Sell $750 Million Notes
description: New York City officials yesterday announced plans to offer $750 million of notes during the week of Oct. 3 through underwriters led by the Merrill Lynch Capital Markets Group.

title: WATT REMARK ON COAL PANEL OFFENDS 4 GROUPS
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt, upset by a Senate vote barring him from leasing any more Federal land for coal mining, told a business group today that he was being advised on the issue by ''every kind of mixture you can have. I have a black, I have a woman, two Jews and a cripple.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dave Concepcion , shortstop for the Cincinnati Reds, has lost an appeal of his three-day suspension for spitting on Dave Pallone , an umpire, in a game Aug. 23 in Chicago. He will begin serving the suspension Friday.

title: BRIEFS
description: Computer Devices Inc. announced that it is holding preliminary discussions with several concerns about an equity investment in the company, or an outright purchase, and that it had retained Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette as its investment banker.

title: BALLET THEATER BOARD APPROVES FULL SEASON
description: The board of the American Ballet Theater yesterday announced that it had voted unanimously to proceed with all aspects of its 1983-84 season.

title: 2 WOMEN SELECTED BY NASA FOR SPACE SHUTTLE MISSIONS
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today assigned two female astronauts, both physicians, to space shuttle missions planned in June and August next year.

title: ONCE AGAIN ALLENDE'S NAME BRINGS CHEERS IN CHILE
description: In the midst of one of the recent anti-Government protest rallies in downtown Santiago, a group of demonstrators touched off a wave of astonished cheers when they unfurled a banner bearing a likeness of Salvador Allende Gossens, the Marxist politician who was Chile's last elected President.

title: Glen Cove Presses Soviet on Taxes
description: Officials of Glen Cove, L.I., said in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday that the Soviet Union no longer used an estate it owns in Glen Cove for diplomatic or consular purposes and should therefore not be exempt from property taxes.

title: Article 181794 -- No Title
description: The House of Representatives today approved a bill that would provide $3.5 billion to subsidize jobs for people who have been unemployed for at least 15 weeks.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 22, 1983
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: ROSWELL MILLER JR.
description: Roswell Miller Jr., a retired civil engineer and real-estate executive, died Monday at the Sharon (Conn.) Hospital.

title: AUSTRALIA'S FLAG DAY
description: Australia apparently thinks that the America's Cup is a two-out-of-five series. By the time the fastest of the spectator and news media flotilla returned to Newport Harbor yesterday, a huge Australian flag, blue with the stars of the Southern Cross constellation on it and a small Union Jack in the upper left corner, was billowing in the breeze above the Newport Offshore dock where Australia II hides its mysterious keel behind a green veil.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: GRIZZLY IS GOING TO CHASE THE MOOSE
description: Can a Grizzly catch the Moose?

title: No Headline
description: THE PENITENT. By Isaac Bashevis Singer. 170 pages. Farrar, Straus, Giroux. $13.95.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article about the former basketball player Rick Kuhn in Sports Pages on Tuesday incorrectly attributed the statement that his cooperation with the authorities had led to the indictment of another former player, Ernie Cobb. The statement was made by the prosecutor, Edward McDonald.

title: SMOKING BY MOTHER IS FOUND TO CUT CHILD'S LUNG FUNCTION
description: Children whose mothers smoke may suffer reduced lung development, doctors reported today.

title: ATLANTIC TELECASTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PLANT AND TREE MAINTENANCE CLASSES IN THE CITY
description: The following is a list of plant and tree maintenance classes around New York City.

title: Seaport as Neighbor
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Fish Cancer in 4 States Spurs Plea for Inquiry
description: A scientist, passing out plastic bags containing tumor-covered fish heads, asked the Federal Government today to determine whether environmental contamination was to blame for cancer epidemics among fish in New York and three other states.

title: Humor and the Budget
description: During what Mayor Koch called the

title: CORRECTION
description: An article and photo caption yesterday incorrectly identified a Chicago church that offers sanctuary to Central American refugees. It is the Wellington Avenue United Church of Christ.

title: SUPER VALU STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 10
SPANIARD ADDRESSES ARMY 'UNEASINESS'
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez has reassured Parliament that his Government is keeping tabs on the mood within the army and that the armed forces will not become an ''autonomous power'' in democratic Spain.

title: Patriotic Cheers
description: The 1984 United States Olympic hockey team is receiving some impressive receptions during its exhibition schedule, courtesy of the 1980 team, which won the gold medal in Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: Coal Leasing Delay Adopted
description: The Senate, in a 76-to-18 vote today, approved a $8.04 billion Interior Department spending bill that bars Interior Secretary James G. Watt from selling Federal coal leases for six months.

title: Key Rates
description: * Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Broken Hill Bid
description: Wigmores Ltd., a tractor marketing company, said it had sweetened its takeover offer for Australia's largest public company, the Broken Hill Proprietary Company, by about $310 million, to more than $3.8 billion. James McNeill, the Broken Hill chairman, said the increased Wigmores offer did not change Broken Hill's opposition to the takeover bid.

title: STANLEY STYMIES YANKS AGAIN
description: Just when the Yankees thought they finally had Bob Stanley where they wanted him, the Boston relief pitcher helped himself and then got an assist from Reid Nichols tonight.

title: Louisiana Bonds Yielding Up to 9%
description: A $100.2 million issue of Aa-rated Louisiana general obligation bonds was offered with yields ranging from 5.5 percent in 1984 to 7.9 percent in 1993 and 9 percent in 2002-03, through underwriters led by Citibank.

title: PILLSBURY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Soviet Delegate Admits Error in Plane Incident
description: A Soviet delegate to an international conference here acknowledged today that Soviet pilots made a ''mistake'' in the downing of a South Korean airliner. He said they wrongly identified it as a military reconnaissance plane and wouldn't have shot it down if they had known it was a commercial flight.

title: Reagan Appoints 10 As Delegates to U.N.
description: President Reagan has named a 10-member delegation to the United Nations General Assembly.

title: DANCE: BAT-DOR TROUPE DISPLAYS WIDE RANGE
description: THE Bat-Dor Dance Company of Israel is a deliberately eclectic group, and one of the pleasures of watching it is that of seeing unfamiliar works by several different choreographers. The choreographers represented on Tuesday night's program in the Joyce Theater attempted some ambitious things. But, too often, they failed to translate their themes into dance terms.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Maybe all those delegates should have six months in the United Nations meeting in Moscow and then six months in New York, and it would give them an opportunity to see two ways of life.

title: News Analysis; TIMELESS DEBATE: HOW TO PICK JUDGES
description: Like proposals to revamp New York's Byzantine court structure, calls to abandon the direct election of judges have been sounded repeatedly. But because of patronage politics, skepticism of ''merit selection'' plans and the difficulties of amending the State Constitution, the outcry following the renomination controversy in the Bronx is unlikely to bring about any dramatic changes quickly.

title: Nuclear Weapon Is Tested
description: Scientists exploded a nuclear weapon beneath this desert mesa today to test the effects an enemy attack from space would have on missiles and military equipment. A Department of Energy spokesman said the test, 93 miles northwest of Las Vegas, had an explosive force of less than 20,000 tons of TNT.

title: RAND INFORMATION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 14
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $350.

title: PASSENGER CUTS FUEL TO A PLANE ENGINE, BUT NO ONE IS HURT
description: A passenger reached into the cockpit and shut off the fuel to one engine of a twin-engined commuter airliner yesterday, but the plane landed safely in Syracuse after the man was overpowered, according to the.

title: Profit Up 36% At Pillsbury
description: The Pillsbury Company said today that profit rose 36 percent and sales increased 15 percent in the first quarter of its fiscal year, spurred by its restaurant group. Profit in the three months ended Aug. 30 rose to $34.8 million, or $1.60 a share, from $25.6 million, or $1.18 a share, in the period last year.

title: WHEN NEIGHBORLINESS TURNS HIGH TECH
description: THERE was a time when neighbors dropped in to borrow a cup of sugar or to offer advice on backyard planting, but the home computer has created a new kind of neighborliness. Nowadays, the computer owner from next door drops in to borrow the little cartridges or disks that make computers do everything from play games to balance checkbooks, or for an advisory session on computerese.

title: SKETCHES OF 2 STATE SUPREME COURT JUSTICES AND 4 CANDIDATES
description: In 1962, he was elected a justice of the Civil Court of the City of New York. In 1950, he was elected to the State Assembly, where he represented the Kingsbridge, Mosholu and Riverdale sections of the Bronx.

title: PANEL FINDS NO VALID EXCUSE FOR NOT TREATING AIDS CASE
description: A medical study group at the University of California in San Francisco has concluded that there is no scientific reason why health care personnel who are reluctant to treat victims of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, should be excused from doing so.

title: DYING GIRL GETS MEDICAL AID OVER FATHER'S PROTEST
description: A state appeals court ruled today that a 12-year-old girl who is suffering from life-threatening bone cancer must undergo treatment despite the objections of her family.

title: Lucille Armstrong Suffers Heart Attack
description: Lucille Armstrong, the widow of jazz trumpet great Louis (Satchmo) Armstrong, was hospitalized in critical condition after suffering a heart attack today, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Bridge:Brazilians
description: World Team Competition

title: SHEPHERD PRODUCTS reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a special gain of $50,660. c-Includes a special gain of $92,898.

title: Sale of Generals Is Set
description: The sale of the Generals to the real estate executive Donald J.

title: Williams in Pact With Allen Firm TULSA, Okla., Sept. 21 (AP) - The Williams Companies, an energy and agriculture concern, said it had signed an agreement allowing it to proceed with its takeover offer for the Northwest Energy Company, ending a New York investment firm's competing bid for Northwest.
description: Williams has agreed to pay $39 a share in cash for Northwest's 18.55 million common shares outstanding, or about $724 million. It also would pay Allen & Company Inc. of New York, which initially bid for Northwest, $26.7 million to drop out.

title: Biscayne Appeal
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said it would appeal a Federal judge's decision that the agency acted illegally in seizing Biscayne Federal Savings and Loan Association of Miami. Judge Eugene Spellman of District Court ruled Sept. 9 that the bank board blocked stockholder attempts to rescue the financially ailing Biscayne by conducting negotiations ''wrapped in a shroud of deception'' and therefore must return the thrift unit, seized on April 6, to its owners.

title: Block Orders a Halt in SalesOf Meat From 2 Companies
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block today ordered a halt to sales of meat to the Government by two Colorado and Nebraska companies until an investigation into their operations was completed.

title: Ford Credit Unit's Extendable Notes
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company's $100 million of five-year extendable notes with a final maturity of 1998 were offered at a price of 100 with a 12 1/4 percent coupon,through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: FLORENTINE VILLA IS BEQUEATHED TO N.Y.U.
description: Many years hence, Sir Harold Acton hopes, New York University will open a new center that it will have inherited from him far from Washington Square.

title: Market Place Dr Pepper Co. And Its Options
description: THE Dr Pepper Company used to grow with the best of the soft-drink companies. But the competition has stiffened, squeezing smaller companies, and Dr Pepper is looking at several bullet-biting strategies. Not the least of them is acquisition by another company.

title: Nippon Steel Order
description: The Nippon Steel Corporation said today that it had won, with its Kuwaiti subsidiary, a $41 million order for the maintenance of the oilfields of the Arabian Oil Company in the zone of the Persian Gulf divided between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. The contract, which begins next September and runs for five years, covers maintenance at production facilities in the Khafji oilfields. The Kuwaiti subsidiary is the International Marine Construction Company.

title: AUSTRALIA II BEATS LIBERTY BY 1:47
description: Australia II today defeated Liberty, which had gear problems, by 1 minute 47 seconds in the fifth race of the 25th America's Cup series. Liberty still leads the four-of-seven series, 3-2, and the sixth and possibly final race will be sailed Thursday.

title: Olympic Team Winss
description: Pat LaFontaine scored three goals and assisted on another to lead the United States Olympic team to an 8-4 victory over the Hartford Whalers.

title: Chemical Plant Blasts Hurt Five in Carolina
description: Up to four fiery explosions felt two miles away rocked a chemical company today, injuring at least five people and forcing the evacuation of 75 families because of toxic smoke, the authorities said. Flames leaped 200 feet in the air.

title: 3 Sentenced in Jersey In Extortion Attempt
description: Three college students who pleaded guilty to threatening a family in an attempt to extort $50,000 have been sentenced to prison.

title: ROUGHING IT AT WESTERN REHABILITATION CENTER
description: When young criminals or rape victims or mentally disabled teen-agers are sent to the Santa Fe Mountain Center, they are not there for just a walk in the woods.

title: THE PSYCHOLOGY OF THE FEAR OF NUCLEAR POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: New Pentagon Spokesman
description: President Reagan has nominated Michael I. Burch to be Assistant Secretary of Defense for public affairs, the White House said today. Mr. Burch will replace Henry E. Catto Jr.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective. Corrections, also on this page, continue to deal with factual errors.

title: Tribute to the Met Opens at Lincoln Center
description: The most elaborate and loving tribute to the Metropolitan Opera's first century of life opened yesterday at the Lincoln Center Library for the Performing Arts, the culmination of five years' planning.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Bakeries Co. has elected Don K. Vance president of its Taystee division and a corporate senior vice president.

title: BRINGING BACK THE GRANDEUR OF RIVERSIDE PARK
description: Riverside Park, the slender strip of greensward that runs along the Henry Hudson Parkway by the banks of the Hudson River, is entering its second century, and a major restoration has begun.

title: Candidate Backs Use of Shoreham
description: Assemblyman Patrick G. Halpin, the Democratic challenger for Suffolk County Executive, announced today that he would support the opening of the Shoreham nuclear power plant, provided certain safety conditions were met.

title: POLITICAL WINDS SHIFT, BUT HOUSTON'S MAYOR IS LIKELY TO WEATHER THE STORM
description: Six months ago, Mayor Kathy Whitmire appeared unbeatable.

title: 7 KILLED AS AN ANTI-MARCOS CROWD BATTLES SECURITY FORCES IN MANILA
description: Security forces clashed Wednesday night with thousands of anti-Government demonstrators who tried to march on the presidential palace, and officials said at least seven people were killed and more than 150 wounded.

title: JAMES F. DILLON
description: James F. Dillon, a former Democratic State Assemblyman, died Monday in the Albany County Nursing Home in Colonie, N.Y. He was 88 years old and lived in Watervliet.

title: Afghan Rebels Reported To Damage Airport
description: Western dipomats said Tuesday that 150 Afghan rebels, firing rockets, mortar rounds and heavy machine guns, attacked an airport near the Afghan-Soviet border early this month and put it out of commission for about a week.

title: News Analysis; WAR POWERS COMPROMISE: A QUANDARY
description: Byrd Voices Reservations In reaching a compromise with President Reagan on Lebanon, Congress appears on the verge of establishing an important legal precedent. But some uneasiness has developed that Congress is being drawn into authorizing greater American involvement in Lebanon than was originally intended. For just as Congress is about to win the constitutional point that has been the prime objective of many legislators, many members say they are faced with a quandary.

title: Coetzee Discarding Can't Win' Feeling; Confident For Dokes Title Bout
description: Gerrie Coetzee's father goes around saying that Coetzee has maybe a 30 percent chance of defeating Michael Dokes at the Richfield Coliseum Friday night.

title: CBS IS SAID TO HAVE PAID 2 FUGITIVES FOR INTERVIEW
description: CBS News paid $10,000 to two fugitive gunrunners to interview them for ''60 Minutes,'' according to the Manhattan District Attorney's office. CBS News said yesterday that it had not paid the fugitives, but that the money was for an intermediary's fee.

title: U.S. BLAMES SOVIET FOR SYRIANS' ROLE IN LEBANESE STRIFE
description: President Reagan and Secretary of State George P. Shultz both said today that the Soviet Union was sponsoring and supplying the growing role of Syria in the battle for control of Lebanon.

title: MODEL ROOMS BASED ON FRENCH THEMES
description: THE preponderance of French Provincial reproduction furniture and French Proven,cal printed fabric was to be expected in the new model rooms that opened at Bloomingdale's last week. As part of the department store's ambitious F^ete de France promotion, the rooms encompassed two types of settings. The most elaborate were designed by the store itself, based on French themes, and included a majority of furnishings from France.

title: EARLY DATA SHOW ECONOMIC GROWTH REMAINS VIGOROUS
description: The nation's resurgent economy is still growing vigorously, the Government reported today, and for the moment, inflation remains in check.

title: B.A.T's Profit Climbs by 27%
description: B.A.T Industries P.L.C., a retailer and tobacco producer, said today that lower taxes helped it increase profit 27 percent in the first six months of the year from the same 1982 period. Net income for the first half was $:189 million - about $283.5 million at current exchange rates - compared with $:184 million in the first half of 1982, the company said.

title: CURB ASKED ON TRADE TO SOVIET
description: The President's national security adviser, William P. Clark, has endorsed a proposed tightening of controls over exports to the Soviet Union, Administration officials said today. His action intensifies an interagency conflict over Washington's response to the Soviet downing of a Korean Air Lines plane on Sept. 1.

title: U.S. Sales Push Is Set by VW
description: In two moves designed to spur lagging car sales, Volkswagen of America Inc. said it would make diesel engines standard in some cars, and cut 1984 model car prices an average of $45 from current levels. Diesel engines, offering greater fuel economy than gasoline power plants, have always been an option on Volkswagen cars and cost at least $500 extra on 1983 models.

title: CREDO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Appeals Court Rejects Tax Disclosure Forms
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit has ruled that the Reagan Administration acted illegally in trying to force some four million handicapped or aged recipients of Social Security benefits to disclose confidential tax information.

title: ISRAELI ECONOMICS ILLS
description: In patching back together Israel's governing coalition, Yitzhak Shamir, the Prime Minister-designate, has passed a crutial test of authority. But Mr. Shamir cannot be optimistic about keeping that coalition together unless he finds a way to overcome the consequences of the previous Government's economic misdeeds. The United States should be careful how it is drawn into his effort.

title: MEMPHIS PRESS-SCIMITAR TO SHUT NEXT MONTH
description: The Memphis Press-Scimitar will close at the end of next month, its owner, the Scripps-Howard newspaper chain, said yesterday.

title: Cable TV Fee Opposed
description: The cable television industry asked the United States Court of Appeals today to overturn a regulatory decision that increased copyright fees and prompted hundreds of cable operators to drop the signals of so-called superstations and other independent TV stations.

title: Blaming Parents
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: S-P DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
GLOBAL NATURAL RESOURCES PROPERTIES PLC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes $3,200,000 received in settlements of certain nonrecurring claims originating in prior years. c-Net loss after charges of $2,100,000 for nonrecurring proxy expense and related litigation. Results for the latest 6 months include the operations of Natural Resources Corp. of Texas-formerly McFarlane Oil Co.-which was acquired in September 1982.

title: CYBERMEDIC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net inc.

title: ABC LEADS IN NIELSEN RATIGS FOR SECOND WEEK
description: ABC swept ahead of the two other networks in the A. C. Nielsen ratings for the second straight week, aided by its strategy of introducing several new shows two weeks before the start of the new television season.

title: ACID-VOICED ASSEBLY CHIEF
description: It was during a heated debate here last year on the war in the Falkland Islands that a Latin American diplomat rose and said that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's actions had to be understood in the context of ''the glandular system of women.'' The comment evoked a barrage of criticism from other members, especially the British delegation, and from the women's movement.

title: Commodities Broker Is Held As the Head of a Drug Ring
description: A Manhattan commodities broker was arrested today and accused of heading an international drug smuggling ring that plotted to import $10 million worth of cocaine and marijuana. A Nigerian diplomat was said to have been recruited in the plot.

title: Reporter in Hitler Hoax Is Said to Be Cleared
description: The reporter who bought the bogus Hitler diaries for Stern magazine was freed from jail today and ''completely cleared'' of suspicion in the case, his attorney said.

title: LEAR FEARS LOSS FOR VIEWERS IF TV NETWORKS GAIN POWER
description: Norman Lear, the television producer responsible for ''All in the Family,'' ''Maude'' and ''The Jeffersons,'' warned an audience of 200 at the National Press Club in Washington yesterday that if the three commercial networks became more powerful they would further drive down the quality of television programming.

title: SWISS PROTEST TO U.S. ON MARC RICH CASE
description: The Swiss Government formally protested to Washington today United States attempts to seize evidence against Marc Rich, a multimillionaire commodities trader, in Switzerland.

title: SNARLING DETENTE
description: As Joan Rivers might say to Henry Kissinger: ''Can we talk global strategy?''

title: AND A DIPLOMATIC LESSON FROM THE PAST
description: To the Editor:

title: RIVER OAK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes an after-tax charge of $521,000 for a write-off of an investment in the retail sale of homes and for expenses associated with a merger last June.

title: Mall Fire Destroys 39 Stores, Leaving 1,000 People Jobless
description: Fire destroyed 39 of the 43 stores in the Brunswick Mall Tuesday, leaving millions of dollars in damage and about 1,000 people without jobs, officials said.

title: QUICK & REILLY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
Judge Clears Way For Weirton Vote
description: A judge has rejected two lawsuits seeking the release of more information on plans for an employee takeover of Weirton Steel, clearing the way for Friday's vote on the proposal.

title: TORREZ LOSES 17TH
description: The St. Louis Cardinals snapped their seven-game losing streak tonight when they overpowered the Mets, 9-3, and sent Mike Torrez to his 17th defeat of the season.

title: ITT EXECUTIVE TO RUN NEW AUTOMOTIVE ENTITY
description: Edmund M. Carpenter gets excited when he talks about the auto industry, and it is not hard to understand why. At the age of 42, he was promoted yesterday to president of the newly formed ITT Industrial Technology Corporation, where automotive operations generate roughly 35 percent of revenues in an improving consumer climate.

title: SOVIET DROPS HOCKEY TOUR
description: Citing safety fears, the Soviet Union today announced cancellation of plans to send a hockey team to the United States in December for a series of matches against the United States Olympic squad.

title: OPERA WAS MASSENET'S 23D
description: Jules Massenet's setting of the Cinderella story, ''Cendrillon,'' is the 23d of his 34 completed operas. Since its triumphant premiere at the Opera-Comique in Paris in 1899, it has found modest international favor from time to time, though remaining obscure in comparison to Massenet's more popular works such as ''Manon,'' ''Tha"is'' and ''Werther.''

title: Gerry Lindgren: A Mystery Story
description: The mystery of what has become of Gerry Lindgren, who was one of the nation's top distance runners in high school and at Washington State University in the 1960's, continues to perplex people who once knew the 5-foot- 6-inch, 120-pound star.

title: Zambia Debt Payments
description: Zambia plans to make quarterly payments of $25 million to settle its foreign debt and restore commercial confidence in the country, the Bank of Zambia said today. In a letter to commercial banks authorized to deal in foreign exchange, the bank said that payments would start in the first quarter of next year and were intended to clear Zambia's arrears by the end of 1988. Banking sources said the arrears, including import payments, dividends and personal remittances, totaled $700 million.

title: Navy's Goat Fine
description: The rumors of the demise of Bill XXII, the Angora goat that has been the official mascot for the United States Naval Academy since 1979, have been exaggerated. He will be on the field Saturday when the Middies (0-2) play their first home game, against Lehigh at Annapolis, Md.

title: Decision Shifted On Owens Statue
description: The Lawrence County Commission, reversing itself a second time, decided Tuesday not to allow a monument to the famed Olympian Jesse Owens to be placed on the courthouse lawn in Moulton, the county seat.

title: THE PSYCHOLOGY OF THE FEAR OF NUCLEAR POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME BEAT
description: NOW that telephone equipment is not supplied exclusively by the telephone company, there seems to be no end to the telephone's myriad guises.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT ISLANDER, 7-1
description: The Rangers, despite using seven rookies, outplayed the Islanders and triumphed, 7-1, in an exhibition game last night at Madison Square Garden before a crowd of 16,606.

title: CUOMO ABOUT TO CHOOSE CONVENTION CENTER CHIEF
description: Governor Cuomo is about to nominate Thomas F. Galvin, an architect who has served as head of several city and state agencies, as president of the agencies building and operating the New York City Convention Center, a ranking official within the Cuomo administration said yesterday.

title: LAWHON, JOHN F, FURNITURE reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income which includes a tax credit of $332,678 for the 6 months and a gain on the sale of leasehold interest of $503,878 for the 6 months.

title: GEAC COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BRIEFING
description: Cardinal Cooke's Appeal

title: HAVE COMPUTER, WILL TRAVEL THE CAMPAIGN TRAIL
description: In last November's election more than 50 Republican candidates for the House of Representatives placed computer terminals in their campaign offices that allowed them to draw quickly upon research on the opposition and other services offered by the National Republican Congressional Committee.

title: DOCK UNIONISTS WARN OF ATLANTIC AND GULF STRIKE
description: Leaders of the International Longshoremen's Association have recommended rejection of a master contract agreement and warned of a possible strike of Atlantic and Gulf Coast longshoremen next month if the use of rules on the loading and unloading of containerized cargo is enjoined.

title: KOREAN TRAGEDY'S LESSON FOR THE FUTURE
description: To the Editor:

title: Letter: On Red Tape; Don't Drown Senior Housing in Paper
description: To the Editor:

title: FOREST SERVICE PUTS UP A WALL TO SAVE A RARE ALPINE FLOWER
description: The world's last remaining patch of the rare alpine plant Robbins cinquefoil holds its own against the brutal climate on the Northeast's highest mountain, but it is poorly equipped to survive the attention of people who might love it to death.

title: BUSH PROMISES AID FOR EAST BLOC STATES WITH INDEPENDENCE VIENNA, Sept. 21 (UPI) - Vice President Bush blamed Moscow today for the East-West division of Europe and pledged American support for countries that stray from the Kremlin's line.
description: Mr. Bush, before flying home to Washington after a tour that included stops in Hungary and Rumania, specifically praised the two Warsaw Pact countries for their independent policies.

title: Prices Up in Sweden
description: Rising prices for some food, clothing, shoes and gasoline helped to increase Sweden's consumer price index in August by five-tenths of 1 percent, to 133.5, from July, the Government reported today. The index, with a 1980 base equaling 100, was up 9.34 percent from August 1982.

title: U.S. Studies Nippon Pact
description: The United States is likely to ask Japan to revise an agreement on procurement procedures with the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Public Corporation, a United States Government official said today.

title: First Black Newspaper In U.S. Is Honored
description: A new plaque in Harlem recognizes

title: PRESIDENT BACKS IDEA THAT U.N. CAN LEAVE U.S.
description: President Reagan, endorsing the suggestion that disgruntled members of the United Nations are free to leave New York, said today that perhaps they should consider splitting their sessions between the Soviet Union and the United States.

title: Winters Quits N.B.A.
description: Faced with recurring back injuries that had kept him out of 51 games over the last 3 seasons, Brian Winters , the high-scoring free-agent guard, announced his retirement. Winters, 31 years old, who starred at Archibishop Molloy High School in Queens and the University of South Carolina, played the last eight seasons with the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: PLANES TRACK GAS IN ACID RAIN STUDY
description: This week, 200 years after the industrial revolution brought factories, smokestacks and all that they spew into the sky, a team of scientists in the United States and Canada began the first broad-scale experiment to determine where the stuff that goes up comes down.

title: Wometco Agrees To Buyout
description: Wometco Enterprises Inc. yesterday agreed in principle to be acquired by a group of investors led by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

title: SHAMIR IS INVITED TO FORM CABINET
description: President Chaim Herzog, after determining that Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir had the support of a majority in Parliament, asked him today to try to form a new government.

title: No Headline
description: Mr. Cuomo's Steel Tax on Subways Governor Cuomo is asking New Yorkers to pay up to $50 million a year more in subway and commuter train fares to assist the steel companies of Gary and Pittsburgh. That as dd Pittsburgh. That as ransportation Authority to adopt. The agency needs help in resisting.

title: NEW COURT MOVE TO CURB MANVILLE
description: Lawyers for thousands of claimants with asbestos-related diseases filed a motion yesterday to have the Manville Corporation's bankruptcy reorganization dismissed by the Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: MUSIC: ADRIAN BELEW
description: ADRIAN BELEW can make his guitar sound like a sea gull, a whale, a train, a rhinoceros or a gunfight in a glass factory. He is also a virtuoso in a more conventional sense, a forthright singer, and an unabashedly cheerful performer.

title: PUBLIC AND PRIVATE COLLEGE SUBSIDIES
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: Common Stock

title: What Secrets? And at What Price?
description: The Reagan Administration is mad, to the point of madness, about secrecy. It thinks the Federal Government is one big sieve, that important secrets are dribbling out and that a firm disciplinary hand is needed. So the Administration is preparing to lower the boom on thousands of Government employees. They'll be forced to sign new pledges not to disclose classified information and new agreements to clear speeches, books and articles with Federal censors. And for what?

title: BLOUNT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split declared June 27.

title: Biogen Begins Clinical Tests
description: Biogen N.V. said yesterday that it had begun testing gamma interferon, produced by using recombinant DNA techniques, on human cancer patients. Clinical testing is the first step toward receiving Government approval for use of the substance, which arises naturally in the body's immune system.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Friday about the failure of the Exchange Bank of Bloomfield, Iowa, reported that, according to the Federal Deposit Insurance Association, there are 424 uninsured commercial banks in the United States, including 133 in New York. The F.D.I.C. has since indicated that its statistics included those United States offices of foreign banks that do not accept deposits from consumers. The New York State Bankers Association says that none of the uninsured banks in New York are full-service institutions taking ordinary consumer deposits.

title: ATOM PLANT OWNER SAID TO SEE REPORT EARLY
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission gave the owners of three nuclear reactors, including the Diablo Canyon plant in California, a draft report on quality control before it was sent to Congress, according to the chairman of a Congressional subcommittee.

title: MOUNTAIN TOWNS RESISTING PHILADELPHIA'S SLUDGE
description: The small towns of the Allegheny Mountains have taken on Philadelphia in a fight to keep tons of processed sewage out of western Pennsylvania strip mines.

title: Comatose Student In Court Case Dies
description: A comatose Long Island college student has died before a judge could rule on a request by the student's parents' for a court order to turn off his life-support equipment.

title: Sea Goddess Cruises To Warren Pfaff Inc.
description: Now that more and more ordinary people can afford some of the better things in life, the people who could always afford them are prime prospects for products and services that will continue to keep them a few notches above the masses.

title: SCHAAK ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
EXPERT ON WOMEN IN UNIONS
description: Barbara Mayer Wertheimer, an authority on the history of women in the union movement, died of cancer Tuesday at her summer home in Lakeville, Conn. She was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: WHERE CROQUET IS NOT CHILD'S PLAY
description: ''Croquet,'' Nelga Young was saying yesterday, ''is a game that will teach you humility.''

title: NEW GETTY MUSEUM PLANS
description: Plans for construction of a $100 million art complex to be built in the foothills of the Santa Monica Mountains in West Los Angeles were made public Tuesday by the J. Paul Getty Trust, founder of the Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif.

title: STRIPPING THE PAINT OFF WOOD INTERIORS
description: WHILE furniture that needs stripping can be taken to an outside refinisher, attached wood surfaces such as moldings, fireplaces or paneling in old houses or apartments usually must be dealt with where they are if layers of paint are to be removed.

title: Officers Upheld In Fatal Shooting
description: A four-officer police advisory board concluded Tuesday that the policemen who fatally shot Denver Smith, a former starting defensive lineman at Indiana University, had acted properly.

title: CALENDAR: FRENCH FABRICS FOR HOME
description: At Home With France, Seventh Regiment Armory, 643 Park Avenue (67th Street), 212-288-0200. An exhibition in nine major categories of some of France's finest textiles for the home opens to the public Saturday from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 22, 1983
description: The Economy

title: SOLVING GREENHOUSE PROBLEMS
description: WITH a plastic vial in one hand and a camel's-hair brush in the other, Colleen Armstrong dabbed predatory mites onto the leaves of cucumber plants. The vegetable's leaves looked dusty and were yellowing from a bad infestation of spider mites.

title: Legal Aid Action Is Deferred
description: The Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, still split along party lines, deferred action today on renewing the authority for the Legal Services Corporation, the Federal agency that gives legal help to the poor.

title: HERS
description: WHY do so many women who agree with feminist goals choose to disavow feminism? For me the question became urgent a few weeks ago when I read concurrent disclaimers from three prominent, strong women: Christine Craft, the television anchorwoman who sued her employer; Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro, and the actress Estelle Parsons. When I checked out each quotation, my question elicited very different but equally revealing answers.

title: Savings Bank Picks Muller Jordan Weiss
description: Muller Jordan Weiss has been named agency for the Society for Savings, Hartford, Connecticut's oldest savings bank, founded in 1819. The previous agency was Harland, O'Connor & Tine of Hartford.

title: SALVADORANS TO GAIN REFUGEE STATUS
description: The Reagan Administration has quietly informed Congress that for the first time the United States will admit as many as 200 Salvadorans as political refugees to this country.

title: CUBAN EXILE GROUP REPORTEDLY PLANNED TO KILL CASTRO ON HIS '79 U.N. TRIP
description: Federal authorities disclosed yesterday that a man described as the leader of the Omega 7 terrorist group had secretly told the F.B.I. about an aborted plot to assassinate the Cuban leader Fidel Castro during a visit to the United Nations in 1979.

title: Carter's Handiwork
description: Know what Jimmy Carter has been doing since Jan. 20, 1981? He spent part of his time making two pairs of cane-bottomed chairs.

title: No Headline
description: U.S. Grain Sold To Russians

title: DODGERS WIN AND LEAD BY 4
description: Bill Russell of the Dodgers lined a double down the left-field line in the seventh inning to score Steve Sax with the deciding run for Los Angeles in a 2-1 victory tonight over the Houston Astros.

title: LEBANESE LEADER VISITS ARMY POST
description: President Amin Gemayel made an unexpected visit on Wednesday to the beleaguered Lebanese Army garrison in Suk al Gharb as the stronghold came under another daylong tank and artillery attack from Syrian-backed Druse and Palestinians.

title: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD UP TO RECORD LEVEL
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 5.8 percent, or 9.3 million shares, in the month ended Sept. 15, to a record 168.7 million shares. The previous high of 166.2 million shares was set on July 15. The short interest for the period a year earlier totaled 120.1 million shares.

title: GENERAL INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
CONCERT: LILA DEIS, SOPRANO
description: THE pleasure derived from the singing of the soprano Lila Deis Monday night in Merkin Hall was of the sort not often found in New York concert halls. Some of this pleasure arose because Miss Deis herself found it in her songs, whether she was exuberantly singing Rachmaninoff's ''Floods of Spring'' or playing with the eclectic gestures of ''Five Poems of Anne Spencer Lindbergh,'' a work by her accompanist David Alpher.

title: Advertising; 3M's Goal Of Leading In Video
