description: WITH an eye on an exploding market and its trophy case sporting a brand-new Emmy for pioneering work in developing videotape, the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company is preparing to outspend all its competition on advertising.

title: Oregon Voters Approve Taxes for 50 Districts
description: Oregon residents approved tax rates for 50 of 56 public school districts in votes that will allow the 5,000-student Lincoln County system to reopen its schools and leave only one district faced with imminent closing, officials said today.

title: Deregulation Of Trucking
description: Transportation Secretary Elizabeth H. Dole has sent the White House draft legislation that would fully deregulate the interstate trucking industry, she said today.

title: TV: 2-HOUR PRREMIERE OF 'TRAUMA CENTER' SERIES
description: ''TRAUMA CENTER,'' which is being given a special two-hour premiere on ABC-TV at 8 o'clock tonight, is a kind of updated version of ''Emergency!'' In this instance, the required fast action is linked to the one hour, called the ''golden hour,'' that may be left to many people following a serious accident. We are assured that of the thousands of people who die in emergency rooms each year, half could have been saved in trauma centers, which are specially equipped medical facilities.

title: DOW IS DOWN BY 5.90, TO 1,243.29
description: Stock prices pulled back yesterday after strong gains on Tuesday as investors cashed in some of their profits. Trading was active, but at a more subdued pace.

title: BATTLE TO FILL DRUG POST IS RENEWED
description: One of the longest-running battles between the Reagan Administration and Congress has nothing to do with the budget or foreign affairs. Rather, it is the long-delayed confirmation of Francis M. Mullen Jr. to head the Drug Enforcement Administration, where he has acted as chief for more than two years by order of the Attorney General.

title: Pipeline Offering
description: The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation's $100 million of 12 3/4 percent debentures due in 2008 were offered at 99 5/8 to yield 12.80 percent, through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company. When the price was set, the pipeline company's debentures, rated A-2, yielded about 1 1/4 percentage points more than outstanding 12 percent Treasury bonds due in 2013.

title: Mets Optimistic
description: The success of Met farm-system clubs this season has created a lot of optimism in the front offices of Shea Stadium about the future. Not only did the Mets' Class AAA team at Tidewater win the International League playoffs and the round-robin Little World Series over Portland and Denver, but the combined winning record for the six teams in the farm system was more than 57 percent,

title: MENTAL HEALTH ASPECTS OF BILINGUAL EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS Plans New Hourlong News Show
description: CBS announced yesterday that it would offer a new hourlong news program in prime time sometime next year with Bill Moyers and Charles Kuralt as anchors.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Q&A
description: Q. There is a crawl space with a dirt floor under my house. Inside, I am having a constant problem with dirt on the walls, woodwork and windows. In the winter when the furnace is on, these surfaces, as well as the draperies, all get very dirty. I had the plumber check out the furnace, but he said there is nothing wrong with it. There are sufficient louvers to ventilate the crawl space properly. Could the furnace be drawing dirt up from the floor of the crawl space and causing my problem?

title: 2 WOMEN LOSE FIREFIGHTER JOBS AFTER PROBATION
description: Two women serving as probationary firefighters, including the woman whose Federal lawsuit broke the all- male tradition in New York City's Fire Department, were dismissed yesterday on the ground that they could not meet minimum firefighting standards.

title: DYNEER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
EXCERPTS FROM A STATEMENT BY SHULTZ ON AMERICAN POLICY IN MIDEAST
description: Following are excerpts from a statement today by Secretary of State George P. Shultz before the Senate Foreign Relations and the House Foreign Affairs Committees:

title: SUBSTANTIAL RATE DROP DOUBTED BY ECONOMISTS
description: Security prices surged early this week as traders speculated about the possibility of an ''easing'' in Federal Reserve policy and lower interest rates. But interviews with market participants have disclosed uncertainty about whether a drop in the cost of credit can be sustained, and, if rates go back up again, whether the economy will continue to expand.

title: WOLF, HOWARD, B, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $28,060. c-Includes a tax credit of $9,778.

title: Mayor of Miami Beach Is Fearful of Refugees
description: Fearing a flood of Cuban refugees into Miami Beach if they are freed next month from an Atlanta Federal prison, Mayor Norman Ciment has proposed erecting roadblocks to keep them out.

title: MUSIC: CITY OPERA OFFERS 'CENDRILLON'
description: THE New York City Opera was not lost after all, but merely strayed. It returned last night, licking its wounds after a long, grinding labor dispute, to open its disrupted season with an irresistible production of Massenet's virtually unknown ''Cendrillon.'' Equally novel was the company's introduction of projected English subtitles, a dangerous experiment in audience education that on the whole worked astonishingly well. More on that later.

title: Broadway Celebrates Development Fund
description: Broadway stars, Broadway tunes

title: Volksoper Plans U.S. Tour
description: The Vienna Volksoper, which has made a specialty of ''light'' opera, will appear at the New York State Theater from April 9 to April 22 to begin its first American tour. The visit, through May 20, will also include performances in Chicago, Los Angeles and Washington. The productions to be presented in New York will be ''The Merry Widow,'' ''Die Fledermaus'' and Imre Kalman's ''The Gypsy Princess.''

title: PRESIDENTIAL DECISION NEARS FOR JESSE JACKSON
description: The Rev. Jesse Louis Jackson, just back from a European trip, is preparing to make a decision that could have a profound impact on politics next year: whether to run for President.

title: VERITIES SUSTAIN 'MISS AMERICA PAGENT'
description: THE ''Miss America Pageant'' on NBC last Saturday night attracted 45 million viewers, fewer than will watch, say, a Super Bowl, but considerably more than will turn on most programs in prime time.

title: President Quits at Continental Air
description: Stephen M. Wolf has resigned as president of the financially troubled Continental Air Lines, company officials said today in a statement. The company gave no reason for the resignation.

title: STAGE: TALES OF THE HILLS BY A KENTUCKY TROUPE
description: ''SOUTH OF THE MOUNTAIN'' is a warm-hearted collage of back-country tales and biscuits-and-gravy music, written by Ron Short and performed by the author, Tom Bledsoe and Nancy Jeffrey. This presentation of Kentucky's touring Roadside Theater opens the Dance Theater Workshop series ''I Got a Story You Ought to Hear: New Experiences in Narrative Theater.'' The homespun show is as comforting as a quilt, but it is a little threadbare as an evening of theater. It might be equally effective on a phonograph record as in a live performance.

title: Western Airlines
description: Financially troubled Western Airlines is offering its employees up to 27 percent of the company's stock and 20 percent of its profits in exchange for pay cuts that could save the carrier more than $40 million. Western has lost about $190 million since 1980.

title: PLAYERS
description: ''That's the phone right there, the one he called me on,'' she said. ''You can go over and touch it, if you like.'' Linda Down laughed, and pointed to the telephone, a black standard dial phone on the end table in her living room in Manhattan. She was referring to a call on the evening of last Oct. 25, the day after the New York City Marathon.

title: Interest Rates Move Higher
description: A heavy supply of new Treasury securities yesterday helped lower note and bond prices by as much as three-quarters of a point. Rates on short-term securities edged up.

title: 672 Turks Banned From Seeking Office
description: Turkey's military rulers today banned 672 prospective candidates, most of them former members of Parliament and columnists on right-wing newspapers, from running in general elections Nov. 6.

title: KLECKO IS SHIFTED TO LEFT TACKLE SLOT
description: After consecutive losses in which the opposition ran freely at the Jets, Coach Joe Walton yesterday switched two players on the defensive line. He changed Joe Klecko from right end to left tackle in a trade of positions with Kenny Neil.

title: NEW MOVES STIR PENTAGON MANPOWER FEARS
description: Military Analysis

title: REGIONAL STYLES ENTER THE ARCHITECTURAL MAINSTREAM
description: MANY pf the avant garde architects who once paid no more homage to regional buildings than to stop their car to take a 35-millimeter slide - ''charming,'' they said - have, during the last decade, turned their thinking around. The traditional houses that have been familiar to millions of Americans have become an increasingly strong and serious influence for architects once trained to design crisp, machine-inspired buildings.

title: TEACHERS ON COAST RENEW STRIKE TALK IN REJECTING OFFER
description: Negotiators for the city's 17,000 teachers renewed their strike threat after rejecting a contract offer Tuesday night. A strike would affect 550,000 students in the nation's second largest school district.

title: JURY IS TOLD MAN USED CAR TO MURDER HISPANIC BOY
description: The prosecution charged today that a 19- year-old man used his car as a murder weapon, swerving into a Hispanic child after he suggested ''picking off some Puerto Ricans and niggers.''

title: KEY MURDER TRIAL WITNESS DENIES SEEKING BENEFITS
description: A key prosecution witness who admitted being a police informer for 14 years testified yesterday that he sought no benefit for himself when he gave Bronx prosecutors incriminating evidence about a suspect in the Nat Masselli murder case.

title: SMALL EXPECTATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: DeLeon Winner
description: Carlos (Sugar) DeLeon floored Alvaro (Yaqui) Lopez with a left to the face in the opening minute and then knocked out the No. 2-ranked challenger at 2:51 of the fourth round tonight to retain his World Boxing Council cruiserweight title. Lopez, who had failed in four attempts for the light-heavyweight title, suffered his 14th loss against 61 victories.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
SEWING MADE EASIER WITH SIMPLE DEVICES
description: THE Singer Company has introduced a line of small appliances called Easy Menders, designed to do a specific stitching or mending task. They seem to be aimed at those who have not learned how to use a sewing machine or even a needle and thread.

title: Sallie Mae Is Offering 10 Million Shares at $20
description: The initial public offering of common stock in the Student Loan Marketing Association begins today, with underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company offering 10 million shares at $20 each.

title: EASTERN WILL SEEK WAGE CUTS OF 20%
description: Eastern Airlines, faced with recurring financial troubles, is asking its 37,500 employees to give up 20 percent of their pay and up to 25 percent of their vacations, beginning next year.

title: New Sport for Finks
description: Jim Finks has been a player, a coach and a general manager in football, but until yesterday he hadn't had a baseball role.

title: UNIFAST INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $32,916. c-Net loss.

title: Salvador Official Seized By Rightist Death Squad
description: A right- wing death squad said in a communique today that it was responsible for the kidnapping Tuesday of the director of economic affairs for the Foreign Ministry.

title: PANEL APPROVES NICARAGUA AID
description: The Senate Intelligence Committee tonight endorsed President Reagan's new plan for aiding Nicaraguan rebel forces, but moved to tighten control over the program's funds.

title: No Headline
description: The U.N. Today Sept. 23, 1983 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: COLLINS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Money Fund Assets Climb
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $389 million, to $164.55 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: President Is Appointed By Martin Marietta
description: Laurence J. Adams, who was instrumental in fending off an intense bid for the Martin Marietta Corporation by the Bendix Corporation last year, yesterday was elected president of Martin Marietta. Mr. Adams, 62, continues as chief operating officer of the aerospace concern, which is based in Bethesda, Md.

title: AFTER SIX, INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $330,000 for the quarter and $1,711,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $11,000 for the quarter and $335,000 for the 6 months, and tax credits of $67,000 for the quarter and $197,000 for the year. Sales for the year-ago quarter and year include uniform sales of $87,000 and $1,614,000, respectively.

title: 2 SHOWS OF JAPAN'S NATIONAL TREASURES
description: The art gallery at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, boasts ''Emaki: Narrative Scrolls From Japan'' (through Nov. 6), a small but incomparable group of lively ''picture scrolls,'' from medieval times to the 20th century, which regale us with dramatic scenes of adventure, romance, battle, history, biography and Buddhism.

title: Miamian Is Held in Beating Of Woman and Her Rescuer
description: Witnesses to the beating of a handyman who saved a young woman from an angry mob have ''finally'' come forward and led the police to a suspect, officials said today, adding that more arrests were expected.

title: Judge Allows Gold Project
description: A Federal judge has granted the co-owners of the collapsed International Gold Bullion Exchange permission to dig for gold in an offshore mine in Alaska in an attempt to pay back their creditors.

title: Foster's Band to Play
description: The saxophonist and arranger Frank Foster will lead the Non-Electric Company, a big band, tonight and tomorrow at the Jazz Cultural Theater (244-0997), 368 Eighth Avenue, at 28th Street. Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. Admission is $8; $4 for students.

title: Mortage Agency to Sell Collateralized Securities
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation yesterday announced plans to sell $684.6 million of collateralized mortgage obligations through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Jumping Leagues
description: For most of his life, Jim Finks has been involved with football. He was a T-formation quarterback at Tulsa University and played for seven years with the Pittsburgh Steelers. Then, after one year as an assistant coach at Notre Dame, he became the general manager of the Calgary Stampeders of the Canadian Football League, from 1957 through 1964.

title: URGENT: A POLICY!
description: The decision to compromise on sidestepping the constitutional issue of the War Powers Resolution as it applies to Lebanon was helpful. A confrontation inside Washington in the midst of battle would have blocked what chances there may be for devising a policy.

title: WIDOW, 'PAUPERS' AND POLITICIANS SCRAMBLE FOR MCDONALD SEAT
description: Representative Larry P. McDonald's death aboard a Soviet-downed Korean Air Lines passenger plane three weeks ago has touched off a spirited 20-candidate scramble for his seat in Congress.

title: Outdoor Rock Session
description: A free five-hour outdoor rock jam session will begin at noon tomorrow in front of Sam Ash Music, 150 West 48th Street. The concert, sponsored by the Electro Harmonix equipment company, will feature the guitarists Adrian Belew and Elliott Randall, the drummer Chango Charles and two rock bands, the Privates and the Hellions. The number for more information is 741-1770.

title: FASHION: ON THE FALL CIRCUT
description: Dresses by day and glitter by night - these were two major fashion developments this week as fall fashion promotions, many with an international flavor, peaked and women who already had them dressed up in new-season clothes.

title: 4 HASIDIM HELD FOLLOWING CLASH WITH POLICE
description: Nine police officers were slightly injured yesterday and four people arrested in a melee between the police and Orthodox Jews leaving a synagogue holiday service in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: NEWHALL LAND & FARMING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1,590,000 for the quarter and $4,086,000 for the 6 months. Year-ago results were restated.

title: Bed Designs
description: Side by side on the bookshelves, they look startlingly alike. In fact, ''The Moons of Jupiter,'' ''In the Palomar Arms'' and ''August'' have more in common than being new.

title: MRS. BURFORD SOUGHT STUDY OF 'POLITICAL DEADLINE'
description: Last winter Anne McGill Burford, then head of the Environmental Protection Agency, alerted the Justice Department to an internal document indicating political considerations may have played a role in enforcement of the hazardous waste program.

title: Clark Trade Sought
description: In his seven years with the San Francisco Giants, Jack Clark , the team's slugging right fielder, has been a critic of the club's operations. But now, after a year of special frustrations for Clark, the Giants have finally made an executive decision to his liking.

title: New College Group Has an Ivy Look
description: Emphasizing the word ''student'' in ''student-athlete'' and using the Ivy League as a model, six Eastern colleges have formed a football conference that will be known as the Colonial League.

title: A.C. Nielsen Jr. To Retire in May
description: Arthur C. Nielsen Jr., the chairman and chief executive officer of the A. C. Nielsen Company, said yesterday that he will retire from his positions May 1, after reaching his 65th birthday. He will step down after serving 27 years as either president or chairman of the big market research concern, which is best known for its TV ratings.

title: MARCOS WARNS OF TOUGH STEPS TO END CLASHES
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he would be compelled to order ''extreme measures'' if there were any resumption of the anti-Government rioting of Wednesday night and early today.

title: WATERS INSTRUMENTS, INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Economic Scene; Recovery, But No Boom
description: ECONOMISTS see through a glass darkly when they try to measure the current pace of the recovery. The Commerce Department's ''flash'' report Wednesday for the current quarter showed real gross national product - the total output of goods and services, adjusted for inflation - growing at an annual rate of 7 percent. But the department cautions that, when later revisions are made, the rate may turn out to have been as low as 4.5 percent or as high as 12.5 percent.

title: Eagle Crash Claim
description: The survivor of a car crash that killed Dennis Barnhart, founder and president of Eagle Computer Inc., plans to file a claim for more than $1 million against Eagle and Mr. Barnhart's estate for injuries he suffered in the June 8 accident. The accident happened the day Eagle's stock went public. Eagle will be a party to the action on the theory that Mr. Barnhart was operating as an employee of the company when the crash occurred, said Haig Arsen Harris Jr., attorney for the passenger, Sheldon Caughey.

title: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
TELECI INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: U.S. SAYS RUSSIANS REJECTED APPEAL
description: The Soviet Union has rejected an American appeal that it use its influence to restrain Syrian military involvement in the fighting in Lebanon and has blamed the United States for the trouble there, Administration officials said today.

title: THE ROSENBERGS: NEW EVIDENCE, OLD PASSIONS
description: A new book's conclusions that Julius Rosenberg was indeed a Soviet spy whose execution served the purposes of the American Government and the Communist Party has revived an emotional debate about his guilt and the role of his wife, Ethel.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issue

title: TOKHEIM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Gunman Killed on Coast In Attempted Robbery
description: Three would-be robbers took over a film processing plant and forced 20 employees into darkrooms before law officers killed one of the men and arrested two suspects.

title: CURRENCY CRISIS
description: As finance ministers and central bank presidents attend the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank here in coming days, they again face a currency crisis. The dollar is overvalued by about 25 percent, compared with the underlying competitive relationship between the United States and other major countries. The Japanese yen and West German mark in particular are correspondingly undervalued.

title: At 80, Reflections on Realty
description: Brewster Ives, whom friends describe as a gentle curmudgeon, turned 80 yesterday and he spent the day in his real-estate office, precisely as he has done for 55 years.

title: Pratt & Whitney
description: The Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Group said it would invest $1.5 billion over the next eight years to modernize its four Connecticut jet engine manufacturing plants. The announcement reduced fears that the company was planning to move out of the state. The company has trimmed its work force from 47,500 in 1968 to 26,000.

title: Memorial for Earl Hines
description: When the Overseas Press Club's Twilight Jazz concerts began in 1969, the organizer, Wilma Dobie Dougherty, invited Earl Hines and Maxine Sullivan, her fellow former Pittsburgh residents, to be the first performers and co-presidents of the new Overseas Jazz Club.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: TODAY, ''The Big Chill'' opens the New York Film Festival (reviewed on page C14); next Wednesday, it will start its regular run in movie houses, and shortly after, one of its eight leading players, Jobeth Williams, will take off for Paris, where she will spend three months making ''American Dreamer,'' opposite Tom Conti. Miss Williams's career is looking good.

title: SCREEN: 'THE BIG CHILL,' REUNION OF 60'S ACTIVISTS
description: IN the opening sequence of ''The Big Chill,'' Lawrence Kasdan's sweet, sharp, melancholy new comedy, seven friends, who went through the University of Michigan together and are veterans of the activist 1960's, meet at the funeral of one of their comrades, who has inexplicably committed suicide. The setting is a small Baptist church somewhere in the South.

title: EDWARDS A G & SONS, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
FEEDING OUR HUNGRY
description: When the President created a White House task force on food assistance, he said he was puzzled by news accounts showing that hunger is again on the rise. There really is no mystery behind this unfortunate development. The increase in hunger in America is due mainly to the highest sustained rate of unemployment since the Great Depression and cutbacks in benefit programs designed to aid the truly needy.

title: Korean Dies in Blast At U.S. Culture Center
description: A explosion blew out the main entrance to the American Cultural Center in the city of Taegu tonight, killing one South Korean and injuring at least three others, officials said.

title: ART: 'CIRCLES' AND 'AGE' FROM CHARLES SIMONDS
description: AT a distance, it looks as if giants had piled pink, orange and gray bedclothes into a Guggenheim Museum. Up close, the effect is more of lava slowly extruding from an unseen vent, especially since small buildings are riding down the crests of the billowing forms and toppling into the troughs between.

title: AUSTRALIA II BEATS LIBERTY TO TIE CUP SERIES AT 3-3
description: Australia II, which had trailed in the America's Cup finals by three races to one, sailed into history by tying the series today.

title: THE FOOTHILL GROUP,INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Woman,21,Sentenced In Fatal Beating of Son
description: A 21- year-old Irvington woman convicted of beating her 3-year-old son to death was sentenced today to life plus 25 years in prison by a judge who said he imposed the maximum term as a ''deterrent to child abuse.''

title: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 23, 1983
description: Markets

title: PLAYSLawrie Mifflin
description: Pat LaFontaine is supposed to score goals. Goals - 104 of them in 70 games last season - made him famous as a junior hockey player. They also helped make him the latest No. 1 draft choice of the Islanders, the four-time National Hockey League champions, who have a history of drafting winners.

title: Bridge:French and American Teams Co-Favorites for World Title
description: For two very good reasons the French team will a joint favorite, with the top-ranked United States team, to capture the world team title in Stockholm during the next two weeks.

title: DOKES FIGHTS FOR ATTENTION
description: Michael Dokes, wearing his politics quietly on a short-sleeved dashiki, weighed in light-hearted and lighter today for his second defense of the World Boxing Association heavyweight title.

title: Penney Executive Goes To Household's Chain
description: John P. Herron, sales and merchandise manager of the central region for the J. C. Penney Company, has been appointed president and chief executive officer of the T.G.& Y. store chain owned by Household International Inc. The parent concern is the holding company for Household Finance, which is involved in the personal loan field, and for the merchandising division.

title: Gracie Square Art
description: Works by about 90 artists will be on view in the 13th Gracie Square Art Show tomorrow and Sunday along East End Avenue from 84th to 87th Streets. The site of the free show, sponsored by the Carl Schurz Park Association, is along a recently restored section of the park. The rain dates are Oct. 1 and 2.

title: SCREEN LIGHTS UP ON 21ST FILM FESTIVAL AT LINCOLN CENTER
description: THE 21st New York Film Festival, which opens this evening, has a rich mix of 32 features in 26 programs from 16 countries and departs from its predecessors in three major areas. The 17-day gala brings to Lincoln Center more directors than any previous festival, 16, more American films than ever, 11, and a movie that generated the sharpest critical split in the selection panel in memory.

title: SUBS NEGLECTED ON SCHOOL IMPROVEMENT AGENDA
description: To the Editor:

title: ART PEOPLE
description: When royalty called Arikha.

title: HOUSE PANELS RESIST F.C.C. CHANGE
description: The three commercial television networks were dealt two successive setbacks in Washington yesterday and late Tuesday in their efforts to share in the profits from reruns of prime-time television shows. But they may have gained a reprieve on the most threatening one.

title: CUT HOSPITAL COST BUT NOT AT EMPLOYEE EXPENSE
description: To the Editor:

title: MIANUS BRIDGE COLLAPSE SCRUTUINZED AT HEARINGS
description: The collapse of the Mianus River bridge was examined in detail here this week, under the glare of television lights and the pressure of lawsuits, in four days of hearings.

title: PACE TRIPLE CROWN TO RALPH HANOVER
description: Ralph Hanover won a nine-horse race-off by an impressive four lengths today to capture the 38th Little Brown Jug and become pacing's seventh triple crown champion.

title: GOLD MINING PROJECT IN ALASKA WATERS QUESTIONED
description: A proposed offshore gold mining venture in the Bering Sea near Nome is being held up by environmentalists and Alaskan Eskimos. They fear it may jeopardize marine and other wildlife in the area, including gray whales, an endangered species, which frequent nearby waters.

title: GENERALS ARE SOLD TO TRUMP
description: The Generals have a new owner and soon may also have a new head coach.

title: Street Fairs This Weekend
description: Street fair, Bayard Street, between Mulberry and Mott Streets. Today and tomorrow, 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. Community-information booths. Rain dates, next Friday and Saturday.

title: ; GIVE THE CONSUMER A STAKE IN CONTAINING MEDICARE
description: To the Editor:

title: Watt Calling Panel Members
description: Doug Baldwin, a spokesman for the Secretary of the Interior, said today that Mr. Watt was calling each member of the special commission reviewing his coal-leasing policies to apologize.

title: Rep. Gramm Will Seek Seat Vacated by Tower
description: Representative Phil Gramm announced today that he would run for the Senate seat being vacated by John Tower, Republican of Texas. Mr. Gramm predicted his recent switch from the Democratic to the Republican Party would not hurt his chances.

title: I.M.F. Loan Cutback Seen
description: The International Monetary Fund will cut back on some existing commitments and will not start any new talks on helping poor countries solve their financial troubles, people familiar with the I.M.F. said today.

title: Mexico Plans to Devalue
description: Mexico will gradually devalue pesos traded at the ''free'' exchange rate beginning tomorrow, the Bank of Mexico announced tonight.

title: The Smoke in Manila's Guns
description: The bells in Manila no longer toll for Benigno Aquino, the opposition leader treacherously slain a month ago. They toll now for the erratic and arrogant Marcos dictatorship. President Ferdinand Marcos may still cling to power with the familiar weapons of a floundering tyranny - clubs and tear gas, bluster and blackmail. But whatever moral authority or legitimacy he once possessed expired with the still unexplained death of his most commanding rival.

title: WRONG MOVE ON WRIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: FATHER WINS CUSTODY FIGHT BY POLITICALLY DIVIDED COUPLE
description: A judge today granted temporary custody of 12-year- old Riva Fishman to her father, who refused two years ago to return the child to her mother.

title: Koch to Wed
description: Wedding bells will ring at Gracie Mansion on Sunday. The groom's name is Koch.

title: WAR POWERS BILL WINS INITIAL APPROVAL
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee approved a compromise today that would continue the deployment of American troops in Lebanon for an additional 18 months.

title: Article 183784 -- No Title
description: Dunlop Holdings P.L.C., one of the world's largest tire makers, confirmed that it had agreed to the sale of the greater part of its European tire interests to Sumitomo Rubber Industries of Japan for $123 million. As a condition of the deal, Dunlop will be required to sell its own 40 percent holding in Sumitomo to such buyers as Sumitomo may nominate.

title: DURO-TEST reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Race in Central Park
description: About 1,500 women are expected to take part tomorrow in the fourth Avon Half Marathon through Central Park, which begins at 9 A.M. Runners will complete a 13.1-mile course around the park, beginning at the East Drive and 69th Street and ending at Tavern on the Green at West 67th Street.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective. Corrections, also on this page, continue to deal with factual errors.

title: 8 FRENCH JETS HIT MILITIA POSITIONS IN LEBANON CLASH
description: French jet fighters attacked anti-Government gun batteries behind Syrian lines in mountains east of Beirut today, shortly after a barrage of rockets rained down on French and Italian troops in the capital.

title: IT'S FALL, AND CITY'S FANCY TURNS TO FAIRS AND PARADES
description: TO connoisseurs of street fairs New York City, this weekend will be something of a smorgasbord. On Sunday, 13 blocks of Columbus Avenue will be lined with displays of the Upper West Side's crafts and cuisines, 52d Street will play host to jazz bands, folk musicians and flamenco dancers, and Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn will offer 12 blocks of antiques, clowns, floats and food.

title: CHICAGO BUSINES WATCHES WITH APPREHENSION AS MAYOR AND COUNCIL BATTLE
description: When Mayor Harold Washington made public his final transition report Tuesday, it was signed by several of the city's leading business figures, including executives of Standard Oil, Inland Steel, Commonwealth Edison, Arthur Andersen and Johnson Products.

title: SEARCH GOES ON FOR JET'SBLACK BOX
description: The commander of United States search operations in the Sea of Japan said today that Navy ships had ''some reasonable prospect'' of finding the vital recording instruments of the South Korean passenger plane shot down by Soviet fighters three weeks ago.

title: GULTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-After a loss of $640,000 from discontinued operations. Results do not include the operations of Grinnell Systems Corp. which was acquired on Sept. 19.

title: JOUSTERS AND JUGGLERS AT THE CLOISTERS
description: At the Cloisters on Sunday, the Middle Ages will come to life again.

title: MGIC Unit Sells Policies to CNA
description: The MGIC Indemnity Corporation announced the sale of more than half its policies, primarily officers' and directors' liability insurance, to the CNA Financial Corporation.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Neil Pilsen , president of CBS Television Sports, said he was one of several candidates for the position of baseball commissioner to succeed Bowie Kuhn. . . . Lasse Viren , the Finish distance runner who won the 5,000- and 10,000-meter runs at both the 1972 and 1976 Olympics, said he would run in the New York City Marathon next month in preparation for the 1984 Olympics. . . . Jimmy Arias , who reached the semifinals of the United States Open tennis tournament, has contracted mononucleosis and will be sidelined for a month.

title: Tomorrow, the Decision
description: In the morning, two men in crewneck sweaters were leaning against a marine art store only a block from where the America's Cup yachts are docked.

title: FOLLY AND FLIGHT 7
description: President Reagan has thoughtlessly endorsed the suggestion that United Nations delegates who think the United States may have failed its host-country obligations should get out. The idea, he said, would have ''the hearty approval of most people in America.''

title: CORRECTION
description: The Sports of The Times column Tuesday incorrectly described Buddy Young's standing among black football players. Numerous all-America teams are selected each year by various organizations, but several black players in addition to Fritz Pollard are regarded as having preceded Mr. Young as all-Americans.

title: NASA IN DEAL WITH FAIRCHILD
description: In a step to promote commercial operations in space, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration signed an agreement yesterday with Fairchild Industries for the development of a privately owned space platform on which industrial and Government customers could rent slots for payloads.

title: AUCTIONS
description: 145 Years of transport.

title: KREMLIN RENEWS MISSILE WARNINGS
description: The Chief of the Soviet General Staff, Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, renewed warnings today that the Kremlin would reply to new United States medium-range missile deployments in Western Europe with ''response measures'' that would pose an equal military threat to the United States and Western Europe.

title: Awake in Wonderland
description: ''There was a table set out under a tree in front of the house,'' Lewis Carroll wrote, ''and the March Hare and the Hatter were having tea at it: a Dormouse was sitting between them, fast asleep . . .''

title: U.A.W. WINS RECOGNITION AT COAST G.M.-TOYOTA PLANT
description: The United Automobile Workers union has been recognized as the bargaining agent at a plant in Fremont, Calif., where General Motors and Toyota will jointly produce small cars, the union and the companies announced today.

title: RANSBURG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
BRAKES AT ISSUE IN CASE CHARGING MURDER BY AUTO
description: A friend of a man accused of running over a boy because of ethnic bias testified today that the defendant had always been able to stop his car when he wanted to despite bad brakes.

title: REAGAN MIGHT CUT HIS TRIP TO MAINILA
description: A White House official said today that clashes between Philippine security forces and anti-Government demonstrators in Manila might make it ''very difficult'' for President Reagan to proceed with a visit to the Philippines. Wednesday night and early today at least 11 people were reported killed and more than 200 wounded as demonstrators tried to march on the presidential palace in Manila.

title: UP 14.23
description: The stock market, propelled by a late rally in the credit markets and a favorable short interest report, made a strong advance yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at a new high for the second time this week.

title: INTERNATIONAL MULTIFOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
ICL Chairman Named
description: Sir Michael Edwardes will succeed Sir Christopher Laidlaw as chairman of ICL P.L.C., Britain's major computer maker, the company announced today. He will join the board of directors on Oct. 1 and will take over as chairman next April 2, when Mr. Laidlaw will retire.

title: Topics On Screen, on Deck, Floating Mosque
description: What do an Islamic mosque and a yacht have in common? Only one thing: A visitor is unwelcome if he is wearing street shoes. In the case of the mosque, religious custom is responsible for the insistence that all who enter leave their shoes at the door.

title: PEACETIME ARMY ACTION IN 'FOR LOVE AND HONOR'
description: ''FOR LOVE AND HONOR,'' a new series making its debut as a two-hour movie on Channel 4 tonight at 9, is being presented as ''a realistic depiction of the peacetime Army.'' If so, the country is in worse condition than chronic worriers imagine. The show's 88th Airborne Division has been transformed into something like a college dormitory, resulting in something between ''Animal House'' and ''An Officer and a Gentleman.''

title: DISCLOSURE OF OFFICERS' PAY EASED
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today reduced the amount of information about management compensation that companies must disclose. The new rule is effective immediately.

title: Tale of TwoCities: Koch Does Battle
description: New York's Mayor said yesterday that he liked Detroit, that it was a very nice place to visit, but that, really, it was the ''pits.''

title: Sun Ra at Jazzmania
description: Sun Ra and his big band will play at Jazzmania, 40 West 27th Street, tonight and tomorrow for a ''dance party,'' from 9 P.M. to 3 A.M. Admission is $5 before 9 P.M., $10 afterward. Information: 532-7666.

title: ALLEGHANY TALKS SEEN
description: Shares of the Alleghany Corporation advanced sharply on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday amid signs of talks with the American Express Company to resurrect a $1 billion merger proposal.

title: AFTER 3 YEARS IRAN-IRAQ WAR IS A SMOLDERING STALEMATE
description: The war between Iraq and Iran, which entered its fourth year this week, appears to Western intelligence services to be entering a point of no return in which each side is contemplating action that could destroy any hope of a lasting peace. One element in the strategic situation is the delivery of five French Super Etendard bombers armed with Exocet missiles to Iraq. The arrival of these aircraft and their French-trained pilots raises an immediate threat to Kharg Island, the main Iranian oil port in the northern Persian Gulf, and to other Iranian oil ports.

title: A Black-Tie Gala In Midtown, Too
description: Film buffs eager for a black-tie Hollywood gala may have one Sunday at 7 P.M., when the National Film Society presents a 50-year career- achievement award to James Cagney at the Sheraton-Centre Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 52d Street.

title: Iowa Connection
description: After Bernie Wyatt scored 170 points as a tailback for the Amityville (L.I.) High School football team in 1956, he was recruited to the University of Iowa by an assistant coach for the Hawkeyes, Whitey Piro, another native Long Islander.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Business People column Tuesday incorrectly identified the executive vice president and chief operating officer of the General Cinema Corporation. He is Robert J. Tarr Jr.

title: A TRIBUTE TO A SENATOR AND BIPARTISAN GIVING
description: It's the kind of invitation to a $1,000-a-plate fund-raising dinner that demands a second reading.

title: WATT ASKS THAT REAGAN FORGIVE 'OFFENSIVE' REMARK ABOUT PANEL
description: Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt asked President Reagan's forgiveness today for making a ''morally offensive'' statement in describing an advisory panel as ideally balanced for including ''a black, a woman, two Jews and a cripple.''

title: APPLE EXPECTS BIG EARNINGS DECLINE
description: Apple Computer Inc. said yesterday that earnings for its fourth fiscal quarter ending Sept. 30 would be ''sharply lower'' than its earnings in that period last year.

title: BRIEFS
description: Bergen Brunswig Corp., Los Angeles, announced that it had signed a letter of intent to acquire the Stanley Drug Co. of San Antonio Inc., a pharmaceutical products distributor, for an undisclosed amount of cash and stock.

title: GUITAR CONCERT: YVES STORM
description: THE Wednesday evening debut concert of Yves Storms at Cami Hall revealed the young Belgian guitarist as an artist with a command of both the intricacies of the Baroque and the musical impressionism of Joaquin Rodrigo, Antonio Lauro and Isaac Albeniz.

title: MUSEUMS MARK METROPOLITAN OPERA'S CENTENNIAL
description: The Metropolitan Opera turns 100 this year. And although the centennial season doesn't officially start until Monday, the celebration is already well under way.

title: SOUTHERN INDIANA GAS & ELECTRIC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Steinbrenner Report
description: George Steinbrenner has been cleared of allegations made by a former University of Florida football player who said he received illegal recruiting inducements from the Yankee owner, according to a published report. A spokesman for Steinbrenner, Phil McNiff , told The Tampa Tribune that Steinbrenner met Tuesday with L. Douglas Johnson , an enforcement agent for the National Collegiate Athletic Association, concerning accusations made by the athlete, Joseph Portale .

title: METS BEATEN BY CARDINALS, 3-2
description: Frank Howard said today that he had ''no clue'' to whether he would be kept as manager of the Mets, and added:

title: SCREEN: ITALY'S 'ERNESTO,' TEEN-AGE REBEL IN 1911
description: IF there is a border that separates the journeymen among film makers from the artists, then it may well be positioned where the talent to observe human behavior ends and the genius to illuminate it begins.

title: Addendum
description: * PC Tech Journal is increasing its frequency from a monthly to a bi- weekly, and raising by 36 percent its advertising rates and circulation rate base, to 150,000 from 110,000, effective January.

title: TRENTON POLITICS MIRED IN CONFLICT OVER A JUDGE
description: It has been an anxious two weeks in this capital city, a time when partisan politics has given way to a classic battle over the balance of power.

title: ELECTRO RENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
2 Women Appeal Fire Dept. Action
description: Two women seeking to overturn their dismissals as New York City firefighters charged yesterday that the dismissals were unjustified acts of ''retaliation'' and ''humiliation.''

title: 'DEAR ABBY' EXPLAINS ERROR ON INEQUITY IN SOME BENEFITS
description: The columnist Abigail Van Buren, heeding Government advice, is correcting information she published that prompted a flood of letters to Congress and the Social Security Administration.

title: SQUAD REDUCES CHINATOWN VIOLENCE ON COAST
description: Six years after the murders of five innocent diners at the Golden Dragon Restaurant shocked and angered the community, a special police strike force has all but ended gang-related violence on the streets of Chinatown.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ACCEPTING the U.S.O.'s Gold Medal Award, Danny Kaye addressed his audience as ''generals, admirals, commanders and civilians.'' He didn't mention captains, lieutenants and chief boatswain's mates, whose dress uniforms added a lot of color to the crowd of more than 1,000. They had come for cocktails, dinner and dancing in the hangar bays of the Sea-Air-Space Museum on the aircraft carrier Intrepid. Tickets were $250 each, and the U.S.O. was the beneficiary.

title: SCREEN: 'FINAL OPTION,' ANTINUCLEAR PROTESTERS
description: ''THIS is being done in the name of peace!,'' sneers the terrorist, who is wearing a machine gun over her strapless evening gown. She has captured a group of American diplomats, and in exchange for these hostages she is demanding that a smallish nuclear explosion be arranged and televised. This, she says, will be an unusual and certainly attention-getting way of making the world aware of the need for disarmament.

title: Coltrane on WKCR
description: WKCR, 88.9 FM, is celebrating John Coltrane's birthday with 16 hours of his music, from 5 A.M. to 9 P.M. today. The number for more information is 280-5223.

title: PHILLIES SWEEP THE EXPOS BY 9-7 AND 7-1
description: Charles Hudson, a rookie, pitched a four-hitter and Len Matuszek drove in two runs as the surging Philadelphia Phillies defeated the Montreal Expos, 7-1, tonight and completed a sweep of a doubleheader.

title: MUSIC: CITY OPERA PERFORMS 'TURANDOT'
description: THE New York City Opera does keep you off balance. The company, which opened triumphantly with Massenet's exquisite fairy-tale opera, ''Cendrillon,'' came back last night with a more heavy-handed kind of tale, Puccini's ''Turandot,'' as its second offering. Puccini's work, which he did not live to finish, calls for hefty voices and grandiose staging, both of which the City Opera was able to provide. What it could not offer, however, was a ''Turandot'' that went beyond noisy sensation. The blame goes first of all to Puccini himself, who never wrote a more empty or brutal work, but it must be shared by Franco Alfano, who finished the last act in the same crude style after Puccini's death. On this occasion, too, the opera got little help from the two leading singers or the conductor.

title: BROADWAY
description: Al Pacino bringing American Buffalo' back to New York.

title: U.N. LEADER HEARS 'NO SERIOUS TALK' OF MORE
description: The new president of the General Assembly said today that there had been ''no serious talk'' in either the East or West of moving the United Nations out of the United States.

title: Coleco's Adam Near
description: Coleco Industries' new Adam computer has been certified as meeting Federal Communications Commission standards, clearing a hurdle for the system to be marketed, Coleco said yesterday.

title: SUMMER DIES BUT THE CITY COMES ALIVE
description: The city's pace quickens now, as temperatures decline and the days grow shorter. From the beach and the country, from out of the caves that were their darkened air-conditioned apartments, the people return and are revitalized.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Allegheny Beverage Corp., Cheverly, Md., has named D. B. McLaughlin Jr. president of its building services operations, Macke Building Services Inc.

title: Poor Outlook For New Jobs
description: Although there are ''clear signs'' of an economic recovery in the Western industrial nations and Japan, this upswing ''does not seem likely to make inroads into unemployment for some time,'' the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development warned today.

title: SLIM, PROFITABLE NATIONAL STEEL
description: The National Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh, after one of the worst years in its own and the industry's history, may well be the only major steel company to report an operating profit in 1983.

title: 7-STATION RULE CHANGE URGED
description: The Federal Communications Commission proposed today the elimination or relaxation of restrictions governing the multiple ownership of television and radio stations.

title: BASSETT FURNITURE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
DOCTOR CONVICTED OF RAPES
description: A doctor charged with raping 21 women and terrorizing nine others in the Columbus area was convicted on 60 counts today by a jury that rejected his insanity plea.

title: ORDERS OF DURABLE GOODS RISE
description: Orders to factories for durable goods rose three-tenths of 1 percent last month, with strong gains by some industries mostly offset by a big drop for military hardware, the Commerce Department said today.

title: GOLDEN ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in May.

title: HOW PARENTS VIEW EDUCATION
description: While most American parents believe that a primary purpose of education is to equip children for financial success, an even greater number of them cite enhancement of the quality of life as an important goal, according to a new nationwide study.

title: REAGAN HALTED GROWTH IN NONCASH AID PROGRAMS
description: The Census Bureau said today that changes in Federal aid programs made at President Reagan's request prevented an increase in the total number of households receiving food stamps, Medicaid and other benefits last year despite an increase in poverty and unemployment.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: Upgraded choice; decorative Thai.

title: Boy Found Stabbed to Death
description: The body of a 13-year-old newspaper carrier who disappeared Sunday while on his paper route was found by searchers Wednesday on a gravel road three miles south of here. The authorities said the boy, Danny Joe Eberle, had been stabbed to death. A $23,500 reward fund was established for information in the case.

title: TII INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 24
description: b-Net income The share earnings for all periods are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend which was effective June 24. The loss for fiscal 1983 was caused primarily by a writedown in inventory of $2,805,000 in the first quarter and by absorption of $698,000 in net expenses of its affiliate, TII Computer Systems Inc.

title: OILERS TRADING FOR THE FUTURE
description: No team in the National Football League has fared quite so badly as the Houston Oilers since the strike last season. In their final seven regular-season games in 1982 and three this season, the Oilers are without a victory, and earlier this week they traded their starting quarterback Archie Manning and the tight end David Casper to the Minnesota Vikings for a second- and a fourth-round draft choice next year.

title: Topics On Screen, on Deck; Words and Music
description: The Canadians have created something that makes opera understandable and accessible to many who love the music but can't understand the words. It's called ''surtitles,'' the live-theatrical equivalent of English subtitles, projected above the stage's proscenium arch.

title: Redman at Sweet Basil
description: The tenor saxophonist Dewey Redman will lead a quartet tonight and tomorrow at Sweet Basil (242-1785), 88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street. Sets begin at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. There is a $7.50 cover and a $5 minimum.

title: JACK T. KVERNLAND
description: Jack T. Kvernland, a former executive of the Prudential Life Insurance Company, died yesterday at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J. He was 66 years old and lived in Monmouth Beach, N.J.

title: SAVING THE THEATERS
description: Midway through a long year of meetings on how best to preserve Broadway's 44 legitimate theaters, an advisory council appointed by Mayor Koch was addressed last March by its only actor-member, Ellen Burstyn, the president of the 32,000- member Actors Equity union. She said: ''I wish I could express to you the incomparable joy of being on a stage in a theater like the Nederlander Theater and to sit very quietly and in a very soft voice say a line of potent intimacy and feel the audience listen - feel them stop breathing - and, saying the line, hold the pause so long that the whole room comes together in one point of focus.

title: WHY NOT MAKE ENGLISH MONOLINGUALS BILINGUAL?
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAN GAINS FOR FIRST OUTDOOR TEST OF GENETICALLY ALTERED PLANT LIFE
description: An advisory committee to the National Institutes of Health has tentatively endorsed the first outdoor field test of a genetically engineered organism by an industrial concern, according to sources involved in the decision.

title: FILM: EARLY ROCK DAYS, 'EDDIE AND THE CRUISERS'
description: THERE hasn't yet been a successful movie about the early days of rock-and-roll, even though the subject is certainly capable of generating a lot of emotion. Not even the better efforts in this genre, from ''Stardust'' and ''The Idolmaker'' to ''The Buddy Holly Story,'' have captured anything akin to the excitement of the music itself. The behind-the-scenes drama - the wild ambition, the wheeling and dealing, the image making - convey such different sentiments from the music's explosive, euphoric feeling that there's bound to be a built-in incongruity, for one thing. For another, rock seems to be much more easily embodied than explained.

title: CORRECTION
description: A biographical sketch in Metropolitan Report yesterday misidentified the court in which Justice Donald J. Sullivan sits. It is the Appellate Term of State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: BAR GROUP BACKS TRIAL JUDGE
description: Criticism of the Federal judge who presided over the espionage conspiracy trial of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg was ''unwarranted and without merit,'' a 153-page report by an American Bar Association subcommittee has concluded.

title: THEATER: 'DREAMGIRLS,' CAST AND TEXT CHANGES
description: ''DREAMGIRLS'' is a big, lavish, long-running Broadway musical that is exciting precisely because it doesn't coddle the audience in the way that such Broadway musicals often do. Seeing the show again - with some new performers in principal roles and some recently inserted revisions in the second act - I was struck once more by the many risks that the director Michael Bennett and his collaborators take with what might have been another backstage show-biz saga.

title: Sacrificing Judges in the Bronx
description: The arrogance of Stanley Friedman, the Bronx Democratic leader, strips the last veil of legitimacy from New York's system for picking trial judges. The notion that the people elect the justices of the Supreme Court, the state's principal trial court, stands exposed as pure fiction.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Week's Car Output Up
description: Auto makers in the United States plan to build 157,731 cars this week, up 5.4 percent from last week's 149,699, an industry journal said today. The level is also 54.6 percent higher than the 102,038 cars built in the corresponding week a year ago, Ward's Automotive Reports said. So far this year, domestic auto makers have built 4,740,917 cars, up 24.9 percent from the comparable 1982 period, Ward's said.

title: Article 184750 -- No Title
description: Democratic leaders succeeded today in winning House approval of $300 million more for education and job training. The action came as the House passed a $96.5 billion measure to finance a broad range of social service programs.

title: Jurors Award $15 Million To Victim of Hyatt Disaster
description: A jury awarded $15 million Wednesday night to a woman who was left paralyzed from the neck down by the collapse of a suspended walkway at the Hyatt Regency hotel. It was the largest single award resulting from the disaster, which left 114 people dead and at least 239 injured in 1981.

title: JIM DANCE
description: Jim Dance, who wrote the column ''Minority Report'' for The Miami Herald, died at Doctors Hospital Wednesday.

title: LEARN LATIN AMERICA'S CULTURE
description: The Kissinger panel on Central America doubts that its long-term recommendations can be ready before 1984. It might be excused for taking a bit longer if it addressed the one consideration that has frustrated earlier efforts in dealing with Latin America - our fundamental, dogged, appalling ignorance of the Latin mind and culture.

title: PUBLISHING: CONGRESS HONORS L'AMOUR
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN is scheduled to present a Congressional gold medal tomorrow afternoon to Louis L'Amour, the best-selling writer of westerns. The medal, struck by the United States Mint, was voted ''in recognition of his distinguished career as an author and his contribution to the nation through his historically based works.''

title: John T. DeGraff Dies; Former Law Examiner
description: John Teller DeGraff, president of the state's Board of Law Examiners for 20 years, died Monday at his retirement home in Tucson, Ariz. He was 81 years old.

title: TO BUILD A LIBRARY, SOME CHAIRS GO UP FOR BID
description: What do people think of Jimmy Carter these days?

title: Bitter Times For Witherspoon
description: Tim Witherspoon, who came close to upsetting Larry Holmes in a heavyweight title bout May 20, says he has had only five days of serious training for tonight's scheduled 12-round bout against James (Quick) Tillis. At yesterday's weigh-in for the Michael Dokes-Gerrie Coetzee card, Witherspoon said he did not put in much effort because ''I don't care anymore.''

title: HAVANA TO THE BLUE NOTE WITH PAQUITO D'RIVERA
description: LIKE a lot of jazz musicians, Paquito d'Rivera had dreamed of coming to New York since childhood. He was 6 or 7 years old and already learning to play saxophone from his father, when he heard Benny Goodman's ''Live at Carnegie Hall'' album and knew he wanted to live in New York. Mr. d'Rivera practiced eight and nine hours a day, working his way up the local circuit in dance bands and jazz groups until he was co-leader of the best group in town, an outfit called Irakere.

title: Blizzard Going To First Bowl
description: David Byrne and Neill Roberts scored tonight to give the Toronto Blizzard a berth in the Soccer Bowl with a 2-0 victory over the Golden Bay Earthquakes. The victory, before a crowd of 15,556, gave Toronto a sweep of its two-of three semifinal series with the Earthquakes and marked the first time in the Blizzard's five-year history that it has advanced to thechampionship game. Toronto will meet the winner of the Montreal-Tulsa series in the Soccer Bowl, Oct. 1, in Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday JUDAS' AT THE COCTEAU

title: Writer in Hitler Hoax Now Faces Rearrest
description: The state prosecutor said today that he would demand the rearrest of the reporter implicated in the Hitler diary hoax on suspicion he pocketed $650,000 in the $3.75 million swindle.

title: DISCOUNTER SUES THREE OVER IZODS
description: Toys ''R'' Us, the nation's largest toy retailer and discounter, filed an antitrust suit yesterday against three companies that it said conspired to prevent it from selling Izod children's apparel at reduced prices.

title: CARL F. GRANRUD
description: Carl F. Granrud, former board chairman and chief executive of Lutheran Brotherhood, a fraternal life insurance society with headquarters here, died Tuesday.

title: Chinese Sets Jump Record
description: Zhu Jianhua of China broke the world record in the high jump today, leaping 7 feet 9 3/4 inches at the national track and field championships, Xinhua, China's news agency, reported. An overflow crowd in Shanghai's 30,000-seat Hongkou Stadium watched the 20-year-old, 6-foot-4-inch Zhu break the previous record, which he set in June, by half an inch. Today's effort followed a disappointing showing by Zhu at the world track and field championships in Helsinki, Finland, last month, when he jumped only 7-6 and finished third. ''I was not in my best form in Helsinki,'' Zhu said.

title: Vice President Out at Ashland
description: Bill E. McKay Jr., a vice president of the Ashland Oil Company who publicly disclosed a questionable payment that the company made to acquire foreign crude oil in 1981, was dismissed from his job this week, Ashland said yesterday. A spokesman for Ashland, the nation's largest independent oil refining company, said Mr. McKay was ''terminated from his job on Monday, effective immediately.'' The spokesman, Dan Lacy, added that the action was ''absolutely not related'' to Mr. McKay's role in the disclosure of the foreign payment. Mr. McKay could not be reached for comment despite repeated calls to his home in Ashland, Ky., where the company is situated.

title: AIR EXPERTS WORK ON A NEW SAFETY PLAN
description: Aviation experts are working on measures that they think could go far in preventing a repetition of the South Korean airliner disaster.

title: VISIT TO A VASSAR MANSION
description: Fifteen Hudson Valley designers have transformed a 20-room Tudor- style mansion into a showplace that will be open to the public for inspection starting tomorrow in Poughkeepsie.

title: BRINKMAN L D reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $958,000 for the quarter and $629,000 for the year.

title: Books: Bloomsburian
description: VANESSA BELL. By Frances Spalding. 399 pages. Ticknor & Fields. $22.95.

title: Mr. Watt's Disabling Offense
description: What can you make of Mr. Watt? Time and again the Secretary of the Interior gratuitously offends groups of his fellow citizens, be they Indians, Jews, liberals or the Beach Boys. Each time he expresses regret, but the pattern persists. This time he has forfeited any benefit of doubt. Mr. Watt speaks as he thinks, and his style of thought, quite apart from his objectionable policies, is unacceptable.

title: PRICES MOVE SHARPLY HIGHER
description: Yesterday's auction of $3.5 billion of 20-year Treasury bonds - in the past the most difficult of all Treasury issues to sell - turned out to be the catalyst for heavy institutional buying and a brisk rally in the bond market.

title: S A L CABLE COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income

title: GRAND CENTRAL, INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $930,000, or 41 cents a share, from the sale of a store lease. c-Net loss d-After the net effect of an accounting change of $341,694.

title: OWNER OF NEWSPAPER FOR HAITIAN EMIGRES IS SLAIN IN BROOKLYN
description: The owner of a Haitian newspaper published in New York City, who had reported death threats because of his criticism of the Haitian regime, was shot to death Wednesday night outside his Brooklyn home, the police said yesterday.

title: SENATE VOTES TO CUT U.S. CONTRIBUTION TO U.N.
description: The Senate voted 66 to 23 tonight to drastically cut the United States contribution to the United Nations.

title: MCI PLAN TO DELIVER MESSAGES
description: The MCI Communications Corporation, the first to take on the giant Bell System in the long-distance telephone business, is to take on the Postal Service, Western Union, Federal Express and other giants in the message delivery business, industry sources said yesterday.

title: Required Reading 'Vietnam, a History'
description: McNamara had been a brilliant corporation executive who could scan a balance sheet with unerring speed and skill. When he made the first of his many trips to Vietnam in May 1962, he looked at the figures and concluded optimistically after only 48 hours in the country that ''every quantitative measurement . . . shows that we are winning the war.''

title: Advertising; Colgate Shifts to Y. & R.
description: WITH the same suddenness that marked the consolidation of the Chrysler account at Kenyon & Eckhardt in 1979, the giant soaper Colgate-Palmolive announced yesterday that Young & Rubicam, having resigned its remaining Procter & Gamble business, has been named Colgate's third worldwide agency.

title: ZAMBIAN SAYS U.S. ASSISTS PRETORIA
description: President Kenneth D. Kaunda, expressing frustration over the diplomatic stalemate in southern Africa, is now accusing the Reagan Administration of being an accomplice of South Africa in Angola.

title: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 23, 1983
description: International

title: Mexico Loan Payments
description: Reflecting improved liquidity, Mexico yesterday informed commercial bank creditors that by Dec. 15 it intended to pay lenders the remaining $560 million in private sector interest arrears that accumulated between August 1982 and January 1983.

title: Soviet Move Criticized
description: F. Don Miller , executive director of the United States Olympic Committee, chided the Soviet Union yesterday for canceling a six-game American hockey tour and called the Soviet fear for team members' safety a ''very, very hollow'' excuse. According to Tass, the official Soviet press agency, the Soviet ice hockey federation canceled the tour because ''there are serious fears'' for the safety of its team in light of American reaction to the recent downing of a South Korean passenger plane by a Soviet jet fighter.

title: Shultz Photo Carried A Misleading Caption
description: An Associated Press photograph of Secretary of State George P. Shultz distributed Wednesday night and published Thursday by The New York Times carried a misleading caption.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: LINDA RONSTADT AT MUSIC HALL: A NIGHT OF THE 50'S
description: WHEN Linda Ronstadt takes the stage of Radio City Music Hall tomorrow night, backed by the 47-piece Nelson Riddle Orchestra, it may well be the first time a rock star has publicly performed an evening of prerock standards using formal 1950's orchestrations. The repertory will include nine ballads that she and Mr. Riddle recorded for her latest album, ''What's New,'' plus two or three songs that were dropped from that record. Mr. Riddle will lead an orchestral interlude of his most famous arrangements for Frank Sinatra and other singers in the 1950's.

title: GERMANS ENLIST POLL-TAKERS IN MISSILE DEBATE
description: As the partisan debate sharpens over the projected stationing of American medium-range missiles in West Germany, opposition politicians are increasingly resorting to opinion polls to demonstrate that an overwhelming majority of the country is against the new weapons.

title: STREET URCHINS IN BRAZIL FIND A TOWN THAT CARES
description: In most respects, this town of 20,000 inhabitants on Brazil's vast tableland is like thousands of other towns across Latin America.

title: No Martial Law, Marcos Says
description: While President Marcos threatened obliquely in addressing his people today to reimpose martial law, he said in a subsequent interview for American audiences that he was ''not thinking of that now.''

title: No Headline
description: State Bank Rule Change

title: Fall to Be Welcomed
description: The autumnal equinox, the official beginning of fall, will be marked with a free celebration of music and magic today from 6 to 10 P.M. at the Central Park Bandshell, 72d Street, off Fifth Avenue.

title: DEVELOPER IN MANHATTAN PLANS SALES, THEN BUILDS
description: On the 25,000-square-foot parcel at the southeast corner of First Avenue and East 70th Street in Manhattan, the city zoning code would have let Bruce Eichner, the developer, construct a 27-story building with 10,000 square feet on each floor.

title: STANDUN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a loss of $4,000 from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $96,000 for the quarter and $518,000 for the 9 months. Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split effective Aug. 15.

title: TRIAL COMED TO END IN CRASH OF BOEING JET THAT KILLED 213
description: Both sides summed up their cases today in a damage suit in which the stakes are not only the claims of some 200 survivors of victims of an airliner crash but also the image of the Boeing 747 jumbo jet.

title: Chrysler Profit
description: The Chrysler Corporation will have a profit in the 1983 third quarter but it will be the weakest quarterly performance of the year, according to Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman.

title: MARLBORO FAVORS BATES MOTEL
description: Why should the Marlboro Cup tomorrow at Belmont Park turn out much differently from the Woodward Stakes three weeks ago? Slew o' Gold and Bates Motel, who finished a nose apart in that order and five lengths ahead of everyone else in the Woodward, will renew their rivalry and will be heavily favored to run away from Gato del Sol, Bold Style, Highland Blade, May Day Eighty, Sing Sing, Deputed Testamony and Hyperborean. It is difficult to pick between two horses who ran the race of the year and finished a few hairs apart last time out, but several factors favor Bates Motel to reverse the Woodward decision.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Investors GNMA Mortgage Backed Securities Trust Inc. is offering $500 million of bonds backed by a pool of Government National Mortgage Association mortgage pass-through certificates through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc.

title: G.O.P. Leader Backs Rejection of 2 Judges
description: State Senator John D. Calandra, the Bronx Republican leader, said yesterday that he would go along with the rejection of the renomination of two State Supreme Court judges and endorse three Democrats and a Liberal nominated by Bronx Democrats for four Supreme Court posts.

title: Bid for Wigmores
description: The Bell Group Ltd. has offered to purchase all the operating assets of the Wigmores Ltd. group for $40 million (Australian) on Dec. 31, both companies announced. This would give Wigmores a cash asset backing of $6.20 a share, they said. Wigmores is bidding for the shares of the Broken Hill Company.

title: CRACKING A SWISS BANK'S CODE
description: The possible breaching of the venerable Swiss system of bank-account codes, apparently through the use of high-powered computers, has led to a sharp exchange between the French Government and a leading Swiss bank.

title: TeinPlane'sFall
description: A judge ordered a mental examination today for a 27-year-old man accused of switching off the fuel to one of a commuter airliner's two engines on Wednesday, sending the plane into a sharp drop.

title: Tosco Projection
description: The Tosco Corporation said it may not return to profitability in the third quarter, as previously predicted. ''Our third-quarter operating results will show significant improvement over first- and second-quarter results, but the recent and rapid drop in gasoline prices on the West Coast has reduced product margins,'' said Matthew J. Talbot, president and chief executive officer.

title: IN BRUTAL CIVIL WAR, CHARGES OF ATROCITES ABOUND
description: Many innocent lives have been lost in the brutal fighting in the mountains around Beirut. Some of those lives - no one knows how many - may have been lost in massacres carried out by the Christian and Druse militiamen who are waging a civil war.

title: No Headline
description: A RIVER RUNS THROUGH IT. By Norman Maclean. Photographs by Joel Snyder. 124 pages. Illustrated. Chicago. $25.

title: No Headline
description: The Presumed kidnappers of Emanuela Orlandi, a 15-year-old schoolgirl, appeared today to have dropped a demand for the release of Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turk convicted of shooting Pope John Paul II two years ago.

title: Key Rates
description: * Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Woman Missing 5 Days Found in Wrecked Car
description: A 31-year-old woman missing five days was found alive Wednesday by a hitchhiker in the wreckage of her car, partly submerged in a creek, the authorities said.

title: Jets Send Out an S O S for Place-Kickers
description: He was back in his room at Syracuse University, reading a book on management, when the Jets called Russ Carpentieri on Wednesday and told him they might have a job for a place- kicker.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I warn the opposition, do not force my hand. Do not compel me to move into the extreme measures that you know of.

title: Mine Wounds 3 in Ulster
description: Guerrillas exploded a land mine that slightly wounded three parttime soldiers, the police said today. A police spokesman said the soldiers, members of the Ulster Defense Regiment, received superficial wounds in the attack Wednesday night near Gulladuff in County Londonderry. In other attacks late Wednesday, guerrillas bombed a gas station and an auto showroom in the city of Armagh and a lumberyard in Newry.

title: HARASSING GROMYKO DAMAGES U.S. IMAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: N.B.A. Referees File Grievance
description: National Basketball Association referees filed an unfair labor practice complaint with the National Labor Relations Board today, charging the league with a lockout.

title: Health Care Plans
description: The Justice Department has notified two groups that it does not intend to challenge their establishment of ventures to package and market medical and hospital services. The groups are the Health Care Management Associates of Moorestown, N.J., and the Hospital Corporation of America, Nashville.

title: Market Place; Mesa's Offer To KN Energy
description: WHEN the Mesa Petroleum Company made a bid last week for KN Energy Inc., a lot of people thought that T. Boone Pickens was just going through one of his profitable exercises again and was not entirely serious about acquiring the company.

title: OLMSTED CONFERENCE HAILS CREATOR OF URBAN PARKS
description: They are landscape architects, park historians, urban planners, community activists and park managers. They have come by the hundreds from all over the country, and even from abroad, to honor the man they believe was the greatest park maker of all: Frederick Law Olmsted.

title: BRIEFING
description: Assassination Anniversary

title: No Headline
description: Qiao Guanhua, a former Chinese Foreign Minister who fell into disgrace for his purported connections with the radical faction now castigated as the Gang of Four, died of lung cancer today. He was 70 years old.

title: New Pennzoil Unit Seeks Acquisitions
description: The Pennzoil Company, an oil and natural gas producer, said yesterday that it had received $261 million in financial backing from a group of outside investors to form a new company that would seek acquisitions in the oil and gas field.

title: ZONING BONUSES IN CITY PROVOKE HEATED DEBATE
description: Sharp disagreements among planners, elected officials and housing groups emerged at hearings that ended yesterday on zoning proposals that would reward builders with permission to build extra floor space if they contributed money for low- and moderate-income housing.

title: 3 WOMEN WHO LED RESCUE OF BUILDING IN SOUTH BRONX SEE HOPES FULFILLED
description: For four years it was Last Hope, the only building still standing, and still occupied, in a block of urban rubble in the South Bronx. With speeches, balloons and a marching band, Last Hope yesterday formally became New Hope Plaza and was welcomed as another sign of revitalization in a once-proud neighborhood.

title: IRVING LEHMAN
description: Irving Lehman, a painter and sculptor whose abstract expressionist works have been shown in galleries throughout the United States and abroad, died Sunday at a nursing home in Great Barrington, Mass. He was 83 years old and lived in East Chatham, N.Y., and Manhattan.

title: Esiason Won't Start
description: Boomer Esiason , Maryland's highly rated senior quarterback, will not start against Pittsburgh today and may not play at all, Coach Bobby Ross said yesterday. This would be the first time Esiason had failed to start for the Terrapins since he won the job in the second game of the 1981 season. The left-handed quarterback, hailed as a Heisman Trophy candidate before the season began, strained a ligament in his right shoulder against West Virginia last week.

title: Free Tests at Street Fair
description: Free testing for diabetes, hypertension, foot ailments and other medical problems will highlight a street festival on Sunday sponsored by the Stuyvesant Polyclinic, Second Avenue, between Ninth Street and St. Marks Place. The festival, which celebrates the 100th anniversary of the facility, will also include crafts, ethnic food and entertainment. Hours are noon to 5 P.M. The rain date is Oct. 2.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP BY 0.4%
description: Despite sharp increases for automobiles and gasoline, consumer prices rose only four-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Government reported today. Food prices rose for the first time since May although only slightly, beginning to reflect the effects of the summer drought.

title: SHIPS RETURN FIRE
description: Four United States marines were wounded tonight as shells, mortar rounds and small arms fire struck the Marine compound at the airport here. Two American warships and a Marine shore battery fired back.

title: Newton Goes Home
description: Jack Newton , the former Australian Open golf champion who was seriously injured after he walked into the spinning propeller of an airplane two months ago, left a Sydney hospital saying he was ''elated to be alive and going home.'' Newton lost his right arm, the sight of his right eye and suffered severe abdominal injuries in the accident.

title: STEELWORKERS APPROVE PLAN TO BUY THEIR OWN PLANT IN WEST VIRGINIA
description: Steelworkers here voted overwhelmingly today to buy the Weirton steel works and run the vast plant themselves.

title: Nicaraguan Rebels Report 2 Air Raids
description: Two small aircraft owned and operated by a Nicaraguan anti-Government guerrilla group made bombing raids in Nicaragua at 5 A.M. today, according to a spokesman for the rebel group here.

title: CARDINAL MEDEIROS TRIBUTE SURPRISES BOSTON CATHOLICS
description: More than 2,000 people jammed the old brown stone Holy Cross Cathedral beside an elevated subway line in the city's South End today for a funeral mass for the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Boston, Humberto Cardinal Medeiros.

title: 'WIND' FROM MALI AND 'REASSEMBLAGE' IN SENEGAL
description: Souleymane Cisse's ''Wind,'' from Mali, begins on a relatively lighthearted and familial note, though it may take New York Film Festival audiences a little while to untangle the family relationships that are being described.

title: DODGERS TROUNCE BRAVES, 11-2
description: Dusty Baker blasted a home run and drove in four runs and Ken Landreaux homered and drove in three as the Los Angeles Dodgers trounced Atlanta, 11-2, tonight and stretched their lead over the Braves to five and a half games in the National League's Western Division.

title: SAMUEL COZEN
description: Samuel Cozen, who in 15 years at Drexel University compiled a better record than any other basketball coach in the school's history, died Wednesday. He was 75 years old. Mr. Cozen retired in 1973, having led Drexel teams to 213 victories and 94 losses. He had arrived at the university from Overbrook High School in Philadelphia, where he once coached Wilt Chamberlain.

title: Apple's Stock Tumbles 25%
