description: Apple Computer Inc. lost a quarter of its market value in heavy trading yesterday after predicting ''sharply lower'' earnings for its fiscal fourth quarter, ending Sept. 30. Apple shares fell $8.25, to $24.25 bid, in over-the-counter trading.

title: Change for Better
description: Change for Better

title: Northwest Energy Stake
description: An investment group headed Ivan F. Boesky has increased its share of the Northwest Energy Corporation of Salt Lake City to 9.5 percent in a deal whose total worth is $60.1 million, according to records filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Howe of Dodgers Is Suspended Again
description: Steve Howe, the Los Angeles Dodger relief pitcher, was suspended indefinitely yesterday after he missed the team's charter flight to Atlanta and then refused to take tests to detect possible drug use.

title: QUESTIONS RAISED ON PROPOSALS TO SAVE THEATERS
description: Leaders in the theater industry have questioned two current proposals to save Broadway theaters, arguing that the plans would not guarantee the perpetuation of the buildings as theaters.

title: Seoul Gas Import Delay
description: South Korea's plan to import one million tons of liquefied natural gas annually beginning in 1989 will be delayed, probably until the middle of the 1990's, the Resources Ministry said today.

title: Heavy Clashes Reported In Salvadoran Province
description: Heavy fighting was reported today from San Vicente Province, centerpiece of a United States-promoted campaign to win the support of the rural population.

title: Jump in Gas Pressure Brings Boston Fires
description: Surging pressure in natural gas pipes caused several fires and an apparent explosion in East Boston early this morning, sending hundreds of residents into the streets in their night clothes.

title: FOSTER-CARE PLAN SET IN NEW MEXICO
description: New Mexico's entire foster-care system has been placed under the long-term control of a Federal District Court by an order signed here today.

title: Terminal Art
description: It's going to be four times bigger than the 1913 Armory Show that shocked the public and changed the course of art. But how it will compare otherwise is anybody's guess.

title: Officer Sentenced for Taking Bribes From After-Hours Club
description: A former police sergeant, John P. DeLuca of the Ninth Precinct in Manhattan, was sentenced to two years in prison yesterday for taking payoffs from an after-hours club.

title: CARLTON ATTAINS 300TH VICTORY
description: Steve Carlton tonight became the 16th pitcher in baseball history to win 300 games when he pitched the Philadelphia Phillies to a 6-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals and ran their winning streak to eight games.

title: Letter: From ACDA Building a Base for Arms Control To the Editor:
description: Your editorial of Aug. 27 noted the constructive steps President Reagan is taking to ''rearm'' the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency (ACDA) to insure that it is a strong and effective force in formulating and implementing U.S. arms control policies. We are very well pleased with the concrete steps the President has taken to strengthen ACDA's funding, staff and clout. The Times's caution regarding these moves may be fair at this stage, but the false and incomplete reports in the editorial are not fair to your readers.

title: UTILITY ASSAILS CRITICISM OF 3 MILE ISLAND
description: The utility in charge of cleaning up the damaged Three Mile Island nuclear reactor charged today that a recent critical evaluation from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission was narrow, unfair and ''misleading to the public.''

title:
PATENTS;
Activating Genes to Aid In Treatment of Disease
description: Means of identifying and activating genes, so that they can be used to produce recombinants potentially useful in the diagnosis and treatment of disease, have been invented for the Department of Health and Human Services by staff members. Patent 4,405,712 was granted this week to George F. Vande Woude and three co-inventors. They are researchers for the National Cancer Institute.

title: 'L'ARGENT,' 13TH FEATURE BY BRESSON
description: That Robert Bresson, the veteran French director, is still one of the most rigorous and talented film makers of the world is evident with the appearance of his beautiful, astringent new film, ''L'Argent,'' which will be shown at the New York Film Festival in Lincoln Center today at 12:30 P.M. and tomorrow at 7 P.M. Mr. Bresson does not make films casually - ''L'Argent'' is only his 13th since his first feature, ''Les Anges du Peche'' (Angels of the Streets), was released in 1943.

title: C.I.T.'S BUSINESS: BROAD-BASED LENDING
description: The giant C.I.T. Financial Corporation is one of the country's largest financial companies. Its main business is lending money, and it owns divisions that will lend money for everything from an airplane to an education.

title: WATT TOLD BY BAKER HOLD ON INTERIOR JOB IS IN SERIOUS TROUBLE
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, gave Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt a grim assessment today of his standing on Capitol Hill amid mounting demands for Mr. Watt's resignation.

title: Columbia Student Drowns
description: A man whose body was found on the beach here Wednesday was identified today as Sheldon Scheps, a 34-year-old student at Columbia University who lived on West 118th Street in Manhattan, the East Hampton police said. They said that a friend, Arthur Biderman of Hollis, Queens, told them he had fallen asleep on the beach while Mr. Scheps was swimming.

title: No Headline
description: THE HEALING HEART. Antidotes to Panic and Helplessness. By Norman Cousins. Introduction by Bernard Lown, M.D. Afterwords by K. I. Shine, M.D., David S. Cannom, M.D., Omar Fareed, M.D., and William M. Hitzig, M.D. 288 pages. W. W. Norton. $13.95. IN his recent book, ''Anatomy of an

title: PRESIDENT'S WAR JET IS TO BE BASED FARTHER INLAND
description: Plans to evacuate the President from the White House in a nuclear war have been changed so that a helicopter would whisk him from the White House lawn directly out of Washington rather than to a jet at a nearby air base, a Government official said today.

title: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 24, 1983
description: International

title: DOKES LOSES TITLE TO COETZEE
description: Gerrie Coetzee, a 28-year-old South African whose two earlier title fights ended in defeat, knocked out previously undefeated Michael Dokes tonight to capture the World Boxing Association heavyweight championship.

title: SENATE UNIT BACKS LEBANON MEASURE
description: After a sharp debate over the Reagan Administration's policy in the Middle East, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted along party lines today to approve a resolution that would authorize United States Marines to remain in Lebanon for another 18 months.

title: AMERICAN COMMITMENT TO A SECURE LEBANON
description: To the Editor:

title: Options Start On Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange entered the options business yesterday as trading began in an option on its composite index.

title: HANOVER BUYS C.I.T. FROM RCA
description: In a major expansion of its nationwide network, the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to buy the RCA Corporation's big financial services arm, the C.I.T. Financial Corporation, for $1.5 billion. Manufacturers Hanover said it was the biggest acquisition ever by a bank holding company.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: Koch Is 'Shocked' By Brooklyn Clash
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he was ''shocked and angry'' because a crowd of Orthodox Jews had attempted to prevent police officers from making an arrest Thursday in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn. Ten officers were slightly hurt in the melee that followed, and four Hasidic Jews were arrested.

title: Insilco to Sell Silver Interest
description: The Insilco Corporation has announced an agreement in principle to sell off its last remaining interest in silver, which was the company's only line when International Silver was formed in 1898.

title: REAGAN TO OFFER NEW MISSILE PLAN FOR EUROPE TALKS
description: Adminstration officials said today that President Reagan will make public at the United Nations Monday a new proposal for breaking the deadlock in the medium-range nuclear missile talks with the Soviet Union.

title: FOOLISH POLICY ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: The Reagan Administration's policy of ''constructive engagement'' in South Africa could very well have been designed in Pretoria.

title: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 24,1983
description: Companies

title: A.P. SAYS ITS SHULTZ CAPTION WAS MISLEADING
description: The Associated Press said yesterday that it supplied a misleading caption Wednesday with a picture of Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

title: COMPUTER WIZARDRY LED TO $1.7 MILLION SLOT MACHINE JACKPOT
description: The Econopoulos affair began in the early afternoon Friday, Aug. 19, when an electronic slot machine at Harrah's Tahoe casino showed a giant jackpot winner.

title: WINDS DECISIVE FACTOR FOR CUP FINAL
description: The seventh and decisive race in the 25th America's Cup series begins at 12:10 P.M. Saturday between Australia II, the challenger that is faster, and Liberty, the United States defender that must rely on a faster-thinking crew.

title: ASSESSING INSURANCE FOR HOME
description: MOST consumers, when they are about to make large purchases such as major appliances or automobiles, compare costs and available options. That same attention to the smallest detail should be followed when you buy or renew homeowner insurance, the New York State Consumer Protection Board warns.

title: FIGHTING ACID RAIN HERE
description: In an atmosphere of stalemate in the acid rain debate, a state government has at last taken action. New York's decision to restrain sulfur-dioxide emissions should help point the way for other states, Congress and the Environmental Protection Agency as they search for answers to the problem of acid rain.

title: BUYING OF KIDNEYS OF POOR ATTACKED
description: A plan to purchase kidneys from living donors, primarily the indigent, for sale to people needing transplants and able to afford them drew strong opposition yesterday on ethical and medical grounds from officials of the National Kidney Foundation.

title: CITY OPERA: 'TURANDOT,' 2D OF SEASON
description: The New York City Opera does keep you off balance. The company, which opened triumphantly Wednesday with Massenet's exquisite fairy-tale opera, ''Cendrillon,'' came back Thursday night with a more heavy-handed kind of tale, Puccini's ''Turandot,'' as its second offering. Puccini's work, which he did not live to finish, calls for hefty voices and grandiose staging, both of which the City Opera was able to provide.

title: UNITARY TAX CURB RULED OUT
description: The Reagan Administration announced today that it would not, for now, ask Congress to limit the application by states of the unitary tax, which allows the worldwide income of multinational companies to be included in figuring state taxes.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: GOVERNMENT TROOPS CRACK DOWN ON DEMONSTRATIONS IN PHILIPINE
description: More than a thousand Government troops beat back crowds of young demonstrators tonight as they tried to advance on the presidential palace.

title: Public-Parochial Plan For School Is Barred
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that a public-parochial educational program in schools at Grand Rapids, Mich., violated the constitutional separation of church and state.

title: VIBRANT JOURNAL FOR THE ELDERLY
description: Articles deal with things such as how a former spy is working with the hard of hearing and how a puppy or parakeet can help fight loneliness. Advertisements tilt toward arthritis rubs, Florida condominiums and salt-free foods. Letters from readers wonder about steadying loose dentures and contributing one's body to science.

title: U.S. TO TELL CREIDT BUREAU ABOUT OVERDUE DEBTS
description: The Government announced today that after Oct. 31 it would give private credit bureaus the names of people who have not agreed to repay delinquent Government loans and other overdue Federal obligations.

title: Man Gets 15 Years In Priest's Slaying
description: A Bridgeport man who pleaded guilty to a reduced charge in the slaying of a Roman Catholic priest was sentenced today to 15 years in prison, Superior Court officials said.

title: Biscayne Bid Details Noted
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today disclosed details of the lowest bid it received for the failed Biscayne Federal Savings and Loan Association of Miami, although the agency did not disclose the bidder's identity.

title: >TO> -Connecticut Legislator
description: Herbert L. Cohen, a lawyer and a member of the Connecticut General Assembly from 1933 to 1937, died Thursday of a heart attack at a hospital while visiting London. He was 78 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Anchor Hocking Corp., Lancaster, Ohio, said it had entered into an agreement to acquire an 80 percent interest in Embassy Industrial Corp., an international trading company based in Alhambra, Calif. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: REAGAN REAFFIRMS SUPPORT FOR U.N.
description: President Reagan, in an effort to clarify American intentions, has decided to ''reaffirm strongly the U.S. support for the United Nations.'' But he will also criticize the way the organization functions when he visits New York on Sunday and Monday, a senior Administration official said today.

title: New Offer Averts Strike at Casinos
description: New concessions from the casino industry 30 minutes before a scheduled strike vote helped avert a weekend walkout by the city's largest casino workers' union, officials said today.

title: Abuse of 'Courtesy' in Trenton
description: New Jersey seems to be unique among states in clinging to the custom of ''senatorial courtesy.'' It allows a single state senator to block confirmation of any gubernatorial nominee residing in his legislative district.

title: Adding to Full Coffer
description: Even in this campaign off-year, there is no rest for contributors.

title: Pilot's Body Is Found In Crash in Catskills
description: A pilot for Catskills Airways was killed Wednesday in the crash of his plane in a storm in the Catskill Mountains, and yesterday his body was recovered, the authorities said.

title: PACE MAY MAKE THE MARLBORO RACE
description: When Bates Motel breaks from the starting gate today in the 11th Marlboro Cup at Belmont Park, he will be running against not only eight Grade I stakes winners but also a strong historical bias. Bates Motel is the favorite, the top weight and a stretch-runner, three traits that have often added up to defeat in the Marlboro.

title: DISCORD ON AID TO POOR LANDS
description: For Haiti, $26 million for energy resources. For the Central African Republic, $11 million for education programs. For Bangladesh, $110 million for food imports.

title: I.B.M. and Sperry
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has awarded design contracts worth more than $76 million to the International Business Machines Corporation and the Sperry Corporation in a program to replace air traffic control computers. The 21-month competition phase will culminate in selection of one contractor for new computers to replace the current I.B.M. 9020's used in the F.A.A.'s air route traffic control centers. The F.A.A. said the I.B.M. contract is valued at about $40.5 million and the Sperry award is for $35.6 million.

title: GRACE E. HAWK
description: Grace E. Hawk, professor emeritus of English at Wellesley College, died Thursday at the Wellesley Manor Nursing Home, Wellesley, Mass., after a stroke.

title: South Africa Drops Out Of the 1984 Olympiad
description: South Africa will stay away from the World Bridge Team Olympiad in Seattle next fall, thus avoiding a possible major split in the World Bridge Federation.

title: 2-Year-Old Survivor Describes Her Beating
description: A 2-year-old girl who survived a rampage by an intruder who killed the rest of her family told the police she saw the man who shined a flashlight in her eyes and beat her, officers said today.

title: Your Money; Tax Planning For Year-End
description: MANY individuals delay the start of their year-end tax planning until there are just a few weeks or days remaining in the year. But by that time, it may be too late to prepare the strategic moves that must be undertaken in 1983 to help save money when filing Federal income tax forms next April.

title: DEMOCRATS ASK CURB ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: Six Democratic Presidential candidates, calling apartheid a ''unique and unconscionable system of legalized discrimination,'' endorsed legislation today that would place stringent economic limits on American relations with South Africa.

title: J. Ward O'Neill Is Dead at 81
description: J. Ward O'Neill, a New York admiralty lawyer, died at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital yesterday as a result of injuries he suffered in an automobile accident last Jan. 2.

title:
PATENTS;
A Supersonic Biplane Is Developed for Navy
description: A supersonic biplane with variable-wing positions was patented for the Navy this week by Robert M. Taylor, an aerospace engineer in Washington.

title: Rush for B.P. Shares
description: Investors swamped banks today with offers to buy Government shares in the British Petroleum Company, forcing the sale to close 60 seconds after it began.

title: COURT TOLD YOUTH VEERED AUTO IN ORDER TO HIT BOY
description: A 15-year-old girl testified today that she saw Gerald T. Gerlock Jr. veer his speeding car at a 7-year-old boy on a residential street here and hit him as the boy sat on his bicycle, which was parked with one of its tires touching the curb.

title: HOW MUCH CAN THE STRIPED BASS TAKE?
description: To the Editor:

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10.

title: FORD PLANT VOTES CONCESSIONS
description: Workers at the Ford Motor Company's Rouge automaking complex overwhelmingly approved a contract tonight that will cut wages and benefits for 4,000 company steelworkers by $4 an hour.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, Bernard Avishai's article, ''Israeli Economic Ills,'' published Thursday, said the Likud-led Israeli Government has spent billions of dollars on housing subsidies. It should have said hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: PRECLUDING BETTER SUBWAYS VIA WESTWAY
description: To the Editor:

title: PRECLUDING BETTER SUBWAYS VIA WESTWAY
description: To the Editor:

title: Niagara Trading
description: The Niagara Trading Company has acquired the Libby brand name from Libby, McNeill & Libby Inc. of Chicago for a wide line of canned pineapple products that Niagara will be selling throughout the United States, including Alaska and Hawaii. ''This contract makes Niagara Trading the second-largest importer of pineapple in the United States,'' Michael J. DeRose, chairman of Niagara Trading, said in announcing the deal.

title: BULGARIAN SEIZED IN NEW YORK AND CHARGED AS SPY
description: A man described by Federal officials as a Bulgarian intelligence agent was arrested on an espionage charge last night as he left a restaurant in Manhattan. He was said to have been carrying highly classified nuclear secrets received from an American who was cooperating with the authorities.

title: United to Pay In-Plant' Fees
description: United Airlines said yesterday that it would resume the payment of commissions to ''in-plant'' agents, a step that insures that most of them will be able to continue to function as in the past. United had let the payment of commissions lapse last Sept. 12.

title: NEW YORK AREA COSTS ROSE BY 0.1% IN AUGUST
description: Prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose one-tenth of 1 percent in August on a seasonally adjusted basis, the regional office of the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: JERSEY NUNS FIGHT DEVELOPER
description: An order of cloistered Carmelite nuns living here under 13th-century tenets have mounted a rare and so far successful public protest in recent days against a bit of 20th-century suburbia - a proposed five-story glass office building.

title: N.B.A. Talks Stalled
description: Negotiations between the National Basketball Association and its referees' union have broken off, with the league setting an Oct. 1 deadline for agreement on a contract. If the dispute is not resolved by then, the N.B.A. said, it will replace the 27 regular referees with substitute officials until agreement is reached. The referees are seeking a new salary scale ranging from $35,000 to $95,000, increased from $24,000 to $65,000. . . . The N.B.A.'s board of governors granted unanimous approval for the sale of the Boston Celtics to a group headed by Donald Gaston . . . . Thurl Bailey , the 6-11 forward who helped lead North Carolina State to the national championship in basketball, has signed with the Utah Jazz.

title: St. Kitts-Nevis Joins U.N.
description: The newly independent Caribbean state of St. Kitts-Nevis was admitted to the United Nations today as its 158th member.

title:
Patents;
Inventors Exposition Scheduled
description: THE Patents and Trademark Office announced this week that

title: CITY IS PLANNING TO OPEN TOMBS BEFORE SCHEDULE
description: The Manhattan jail known as the Tombs, which was closed nine years ago when a judge found that conditions violated the constitutional rights of inmates, may open a week from tomorrow even though its renovation has not been completed, the city's Department of Correction said yesterday.

title: 10-DAY AUTO SALES CLIMB 3.8%
description: Sales of new cars by the nation's three largest auto producers rose 3.8 percent in the Sept. 11-20 period, the companies reported today. A slim increase had been expected because mid-September last year was one of the few strong selling periods of 1982 and inventory shortages are now plaguing dealers.

title: CANAL-RANDOLPH STUDIES LIQUIDATION
description: The Canal-Randolph Corporation, a major operator of real estate properties and livestock stockyards, announced yesterday that its board of directors is considering a specific liquidation plan under the previously announced proposal to sell its income-producing real estate properties.

title:
PATENTS;
Three New Advances In Nuclear Reactors
description: Several of the week's patents illustrate government and industrial interest in nuclear reactors.

title: NEW YORK PANEL SEEKS FASTER CHECK CLEARANCE
description: In an effort to speed clearance of checks through the banking system, the New York State Banking Department recommended yesterday that maximum check-clearing times be established for all banks operating in the state. The times would range from two to eight business days.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 14.

title: 'THE STORY OF PIERA,' FROM CHILD TO ACTRESS
description: The films of Marco Ferreri have a kind of aggressively grotesque intensity about them that, as often as not, inspires laughter, sometimes intentional, as well as shock. He delights in making audiences uncomfortable, which, given the nature of his subjects, isn't very difficult to do.

title: A Singular Signature
description: So distraught was Vice President Theodore Roosevelt on the day he learned of the shooting of President McKinley that he misspelled his own name in a telegram seeking information.

title: Leahy Able to Kick
description: Pat Leahy , the Jets' place-kicker, apparently is well enough to perform against the Los Angeles Rams Sunday at Shea Stadium. Leahy had been suffering from back spasms that prevented him from attempting field goals last Sunday against New England.

title: It Won't Swing
description: On Saturday the kids in orange hair and lavender face paint head for King's Road in Chelsea and hang around.

title: G.M. Callback
description: The General Motors Corporation will call back 4,300 indefinitely laid-off workers for a second shift at its Framingham, Mass., assembly plant outside of Boston, according to a statement from F. James McDonald, G.M.'s president. The announcement followed by less than a week Mr. McDonald's Sept. 16 statement that 14,000 to 15,000 laid-off workers would be called back Dec. 1 to begin production of front-wheel-drive Cadillac De Ville, Oldsmobile 98 and Buick Electra models at Wentzville, Mo. and Lake Orion, Mich. G.M. has called back more than 65,000 laid-off workers so far this year, adding 12 shifts at United States and Canadian assembly plants, the statement said.

title: MONEY SUPPLY DECLINES $3.1 BILLION IN WEEK
description: The basic measure of the money supply dropped an unexpectedly large $3.1 billion in the week ended Sept. 14, the Federal Reserve System reported late yesterday.

title: 112 ABOARD AIRLINER ARE KILLED IN CRASH IN PERSIAN GULF SHEIKDOM
description: A Gulf Air jetliner crashed and burned in the mountains of this desert sheikdom today and airline officials said all 112 people aboard were killed. The passengers inluded an American.

title: Washington Post to Put Wage Offer Into Effect
description: The Washington Post declared an impasse in contract negotiations with a Newspaper Guild union local today and announced it would impose its final wage offer Monday.

title: UNIONS' MEMBERS POLLED ON '84 VOTE
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. announced today that some of its 96 affiliated unions were seeking their members' opinions, either directly or through professional polls, about whom the federation should endorse in the Democratic Presidential race.

title: SOVIET STARTS MAKING SOME ADMISSIONS
description: After two weeks in which all Soviet public statements offered unyielding justifications for shooting down a Korean airliner, Soviet representatives here and abroad have begun to tell Western audiences that attacking a civilian plane was a mistake, or at least that the Soviet military bungled matters by not admitting the action right away.

title: Argentina Changes Debt Law
description: Although Argentina has changed its bankruptcy law to appease foreign banks, legal experts here said the move would not be retroactive and therefore would not affect contested liabilities that foreign creditors owe under the previous law.

title: YANKS WIN, 7-4, ON 4-RUN 8TH
description: Roy Smalley, unhappy that he has been singled out as a reason the Yankees are not going to win the American League East title this season, prevented them from officially falling out of the division race last night.

title: Boston College Is Thinking Small
description: Boston College Is Thinking Small

title: HOW MUCH CAN THE STRIPED BASS TAKE?
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFING
description: Bernardin to Get Prize

title: WELCOMING HAND ON EMBASSY ROW
description: In many ways, this is a city of strangers.

title: CUSTOMIZED BICYCLES, ITALIAN STYLE
description: One of the best-known Italian bicycle manufacturers recently opened a store adjacent to its warehouse in Milan that designs custom bicyles and sells beautifully designed accessories to go with them.

title: Cleanup Ordered At Jersey Landfill
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency today ordered eight companies to begin cleaning up toxic wastes in the Kin-Buc landfill, which is on the Federal list for funds.

title: '83 Arms Pact Ruled Out
description: An agreement on strategic arms is all but inconceivable this year, even on broad principles for a new treaty, a senior Administration arms control official said today. The official said that Edward L. Rowny, chief United States negotiator in the strategic arms talks, believes agreement on general guidelines is remotely possible this year but only if several very difficult conditions are satisfied first.

title: ARGENTINE ARMY GIVEN AMNESTY FOR 'DIRTY WAR'
description: Argentina's military Government approved a law today granting the military and the police immunity from prosecution for crimes committed during the so-called dirty war against leftists.

title: Labor Party Doubtful About Israeli Coalition
description: Labor Party leaders expressed strong doubts today about an agreement with the Likud bloc that would enable them to form a coalition. But the consensus, according to a participant in the discussion, was against an outright rejection of the invitation extended Wednesday by the Prime Minister-designate, Yitzhak Shamir.

title: ACAPULO IN SEPTEMBER: WHERE THE MEXICANS ARE
description: The Acapulco of September is not the one of American tourist fantasies. The people darting in and out of the restaurants and boutiques are not the fashionable or famous, but solid, hard-working, middle- and upper-middle-class Mexicans, looking for a break from the pressures and pollution of city life. The polyglot of English and French and Italian on the beaches is replaced by almost pure Spanish. The hotel staffs seem relaxed with people who understand better their language, their manners, their culture and their situation.

title: Polish Weekly Says Church Is Power Hungry
description: The Communist weekly Polityka accused Poland's Roman Catholic Church today of taking advantage of social frustrations to enhance its own ''material and political power.''

title: Chrysler Increase
description: The Chrysler Corporation will increase prices of its 1984 model cars by an average 2 percent, company sources said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I voted for it. We have got no other choice. It's vote yes or we get no work.''

title: So Near . . .
description: One little letter and, all of a sudden, there's another political disagreement in the Bronx.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES
description: On the Waterfront In a leafy inlet here 20 miles up Narragansett Bay from Newport, the yacht Liberty appeared to have been pirated and abandoned. Its mast had been removed. Its deck was empty. Its red hull wore small strips of tape about as big as Band-Aids, the markings for its alterations. Soon the 12-Meter would be lifted out of the water in order to be adjusted to benefit from the light winds forecast for today's decisive seventh race of the America's Cup.

title: REAGAN OFFERS ANOTHER HINT HE WILL RUN FOR RE-ELECTION
description: President Reagan, rallying Republicans to fight what he called Democratic ''sermonettes about fairness and compassion,'' offered another hint of a candidacy for re-election today when he said, ''We can and will work together for victory.''

title: TV: THE PROBLEM OF 'TEEN-AGE SUICIDE'
description: The suicide rate among young Americans has risen some 300 percent in the last 25 years, with the suicide rate among young American males, in particular, now one of the highest, if not the highest, in the world. Whatever the complicated, layered reasons for this, it is clear that suicide, no matter how poorly understood, is a serious subject. Commend WNBC-TV, therefore, for producing ''Teen-age Suicide: Too Young to Die.'' It will be seen at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: No Headline
description: Bridge: Big Number of Life Masters Has Diluted Title's Meaning

title: CUOMO ORDERS AIDS STEEL MAD IN U.S.
description: Governor Cuomo issued an executive order yesterday designed to make all state agencies buy American-made steel for construction projects. The Governor, whose order sets a cost standard for steel, said he was complying with a ''Buy American'' measure passed by the State Legislature earlier this year. He acted shortly after the Metropolitan Transportation Authority rebuffed his attempt to impose a more flexible cost standard than the one it adopted yesterday for the purchase of American steel for transit projects.

title:
PATENTS;
Gold Ions Injected To Treat Arthritis
description: A method and apparatus for treating rheumatoid arthritis by the direct injection of gold ions into the patient's troubled joint were patented this week by Wilson Greatbatch, an engineer in Clarence, N.Y.

title: Love Pomes
description: Police officers around town have taken to wearing little gold apples in their collars - a version of the ''Big Apple'' emblem publicized by the Association for a Better New York.

title: 'L'ARGENT,' 13TH FEATURE BY BRESSON
description: That Robert Bresson, the veteran French director, is still one of the most rigorous and talented film makers of the world is evident with the appearance of his beautiful, astringent new film, ''L'Argent,'' which will be shown at the New York Film Festival in Lincoln Center today at 12:30 P.M. and tomorrow at 7 P.M. Mr. Bresson does not make films casually - ''L'Argent'' is only his 13th since his first feature, ''Les Anges du Peche'' (Angels of the Streets), was released in 1943.

title: Honeywell Contract
description: Honeywell Inc. won a $500.1 million Navy contract for engineering development of the X-50 advance lightweight torpedo, including design, building of prototypes and testing, the Defense Department said today. It also said Pan American World Airways Inc. had received $42.5 million from the Air Force for Civil Reserve Air Fleet enhancement to modify wide-body 747 passenger aircraft.

title: ARCTIC PRECURSORS
description: To the Editor:

title: S.E.C. APPARENTLY HALTS INVESTIGATION OF SEAFIRST
description: A Federal investigation into possible violations of disclosure rules by the Seafirst Corporation has apparently been suspended, because of court rulings that targets of such investigations must be notified when outside parties are subpoenaed.

title: Good in Football, Good in Classroom
description: Jeff Hostetler is not a small-town boy. He's a no-town boy. Thequarterback for West Virginia University, which plays Boston College today in a regionally televised game between two of the best teams in the East, is listed on the game program as being from Hollsopple, Pa.

title: Gate Losses Too
description: Gate Losses Too

title: JAPAN'S EFFORTS ON BEHALF OF SAKHALIN'S KOREANS
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE BIG PICTURE

title: FOREST HILLS, 12 YEARS LATER
description: Twelve years ago, New York City was almost torn apart by a struggle between the middle-class residents of Forest Hills and Mayor John V. Lindsay's administration, which sought to meet the housing needs of low-income, minority families by placing a public housing project in the neighborhood. They placed the project there and, mirabile dictu, the neighborhood remains undeteriorated, uncriminalized and unaffected.

title: Youth Orchestra of Ireland
description: The Youth Orchestra of Ireland, composed of performers 16 to 21 years old, will appear on Oct. 26 at 8 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center.

title: TRADING IS HEAVY
description: Stock prices ended slightly lower yesterday in continued active trading after having posted sharp gains earlier in the week.

title: WHEN COLLEGE IS A SUBWAY RIDE AWAY
description: A young woman came out of the subway at 137th Street and Broadway and walked quickly by a dozen men with slurry eyes lounging on broken benches and sipping from bottles wrapped in brown paper bags.

title: Agency Is Faulted In Bridge Collapse
description: The State Department of Transportation failed to follow its own policy of keeping records of citizen complaints before the collapse of the Mianus River Bridge, the state police said today.

title: Underground Nuclear Test
description: A thermonuclear weapon was exploded beneath the Nevada desert Thursday, the second such nuclear test in 24 hours.

title: Key Rates
description: * Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: TEXACO ADDING SOCAL UNITS
description: Texaco Inc., expressing its intention to expand its refining and marketing business in several European countries from which other American oil companies have withdrawn, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a refinery and 2,600 service stations from the Standard Oil Company of California.

title: News Analysis
description: When Governor Cuomo appointed a commission in mid-May to study the safety and economics of the Shoreham reactor, the plant was far behind schedule and over budget, and the state and Federal Government were moving toward a collision over whether it should open. Those problems have not only intensified, but technical problems have also been added, and the commission's report - three weeks overdue but expected by mid-October - will not offer solutions, members say.

title: RESTAURTEUR, FEED THYSELF
description: One of the generally accepted rules of restaurant management is that it is bad form for the owner to sit down and eat during the peak hours of lunch or dinner. For the most part, this rule makes sense, because the owner should be paying attention to the dining room instead of taking up the staff's time when customers are waiting to be served. But considering how uncomfortable many restaurants are, it seems wise to break that rule occasionally so the owner will know exactly what it feels like to live through a meal at the busiest times.

title: AMENDMENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Adelman Protests
description: We may have been wrong about the new director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, Kenneth Adelman, as his letter below insists. We envisioned a constructive recovery from the Administration's repeated budget cuts, personnel purges and damaging reorganizations that took place before his appointment.

title: THE G. IN G.O.P. IS 'GAFFE'
description: The Republican Party being the party of tradition, it was fitting that Interior Secretary James G. Watt should continue one of the more notorious ones in his remarks to the U. S. Chamber of Commerce.

title: Convention Center Draws 4 Bids
description: Four sets of bidders have submitted proposals to buy New York City's troubled Convention Center for $608 million and lease it back to the state, the head of the state's Urban Development Corporation announced yesterday.

title: Conagra Plans
description: Conagra Inc. will seek to rid itself of labor troubles at 13 Armour meatpacking plants it is about to acquire from the Greyhound Corporation by closing the plants and then opening them the next day with a new work force, Conagra's chairman and chief executive said at the annual meeting of shareholders. About 2,000 Armour workers voted last week to reject a new contract calling for a reduction in pay from $10.69 an hour to $8 an hour. Conagra, an Omaha-based food and agricultural products company, expects to conclude its purchase of Armour from Greyhound for $166 million in December.

title: DOUBTS IN LEBANON
description: Slowly, concern is developing in France, Italy, and Britain about the possibility that the multinational force in Lebanon might be drawn into a war of imprecise and dangerous dimensions. But the concern in Europe has not been intense, as it has in the United States. Perhaps because public interest has been restrained and unemotional, the debate on the future of the force and the role it should play has been limited.

title: NEW TYPEWRITERS JOIN THE COMPUTER AGE
description: ''John Mariani is trying out this typewriter with the intention of taking it in an airplane to work with as he sees fit.'' Mr. Mariani, a writer, typed those words last week as he tried out a very thin five-pound portable electronic typewriter at a New York camera outlet.

title: Gaylord Perry Retires
description: In Kansas City, Gaylord Perry of the Royals, the only pitcher to win a Cy Young Award in both major leagues, ended a 21-year. 314-victory career last night by announcing his retirement.

title: Soviet Line Status Report
description: Less than half the compressor stations on the Siberian-West Europe gas pipeline have been built, but the line is capable of delivering as contracted, the Minister of Oil and Gas Construction, Boris Shcherbina, said today.

title: Prisons on Borrowed Time
description: ''The final (relatively bloodless) result was to some degree fortuitous. We were lucky to have averted catastrophe.'' That's the conclusion of a new report about last January's uprising at Ossining prison. The report is strikingly germane, for just as it is issued, the state is taking the initial steps in a sentencing program that might make true control of its prisons impossible for years to come.

title: Raiding Pension Plan
description: The corporate practice of siphoning money from employee pension plans to finance acquisitions, fight takeovers, retire debt or dress up financial statements has caught the eye of Congress. Hearings open Wednesday before the House Select Committee on Aging.

title: Beth Diane Titus Wed To Christopher Cullen
description: Beth Diane Titus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Richmond Titus of Locust Valley, L.I., was married there yesterday to Christopher Cox Cullen, son of June Cox Cullen, also of Locust Valley, and the late James Freston Cullen. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church.

title: A TIME TO REMEMBER CORNEAL TRANSPLANTS
description: To the Editor:

title: CUP FINALE RESCHEDULED FOR TOMORROW
description: The seventh and decisive race in the 25th America's Cup series between Australia II, the challenger, and Liberty, the defender, was postponed today because of insufficient wind.

title: 200 Reported Arrested In Pakistan Campaigning
description: The police were reported to have arrested nearly 200 people today, and troops and paramilitary forces were on standby alert in Pakistan's Sind Province as campaigning officially started for local council elections on Wednesday.

title: Ann Bachelder Is the Bride Of Thomas Bullitt, Banker
description: Ann Bachelder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Bachelder of Hallowell, Me., was married yesterday to Thomas Walker Bullitt, son of Lelia Wardwell Seidner of Heidelberg, West Germany, and John C. Bullitt of New York and Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Geoffrey M. Hahneman performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Advent in Boston.

title: PROBATION SYSTEM IS CHANGED BY CITY
description: Changes in the City Probation Department have been announced by Mayor Koch 10 months after a private study said the probationary services were ''totally inadequate for the needs of children before the Family Court.''

title: JAILS USING NEW ENERGY PLAN
description: AS the Long Island Lighting Company contemplates its latest request for a rate increase, preparations are well under way for installation of cogeneration systems at two county facilities. The first will be at the new County Correctional Facility in Ya phank, the second at the Riverhead Jail, and both are expected to be running by the end of the year.

title: J. A. Riggsbee 3d, Linda Simon Wed
description: Linda Lee Simon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee K. Simon of Greensboro, N.C., was married at the Westminster Presbyterian Church there yesterday to Joseph Albert Riggsbee 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Riggsbee Jr., also of Greensboro. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. George C. Carpenter, assisted by the Rev. William D. Varken.

title: Israeli Asserts Marines Are a Prop for Gemayel
description: Former Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin said today that Israel must make clear to the American public that United States forces in Lebanon are not there at Israel's request.

title: Rentals
description: To the Editor:

title: Doubts Deepen On Manila Visit
description: The lid blew off Manila last week with four consecutive days of violent street demonstrations, raising questions in Washington about whether it was a physically or politically safe place for President Reagan's scheduled visit early in November. President Ferdinand E. Marcos ordered a strict security force crackdown after 11 people were killed in anti-Government protests.

title: ARGENTINES FEAR LABOR UNREST MAY IMPERIL ELECTIONS
description: A spree of Argentine wildcat strikes resulting from inflation and falling living standards has raised fears of a social explosion that could interrupt elections scheduled for Oct. 30.

title: Giants' Ledbetter Stricken
description: Bob Ledbetter, the Giants' offensive backfield coach, suffered a carotid-artery blockage Friday night. Today, on his 49th birthday, he was placed in the intensive-care unit of St. John's Episcopal Hospital in Smithtown, L.I. A hospital spokesman said his condition was listed as critical, which he said applied to all patients for their first 24 hours in intensive care. Bill Parcells, the Giants' head coach, said he was told that Ledbetter's condition was ''stable and improved.''

title: THE BEAR AND THE LEPRECHAUN
description: DURING the 1960's, I planned to visit a friend in Oceanside. I called for directions. ''You'll see a large wooden bear - can't miss it, in the yard of a dentist, a Dr. Marsh, then, turn left.''

title: HEADLINERS;
description: Marc Rich was unquestionably one of the world's most successful commodities traders.

title: U.S. MISSILE OFFER DERIDED BY SOVIET
description: A commentary in the Communist Party newspaper Pravda today dismissed President Reagan's new proposals on curbing medium-range missiles in Europe, saying they were a ''mockery of common sense'' and calculated to make agreement impossible at Soviet-American negotiations in Geneva.

title: THEATER: COMEDY BY FRY
description: The Equity Library Theater, one of the city's most important institutions for giving a showcase to New York's professional acting population, has opened its 41st season with one of the tougher nuts it has tried to crack, Christopher Fry's ''Lady's Not for Burning.''

title: A TIME FOR QUALITY
description: rchitecture and interior design are in a transition period. With the recent retreat from the International Style, no new dominant design philosophy has appeared to take its place. Even the much talked about postmodernism is an ambiguous term that does not seem to be enough of a movement to become a style. But, while the design scene may appear quiet, there is actually quite a bit going on. Probably the best description of the design situation today is that it is a time for quality. If there is no valid new style movement, designers seem to be saying, let's investigate the best of the past. Of course, there are fads, but, interestingly enough, few are investing in them.

title: A RECONSTRUCTION AND A SEQUEL
description: PERPETUAL MOTION By Graeme Gibson. 283 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $12.95. THE FURTHER ADVENTURES OF HUCKLEBERRY FINN By Greg Matthews. 500 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $15.95.

title: Elaine M. Ryan and Dr. Francis P. Ittleman Marry
description: Elaine M. Ryan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard J. Ryan of Islip and Shelter Island, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Francis P. Ittleman, son of Mrs. Felix Ittleman of Great Neck and Westhampton Beach, L.I., and the late Dr. Ittleman. The ceremony was performed at Our Lady of the Isle Roman Catholic Church on Shelter Island by Msgr.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: BETRAYERS OF THE TRUTH: Fraud and Deceit in the Halls of Science. By William Broad and Nicholas Wade. (S&S/Touchstone, $6.95.)

title: A 'FLASH' REPORT CHEERS WASHINGTON
description: The recovery remains vigorous and the Reagan Administration is purring. The Government's so-called ''flash'' report on third-quarter growth showed a strong 7 percent annual rate of expansion after adjusting for inflation. This was down from an overheated 9.7 percent level of growth in the gross national product in the second quarter. ''We're really on track,'' said the President's chief economist, Martin Feldstein, ''a track that can really be sustained.'' Yet Mr. Feldstein also took the opportunity to dampen the celebration. He warned again that the deficit was still too high. A goodly infusion of economic strength came from housing, which showed surprising vigor in August after an almost equally robust July performance. Despite a two-percentage-point rise in mortgage rates this summer, work began on new houses at an annual rate of 1.94 million units - the highest level in four and a half years. As for inflation, the Consumer Price Index rose four-tenths of 1 percent in August, helped by the first jump in food prices in three months.

title: A COLLECTOR ADAPTS TO LIFE WITH CD'S
description: Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians.

title: COUNTY CLERK'S OFFICE HOST TO SOME OLD-FANGLED RECORDS
description: HE may have lost the Motor Vehicle Bureau, but County Clerk Andrew Spano has gained the Lower Hudson Conference, an educational support organization for museum and historical agencies in Westchester, Putnam, Rockland and Dutchess Counties.

title: Montserrat
description: To the Editor:

title: David Ober, Polly Norris Are Married
description: Polly Foster Norris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William K. Norris of Bedford, N.Y., was married there yesterday to David Graham Ober, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank B. Ober Jr. of Monkton, Md. The Rev. Louise P. Weld performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church.

title: 9 REPORTERS SEEK RULING ON TRESPASS
description: A group of nine Oklahoma reporters are asking the United States Supreme Court to determine whether their hot pursuit of a news story entitled them to violate state trespass laws.

title: FRIENDS AND OPPONENTS
description: FOR the past eight years, State Senator Thom Serrani, a Democrat, and State Representative Christopher Shays, a Republican, have represented Stamford in the General Assembly. They worked on legislation together, commuted to the State Capitol together, socialized together and became what they each describe as ''great friends.''

title: HOLDING CONCERNS FORM EXPORT SERVICE
description: -based holding companies have taken it upon themselves to solve some of the country's problems in export trading.

title: INQUIRY CRITICIZES MENTAL HOSPITALS
description: Mindaltering drugs are dispensed with a ''casual attitude'' at many New York mental hospitals, a state commission reported today.

title: WHAT THE U.N. IS GOOD FOR, ANYHOW
description: When President Reagan last week suggested moving the United Nations to Moscow for half the year, he seemed to be playing to the home audience rather than making a serious proposal. But the remark and similarly caustic expressions by other American officials reflected the frustrations recent Administrations have experienced in dealing with the ungainly and flawed world body, created 38 years ago amid so much idealism and hope for world order.

title: Alcohol Is Dumped in Nile
description: Thousands of gallons of liquor, beer and wine were poured into the Nile on Friday in a ceremony attended by President Gaafar al-Nimeiry, who ordered the move as part of his campaign to put Islamic law into effect in the Sudan.

title:
STAMPS;
COMMEMORATIVES PAY TRIBUTE TO THE TROLLEY
description: The streetcar, which was first pulled by horses and then propelled by electricity, was America's first major form of mass transportation. It is recalled by a nostalgic block of four commemoratives that spans more than a century, from the early horsecar on tracks to the sole trolley line still operating in America today.

title: A JOURNEY TOWARD MATURITY WITH THE WHITE SOX
description: IT happened on 35th Street, barely an echo from the Dan Ryan Expressway: in a cozy block of green sandwiched between neighborhoods of brown Chicago bungalows and graying housing projects.

title: THE MUSICAL ACCORDING TO BENNETT
description: The ads call it ''The Best Musical Ever,'' a judgment that is at least debatable. But as of Thursday, no one can dispute that ''A Chorus Line'' is the longest-running Broadway show ever. This week, almost eight years after it opened, Michael Bennett's Broadway show about dancers auditioning for a Broadway show will celebrate its 3,389th performance in suitably grand style. The current company of ''A Chorus Line'' will be joined by not only the original company but also the national touring company, the international company, the two bus-and-truck companies, the Las Vegas company, and members of the foreign companies - each group performing a segment of the show, and all of them appearing in the finale, 350 dancers strong.

title: WATEFORD CRYSTAL: SPARKLING IRISH PRIZE
description: The image of gnarled, taciturn old craftsmen working away in primitive surroundings dies hard when faced with any beautiful object bearing a tag saying ''handmade'' - especially, perhaps, when the tag also says ''handmade in Ireland.'' So visitors heading for the headquarters of Waterford Crystal, makers of some of the most sought-after - and expensive - handcut crystal in the world, are in for a surprise when the road leads through an industrial development and stops in front of an uncompromisingly modern factory complex. ''Are we in the right place?'' is a common reaction.

title: HEYWARD LEADS PASSAIC OVER CLIFTON
description: Craig Heyward, the 1982 state scoring leader with 175 points, took aim at another scoring title yesterday when the bruising fullback from Passaic scored two touchdowns in a 20-7 victory over Clifton in Clifton.

title: FOR MUSHROOMS, THE TIME IS AT HAND
description: AT this time of year, mushrooms are at their peak. As everyone knows, interest in American home-grown products has never been greater - so it is hardly surprising that there are so many varieties of mushrooms to choose from this month. Golden orange chanterelles are in abundance; there are also buttery oyster mushrooms, thin little enoke mushrooms for salads, meaty shiitake mushrooms and wild oak mushrooms from Virginia. C ebes, also called funghi porcini, are strong-flavored and succulent, available both fresh and dried and delicious with garlic, parsley and olive oil, prosciutto or pancetta - Italian bacon. The dried ones may seem extravagantly priced, but once they have been soaked they expand in volume and their concentrated richness goes a long way.

title: SURGING PHILLIES WIN 9TH SRAIGHT
description: The first-place Philadelphia Phillies won their ninth straight game today when they rallied for five runs in the ninth inning off Bruce Sutter and overpowered the St. Louis Cardinals, 9-6.

title: WHY WOMEN SEEK SHELTER
description: JERSEY CITY TWO women sit in a living room, comforting the toddlers who tug at their clothes. In an adjoining room, half a dozen children play with coloring books and crayons.

title: Elizabeth Disch Marries
description: Elizabeth Ann Disch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Giles E. Disch of Spring, Tex., formerly of Fair Haven, N.J., was married yesterday to David Patchett Culbertson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander B. Culbertson of Amherst, Mass. The Rev. Ralph N. Silverio performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Nativity in Fair Haven.

title:
DINING OUT;
FARE FROM THE SEA IN MOUNT KISCO
description: A RATING most often is the result of averaging many factors of a restaurant's operation, hits and misses; weighed heavily are the quality of the ingredients and the skill of their preparation. On the Bounty, a long-anticipated seafood restaurant that finally opened early this summer in Mount Kisco, is particularly difficult to assess.

title: Who Elected You?
description: CREDIT TO COME

title: Headliners Looks, Brains, Money
description: While black leaders focused last week on the symbolic aspects of a first black Miss America, the winner, Vanessa Williams more concerned with more practical rewards of the job - and quite candid about it.

title: JAZZ
description: A worldwide convention of jazz vibraphonists would probably not strain the capacity of a small living room so the presence in New York this week of two outstanding vibraphonists representing two different eras is an unusual event.

title: RANGERS' EX-OLYMPIANS SAVOR SCENE OF TRIUMPH
description: Bill Baker, Rob McClanahan and Dave Silk ambled along Main Street here Friday afternoon, having just arrived with the Rangers for an exhibition game tonight against the 1984 United States Olympic team.

title: CALGARY MAKES PROGRESS TOWARD '88 GAMES
description: The city of Calgary has received praise from top Olympic officials for its preparations for the 1988 Winter Olympic Games, Frank King, chairman of the organizing committee, said in a telephone interview this week.

title: EASIER VOTING FOUND UNLIKELY TO LIFT TURNOUT
description: Low voter turnout in the United States is unlikely to be changed much by simplifying voting and registration procedures, extending voting hours or instituting Sunday or holiday voting, an ABC News Poll suggests.

title: MEMORIES OF BEAUTIFYING U.S. IN 30'S
description: With the cleansing perspective of 50 years, Allen Brazelton, Johnny Romanowski, Jim Ratcliff, Arnie Blumhardt and hundreds of other men gathered here can now see the Depression of the 1930's for what it really was to them: a period of some difficulty filled with happy times in the woods, as comradely companies of young men marched from their camps at dawn to construct roads, plant trees and fight erosion together to build a better land for the future.

title:
TV VIEW;
A CASTING COUP PAYS OFF
description: For whatever arcane logistical reasons, ABC has started its new series this season earlier than the other two commercial networks. In terms of format, the typical ABC product is conservative, sticking to familiar gimmicks that occasionally border on shameless imitation. ''Webster,'' featuring an adorable black youngster living in a white household, is 1983's ''Diff'rent Strokes.'' ''Lottery'' harks back to ''The Millionaire'' of the 1960's. ''Hardcastle & McCormick'' seems to be a tribute to every car-chase opus ever made. And so on, not infrequently to ennui.

title: THE RUSH DEREGULATION
description: As a fellow public administration scientist, I take issue with Martin and Susan J. Tolchin's concept of ''the rush to deregulate'' (''The Rush to Deregulation,'' Aug. 21). There has never been a rush to deregulate.

title: Baldwin Date Canceled
description: An appearance tomorrow by the novelist James Baldwin at the 92d Street Y has been canceled because of his illness. He will appear later, at a date to be announced.

title: GREAT NECK THEATER SEEKS TO ADD STORES
description: THE recent saga of the Playhouse Theater in Great Neck has been unfolding in suspenseful chapters reminiscent of ''The Perils of Pauline.''

title: Simone M. Peyton to Wed James G. Valentine Nov. 5
description: Simone Marie Peyton and James Gordon Valentine plan to be married Nov. 5. Mrs. Richard Hall Macatee of Arlington, Va., has announced her daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Massie Valentine of Richmond.

title: 'Covert' Funds With a Catch
description: The Reagan Administration last week officially broadened its rationale for aid to the anti-Government forces in Nicaragua. Support for the rebels would continue, Secretary of State George P. Shultz and William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence told the Senate Intelligence Committee, until the Nicaraguans stop their subversion in neighboring countries. The earlier explanation - that the Administration was acting to bar weapons flowing from Nicaragua to the Salvadoran rebels - proved difficult to document, while the anti-Sandinistas made no secret of their main aim, toppling the junta.

title: WINDSOR CAPS YEAR OF ATTAINING 350
description: WINDSOR THIS town, Connecticut's oldest, concludes a yearlong observance of the 350th anniversary of its founding today with a parade, a cake, dancing and a massive birthday party on its green.

title: It's Heating Up, For Marines And Negotiators
description: Lebanon's civil war widened dangerously last week, drawing the international peacekeepers even closer to the conflagration. Striving to put out the Middle East's latest three-alarmer, Saudi Arabian, Lebanese and American mediators shuttled between Beirut and Damascus trying for a cease-fire. Syria and its allies in Lebanon raised objections - pushing to undermine President Amin Gemayel's Government by excluding Government leaders from national conciliation talks and by insisting the concilators' eventual decisions be binding on the Government. In Damascus, Walid Jumblat, the Druse leader, called for withdrawal of the 5,500-man multinational force, the shaky Government's main prop against collapse.

title: MOTORLESS VERMONT TOURS
description: For many years roaming from country inn to country inn has been a favorite pastime of motorized travelers. In the last decade or so, however, Vermont tour operators, capitalizing on the exercise boom and the inns' heightened popularity, have found other ways to shepherd vacationers around the countryside. One mght even say a competition has emerged to find the most primitive manner to get from inn to inn.

title: Guatemalan Officer Cleared Of a Plot Against Rios Montt
description: An army officer accused of plotting to overthrow the military Government of former President Efrain Rios Montt has been cleared of all charges for lack of evidence, a court spokesman said.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: MASS MARKET

title: Madeleines
description: To the Editor:

title: STRENGHTS OF SINGLE PARENTS UNDERLINED
description: PROFESSIONAL interest in the single-parent family has focused in recent years largely on its problems and weaknesses, Olga Brom, director of the Institute for Single Parent Family, said recently. ''At previous workshops, people were taught strategies to cope with those problems. To my knowledge nobody ever said single-parent families could be strong and maybe even stronger than an intact family or an unhappy family.''

title: Police Hearing Goes Smoothly, Minus Mayor
description: Dozens of black and Hispanic New Yorkers who claim to be victims of police brutality had perhaps the equivalent of a day in court last week. For six hours, they testified before a Congressional panel convened in a Harlem armory to investigate allegations that abuse by officers is widespread.

title: The Kodak Way
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Rice Ends 0-15 Famine, 22-21
description: Phillip Money completed a 2-point conversion pass to Kevin Trigg with 3 minutes 2 seconds to play to give Rice a 22-21 victory over Southwestern Louisiana, ending a 15-game losing streak tonight. Money had passed 11 yards to the tight end Greg Heiskel to make the score 21-20.

title: NORTHERN POWER AT CHEAPER RATES SOUGHT FOR ISLAND BUT UPSTATE OBJECTS
description: BY using relatively cheap Canadian and upstate New York hydroelectric power, Long Islanders have saved an estimated $40 million dollars on electric bills over the last five years, and they could be saving a lot more, according to the Power Authority of the State of New York.

title: U.S. OFFERS A ROAD PLAN TO COSTA RICA
description: The chief of the United States Army's Southern Command in Panama, Gen. Paul Gorman, has offered to build a network of roads and bridges in Costa Rica with the help of the United States National Guard, according to American diplomats here.

title: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE
description: The use of an ant colony as a metaphor for the interaction of signals in thought processes may be accurate, but to say that a kind of knowledge of the colony's behavior ''is nowhere to be found in the individual ants'' is questionable.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE WORK PLACE;
HOW WORKERS MAKE SENSE OF COMUTERS
description: COMPUTERS have been around longer than robots, so they offer another and perhaps more complete picture of the social and psychological strains placed on workers as new technologies are introduced. In 1981, American companies purchased 1 million data terminals, increasing the total in use to 5 million; the market is expected to grow at a rate of 25 percent a year over the next decade.

title: LAWRENCE TRIUMPHS ON POPRILO TOUCHDOWN
description: Don Poprilo, a highly touted rusher for Lawrence, scored twice yesterday - once on the last play of the game - to power the Golden Tornados over Massapequa, 13-8. Poprilo, a 205-pound running back and a senior, scored on a 1-yard run in the first quarter and on a 30-yard pass from Charlie Trotta to win the game in the fourth quarter. On 21 carries, Poprilo gained 109 yards.

title: Connecticut Deals Yale 2d Loss, 38-12
description: After 17 years of almost continuous success, Coach Carm Cozza and Yale football are experiencing hard times. Cozza's latest team lost to Connecticut today, 38-12, before a crowd of 29,066 in the Yale Bowl and several new standards were set, negative ones for the Elis.

title: RAW MILK SUBJECT OF DEBATE
description: SOME people prefer their cow's or goat's milk raw; they say the heat of pasteurization kills off important nutrients and increases the cholestrol content of the milk. Their preferences to the contrary, it has been 32 years since the sale of raw milk was permitted in Suffolk County.

title: Shop Chemicals Getting Tagged
description: Most workers would presumably like to know about potential hazards from chemicals used in their trade. Just who should be told, and what kind of information should be given, are subjects hotly contested by industry and labor officials. After years of debate, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration is in the final stages of making a new set of ''right-to-know'' rules for the labeling of workplace chemicals.

title: CITY OPERA: SEASON'S FIRST 'LA BOH EME'
description: The New York City Opera got a little further into its young season Friday night with its first ''La Boh eme.'' A collection of healthy young voices made Puccini's opera work, and this solid singing was surrounded by simple, straightforward staging and some very attentive playing from the City Opera's orchestra conducted by Imre Pallo.

title: CUOMO DESIGNATES BOND ISSUE PANEL
description: After winning new support for his proposed $1.25 billion ''Rebuild New York'' transportation bond issue last week, Governor Cuomo named a bipartisan private committee yesterday to work for its passage by the state's voters in November.

title: SON OF SENATOR SEEKING N.H.L. JOB
description: SOME members of the Hartford Whalers occasionally call one of the team's rookie goalies ''Senator.'' That is not surprising since the player, Gray Weicker, is the son of United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Greenwich.

title: MAKING THE CUT
description: BY JOHN TARKOV John Tarkov is a senior editor of Geo magazine. EDWARD SOREL

title: AFTER A YEAR OF KOHL, GERMANY GETS IMPATIENT
description: It is just a year since Chancellor Helmut Kohl came to power in a backstage switch of parliamentary alliances, and seven months since his conservative coalition of Christian Democrats and Free Democrats ratified its hold with a decisive electoral victory. By any benchmark, the Chancellor's honeymoon is over.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: PEACEMAKING FORUM

title: SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 25, 1983
description: International

title: LEARNING LIFE LESSONS BY SETTING GOALS IN SPORTS
description: THE New York Islanders win their fourth straight Stanley Cup and are proclaimed the best team in hockey history. Carl Lewis wins three events at the United States Track and Field Championships. He is the first person to win three individual events at a national championship since 1886. Martina Navratilova sweeps to titles at Wimbledon and the United States Open.

title: LARGE BACKLOG IN CIVIL COURT CAUSES CONCERN
description: ONE day in 1979, when she was on her way to work as a bookkeeper, Martha O'Brien of Greenwich tripped on a sidewalk in town, fell and broke her hip. A year later she sued the company that owned the sidewalk. After two operations she had accumulated $20,000 in medical bills and was disabled to the extent that she could not return to work.

title: INSURANCE FOR THE INDUSTRY'S FUTURE
description: EARLIER this month, a Federal appeals court in Philadelphia delivered a landmark ruling that may have saved the future of the United States computer software industry. In a case brought by the Apple Computer Company against the Franklin Computer Corporation, in which Apple sought to stop Franklin from copying two of its popular models, the court decided that all computer software, whether it appears on a floppy diskette or is etched into the silicon chips deep inside a computer, is protected by United States copyright laws.

title: 5 Abducted in Robbery Found Slain in Texas
description: The bodies of five people apparently abducted from a fast-food restaurant in a robbery were found today off a rural road about 15 miles south of here, each one shot in the back of the head.

title: Lutherans and Catholics Bridge A Wide Chasm
description: As they grope toward common theological ground, Christians have sometimes found doctrinal differences to be matters of semantics more than of substance. But the major rift between Roman Catholics and Lutherans has been substantial, involving contrary interpretations of the doctrine of ''justification'' that describe how sinful humanity can obtain salvation.

title: PERSONABLE INTERIORS
description: There are rooms that are remarkable for reasons that are not architectural. A perfectly bland apartment, for example, might be special because of its 20th-floor view into a pack of skyscrapers: The environment is really in the view, not the room - you live in its mists, the randomness of the lights, the reflections of the sky in the windows. There are children's rooms, lined with dolls, that are environments of stories and wishing, rather than four-sided spaces occupied by a child. The Mexican architect Luis Barragan has used colors so intense that the environment in between is an emotion. There are houses furnished with so many cues to a family's past - family pictures, mementos, heirlooms - that they are environments of memory.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: THE summer may be over, but the fleet is still on the water. The fleet of motorized model boats, that is, launched by a group of full-grown men on Woodlands Lake here every Thursday evening as long as the weather holds.

title: GERMANS TO JOIN AMERICANS FOR TRICENTENNIAL CELEBRATION
description: THIS city is expecting thousands of visitors from the area, as well as from Germany, next month to help celebrate the 300th anniversary of the founding here of the first permanent German settlement in America.

title: BEYOND PAPER AT THE HUDSON MUSEUM
description: FOR both viewer and reviewer, the art of Paul Wong should be a piece of cake. His sculptures now at the Hudson River Museum are festive confections out of handmade paper and bamboo.

title: TAX PLAN IS MAPPED AS LURE TO HIGH-TECHNOLOGY INDUSTRY
description: MEMBERS of the Commission on Science and Technology appointed by Governor Kean a year ago have concluded that, if new high-technology businesses are to come to New Jersey and existing companies are to stay and expand, the state will have to do something about:

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: PORT RICHMOND
description: THE trees lining Richmond Avenue, the main commercial street of Port Richmond, S.I., are scrawny and new, planted in freshly dug plots in the long shadows of the modern street lamps.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ''PEOPLE are hungry in New Jersey. They're going without shelter, without health care. Their fundamental needs of life aren't being met.''

title: Helen Sandberg Becomes a Bride
description: Helen Park Ershler Sandberg, daughter of Mrs. Stanley M. Finkel of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., and the late George Sandberg of New York, was married yesterday to Timothy Peter Bleichroder Metzger, son of Juan E. Metzger of New York and Stratton Mountain, Vt., and Irene Bleichroder Wright of Boston and Orleans, Mass. Rabbi David Posner of Temple Emanu-El in New York performed the ceremony at the Helmsley Palace Hotel.

title: HOSPITAL RATES: CRITICISM RISES AS U.S. SHIFTS
description: An Opinion article about the D.R.G. system is on page 30.

title: ENRIRONEWS
description: THE New Jersey Environmental Congress, a major educational gathering of environmentalists in the state, will take place in Princeton on Oct. 22 More than 500 people are expected.

title: Susan Menconi and Bruce Hoheb Exchange Vows
description: Susan Ewen Menconi and Bruce Anthony Hoheb were married yesterday at the Wequassett Inn in Chatham, Mass., by the Rev. Charles W. Tait, Episcopal chaplain of the Salisbury (Conn.) School.

title:
ART;
PRINCETON: POETRY, SANS NOSTALGIA, IN PHOTOGRAPHS
description: AT THE least, one wishes that the photographer Harry Callahan were a travel agent so he could book us into the essence of a place without distractions. But the exhibition of his recent dye-transfer color photographs at the Princeton Gallery of Fine Arts, 8 Chambers Street, reveals that giving guided tours is not Mr. Callahan's foremost concern.

title: COUNTY TO GET ITS FIRST SHELTER FOR RUNAWAYS
description: AIDED by a $45,000 Federal grant, the county's first shelter for runaway and homeless youths will open its doors this fall in White Plains. The shelter, in a Longview Avenue house that had been used as a residence for mentally retarded adults, will have room for seven people and it is expected that 400 youths will use it in its first year of operation.

title: STATE'S TOP TEAM WOOS COMMUNITY
description: There are no hot spots here. Two restaurants and a new shopping mall with the town's only movie theater are considered mildly warm. But residents concede that the city is pretty quiet, and a good laugh is had whenever someone mentions the summer's popular T-shirt that advised: ''Clifton Park, Noted for Nothing, Just a Stopover.''

title: MORE FOR LESS
description: n home furnishings, there are three basic types of quality,'' says David Easton, the interior designer. ''There is quality of manufacture - first-rate materials skillfully joined; and quality of provenance - objects with a distinguished past. Unfortunately, neither of these types of quality is available to people who don't have a lot of money. But quality of design is not always reflected in what something costs.''

title: KOCH'S PLEA ON 'SPECIAL INTERESTS' SETS OFF A DISPUTE WITH GOTBAUM
description: Mayor Koch's recent call for Democrats to stop concentrating on appealing to ''special-interest groups'' has touched off an argument between the Mayor and the leader of New York City's largest municipal union.

title: A FUMBLING START FOR DICKERSON OF RAMS
description: THROUGHOUT the week of practice for the game against the

title: STATE S.A.T. SCORES UP
description: CONNECTICUT'S 1983 class of graduating high school seniors increased their scores on the Scholastic Aptitude Test by one point in mathematics and one point in verbal skills, the State Education Department reported last week. It was the second consecutive year of increases, the department said.

title: Rhus radicans
description: Size: Varies as to habitat.

title: Flight Recorder Found In Mideast Air Crash
description: Investigators today found the flight recorder of a Gulf Air jetliner that crashed Friday 30 miles north of here, killing all 111 people aboard.

title: LOUISIANA TOLD TO REVISE 2 CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICTS
description: Louisiana has been ordered by a Federal court to redraw the boundaries of two Congressional districts in the New Orleans area to eliminate gerrymandering that kept either district from becoming predominantly black.

title: ELLEN BETH BROWN ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jay M. Brown of Hamden, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Beth Brown, to Mark Lloyd Factor, son of Dr. and Mrs. Eli Factor of Brockton, Mass.

title: WASHINGTON POST IMPOSES SPURNED PAY OFFER
description: After more than a year of what The Washington Post called ''fruitless'' bargaining with the Newspaper Guild, the newspaper told its 1,350 news and clerical employees Friday that it would unilaterally impose the terms of its ''final offer,'' beginning Monday.

title: GENE-SPLICED ORGANISMS ARE ABOUT TO COME OUT OF THE LAB
description: Proposals for releasing genetically engineered organisms into the environment reawakened last week some of the controversy over gene-splicing research that has erupted from time to time in recent years.

title: AN AUTO MAKER'S FAUSTIAN COURSE
description: GRAND DELUSIONS The Cosmic Career of John DeLorean. By Hillel Levin. Illustrated. 336 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $15.95. DREAM MAKER

title: E.L. Spalding Jr. Wed To Dinorah Rudolph
description: Dinorah Rudolph, daughter of Mrs. Vincent Stanley Rudolph of Los Angeles and the late Mr. Rudolph, and Edward Lewis Spalding Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Spalding of Kennebunkport and South Harpswell, Me., were married yesterday at St. Beade's Chapel at the Daycroft School in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Robert Kyte, a Congregational minister.

title: U.S.C. UPSET, 26-20
description: Frank Seurer threw for 385 yards and one touchdown, and Bruce Kallmeyer kicked four field goals today as Kansas upset Southern California, 26-20, in the first game between the schools.

title: Early Payoffs
description: To the Editor:

title: Producing for Kids
description: One of NBC's major programs aimed at children in the 8-to-12 year old range is titled ''Special Treat.'' The latest ''Special Treat,'' which was produced by the local station WMAQ-TV in Chicago, is called ''Kidstown U.S.A.'' It consists of three segments: A re-creation of explorer Robert Cavelier LaSalle's 1681 canoe trip down the Mississippi River from Canada to New Orleans, which includes performances by five Chicago area children, ages 9 through 12; a visit to Baseball's Hall of Fame and behind-the-scenes views of the Chicago White Sox; and a tour of both Chicago's Museum of Science and Industry and a movie set in order to observe the making of a feature film.

title: DUBLIN
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: MILL Written and illustrated by David Macaulay. 128 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $14.95. (Ages 10 and Up) By D. J. R. BRUCKNER

title: SAVORING WISCONSIN BREWS
description: One of the first things you notice while driving on the back roads of Wisconsin, past fields of waving cornstalks and through quiet, rural towns, are the countless taverns. This is beer country. Not only do Wisconsinites drink more beer per capita than residents of any other state, but they also are the nation's leading producers. In addition to big, well-known manufacturers like Miller and Pabst, the state has several small breweries. Although more than six dozen Wisconsin beer makers have closed in the last 50 years, hardy independents such as Leinenkugel, Huber, Stevens Point and Walter have survived.

title: EXPERIMENTING WITH COLOR
description: Throughout history, fashion has been a mirror of life style. And in that mirror, the way women have worn their hair and applied their makeup has not only reflected the various times, but has played a major role in the evolution of taste.

title: WHEN AMERICA WON CUP
description: OUT on the water of Rhode Island Sound tomorrow, the future of the America's Cup will be blowing in the wind - as long as there's enough wind, but not too much.

title: FAMILY-VIOLENCE LAW: MIXED REVIEWS
description: LAST Monday, President Reagan announced the formation of a Justice Department task force to study the ''darker side to family life in America - the problem of family violence.'' Hearings are to be held in the next six months.

title: REFUSE PROJECT HOLDS FISCAL PROMISE
