description: SAUDI ARABIA, Libya and Venezuela, move over. Westchester County is shortly to go into the energy-production business, and it will get the same high prices that OPEC does.

title: TO MAKE MONEY, NOT HISTORY
description: NEWSPAPERMAN S. I. Newhouse and the Business of News. By Richard H. Meeker. Illustrated. 294 pp. New York and New Haven: Ticknor & Fields. $17.95.

title: FROM SUTTEE TO BASEBALL TO COCKFIGHTING
description: LOCAL KNOWLEDGE Further Essays in Interpretive Anthropology. By Clifford Geertz. 244 pp. New York: Basic Books. $18.50.

title: MAKING A CASE FOR HANDEL
description: After one week of rehearsals, Raymond Leppard, Andrei Serban and the cast of Handel's ''Alcina'' are having what Mr. Leppard calls a ''stagger-through'' (as opposed to a run-through) in a New York City Opera rehearsal room, preparing for the new production that opens on Thursday. It is the beginning of Act I, and as the flighty sorceress Morgana (Erie Mills) leads two terrified strangers through an enchanted realm, Mr. Leppard substitutes for both chorus and orchestra at the piano. ''

title: India Saves 6,500 in Floods
description: Army and civilian teams have evacuated more than 6,500 people who were marooned in flooded areas of northern and northeastern India, the authorities said today.

title: SURVEY FINDS 73% OPPOSE RACIAL QUOTAS IN HIRING
description: Nearly three out of four Americans reject racial quotas in affirmative action programs and think that all hiring and promotion should be based solely on merit, according to a new poll by the Anti-Defamation League.

title: HOW RATES FOR D.R.G. WERE SET
description: TRENTON COLLECTING dust in a corner of Faith Goldschmidt's office in the state's Department of Health here are 77 volumes of computer printouts, the data upon which New Jersey's D.R.G. - or Diagnosis Related Groups - system is based.

title: IRISH FESTIVAL
description: Fourteen pipe bands, two ceili bands and 600 Gaelic dancers will descend on Convent Station today as the Irish-American Association of Northwest Jersey presents its second annual feis on the campus of St. Elizabeth College.

title: No Headline
description: The fashion designer Ralph Lauren, in his collections for J. P. Stevens, has taken paisley foulards and club stripes from men's silk ties, and the bright red-and-black plaid from woodsmen's flannel shirts, and put them on fabrics and wallpapers. And both he and Perry Ellis, in his linen designs for Martex, have taken hem-stitched linen sheets out of the domain of antique shops and made them available in department stores. Lauren has also designed trim for his white linen wall covering, an eight-and-one-half- inch-wide border handpainted to resemble cross-stitching - an imaginative addition to a house that is architecturally modest. Both of these fashion designers' collections are examples of fine quality.

title: COURT CASE YANKS ON THE WHOLE BALL OF FEDERAL-AID STRINGS
description: A week from tomorrow, the United States Supreme Court convenes for its 1983-84 session. Before it is a challenge to one of the enduring patterns of the century - the tendency of Federal law to follow paths first blazed by Federal dollars into untouched areas of private or state activity.

title: CHAMBER MUSIC'S CROWDED CHAMBERS
description: IT may seem odd to plan your

title: AN AMERICAN IN VIENNA
description: Paul Hofmann, the former Rome bureau chief of The New York Times, frequently writes about European affairs for this magazine. by Paul Hofmann HIS IS A MUSIC-MAD AND opera-mad city,'' said Lorin Maazel, after finishing his first season last June as director of the Vienna State Opera, ''and I am the Pope here.''

title: Leslie Weber Marries
description: Leslie Eve Weber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving A. Weber of Teaneck, N.J., was married yesterday to Alan Martin Golub, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Golub of Woodcliff Lake, N.J. Rabbi Andre Unger performed the ceremony at the Plaza Hotel. The bride is an executive placement specialist with Raymond Alexander Associates in Totowa, N.J., and the bridegroom is a student at Fairleigh Dickinson University.

title: A SOVIET DIRECTOR ELECTRIFIES LONDON
description: The early autumn sensation in London's theater is a stage version of Dostoyevsky's ''Crime and Punishment.'' Dramatizations of this novel are not uncommon, but this one comes to us with special authority. It is staged and adapted by one of Russia's leading directors, Yuri Lyubimov; it is, in fact, a re-creation, with an English cast, of a production that for five years has been in the repertory of his celebrated Moscow theater, the avant-garde Taganka.

title: HONOR FOR STICKLEY
description: MORRISTOWN ''GUSTAV STICKLEY DAY'' in Morris County next Saturday will feature a progression of events focusing on Stickley, the early 20th- century leader of the American arts and crafts movement.

title: Ann H. Boling and Carl Solberg Marry
description: Ann Hartinger Boling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Howe Boling of Wisconsin Rapids, Wis., was married yesterday to Carl Tobias Solberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Solberg of Port Chester, N.Y. The Rev. Richard W. Solberg, the bridegroom's uncle, performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Lutheran Church in New York, assisted by the Rev. John S. Damm.

title: JEWS CELEBRATE A HARVEST FESTIVAL
description: ACCORDING to the Hebrew calendar, the Jewish festival of Succoth, the Feast of Tabernacles, falls five days after the end of the solemn High Holy Days of Rosh ha-Shanah and Yom Kippur. Jewish families throughout Connecticut celebrate Succoth this week, a holiday that is, in contrast, anything but solemn.

title: HASTINGS ROLLS OVER HAMILTON
description: Jason McGinnis rushed for 205 yards on 20 carries yesterday, and Dennis Gromelski passed for 132 yards and 4 touchdowns as Hastings trounced host Hamilton, 35-7.

title: 10 YEARS AFTER OIL CRISIS: LESSONS STILL UNCERTAIN
description: Ten years ago, in the early hours of Oct. 17, 1973, six Arab and non-Arab members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, meeting in Kuwait, decided to raise the price of their oil by 70 percent.

title: Lois Romano Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael Romano of Fishkill, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lois Romano, to Sven Erik Holmes, son of Dr. and Mrs. Clifford N. Holmes of Bartlesville, Okla. The wedding is to be Jan. 28.

title: MARCOS WARNING ON PROTESTS
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that his Government and military forces would allow no more unauthorized demonstrations.

title: Chilean Police Seize 6 In Clash With Students
description: The police clashed today with a group of about 150 students who marched out of memorial services for the Nobel Prize-winning poet Pablo Neruda shouting slogans against the military Government of President Augusto Pinochet.

title: Naples
description: To the Editor:

title: MELODRAMA IS HIS STOCK IN TRADE
description: If you play an identify-the-surname game in Ireland, and ask what name follows Garret, many people will automatically say FitzGerald.

title: REGENTS URGED TO PRESS FOR MORE SCHOOL AID
description: Representatives of several major education groups told the State Board of Regents this week that it should press the Legislature to provide more school aid to localities.

title: Article 187547 -- No Title
description: A mathematics professor, retired from North Dakota State University, left his entire estate of $90,000 for an endowment to feed birds and squirrels, the Fargo-Moorhead Area Foundation has announced.

title: WHEN LANGUAGE INVADES REALITY
description: BETWEEN FANTOINE AND AGAPA By Robert Pinget. Translated by Barbara Wright. 83 pp. New York: Red Dust. $8.95. THAT VOICE

title: CONCERT: WATTS AND KUBELIK
description: Andre Watts, the American pianist, joined Rafael Kubelik and the New York Philharmonic in an all-Beethoven program in Avery Fisher Hall Thursday night. Mr. Watts's contribution was the solo part in the ''Emperor'' Concerto. Mr. Kubelik also conducted the orchestra in the ''Eroica'' Symphony, repeated from last week's subscription series.

title: 9TH DISTRICT: THE 'FAIR FIGHT' CAMPAIGN
description: OSSINING AS the sun beat down on the Chilmark Shopping Center here, Bill Crosbie assembled campaign literature last week under the raised trunk lid of Stan Kirwin's Toyota.

title: POPE AGAIN EXHORTS U.S. ON SEXUAL MORALITY
description: For the third time this month, Pope John Paul II made a major statement today condemning those who disobey the Roman Catholic Church's teaching on marriage and the family.

title: A LOW-PRICED FIND IN BETHEL
description: CHARISMA may be as important in the restaurant business as in politics. How else do you explain why restaurant A thrives and restaurant B, similar in menu, preparation, service and ambience, does not?

title: A DIETER'S DILEMMA IN FRANCE
description: The franc was low, we hadn't been in the French countryside for a long time and my husband said, ''Now's the time. We'll take in a two-or three-star restaurant every night and drive around during the day.''

title: Q&A
description: Can a Wall Be Legalized?

title: WHY HAS RADIO TUNED OUT CHILDREN?
description: There is little reason to believe that when television entered children's lives in the 1950's it somehow destroyed their ability to enjoy other forms of entertainment. Most children, after all, continue to read books; indeed, according to industry statistics, the number and variety of books published for younger readers have increased over the past decade. Why, then, do children under 12, once among radio's most enthusiastic fans, rarely turn to radio?

title: A HOMECOMING FOR ETCHELLS
description: THIS season E. W. (Skip) Etchells is going to another world championship yachting regatta, but fortunately for this year's entrants, he won't be at the helm of a competing boat.

title: Woman Who Won Anti-Klan Lawsuit Dies Penniless at 51
description: A black woman awarded $115,000 in a lawsuit againt Ku Klux Klan violence never collected the money and died a pauper, but civil rights leaders promised today to give her a ''decent burial.''

title: SIGNING A CONTRACT BEFORE MARRIAGE
description: WHEN the head of a large public company recently separated from his wife, the man's lawyer, Roy M. Cohn, was relieved, but not because the marriage was over. Two years earlier, at Mr. Cohn's insistence, the couple had signed a prenuptial contract. Now, instead of a divorce settlement that would make headlines, the woman would quietly receive a small, lump sum settlement. Mr. Cohn, a New York lawyer whose practice includes many wealthy individuals, says 90 percent of his clients who get married now have prenuptial contracts.

title: On Unreasonable Expectations
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: EVEN MINIMAL SHEPARD IS FOOD FOR THOUGHT
description: REGEN Nightingale Tues A.M. Back in 1970, Sam Shepard's ''Unseen Hand'' introduced us to the Sorcerers and Silent Ones of the High Commission of Nogoland, reclusive but awesomely influential creatures with a special enthusiasm for mind warps, time splits, telepathic force-fields, dimensional overlays and other brain-splintering voodoo. Well, 13 years later it looks rather as if Mr. Shepard was writing coded prophecies about himself. With ''True West'' nearly a year into its run at the Cherry Lane, ''Fool for Love'' thriving at Circle Rep, and ''Superstitions'' and ''The Sad Lament of Pecos Bill'' just arrived at La Mama, it is clear that he has cast a much more than ordinary spell over the theatrical faithful; no bad thing in my view, and perhaps no surprising one either, given the competition currently about. There is nothing like hearing some other dramatists hold forth on American themes to make one appreciate Shepard, even minor Shepard, and even minimal Shepard, such as the two fragments at La Mama.

title: Vermont
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Danehower And an Executive Wed in New York
description: Susan M. Danehower, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Danehower of Lansdale, Pa., was married yesterday to Christopher d'Arnaud-Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert d'Arnaud-Taylor of London. The Rev. Andrew Mullins performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title:
ART;
VIDEO ART: READY FOR PRIME TIME?
description: ARTISTS compelled to be at the cutting edge of developing ideas have been experimenting with technology-related approaches, believing this to be art's latest frontier. Many have begun to explore the unusual, intensely luminous results possible when the camera records images placed on a monitor screen, and they admit to being influenced by the fact that video photography lends itself to wall hanging, with the accompanying opportunities for display and discussion in traditional settings, particularly galleries.

title: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE
description: It is uplifting to read that in this world of increasing specialization, Douglas Hofstadter is reaching out, laterally as it were, and putting ideas together from such diverse fields as philosophy, neuroscience and artificial intelligence (''Exploring the Labyrinth of the Mind,'' by James Gleick, Aug. 21).

title: Q&A
description: Question: I have been told that there is inn-to-inn hiking, biking (and cross-country skiing in winter) in the mountain regions of New York State; can you tell me how to find out about lodgings that participate in such programs? - P.T., Danbury, Conn.

title: THE RUSH TO DEREGULATION --
description: The first example, concerning infant formula, in the article, ''The Rush to Deregulate'' is totally inappropriate.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: AUTHOR ON AUTHORS

title: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE
description: I found special irony in James Gleick's statement that the next term in the sequence ''1-2-2-3-3-3-'' could be determined without thinking.

title: GALLERY VIEW ; SCULPTORS ON PAPER AND A GALLERY ON THE MOVE
description: As artists, sculptors get a bonus. They work in the round, but they can also work in the flat, making drawings on paper that they may or may not translate into sculptural mediums. They thus enjoy both dimensions, 2-D and 3-D, whereas painters have only one, unless they are those rare polymediastes who can switch back and forth between disciplines.

title: New Soviet Signals on KAL 7
description: Passions aroused by the shooting down of Korean Air Lines Flight 7 took on a life of their own last week. Reagan Administration officials said the partial freeze in Soviet-American relations could last until after next year's Presidential election. Possibly dismayed at that prospect and by international reaction, the Russians began dropping hints of regret and admissions of error.

title: Margeret Hilles Stone Becomes Bride
description: Margaret Hilles Stone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Stone 3d of Washington, was married yesterday to Armand de Torres, son of Mr. and Mrs. Manuel de Torres of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., and Key Biscayne, Fla. The Rev. John Crocker performed the ceremony at the Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J.

title: KEAN TAKES THE OFFENSIVE ON HOBOKEN WATERFRONT PLANS
description: FACED with a new set of demands by Mayor Koch of New York City and an increasingly sluggish Legislature in Albany, Governor Kean, in his latest efforts on behalf of Hoboken's $500 million waterfront-revival plan, has threatened to block funds for a projected Navy base on Staten Island.

title: THE NEW EFFORT TO CONTROL INFORMATION
description: A MONTH AGO TODAY, THE REAGAN ADMINistration publicly released a contract that has no precedent in our nation's history. To be signed by all Government officials with access to high-level classified information, it will require these officials, for the rest of their lives, to submit for governmental review newspaper articles or books they write for the general reading public.

title: FORMING VOLUNTEER PATROLS
description: WHETHER people live in a city apartment or a suburban house, they are finding that a sense of security in their homes often requires more than extra locks on the doors or even electronic warning systems.

title: LEGACY OF A YOUNG GIRL
description: I walk beside the tree-lined Prinsengracht, searching for No. 263, surprised that the area is so attractive, that the houses are lived in, their shiny windows reflecting the first few fallen leaves of autumn drifting on the olive surface of the canal. Above me, glints of sunlight filter through the trees and outline each gabled roof. Cars cram the uneven street, and houseboats, some with gardens on their roofs, scrape at their moorings inches away.

title: HOW AN EDUCATIONAL IDEA CAN GO AWRY
description: ALARGE number of children returning to school this fall are being exposed to one or more new educational programs, and if history is a guide, some of those programs will soon be abandoned.

title: Seaver and Mets Down Cubs
description: Brian Giles had four hits and four runs batted in, George Foster had his first four-hit day of the season, and Tom Seaver earned the 273d victory of his career today as the Mets defeated the Chicago Cubs, 7-6.

title: 11 Food Outlets Cited by City For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 11 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

description: The Defense Department, once confident that its computers were virtually impregnable, has become increasingly concerned about their future security.

description: In reference to the article ''G.O.P. Leadership Disputed in Suffolk'' (Aug. 21), your readers should be aware that the Suffolk County Republican chairman, Anthony Prudenti, was named County Leader of the Year by his peers.

title: Reagonomics Doll
description: Unemployment was up, the economy was down, and critics of the Administration said ''Reaganomics'' was to blame. David L. Howell and his wife, Margaret-Mary, operators of a novelty gift business called Dots Okay Inc., saw room to turn a buck.

title: CARLTON AIMING TO BECOME 3D PITCHER TO WIN 400
description: Next on the agenda for Steve Carlton: No. 400.

description: ''Wien, Wien, Nur du Allein,'' or ''Vienna, Vienna, Only You,'' is a tedious, long ballet by Maurice Bejart that is by no means one of his worst.

title: Stuart Greenspon Wed To Camilla Trinchieri
description: Camilla Trinchieri, daughter of Mrs. Kathleen Reeder Trinchieri of Rome and the late Alfredo Trinchieri, was married yesterday to Stuart P. Greenspon, son of Mrs. Emanuel Greenspon of Bal Harbour, Fla., and the late Dr. Greenspon of Newport News, Va. Justice Theodore R. Kupferman of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Manhattan.

title: U.S. JUDGE UPHOLDS THE REORGANIZATION OF MILFORD FIRE DEPT.
description: A Federal judge has upheld a decision that ended the City of Milford's longstanding tradition of private volunteer firefighting companies.

title: AN UNFINISHED LIFE
description: The publication next month of 'Ever the Winds of Chance,' Carl Sandburg's unfinished sequel to his youthful reminiscences, 'Always the Young Stranger,' stirs memories of my visits with him and thoughts about how authors spend their precious sunset years. What obligation does a major writer (or artist in any field) have to follow his muse to the end, to be responsible not simple to his audience but to his own talent that is, to himself?

title: POETS' ASSOCIATION HAILED BY THE CITY
description: The City of New York celebrated the 50th anniversary of the Academy of American Poets at Gracie Mansion last Thursday evening with a reception that attracted the poetry establishment - 150 poets, 60 friends of poetry and local officials.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THERE she isn't, Miss America. That will be the case for a while in Millwood, home of the newest Miss America, Vanessa Williams. Officials of the town of New Castle had hoped to get Miss Williams back home soon after the pageant, but a hectic schedule has intervened. So residents who saw the newly crowned 20-year-old junior at Syracuse University walk down the Atlantic City runway last weekend will have to wait until Oct. 15 to see her walk down Millwood streets.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I can't figure out who are the good guys and who are the bad guys.'' - Staff Sgt. Manusamoa Fiame of the Marines, in Beirut. (16:4.)

title: MARYLAND DEFENSE SURPRISES PITT, 13-7
description: Doug Cox, a junior walk-on linebacker, ran 49 yards for a touchdown after blocking a second-quarter punt to put Maryland ahead, and the Terrapins held on to upset Pitt, 13-7, today.

title: EFFORTS BEING MADE TO RESTORE BLUEBIRDS
description: HACKETTSTOWN WHEN he was a boy in the 1930's and 40's, said Jim Birchard, ''bluebirds were about as common as robins.'' By the 70's, he added, ''their population had declined to something like 10 percent of what it was in those earlier days.''

title: HOME FURNISHINGS
description: he emphasis today among manufacturers and designers of products for the home is on longevity, not on razzle-dazzle styling. It may seem like an antiquated virtue, but it is just possible that we have entered an era when furniture is forever again. As a result, furnishings manufacturers have been turning their sights inward and are concentrating on technology and workmanship. In lighting, for example, one manufacturer, Norelco, has created a fluorescent bulb that promises to combine the esthetic and psychological advantages of incandescent light with the energy efficiency of fluorescent - a substantive advance unrelated to style. In fact, in furniture and fabrics as well as lighting, for the first time in decades, the heated pursuit of a ''new look'' has been eclipsed by another, perhaps more solid goal: the quest for quality.

title: Smithsonian Isn't All Show and Tell
description: The Smithsonian Institution is often called the nation's attic, but meetings of its governing Board of Regents are figuratively held in a closet. Last week, the regents denied the latest request to let the public and press in on their sessions.

title: FAMILIAR BARBARITIES
description: '1984' REVISTED Totalitarianism in Our Century Edited by Irving Howe. 276 pp. New York: Harper & Row Cloth, $10.95. Paper, $3.50.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: THE Japanese word ''kiku'' can mean a chrysanthemum (an important symbol of the Japanese Imperial family) or it can be someone's name.

title: PRESERVATION FUND MAKE ITS FIRST LOAN
description: THE vaulted ceiling over the sanctuary of a 158-year-old landmark church near Washington Square in the Greenwich Village Historic District will be the first project financed by a new loan fund set up to preserve historic buildings.

title: Wendy E. Wise to Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Wise of Bedford, N.Y., and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Elizabeth Wise, to Carlos J. Routh Jr., son of Carlos J. Routh of Delray Beach, Fla., and Mrs. Eugene F. O'Neil of Greenwich, Conn.

description: Roberto Cabanas, the Cosmos' high-scoring young forward, has been named the North American Soccer League's most valuable player for this season.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Sept. 11 issue of Travel, the photograph on page 9 accompanying the articles on the changing faces of Asia and the Pacific was taken by Eric Kroll/Taurus Agency.

title: Democrats Plan TV Debates
description: House Democrats have agreed to sponsor a series of televised debates among Democratic Presidential candidates. The decision by the House Democratic Caucus was announced Thursday by its chairman, Representative Gillis W. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, who said a committee to make arrangements for the debates would be headed by Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn.

title: STATE SUES 2 COMPANIES ON OUSTERS IN TOXIC CASES
description: New York State has filed suit against two companies on the ground that they illegally dismissed employees who had asked for information about potentially toxic chemicals.

title: BURGER'S WARREN COURT
description: Predictions of the death of the Warren Court have been considerably overstated. Whether they have been only premature, or will instead come to be viewed as false alarms, is likely to be decided in the next nine months and on Election Day 1984.

title: A CARDINAL'S PRISON DIARY
description: On this day, 30 years ago, Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, who from the end of World War II to the present has been the personification of Poland's struggle against Communism and Soviet domination, was arrested and imprisoned. The Polish Government, which saw the Roman Catholic primate as a threat to its stability, had earlier jailed eight bishops, 1,000 priests and more than 1,000 nuns, despite an agreement safeguarding the rights and freedom of the church.

title: Haitian Critic Gunned Down
description: A month ago, the owner of a newspaper for Haitian exiles published in New York wrote that he had received an anonymous threat he would be killed if he continued to publish articles on Haitian jails. Last week, the publisher was shot to death outside his Brooklyn home.

title: BABYLON LEADER SET TO OUST PRUDENTI
description: SUPPORTERS of William M. Blake, the Babylon Republican leader, expressed confidence last week that Mr. Blake had enough votes to be elected the Suffolk County leader of his party in a few weeks, ousting Anthony J. Prudenti.

title: A Jewel for N.Y.U.
description: Rich universities get richer, too. New York University announced last week that Sir Harold Acton had bequeathed the institution his art-filled Renaissance Italian villa near Florence.

title: DANCE: FOUR NEW WORKS
description: The Yard is an art colony on Martha's Vineyard where, every summer, dancers gather to collaborate on works that are later shown in New York. Thursday night at the Riverside Church, this summer's choreographers at the Yard offered a program of four dances.

title: Celeste Angiolillo to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Angiolillo of Roslyn Harbor, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Celeste Anna Angiolillo, to Gerald James Scaife, son of Robert Scaife of Newbury Park, Calif., and Mrs. William Graf of Rowland Heights, Calif.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term.

title: BRAZIL'S PERVASIVE CULTS
description: Your readers may be interested to know that a religion virtually identical to the macumba cult described in Warren Hoge's article is widely practiced by Hispanics and others in most large American cities, particularly New York and Miami (''Macumba: Brazil's Pervasive Cults,'' Aug. 21). The religion of Santeria (meaning ''worship of saints'' in Spanish) represents the gods of the Yoruba pantheon as Catholic saints.

title: Teachers in Catholic Schools To Vote Today on a New Pact
description: Lay teachers on strike at 11 Roman Catholic high schools run by the Archdiocese of New York have scheduled a vote today on a contract package proposed by government mediators, union officials said.

title: Excavation Atom Blast By Russians Detected
description: The Seismological Institute at Uppsala University said today that the Soviet Union fired six nuclear devices today north of the Caspian Sea at five-minute intervals, raising speculation about the possible use of nuclear explosions for engineering purposes.

title: GROWTH OF OPERA POINTS TO URGE TO KNOW ONESELF
description: THERE must be a reason. Twelve years ago, there were 40 opera companies in the United States; today there are 133. Smaller operatic performing groups totaled 269 in 1971; now there are 416. Opera telecasts have become regular features on public television, and even the movie industry is getting into the operatic act. Obviously, there are new audiences for an art form that only two decades ago drew the same determined faces to its doors.

title: SERVICE CLUBS: IT'S TIME TO ADMIT WOMEN
description: AT a recent meeting of the American Bar Association in Atlanta, the House of Delegates of the association voted to support an amendment to the Federal Civil Rights Act of 1964 that would prohibit discrimination against women and members of minorities in private business clubs.

title: Joan Kirbach Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Arnold R. Kirbach of Mendon, Vt., of the engagement of their daughter, Joan Benwell Kirbach, to Jeffry Alan Blumenfeld, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin A. Blumenfeld of New York and Ocean Reef, Fla. The wedding is to be Oct. 30.

title: JOURNEY TO THE CITY OF THE THUNDERBOLT
description: Like an island of ivory afloat on a blue sea, the third highest mountain in the world looms out of the mist. Hindu legend claims that Kanchenjunga is the abode of Lord Shiva, who sits among its windswept peaks in eternal meditation upon the universe he created. Fifty miles south of Kanchenjunga, on a massive curve of mountain ridge, lies Darjeeling, the City of the Thunderbolt. It gets this epithet from the electrical storms that beset the Himalayas and from the dorje, or thunderbolt, of tantric worship. For the Hindus and Buddhists, whose temples and monasteries are found in abundance around Darjeeling, the thunderbolt stands for the wild processes of creation. Darjeeling is a witness to the spiritual power of the Himalayas where Lepchas, Tibetans, Bhutias, Nepalese and Bengalis live in the vast shadow of a range of mountains that has encouraged religious thought and art for a thousand years. There is another Darjeeling. It is the vacation spot whose appeal has been its brisk air and grand scenery ever since the British Raj, more than a century ago, headed for the northern tip of West Bengal by palanquin, boat and pony to escape the hot flat sprawl of teeming Calcutta. This is the Darjeeling of resort hotels, antiques shops and mountain excursions. In typical Indian fashion the opposition of these two Darjeelings enhances the qualities of both.

title: SCHOOLS IN U.S. LAG ON ASBESTOS PERIL
description: Well over half of all schools in the country have not fully complied with rules requiring them to identify and report on any asbestos that may threaten the health of children, according to an internal report prepared in the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Selling a Cemetery
description: It was in June 1982 that New York City, after operating the century-old Canarsie Cemetery in Brooklyn for nearly 40 years, said it was really in the wrong business. The Department of General Services said the 13-acre site was going on the block through a negotiated precedure known as Request for Proposals.

title: ARMY OVERCOMES DARTMOUTH
description: Army's defense shut down Dartmouth in the second half, and the offense awakened to rally the Cadets to a 13-12 victory today.

title: Argentine Army Forgives Itself
description: The military rulers of Argentina last week admitted, sort of, that soldiers and police had been overzealous in the anti-leftist campaign of the 1970's in which hundreds were killed and more than 6,000 people disappeared. The admission was the trimming on a package of pre-election magnaminity mainly consisting of a new law granting security forces amnesty for those crimes.

title: 5 Executives Sentenced In Italian Dioxin Case
description: A court sentenced five former chemical plant executives to prison today for their role in an explosion that released poisonous dioxin that killed thousands of animals and caused severe skin diseases in children.

title: ISRAELI 'BRANDEIS' TALKS AT N.Y.U. LAW SCHOOL
description: Justice Aharon Barak of the Israeli Supreme Court went to the New York University Law School last week and, in a pair of lectures, took on the difficult task of separating law and politics in the Middle East.

title: LEBANON'S TROOPS BATTLE THE SHIITES IN A BEIRUT SUBURB
description: The Lebanese Army, backed by tanks and heavy artillery, fought a daylong street battle with Shiite Moslem militiamen in a crowded Beirut suburb today as the focus of the Lebanese conflict shifted to the capital.

title: BENNETT SCHOOL MAGNET FOR MUSIC
description: ''ISTARTED at the Bennett Conservatory of Music when I was about 10 and went there right through high school,'' recalled Peter Salaff, violinist of the renowned Cleveland Quartet, who returns to his home town of Croton-on-Hudson for a special scholarship fund benefit concert Tuesday. ''Charles Bennett was my first teacher, and he was really very inspirational. I wasn't the prodigy type - it took me quite a while to grow musically - but he was always very supportive and took a great deal of interest in what I was doing.''

title: Recent Sales
description: Bridgewater *2*178 Leghorn Avenue, 4-bedroom, 1-bath, *2*55-year-old Cape Cod; oak kitchen cabinets, *2*wall-to-wall carpeting; taxes $698. Gladstone $137,000 *2*33 Mendham Road, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*27-year-old colonial; hardwood floors, 6-panel *2*doors, bay window; taxes $1,593. Midland Park $116,000 *2*13 Fairhaven Drive, 4-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*30-year-old Cape Cod; den with wood stove, patio; *2*taxes $2,142.
