title: THE LUSITANIA SINKING IN LIGHT OF FLIGHT 7
description: To the Editor:

title: BOSSES AND JOBS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Using the Beach At Miller Place
description: This is a response to the article ''Vehicles on Beach Draw Protest'' (Aug. 21). It appears that the Miller Place Beach and Civic Associations are confused about the erosion at Miller Place and beach use in general.

title: Fighting a Rap
description: In eight years as an aide to Lyndon B. Johnson, ? Bobby Baker managed to increase his net worth from $11,000 to $1.7 million.

title: SAVING THE EVERGLADES, WITH A PASSION
description: Gov. Bob Graham, who grew up next to the Everglades and has an enduring love for them, heads the list of converts. ''In the past we saw the Everglades as an ominous, hostile swamp to be drained for human use,'' he said. ''Only recently have we begun to see its preservation as crucial for human survival.''

title: General Toyota Makes a Deal
description: American labor principles and Japanese management practices bowed to each other last week - and to some practicalities.

title: Trevino's 68 Provides 2-Shot Lead in Texas
description: Lee Trevino trimmed four strokes off par on a three-hole stretch and moved into a two-stroke lead after the third round of the $350,000 LaJet Coors Classic golf tournament today.

title: Bosses and Jobs
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Scotland
description: To the Editor:

title: NAPLES
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY'S LIASON AT U.N.: DIPLOMATS' DIPLOMAT
description: It comes as something of a surprise when you consider that she grew up in Grand Rapids, Mich. Gillian Martin Sorensen, New York City Commissioner for the United Nations and for the Consular Corps, speaks English with a lilting English-Irish accent.

title: THE VICTORY OF LOSERS, INC.
description: A new confidence can be found in the legion of self-doubt. Isolationist legislators and dovish pundits sense that their brand of defeatism is gaining the upper hand in the formation of public opinion. In debates and polls on our involvement in Lebanon and El Salvador, we have been witnessing the triumph of Losers, Inc.

title: TRIAL ENDING FOR 3 OVER LAB SAFETY RESEARCH
description: Testimony has ended in the Federal trial here of three former officials of Industrial Bio-Test Laboratories who are accused of falsifying safety tests.

title: The Smokies
description: To the Editor:

title: 30,000 MARCH
description: An estimated 30,000 marchers in a southern city today demanded the resignation of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, and the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Manila pleaded with him to accept a compromise aimed at averting ''a bloody revolution.''

title: Hebrew High School And Its Program
description: I want to commend Michael Winerip for his most enlightening article, ''Around Card Tables, an Old World Discussion Is Revived''(Aug. 21). It presented to the readers a clear picture of how many professional businessmen and young adults continue to study Talmud and Jewish Law.

title: THE 'BALLETS RUSSES' LEGACY
description: As the 1983 dance season goes into its final quarter, a special anniversary should not go unnoticed. It will soon be 50 years since the Ballets Russes de Monte Carlo performed in the United States for the first time at the St. James Theater in New York on Dec. 22, 1933. The same half-century mark holds true for London, where this once-glamorous and always controversial company burst upon an excited ballet scene on July 4, 1933.

title: Miss Curtis Is Married
description: Deborah Eaton Curtis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Peck Curtis Jr. of Rochester, was married yesterday to William Michael Donovan, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Francis Donovan of Lynnfield, Mass., and Marco Island, Fla. The Rev. Robert M. Wainwright performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Rochester.

title: LOS ANGELES FAMILY TELLS OF WAR WITH GANGS
description: ''It's like an armed camp,'' Eugene Hawkins said of the vigil he and three brothers have been keeping since members of neighborhood youth gangs began threatening his family and attacking the Hawkins home.

title: PEANUT BUTTER
description: To the Editor:

title: Needed: Details On the Bond Issue
description: The article ''Lines Forming on State Transit Bonds'' (Aug. 28) clearly points to the need for a list of the individual infrastructure projects of the ''Rebuild New York'' bond issue.

title: PRIVATE SPACES
description: or many people, there is nothing quite as luxurious as a custom-designed and impeccably executed bathroom and dressing room that combine the newest modern equipment with a classic, gracious style. ''Nothing was there,'' says Peter Marino, the architect of this lavish bathroom complex designed for his clients, Lawrence and Carol Saper. ''The walls were all moved and the spaces newly created.''

title: ; TAXATION AS A MARRIAGE DISINCENTIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: Aruba
description: To the Editor:

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: A Federal district judge has granted the wishes of public school officials and approved nearly $46 million to improve education in the metropolitan area's voluntary desegregation plan.

title: CONFLICTING INTERESTS
description: Donald H. Bell devotes much of his article, ''Conflicting Interests'' (About Men, July 31), to belaboring the difficulties men have adjusting to the needs of both the home and the workplace.

title: The Repercussions Of Cutbacks at Parks
description: According to John Sheridan, general manager of the Long Island State Parks and Recreation Commission, insufficient state budget allocations during 1983 forced the systematic closing of fields and seasonal staff reductions and deferred maintenance at many state park facilities on Long Island. The closings of Jones Beach No. 1, West End No. 1 and Robert Moses No. 4 are particular examples.

title: Linda Frackman To Wed Lawyer
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Armand J. Kleinberg of New York of the engagement of Mrs. Kleinberg's daughter, Linda S. Frackman, to Daniel J. Beller, son of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold Beller, also of New York. A December wedding is planned.

title: Debra Judell Has Nuptials
description: Debra T. Judell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Judell of White Plains, and Jeffrey Dean Mamorsky, son of Mildred Mamorsky of New York and Paul Mamorsky of Fort Myers, Fla., were married yesterday. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony in the Beth-El Chapel of Temple Emmanu-El in New York.

title: WOMEN'S PANEL MARKS 10TH YEAR
description: SINCE its establishment 10 years ago by the General Assembly, the Connecticut Permanent Commission on the Status of Women has discovered that the barriers to equal rights can be more than legal or attitudinal ones.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THERE'S another empty room in the house. The second son has left the nest, and our once noisy household of four has been halved to a somewhat less restive two.

title: Dixon Wins at 10 Miles
description: Rod Dixon of New Zealand today won his third Virginia 10-Miler with a time of of 47 minutes 12 seconds.

title: CPTV COMPETING FOR MORE VIEWERS
description: WHEN the new Connecticut Public Television schedule was announced last week, it appeared to be the standard fare of national features and locally produced programs. But a look between the lines revealed a polite struggle to attract more Connecticut residents to the Connecticut channel.

title: Miss Bailey Wed To David Noling
description: Victoria Bailey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Bailey of Washington, was married there yesterday to David Eric Noling, son of Monica L. Williams and Lawrence J. Noling, both of Indianapolis. The Rev. Vienna Anderson performed the ceremony at St. Alban's Episcopal Church.

title: ROCK: VOCAL DUO AT FOLK CITY
description: Odd mixtures of country fiddling and Motown rhythms characterize the music of Helen Hooke and Sindy Scalfi, the female singer-instrumentalist duo who appeared at Folk City Thursday with a rock rhythm section.

title: MARLBORO TO HIGHLAND BLADE
description: For a moment, it looked like the Woodward Stakes all over again: Slew o' Gold clinging to the lead and Bates Motel gaining on the outside. But two jumps before the finish line, Highland Blade flew up on the rail and passed them both to win the $400,000 Marlboro Cup yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: WHAT'S WRONG WITH NATO?
description: ACCORDING TO A RECENT REPORT by the International Institute for Strategic Studies, the London-based research center, NATO is in trouble. Western Europe and the United States, the study points out, appear to have different attitudes and policies toward the Middle East, Central America and Poland, different perceptions of the Soviet threat, different conceptions of the proper economic relations between the West and the Russians; and there seems to be a belief in Europe that the Reagan Administration is somewhat too casual about the possibilities of nuclear war.

title: SERIES FOR FAMILIES OF HOMOSEXUALS
description: ''ARE you still my mother?'' That is what Gloria Back's son asked her not long after he told her he was homosexual. Now Mrs. Back, a social worker, is trying to help other parents answer that question in the affirmative: ''I want gay children, whatever age, to be integrated into the family normally,'' she said. ''It is a false idea that a gay person must be alienated from parents and siblings.''

title: WHEN ARCHITECTS DESIGN FURNITURE
description: Architect-designed furniture of the 20th century, one of the hottest areas of collecting today, is bound to increase in importance this season, stimulated by museum and gallery shows, auctions, a major book on the subject and a proliferation of reproductions.

title: TAX BENEFITS AIDING LOW-INCOME HOUSING
description: IT IS safe to say that most of the people living in the 200 apartments of Southview Towers in Rochester are not familiar with the Accelerated Cost Recovery System.

title: No Clear Win In Budget Battle
description: With the close of the 1983 fiscal year a mere seven days off and the 1984 campaign year already well under way, the House leadership was still scrambling last week to win one in the budget battle with the White House. As the passage of a $96.5 billion measure to finance the Departments of Labor, Education and Health and Human Services readily demonstrated, the much-trumpeted drive to paint President Reagan as uncharitable by reversing his cost cutting on social spending hasn't gotten off the tee.

title: NUMBER OF FIRST-YEAR MEDICAL STUDENTS FALLS
description: Enrollment of first-year medical students has decreased for the first time in 17 years and the number of students who are women has increased, according to a report to the American Medical Association.

title: HISTORIC VIEWS BEHIND THE LENS
description: PRESIDENT Theodore Roosevelt was born 125 years ago; his great-granddaughter Alexandra Roosevelt was born 38 years ago, and although her means of expression is totally different from that of her great-grandfather, she too has a special vision - one that developed on Long Island.

title: A PARTNERSHIP WAXES STRONG
description: One of the subsidiary pleasures provided by the appearance of ''Heat and Dust'' is the realization that this haunting, beautiful high-comedy marks the 20th anniversary of its collaborators: James Ivory, the director; Ismail Merchant, the producer, and Ruth Prawer Jhabvala, the novelist who has written all of the best Merchant-Ivory screenplays.

title: 1,600 MARINES NOW IN BEIRUT
description: The Defense Department said this week that 1,600 marines are ashore at Beirut, 400 more than the number called for in the agreement with Lebanon that set up the multinational force.

title: Yonkers Football Player Dies During High School Contest
description: A 15-year-old junior varsity football player from Yonkers High School collapsed and died today during a game against Scarsdale High School, authorities said.

title: THE TROUBLED WORLD OF DISNEY
description: IT'S a far cry from Snow White, but come February, Walt Disney Productions will be bringing out a new comedy film called ''Splash,'' which will feature mermaids, nudity and four-letter words. The plan has raised eyebrows in both Hollywood and Middle America, but Disney is betting that it will also raise profits in the company's sagging film production unit, which has long been the biggest headache at the $1 billion family entertainment company.

title: THE CLASSIC NOTE
description: modernists have felt freer to use classic references in

title: JAZZ: JOYCE COLLINS, PIANIST
description: Joyce Collins, a sunny, blonde bouquet peering out over the piano at Bradley's, 70 University Place, is making a long-delayed New York debut as a solo pianist through tonight. She has been in New York before, playing piano and singing with the pianist and singer Dave Mackay and with the singer Bill Henderson.

title: AIDE SAYS WATT HAS NO PLAN TO RESIGN UNDER FIRE
description: President Reagan fended off questions about Interior Secretary James G. Watt today and a spokesman for the Secretary said there were ''no plans'' for him to resign over his recent remarks.

title: WORCESTER SHEDDING SMOKESTACK IMAGE
description: In bygone decades this manufacturing center in the heart of Massachusetts made steel, the barbed wire that helped tame the West and wire for telegraphs, pianos and the hoops for skirts.

title: UNPRECEDENTED SOUND
description: n a widely discussed essay published in The New York Times

title: CITY FAILING TO AID HOMELESS YOUTHS, STUDY SAYS
description: Thousands of youths under the age of 21 in New York City are homeless and living on their own in abandoned buildings, in the subways, on the streets and at other public places, according to a survey released yesterday by three groups concerned with homeless children.

title: HOSTILE WORDS OVER SENATORIAL COURTESY
description: Whenever two branches of government vie openly for power, the result is often high political drama. So when Senate President Carmen A. Orechio convenes his house in a session that was scheduled for tomorrow, the stage will be set for what may be the climactic act in a classic struggle between the Governor and the Legislature. The conflict turns on custom - an unwritten rule called senatorial courtesy that allows a lone Senator to block a gubernatorial appointment. The privilege has frustrated governors for decades and last week Governor Kean, no less nettled than his predecessors, labeled the practice ''insidious'' and an ''egregious example of how bad the system is.'' Mr. Kean's ire was directed at State Senator Gerald Cardinale, a fellow Republican from Demarest, who invoked the privilege to block the reappointment of Sylvia B. Pressler, a judge in the Appellate Division of Superior Court. Mr. Cardinale said he had received many complaints about the judge's demeanor on the bench and the way in which she decided cases that came before her. The judge refused comment, but her supporters began a vigorous campaign in her defense. The Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court, Robert N. Wilentz, called Judge Pressler ''one of the most outstanding members'' of the state's judiciary, who has a ''mastery of the substantive law'' and who is the ''most highly respected authority in the state on legal practice and procedure.'' Mr. Orechio and a number of his Senate colleagues also expressed support.

title: DRUNKEN DRIVERS ARE TO BE TESTED
description: AS a reminder of the new anti- drunken driving laws that go into effect on Saturday, Stamford Hospital is sponsoring a program in which inebriated drivers will test their driving skills through an obstacle course.

title:
GARDENING;
WEEDS, WILDFLOWERS, CULTIVATED PLANTS
description: A RECENT letter from a reader asked the differences between weeds, wildflowers and cultivated flowers.

title: Correction
description: The Personal Finance column of July 24 incorrectly stated the valuation date that may be used in calculating estate taxes. It may be any date within six months of death.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: SUFFOLK County's intergovernmental representative, Laure C. Nolan, has been elected president of the New York State Association of Counties - the first woman and the youngest person to head the group.

title: REAGAN TELLS ALLIES U.S. IS OPPOSED TO TAX INCREASE
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan told the finance ministers of 10 industrial countries today that an international recovery led by the United States could be aborted if taxes were raised to cut the American budget deficit, according to participants in the session.

title: MELDING ERAS IN ARCHITECTURE
description: There is far less interest in newness for its own sake in design today, and, more important still, there is far less of a belief that novelty in and of itself is going to be any assurance of the quality that we have come to seek. ''To be new and different is not necessarily to be good'' is more the motto now, and, in the last few years, the mood has shifted so much as to make the very idea of novelty almost suspicious as a basis for design.

title: A TIGER BY THE TAIL ON CONVERSION?
description: RECENT approval by the the New York City Board of Estimate of a resolution reserving its authority over the conversion of some city-subsidized housing developments has further clouded an already confusing issue, according to some city officials.

title: No Headline
description: Autumn in New York There are ways to tell when it's autumn in New York, and they have nothing to do with leaves turning, wood burning and pumpkins appearing on the vine. Those are out-of-town phenomena.

title: SUMMIT DEFEATS WESTFIELD
description: Leroy Horn, a senior halfback, rushed for 208 yards and two touchdowns to lift Summit to a 17-7 victory over Westfield yesterday in Westfield.

title: HUSBANDS, LOVERS AND PARENTS
description: -BODY PROBLEM

title: ARMY RESTORES 'PUGIL TRAINING' FOR MORE REALISM
description: The soldiers wear the look of ancient warriors, crouching stiff as gargoyles in the soggy sawdust and squinting against the downpour. Each wears football helmet, hockey gloves, groin cup and chest protector of plastic foam. Each wields a heavy padded club.

title: Education for a 'Transformed World'
description: In the months since the National Commission on Excellence in Education warned of a ''rising tide of mediocrity,'' the public has been deluged with proposals for reform. Many of them, like merit pay and a longer school year, are superficial and simplistic.

title: No Headline
description: au courant and curious about the latest happenings. Yet she lives in an apartment whose entertaining rooms have not been changed in almost 20 years. Inconsistent? Not at all. ''When you have something good going for you, stick with it'' is the Parnis philosophy and the rooms reflect this. ''Besides,'' she says, ''I get enough change in my fashion business.''

title: HIGH SCHOOLS MUST GET TOUGH
description: THE timely and courageous report of the National Commission on Excellence in Education offers a clear mandate for educational reform, and has already generated many useful responses. But from my vantage point as a university president, one area concerns me more than the others; the high school curriculum. It is imperative that the high school curriculum be immediately strengthened in the areas of quality and quantity.

title: Rebecca Aikman, Reporter, Is Wed
description: Rebecca Aikman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Aikman of Brookville, Pa., was married yesterday to Bernard Lefkowitz, son of Ann Lefkowitz of Brooklyn and the late Edward Lefkowitz.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
GOLD COIN IN PRODUCTION
description: For the first time in more than half a century, gold is once again a part of United States coinage. It returned on Sept. 13, when the U.S. Mint formally launched production of the 1984 Olympic eagle, or $10 gold piece.

title: MURDER CASE IS 10 YEARS OLD
description: ON Sept. 28, 1973, Barbara Gibbons, 51 years old, was stabbed to death in her cottage in Falls Village, in upper Litchfield County.

title: THE JEFFREY MACDONALD MURDER CASE
description: FATAL VISION By Joe McGinniss. 663 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95.

title: YALE U. PRESS MARKS 75TH ANNIVERSARY
description: IN 1920, selected alumni of Yale University received a slim pamphlet with a blue cover entitled ''The Story of the Yale University

title: PROFILING BUYERS
description: Anyone in the market for a home does not need the results of a national survey to tell him that the cost of buying and supporting a new house has increased dramatically in the last few years. Nevertheless, when the changes are measured, they turn out to be striking.

title: NOW WHERE DO THE MIKES GO?
description: Faced with a greatly changed situation, one often has to rethink things from the ground up. Conventional assumptions and convenient habits suddenly no longer fit, and you scratch your head for alternatives.

title: CITY'S MINORITY POLITICIANS OPEN THREE MORE FRONTS
description: A single line could be drawn through three separate events last week, adding fresh detail to New York's political profile. A Congressional hearing into allegations of police brutality against blacks and Hispanics; a threatened sit-in on subway tracks to dramatize demands that a black be considered for the chairmanship of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority; and the dumping of two white judges in a political deal that included the nomination of a black and a Hispanic candidate all signaled a growing recognition of the yearning for political power by New York City's minority groups.

title: 'SIGNORA DI TUTTI,' AN EARLY WORK BY MAX OPHULS
description: The elegance and pathos of Max Ophuls's great films of the 1950's, such as ''Lola Montes'' and ''The Earrings of Madame De'' are also evident in his early work ''La Signora di Tutti,'' a 1934 Italian film that is being shown today as a New York Film Festival retrospective selection. So is an uncharacteristic bluntness, which was so thoroughly refined out of Mr. Ophuls's later style.

title: BEST SELLERS FICTION
description: 114 POLAND, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Seven centuries of history in fictional form. 223 CHANGES, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $15.95.) The crises that arise when a television anchorwoman and a glamorous physician fall in love. 3314 THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Helen & Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $15.95.) Unraveling the mystery of a murder in a 14th-century Italian monastery. 447

title: Ohio Doctor Sentenced To 191 Years for Rapes
description: Dr. Edward Franklin Jackson Jr. was sentenced Friday to 191 to 665 years in prison and was fined $131,250 for 21 rapes and related charges.

title: MANHATTAN'S NEWEST LAND BARON
description: WHEN Howard P. Ronson, a successful European developer, opened an office in New York in 1979, the real estate community took little notice. Manhattan real estate development is a clubby enterprise, dominated by the few family dynasties that controlmuch of the prime commercial property.

title: STATUS OF MAJOR FIGURES IN THE BRINK'S CASES
description: Kuwesl Balagoon - Also known as Donald Weems. Convicted Sept. 14 in the state case on three counts of first-degree armed robbery. Identified in testimony as one of at least five gunmen wh jumped from a rented truck and shot at police near the roadblock.. After the shooting, he commandeered a car and escaped. His palm print was found on the tag of a stolen Brink's money bag containing $361,000. He had earlier excaped from New Jersey prison and still must serve a sentence for armed robbery and attempted murder there.

title: SALVADOR'S REBEL GROUPS MOVE TOWARD UNITY
description: Salvadoran leftists and diplomats who observe their activities said in interviews last week that the rebel movement had taken major strides toward internal unity in the last few months.

title: Newark Airport
description: To the Editor:

title: Paul R. Andrews, 77; Headed Prentice-Hall
description: Paul Revere Andrews, a former president and retired chairman of Prentice-Hall, which publishes books and provides newsletters and tax services, died of emphysema Thursday night at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: WEEK'S CONCERTS

title: 'FORBIDDEN RELATIONS,' STORY OF INCEST IN HUNGARY
description: En route home to visit her parents after the suicide of her husband, Juli, a serious young woman, meets an attractive, slightly older fellow named Gyorgy, a tailor, who is traveling to the same village. Juli and Gyorgy immediately respond to each other. Both carry psychic scars. Juli realizes that she will never know why her husband killed himself. Gyorgy, having had two unsuccsssful marriages, is sure he's one of life's losers.

title: STAGE: BABE'S 'HOME AGAIN KATHLEEN'
description: In ''Home Again Kathleen,'' at the American Renaissance Theater, Thomas Babe reconsiders one of his favorite themes, the responsibility, if any, that a parent has to his offspring. In ''Prayer for My Daughter'' and, to a lesser extent, in ''Fathers and Sons,'' Mr. Babe offers compelling evidence of his ability to deal with the complex subject. This time, however, the playwright skirts the principal issue until the audience is long past the point of caring about the outcome.

title: TWO GROCERS AND THE TIME MERCHANT
description: MY mind sometimes travels to the early years of the Depression. Two memories I occasionally visit are the local grocery store and a bill collector who regularly attempted to storm our home.

title: NEW CANAAN DEFEATED
description: Millo Ceci, a senior running back, went over from the 1 in the fourth quarter yesterday to lead Stamford Catholic to a 14-13 victory over last year's state champions, New Caanan.

title: Sports of The Times; Jets Try to Find Their 'Swarm'
description: AFTER watching from the sidelines for almost all of the two alarming losses in the last two weeks, Greg Buttle hopes to be back on the field this afternoon when the Jets take on the Los Angeles Rams.

title: Shoreham Plant Satisfies Panel
description: The Shoreham nuclear reactor finally passed a physical last week. The Long Island Lighting Company's virtually completed power plant, which must still survive serious licensing challenges, got a clean bill of health from a Nuclear Regulatory Commission licensing panel.

title: SKEPTICISM TURNS TO JOY AS CHICAGO GETS A WINNER
description: THEY bounded up the dugout steps and on to the playing field to take another bow, bundled in their windbreakers but warmed by the applause generated by more than 37,000 people, many of whom have been waiting 24 years to shower the White Sox with affection. A fireworks display would follow, but these fans were comforted by the knowledge that this time the rockets' red glare would be a reaffirmation of victory and not merely a noisy diversion from still another disappointing season.

title: POLICE KILLING OF STUDENT STUNS INDIANA RESIDENTS
description: The voices of the Afro-American Choral Ensemble rose, sweet and sad. ''Listen to the lambs, all are crying,'' they sang, and in the packed auditorium at Indiana University 400 relatives, friends, teammates and classmates of Denver Smith gulped back tears.

title: RETURN OF THE TV SET
description: fter more than a decade of eclipse by more recent technology, the television set is making a comeback. From its status as an ''idiot box'' relegated to an obscure location in the home - and in ever-shrinking screen sizes - the much-maligned television set is undergoing a rebirth as the home video terminal - the centerpiece of the new home audio-visual system. In the course of this transformation and as a result of its demands, the television set is being redesigned from the inside out, in a merger of technology and styling.

title: Michelle Diane Farley Marries Robert G. Canning
description: Michelle Diane Farley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack L. Farley of Lousiville, Ky., was married in Manhattan yesterday to Robert Gerard Canning, son of Robert J. Canning of Greenwich, Conn., and Boynton Beach, Fla., and the late Mary Mooney Canning. The Rev. Charles S. Temple Jr. performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (Little Church Around the Corner).

title: CRIME
description: Martha Grimes is described on the jacket of THE ANODYNE NECKLACE (Little, Brown, $14.95) as an English teacher at Montgomery College in Takoma Park, Md. But her novel is a traditional British mystery, set in a small town, with a smart cop from Scotland Yard and his titled friend (a la Lord Peter Wimsey) who goes along for the ride and helps him solve the case. There is also the expected assortment of samlltown types, many of them altogether unpleasant. A combination of Agatha Christie and Dorothy L. Sayers? Wrong.

title: Ruth McCrea Jr., John Lizars, Wed
description: Ruth Dickinson McCrea Jr., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Craig McCrea Jr. of East Hampton, L.I., and John Leslie Lizars, son of the late John Valentine Lizars of Chicago and the late Agnes Mahoney Beacom of Pompano Beach, Fla., were married yesterday. The ceremony, at the home of the bride's parents, was performed by the Rev. Peter D. MacLean of St. Mary's Episcopal Church on Shelter Island.

title: WATERCOLORISTS DEAL IN DELICACY
description: THIS writer has often commented on the difficulties inherent in the medium of watercolor, or aquarelle, as it is also called. Unlike oil colors or acrylics, watercolor paints are usually translucent in their effects and require a delicacy of touch that also involves a high degree of control. The pigments are essentially stains that sink into the moist paper and allow little margin for error. Once a color is laid down, there it is, right or wrong, for all the world to see.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: ALBERT EINSTEIN, who spent the last 22 years of his life in Princeton, has been dead since 1955, but jolting allegations about the role the German-born scientist played persist in both fact and fiction.

title: Carlyle in New Jersey
description: To the Editor:

title: MANY NEW PLAYS IN LINE FOR THE SEASON
description: AROUNDUP of the new season's repertory in local and nearby professional theaters reflects a certain amount of uncertainty and change, the major postponement of a new theater's opening and many new plays.

title: Alexander Praised for Dominating Style
description: They call him ''Bayou,'' ''Gator'' and ''Cajun,'' because there is something backwoodsy about Dan Alexander. Perhaps it is the camouflage-design outfits he wears to the Jets' camp, or his habit of munching from a plastic sack filled with a survival mix of nuts and fruits that he keeps in his locker.

title: IN VENEZUELAN CAMPAIGN, THE FERVOR IS LACKING
description: Even the waters of the Caribbean have been enlisted for the presidential campaign here. On reaching the coast, a drive of some 30 miles from the capital, motorists can see floats urging ''Vote white'' or ''Vote green.''

title: CRAFTS
description: the exchange of a master's knowledge for a beginner's labor - retains its validity as a stage in the professional development of craftsmen.

title: MOROCCO
description: To the Editor:

title: One Dead Heat
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Susan K. Henes Wed to a Banker
description: Susan Kathleen Henes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David E. Henes of Phoenix, was married yesterday to Charles Louis DeQueljoe, son of Mrs. David H. DeQueljoe and the late Dr. DeQueljoe of DeKalb, Ill. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, a Southern Baptist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Church Center for the United Nations in New York.

title: Torrential Rains Flood An Arizona County
description: Gov. Bruce Babbitt declared a state of emergency for Yavapi County, where torrential rains on Friday collapsed a small earthen dam and the authorities breached another dam, bringing on widespread flooding.

title: David Burton Driscoll Weds Patricia Rowell
description: Patricia Ellen Rowell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Seabury Rowell of Hamden, Conn., was married yesterday to David Burton Driscoll, son of Mrs. Hugh MacPherson Driscoll of Santa Barbara, Calif., and the late Mr. Driscoll.

title: NEBRASKA VICTOR
description: There may be only one team capable of stopping or even slowing down the Nebraska football machine this season. That could be Nebraska itself, because of fumbles, a tendency the Cornhuskers displayed again today although they routed U.C.L.A., 42-10.

title: POWERBOATS RETURN TO CITY
description: Far from the view of the thousands who watched the big powerboats from riverside cafes, high-rise apartments and the shoreline, there were some heroic deeds performed yesterday when the Chrysler Laser Classic 200 brought offshore racing back to New York after 18 years.

title: UNDETERRED BY TWO HANDICAPS
description: WHEN a friend cautioned Robert J. Smithdas, an educator, writer and poet from Port Washington, against wallpapering his kitchen because he might have difficulty matching patterns, Mr. Smithdas, like any self-respecting do-it-yourselfer, went right ahead and did it anyway. The job is perfect.

title: Refuge for Some Foes of Friends
description: The Reagan Administration ended a protracted internal debate last week, recognizing that El Salvador has political refugees. But in offering them a helping hand, the Administration had to admit that the treatment of dissidents in El Salvador can be iron-fisted.

title: CONFERENCE WEIGHS PRIORITIES FOR NEXT 2 DECADES
description: MORE than 100 of the county's planners, local officials, civic leaders and experts gathered last Wednesday in White Plains to set an agenda for the next two decades. Even before they adjourned for lunch, however, some basic divisions were apparent, as they have been for decades.

title: Eurailpass
description: To the Editor:

title: Sophie Bell to Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. George de Benneville Bell of Gladwyne, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sophie Baker Bell, to Warren Dillaway Ayres Jr., son of Mrs. Robert H. B. Baldwin of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I., and the late Mr. Ayres of Montclair, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: SPAIN IS UNSETTLED BY LABOR TROUBLE
description: The Socialist Government in Spain appears headed for labor trouble, sparked by plans to reduce the work force in government industry to make it more competitive.

title: DOUBT VOICED ON BEQUEST TO HEIRS IN MOSCOW
description: Last Jan. 8, Raymond Goldin died in Miami and left more than $100,000 to be distributed to a niece and nephew living in Moscow. Mr. Goldin's will says that if his bequest is ''unlikely'' to reach the beneficiaries the money should be donated instead to an Israeli charity.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Pursuing the Wild Whatever

title: The Worm and the Apple In the Open Air; Concert Containment
description: There was much work to be done after last July's Diana Ross concert in Central Park, which ended in disaster as gangs of young people went on a rampage of assaults and robberies.

title: Portugal
description: To the Editor:

title: 'THE RIVER NIGER' IN SCORCHING STYLE
description: NEWARK MORE than a decade after its Negro Ensemble Company premiere in New York, ''The River Niger'' by Joseph A. Walker remains, by turns, a potent and tender play.

title: The Speaker, on the Border
description: Two tides are running in America. One is at the border, a flood of illegal immigrants fleeing political turmoil and economic stagnation. The other is subtler, a wave of reaction so ugly that it threatens legal, healthy, necessary immigration.

title: Trautmann Takes 5,000
description: John Trautmann, a 15-year-old sophomore at Monroe-Woodbury, clocked the meet's fastest time in winning the fourth varsity cross-country race today at the Westlake Invitational at Blue Mountain Reservation. Trautmann's time was 16 minutes 4 seconds over the 5,000-meter course. It was his first victory in a varsity race. Last May, he tied the national high school freshman record for the 3,000-meter steeple chase, clocking 9:44.2. ''I was just hoping to place in the top 10,'' Trautmann said. ''I was expecting a lot of other guys to be up with me, but when I looked around with about a mile to go, no one was there.'' Kim Hawkes of Montville, Conn., was the leading girl's competitor, winning her race in 18:29, a course record. Connecticut schools won five of the seven varsity races and swept all four boys' contests. The boys' winners were Xavier with 41; Ridgefield, 91; St. Bernards, 68 and East Catholic, 52. In the girls' division, Warwick, with the individual winner Carol Parietti, won the first race with 58 points. Montville scored 26 to take the second race, and North Rockland won the third with 53.

title: THE CITY OF GOLD
description: Legend has it that the stones and soil of Istanbul are made of gold. It is the dream of every Turk to live in Istanbul, the land of golden opportunity, a vigorous city of business, finance and art, like an Oriental New York. People buy and sell almost everything, including the Galata Bridge and Tower. This cosmopolitan city was once the capital of three great empires, and each has left its mark: the Romans their defense walls and aqueduct, the Byzantines their churches and the Ottomans their palaces and mosques. But Istanbul's charm is its setting on the Bosporus, linking Europe and Asia. There's nothing quite like the green hills along the strait, the shimmering skyline on the Golden Horn at sunset and the early morning mist on the Sea of Marmara.

title: AT THE I.M.F., THE NEXT TEST FOR WEST GERMANY'S FINANCE MINISTER
description: LAST March, Europe's finance ministers were deadlocked in Brussels, trying to realign their currencies to avoid a potential trade collapse. France had run up an $11 billion trade deficit in 1982, and the new year had begun badly. As pressure mounted against the franc from the German mark, the credibility of France's Socialist Government had eroded and Jacques Delors, the French Finance Minister, was heard to mutter upon his arrival in Brussels something about the ''arrogance of some Germans.''

title: ART
description: The Gruenebaum Gallery, at 38 East 57th Street, has done as much as any New York gallery to sustain the vitality of Abstract Expressonism. The gallery began to focus on first and second generation Abstract Expressionism soon after it opened 10 years ago, at a moment when this formative phase of American art seemed so definitively relegated to the cubicles of art history that a number of established artists who had participated in Abstract Expressionism no longer had a place to show.

title: V.A.'s Code for Right to Die
description: The Veterans Administration, which runs the nation's largest hospital system, has joined many public and private hospitals in recognizing a patient's right to die. A new policy permits doctors to write explicit orders in advance for the denial of lifesaving therapy.

title: Aves Coaxum a Bride
description: Aves Wonza Coaxum, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Ford Coaxum of the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Walter Lee Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter T. Davis, also of Flatbush.

title: BRITISH ALLIANCE PLAYS DOWN ITS DIFFERENCES
description: The two leaders of the Liberal-Social Democratic alliance ended two weeks of separate party conferences today amid confidence that the political goals that bind them together are stronger than the differences that periodically threaten to push them apart.

title: SPLITS APPEAR IN WEST GERMAN ANTIMISSILE GROUPS
description: With the deployment of American medium-range missiles looking increasingly probable this autumn, divisions have opened in the ranks of the West German antimissile movement between those favoring nonviolent demonstrations and a minority arguing for the sabotage of American military installations and other violent actions.

title: COMBAT BRINGS NO JOY TO SHIITE CHIEFS
description: The 122-milimeter shells from the Lebanese Army gun battery just up the hill here make a whoosh as they fly overhead.

title: A REVIEW OF THE SUMMER
description: -so summer. How can I make such a blanket statement without benefit of a far-reaching network of fact-gatherers and trend-probers?

title: Czech Said to Confess To Writing Bogus Letter
description: Czechoslovakia said today that a man had confessed to writing a letter last month that criticized Government policy on religion in the name of the head of the country's Roman Catholic Church, Frantisek Cardinal Tomasek.

title: THE ECONOMY LOOKS READY FOR PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
description: Month after month the economy has been cruising on a winged keel, leaving the nation's leading forecasters, foremost among them the Administration's own, luffing in a backwash of ever more positive evidence of the nation's good health. So it was once again last week, when the Government reported that consumer price inflation has held to only 3.4 percent for the year and that growth in the July-to-September period could be around 7 percent.

title: Spellman Tops Holy Family
description: Kevin Hellmann completed 9 of 16 passes for 126 yards and two touchdowns to guide Cardinal Spellman to a 28-0 victory over Holy Family yesterday. Chris Menta scored the final touchdown on a 54-yard interception return with 1 minute and 36 seconds left in the fourth quarter. Novica Prekpalaj kicked all four of the extra points.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: AMID a pile of self-help books, one leaped out at us: Arnold Zenker's ''Mastering the Public Spotlight,'' which promises to help readers overcome stage fright, compose an effective speech and generally look and act their best.

title: HIGH TECH'S QUIET PUSH FOR LOWER TAXES
description: WASHINGTON IN a city fearful of deficits and

title: Car Insurance Blows a Tire
description: The proposed new ''pay as you go'' plan to cut auto insurance bills in New Jersey may not get very far. After announcing a bipartisan agreement in August, Governor Kean and legislative leaders had a falling out last week over how to reduce accident-related lawsuits that have helped make premiums the highest in the nation.

title: LIGHTING
description: t seems to be a paradox of physics, or perhaps metaphysics, that you not only need light to see objects, you

title: WHERE CORPORATIONS AND A FARMER COEXIST
description: IN just 20 years, the Borough of Montvale near the New York State line in Bergen County has changed from a town of farms and small shops to one of the area's most desirable locations for corporate offices.

title: ENDORSING A COMPUTER MONOPOLY
description: The Apple-Franklin litigation has been the subject of much notoriety and controversy. It has broadened beyond a dispute between two parties and has raised questions involving the rights of computer manufacturers, software companies, and, most importantly, consumers.

title: Monique Edwige Yingling Weds Gerald A. Feffer
description: Monique Edwige Yingling of Washington, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Carl S. Yinglng Jr., was married yesterday to Gerald Alan Feffer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Charles Feffer of Asheville, N.C., formerly of New York. The Rev. Elizabeth Wiesner performed the ceremony in the Bethlehem Chapel of the National Cathedral in Washington.

title: IS ANYBODY LISTENING?
description: President Reagan is getting so much noisy advice these days that he must wonder occasionally whether he was wise to get a hearing aid.

title: NAPLES
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ROOTS OF NOT-QUITE-LOCAL GOVERNMENT
description: SWELLED by the population exodus from the city, New York's pioneer suburbs, Nassau and Westchester, were the first to elect county executives in 1938. Among the areas that followed suit were Baltimore County - where Spiro T. Agnew once served as county executive - Baton Rouge, La., Milwaukee County and King County (Seattle) in Washington.

title: A Step Back for Two Firefighters
description: The ladder of success proved slippery for Brenda Berkman, whose lawsuit forced the New York City Fire Department to admit women last year. Miss Berkman and a second woman, Zaida Gonzalez - members of the department's first class of 42 female recruits, sworn in last September - were dismissed last week because they did not meet minimum standards.

title: Drug Case Moved
description: Federal authorities have dropped their charge against a Florida man who reportedly said he supplied cocaine to members of the Miami Dolphins, and have turned him over to New York State authorities for prosecution on a more serious charge. The suspect, Osvaldo Pardo, and 12 others were arrested by Federal authorities on Aug. 30 and accused of operating a cocaine-trafficking ring in Central New York.

title: Widow in the Race
description: Another McDonald is hoping to represent Georgia in Congress.

title: Moscow Asserts Nixon Canceled Seat on 747
description: The Soviet press said yesterday that former President Richard M. Nixon had booked and then canceled a seat on the South Korean Boeing 747 shot down by the Russians, but the report was denied by a spokesman for Mr. Nixon.

title: Fatal Stabbing in Manhattan
description: A 28-year-old Manhattan man died last night after being stabbed repeatedly by unknown assailants about 15 blocks from his home, the police said. The victim, tentatively identified as Mario Dumesil of 930 West End Avenue, at 106th Street, was found dead in the lobby doorway of 206 West 92d Street, near Amsterdam Avenue, at 9:30 P.M., according to Sgt. Edwin LeSchack, a police spokesman.

title: HOLDING UP A KING
description: If the international bridge community offered a prize for the Champion Globetrotter, the strongest European candidates would be two London-based players. One is Zia Mahmood, who begins play today in the world team championship in Stockholm, representing Pakistan. His complete itinerary for the past 12 months is not available, but it certainly includes Biarritz, New York, Tokyo, Mauritius, Karachi and many parts of Europe and North Africa. The other is Martin Hoffman, who was playing in and around New York last month. His entry would include: Biarritz, Bonn, Agadir, Tunis, Tel Aviv (twice), Venice, Paris, Amsterdam, Tokyo, Cadiz and Marbella (Spain), Charbonnier (France) and Cran-sur-Sierre (Switzerland). However, both would have to bow to this writer, with visits to 19 cities outside the U.S. in the same period.

title: IS SYRIA A HIRED GUN OR A LOOSE CANNON?
description: When the Syrians first entered Lebanon in June 1976, a story made the rounds in Damascus that said much about the degree the Soviet Union was able to influence Syria. Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, was displeased with the Syrian involvement in Lebanon and ordered his ambassador to deliver a letter to President Hafez el-Assad telling him so. Mr. Assad read the letter, the story goes, and promised to send a reply in a few days, which he did. Two months later, the Soviet ambassador delivered another Brezhnev letter urging the Syrians to get out of Lebanon. The Syrian President politely read it and put it on his desk. Thirty days later, when the Soviet envoy delivered a third letter of protest, President Assad, according to Damascus diplomatic lore, threw it into a wastebasket in front of the astonished ambassador.

title: CARVER HONORED FOR CARROUSEL
description: -go-round when he began to make a three- horse working carrousel as his senior project at Goddard College eight years ago.

title: STIFF CURBS ASKED TO IMPROVE AIR IN NEW YORK AREA
description: ''Extraordinary'' measures to curb air pollution in the New York City metropolitan area have been tentatively proposed by the state's Environmental Conservation Department in its effort to meet Federal air-quality standards.

title: EX-INSIDER VIEWS CHILDREN SPORTS
description: ''ITHINK it's wonderful to introduce sports, recreational activity to kids at an early age,'' said Emily Greenspan, ''but for parents to throw them into competition before the emotional maturity is there is a dangerous thing.''

title: ENTER THE INFLATIONARY UNIVERSE
description: THE MOMENT OF CREATION Big Bang Physics From Before the First Millisecond to the Present Universe. By James S. Trefil. Illustrated. 234 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $15.95.

title: THE STATE OF THE SPOKEN WORD
description: Ronald R. Butters's article, ''Can I Ax You About that Arruh?'' (On Language, Aug. 21), interested me less for the thesis, that our regional dialects are disappearing, than for what he does not discuss - the state of the language as it is spoken throughout the nation. As a teacher of drama and speech, I have been appalled at the steady deterioration of American diction, including vocabulary, word choice, usage and articulation.

title: An Upset in Half Marathon
description: Cathy Schiro, a 16-year-old from Dover, N.H., surprised veteran distance runners yesterday when she led for nearly the entire race and won the Avon Half Marathon at Central Park. Her time for the 13.1-mile event was 1 hour 13 minutes 19 seconds, a United States junior women's record for the half marathon and more than 2 minutes faster than that of second- place Isabelle Carmichael.

title: BETWEEN THE LOBS, IT'S LOLLIPOP TIME
description: EDGEWATER HIROSHI SUDA stood at the net, knees bent, his racquet at the ready. The ball came straight at him, and he punched a two-handed forehand volley across the net.

title: J. H. Arnold Wed To Miss Bunting
description: Sandra Pearce Bunting and James Hambleton Arnold were married yesterday by the Rev. Warren H. Davis Jr. at St. Christopher's Episcopal Church in Gladwyne, Pa.

title: SURFACES IN DEPTH
description: Their procedure is not a project for everyone, as it involves tremendous amounts of labor, painstakingly performed. To begin with, the plaster surfaces are sanded and then resanded.

title: A ZECKENDORF DEAL
description: It took six years for William Zeckendorf Jr. to assemble the site for the building it is putting up at 55 East 59th Street between Madison and Park Avenues. Involved was the aquisition of four contiguous midblock properties as well as a deal for the purchase of air rights from the French Institute, which occupies a building on the 60th Street side of the block.

title: Miss Siegel-Coleman Married to David Carr
description: Sharon Siegel-Coleman and David J. Carr were married yesterday at their summer home in East Hampton, L.I. Justice Shepard Frood of the East Hampton Justice Court performed the ceremony.

title: GUIDRY BEATS INDIANS FOR 20TH
description: The Yankees held a Fan Appreciation day yesterday, but the fans apparently haven't appreciated the Yankees this season, because an announced crowd of 30,202, relatively small for a Yankee Stadium promotion, showed up.

title: Maneuvering on Missiles, Home And Abroad
description: Senate Democrats failed in their bid to get a nuclear freeze resolution reported out of committee favorably last week, but pressure for an arms agreement in Geneva was nevertheless cranked up another notch.

title: THE HOUSE TIES REAGAN'S HANDS WITH A SLIPKNOT
description: FOR Congress as well as the Administration, the involvement of American marines in Lebanon has been an exercise in political frustration. Capitol Hill began the week in euphoria over the prospects of establishing an important constitutional precedent by getting White House agreement, for the first time since the Vietnam War, to a Congressional resolution on using American forces abroad. By Friday, it seemed that the legislators might be reaching for a victory of form without substance.

title: Military Analysis
description: The military problems facing the United States Marine Corps and other contingents in the multinational force in Lebanon are likely to worsen in the next few days, according to intelligence analysts. But, they add, so are those of the Druse and the Moslem militias in the hills. The unanswered question, the analysts said, is whether the United States, British, French and Italian forces would venture out to meet the guerrillas in the event the rebels started to penetrate Beirut's defenses.

title: 2 PARADES ON FIFTH AVE. STEP THEIR OWN WAYS
description: German folk dancers, marching bands, beauty queens and Mayor Koch paraded on Fifth Avenue yesterday - and so did four 50-foot-high chariots and the chanting, drum-pounding, robe-clad members of the International Society for Krishna Consciousness, more often known as the Hare Krishnas.

title: LASTING PATTERNS
description: here has never been a middle-of-the-road option when it comes to the use of pattern in interior decorating. Instead, the standing rule - use a lot of it or use a little of it - has been firmly upheld within the design world. Today, many designers are opting for the former.

title: Craig Burke Wed To Molly Lazarus
description: Molly Lazarus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lazarus Jr. of Columbus, Ohio, and Craig Burke, son of Dr. and Mrs. William G. Burke of Phoenix, were married yesterday at Gabriel's Inn in Ijamsville, Md. The ceremony was performed by Sara Barber-Braun of the Cedar Lane Unitarian Church in Bethesda, Md.

title:
ABOUT CARS;
Racing Lures Detroit Again
description: THERE was a time when it all

title:
GARDENING;
WEEDS, WILDFLOWERS, CULTIVATED PLANTS
description: A RECENT letter from a reader asked the differences between weeds, wildflowers and cultivated flowers.

title: ORIOLES LOSE BUT GAIN TIE
description: Robin Yount and Jim Gantner each had three hits to lead a 14-hit attack, and Jaime Cocanower allowed six hits over eight innings for his first major league victory tonight, enabling the Milwaukee Brewers to defeat Baltimore, 5-2.

title: FIGHTING THOSE INVISIBLE INVADERS
description: HAY FEVER is the perfect metaphor for irritation in modern life. It is melodramatic, explosive, grasping and hysterical - in short, an over- reaction to the innocuous.

title: THE SPECTACULAR AMARYLLIS FLOWER IS SURE TO PLEASE
description: An amaryllis bulb provides almost instant gratification when coaxed into bloom indoors. In size alone, the trumpet-shaped flower clamors for attention. The pointed, six-petaled blossom often measures eight to 10 inches across. Each flower stem may produce two to eight blossoms though three seem to be the norm.

title: CHILDREN'S HOSPITAL BEING DEDICATED BYT DOUBTS REMAIN
description: -bed Schneider Children's Hospital of Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center scheduled for today, the Island will have a hospital specializing in childhood diseases, a pediatric center that promises to be a technologically advanced resource for the entire region.

title: Murder Trial to Proceed
description: A state appeals court refused Friday to stop the trial of the California feminist leader Ginny Foat for a 1965 murder, rejecting arguments that Louisiana waited too long to bring her to court. However, a three-judge panel of the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit sent one issue back to the trial court for additional hearings on whether evidence from the 1965 murder in Nevada could be used against her. The trial for Mrs. Foat is scheduled to begin in this New Orleans suburb Oct. 11.

title: THE MET OPERA AT 100--WHERE IS IT HEADED?
description: As the Metropolitan Opera prepares to open its centennial season with tomorrow evening's revival of ''Les Troyens,'' it finds itself in a strange position for an opera company. The Metropolitan, which so often has staggered along at the brink of fiscal disaster, today stands accused of being financially and administratively stable. No doubt there has been some chuckling over this ironic situation in the front offices at lincoln Center. However, to some uneasy skeptics, this writer among them, it appears that the company has devoted far more energy and ingenuity to balancing the books than to staying artistically solvent. The Met is 100 and, in too many ways, acts it.

title: Ex-I.R.S. Employee Accused In Death of Visiting Tax Agent
description: A former employee of the Internal Revenue Service shot and killed an I.R.S. agent who was visiting his home, officials said today.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
TOMATOES, ANYONE? ZUCCHINI? BEANS?
description: IT IS now harvest time, and all those joys of spring in New Jersey have come to fruition with a vengeance.

title: HANDLING NEW TECHNOLOGIES
description: WAYS to counter the social and psychological pressures that workers often face with the introduction of new technologies is the heart of the research under way by Richard E. Walton, professor of human resource management at the Harvard Business School.

title: Holmesian
description: To the Editor:

title: PACKERS' LOFTON A PROBLEM FOR GIANTS
description: Beasley Reece says James Lofton is a fine person. He says Lofton has a lovely wife. He says Lofton is such enjoyable company that when Lofton arrives Sunday, he may telephone him just to chat.

title: GERMANY ROCKS TO A NATIVE BEAT
description: WEST BERLIN

title: IOWA DEFEATS OHIO STATE FOR THE FIRST TIME IN 21 YEARS
description: With 22 seconds left in the game today, a swarm of Iowa fans tore down the north goal post of Kinnick Stadium.

title:
GARDENING;
WEEDS, WILDFLOWERS, CULTIVATED PLANTS
description: A RECENT letter from a reader asked the differences between weeds, wildflowers and cultivated flowers.

title: REUSING ARMORY
description: For several years, the 70-year-old West Hartford Armory at 836 Farmington Avenue has been an empty eyesore for residents of the Connecticut town and commercial property-owners in the neighborhood. But now Leonard Udolf, a developer who purchased the 60,000-square-foot building from the state for approximately $626,000, has announced plans to renovate the structure in which National Guardsmen used to train.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article about the Westchester Cinema Club last Sunday, the name of Mark Urman of Triumph Films was misspelled and the price of the club's eight-program subscription series was incorrect. It is $56.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Music listeners hungry for a little action in the competition arena can watch young instrumental competitors battle on two fronts this week. The price is right too - both events are free to the public.

title: SMALAL LABELS ENTER THE FRAY
description: While the Compact Disk scene at this early stage is dominated by the industry's giants, the smaller companies are wasting no time getting into producing the laser-played disks. Telarc has already released a number of Compact Disks, which have received excellent notices, and now the Vanguard Recording Society is planning its first CD releases before the end of the year.

title: TALK OF COETZEE-HOLMES BOUT BEGINS
description: Gerrie Coetzee said he could not sleep. He got out of bed and took a sleeping pill. It didn't work. He tried another. Still no sleep.

title: NOTRE DAME DUFFERS 20-0 LOSS TO MIAMI
description: A freshman, Bernie Kosar, passed for 216 yards and one touchdown tonight as Miami dealt Notre Dame its second consecutive loss, 20-0.

title: FINDING SPACE FOR NEW PENTHOUSE
description: It was a whim that sent Gerry Greengrass to inspect the rooftop premises of 470 Park Avenue, a cooperative apartment house at 58th Street, where 12 cramped and dingy maids' rooms were for sale. Mrs. Greenglass was disappointed by the dilapidated condition of the servants' quarters, but the development potential of the rooftop space so impressed her that she shook hands on a deal to buy.

title: LIFE 4,775 YEARS AGO IN OLD LYME
description: ELEVEN years of excavations have uncovered some of the oldest archeological finds in the Northeast and revealed 4,775 years of the history of a small coastal town.

title: EAST ISLIP HALST BRENTWOOD BY 21-0
description: East Islip, last year's Division I champions, defeated Brentwood yesterday, 21-0, with a team composed mostly of new faces. Nine of 11 starters this season were reserves a year ago. East Islip finished last season with a 10-0 record, won the Rutgers Cup and was ranked the top team in the state in a poll of New York sportswriters. But last June, the team lost 24 seniors. Despite the victory over visiting Brentwood, Coach Sal Ciampi is still not certain of his team's ability.

title: PIRATES' CANDELARIA TURNS BACK EXPOS
description: John Candelaria allowed only three hits in five innings and drove in the only run with a double to lead the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 1-0 victory over the Montreal Expos today. The triumph kept the Pirates in the race for the National League East title, three games behind the first-place Phillies.

title: Future Events Presidents and Benefits
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. For the March of Dimes Sept. 28 - In the town house at 47 East 65th Street, a man in his early 30's struggled with the mental and physical impact of polio, resolving that his political career would not end. It was the 1920's, and the man was Franklin Delano Roosevelt. In 1938, President Roosevelt helped establish the Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, now the March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation.

title: REAGAN ASSAILS SOVIET 'INFLEXIBILITY'
description: President Reagan, in a radio broadcast carried live by the Voice of America throughout the world, asserted today that ''the inflexibility of the Soviet Government on arms control'' was preventing progress in the arms negotiations under way in Geneva.

title: A CHINESE PIANIST RESUMES AN INTERRUPTED CAREER
description: Cheng-Zong Yin will give a Carnegie Hall piano recital on Wednesday. He comes from the People's Republic of China, and was briefly in the news in 1973, when the Philadelphia Orchestra - the first American orchestra ever to appear on the Chinese mainland - gave concerts in Beijing and Shanghai. Eugene Ormandy wanted to put come Chinese music on his program. But Chairman Mao was alive, the Cultural Revolution was still in progress, and there was not much to choose from. So faute de mieux the ''Yellow River'' Concerto was selected.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN LOS ANGELES
description: The countdown for the 1984 Summer Olympic Games has begun, and Los Angeles is grooming itself for the two weeks next year when it will take center stage of the sports world. At Los Angeles International Airport, work has passed the midway point on a $750-million expansion that is scheduled to be finished by the time Olympic visitors arrive next summer. A volunteer group called The Tree People has pledged to plant hundreds of thousands of trees throughout the city before the Olympic torch is lighted next July 28.

title: Dr. Phillips Wed In L.I. Ceremony
description: Dr. Kathleen Anne Phillips, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Hess Phillips of Syosset, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Winthrop Crusan Davis, son of Mrs. Roy Bryan Davis of Greenville, Del., and the late Mr. Davis. The Rev. William Koenig performed the ceremony at St. Edward the Confessor Roman Catholic Church in Syosset.

title: LOWENSTEIN'S CONSTITUENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAN TO CLOSE PHONE PLANT STUNS INDIANAPOLIS
description: In the 1960's the Western Electric plant here was known as the largest telephone maker in the world. With over 9,100 workers, it was one of this city's larger and more stable employers.

title: FURNITURE
description: n a factory building on Second Avenue near 65th Street, 30-year-old Michele De Angelis oversees the making of fine upholstered furniture using virtually the same materials, the same techniques and the same trained staff as her father did when he began Thomas De Angelis & Company over 40 years ago. Each craftsman has his specialty. Some do nothing but hand-cut maple or mahogany frames; others, called ''springers,'' apply custom-made springs to the frame so that, when a piece is finished, it will be exactly as soft or as firm as a decorator desires. And there is even a man whose sole job is to stuff down feathers into special cases that will line the material of a sofa or chair. Naturall y,the price for such meticulous handiwork is high. The average armchair costs about $1,800 and a sofa about $6,000, not including the cost of the fabric. And nothing is produced overnight. It takes at least 16 weeks from the time an order is placed to enjoy the luxury of these sumptuous custom-made pieces. But, even so, Miss De Angelis reports, her office is busier than ever. ''People are willing to pay the price and to wait for quality.''

title: PARK TO BE SITE OF OCTOBER FESTIVAL
description: NEW HAVEN LIGHTHOUSE PARK, a former amusement park and the site of the only public beach in New Haven, is underused, according to group of city residents.

title: EDISON DEFENSE FIRM IN ROUT
description: Edison, behind a strong defense, held East Brunswick to 88 yards and scored a 20-0 shutout yesterday in East Brunswick.

title: Elizabeth R. Powers Marries
description: Elizabeth Radley Powers, daughter of Helen Whitecotton Powers of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Francis Clement Powers of New York and Honolulu, was married yesterday to Isaac Hallowell Clothier 5th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clothier 4th of Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. T. Carlton Lee performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., assisted by the Rev. Linda Peyton.

title: INDIA TO PRESIDE OVER TALKS AT U.N.
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi is due to arrive in New York on Monday to preside over round-table discussions by some 25 heads of state or government on problems of peace, arms control and out-of-balance ills of an interdependent world economy.

title: Browsing Room
description: Four years ago, on a September Sunday, New York held its first book fair on the sidewalks of Fifth Avenue between 47th and 57th Streets. The city would not consider closing the avenue to traffic.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective.

title: Catherine G. Roberts and Piero Casalicchio Marry
description: Catherine Gordon Roberts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Henry Roberts 3d of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Piero Casalicchio by the Rev. T. Carleton Lee at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. The bridegroom is a son of Lidia Casalicchio of Borgosesia, Italy, and the late Aurelio Dante Casalicchio.

title: ISLAND STOCK PERFORMANCE RATED
description: AS Long Island businesses prepare to enter the final quarter of 1983 next week, a survey of their performance in 1982 has found that in contrast to the year before they significantly outperformed every national stock market index. The gains reflected renewed investor confidence in the small, tightly organized companies that are the mainstay of the Island's business community.

title: DANCE
description: Those eternal choreographic themes of love and death are among the favorite themes to which Maurice Bejart returns again and again in his works for his Ballet of the 20th Century, now at the City Center. Thus Sunday afternoon and Tuesday and Saturday nights the company offers repeat performances of ''Wien, Wien Nur Du Allein,'' the evening-long chronicle of love and death in old Vienna, and pagan orgies will be on view in Mr. Bejart's version of ''The Rite of Spring,'' on Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday nights.

title: Steamtown's Autumn Outing S02.6 Is a Farewell
description: The mood will be autumnal on the weekend of Oct. 22-23, when the railroad museum known as Steamtown, U.S.A., stages ''Farewell to Vermont.'' Not only will the 100-mile rail excursions on each of the days feature the seasonal beauty of the Vermont countryside, but the journeys themselves will mark the museum's farewell to the state. ''Farewell to Vermont'' will be the final event before the museum moves next year to Scranton, Pa.

title: U.S. PLAN: A MAJOR DIFFERENCE
description: ALTHOUGH the new Federal plan for limiting Medicare reimbursements to hospitals, which begins Saturday, is similar to New Jersey's D.R.G. - or Diagnosis Related Groups - system, there are important differences.

title: STARTING EARLY
description: was still in a highchair

title: DARTMOUTH REMEMBERS NELSON ROCKEFELLER ('30)
description: When Nelson Aldrich Rockefeller was in Dartmouth College's class of 1930, he came to be known as a boy who loved soccer, the outdoors, student government and the arts. And in the Rockefeller tradition of not leaning on the servants, he knew how to sew and darn his own socks.

title:
INVESTING;
TRADING NEW OPTIONS TIED TO INDUSTRIES
description: WALL Street is expanding the options tools used by its hedgers and speculators. And the newest instruments in the collection are options on industry stock indexes. While options on broadly based indexes, such as the one tied to the Standard & Poor's 100 (traded on the Chicago Board Options Exchange) and now the one linked to the New York Stock Exchange Composite Index (traded by the Big Board), have given investors a chance to play the ups and downs of the market in general, industry index options give the investor a chance to speculate in the movements of stocks in particular industries, such as oil and gas, or high-technology.

title: MONTAUK TOWER BECOMES A CONDO
description: H. DALE HEMMERDINGER, the 38-year-old president of the Hemmerdinger Real Estate Corporation of New York City, has little in common with the late Carl Graham Fisher, builder of the Indianapolis Speedway and Miami Beach, except an interest in the development of high-class summer residences in Montauk. Like Fisher before him, Mr. Hemmer dinger paid a casual visit to the area and became enthusiastic about its potential.

title: SCHOOL REFORMS MEAN LONGER DAYS FOR SOME
description: Education reform is not a fuzzy concept to Ronald Raymer. Returning to high school this year, he found himself to be one of those affected by America's attempt to make the schools better.

title: PHILADELPHIA SUMMER SCHOOL TEST A SUCCESS
description: When school closed in June, 11-year-old Germyce McTillman failed fifth grade, but when school reopened this month, Germyce entered sixth grade.

title: PEDDIE BOWS, 13-3, TO LAWRENCEVILLE
description: Marty Doggett scrapped the single-wing offense this year when he took over as head coach at Lawrenceville, where that system had been used for 21 years by Ken Keuffel. Yesterday, Doggett's newly installed I formation got its first test and the result was a victory for the Larries over Peddie 13-3 in the season opener for both schools.

title: MISERY IN A SOUTH AFRICAN 'HOMELAND'
description: WHEN HE ROSE TO SPEAK, THE general was still wearing his cap, with the full complement of ornamental braid due his rank. Solemnly, he gave his undergraduate audience a rigid salute. The white, rosy-cheeked expressions turned up to him could not have been more earnest had they been in church. And the general easily slipped into an evangelist's role, depicting a conflict between forces of light and darkness. The former, it went without saying, were well represented in this lecture hall at the University of the Orange Free State in Bloemfontein, an Afrikaans-language citadel not noted for its tolerance of wayward ideas. The forces of darkness were the ''terrorists,'' black South Africans manipulated by the ''dragon'' of international Communism. It was exactly what might have been expected in Bloemfontein, except for one conspicuous detail: The general, Xhanti Charles Sebe, Director of State Security of the supposedly independent ''homeland'' of Ciskei, was black. More than pigmentation made him a surprising figure. A handful of young Afrikaners in the hall seemed uneasily aware that here was a black man who surpassed them in ideological commitment; from their point of view, he was almost too good to be true. The coiled energy and enthusiasm in the man came out in a gravelly voice and staccato articulation. When he spoke of ''the devilish, destructive actions of trained terrorists,'' he squeezed off each syllable like a retaliatory shot.

title: A ROEBLING IS GETTING HER DUE
description: Were it not for the determination of Emily Warren Roebling, the Brooklyn Bridge might not have been built according to its chief engineer's master plan.

title: HAPPY FAMILIES
description: To the Editor:

title: SHULTZ REFUSES TO SET A LIMIT ON THE MARINES' STAY
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the mission of the United States marines and other Western forces should continue in Lebanon until there is stability in that country, which he indicated should include the withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestine Liberation Organization forces.

title: Hope Brauzer Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Brauzer of Far Rockaway, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hope Barbara Brauzer, to Dr. Allan Kaplan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Kaplan of Brooklyn. The wedding is to be Oct. 15. The future bride is a dental hygenist in Hewlett, L.I. Dr. Kaplan is a dentist in Brooklyn.

title: On the Track Of the Scratch
description: For 30 years scientists have been unable to find, let alone analyze, the cause of ''cat scratch disease,'' which strikes some 2,000 people a year. Researchers at the Armed Forces Institute of Pathology in Washington, D. C., and the Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences in Bethesda, Md., believe they now have the answer.

title: SUMER FOR MODERNS
description: INANNA

title: THE NOISY WAR OVER DISCOUNTING
description: THE new display at more than 2,000 K Mart discount stores nationwide doesn't stand out much among all the flashy banners advertising bargains.

title: Laura Huntsman Becomes a Bride
description: Laura Ann Huntsman, daughter of Mrs. Charles S. Rowe of Fredericksburg, Va., and Lawrence D. Huntsman of Clifton, Va., was married yesterday to Stephen Edward Lemenager, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Lemenager of Edgartown, Mass. The Rev. Charles Sydnor performed the ceremony at St. George's Episcopal Church in Fredericksburg.

title: REGGAE: YELLOWMAN
description: With typical modesty, the reggae singer Yellowman touted himself as ''King of the Deejays'' when he performed Wednesday at the Ritz. Winston Foster, who uses the stage name Yellowman because he is an albino, is indeed a former disk jockey whose singsong commentary above the music, known in Jamaica as ''toasting,'' has made him one of the island's most popular performers.

title: WHAT COUNTS IN A LENDER'S APPRAISAL?
description: A CRITICAL aspect of any house sale involving a mortgage is the lender's appraisal of what the house is worth. This is because the lender often decides how much it is willing to lend based on its appraisal of the property's value - or whether it will give a mortgage at all.

title: AMERICAN-STYLE THINK TANKS MINDING EUROPE'S BUSINESS
description: A discreet brass plate on an 18th century house in Brussels announces the ''Centre for European Policy Studies.'' It conceals one of Europe's latest experiments in American governance - a think tank.

title: Baltimore Zoo Giraffe Is Dead With Her Calf After Delivery
description: Patience the giraffe and her new calf have died, bringing to six the number of giraffes that have died at the city zoo in the past six weeks.

title: THE BENKO: STILL SOLID
description: About 40 years of sporadic experimentation followed by almost 20 years of heavy use and analysis have failed to stale the Benko Gambit. There are coteries who swear by it and legions who swear at it.

title: COLUMBIA LOSES TO LAFAYETTE RALLY, 34-29
description: Frank Novak passed for four touchdowns and the fullback Craig Williams rushed for the game-winning touchdown with 71 seconds remaining today as Lafayette defeated Columbia, 34-29.

title: NEW YORK'S COUNTIES NOW HAVE CLOUT
description: Edward V. Regan became the first county executive in New York to move up to statewide office when he was elected comptroller five years ago. Last year, Mr. Regan, an Erie County Republican, was re-elected and another county executive, Alfred B. DelBello of Westchester, a Democrat, was elected lieutenant governor.

title: PROFILING THE SOUND'S BOTTOM
description: ONE evening late last month, a yachtsman stepped off his sailboat at the end of Port Jefferson's town dock and saw an almost identical pair of scientifically equipped boats tied up.

title: Study Asserts Heavy Trucks Cause Big Damage to Roads
description: Heavy trucks prematurely wear out the nation's highways, a private study says, estimating the cost of road and bridge repair at more than $331 billion in the next 20 years.

title: Guest Observer
description: The Definitive Word PATRICK MCDONNELL

title: THE MUSIC SEASON GETS A DOWNBEAT
description: PREMIERES and prize winners, familiar faces and some lesser-known ones add a note of excitement to the opening weeks of New Jersey's 1983-84 concert season.

description: THE lobbying group on energy issues that was founded by Ralph Nader does not like nuclear power, but as reactors go, Connecticut's three look good, the group said last week.

title: AMERICA CAN'T BRING SENSE TO LEBANON
description: We should be under no illusions about the meaning of those American destroyers off Lebanon's coast shelling the Shuf Mountains: The United States has walked into the midst of an old fight. In that neurotic land to which American troops were so thoughtlessly dispatched, foreign gunboats have always meant strangers from afar coming to tip the scales of power in favor of one group at the expense of others.

John Campbell performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Heinz Chapel at the University of Pittsburgh.

description: The Government has netted nearly $50,000 from a sale of luxury goods that had been obtained illegally by Federal workers.

title: Gyula Pap, Hungarian Artist; Figure in Bauhaus Movement
description: Gyula Pap, painter and prominent member of the Bauhaus movement in 20th century art, died today, the Hungarian radio said.

title: NEW ENGLAND'S OUT-OF-THE-WAY MUSEUMS
description: In the six New England states no less than 101 art museums, libraries and historical societies house art of such quality and diversity as to whet the appetite of any serious enthusiast. This treasure, in an area only a sixth the size of France - if the museumless expanses of hinterland Maine are eliminated - is more concentrated than in any comparable region anywhere, metropolitan centers excepted.

title: STYLE AND COMFORT
description: All four of the stylish and comfortable rooms on these pages share several attributes. Though each contains distinguished antiques, a contemporary sensibility informs their overall designs. All have color schemes that are subtle and relaxed. And, despite the presence in each of some bravura decorating - an alpaca blanket used as a tablecloth in the Angelo Donghia room,
