description: To the Editor:

title: MEDIA STAR AND MAJOR HISTORIAN
description: A PERSONAL HISTORY By A. J. P. Taylor. Illustrated. 278 pp. New York. Atheneum. $14.95.

title: Joyce Goldsmith Wed To Jean-Louis Pernin
description: Joyce Caryn Goldsmith, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Morris Goldsmith of Massapequa, L.I., and Hollywood, Fla., was married yesterday to Jean-Louis Pernin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Emile Pernin of Lyons, France. District Court Judge Anthony Barbiero of Nassau County performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Montclair Overwhelms Kean
description: Mark Casale threw touchdown passes of 10 yards to Pierce Frauenheim and 33 to Bob Vannoy, and ran 1 yard for another score yesterday in leading Montclair State to a 48-7 rout of Kean in the fifth annual Pride Bowl at Schools Stadium in Newark before 12,561 fans.

title: SHAMIR APPROACHES HIS DATE WITH DESTINY A STEP AT A TIME
description: Israeli politics can be a strange mixture of the dramatic and the tedious, moving from the exciting promise of change to the dismal prospect of monotony, from crisis to inertia. That is the way it has been since Aug. 28, when Menachem Begin, frail and withdrawn, made his sudden announcement to his Cabinet that he could not carry on as Prime Minister. It looked at first like an upheaval - the visionary leader, born of the Holocaust and burdened by the destiny of the Jewish people, stepping down and leaving a terrible void. His colleagues, who feared that he would take them down with him, begged him to change his mind. When he did not, they began a flurry of maneuvering and bargaining. Mr. Begin's Herut Party elected as the new party leader Yitzhak Shamir, 67 years old, former underground guerrilla, former high official in the Israeli intelligence agency Mossad, former Speaker of the Knesset, now Foreign Minister.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER
description: Hundreds of thousands of Americans flew to Europe and back by cut-rate chartered jetliners this summer, according to estimates. The vast majority appear to have been satisfied; at least they haven't been complaining publicly.

title: CORPORATED DAY CARE OFF TO A SLOW START
description: DAY care provided or supported by businesses is catching on slowly in Connecticut, according to Frances Roberts, director of the state's Office of Child Day Care.

title: HOW TO EXPLORE ISTANBUL'S MOSQUES
description: Every great city possesses a distinctive architecture, as recognizable as a person's handwriting. New York has its glass and steel skyscrapers, Paris its slate mansard roofs and chimney pots. Istanbul, with its 10 imperial mosques, is no exception. The great brooding monuments, flanked by pencil-thin minarets, punctuate the skyline and emphatically proclaim to any Western visitor that he has taken an enormous stride beyond the familiar and comfortable. The imperial mosques were constructed by the Sultans for themselves and their immediate families between the Ottoman conquest in 1453 and the mid-18th century. They are not necessarily the most beautiful or pleasing. Frequently, the smaller mosques achieve greatness because of the constraints of money and space that the architects had to observe. But the imperial mosques are without question the largest and grandest; situated as they are on the hills of the city, they are visible for miles around.

title: WHAT'S MISSING? THE PORCH . . .
description: WHAT'S missing on Long Island? This question might enliven town meetings; it surely would evoke revealing responses.

title: LOOKING BACK
description: WHEN Dr. Joseph Sweeney, the East Brunswick Superintendent of Schools, read a magazine piece about the 10 best high schools in the country, he wrote to the schools. What he discovered, he said, was that, by and large, the schools had done ''amazingly little experimenting with the curriculum.''

description: Japanese leaders told Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger on Saturday that it would be disastrous for Japan if the United States sacrificed Asia in the negotiations with the Soviet Union to limit medium-range nuclear missiles.

description: Political handicappers had an easier run with the elephants than the donkeys last week.

title: Further Thoughts Of James Watt
description: James G. Watt had one foot in his mouth last week and, some thought, the other out the door. The Interior Secretary with a penchant for provocation managed in a single stroke to insult women, blacks, Jews and the handicapped. For an Administration that has been struggling for months to demonstrate its sensitivity to minorities and women, Mr. Watt's idiosyncratic sense of humor could not have been more badly timed.

title: FRESH WATER DELICACIES: CRAYFISH
description: ONE OF THE most curious things about the American kitchen is how it seems to ignore - except regionally - various indigenous foods that are uncommonly good, foods that are in great and understandable demand on the tables of Europe.

description: THE PENITENT By Isaac Bashevis Singer. 170 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $13.95.

title: WILL C.P.A.'S REPLACE M.D.'S?
description: A NEW member has joined the New Jersey health-care team - the cost accountant - and soon will be a fixture in every American hospital. What he does could hurt, rather than help, you.

title: ...AND THE TIME TO SIT AND SWING
description: IN an age when Captain Video is no longer a school child's hero but an electronic games parlor, when ''1984'' is no longer an ominous novel about some time in the far distant future but a few months away, and computers are not the exception but the rule, it's reassuring that in the unlikeliest of us there still beats a heart with room for romance and nostalgia and dreams.

title: ZABLOCKI TAKES THE CREDIT AND THE HEAT
description: WASHINGTON REPRESENTATIVE Clement J. Zablocki, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, was leaning back in his big chair, beneath a massive portrait of himself staring down from the wall. The Wisconsin Democrat had just piloted through a resolution that would invoke the War Powers Act but allow American marines to remain in Lebanon for 18 months, and rebellious Democrats were denouncing the measure as a sellout to the Administration. ''They must be sticking pins in Zablocki dolls,'' the lawmaker said.

title: Sibling Sublet
description: To the Editor:

title: ENTER THE 'NEW AMERICAN CUISINE'
description: INNOVATION comes slowly to the Island's restaurants, but Savories in Port Jefferson is one place where a number of new ideas have taken hold. French nouvelle cuisine interpreted in an eclectic manner by young American chefs using native products has been given the name ''new American cuisine.''

title: TAKING A HARD LOOK AT BRIDGES, ROADS AND BUILDINGS
description: IT was not a courtroom, but at

title: Pickpockets

title: REAGAN RIDES THE CREST OF AN ANTI-SOVIET WAVE
description: -Communist core of President Reagan's foreign policy has never been so boldly on display as since the downing of Korean Air Lines Flight 7 by the Russians on Sept. 1. In the Middle East, Central America and the negotiations on nuclear weapons, Mr. Reagan seems determined to resurrect his basic contention that the Soviet Union is indeed the ''evil empire.'' To the surprise of his aides, the strategy is proving effective, at least in building domestic support for his foreign policies.

title: WILL THE REAL DEFICIT PLEASE STAND UP?
description: INFLATION plays all kinds of tricks, and not the least of them on Federal budgets. The tricks have greatly confused public discussion of budget deficits, past, present and future.

title: KENNEDY TRIUMPHS ON LATE FIELD GOAL
description: The numbers were clear. The clock showed 16 seconds to play, the scoreboard read Jackson 14, Kennedy 12 and the distance between Angelos Brisnovalis and the goal line was 37 yards. With one sweeping motion, the clock wore down, Brisnovalis kicked the ball and erased the distance to the goal and the tally was raised to Kennedy 15.

title: NEWLY UNITED ANTI-MARCOS FORCES WALK A TRICKY LINE
description: Foes of President Ferdinand E. Marcos seemed to gather strength daily last week, fed nearly as much by resentment of President Reagan's proposed visit - interpreted by some as a show of support for the Marcos regime - as by anger at the Government. What the revitalized opposition movement would do next in the face of Mr. Marcos's power was questionable, but it was clearly determined to keep the pot boiling.

title: NIGHT FLIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE WORK PLACE;
By HUMANS AND ROBOTS: A WARY ALLIANCE
description: UNTIL quite recently, most discussions of high technology have stressed its potential for increasing low productivity and restoring the American competitiveness in world markets. Business schools and scholars, however, are starting to explore the two-sided effects of introducing these technologies into the workplace. High technology promises great economic gains, but it can also create social and psychological costs for workers that, some say, can undercut the economic benefits.

title: FINE BRAHMS POURS FORTH
description: With the release of its eight-volume Brahms Edition earlier this year, Deutsche Grammophon took a discographic plunge worthy of the sesquicentennial of Brahms's birth. In the wake of that 62-disk juggernaut have come a number of worthy if less ambitious issues from other labels. A few which for one reason or another were left out of the big package are even on the way from DG. For the Brahmsian who already took his own plunge and bought that package, the new arrivals may be an anticlimax. But for the listener who still has space on his shelf, they offer unusual rewards.

title: HERE'S HOW TO FIX THE FLUSH MECHANISM IN THE TOILET TANK
description: WHEN a toilet tank doesn't flush properly, or when water continues to run into the tank and/or bowl without the tank's ever refilling after it has been flushed, most people start jiggling the handle in an effort to make the thing work properly. Sometimes this helps and sometimes it doesn't, but the problem can almost always be eliminated by making a few simple adjustments or repairs to the flush mechanism inside the tank.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: ''From what I've been able to see,'' says Lieut. Dennis Clark, who is in charge of the new patrols, ''the use of the dog as a tool, to help in police work, definitely has a lot of positive aspects to it.''

title: NEW SETBACK FOR M.T.A. ON LABOR JURISDICTION
description: Efforts of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to place the labor relations of its subsidiary railroads under New York State's Taylor Law received another setback last week.

title: U.S. SAYS SUSPECT SOUGHT ARMS DATA
description: Secret documents on security procedures for United States nuclear weapons were passed to a suspected Bulgarian intelligence agent shortly before he was arrested in New York on espionage charges Friday night, Federal officials said in court yesterday.

title: GETTING AROUND THE LITERALNESS OF THE CAMERA
description: History is written, and rewritten, to fit the present, in photography as in everything else. For as long as there was general agreement that photography's mission was to represent the world and its objects as realistically as possible, given the medium's two-dimensional limitations, the history of photography primarily concerned itself with the heritages of documentary and other ''straight,'' hands-off modes of picture taking. But ever since art photography became fascinated with the medium's illusionistic aspects and fictional potentials, the conventional histories have come to seem inadequate, if not exclusionary.

title:
ANTIQUES;
COURSES AND CLASSES FOR COLLECTORS
description: ANTIQUES are the artifacts of history and culture that anyone may acquire. Like good historians, all serious collectors, become curators of the past.

title: HOW THE BATTLE TO BRING 'BRAINSTORM' TO THE SCREEN WAS WON
description: The death of a star in the middle of filming is the nightmare that every director dreads. When this has happened in the past, filmmakers have utilized many different strategems to salvage their movies. A double was used for several of Jean Harlow's uncompleted scenes in ''Saratoga'' (1937). For Robert Walker's unfinished scenes in ''My Son John'' (1952), the director was forced to rely on out-takes from Mr. Walker's preceding film, ''Strangers on a Train.'' In the case of ''Giant'' (1956), James Dean had completed principle photography a few days before he died in a car crash, but some of his scenes were inaudible and needed to be redubbed; in the climactic scene, his drunken speech to an empty banquet hall was rerecorded by Mr. Dean's friend, the actor Nick Adams. When Tyrone Power died halfway through filming ''Solomon and Sheba'' (1959), the existing footage was scrapped and the film was started all over again with Yul Brynner in Mr. Power's role.

title: A DREAM COMES TRUE FOR AN ENTREPRENEUR
description: THE recording studio that John Montagnese built in his converted carriage house in Stamford looks like a space- age sound-stage fantasy fulfilled.

title: Somebody Goofed
description: It is a familiar picture - five interlocking colored rings floating over the image of a torch-bearing runner - and it seemed an ideal graphics touch for the covers of telephone books circulated in the Los Angeles area on the eve of the 1984 Olympics. It would have been even more ideal had the telephone company got the permission of the United States Olympic Committee before using the official Olympic symbol on the 400,000 directories.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: 2 VIOLINISTS AWARDED FIRST PRIZE IN COMPETITION
description: Robert Davidovici and Maryvonne Le Dizes-Richard shared first prize in the 1983 International American Music Competition for Violinists at Carnegie Hall early yesterday evening. It was the first time the competition had split the first prize.

title: LESS TIGHT FED POLICY IS SEEN
description: To the layman and to many participants in the bond market, the decline in overnight interest rates last week was a sign that the Federal Reserve has adopted a less restrictive monetary policy. By encouraging lower short-term rates, they concluded, the Fed's actions will help reduce other rates as well, at least for now.

title: D. L. Kuhns Wed To Karin Epstein
description: Sylvia Karin Epstein, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William A. Epstein of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Lindley Kuhns, son of Mrs. Margaret H. Kuhns of Sarasota, Fla., and the late E. Lindley Kuhns. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents by Canon William A. Johnson of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine.

title: MEXICO'S 'FREE MARKET' PESO
description: Mexico's decision to begin a gradual devaluation of the ''free market'' peso is being praised by bankers, business executives and economists here for being uncommonly realistic.

title: DETROIT OFFICIALS DEFEND THE POLICE
description: In lashing out at a Michigan Congressman over a police brutality hearing, Mayor Koch of New York displayed what Detroit community leaders and academics say is an outdated image of police-community relations here.

title: Debra Weaver Wed To Jonathan Gelberg
description: Debra Stafford Weaver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. Davis Weaver of Birmingham, Mich., was married yesterday to Jonathan David Gelberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Gelberg of Roslyn Heights, L.I. Justice Beatrice Shainswit of State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club.

title: To Spend Tax Incentives Wisely
description: To revive New York City's development a decade ago, the city created an elaborate procedure to excuse the realty taxes on some buildings where people would find new jobs. Some of these projects created many jobs, but it's impossible to prove that they would not have gone forward without tax concessions. Critics charging unnecessary giveaways have had a field day against this system and the Industrial and Commercial Incentive Board that made the project-by-project decisions.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: TV: '60 MINUTES' AND NEWS ANCHORS
description: ''60MINUTES'' looked at network television anchors last night, examining, with some sense of urgency, Dan Rather's failure to jump ship and move to ABC, Tom Brokaw's ascendancy over Roger Mudd at NBC and whether or not anchors are paid too much money. Other issues arose, but ''60 Minutes''' gave them the back of its hand.

title: Los Angeles Teachers Reach Tentative Accord
description: Negotiators for the nation's second biggest school district and its teachers' union reached a tentative contract agreement early today, lifting a strike threat that had been hanging over the school system for weeks.

title: BLACK ALUMNI WEIGH YEARS' CHANGES AT SYRACUSE
description: Three years ago, Shelia Payton, Syracuse University class of 1970, returned to campus for her 10-year reunion expecting to talk with other black graduates who had ''gone through the struggle'' with her. But not one had come back.

title: REAGANS PAY BEDSIDE VISIT TO ILL CARDINAL
description: The President of the United States went calling on an old friend in New York yesterday.

title: Business Week Ad Stirs Memories at Newsweek
description: Business Week magazine, the flagship publication of McGraw-Hill Publications, has been making a big splash on the media advertising scene these days with a campaign that uses the theme line ''The Voice of Authority,'' created by Bozell & Jacobs.

title: Balcha of Ethiopia Takes Marathon
description: Kebede Balcha of Ethiopia broke out of the pack late in the race and and won his third Montreal International Marathon in a time of 2 hours 10 minutes 3 seconds today.

title: DAON'S BID TO RAISE NEW CASH
description: The financially troubled Daon Development Corporation, one of the high-flying Canadian realty groups that expanded aggressively into the United States in the mid-1970's, has surprised the property market in Canada with its plans to raise $165 million (Canadian) of new capital following a reorganization of its debt. A Canadian dollar is worth about 81 United States cents.

title: BRAVES CUT DODGER LEAD TO 3 1/2
description: Rafael Ramirez and Glenn Hubbard had two- run singles and Brett Butler a home run as the Atlanta Braves downed the Los Angeles Dodgers, 7-1, today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FOOLS OF FORTUNE. By William Trevor. 239 pages. Viking. $13.95.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 26, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: BRAZIL'S MORTADELLA MAN
description: In a wooden shack near a gold mine camp in the Amazon jungle, there was a man selling pungent sandwiches of mortadella ham, onion and cheese. As sweat stained his faded red University of Arizona T-shirt, he slapped together a couple for two visitors. He didn't want money, he said in Portuguese, he wanted an audience for his sermon: Brazil is becoming a great nation, he wanted us to know - it will be rich and powerful and free. It will be like the United States.

title: Illegal Alien Captures Put at Record for Year
description: The Border Patrol has caught more The Border Patrol has caught more than a million aliens trying to cross the United States-Mexico border illegally this year, the largest number on record, according to an Immigration and Naturalization Service official.service, said at a news conference last week that the total nationwide was 1.2 million for the fiscal year that ends Sept. 30.

title: Rangers' Allison in Fine Start
description: The Ranger players who have been Rangers in previous seasons agree: This has been the most competitive training camp they've attended.

title: Texas Officials Ride Roads in Murder Case
description: Law-enforcement officials rode horses over rural roads today, searching for evidence in the slayings of three male college students and two women kidnapped from a fast-food restaurant by thieves, shot in the head, and left lying side by side on a dirt road.

title: HOLMES SURVIVES BOOS, FIGHT
description: MAYBE the Jets were spurred by the fight that broke out at the dance yesterday, or maybe the bench-clearing brawl didn't make that much difference. But Jerry Holmes was definitely spurred by something that happened a few hours before the big fight.

title: Eddie Bauer's President Pushes Restructuring
description: The Ford Motor Company has just unveiled its newest four-wheel-drive truck, the Eddie Bauer Bronco II. It is one of the factors in the increased customer awareness that Eddie Bauer Inc. has received in recent days, and is an indication of the expansion that the president of Eddie Bauer, James J. Casey, seeks for the sporting goods retailer.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the Economic Scene column in Business Day Friday misstated the change in nonfarm business inventories.

title: LED THE BELGIANS
description: King Leopold III, who was forced to abdicate to his son Baudouin in 1951 for surrendering to invading Nazi forces during World War II, died today after a heart attack, the royal palace announced. He was 81 years old.

title: TOOLS ORDERS OFF BY 22% IN AUGUST
description: Machine tool orders, reflecting the usual lack of activity during the summer, fell 22 percent in August from July, the National Machine Tool Builder's Association said yesterday in its monthly report.

title: Questions About 007
description: More than three weeks after a South Korean airliner with 269 people aboard was shot down by the Soviet Union, important details about the incident remain clouded.

title: MAKE GOVERNMENT JUSTIFY DATA-GATHERING
description: To the Editor:

title: Piquet Captures Prix of Europe
description: Nelson Piquet of Brazil, in a Brabham-BMW, won the Grand Prix of Europe today, as the season's point leader, Alain Prost of France, finished second in a Renault turbo.

title: Michelle Mariash Marries
description: Michelle Eliot Mariash and Peter John Alusitz, graduates of the Rhode Island School of Design, were married at their Manhattan apartment yesterday by Judge Beverly Cohen of Civil Court. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Mariash of Pine Brook, N.J., and Mr. and Mrs. William Alusitz of Meriden, Conn. The bride is an apparel designer with Space Legs Inc. in New York, and Mr. Alusitz is an architect with the New York firm of Buckhurst Fish Hutton Katz.

title: Reopening at Louvre
description: The Louvre Museum has reopened its Roman sculpture rooms after 12 years of renovation, unveiling a priceless collection that past visitors had to peer at through the gloom of dimly lighted galleries. France's Culture Minister, Jack Lang, on hand for the opening of exhibits that have not been seen by the public since 1971, said the new presentation was the first phase of the renovation and transformation of the entire museum.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: TEAMSTER SAYS UNION PREFERS REAGAN TO MONDALE
description: The teamsters' union will support President Reagan in 1984 if he is running against Walter F. Mondale, the union's president, Jackie Presser, said in an interview today.

title: NEW YORK CITY BALLET OPENS PARIS DANCE FESTIVAL
description: ''Joy,'' exclaimed the new director of the Paris Opera Ballet, Rudolf Nureyev, when asked for his reaction to the New York City Ballet's performance in Paris last Wednesday. ''Sheer joy!''

title: Rescuer of BL Set For Computer Task
description: Sir Michael Edwardes, the diminutive 52-year-old former chairman of BL P.L.C. who will become chairman of International Computers Ltd., has made clear in his autobiography that the public's image of his work interests him as much as the work itself.

title: OPERA: A CHANGE FOR 'CENDRILLON'
description: MASSENET'S ''Cendrillon'' may not be one of the most familiar selections in operatic history, but the New York City Opera, in choosing it as the showcase to open its shortened season, has had good fortune. Many of the cast members have sung in the work previously, and the production itself was altered for the New York State Theater from a tested and tried staging that had already played in Washington, Ottowa and Paris.

title: U.S. URGING CURBS ON LOANS BY I.M.F. TO POOR COUNTRIES
description: The Reagan Administration, fighting an uphill battle to get Congress to approve financial support for the International Monetary Fund, found itself isolated in the international community Sunday in pressing for curbs on loans to poor countries.

title: Lendl Tops McEnroe
description: Ivan Lendl overcame early wildness, crushed John McEnroe in a second- set tiebreaker, then outdueled the top- seeded star in the third set tonight and posted a 3-6, 7-6, 6-4 victory in the final of the $265,000 Transamerica Open tennis tournament.

title: Browns 30, Chargers 24
description: Brian Sipe hit Harry Holt with a 48-yard touchdown pass 1:53 into overtime to give Cleveland the victory. Holt, the tight end, caught the pass at the San Diego 20-yard line and broke two tackles.

title: St. Francis Prep Triumphs by 25-6
description: St. Francis Prep, the favorite to put pressure on St. John the Baptist, the defending Metro Bowl and Catholic High Schools Football League champion, gained 476 yards yesterday en route to a 25-6 victory over Mount St. Michael in the Bronx. St. Francis, of Queens, scored on runs by Phil Matzat for 8 and 3 yards. Marlan Morris made the score 18-0 in the third quarter when he ran 73 yards with a pass from Joe Donodio.

title: Irish Detail Allegations In Russian Expulsions
description: Two Soviet diplomats and the wife of one of them had gotten in touch with the outlawed Irish Republican Army apparently in an attempt to trade arms for information before they were expelled from the Irish Republic, according to Irish security sources.

title: A MESSENGER FOR THE SAUDI KING
description: Bandar ibn Sultan ibn Abdel Aziz, the Saudi Arabian Prince who helped bring about today's cease-fire in Lebanon, is regarded here as the epitome of a new breed of Saudi diplomat - outgoing, sociable and articulate. The 34-year-old Prince, who has been named as the new Saudi Ambassador to the United States, is viewed as operating in a way that is the antithesis of an earlier style of Saudi diplomacy that emphasized caution and a desire to avoid public scrutiny while quietly negotiating behind the scenes.

title: FOR A FARMER IN ZIMBABWE, A FAREWELL TO ARMS
description: Timothy Gibbs, who spent the years of guerrilla war before Rhodesia became the independent nation of Zimbabwe farming and challenging the Government with his own vision of a multiracial state, has regretfully decided to leave Zimbabwe and the farm on which he was born 43 years ago.

title: YOUTHS RESTORE BUILDING AND REBUILD OWN PRIDE
description: First there was Victor Ortiz. Less than 16 years old at the time, a self-described hoodlum who was out of school and out of work, he wanted a clubhouse, so he found an abandoned building and claimed it as his own.

title: Flying Crisis Command Post Is Said to Have Indiana Base
description: The plane the President would use as a flying command post in the event of a nuclear attack will be moved to Indiana, according to Senator Dan Quayle, Republican of Indiana.

title: CALDWELL'S 66 EDGES TREVINO
description: Rex Caldwell shot an early six-under- par 66 and watched it stand up for a one-stroke victory over Lee Trevino in the LaJet Coors Classic today. It was Caldwell's first PGA Tour victory.

title: A G.O.P. Leader Pledges To Save Watt's Job
description: A leading Senate Republican, declaring that James G. Watt is a ''God-fearing man'' and not a bigot, promised today to block a Senate resolution calling for the resignation of the Secretary of the Interior. Another Republican Senator predicted that Mr. Watt would not last another week in the Cabinet.

title: Howe's Drug Use Reportedly Denied
description: Steve Howe's lawyer has reportedly denied that the suspended Los Angeles Dodger pitcher is currently using drugs, but he said he would advise Howe to sit out the rest of the season

title: BRIEFING
description: Lost: One Union

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: HOW THE U.N. BOWS TO PRESIDENTS AND PRECEDENCE
description: When President Reagan appears here Monday, he will be the first person to address the full 38th General Assembly, whose working sessions will begin that day.

title: Cardinals 14, Eagles 11
description: Jim Hart threw a 26-yard touchdown pass to Roy Green with 29 seconds left in the game to give St. Louis its first victory.

title: BRAZILIANS BLAMMING I.M.F. FOR PROBLEMS
description: For millions of Brazilians who a short time ago had never heard of the International Monetary Fund, the agency has today become a three-letter word.

title: Maine Hunters Bag 739 Moose
description: Hunters killed 739 moose in Maine's third modern-day moose season, the Fisheries and Wildlife Department reported today.

title: KOREAN JET: POINTS STILL TO BE SETTLED
description: President Reagan is to deliver a wide-ranging speech on world issues at the United Nations on Monday that is expected to include criticism of Soviet actions in the shooting down of a South Korean airliner on Sept. 1, in which 269 people were killed.

title: 5 Shot in Kenyan Voting
description: Five people were wounded today when a bodyguard of the Economic Planning and Development Minister, Zachary Onyonka, opened fire on supporters of a rival candidate in Kenya's general election, the Kenya press agency said. The incident took place in western Kenya and was the second involving one of Mr. Onyonka's bodyguards in two weeks, the agency said.

title: DANCE: ISRAEL'S BAT-DOR IN EARLY KYLIAN WORK
description: ''BLUE SKIN,'' which received its New York premiere with the Bat-Dor Dance Company of Israel on Saturday night at the Joyce Theater, is an early work by Jiri Kylian, director of the Netherlands Dance Theater.

title: U.S. Rowers Score in Regatta
description: The United States national rowing team scored its most promising victories in recent competition today.

title: AMERICAN WAY OF LIFE ALTERED BY FUEL CRISIS
description: Ten years ago energy for most Americans was an invisible wonder - something people did not see and did not pay much for. Beginning soon after the Arab oil embargo in 1973 and the successive price increases imposed by OPEC, however, the way Americans used energy became amply evident in fuel bills that got steeper by the month. As a result, millions of Americans began to reshape the way they worked and played.

title: DALLAS SIGN PANEL BANS 6 GIANT PERFORMING FROGS
description: A ribbeting question has arisen here: Are the frogs signs or are the frogs art?

title: Mayor of Washington Suffers Chest Pains
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. was reported in ''guarded condition'' today at Howard University Hospital after suffering chest pains.

title: TWO HURTFUL WAYS TO 'HELP'PUBLIC RADIO
description: To the Editor:

title: Letter: On Natural Gas; Consumers Hostage to Pipeline Prices
description: To the Editor:

title: WEINBERGER ARRIVES IN CHINA AND GETS A MIXED WELCOME
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger arrived in Peking today to a Chinese welcome that was at once cool and warm.

title: Dr. Maxwell E. Lapham, 83; Aided in 'Rabbit Test' Work
description: Dr. Maxwell E. Lapham, dean emeritus of the Tulane University School of Medicine who helped develop the ''rabbit test'' for pregnancy, has died at the age of 83.

title: MUSIC: GARTHWAITE, HAWKINS AND SORRELS WEAVBE FOLKLORE
description: TERRY GARTHWAITE, Bobbie Louise Hawkins and Rosalie Sorrels have been touring together on and off for several years, weaving music and storytelling into fascinating evenings of impromptu modern folklore.

title: THE LAST HOURS OF FLIGHT 007: RETRACING THE FATEFUL NIGHT OVER SAKHALIN
description: On the morning of Sept. 1 a Korean Air Lines jetliner with 269 people aboard, on a flight from New York to Seoul by way of Anchorage, flew over Soviet territory and was shot down by an SU-15 fighter.

title: PESTICIDE INACTION PROMPTS INQUIRY
description: Almost 10 years after the public was alerted to the dangers of ethylene dibromide as a potent carcinogen, a Congressional subcommittee will inquire Monday into the reasons for Federal inaction on banning or restricting the substance, a widely used pesticide and gasoline additive.

title: Market Place; Overcoming Investor Inertia
description: A SLIGHT easing of credit conditions by the Federal Reserve Board and a rally in the bond market - that's all it took to overcome investor inertia and send the Dow Jones industrial average racing ahead last week to new closing highs.

title: WINE FOR THE BABY AND OTHER ADVICE
description: A new compendium of advice about parenthood offers some startling recommendations:

title: Celebrating Succoth
description: The Educational Alliance, a Lower East Side community center, celebrated Succoth in the traditional way: It built a leafy roofed succah, on top of the Loeb Student Center at New York University at Washington Square.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: URBANSCAPES

title: 3 Great Geldings United
description: The three great geldings of modern thoroughbred racing will be united at Belmont Park Oct. 15, when Forego and Kelso are paraded and John Henry runs in the Jockey Club Gold Cup.

title: KOHL PARTY SUFFERS SETBACK IN STATE VOTE
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Party suffered a sharp reverse today in a closely watched election in the industrial state of Hesse, where the national opposition party, the Social Democrats, emerged as the largest single group but fell short of a governing majority.

title: PHILADELPHIA'S MAYOR AND COUNCIL CLASH OVER CABLE TELEVISION
description: The normally equable City Council president, Joseph E. Coleman, was seething. The often volatile Mayor, William J. Green, seemed adamant and unperturbed.

title: Miss Colwin, a Writer, Wed to Peter Jurjevics
description: Laurie Colwin, daughter of Mrs. Milton H. Snellenburg of Philadelphia and the late Peter Barnett Colwin, was married yesterday to Peter Jurjevics, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arved Jurjevics of Lake Clear, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by Justice Edwin Torres of State Supreme Court in the home of Charles and Robwynne Ruas in Manhattan.

title: BELEAGUERED GIANTS REMAIN OPTIMISTIC
description: THE Giants have every reason to be frustrated in this young pro football season.

title: The War for Cuba's Ear
description: If the White House will now let well enough alone, it can claim a victory in the vexed matter of Radio Marti. That is the name of the station President Reagan dearly wants to wage propaganda war against Fidel Castro.

title: NATIONAL LAMPOON HOPEFUL ON MOVIES
description: Is The National Lampoon still funny?

title: A NEW ERA FOR HISTORIC ST. MARK'S IN BOWERY
description: Carting away the rubble from the fire took a year. There was so much of it: bits of charred shingles and brick, embers from the balcony, shards of the nine century-old stained-glass windows that firefighters had shattered to get at the flames.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Arizona Public Service Co. has elected Paul A. Williams 2d vice president and treasurer.

title: TREASURY BORROWING NOW LIGHT
description: The credit markets can look forward to a month of light Treasury borrowing. This may help reduce interest rates, some analysts say.

title: PHILS EDGE CARDS, LEAD BY 4
description: The Philadelphia Phillies won their 10th straight game today and took a commanding lead in the National League's East when they defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 6-5, in 10 innings.

title: BLACK LEADERS GATHER FOR GLITTERING PARTY
description: It was, said the host, as he stood in the Corcoran Ballroom of the Four Seasons Hotel Friday night in his embroidered blue robe and fez-type hat, a purely social occasion. But when the occasion is the same week as the annual workshops and dinner sponsored by the Congressional Black Caucus and its foundation, and the guests, from Africa, Europe and every part of the United States, are top political, professional and businessmen and women, the definition of social gets stretched quite a lot.

title: Urban Cowboys
description: It's ride-'em-cowboy time at Madison Square Garden once again. When the World's Toughest Rodeo comes to town this Friday for a three-day stand, don't think it will be a novelty exhibition designed to indulge Eastern visions of the Wild West.

title: South African Catholics Oppose New Charter
description: South Africa's Roman Catholic Church today denounced the Government's campaign for a new constitution, saying the proposal failed with regard to justice, truth, love and freedom.

title: CITY OPERA: FIRST 'CARMEN' OF SEASON GETS PHYSICAL
description: IT was in the fight scenes that the City Opera production of ''Carmen'' came to life in the first presentation of the season Sunday afternoon. When Harry Theyard as Don Jose threw Carmen to the ground or when he and Escamillo took out their knives or when he and Zuniga battled it out, the action suddenly became more urgent, the singing more impassioned.

title: Harold M. Koch Wed to Gail Kleinberg
description: Gail Z. Kleinberg, a sales manager with Satellite Business Systems, a communications company in New York, was married yesterday to Harold M. Koch, president of International Carpet Importers of New York. Justice Leonard H. Sandler of the Appellate Division, First Department, of the New York State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at Gracie Mansion, the residence of the bridegroom's brother, Mayor Koch.

title: ALASKA NATIVES PONDER KEEPING ACCESS TO LAND
description: Eskimo, Indian and Aleut leaders are searching for a way to keep corporate raiders from taking aim on the 44 million acres of land owned by Alaska regional native corporations and villages.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Consolidated Natural Gas Co., Pittsburgh, said it has been awarded drilling rights to five tracts in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: 49ERS DEFEAT FALCONS
description: The San Francisco 49ers won only three of the nine games they played in 1982, the season in they were the defending Super Bowl champions, largely because of a poor running game and a poor pass rush.

title: PAUL JACOBS, HARPSICHORDIST AND PIANIST OF PHILHARMONIC
description: Paul Jacobs, the pianist and harpsichordist of the New York Philharmonic and an internationally respected authority on contemporary music, died in his New York home yesterday morning after a long illness. He was 53 years old.

title: Francene Turken Is Married to Jeremy Weingast
description: Francene Turken, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Turken of Phoenix, was married yesterday to Jeremy Weingast, son of Dr. and Mrs. David Weingast of Ridgefield, Conn. and Seaview, L.I. Rabbi Robert Orkand performed the ceremony at the Tower Suite in the Time & Life Building in Manhattan.

title: J.D.L. Says It Patrols The Yeshiva U. Area
description: The Jewish Defense League said yesterday that it had sent armed patrols and decoy units into the area around Yeshiva University in upper Manhattan to hunt for a sniper believed responsible for several shooting attacks in the area since June, which the university has described as anti-Semitic.

title: Commodities; Puzzles In Gold And Silver
description: PRICE movements for gold and silver are puzzling commodity analysts, who ponder two oddities: gold prices seem impervious to world crises, and silver prices remain low despite a healthy increase in industrial production and, presumably, demand.

title: Vikings 20, Lions 17
description: Benny Ricardo kicked his second field goal of the game midway through the final period as Minnesota, which had eight sacks, improved its record to 3-1.

title: Muppet Crew Celebrates A Film and a Birthday
description: The Muppets finished shooting their first made-in-Manhattan movie Saturday, also the 47th birthday of Jim Henson, a.k.a. Kermit, Ernie and a Muppet founder. To celebrate both events, the cast and crew of ''The Muppets Take Manhattan'' gathered that evening at Panache, a West 43d Street disco.

title: BRONX LIBERAL LEADER TO SUPPORT 2 JUDGES REJECTED BY DEMOCRATS
description: The leader of the Liberal Party in the Bronx said yesterday that he would support the renomination of two Bronx Democratic justices of the State Supreme Court who were rejected by their own party last week.

title: THE VERDICT IS CLEAR ON DIOXIN AND TRAHS INCINERATION
description: To the Editor:

title: GUIDE TO COMMITTEES
description: Finance ministers and central bank governors from nearly 150 countries have gathered here for the 38th annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, or World Bank. Since their establishment in 1945, a number of other bodies have been set up to coordinate economic policy. Here are some of these others and what they do:

title: X Marks Success
description: Since the early days of baseball, managers and scouts have been trying to discover some unmistakable physical traits or mannerisms that might serve as telltale signs of future stardom and give them an edge in separating the merely promising prospects from those destined for greatness.

title: JETS WIN IN OVERTIME, MCNEIL HURT
description: The Jets lost Freeman McNeil for 6 to 8 weeks. Three players suffered concussions. Mark Gastineau was punched for show-boating. And yet, when the four-hour game ended after dusk at Shea Stadium last night, the Jets were leaping and laughing.

title: SOVIET DENOUNCES REAGAN'S ADDRESS
description: The Soviet press agency Tass today denounced President Reagan's Voice of America broadcast as a ''fresh demagogic speech'' and a ''propaganda performance'' designed to camouflage the militaristic course of his Administration.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Sports World Specials in the Sept. 18 issue of SportsMonday incorrectly identified the last Heisman Trophy winner who did not pursue a career in professional football. He was Pete Dawkins of Army, the 1958 winner.

title: Iraq Reports Air Raid Against the Iranians
description: Iraqi war planes attacked Iranian troops on Saturday in a new outbreak of fighting between the two neighbors, the state-run Iraqi press agency reported.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: * Rate depicted in Long- or Short-Term Rates chart.

title: Number of Agencies Receive New Accounts
description: Last week ended with a number of agencies announcing new accounts. The biggest piece of business was going to Ally & Gargano, which estimated that the billings on its assignment from Union Carbide should reach $3 million.

title: COLIARD ORCHESTRA DEBUT
description: A NEW ensemble, the Goliard Chamber Orchestra, had its first New York outing at Abraham Goodman House on Saturday night. The group ranged from 10 string players, in Bach's ''Wohl euch, ihr auserw"alten Seelen'' from Cantata No. 34, to 16, in Britten's wonderful Serenade for Tenor, Horn and Strings.

title: Campaigns By L'eggs And Atari
description: THE three-hour Emmy awards show on the NBC-TV network last night also served to introduce new ad campaigns for both Atari home computers and L'eggs Sheer Energy pantyhose, and each was a radical departure from past efforts.

title: 'Measure' Starts Season Of American Repertory
description: The American Repertory Theater will open its fifth season as the ensemble in residence at Harvard's Loeb Drama Center with a production of Shakespeare's ''Measure for Measure,'' beginning on Nov. 25.

title: YASTRZEMSKI SEEKS THE PERFECT SWING IN HIS FINAL INNINGS
description: THE message taped to the back of his locker told as much as anything else about the ballplayer's dedication.

title: SANDINISTAS MAKE CEREMONY OF FREEING EX-REBELS
description: Ten local youths who said they had defected from anti-Sandinista brigades were officially set free today in a public ceremony here.

title: SMITHSONIAN POST DRAWS 235 HOPEFULS
description: ''It is not a high-turnover job,'' John Jameson, a Smithsonian Institution official, said the other day, of offering one of the reasons 235 people have applied to become the next secretary of the institution.

title: U.S. EXPERT ON SOVIET TRADE QUITS
description: The State Department's top official responsible for trade with Communist countries resigned today to protest recent moves within the Reagan Administration to take a tougher stance on the sale of high technology to the Soviet Union.

title: PROTEST OFF FOR FINAL CUP RACE
description: Once again, after a postponement because of insufficient wind, Liberty, the United States defender, and Australia II, the challenger, will attempt to sail the seventh and decisive race in the 25th America's Cup series Monday.

title: People
description: * Sherman Agins, Stan Schumsky and Nat Waterston have been elected senior vice presidents at Doyle Dane Bernbach Inc.

title: Australia Freeze to End
description: A nationwide wage freeze will end with a 4.3 percent pay increase for Australian workers on Oct. 6, the National Arbitration Commission has ruled.

title: Pakistan Accuses India Of Hostile Propaganda
description: Pakistan has accused India, through Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, of running a propaganda campaign against Pakistan and misusing its position as head of the group of nations espousing nonalignment.

title: Mondale Says Reagan Policy Fortifies the Latin Right Wing
description: President Reagan's Central American policy strengthens ''the forces of right- wing extremism,'' former Vice President Walter F. Mondale said today.

title: Bridge: Americans Off to Fine Start In the World Championship
description: The American team officially described as U.S.A. II made a superb start in the world championship, which began here Sunday.

title: 38 ARMED IRISH TERRORISTS ESCAPE FROM TOP-SECURITY BELFAST PRISON
description: Thirty-eight Irish nationalists broke out of the maximum security Maze prison today after a gun battle and hand-to-hand fighting in which one guard was stabbed to death and five others were injured.

title: SUPPORT IS URGED FOR AMENDMENT TO HELP RUNDOWN AREAS IN STATE
description: Supporters of a proposed amendment to the State Constitution that would help local governments spur development in blighted areas have opened a campaign to win support for its passage by voters in November.

title: Ellen E. Fuhrer and Frank Beatrice Are Married
description: Ellen Elizabeth Fuhrer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Fuhrer of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Frank Beatrice, son of Mrs. Salvatore Beatrice of Maywood, N.J., and the late Mr. Beatrice. Rabbi Helene Ferris performed the ceremony at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue in Manhattan, assisted by Rabbi Eric H. Hoffman.

title: No Headline
description: Steve Grogan connected with the rookie Stephen Starring on a 76-yard touchdown pass with 3 minutes 59 seconds remaining as the New England Patriots rallied to upset the Pittsburgh Steelers, 28-23, today.

title: LEARY IS ROUTED BY CUBS
description: In 1979, Tim Leary was the Mets' top draft choice, the second player chosen in the semi-annual free-agent draft. After his selection as the most valuable player in the Class AA Texas League while with Jackson in 1980, Leary, the 6-foot-3-inch right-hander out of U.C.L.A. not only made the Mets' 1981 roster, but was touted as the Mets' best pitching prospect since Tom Seaver arrived at Shea Stadium for the 1967 season.

title: Accounts
description: * Jordan Marsh has reappointed Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos Inc. for broadcast advertising.

title: Now in Big Stores, Levi Seeks Return Of Smaller Outlets
description: Levi Strauss Inc., the nation's largest manufacturer of jeans and other casual wear, has a continuing and sticky problem with its retailers.

title: CONCERT: ARZRUNI AT MUSEUM
description: IT was a case of man versus machine Friday night at the Metropolitan Museum, where Sahan Arzruni played music by Beethoven and Schubert on a 160- year-old Viennese pianoforte. The pianoforte, a precursor of today's concert grand, has a distinctive tone; paradoxically, it sounds like nothing so much as an out-of-tune piano played in tune.

title: 2 Israelis and 3 Arabs Hurt In West Bank Grenade Blast
description: Two Israeli soldiers and three Arabs were wounded this morning in the city of Nablus in the occupied West Bank when a grenade was thrown outside the Mayor's office, an Israeli Army spokesman said today.

title: TWO HURTFUL WAYS TO 'HELP' PUBLIC RADIO
description: To the Editor:

title: ORIOLES CLINCH EASTERN TITLE
description: Jim Dwyer and Joe Nolan hit home runs, and Storm Davis and Tippy Martinez combined on a six-hitter today as the Baltimore Orioles clinched the American League Eastern Division title with a 5-1 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: NBC BEATS ABC AND CBS COMBINED IN EMMYS
description: NBC, the network that for years has trailed in the ratings, won more awards last night at the 35th Annual Emmy Award show than the other two networks combined. It was the third year that NBC has dominated the awards.

title: Rudd Triumphs In 500 Car Race
description: Ricky Rudd took the lead for good on the 171st lap and outraced Bobby Allison the rest of the way to win the Goody's 500 Grand National stock-car race at Martinsville Speedway today.

title: BRIEFS
description: Common Stock

title: Founder Quits Post At Venture Magazine
description: After quite a few ups and downs, Joseph D. Giarraputo, founder and publisher of Venture, the Magazine for Entrepreneurs, is leaving to become executive vice president and chief operating officer of Viare Publishing, New York publisher of Video Review and Videopro, Home Computer Review and Electronic Fun With Computers and Games.

title: CENTRAL AMERICAN NATIONS REFUSE TO JOIN U.S. BOYCOTT OF NICARAGUA
description: Four Central American nations, despite their hostility toward Nicaragua, have refused to join the Reagan Administration's informal economic boycott of the Sandinista Government, officials in the region say.

title: DECISION NEAR ON NEW CHIEF OF THE M.T.A.
description: Lewis Rudin called from his hospital bed.

title: Taiwan Mission in U.S.
description: A Taiwanese trade mission is in the United States to buy $600 million worth of United States products to narrow the trade gap between the two countries, a Board of Foreign Trade spokesman said Friday. The 40-member mission will also hold talks with United States officials on measures to reduce the trade imbalance, the spokesman said. Taiwan had a surplus of $4.2 billion in its trade with the United States last year and officials said the figure was likely to reach $6 billion this year.

title: HEARTLIGHT NO. ONE WINNER IN RUFFIAN
description: To the strains of pop music, a 3-year-old filly named Heartlight No. One all but wrapped up a championship when she scored an impressive victory over a strong field in the $171,900 Ruffian Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: Chips Are Down
description: Cap days are old hat, and so for that matter are bat days, ball days, T-shirt days and wristband days. But just as you were afraid that baseball was running out of promotional equipment, somebody sneaked a computer into the clubhouse and out popped Microchip Day.

title: The Financier vs. the Scholar
description: Treasury Secretary Regan is busy playing the Administration optimist these days, crowing about recovery and brushing aside calls for a future tax increase. Martin Feldstein, the President's economic adviser, looks at the same glass and claims it's half-empty. He says the prospect of huge deficits in 1984 and beyond is reducing exports, holding up interest rates and slowing capital formation. What's needed, Mr. Feldstein argues, is a big tax increase effective in October 1985.

title: Kalichstein at Carnegie Hall
description: An all-Schubert program will mark the Carnegie Hall recital of the pianist Joseph Kalichstein on Nov. 30 at 8 P.M. Mr. Kalichstein is part of a trio that also includes Jaime Laredo and Sharon Robinson. Tickets, which range from $8 to $15, will be available at the box office on Oct. 24.

title: COWBOYS WIN ON LATE SAFETY
description: The linebacker Anthony Dickerson trapped the New Orleans Saints' quarterback Ken Stabler in the end zone for a safety with 1 minute 58 seconds to play today, turning what appeared to be a Saints' victory into a 21-20 victory for the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Colts 22, Bears 19
description: Raul Allegre, a rookie who missed a 45-yard field goal with 3 seconds left in regulation time, kicked a 33-yarder after 4:51 of overtime. Allegre had field goals of 37 and 47 yards in the fourth period.

title: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 26, 1983
description: International

title: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 26, 1983
description: Companies

title: REAGAN SAYS U.S. BACKS U.N.
description: President Reagan last night told foreign leaders and foreign ministers attending the United Nations General Assembly that the United States was ''proud to be the home'' of the United Nations and would ''continue to work constructively'' there for world peace.

title: OUTDOORS: HARROWING SPILL FOLLOWS A BAD MOVE
description: HAVING purchased a lovely, new, 18 1/2-foot Kevlar- Airex canoe from Mad River, I then proceeded to tip it over on a remote New Hampshire brook trout pond with Vic Pomiecko, my fly fishing companion of nearly 30 years, aboard.

title: Ali: Champ Of Champs
description: THEY were wearing tuxedos instead of trunks. Nearly two dozen boxing champions of the last two decades had gathered for the World Boxing Council's 20th anniversary dinner at the United Nations building. When the television cameras arrived, they focused on Muhammad Ali as if he were still the heavyweight champion. So did most of the people who wanted an autograph or a handshake. Muhammad Ali was still ''the champ'' to them, as well as to the other champions.

title: Postal Service Keeps Y. & R.
description: Young & Rubicam, the agency for the United States Postal Service since 1974, on Friday won the account again for the year beginning next Saturday. The authorized budget is $24 million, which will cover every aspect of advertising and promotion.

title: 'DANGER' TO THE SOVIET
description: The ostensible aim of the new round of Soviet- American arms control negotiations taking place in Geneva this fall is mutual and balanced reductions in the superpowers' nuclear arsenals. It seems highly doubtful that this aim will be achieved. The reason is simple. Soviet leaders, in all likelihood, cannot agree to such reductions - now or at any time in the future. Paradoxical though it sounds, balanced nuclear disarmament would seem to them to endanger their state.

title: JUSTICE AND SECURITY
description: Robert Mugabe, Prime Minister of Zimbabwe, has been on an extended visit to the United States. As a regional leader important to this country, a key figure in black Africa, he drew respectful attention in Washington. But there was a notable aspect of this visit beyond the official exchanges.

title: EXPAND THE SCOPE OF PUBLIC DAY CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Watch; 'Expansion' In, Recovery' Out
description: A JOYFUL new word burst from the Government's cheerleaders last week and another slipped off. ''Since the beginning of the year,'' said President Reagan, ''the expansion of the economy has been robust.'' Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said, ''We want solid and steady expansion .'' The abandoned word? Recovery .

title: TV: SHOW ON E.L. DOCTOROW TOUCHES ON 'AMERICAN MYTH'
description: The program, produced for public television by WGBH in Boston and Nancy Porter Productions, includes film footage from the movies made from two of Mr. Doctorow's books, ''Welcome to Hard Times'' and ''Ragtime.'' Mr. Doctorow says he was distressed by the first movie, a western, because ''the people in my book were poor people, pock marked and dirty,'' but the people in the movie ''were very beautiful and wore color-coordinated costumes.'' ''Ragtime,'' however, seemed to please him.

title: ON JOINING A FAMILY BUSINESS
description: WHEN he was 8 years old, David Rosenzweig used to fold boxes at the family apparel store for 5 cents a box. Now, at 34, he is the heir apparent to the business.

title: RAIDERS TROUNCE BRONCOS BY 22-7
description: Jim Plunkett threw two touchdown passes to Cliff Branch and the National Football League's leading defense held the Denver Broncos scoreless until the closing minutes as the Los Angeles Raiders raised their record to 4-0 with a 22-7 victory today.

title: MODALE'S MACHINE, A TEXTBOOK CASE
description: It is mid-morning in James A. Johnson's sunny corner office, and he is receiving a report from an outpost of the nation's most elaborate Presidential campaign organization.

title: Bengals 23 Buccaneers 17
description: Ken Riley scored on a 34-yard interception return, and Robert Jackson stopped a late Tampa Bay threat with an interception in the end zone as Cincinnati won its first game of the season.

title: DELAY IN PROPOSAL TO BAN CHEMICAL LAID TO EX-E.P.A. OFFICIAL
description: A former top Environmental Protection Agency official, after meeting with White House and citrus industry officials, stalled for a year or more plans to ban the pesticide ethylene dibromide, agency officials said today.

title: News Analysis
description: A private study released last week charged that, in effect, New York City officials had misplaced priorities. At a time when the city should have directed funds to programs for poor children to compensate for Federal budget cuts, the report said, it decided instead to increase allocations to such agencies as the Department of Cultural Affairs. The report highlighted again the longstanding debate over how the city's complex pattern of resources and services should be distributed fairly to its diverse constituents.

title: Marny Goodman and Harold L. Glasser Are Wed
description: Marny S. Goodman, daughter of Mildred Sharfstein of Yonkers and the late Morris Sharfstein, was married yesterday to Harold L. Glasser, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Herman Glasser of New York. New York State Supreme Court Justice Alfred Ascione performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home in Manhattan.

title: TO BLUNT WARSAW PACT'S CONVENTIONAL EDGE
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the planned release dates for major economic indicators to be reported this week. Monday

title: COALITION TALKS BACKED IN ISRAEL
description: The opposition Labor Party authorized its leader, Shimon Peres, today to explore the possibility of sharing power with the Likud bloc in a Government of national unity under Prime Minister-designate Yitzhak Shamir.

title: DOMINGO, LIKE OTHER GREAT SINGERS, BECOMES WARY ABOUT HIS VOICE
description: THERE was commotion at the Metropolitan Opera a few weeks ago while Placido Domingo was having second thoughts about appearing in tonight's ''Troyens,'' which opens the Met season. It is not that Mr. Domingo is having vocal problems. He never seems to have vocal problems. It was about 15 years ago that this writer predicted a short career for the gifted Spanish tenor. He was singing too much, in roles too demanding for his voice, and the intelligent conclusion was that he would be sung out in a few years. Mr. Domingo triumphantly proved that conclusion wrong. He went on to where he is today - the best tenor in action. And he will sing at tonight's opening.

title: MRS. THATCHER SAYS SOVIET HAS BAD FAITH ON ARMS
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher accused the Soviet Union today of bad faith bargaining in the Geneva negotiations to limit medium-range nuclear weapons.

title: MONTEFUSCO IS WINNER AGAIN
description: John Montefusco, the effective right-handed starter the Yankees had lacked, continued to glow yesterday amid the rubble that is the Yankees' season.

title: Major Rebel Group Reports Attack on Nicaraguan Town
description: The major group fighting the Nicaraguan Government said today that 2,000 of their soldiers were attacking the town of Ocotal and nearby villages in northern Nicaragua.

title: Changes at Ogilvy
description: Henry P. Bernhard, 55-year-old vice chairman of Ogilvy & Mather, who has been running the Chicago office, is returning to the New York office after seven successful years out there. He is turning management of the office, which has annual billings of about $102 million, over to the three-man team headed by William E. Whitney, 50, already managing director; Curvin O'Reilly, 41, already executive director, and Wim Slootweg, 39, a Hollander and Procter & Gamble alumnus, who has worked for Ogilvy in a number of countries. He will now be senior vice president and general manager.

title: John Brennan Weds Marian M. Schuman
description: Marian Maura Schuman, a lawyer, and John Clark Brennan, deputy commissioner and general counsel of the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission, were married yesterday. Algernon D. Black, Leader Emeritus of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, performed the ceremony at the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan.

title: 3 U.S. MARINES HURT IN BEIRUT FIGHTING
description: Three American marines were wounded as fighting raged here today both before and after the announcement of a cease-fire.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about Dave Winfield's charitable foundation in Sports Pages Thursday incorrectly described his agent, Al Frohman. Mr. Frohman is no longer an officer of the foundation.

title: Title to Jones Duo
description: Kiley Jones and Richard Illingworth of the the New York Croquet Club won the United States Croquet Association doubles title yesterday by beating Archie Peck and Dana Dribbin of the Palm Beach (Fla.)

title: ARMY GEN. HAROLD K. JOHNSON, CHIEF OF STAFF FROM 1964 TO '68
description: Gen. Harold K. Johnson, Army Chief of Staff from 1964 until his retirement from active duty in July 1968, died of cancer Saturday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. He was 71 years old and a longtime resident of Fort Myers, Va.

title: MAKING BETTER USE OF BOXCARS
description: Jack P. Bolyard, the terminal superintendant of the Pavonia rail yard here for Conrail, gestured toward a freight train that was being formed. ''See those freight cars,'' he said. ''They're going back empty.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''An agreement has been reached for a cease-fire in Lebanon, ending the war and starting a national dialogue.

title: MARCOS SAYS ARMY WILL GET TOUGH ON PROTESTERS
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos warned businessmen as well as radicals and ''vandals'' today that armed troops would use force to break up anti-Government rallies that fail to get permits and resist demands that they disperse.

title: CUBA DENOUNCED OVER PRISONERS
description: A human rights group charged today that at least 250 long-term political prisoners are confined to Cuban jails under ''brutal conditions'' while up to 2,000 former prisoners ''languish as pariahs in Cuban society, denied decent work and respect, longing to leave.''

title: Addendum
description: Reader's Digest increasing its advertising rates 5 percent, effective with the January issue.

title: 'IN THE WHITE CITY,' ALAIN TANNER'S LATEST
description: ''IN THE WHITE CITY,'' the new film by the Swiss director Alain Tanner (''La Salamandre,'' ''Jonah Who Will Be 25 in the Year 2000,'' among others), is set in Lisbon, but the city of the title is less a particular place than a series of states of mind.

title: UNIVERSITY HELPS SAVE A FACTORY IN ALABAMA
description: Last fall, the betting among the 200 workers employed at the Rochester Products carburetor plant here was that they would be out of work before Christmas.

title: REALISM ON MISSILES
description: Senator John Glenn, who is not renowned for radical notions, put a daring idea to the Foreign Relations Committee last week. In future arms control talks with the Soviet Union, he said, the U.S. must begin to count the nuclear weapons of Britain and France as part of the West's arsenal.

title: Virginia and Kentucky Big Surprises
description: Of the undefeated and untied teams in major college football, Virginia must be the biggest surprise to most people, with Kentucky a close second. Both Southern teams are 4-0 after Saturday's games, in which Virginia beat North Carolina State, 26-14, and Kentucky defeated Tulane, 26-14.

title: All Over Town, Crowds Turn Out for Fairs
description: As summer segued into autumn this weekend, street fairs sprouted on many blocks. Under sunny skies, with temperatures in the 60's, hundreds of thousands of people munched and mingled yesterday on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn, on 52d Street from Broadway to Park Avenue in midtown Manhattan and on Columbus Avenue on the Upper West Side. At the Cloisters, jousters jousted at the Medieval Festival in Fort Tryon Park.

title: BLACK CAUCUS WEIGHS CANDIDACY BY JESSE JACKSON
description: The leap from a theoretical candidacy for President to a real candidacy is a great one, and last week, throughout the events of the Congressional Black Caucus's annual workshops and dinner, the Rev. Jesse Jackson looked like a man teetering on the edge.

title: CONTINENTAL AIR TO KEEP 4,200 ON JOB
description: Continental Air Lines said yesterday that it would resume operations on Tuesday with about 4,200 of the 12,000 workers it laid off Saturday when it filed for protection from its creditors. But those workers who are rehired will have agreed to take sharp cuts in their salaries and benefits, Continental said.

title: TV Weatherman Killed
description: A television weatherman, Jim O'Brien, 43 years old, died today when he plunged to the ground in a sky dive at a small airport, officials said. The death of Mr. O'Brien, who appeared on WPVI, Channel 6, in Philadelphia, was confirmed by the station's news director, Bob Feldman.

title: Joanne Lescher Is Married
description: Joanne Lescher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Lescher of Flushing, Queens, was married yesterday to Jacob A. Huelstrunk, son of Florence Huelstrunk of Ridgewood, Queens, and the late Jacob J. Huelstrunk. The Rev. Stewart Brown performed the ceremony at St. Pancras Roman Catholic Church in Glendale, Queens.

title: Mrs. Lloyd to Play At Least 2 Years
description: Chris Evert Lloyd said today that she would play tennis at least two more years, then decide whether to retire.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: On fourth down, with the ball on its 1-yard line, a National Football League team punts the ball from its end zone. The ball goes straight up. A defensive receiver signals for a fair catch, runs up and catches the ball in the end zone. What is the ruling? What happens if, as he is signaling for a fair catch, the receiver is knocked down and the ball bounces untouched back from the end zone into the playing field?

title: STRIKING LAY TEACHERS ACCEPT A MEDIATED PACT
description: Striking lay teachers at 11 Roman Catholic high schools run by the Archdiocese of New York voted yesterday to accept a contract package worked out by government mediators and were set to return to class this morning.

title: CEASE-FIRE ACCORD GAINED IN LEBANON WITH SAUDIS' HELP
description: The United States said yesterday that it regarded the announcement of a cease-fire in Lebanon as only ''a first step'' toward the more difficult goals of bringing about a strong central government in that country and the withdrawal of all Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces.

title: Mubarak Seeks to End 2 Emergency Measures
description: President Hosni Mubarak has announced that he is proposing to Parliament the repeal of two emergency laws.

title: INDIAN REMAINS SHED NEW LIGHT ON SYPHILIS
description: A skull from a Narragansett Indian cemetery at North Kingstown supports a theory that syphilis did not originate in the New World but was brought by Europeans to America, according to a physical anthropologist who has examined bones from the cemetery.

title: Dolphins 14, Chiefs 6
description: Miami's David Woodley threw a touchdown pass and Andra Franklin scored on a 1-yard run in a game that tied an N.F.L. record for turnovers. Kansas City failed to score a touchdown for the second straight game.

title: Bills 30, Oilers 13
description: Joe Cribbs rushed for 166 yards and 1 touchdown to lead Buffalo and overshadow an impressive performance by Houston's Earl Campbell, who gained 142 yards in 30 carries.

title: Dome Petroleum Restructuring
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. is continuing to prepare its own financial restructuring plan that will likely involve a large share issue, according to banking sources.

title: POP MUSIC: LINDA RONSTADT AND RIDDLE AT MUSIC HALL
description: THE question on everyone's mind Saturday, when Linda Ronstadt and the arranger- conductor Nelson Riddle appeared together at the Radio City Music Hall, was whether Miss Ronstadt, a singer more at home in front of a rock band than a 47-piece orchestra, could recreate the creamy aural perfection of ''What's New,'' the album she and Mr. Riddle made. The answer was a definite yes.

title: Redskins 27 Seahawks 17
description: Joe Theismann threw three touchdown passes, including bombs of 64 yards to Charlie Brown and 47 to Alvin Garrett in the second quarter, as Washington won its ninth straight road game.

title: TV: 'SESSIONS,' A DRAMA ABOUT PROSTITUTION
description: Perhaps because of the very nature of the medium, which will sell anything to gain a ratings point, prostitution is becoming an increasingly popular subject on television. Just last week, the premiere of ABC's ''Hotel'' featured Morgan Fairchild as an unfortunate sultry hooker caught in a preppie business venture that turns sour. Tonight on NBC, there is ''Sessions,'' a television movie that stars Veronica Hamel as a high-priced call girl who is having, with good reason, an identity crisis.

title: USE OF LASER IN ARTERY DESCRIBED
description: In what was called an important step toward laser heart surgery, doctors at Stanford Medical Center said today that they had snaked a laser beam tube into the leg artery of a man to burn away a blockage.

title: BLACK COLLEGES DAY MARKED BY ENACTMENT OF MORE U.S. AID
description: President Reagan marked National Historically Black Colleges Day today by signing a bill authorizing nearly $5 million more next year in Federal aid to black schools and other developing institutions.

title: STAGE HISTORY OF THE OPERA
description: Berlioz completed ''Les Troyens'' in 1858, but the five-act score proved more than the Paris Opera cared to produce. He tried to win a performance by dividing the work into two installments, to be played on different nights: ''La Prise de Troie'' and ''Les Troyens a Carthage.''

title: Role Is Denied In $7 Million Theft
description: The fiancee of a security guard accused of stealing $7 million in cash from a Wells Fargo depot here Sept. 12 pleaded not guilty today to charges of hindering the prosecution and making a false statement to the police.

title: SOVIET HANDS OVER DEBRIS FROM KOREAN PLANE
description: The Soviet Union handed over to United States and Japanese authorities today five wooden boxes containing debris from the South Korean plane shot down by a Soviet fighter on Sept. 1.

title: TECHNOLOGY MARKETING reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income includes a tax credit of $59,000.

title: GRANTS IN METROPOLITAN AREA
description: The following grants by the National Endowment for the Humanities were awarded today in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut: New York

title: ZIYAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
EX-E.P.A. OFFICIAL SAYS PRESSURE DIDN'T DELAY ACTION ON PESTICIDE
description: A former top official of the Environmental Protection Agency testified today that neither the White House nor industry influenced his decision to delay restrictions on a cancer-causing pesticide.

title: Traffic Fatalities Drop 11%; The Experts Don't Know Why
description: Americans recorded the biggest drop in traffic fatalities last year since the speed limit of 55 miles an hour was adopted in 1974, the National Safety Council reported today, but the experts said they did not know why.

title: Kenyans Vote For a New Parliament
description: Kenyans voted in general elections today to replace the Parliament dissolved by President Daniel arap Moi last June a year ahead of schedule to purge what he called disloyal elements.

title: STERCHI BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
REAGAN SAYS U.S. IS WILLINGTO CUT BACK ON WARHEADS IT WANTS TO BASE IN EUROPE
description: President Reagan, calling on the Soviet Union ''to reduce the tensions it has heaped on the world in the past few weeks,'' today offered what he described as concessions aimed at advancing the deadlocked Soviet-American talks on medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: MET OPENS 100TH SEASON WITH 'LES TROYENS'
description: With trumpets flourishing fanfares on a picture-perfect New York autumn evening, the Metropolitan Opera, America's largest, grandest performing-arts instituton, opened its centennial season last night.

title: Baseball Musings
description: Bill Veeck, the former owner of the Cleveland Indians, the St. Louis Browns and the Chicago White Sox, is enjoying life in Hyde Park, a Chicago suburb. But baseball is still on his mind.

title: FOUR STAR INTERNATIONAL INC L reports earnings for Year to June 25
description: Share earnings for the latest quarter are adjusted to give effect to a 3-for-2 stock split on July 25. Year-ago share earnings are adjusted to give retroactive effect to 3-for-2 stock splits on Feb. 25 and July 1.

title: MAYORAL DEBATE HELD IN PHILADELPHIA
description: Under the brilliant glare of television lights, two of Philadelphia's mayoral candidates opened sharp attacks on each other tonight but reserved their harshest criticism for the man they must beat, W. Wilson Goode.

title: OUSTED ONCE, ALIENS YIELD AGIAN TO LURE OF LAGOS
description: When he graduated from a Presbyterian secondary school in Accra two years ago, Michael Addo, then 24 years old, hoped to go into business. But given the sickly state of the Ghanaian economy, even the best job he was offered would have paid him in a month only enough to buy food for about a week.

title: Market Place; The Potential At Godfather's
description: THE pizza portion of the fast-food business for a long time seemed to have done best in the hands of the moms and pops - neighborhood stores with an oven, a counter and a chef in the window tossing the dough.

title: DYNATREND INC .  reports earnings for Year to June 26
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * A.T.& T. Communications, the organization that will provide long-distance and international services after the Bell System divestiture, has appointed Charles R. Jones vice president of external affairs.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday incorrectly identified an advertising copy writer who occasionally contributes to The National Lampoon.

title: SANTA FE MERGER EXPECTED
description: Santa Fe Industries and the Southern Pacific Company, owners of two of the largest railroads serving the Western half of the nation, asked that trading in their stock be halted yesterday, amid widespread expectation that they would announce a newly negotiated merger.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: News Analysis
description: The quiet decision earlier this month not to appeal an immigration judge's ruling that granted asylum to Dennis Brutus put a surprisingly muted ending to a long and heated battle over Mr. Brutus, a South African poet and political activist. But while Mr. Brutus's immigration status is resolved, the significance of his case remains uncertain, in part because its original impetus has never been clear.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Baseball
description: Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox , at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Carl Yastrzemski, retiring at the end of the season, makes his last appearances at the Stadium as the Yankees close out their home schedule with three games against Boston.

title: Chevron Contracts
description: The Standard Oil Company of California subsidiary Chevron U.S.A. Inc. said it had awarded initial construction and installation contracts for its new oil-producing platform, Hermosa, off the California coast to Japanese and Swiss companies. The contracts, which amount to about 5 percent of the $1 billion total cost of the project, went to the Hitachi Zosen Corporation of Japan and Heerema Marine Contractors of Switzerland. Chevron said bids from United States companies were between 35 and 83 percent higher than the winning bids.

title: Mrs. Bhutto Asks Army To Overthrow Zia
description: The widow of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto called on Pakistan's army today to oust President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, free all political prisoners and set a date for free elections.

title: GIANTS TRIUMPH ON PACKER ERRORS
description: The Giants expected all kinds of problems from the Green Bay Packers tonight because the Packers had such a strong passing game and the Giants' defense was undergoing major changes.

title: Charlotte Curtis Politics, Women and Money
description: THE invitation on Democratic National Committee stationery was for a women's luncheon with Isabelle Leeds and Marife Hernandez as the hosts, and it mentioned ''access to the decision- making process'' and hinted at ''benefits'' accruing to those who contributed between $1,000 and $10,000. Fourteen women, including Faith Stewart-Gordon of the Russian Tea Room, Betty Friedan and Mrs. Joseph E. Levine, the movie mogul's wife, were sufficiently intrigued, and they showed up at the ''21'' Club to see what was going on.

title: A.T.& T. Service Unit Names 2 Top Officials
description: A.T.& T. Information Systems, the company that will provide business customers of the soon-to-be broken-up American Telephone and Telegraph Company with a broad range of installation, maintenance and sales services, has appointed two top officers to help in its transition.

title: Japanese Weighing Car Limit Renewal
description: The three-year program restricting the flow of Japanese automobiles into the United States still has six months more to run, but the campaign to extend it in some form for another year is already well under way.

title: Shorter Aiming For '84 Olympics
description: Frank Shorter, the former Yale track and cross-country star who won a gold medal in the marathon at the Olympic Games in 1972 at Munich, yesterday said he was aiming to take another crack next year in Los Angeles. He finished second in 1976 in Montreal.

title: NICARAGUAN REBELS FAIL IN EFFORT TO SEIZE LARGE TOWN IN THE NORTH
description: The largest group of guerrillas fighting the Nicaraguan Government said today that it had failed in an attempt to seize a large town in northern Nicaragua, but that it had taken three outlying areas.

title: Frustrated Coach
description: Mike Ditka had his right hand in a cast, the result of an unyielding steel cabinet, but the Chicago Bears' coach maintained, ''I really wasn't mad when I did it.'' That left people to wonder what would have happened if he had been angry.

title: VIETNAM'S 'BOAT PEOPLE'
description: THE subject of Ann Hui's ''Boat People'' would not seem to lend itself to ordinary movie-making tactics, since the film depicts the horrendous living conditions to be found in the northern part of Vietnam in 1978, three years after the war ended.
