However, Miss Hui brings a conventional - and for the most part highly effective - storytelling talent to bear upon this material. She's able to create both sensationalism and drama, even if her film never generates an air of realism, or frees itself from coincidence and cliche.

title: No Headline
description: METZGER'S DOG. By Thomas Perry. 314 pages. Scribner's. $14.95. THE ADDRESS BOOK. By Anne Bernays. 255 pages. Little, Brown. $14.95.

title: Yale Literary Magazine Wins 'Values Award'
description: The Yale Literary Magazine, the quarterly established in 1821, was named the first winner of the American Values Award for Distinguished Journalism, given by the U.S.I.C. Educational Foundation of Nashville.

title: Chairman Reappointed By British National Oil
description: Lord Croham, 65, has been reappointed to a two-year term as part- time nonexecutive chairman of the state-owned British National Oil Corporation, beginning Nov. 1. He was first appointed to the post in 1982 and had previously been part-time deputy chairman since 1978, two years after the formation of the organization on Jan. 1, 1976.

title: S. Carolina Deal For Fleet Financial
description: The Fleet Financial Group announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to purchase the Bankers Mortgage Corporation, the mortgage- banking operation of Bankers Trust of South Carolina, and its $3.8 billion mortgage-servicing portfolio.

title: SYNTHETIC ARGUMENT AGAINST SYNTHETIC FUELS
description: To the Editor:

title: THREE BACKS ON JETS TO REPLACE MCNEIL
description: Faced with playing at least half the season without Freeman McNeil, the league's rushing champion, Coach Joe Walton of the Jets said today that three backs would probably alternate in McNeil's place.

title: OPERA: PLACIDO DOMINGO HEADS FIRST-NIGHT CAST
description: TO celebrate the opening of its centennial season last night the Metropolitan Opera revived one of the grandest works that it has ever produced, ''Les Troyens.'' The Berlioz opera, a sprawling epic crammed with fine music, had not been heard in the house since its Met premiere just 10 years ago, much to the regret of devout Berliozites. Now the production is back, in a redirected version but with many of the same flaws in staging and design that made the 1973 performances less than satisfying, however welcome.

title: British Trade Data Given
description: Britain's foreign merchandise trade showed a deficit of about $207 million in August, but the country registered a surplus in its current account, the Department of Trade said today.

title: WHO'LL PAY THE PRICE OF TELEPORT ECONOMIES?
description: To the Editor:

title: Norway Oil Price Rise
description: The Norwegian state oil corporation, Statoil, will increase the price of its crude from the Statfjord field by up to 50 cents a barrel, effective Oct. 1, a corporation spokesman said today. The increase will raise the price of Statfjord crude to an average of $29.80 a barrel.

title: FOOTBALL PLAYER WHO DIED HAD RECORD OF HEART ILLNESS
description: A 17-year-old Yonkers High School football player who died of heart disease in a game Saturday had a history of heart trouble that had gone undetected by school authorities, the superintendent of schools said today.

title: Nissan Unit Plans U.S. Production
description: The Nihon Radiator Company, a major Japanese manufacturer of radiators and mufflers, said it would produce automobile air-conditioner parts in the United States.

title: 11 in Cycle Club Plead Not Guilty in Killing
description: Eleven members of the Outlaws motorcycle gang pleaded not guilty today to murder charges after a man was slain near their new clubhouse.

title: Profit Taking In Eurobonds
description: Profit taking forced fixed-interest dollar bonds off this morning's highs, dealers said.

title: U.S. Protests to Soviet Over Jet Debris Search
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz protested to the Soviet Union today and expressed regret to South Korea about the Soviet refusal to allow South Korea to be represented when debris from the downed Korean jet was turned over, State Department spokesmen said.

title: ALLEGHENY & WESTERN ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Deficit Grew In August
description: The Government spent $17.5 billion more than it took in last month, nudging the Federal deficit for the first 11 months of the fiscal year to $197.3 billion, the Treasury Department said today.

title: QUESTIONS OF TASTE; Sign of the Times
description: In 1979, when a 40-foot iguana was hoisted to its lair above a Greenwich Village cafe, there was some controversy (since rendered academic by the iguana's deterioration) about whether it was or wasn't art.

title: 5 East Texas Slayings Called Work of 'Locals'
description: The authorities said today that the abduction and slaying of five fast-food restaurant employees was probably the work of ''locals'' familiar with the rugged oil country.

title: 'Courtesy' Move Barred on Judge
description: The President of the State Senate, Carmen A. Orechio, announced today that the upper house would not allow Senator Gerald Cardinale to invoke the privilege of ''senatorial courtesy'' to block the renomination of Judge Sylvia B. Pressler to the Appellate Division of Superior Court.

title: Chemical Appoints Division President
description: The Chemical Bank, the nation's sixth-largest bank and the major subsidiary of the Chemical New York Corporation, yesterday named Alan H. Fishman to head a new investment banking division, effective Saturday.

title: PROGRAM FOR CONTROL OF ACID RAIN EMERGING AT ENVIRONMENT AGENCY
description: A limited experimental program to control acid rain is now ''crystallizing'' at the Environmental Protection Agency and is receiving particular attention from the agency's Administrator, William D. Ruckelshaus, according to agency officials and others with whom he has discussed the issue in recent days.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS TO BUY I.D.S.
description: The American Express Company, resurrecting a deal that it canceled last month, announced last night that it had signed a ''definitive agreement'' to buy the Alleghany Corporation's big financial services company, Investors Diversified Services, for about $773 million in cash and stock.

title: AEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 26
description: b-Includes tax credits of $594,000 for the quarter and $1,636,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $1,032,000 for the quarter and $2,245,000 for the 6 months.

title: Television Executive Found Slain on Coast
description: A television executive who had reported receiving crank telephone calls was slain at her home in fashionable Benedict Canyon, the police said today.

title: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 27, 1983
description: International

title: A LONG WAIT FOR ROBERTSON
description: Andre Robertson is home now, a month and a half after the auto accident on the West Side Highway that nearly killed him. His female companion that night, though listed in satisfactory condition, remains in Roosevelt Hospital.

title: IMPROVING THE EARLIEST GRADES
description: THE only school people who feel more neglected than high school teachers are their colleagues in the elementary schools. Therefore, the most remarkable aspect of the recent report by the National Science Board on the need to improve mathematics and science education is that it says reforms must begin in kindergarten. This point has been missing from the recent avalanche of education reports.

title: News Analysis
description: The latest proposals on curbing medium-range nuclear-armed missiles and planes that President Reagan outlined to the General Assembly today seem to meet some previous Soviet objections. But the speech left unresolved a fundamental difference in perception between East and West over the nuclear balance in Europe that continues to make the achieving of an accord very elusive.

title: How Teredos Eat Wood
description: Shipworms, or teredos, live by eating submerged wood. Zoologists have long wondered how they can do so, since they lack any enzymes that can digest the cellulose of which wood is made or any dietary source of nitrogen, which is essential to proteins but lacking in wood.

title: British and U.S. Units Seek Stock Listings
description: Soon American investors will be able to buy a piece of Britain's publicly held Saatchi & Saatchi agency right in the United States of America, while Britons will be able to shop at home for shares in the America's JWT Group, the holding company that includes the venerable J. Walter Thompson Company.

title: Second Thoughts
description: The Montreal Expos made a mistake in signing Gary Carter to a long- term $15 million contract ''because we thought we couldn't win without him,'' said the club chairman, Charles Bronfman. The Expos found that they couldn't win - at least not enough - with Carter, either, and Bronfman is sorry they gave the all- star catcher the richest contract to be awarded in the club's 14-year history.

title: DOUGHERTY BROS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE thrift-shop generation put on its new gray blazer with white flecks, had a cigarette for lunch and went Sunday to the fall opening of P.S. 1's newest exhibition, entitled ''Expressions, New Art From Germany.'' Even Richard Gere showed up, with his hair parted down the middle and a pencil-thin mustache, to view the show's fashion exhibit mounted by Hollywood Di Russo. Called ''Straight White Male,'' it qualifies as the best fashion exhibit ever at the gallery in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Sportswomen of Year
description: For the third time in four years Mary Decker has been named Sportswoman of the Year in the amateur category for her track exploits by the Women's Sports Foundation. Martina Navratilova, the Wimbledon and United States Open champion, was honored as the top professional as the foundation announced its annual awards yesterday in Manhattan.

title: No Headline
description: When the Coca-Cola Company began offering consumers a $3 rebate on a $2.99 bottle of Taylor California Cellars light wine a few months ago, it confirmed to analysts the rumor that the company's Wine Spectrum was for sale. Yesterday, Coca-Cola signed a letter of intent to sell Wine Spectrum, the country's third-largest wine producer, to Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Inc. for more than $200 million in cash.

title: JIFFY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
NEW NURSING RESOURCE
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Howard Samuels, president of the North American Soccer League, said yesterday that the Soccer Bowl format would be changed next year from a single game to a two-of three series. . . The Dallas Mavericks of the National Basketball Association signed their No. 1 draft choice, Dale Ellis of Tennessee, to a five-year contract. Ellis, a 6-7, 210-pound forward, was the ninth selection in the 1983 college draft. . . . Bill Lajoie, who helped to build a strong farm system for the Tigers, has been appointed general manager of the Detroit club.

title: FOR SOME, THE VIETNAM WAR GOES ON
description: It remains one of the final reminders that the Vietnam War is not completely over.

title: BOB FORSCH HURLS HIS 2D NO-HITTER
description: Bob Forsch pitched the second no-hitter of his career and the first in the National League in exactly two years, giving the St. Louis Cardinals a 3-0 victory over the Montreal Expos tonight.

title: CHURCH'S FRIED CHICKEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 4
LENNAR CORP .  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
LEBANON PULLOUT NOT ISSUE IN TRUCE
description: The Lebanese cease-fire does not alter the troop withdrawal accord signed between Israel and Lebanon, a State Department official told a House subcommittee today.

title: Black Help for the Black Family
description: The breakdown of the black family: for years, it's been a taboo subject among black leaders who feared that to focus on it would sound like blaming the victims of social distress. Not anymore.

title: MARCOS TELLS INQUIRY ON AQUINO TO RESUME WORK
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he wanted his commission of inquiry into the murder of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. to resume work immediately and to complete it within a week or two.

title: B.P. Stock Sale Price Is Raised
description: The British Government made an extra profit of almost $60 million from the sale of part of its stake in the British Petroleum Company today when the share price was fixed at a higher level than expected. The Bank of England, Britain's central bank and the Government's agents in the sale, said the shares would be sold at 435 pence each, or $6.53 in United States currency, earning the Government $848 million.

title: REJOICING BEGINS DOWN UNDER
description: An emotional Prime Minister Bob Hawke led Australians in jubilation early today following Australia II's victory over the United States yacht Liberty in the America's Cup race.

title: U.S. Judge Frees Funds In Chicago School Fight
description: Federal District Judge Milton I. Shadur today released $4.3 million of the $48 million in Federal funds he had ordered frozen in the Chicago desegregation dispute.

title: Getting It Right
description: Hell hath no fury like a 5-year-old included among the little kids who are only 4.

title: New Rumasa Case Charge
description: The former president of Rumasa, Spain's giant holding company expropriated by the Socialist Government, was declared in contempt of court by a judge today after failing to appear on fraud charges.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday in Metropolitan Report about the search for a new chairman of the Metropolitan Transporation Authority misidentified Drew Lewis. He is chairman and chief executive officer of Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc.

title: Hungarian Money Plan
description: Hungary plans to rebuild foreign currency reserves to $1.8 billion by the end of the first quarter next year, Janos Fekete, first deputy president of the National Bank of Hungary, said today.

title: CAMBODIAN SOLUTION
description: This year, the United Nations General Assembly will discuss the question of Cambodia for the fifth year in a row. As before, it will debate whether to seat the deposed government of Pol Pot, which ruled from 1975 to 1979, or that of Heng Samrin, who was installed by the Vietnamese in 1979. But it is time to look at the whole problem again - to search for a broader solution that would end the fighting between the Vietnamese occupiers and the Cambodian resistance forces. In fact, there is a simple solution: Ask both sides to drop all fighters and officials who belonged to the Khmer Rouge under Pol Pot's government.

title: Article 192148 -- No Title
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities today announced the award of $66 million in grants to educational and cultural projects across the country, including more than $2 million to the New York City Public Library.

title: Convict Ordered Freed In 'Onion Field' Case
description: A judge today ordered the release of a man convicted of killing a police officer in a case made famous by Joseph Wambaugh's book ''The Onion Field,'' saying a state parole board erred in canceling his scheduled parole last year.

title: Talking Business with Platten of the Chemical Bank International Risk, Reward
description: Donald C. Platten, who has been chairman and chief executive officer of the Chemical Bank since 1973, is scheduled to retire Oct. 1. One of his major accomplishments during his 10 years in charge of the nation's sixth-largest bank was to enhance Chemical's stature as an international institution. He was interviewed this weekend in Washington, where he is attending the annual meetings of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. Q. Considering the serious problems that banks are having in getting repaid on many of their foreign loans, do you believe you might have erred in thrusting Chemical more deeply into the international arena?

title: MUSIC: 'MADAMA BUTTERFLY' AT CITY OPERA
description: THE New York City Opera returned with one of its staples Sunday evening - Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly.'' The Frank Corsaro production remains simple and straightforward, and it is still reasonably attractive. Sunday's cast had not a bad singer in the lot.

title: ROADWAY SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 10
TRIAL ENDING FOR NEW YORKER OVER THE KILLING OF HER FATHER
description: Final arguments are scheduled for Tuesday in the first-degree murder trial of Frances Bernice Schreuder, a New York City woman accused of ordering the death of her father in order to secure her inheritance.

title: JACKSON IS HINTING AT A DECISION SOON ON RUNNING IN '84
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson took a leave of absence today from leadership of his civil rights organization, Operation PUSH, to decide whether the timing and finances were right for him to run for President.

title: AIRLINER'S SHADOW FALLS OVER THE ASSEMBLY
description: The downing by the Soviet Union of a South Korean airliner this month was repeatedly cited in speeches before the General Assembly today as an example of what can happen as a result of world tensions. Speakers called on all nations to work together to end oppression, hunger and the threat of civil war.

title: 6 Groups Call for Resignation Of One U.S. Delegate to U.N.
description: Six religious groups called today for the resignation of Charles M. Lichenstein as a United States delegate to the United Nations because of his comments when a Soviet official was denied landing rights at civilian airports in the New York City area.

title: FLORIDA ALLIGATOR HUNTERS HEAR YEE-HAWS AND SOME DISSENT
description: Near the moss-draped cypress swamp that borders the lake, a single light cuts the darkness and a gunshot scares an eagle out of its treetop aerie.

title: For Steve Kemp, A Season to Forget
description: Steve Kemp remembers lying on the outfield grass at Milwaukee County Stadium and joking about it. ''I said too bad it didn't hit me in the nose. I could've gotten a nose job.''

title: Tribune Co. Stock Split
description: The Tribune Company today announced a 4,800-for-1 stock split as part of its move to become publicly held.

title: CUTBACK IN GERMAN COAL NEAR
description: The West German coal mining industry, facing sharply declining demand from Europe's energy and steel producers, is bracing for harsh cuts in production and jobs.

title: LEBANON CEASE-FIRE ACCORD
description: Following is the text of the cease-fire agreement in Lebanon as made public today by the Lebanese Government and translated by The Associated Press from the Arabic:

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 27, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: A Matter of Timing
description: All foreign policy disputes do not involve foreign policy.

title: BEIRUT PREMIER OFFERS TO RESIGN IN TRUCE ACCORD
description: Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan offered his resignation today to pave the way for the formation of a new Lebanese Government made up of representatives from the leading Lebanese political and religious factions.

title: AUSTRALIA II DEFEATS LIBERTY BY 41 SECONDS IN FINALE
description: Liberty, the vanquished America's Cup defender, was welcomed back into Newport harbor tonight with fireworks, blasts from ships' horns and choruses of ''God Bless America.''

title: BRIEFING
description: Now, a 'Star Wars' PAC

title: BRIEFS
description: * BankAmerica Corp. announced that it had received preliminary approval to establish a banking operation in Rapid City, S.D., and that the operation's primary interest would be insurance.

title: Bergen Dismisses Libyan Tax Plea
description: An appeal by the Libyan Government for a tax exemption for its 25-room mansion in Englewood was dismissed today by the Bergen County Board of Taxation.

title: QUESTION OF TASTE; Inconvenience Food
description: Now that food shoppers are used to generics, with blunt labels and no- nonsense packaging, supermarkets are experimenting with a logical next step: no packages at all. Big chains like Safeway, First National and Grand Union are offering as many as 200 items - flour, sugar, muffin mix, breakfast cereals, spices, potato chips - out of barrels and bins.

title: LEADERS IN SENATE CRITICIZING SHULTZ
description: Republican and Democratic leaders in Congress today sharply criticized statements by Secretary of State George P. Shultz that the Reagan Administration would not feel bound by proposed legislation to invoke the War Powers Resolution and to authorize the presence of American Marines in Lebanon for 18 months.

title: Rangers Sign Allison
description: Mike Allison of the Rangers was entering the option year of his contract, but the 22-year-old center is the team's leading scorer in the exhibition season with four goals and five assists, and that heightened the Rangers' interest in keeping him around. Yesterday they signed him to a new contract, the terms of which were not revealed. Allison missed 41 games last season with a knee injury, and missed part of the previous season with knee problems.

title: Grain Sales To China Rise
description: The Agriculture Department today announced the largest grain purchase by China in nearly a year. Department officials said private American exporters reported selling China 200,000 metric tons of United States wheat for delivery under the third year of a long-term grain agreement with that nation.

title: BALDWIN, A CASUALTY OF FAST EXPANSION, FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation, the Cincinnati piano company that borrowed heavily to move into the insurance business, filed for protection under the bankruptcy laws yesterday in one of the largest financial collapses in American history.

title: FULLER H B reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $897,000.

title: Lionel Corp. to Sell 82% Stake in Dale
description: The Peabody International Corporation of Stamford, Conn., and the Lionel Corporation of New York have agreed that Peabody, which makes environmental control equipment, will acquire 82 percent, or 2,950,000 shares, of common stock of Dale Electronics Inc. from Lionel for $50 million in cash. Lionel, a diversified producer and retailer of electronics equipment and toys, has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act since February 1982.

title: NICARAGUA'S CHANCE TO END ANTI-SEMITISM
description: To The Editor:

title: Vandals Damage Fordham Artwork
description: Four of a current showing of 12 outdoor sculptures at the Rose Hill campus of Fordham University in the Bronx have been damaged by vandals, university officials said yesterday.

title: THE PLAYFUL INVENTOR: VISIONS OF FUTURE FLIGHT
description: THERE he is out in the middle of the Mojave Desert, speeding along in a pickup truck to maintain radio control of a model airplane buzzing high overhead. There he is again in a cluttered office at the Dryden Flight Research Facility in California, drawing odd-looking airplanes that are surely for his own amusement and never meant to fly. He is a recognized master of innovation in aeronautical engineering, Dale Reed, and sometimes his work looks like play.

title: VOLUME OFF
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday in less active trading, bolstered by hopes of lower interest rates.

title: Beatrice Net Climbs by 3%
description: The Beatrice Foods Company said today that the strength of the dollar on overseas earnings limited its overall profit to a 3 percent gain in its fiscal second quarter.

title: UNHYPOCRITICAL OATH
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Of an Ad Executive
description: ''RUNNING an advertising agency is not so difficult that it requires a business man,'' said Kenneth L. Robbins, who runs one from the 42d floor of One Dag Hammarskjold Plaza. ''They don't need office managers. The best agencies are run by advertising people.''

title: Korean Bank Scandal
description: The Cho-Heung Bank said today that it had dismissed 10 employees in a $214 million banking scandal. Auditors found that bank promissory notes totaling that amount had been issued illegally by the employees.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The door to an agreement is open. It is time for the Soviet Union to walk through it.''

title: HELLER INTERNATIONAL PLANS TO LIQUIDATE
description: The Walter E. Heller International Corporation, a financial holding company that has specialized in lending to small and middle-sized companies, said today that its directors had voted to liquidate the concern and distribute the proceeds to its shareholders.

title: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 27, 1983
description: International

title: U.N.DO THE DAMAGE
description: In his address yesterday to the United Nations General Assembly, President Reagan did not repeat his suggestion of last week that the United Nations consider itself free to leave New York City or that, alternatively, delegates divide their time between New York City and Moscow. His speech was conciliatory, and in ways a retraction. Even so, there is damage to be undone.

title: ZDRAVKO MANOLOV
description: Zdravko Manolov, the accompanist for the Bulgarian National Male Choir, Sofia, died of a heart attack yesterday in Manhattan just hours after his first performance in America.

title: YOUTH ADVISES HOUSE ON COMPUTER CRIME
description: One of the Milwaukee teen-agers who broke into dozens of large computer systems said today that most of those abuses could be eliminated by making some ''common sense'' changes in the programs that allow access to computers and by educating people about the ethics of computers.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BRITISH ARE GOING

title: WORLCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: A Faulty Tack on Covering the Races; TV SPORTS
description: The last laugh of the day came during halftime of the Notre Dame-Miami football game on CBS Saturday night. Brent Musburger, who is the host of ''The NCAA Today,'' was updating the America's Cup races, recounting that Liberty, the American 12-Meter yacht, was having about 1,000 pounds of ballast removed so that she might be better able to keep up with the challenger Australia II in the seventh and deciding race. Musburger finished and looked mischievously at his colleague, Ara Parseghian, a former professor of x's and o's, who appeared rather confused. ''Anything you say,'' Parseghian said, smiling.

title: A YACHT CUP WITHOUT A CUP
description: When they began to gather in the dark wooden bar of the New York Yacht Club late yesterday afternoon, Liberty was leading, and they were smiling. Old men and young men in dark suits with striped ties appeared to have stepped out of a Brooks Brothers advertisement. But there is no TV set in this old stone building that opened in 1901 at 37 West 44th Street; no radio, either. In a nearby wooden booth with an old brass ''coin telephone'' sign above it, a young executive was listening to his wife describe what she was watching on cable TV at home.

title: Chess: Tourney
description: First place in the Biel International Tournament in Switzerland was shared by the British grandmasters Anthony Miles and John Nunn. Each scored 8-3 in the 12-player round- robin event. FINAL STANDINGS Player W. L. D. Pts. Miles5068Nunn5068Adorjan6327Meduna5336 1/2Gheorghiu3176 1/2Hebden3355 1/2Kindermann4435 1/2Toth3534 1/2Campora2544Gobet3624Wirthensohn0473 1/2Nemet2723

title: Cuomo Resisting Delay on Westway
description: Governor Cuomo appealed to the Secretary of the Army yesterday to review a decision by the Army Corps of Engineers that could delay the Westway project for at least two years.

title: EVANGELIST AND FAITH HEALER
description: Ruth Carter Stapleton, the Baptist evangelist and spiritual healer who came to national attention as the younger sister of President Jimmy Carter, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Fayetteville, N.C. She was 54 years old.

title: Required Reading; Abortion and the Debt
description: Colloquy on House floor in debate over banning all Federal funds for abortions, Sept. 22, 1983:

title: SHOULD VIVISECTION BE ABOLISHED
description: IN recent months and years, advocates of the rights of animals have sabotaged research laboratories that experiment with animals, physically prevented seal hunters from killing seals, freed caged animals from commercial fur farms, harassed whaling vessels, released animals from zoos, and hindered hunters in their search for prey. In search of public support for their point of view, they have taken advertisements, distributed printed fliers and vivid photographs that give graphic examples of how animals are sometimes treated when they are exploited for the benefit of humans.

title: U.S., HELP THE I.M.F.
description: Though some Congressmen sermonize against the immorality of rescuing greedy banks from the international debt crisis, they should step down from the pulpit and do what is best for America and the world - pass the bill to give the International Monetary Fund the $8.4 billion the Administration committed last February.

title: TEXT OF PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS AT U.N.
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's speech as delivered to the 38th session of the United Nations General Assembly today:

title: TOUGH TALK BY U.S.: NEW DEVELOPMENT FOR I.M.F.
description: One man stands alone among the representatives of 146 countries who have gathered here this week to try to ease the pressures on the world financial system. He is the head of the American delegation, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, and his position marks a departure in the position of the wealthiest Western member.

title: MAN OFFERS FEW DETAILS ON BOY, 7, KILLED BY CAR
description: A passenger in a car that killed a Spanish-speaking boy here last March testified under subpoena today that he could not remember whether the driver had suggested ''picking off some Puerto Ricans and niggers.''

title: Fire Hits Pottery Factory
description: An early morning fire today destroyed the Frankoma Pottery factory and showroom, a source of internationally known ceramics for 50 years. There were no injuries, but witnesses said the two-block-long plant was destroyed. Firefighters said the blaze apparently began near a kiln.

title: Angola Insurgents Tell of Victories
description: Pro-Western guerrillas in Angola said today that they had killed 137 Government soldiers and 47 Cubans in four days of attacks in Angola.

title: Soybeans Fall Limit; Spread Pattern Altering
description: Bearish sentiment deepened in the soybean futures market yesterday, with prices down the daily permissible limit in all except the distant delivery months. The spot November contract closed at $8.79 a bushel.

title: PRESIDENTIAL VIEW ON WHITE HOUSE
description: President Reagan says he has discovered, as all Presidents do, that the White House is a wonderful place to live, but concedes, ''You get a little stir-crazy during the week.''

title: IN THE BATTLE OF THE RESTAURANTS, A WINNER, SORT OF
description: It's crab cakes at 20 paces with matzoh balls rolling in fast as Duke Zeibert and Mel Krupin square off in a culinary duel along Connecticut Avenue.

title: Chronicle of Decay
description: Four pastel-painted houses, each with a jaunty little turret, stand side by side in a picture from the South Bronx in February 1979. In the next picture, one is boarded up.

title: India's Trade In Diamonds
description: Indian diamonds have won much of the large traditional markets for gems on which the profits of De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd. were founded, Davis Borkum Hare, a stock brokerage in South Africa, said today.

title: CHESAPEAKE BAY STUDY CITING POLLUTION THREATS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency reported to Congress today that Chesapeake Bay, the nation's most productive estuary, is ''clearly an ecosystem in decline.''

title: BRAZIL TO RECEIVE $11 BILLION IN AID
description: The International Monetary Fund announced tonight that agreement had been reached to provide Brazil, the world's largest debtor, with $11 billion in loans and credits for the rest of this year and all of 1984.

title: Prentis Triumphs
description: E.A. (Ted) Prentis VI of the Palm Beach (Fla.) Polo and Country Club won the singles final of the United States Croquet Association championships yesterday by defeating Richard Pearman of Bermuda in two matches at Central Park. The scores were, 27-17, 24-18.

title: WHITE HOUSE IS SILENT AS PRESSURE GROWS FOR WATT TO RESIGN
description: White House officials remained silent today as the pressure built for the resignation of Interior Secretary James G. Watt. One the Secretary's few active defenders in Congress said he would ''do what he can'' to build support to keep him on the job.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Clouds are said to form because of adiabatic cooling. ''Adiabatic'' means to occur without loss or gain of heat. How can air be cooled to form clouds and at the same time be adiabatic?

title: ENOUGH HOUSING WITHOUT HOTELS
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-GANG MEMBER LOOKS BACK WITH FEAR AND FONDNESS
description: When he was 11 years old, Johnny Santiago, who calls himself Sting Ray, learned he was too young to join a Brooklyn gang called the Turban Saints. So he and a friend formed a gang of their own. They named it the Assassinators.

title: PITIFUL, HELPLESS GIANTS
description: Now crisis is brewing in the Philippines. It's beginning to sound like Iran in the last year of the Shah. No one should be surprised if President Ferdinand Marcos finally crashes.

title: YCAZA'S 'AT HOME' IN RACING COMEBACK
description: Manuel Ycaza's knees were steady as they gripped the sides of the 2-year-old gray filly in the starting gate. Any second now the doors would fly open and Ycaza would be just one of 14 whooping jockeys trying to hustle their dangerously green and flighty young fillies into contention.

title: AMERICA'S CUP TO AUSTRALIA II AS 132-YEAR U.S. REIGN ENDS
description: Australia II today became the first challenger ever to win the America's Cup, defeating Liberty in the seventh and final race and bringing a dramatic end to the longest winning streak in sports.

title: REAGAN AT THE U.N.: CHEERS AND FOLDED HANDS
description: Delegates without seats stood six or seven deep along the sides of the large, green carpeted assembly hall. Demonstrators chanted outside. Warm applause greeted the President of the United States as he was introduced to the 158 member nations of the General Assembly, though, it was widely noted, the four members of the Soviet delegation did not clap their hands.

title: Beneficial Corp.'s 12 3/4% Debentures
description: A $75 million issue of A-3-rated Beneficial Corporation 12 3/4 percent debentures due in 2013 is offered at a price of 100 through underwriters led by Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc.

title: SOVIET HARSHLY CRITICIZES REAGAN'S SPEECH AT U.N.
description: The official Soviet press agency Tass today reported President Reagan's speech to the United Nations General Assembly but omitted any mention of his new proposal for an agreement on medium- range nuclear weapons in Europe.

title: ISOBEL BAILLIE
description: Dame Isobel Baillie, the British soprano famous for her performances of oratorios, died Saturday at the age of 88. She had performed with the conductor Arturo Toscanini and had sung Handel's ''Messiah'' more than 1,000 times. Queen Elizabeth II made her a Commander of the British Empire in 1951 and a Dame Commander in 1978.

title: S.E.C. Warns Investors
description: Foreign investors should not expect to hide behind the secrecy laws of their own countries if they intend to trade in United States markets, John M. Fedders, head of the enforcement division of the United States Securities and Exchange Commission, said today.

title: INTERIM AGREEMENT REACHED TO AVERT LONGSHORE STRIKE
description: Longshoremen and port employers on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts announced yesterday that they had reached an interim agreement that would avert a strike threatened for next weekend and insure labor peace on the waterfront for three and a half months.

title: PACE QUICKENS IN THE SEARCH FOR IDEAL PLANTS
description: THE field of tomatoes near the southern end of the New Jersey Turnpike looks like hundreds of others in this truck gardening area, but the dark green plants that are now heavy with ripe fruit are different in several thousands of ways from those on nearby farms.

title: Bid for Northwest: No U.S. Bar Seen
description: The Williams Companies said the Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department do not intend to block its offer for the Northwest Energy Company, a major pipeline company based in Salt Lake City.

title: CHINESE SAYS TAIWAN IS STILL MAIN ISSUE
description: China's Foreign Minister called on the United States yesterday to cease any ''official or semiofficial'' relations with Taiwan.

title: NEW FLEXIBILITY URGED TO FILL TEACHER POSTS
description: EVERY state, for the most part, requires teachers to be certified to work in public schools, a requirement that almost always means having to take the necessary education courses in college.

title: SANDGATE CORP .  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sale of Nuclear Gear To South Africa Cleared
description: The State Department has approved a request from seven American companies to provide an estimated $50 million worth of technical and maintenance services for a South African nuclear power installation under construction near Cape Town, United States officials said today.

title: Transsexual Sues for Old Job
description: An Eastern Airlines pilot who was dismissed in 1981 after undergoing a sex change operation has taken the airline to court to seek reinstatement. Karen Ulane, formerly Kenneth F. Ulane, contends in a suit filed in Federal District Court that the airline unlawfully discriminated against her on the basis of sex. The airline contended she suffered from psychological problems resulting from the 1980 sex change and also cited safety concerns, saying that working relationships in the cockpit may be jeopardized because of the operation.

title: PROBLEM SCHOOL HELPED BUT NOT ALL STUDENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. Attendance, TV Ratings Drop
description: The average attendance at National Football League games played through Sunday and the size of the viewing television audience have fallen, compared with the figures for 1981 and 1982.

title: ANDROS ANALYZERS INC Qtr to July 31 reports earnings for 1983
description: b-Net loss.

title: TV: CBS FILM A DOMESTIC COMEDY
description: SADDLED with one of the more unfortunate titles of the season, ''One Cooks, the Other Doesn't,'' tonight's television movie on CBS at 9 turns out to be a mildly pleasant comedy about love, marriage and contemporary mores. Larry Grusin's script gets solid support from the performances of Suzanne Pleshette, Joseph Bologna and Rosanna Arquette.

title: Give IDA What It Needs
description: Seven is not a lucky number for the International Development Association, the World Bank's lending agency for the poorest and most populous nations. For the seventh time since its creation in 1960 (by the United States), IDA is asking richer nations to replenish its funds for a three-year cycle. But alone among the major donors, the United States proposes an absolute reduction, pleading lack of Congressional support.

title: 21 REMAIN AT LARGE AFTER ULSTER PRISON BREAK
description: Heavily armed policemen and British Army patrols searched today for 21 members of the Provisional Irish Republican Army still at large after having escaped from the maximum-security Maze Prison on Sunday.

title: TRYING TO CONTROL TELEPHONE COSTS
description: Powerful new communications technologies - satellites, microwave towers, fiber optics and computers - appear to have almost overwhelmed the ability of the government and industry to control the way the American people communicate with each other and to regulate how much they pay for these services.

title: A Soiled Judicial Process Indeed
description: The Republican leader of the Bronx has a glib explanation for supporting his Democratic rival in the manipulation of judicial nominations. Senator John Calandra approves of Stanley Friedman's refusal to renominate two Supreme Court justices because ''No person has a vested right to continue in his job.'' As he put it, ''The political process gave the judges their jobs and now it's taking them away. What's the big to-do about that?''

title: Bridge: American Team Pulls Away From Pakistan in World Play
description: After running neck-and-neck with Pakistan for three rounds of world team championship play here, the U.S.A. II team finally took undisputed possession of first place in the fourth round Monday night.

title: General Mills Profit Up 19.8%
description: General Mills Inc. said today that its fiscal first-quarter profit rose 19.8 percent from the comparable period a year earlier, despite flat sales. The company said earnings in the quarter ended Aug. 28 rose to $72.5 million, or $1.52 a share, from $60.5 million, or $1.20 a share, in the 1982 period.

title: Home Resales Down 2.9%
description: Resales of single-family homes fell 2.9 percent in August because of a summer rise in mortgage rates, the National Association of Realtors said today.

title: LOGICA HOLDINGS LTD reports earnings for Year to June 30
SCHOLARS CHARGING POLITICS ON SOCIAL SCIENCE RESEARCH
description: A large scholarly organization has charged that the Reagan Administration is improperly using political criteria to evaluate proposals for social science research.

title: Generals Bid To Get Shula
description: Don Shula, the coach of the Miami Dolphins and the fourth-winningest coach in National Football League history, said yesterday that he had been contacted by representatives of the New Jersey Generals of the United States Football League who asked if he would be interested in coaching the team for $1 million a year.

title: ONE-WAY FARES OF $49 OFFERED BY CONTINENTAL
description: Continental Air Lines, saying it intended to become the largest discount carrier in the nation, yesterday offered unrestricted one-way fares of $49 or less, good through Friday.

title: LEGAL AID AGENCY DRAWING PROTEST
description: Thirty- seven directors of legal aid programs financed through the Federal Legal Services Corporation said today that they were ''outraged'' at efforts by the agency's new management, made up of Reagan Administration supporters, to bar its nine regional offices from talking to the press or elected officials.

title: IS THE I.B.M. PEANUT REALLY IN THE WINGS?
description: THE International Business Machines Corporation will acknowledge neither the existence of the Peanut nor its anticipated entry into he low-priced (under $1,000) home computer market. Yet a whole industry has grown up around the alleged product.

title: SLOW START FOR WEINBERGER IN PEKING
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's effort to enlist China in the cause of greater military cooperation, an effort that includes arms assistance from the United States, got off to a slow start today, according to American officials.

title: DANCE STUDIO IN HARLEM VANDALIZED BY BURGLARS
description: Burglary and vandalism over the weekend caused losses of between $75,000 and $100,000 at the building that houses the Dance Theater of Harlem, theater officials said yesterday.

title: Slaying the Messenger
description: Watching television, Governor Cuomo saw Mayor Koch complain that the state was short-changing a city program, according to someone who was watching with him.

title: U.S. STEEL PURSUES TALKS ON IMPORTS
description: The chances of the United States Steel Corporation's reaching an agreement to import steel from Britain to its plant in Fairless, Pa., are ''less than 50-50,'' a U.S. Steel official said yesterday.

title: 2 CHARGED IN ATARI STOCK SALE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged a former chairman and the current senior vice president of Atari Inc., a unit of Warner Communications, with trading on the basis of illegal insider information just before Warner's announcement last December that its earnings would be lower then expected. Warner's stock fell $16.75 a share on the first day it traded after the announcement.

title: J. PATRICK LANNAN, EX-DIRECTOR OF I.T.T. AND BACKER OF ARTS
description: J. Patrick Lannan, a business executive, financial consultant and patron of the arts, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 78 years old and also lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Ozark-Caledonian
description: British Caledonian Airways and Ozark Air Lines today announced an agreement under which British Caledonian would resume nonstop flights from St. Louis to London.

title: 2 NEWSPAPERS FACING STRIKE IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: Contract talks continued today with a Federal mediator in efforts to avoid a strike against San Francisco's two major daily newspapers at midnight Tuesday.

title: BELIEF IN REINCARNATION IS FADING IN NIGERIA
description: UNDER the heading, ''Occasional Myth,'' the British medical journal Lancet has reported that the belief in reincarnation, widely held in Nigeria for many centuries, has waned in the past 30 years because of medical advances. According to a physician at the Clinical Research Center in Harrow, England, the children once thought to be reincarnated were most probably suffering the effects of sickle-cell anemia.

title: Betjeman in Hospital After a Heart Attack
description: John Betjeman, 77 years old, the British poet laureate, suffered a major heart attack and was hospitalized today in serious condition.

title: GALA DRESSING AT THE MET'S OPENING NIGHT
description: They came from all over the country and they brought all the white ties, tails, top hats, capes, furs, feathers and jewelry they could find. And even if tiaras were scarcer than Vanderbilts in the crowd of 4,000 that celebrated the Metropolitan Opera's 100th birthday, last night's opening qualified as the most glamorous that many could remember.

title: China Acts on Joint Ventures
description: China issued new economic regulations today aimed at attracting greater foreign investment by giving more preferential treatment to joint ventures.

title: FISCAL YEAR NEARS IN TYPICAL FASHION
description: Congress today faced the onset of a new fiscal year in its usual manner - with money for Government agencies running out and new funds very much in doubt.

title: Swedish Output Rises
description: Sweden's gross national product grew 1 percent, adjusted for inflation, in the first half of 1983 from a year earlier, the Government said today. Rising exports accounted for the gain as domestic consumption fell.

title: ARGENTINES FIGHT AMNESTY FOR ARMY
description: An Argentine bar association filed suit in federal court here today to declare an amnesty decreed by the ruling military Friday unconstitutional.

title: DOMINATION IS LINKED TO CHEMICAL IN THE BRAIN
description: STUDIES of monkeys and college students suggest that social status is reflected in the chemistry of the brain.

title: 10% TAX EXEMPTS DISAPPEAR
description: A 10 percent yield on long-term tax- exempt bonds - formerly identified as the level needed to attract strong demand from individual investors - is disappearing amid generally declining interest rates.

title: FOR THE DRUSE THE CEASE-FIRE IS JUST A PERIOD OF REST
description: On the Druse side of the cease-fire lines, there was little cheering over the truce that officially went into effect today.

title: TYCO LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-Includes loss of $400,000 from the sale of non-operating assets. c-Includes a gain of $3,500,000, or 41 cents a share, from the sale of Tyco's 20 percent stake in Mobil Tyco Solar Energy Corp., and a foreign exchange gain of $400,000.

title: Denmark Trade Deficit
description: Denmark's net foreign trade deficit narrowed 65 percent in August from a year earlier, the Government's Bureau of Statistics said today. The trade deficit fell to 400 million kroner, or about $42.1 million, from 1.14 billion kroner in August 1982.

title: RIMINI BECOMES SCENE OF FELLINI HOMECOMING
description: About 30 years ago, Federico Fellini, always a man who relishes irony and ambiguity, said in an interview that he would never return to Rimini, his native city, unless, perhaps, somebody gave him a small fisherman's house on the old port.

title: Chrysler Prices
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it would increase prices on its 1984 model cars by an average of 1.9 percent, or $191. Several weeks ago, the General Motors Corporation raised its 1984 car prices about 2 percent and the Ford Motor Company raised prices by 2.3 percent, making Chrysler's increase the lowest of the big three auto makers.

title: PLAN FOR A TOWER ATOP SYNAGOGUE WILL BE REVISED
description: Congregation Shearith Israel yesterday withdrew a plan to build a 488-foot apartment tower behind and above its synagogue on Central Park West. Instead, it said, a shorter building will be proposed.

title: No Headline
description: Speaking in the state where labor hopes to unite behind Walter F. Mondale's Presidential candidacy, Senator John Glenn today criticized labor's involvement in the Democratic campaign.

title: FAIR LANES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $$371,000 for the quarter and $824,000 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $57,000 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $70,000 for the year. Year-ago share earnings reflect 5-for-4 stock splits declared March 31, 1983 and Sept. 20, 1982.

title: LIFE IN CITY'S GANGS: SOME THINGS HAVE CHANGED, BUT IT'S STILL A DEAD END
description: Sidewalks and buildings and schoolyards in parts of Brooklyn are studded with spray-painted drawings of tombstones chronicling the deaths of teen-age members of the city's street gangs. They are kept freshly painted, even the ones that are a decade old, even the ones recording deaths that no one quite remembers.

title: Cummins to China
description: The Cummins Engine Company said it had signed an agreement to establish a distribution and technical service center in Peking. It said it signed the three-year, non-exclusive agreement in July with the China National Technical Import Corporation, which produced Cummins diesel engines last year under license, and with the China National Automotive Industry Corporation, which will operate and manage the center.

title: Minnesota Power Bond Has a 9.95% Top Yield
description: A $210 million bond financing by the Southern Minnesota Municipal Power Agency was tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 9.95 percent for 9 7/8 percent bonds due in 2016 through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc.

title: PHYSICAN-PATIENT CONFIDENTIALITY SLIPS AWAY
description: WHILE aboard an Amtrak train recently, a young doctor was telling a woman traveling with him about his cases. He spoke about how surgeons would soon probe into the brain of Mr. Jones, about the hormonal imbalances in Mrs. White's body and the clinical details of several other patients. He was learning medicine, this young doctor, and he was excited about it. He told his stories so enthusiastically that some passengers in the crowded train, who could not help but overhear the conversation, followed every word.

title: Italy Industrial Output
description: Italy's industrial production rose six-tenths of 1 percent in July from June, but was down 7.9 percent from July 1982, the State Statistical Institute said today. The agency said Italy's seasonally adjusted output of both consumer goods and intermediate goods fell six- tenths of 1 percent in July from June, while production of capital goods rose a strong 6.8 percent.

title: CHALLENGER WHO WOULDN'T GIVE UP
description: On a spring morning in 1970 at Derecktor's Yard in Mamaroneck, N. Y., Alan Bond of Australia and the crew from his yacht Apollo spotted an unusual yacht and climbed aboard to inspect her. She was the newly- launched 12-Meter Valiant, in which all the winches were below deck. A Valiant crew member arrived at the dock moments later and became enraged when he saw foreign sailors, uninvited, aboard the secret 12-Meter, which had been built for the America's Cup defense that summer. He shouted to the Australians to get off. As Ben Lexcen, Apollo's designer and a member of the crew, recalled, Bond had never seen a 12-Meter before and was fascinated. But Bond, too, became furious.

title: CALNY INC .  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 13
Key Rates
description: Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Accounts
description: * The Kiplinger Washington Letter to Bradley, Dimmock & Hugerford Inc. for a 60th anniversary campaign.

title: Ex-Olympian Fined
description: Armin Hary, who won a gold medal for West Germany in the 100-meter dash at the 1960 Olympics, was fined 20,000 marks ($7,600) in Munich after an appeals court lifted his prison sentence for fraud. Hary was convicted in 1981 of misusing Roman Catholic Church funds for real-estate investment and was sentenced to two years in jail. The appeals court reduced his prison term to 18 months and gave him the alternative of paying the fine because so much time had elapsed since the crime was committed.

title: GENERAL MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: b-Reflects a net gain of $21.3 million from its asset redemption program.

title: 3 Flee to West Germany
description: Three East Germans escaped across border barriers to West Germany over the weekend, the West German police reported today. They said two men, aged 20 and 21, fled early Saturday and a 19-year-old man early Sunday.

title: Malta Official's Car Attacked
description: A Government spokesman said today that about 300 members of the opposition Nationalist Party attacked a car carrying Deputy Prime Minister Mifsud Bonnici on Sunday, beating on it with wooden bars. The spokesman said that Mr. Bonnici, who is in line to succeed Prime Minister Dom Mintoff as head of the Labor Party, was not harmed, but that the car was badly damaged.

title: BEATRICE FOODS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Results for 1983 are restated to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No. 52 regarding foreign currency translations.

title: Musical Views
description: Musicians from nearly every orchestra in the New York area have banded together to join Paul Newman, Zubin Mehta and Jessye Norman, the soprano, in a concert on Oct. 24 at Avery Fisher Hall for Musicians Against Nuclear War. At the same time, Performing Artists for Nuclear Disarmament are tuning up for a series of concerts at the Symphony Space, beginning Thursday.

title: New HMW Offer
description: Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, specialists in leveraged buyouts, announced that it had raised the terms of its offer for 1.6 million shares of HMW Industries to $44 a share, from $40.

title: An Honor Waits
description: New York University hopes to honor one of its former star athletes at its Varsity Club Hall of Fame awards dinner on Nov. 3. But the five- man selection committee is having trouble finding anyone to accept the plaque for one of only three Violet graduates to win an Olympic gold medal.

title: Gen. Harrison Thyng, Flying Ace in 2 Wars
description: A funeral will be held Wednesday for Brig. Gen. Harrison R. Thyng, a flying ace in two wars who later ran for a United States Senate seat. He died Saturday of a heart attack at the age of 65.

title: STRAINER FOR OIL RE-USE
description: IT has been said that frugality is a hallmark of a good cook.

title: PRESIDENT'S LETTER TO O'NEILL
description: Following is the text of a letter sent by President Reagan today to Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. on a War Powers Resolution being considered by Congress: Dear Mr. Speaker:

title: Key Rates
description: * Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 2 Sentenced in Cocaine Case
description: A former Congressional page and another man whose arrests last year led to investigation of drug use on Capitol Hill were sentenced Monday to prison for conspiring to distribute cocaine.

title: AIDS AND HEAT
description: This summer, the number of people to contract acquired immune deficiency syndrome rose to nearly 2,000, and mortality neared 50 percent. Appearing at the bedside of Peter Justice, a 40-year-old AIDS patient in New York City, Margaret M. Heckler, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, assured the press that she would urge Congress to approve $40 million for AIDS research in the next year - twice the original request. She had found the extra money in the back of her vast enterprise: $22 million originally committed to ''new furniture and construction'' for the Rural Development Fund. She vowed that research into AIDS would be the Government's ''top priority'' in next year's budget.

title: Market Place; Coca-Cola Without Wine
description: SEVERAL analysts have been recommending the purchase of Coca-Cola shares recently, but some do so with reservations. ''It's a current purchase recommendation,'' said Anton J. Brenner of Cyrus J. Lawrence Inc., ''but not what you would call a table-thumping purchase recommendation.''

title: House Panel Approves Medal Honoring Vietnam Veterans
description: A subcommittee of the House Banking Committee today approved what it called ''the first official Government recognition of Vietnam veterans,'' a bill to mint a national medal honoring all Americans who served in the Vietnam War.

title: Poland Suggests Walesa Has $1 Million in West
description: Polish television suggested today that Lech Walesa, the found of Solidarity, had $1 million in the West that he wanted to place in the Vatican bank with the help of Pope John Paul II. Mr. Walesa denied the charge.

title: AMERICAN FURNITURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
RESIDENTS BELIEVE NEWPORT WILL SURVIVE LOSS OF THE AMERICA'S CUP
description: Before the historic defeat of the yacht Liberty for the America's Cup Monday, someone hung a sign in the Marina Pub on Goat Island here reading, ''Give Me Liberty or Give Me Debt.''

title: Alice Tully Tells How Persistence Paid Off
description: ''I met Alice Tully recently,'' recalled Elliott Stein, a freelance film critic, at the New York Film Festival in Alice Tully Hall the other night. '' 'Oh, Miss Tully,' I said, 'I love your hall.'

title: KIS for Creamer
description: KIS Photo, which was down to Grey Advertising and Creamer in its search for a new agency, has picked Creamer, the smaller shop, to handle its account. It says it plans to spend $2 million for the remainder of the year and $10 million next year.

title: How the West Side Looks at the World
description: Politicians say that New York's

title: RESETTLEMENT PLANS SET BACK
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it had found unexpected leaking of chemicals at the Love Canal in Niagara Falls, N.Y., calling into question last year's Federal declaration that the area was safe to live in.

title: Inmates at Attica Restricted to Cells
description: Most of the 2,167 inmates in New York's State's maximum-security prison here remained locked in their cells today following a nonviolent protest at the prison last week, according to a prison spokesman.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption accompanying a photograph of the Avon Half Marathon in some editions of Sunday's sports section misidentified the runner shown behind the leader. She was Laurie Binder.

title: Beatrice to Sell John Sexton Unit
description: The Beatrice Foods Company said it had agreed to sell its John Sexton & Company foods operation to S. E. Rykoff & Company for cash. Beatrice Foods did not disclose the purchase price, but said it expected an after-tax gain of about $10 million from the sale.

title: USA Today Names Its Third President
description: Cathleen Black, the 39-year-old publisher of New York magazine, yesterday was named president of USA Today, the nationally circulated newspaper, its third president in little more than a year.

title: OXFORD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 2
A FINE FALL DAY BRINGS ANGUISH TO CITY DRIVERS
description: There were the 16 motorcades taking diplomats and heads of state to the Plaza, the Waldorf and the United Nations. There were clanking construction sites, each with its entourage of cement trucks and Dumpsters. There were double-parked trucks. There were roads closed or narrowed for repairs and construction.

title: FORBES'S LIST OF THE RICHEST
description: Gordon Peter Getty got there the classic way. He had wealthy parents. Sam M. Walton did it by selling things cheap. J.R. Simplot did it with potatoes, Robert Vesco fled with millions.

title: PHILS LOSE BUT GAIN EAST TIE
description: Ron Cey hit a two-run homer off Steve Carlton today in leading the Chicago Cubs to a 3-0 triumph over the Philadelphia Phillies. Nevertheless, the Phillies were assured of at least a tie in the National League East hours later when the Mets defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 4-3.

title: A YANK TO LEAD IRELAND IN DAVIS CUP
description: The Irish take their sports seriously. In terms of public interest, Gaelic football, rugby, hurling, track and field, golf and horse racing rate higher than tennis, and the reason may be explained best by a version of the chicken-and-egg riddle: Which comes first, the facilities or the players?

title: FOOD NOTES
description: A Bit Less Coffee

title: Buffalo's Notes Sell Out Quickly
description: A $35 million issue of Buffalo revenue anticipation notes due June 29, 1984, were quickly sold out yesterday at a yield of 5.75 percent through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The notes, which carried the highest rating of MIG-1 by Moody's Investors Service, will be repaid by state aid to education payments due to the city.

title: Winning Without Fighting
description: New Jersey officials have lost a

title: EASTERN APPEALS TO WORKERS
description: Eastern Airlines' chairman, Frank Borman, urged employees in a taped message yesterday to accept a 15 percent cut in wages by Nov. 1 and another 5 percent cut in labor costs on Jan. 1, and warned them that they could be voting for their jobs.

title: U.S. PANEL MEETS TO STUDY HUNGER
description: A Presidential commission studying the problem of hunger in America met today for the first time, and its chairman declared the nation had a moral obligation to solve the problem.

title: Islanders Win Exhibition
description: Gord Dineen, a rookie defenseman, scored with 39 seconds to play in overtime tonight to give the New York Islanders a 2-1 exhibition victory over the Boston Bruins at Nassau Coliseum. The Bruins had erased a 1-0 Islander lead in the third period when Tom Fergus scored at 10:24.

title: DIGITAL INTRODUCES A NEW COMPUTER
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, seeking to strengthen its position in the personal computer market, yesterday introduced a newer more powerful model of its Rainbow 100 system and a new customer service plan.

title: ; HOW HIGH TECH INCREASES JOB FLEXIBILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOLASTIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a tax benefit of $3,154,000. c-After a tax benefit of $318,000 and a nonrecurring gain of $1,463,000.

title: POLITICIZED SUNSET
description: To the Editor:

title: AAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
An Investment Banker Plans New Enterprise
description: James D. Wolfensohn, the 49-year-old private investment banker who shepherded the Chrysler Corporation through much of its troubles and left an executive partnership at Salomon Brothers two years ago to go into business for himself, has a new deal in the works.

title: BEIRUT FLAW: 4-NATION FORCE ISN'T UNITED
description: A week ago Monday, the Lebanese Army and two United States Navy vessels had their cannons loaded, aimed and ready to fire on a unit of Syrian-backed anti-Government militiamen converging on the embattled Lebanese town of Suk al Gharb.

title: American Brands Inc. Promotes 3 Executives
description: American Brands Inc., a company that is putting most of its eggs into the diversification basket, said yesterday that as part of this corporate strategy it was electing three key executives to new posts.

title: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
WAJDA'S 'DANTON,' INSIDE THE FRENCH REVOLUTION
description: COMPARED to the massive scale of the Russian Revolution, the French Revolution of 1789-95 seems almost to have been a chamber piece. Though armies supporting Louis XVI crossed France's border seeking to save the Bourbon monarchy, and though all of France eventually become involved in the bloodshed, the most decisive battles of the Revolution were fought in Paris, in the political clubs and on the streets.

title: WILFRED BURCHETT DIES IN BULGARIA
description: Wilfred Burchett, an Australian journalist who for decades functioned as a Western spokesman for Communist regimes in Asia and Europe, died yesterday in Sofia, Bulgaria. He was 72 years old.

title: FEDERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NEWPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Arrest Made in Slaying Of Hollywood Writer
description: A former aerospace worker who had received alcohol rehabilitation counseling from Muriel Davidson, a writer who published celebrity profiles and crime exposes in national magazines, was arrested today and charged with slaying Mrs. Davidson, who was also a television executive.

title: Sales of Funds At $2.7 Billion
description: Sales of mutual funds continued to exceed redemptions by a wide margin in August, according to data compiled by the Investment Company Institute.

title: WAUSAU PAPER MILLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: CHECKOUT SCANNERS LIKED IN SURVEY
description: More and more supermarkets in New York City have installed electronic scanners at their checkout counters. In its latest survey, the city's Department of Consumer Affairs asked 200 people how they feel about these scanners, among a number of other questions.

title: EX-E.P.A. AIDE SAYS BUDGET OFFICE PUT CASE FOR INDUSTRY
description: The former chief of staff of the Environmental Protection Agency charged today that the Office of Management and Budget improperly promoted industry's efforts to influence the agency's rulemaking.

title: Soccer Rebellion
description: When Lutheran East High School in Harper Woods, Mich., named its soccer team, the 17-year-old senior the coach had described as the school's ''resident soccer expert'' was not on the roster. That struck the player, Estere Wheeler, as unfair, so she went to court.

title: Nonkosher Food
description: A hotel in the Catskills here that advertises itself as being a kosher establishment was charged today with fraud for serving nonkosher foods.

title: Peruvian Demonstrator Killed in 24-Hour Strike
description: Riot policemen shot and killed a demonstrator and injured dozens of others today during a 24-hour strike called by labor leaders to protest economic policies.

title: SENATORS SEEK TO DELAY NEW PHONE ACCESS FEE
description: The Senate Commerce Committee today tentatively approved legislation delaying a plan by the Federal Communications Commission to impose a telephone ''access fee'' on the nation's residences and small businesses Jan. 1.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: JUST before Richard and Dee Mernit were married 37 years ago the bride-to-be suggested to her future husband that they both put on wedding rings during the ceremony. Mrs. Mernit says that not only was she happy to wear a wedding ring but that she wanted the biggest one available. Mr. Mernit's answer was an unequivocal no. His third finger, left hand, remained unencumbered.

title: U.S.-BAHAMIAN RELATIONS ARE STRAINING UNDER DRUG INVESTIGATIONS
description: Relations between the United States and the Bahamas are being strained by a growing controversy over the conduct of American law-enforcement agents in the Bahamas who are seeking to bring charges against Americans suspected of drug and tax violations.

title: Metro-North To Keep Bar Cars
description: Commuters may not enjoy riding crowded Metro-North trains, but they would like it even less if the bar cars were converted to make way for more seats, officials found when they tried to phase out the cars.

title: ALLEGHANY VALUES I.D.S. AT 827 MILLION
description: The Alleghany Corporation, which agreed on Monday to sell Investors Diversified Services to the American Express Company for $773 million, said yesterday that it would actually realize $827.5 million for its big mutual fund and insurance complex.

title: Economic Scene; The Infighting Over the I.M.F.
description: WASHINGTON PRESIDENT REAGAN'S speech yesterday to the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank went beyond conventional expressions of support to make an ''unbreakable commitment'' to increase funds available for the I.M.F.

title: In Pursuit of Reasonable Regulation of Tandems
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants' Defense Forced Packer Mistakes
description: Last Saturday, Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants was talking about the Monday night game at Giants Stadium against the Green Bay Packers.

title: NONDELIVERY FRAUD CHARGED
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged C & R Pastor Securities Inc., the New York subsidiary of a Spanish-based securities concern, with fraudulently failing to deliver more than $200 million of securities to six New York brokerage houses, leaving them with losses of at least $21 million.

title: NICARAGUAN SCORNS U.S. FOR 'POLICY OF TERROR'
description: The head of Nicaragua's governing junta denounced the United States here today for conducting what he described as a war against his people.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Under the Democrats, we never lost the America's Cup.'' - Bob Neuman, director of communications for the Democratic National Committee. (B6:1.)

title: P. Blair Lee Is Dead; Ex-Investment Banker
description: P. Blair Lee, retired president of the Western Savings Fund Society of Philadelphia and a former partner in the investment banking firm of Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, died Monday after a stroke. He was 87 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: STIFEL FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: Results for the latest year and quarter include operations of Bacon Whipple & Co., acquired in June 1982.

title: ICOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a loss of $2,799,000 from the sale of Micrographics business assets. c-Net income includes tax credits of $162,000 for the quarter and $447,000 for the year.

title: BRIEFS
description: American Can Co. announced that it had developed a new multi-layer plastic bottle, called Gamma, that offers extended shelf life to oxygen-sensitive foods, and that H. J. Heinz Co. had begun marketing its ketchup in a Gamma bottle in the Southeast and Texas.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Alcan Aluminium Ltd., Montreal, has named Eric P. West senior executive vice president, and appointed David Morton, Patrick J. J. Rich and Archie F. Black regional executive vice presidents.

title: 4 Hurt as Beaker Explodes at School
description: A beaker of chemicals blew apart in the chemistry lab of a Queens high school yesterday and slightly injured a teacher and three students, the authorities said.

title: SICILY'S SPIRITED COOKERY
description: TO spend two weeks in Sicily sampling its food is to capture the flavor of its history. Just as traces of the Mediterranean crossroad's many invaders can be perceived through its arts, crafts and architecture and in the music, dialect and physiognomy of its people, so its cooking reflects their influences. Occupied by Phoenicians, Greeks, Romans, Arabs, Normans, Swabians, Spaniards and Frenchmen, the island has evolved a cuisine that not only includes recipes taken intact from foreign kitchens but that also often combines the influences of several countries in a single dish.

title: Gromyko Praises Cease-Fire Reached in Lebanon Conflict
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko today welcomed the cease-fire in Lebanon and called for the immediate withdrawal of the Western multinational force and of Israeli troops from the country.

title: PANEL WOULD CURB DISABILTY CUTOFF
description: The House Ways and Means Committee today approved a bill that would make it more difficult for the Government to cut off benefits for people receiving Social Security disability insurance.

title: Fans Worried
description: Under the coaching of Steve Negoesco, the University of San Francico soccer teams have won four national collegiate championships - in 1966, 1975, 1976 and 1980. And the Dons have defeated Santa Clara 16 times with two ties and one loss since 1967.

title: ENTRY FEE EASED BY EAST GERMANY
description: East Germany waived obligatory foreign exchange controls today for children visiting the country.

title: Filipino Takes Flyweight Title
description: Frank Cedeno of the Philippines won the World Boxing Council flyweight title today by stopping Charlie Magri of Britain at 2 minutes 33 seconds of the sixth round.

title: SOUTHERN RIVER PROJECT STIRS ECONOMIC HOPES
description: Now that the last obstacles to the Tennessee-Tombigbee Waterway have been cleared away, local civic boosters, state officials and businessmen all along its course are rushing to position themselves for the cash and commerce they say will surely follow the tow barges down the long network of canals and locks.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: DIVERSE CHUTNEY: SWEET, SOUR, HOT, COOL
description: MENTION the word chutney to half the cooks in the country and the vision that is immediately flushed is of a bottle of Major Grey's leaping from the refrigerator like a lifeguard to the rescue of leftovers drowning in curried cream sauce. While that image is not necessarily a bad place to begin the consideration of chutney, it would be a grave mistake to let it stand as the end of the subject.

title: NAUMBURG WINNER NAMED
description: Stephen Hough won first place in the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation International Piano Competition yesterday. The award includes a $5,000 prize, two subsidized recitals in Alice Tully Hall, orchestral and recital appearances with the Philadelphia Orchestra and Chicago Symphony, among others, and a recording for the Musical Heritage Society label.

title: PUTNAM-GELLMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-Net loss

title: CORVUS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Keystone Talks
description: Keystone Consolidated Industries Inc. and the Amalgamated Sugar Company said they had ended ''by mutual agreement'' talks begun last January aimed at merging Keystone into Amalgamated.

title: SCOTT & FETZER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $252,000 for the quarter and $3,291,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $809,000 for the quarter and $2,462,000 for the 9 months.

title: PRISONERS OF ISRAEL ASK P.L.O. TO SPEED EXCHANGE
description: A committee representing the nearly 5,000 Palestinian and Lebanese prisoners held by Israel have asked the leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization to speed negotiations for a prisoner exchange.

title: COAL-SLURRY BILL LOSES IN HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives, by a surprisingly large 53-vote margin, defeated a bill today that would have cleared the way for construction of underground pipelines to transport coal.

title: OFFICIAL MAY BAR SOME WESTWAY FUNDS
description: The Federal Highway Administrator said yesterday that he was unwilling to commit a large part of the $37 million New York State wants to spend on the Westway over the next 15 months, because of uncertainty about whether the project will ever be built.

title: REAGAN AND CHINESE PREMIER PLAN VISITS
description: President Reagan will visit China next April following a visit by the Chinese Prime Minister, Zhao Ziyang, to the United States in January, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today.

title: 15,000 RALLY IN SAN SALVADOR IN SUPPORT OF LAND PROGRAM
description: About 15,000 farm workers and their supporters from the moderate Christian Democratic Party held a march and rally today in support of the country's land redistribution program.

title: ETHNIC REMARK BARRED IN MURDDER-BY-CAR TRIAL
description: The state today suffered a second setback in its efforts to prove that a driver hit and killed a Hispanic boy with a car here last March because of ethnic prejudice.

title: Cup Loss Placed In Perspective
description: On Monday night, after Australia II had defeated Liberty to take the America's Cup away from the United States for the first time in 132 years, the reactions at Grand Central Terminal from homeward-bound commuters varied greatly.

title: 2 More I.R.A. Fugitives Seized by Ulster Police
description: The police captured two more of the 38 Irish nationalists who escaped from the Maze Prison and said tonight that they believed most of the 19 still at large were in Northern Ireland.

title: Looking North
description: After three straight seasons of declining attendance, the Fort Lauderdale Strikers soccer team may leave Florida next season and relocate in a very different climate - that of Minneapolis.

title: Oil Insurance Is a Bargain
description: Would you reduce insurance on your home because it hasn't caught fire in years? That's what the Reagan Administration proposes for America's insurance against any sudden loss of foreign oil supplies. Congress should resist these false economies in the nation's strategic petroleum reserve.

title: Interest Rates Little Changed;  Fed's Stance Puzzles Some
description: Interest rates were mixed but little changed yesterday, with many traders and investors on the sidelines waiting for a clearer picture of how aggressively the Federal Reserve is willing to bring down short-term interest rates.

title: BBDO International Starts British Shop
description: BBDO International, which currently is represented in Britain by an agency in which it has only a minority position, is also establishing one of its own there, to be called BBDO International Ltd.

title: Canon Net Up 74.3% in Half
description: Canon Inc. said today that its profit in the first six months of the year rose 74.3 percent, to 13.02 billion yen - about $53.3 million - from 7.47 billion a year earlier.

title: UTAH JURY CONVICTS NEW YORK WOMAN IN DEATH OF FATHER
description: Frances Bernice Schreuder of New York was found guilty tonight of first-degree murder for having persuaded her son to murder her father in order to secure her inheritance.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A manhole explosion, apparently caused by a cable short circuit, forced the closing of 53d Street between Seventh Avenue and Broadway

title: Cornucopia of Edibles In the City's Parks
description: Berries, nuts, mushrooms and all sorts of edibles are growing wild in New York's parks. For the past few years, Steven Brill has been teaching people how to recognize them, how to gather them and use them for eating.

title: Gold and Silver Prices Continue to Move Down
