description: Prices of gold and silver futures weakened further yesterday as the spot September contracts expired on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The expired gold contract closed off $1.20 ounce, at $413.90. October, now the spot month, lost $1.60, to $413.90.

title: NEEDED IN CENTRAL AMERICA
description: President Reagan's approach in Central America brings to mind an image of a man long accustomed to driving nails who is given the opportunity to use a screw. Ignoring the more sophisticated option, he just keeps banging away and calling for a bigger hammer - and blaming Congress when his pounding doesn't work. Mr. Reagan's ''secret'' war against Nicaragua has accomplished nothing. It has not interdicted a single rifle. Certainly it has no chance of getting rid of the Sandinistas. On the contrary, by providing a external threat against which they can rally the Nicaraguan people, it may have helped them more than it has harmed them. Yet, the President is determined to go on with it.

title: COALITION URGED FOR HOMOSEXUALS
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson called on about 1,000 homosexual rights activists and their supporters last night to push beyond a ''self-centered, narcissitic movement'' and join with civil rights organizers to form a new national coalition.

title: BOAT RECOVERED IN BOSTON SEARCH FOR STUDENT, 25
description: A missing cabin cruiser that Massachusetts authorities say may be linked to the 1981 disappearance of a Harvard graduate student from New Jersey was hoisted by crane yesterday from 20 feet of water on the Boston waterfront.

title: THE PAINFUL SHIFT TO COSTLY OIL
description: Economic Analysis

title: ONE COACH, TWO TEAMS
description: He wore blue as naturally as he had worn green. Bob Ledbetter joined the Giants this year as their offensive backfield coach after six seasons of tutoring the Jets' runners. Suddenly last Saturday, on his 49th birthday, he was rushed to St. John's Hospital in Smithtown, L.I., not far from his Northport home. Bob Ledbetter had suffered what has now been diagnosed as a stroke.

title: REAGAN'S PUBLIC DIPLOMACY
description: President Reagan's speech at the United Nations Monday was a good example of what has been called the new public diplomacy.

title: Bass-Bayly Tie
description: Bayly Martin & Fay International Inc. said the Bass Brothers, a group of investors, had purchased an interest in the company for an undisclosed cash sum.

title: U.S. Aide Who Invited U.N. To Move Tried to Quit Earlier
description: The United States delegate who suggested that the Reagan Administration would not care if the United Nations left the country tried unsuccessfully to resign two weeks earlier, a White House spokesman said today.

title: Argentine Loan Talks
description: Argentina will meet with its commercial bank advisory group here Wednesday against a background of growing concern about a possible snag in an already signed rescheduling agreement, banking sources said today.

title: GROMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $5,880 for the quarter and $19,730 for the 9 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $577,599 for the quarter and $755,599 for the 9 months, and an extraordinary credit of $117,000 for the 9 months.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 28, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: PRINTERS PROCEEDING IN TALKS ON MERGER WITH THE TEAMSTERS
description: The International Typographical Union is proceeding with discussions of a possible merger with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, according to a message sent to local I.T.U. officers by Joe Bingel, the union's president.

title: EXCERPTS FROM BANKERS' REMARKS
description: Following are excerpts from speeches today by A.W. Clausen, president of the World Bank, and Jacques de Larosi ere, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, to the annual meeting of the World Bank and the fund: A.W. Clausen

title: GREAT WESTERN SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,372 for the quarter and $12,781 for the 6 months.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: THE POP LIFE
description: ARTHUR BAKER is having, as they say in Hollywood, his moment. Only two and a half years ago, the 28-year-old record producer, who is acknowledged as a major innovator in the evolution of syncopated ''hip-hop'' dance music, was sweeping floors at a record warehouse in Long Island City. Today Mr. Baker runs his own highly successful New York-based label, Streetwise, which releases one or two 12-inch dance records a month.

title: Borges Is Given Award
description: Jorge Luis Borges, the Argentine writer, has been awarded the T. S. Eliot Award for Creative Writing and Dr. James Burnham, the political and social philosopher who wrote ''The Managerial Revolution,'' has been awarded the Richard M. Weaver Award for Scholarly Letters.

title: LOW PRICES FOR GOOD WINE: WILL THEY LAST?
description: THE factors that affect retail wine prices in this country are sometimes as complicated as those that determine the quality of the product itself, and this year the equation is more arcane than ever. Industry observers generally agree that bargains for American consumers on both European and American wines are the best in at least a decade, especially among the so-called everyday drinking wines that sell in the $3 to $6 range. Opinions differ, however, about whether prices will decline further.

title: 4 WESTERN NATIONS CONFER ON BEIRUT
description: The United States and the three other Western countries with soldiers in Lebanon met yesterday for the first time since the cease-fire and agreed on the need to keep their troops there to support the Lebanese Government, an American spokesman said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MY LAST SIGH. By Luis Bunuel. Translated by Abagail Israel. Illustrated. 256 pages. Knopf. $15.95.

title: Argentina Issues Antiterrorist Decree
description: Argentina gave the military special antiterrorist powers today.

title: Bell Atlantic Pact
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said it had agreed to market NEC America Inc.'s newest PBX telephone switchboard. Bell Atlantic, the holding company that will own seven of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Bell System companies after A.T.& T. is broken apart next year, said the pact with NEC, a unit of the NEC Corporation of Japan, ''is another step in assembling a complete line of high-quality communications equipment to serve business and government customers in 1984.''

title: ACRO ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SUPERIOR MANUFACTURING & INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 28, 1983
description: International

title: Howe Won't Return
description: Steve Howe, the Los Angeles Dodgers' troubled relief pitcher, will not play again this season, the club said last night. The Dodgers said they were informed by Howe's doctor that he would undergo treatment and would not be available for about four weeks.

title: MACARTHUR FOUNDATION SAID TO PLAN $700 MILLION DIVESTITURE
description: The billion-dollar MacArthur Foundation in Chicago agreed yesterday to sell off part of its vast real estate holdings and all stock ownership of Bankers Life and Casualty Company, one of the country's largest health and accident insurance companies, a member of the foundation's board of directors disclosed last night.

title: SANTA FE, SOUTHERN PACIFIC JOIN
description: Santa Fe Industries and the Southern Pacific Company, diversified corporations that own major railroad lines in the Western half of the nation, yesterday announced an agreement to merge all their operations. The combination, which would create the nation's third-largest railroad, will take place through a swap of some $5.2 billion of stock.

title: NICARAGUA REBELS DO DAMAGE BUT ARE HALTED
description: In a series of coordinated attacks near the Honduran border, anti-Sandinista insurgents Monday killed at least six Government soldiers, damaged an important bridge and destroyed the Nicaraguan customs post at El Espino.

title: BIRD SAID TO GET A $15 MILLION PACT
description: Larry Bird, Boston's all-star forward, is apparently on the verge of signing a contract with the Celtics for more than $15 million.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some editions yesterday about the opening of the Metropolitan Opera gave an incorrect explanation for the fact that the performance of ''Les Troyens'' was not being recorded, and it attributed the explanation to an incorrect source. The reason was a breakdown in negotiations with the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, representing the Met chorus, according to Met and federation officials.

title: Drug Defendants Plead Guilty
description: Six defendants, including a man who had been accused of threatening the life of a Federal judge, pleaded guilty in two drug cases in Federal District Court here today.

title: SKIPPER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 4
description: The share earnings reflect the 50 percent stock dividend paid May 5, 1983.

title: LITTLE KIDS, BIG FINES
description: When, in the course of human events, a kid rolls through a stop sign on his bike, ''excessive bail shall not be required, nor excessive fines imposed, nor cruel and unusual punishment.''

title: Sherod on Waivers
description: Ed Sherod , a guard who played in 64 games for the Knicks last season, averaging 6.2 points and 4.9 assists, was placed on waivers yesterday. ''He's a fine kid but we had to make some cuts because we have such a wealth of talent now,'' said Dave DeBusschere, the Knick director of basketball operations.

title: STAGE: KINGSLEY IN 'EDMUND KEAN'
description: THERE'S no reason to fear that Hollywood's Oscar-night canonization has turned Ben Kingsley's head. In ''Edmund Kean,'' the one-man show Mr. Kingsley has brought to the Brooks Atkinson, this actor refuses to behave like a Star - even though his role, that of the legendary early 19th-century tragedian and scoundrel, gives him every license to do so.

title: On to Deployment
description: President Reagan's latest proposals for Euromissiles are significant primarily for what they reveal about NATO resolve. Having consulted directly with key allies, Mr. Reagan offered only modest new concessions and reaffirmed the decision to start deploying American missiles in Europe in December - if, as now appears likely, no agreement with Moscow is at hand. The allies seem confident they can ride out public protest against the first deployments, particularly in West Germany, and thus elicit a better Soviet offer next year.

title: ACTIVATION OF A CANCER GENE BY SINGLE MUTATION REPORTED
description: A cancer gene that has been activated by the presence of a single mutation has been found in tumor tissue from a lung cancer patient, but not in that person's normal tissues.

title: TRI BASIN RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $300,000. c-Net loss The company is also listed on the Vancouver Stock Exchange.

title: Accord Reached on Wranglers
description: Jim Joseph, owner of the Arizona Wranglers, said today that he had agreed in principle to sell the United States Football League club to Dr. Ted Deithrich. He said he would ask the league to approve the transaction, reported to be $7 million, on Wednesday.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: Tax Changes For Insurers
description: A House Ways and Means subcommittee today approved a new tax structure for the life insurance industry that is projected to raise as much as $1 billion in additional tax revenues next year.

title: STATEWIDE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CBS Shuffle In Publishing
description: Peter G. Diamandis must have greatly impressed CBS management in his year and a half running its Woman's Day, because now he has been made president of the whole CBS Consumer Publishing division with its 10 magazines. The 51-year-old Mr. Diamandis is a former publisher of Geo, Self and Mademoiselle, as well as ex-president of New York and New West magazines.

title: REAGAN PRAISES I.M.F. AND WARNS CONGRESS OVER DELAYS IN NEW AID
description: President Reagan, calling the International Monetary Fund the ''linchpin of the international financial system,'' urged Congress today to back a large increase in the resources of the lending institution to prevent an ''economic nightmare that could plague generations to come.''

title: British Oil Output Up
description: Britain's North Sea oil production averaged 2.3 million barrels a day in August, up 12.6 percent from a year before, according to the Royal Bank of Scotland's oil index, issued today.

title: CULP INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Blood Pressure Centers Opening for Business
description: Tom Dillon, 68-year-old retired chief executive of BBDO International, is now president of American Bloodpressure Centers, whose grand plan calls for a national chain of blood pressure detection and treatment facilities in shopping centers coast to coast.

title: AMERON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
METS PUT PIRATES ON EDGE ON ELIMINATION
description: The Mets, deep in last place with eight losses in their last 10 games, jolted the Pirates tonight, 4-3, and put Pittsburgh closer to elimination in the National League's Eastern race.

title: TEAM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Swiss Ending Aeroflot Ban
description: Switzerland announced today that it would end its aviation boycott of the Soviet Union, which was imposed Sept. 14 because of the downing of the South Korean plane. A spokesman for Swissair said it would resume its four flights a week to Moscow beginning Thursday. Aeroflot has five flights weekly to Switzerland.

title: UNDEFEATED BOXER CLOSE TO FREEDOM
description: There is another undefeated heavyweight prospect from Huntington, L.I., but Mike Garrahan has had his troubles outside of the ring. For the last four years, Garrahan's 7-0 record with seven knockouts has been on hold while he has served time for burglary.

title: Ecuador Debt Talks
description: Ecuador's President, Osvaldo Hurtado, will hold talks with creditor banks this week in New York on his country's foreign debt, the Foreign Ministry said today. Ecuador has reached an accord with its foreign creditors for the rescheduling of $2.7 billion of its external debt falling due in December.

title: MRS. BURFORD ASSERTS REAGAN FORCED HER OUT NEEDLESSLY
description: Anne McGill Burford, who resigned under fire as head of the Environmental Protection Agency last winter, says she believes that she and her colleagues at the agency were needlessly and wrongly forced from office.

title: FIRST REACTION TO WATT BETRAYS WIDER UGLINESS
description: To the Editor:

title: BLAIR,JONI, OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: MONOGRAM OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $491,057 for the quarter and $510,740 for the 9 months, and a gain of $518,623 for the quarter and 9 months from the sale of oil and gas interests. c-Net loss.

title: TEXT OF PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS TO WORLD FINANCIAL COMMUNITY
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's address today to the annual joint meeting of the board of governors of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund: Introduction

title: ALPHA MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
A MAJOR MERGER BY STEELMAKERS EXPECTED TODAY
description: The Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest steel producer, and the LTV Corporation, which owns the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation, the third-largest, will announce today that they plan to merge, a source close to the negotiations confirmed yesterday.

title: Knight-Ridder Adds New Unit
description: Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. announced yesterday that it had formed a new operating group to be called Business Information Services. David K. Ray, a vice president of Knight-Ridder, was named president of the group, which will be responsible for the company's commodity news services, Unicom News, The Journal of Commerce and VU/ Test, the company's newly formed information retrieval system.

title: GIVE AND TAKE
description: Larceny and Love

title: Killy Shifts Gears
description: For the first time since he retired from competitive skiing in 1973, Jean- Claude Killy of France will be racing again on Oct. 23. But the man who won three gold medals in Alpine events at Grenoble, France, in the Winter Olympics of 1968 will not be speeding on skis down a snowy hillside with the talent and dash that made him a superstar.

title: Confident Keough Beats Red Sox, 7-2
description: For a man who had an entirely forgettable season, Matt Keough seems to have kept his head, his sense of humor and his belief that there will be many good years in his pitching career.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: LEANER CONTINENTAL RESUMES FLIGHTS
description: Continental Air Lines resumed service from its Denver and Houston hubs this morning with a sharply reduced flight schedule and employees working reluctantly, for now at least, under the carrier's new low-wage, low-fare policies.

title: Stocks Slump; Trading Slows
description: Stock prices plummeted yesterday in slower trading after advancing sharply in recent sessions.

title: HOW DRUGS CAN CAUSE DECREASED SEXUALITY
description: AT the age of 45, Jim was scarcely ready to cash in his chips as a sexually active man. But as the instances of impotence increased, he began to wonder. At first he blamed his difficulty on the late hour and too many martinis, then on pressures at the office. He said nothing about the matter when he visited his doctor, who was checking the effectiveness of his blood pressure therapy, until the doctor happened to ask about his wife and family. Then Jim blurted out his concerns about the problem that had begun to consume much of his thoughts.

title: THE IMPROBABLE IN PEKING: A MAXIM'S
description: A visitor from Eastern Europe gazed about the paneled salon at the stained-glass windows and plush carpeting and the pink roses adorning the white tablecloths. Solicitous waiters in black tie and white aprons hovered to refill the slender Champagne glasses, while a small orchestra played an excerpt from Vivaldi's ''Four Seasons.''

title: Tests of Suspect Meat Find No Contamination
description: Initial Federal tests found no evidence of contamination in meat from packing plants in Colorado and Nebraska destined for the Federal school lunch program, an Agriculture Department spokesman said today.

title: Cape Cod Train to Run Again
description: By the summer of 1986, commuters and tourists will be able to take the train to Cape Cod and bypass heavy summer highway traffic, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis has announced.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: A $78 million bond issue of the State of Alaska was offered yesterday by a Merrill Lynch Capital Markets group with yields ranging from 5.5 percent for bonds due in 1984 to 7 percent in 1988 and 8 percent in 1993.

title: Nancy Reagan Ill With Cold
description: Nancy Reagan, suffering from a cold, has canceled most of her activities for the rest of the week, her press secretary, Sheila Tate. said today. Mrs. Tate also confirmed that the President and Mrs. Reagan would entertain Princess Margaret at a private dinner Saturday evening.

title: President Asserts Watt Will Decide His Future
description: President Reagan says that whether James G. Watt will remain as Secretary of the Interior is ''a decision that he himself will have to make.'' Mr. Watt's office has said he does not plan to quit.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1.*A Paisley Wrap

title: Steinbrenner Inquiry
description: Contradicting a published report, an official of the National Collegiate Athletic Association said it had not completed an inquiry into a charge that the Yankees' owner, George Steinbrenner, had given money, plane tickets and other illegal gifts to induce an Ohio high school football star to enroll at the University of Florida in 1976. The Tampa Tribune reported that Steinbrenner was cleared after an interview with an N.C.A.A. investigator last week. David Berst, the N.C.A.A.'s director of enforcement, said the inquiry would not be closed until investigators had interviewed Joe Portale , the former Florida running back who had told The Cleveland Plain Dealer that Steinbrenner had given him illegal gifts.

title: JESSYE NORMAN IN WAKE OF A TRIUMPH
description: Jessye Norman celebrated her great success at the Metropolitan Opera's opening night Monday with Chinese food and an hour and a half of sleep.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I am curious to know the origins of the phrase ''Dutch treat.'' Is it true that in the Netherlands each person pays his own share for a meal and other things?

title: S.E.C. Files Suit Against Fuel Unit
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said it had filed charges in Federal court against Gulf Resources Inc. of Las Vegas, Nev., a synthetic fuel company, and five individuals, charging them with fraud in a scheme involving misappropriation of up to $3.5 million from the sale of Gulf Resources Inc. stock. The company, which is not associated with either the Gulf Oil Corporation or the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation, sold stock and limited partnerships and promised to market a device which converted low-grade coal and garbage into synthetic fuel, the S.E.C. said.

title: Asks Court To Halt Girl's Therapy
description: Lawyers for a fundamentalist preacher asked the Tennessee Supreme Court today to stop the cancer treatments his daughter is receiving under a court order because, they argued, the treatments violate the family's religious beliefs.

title: WANTED: GOVERNORS FOR SENATE RACES
description: President Reagan asked Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee to run for the Senate. So did Howard H. Baker Jr., the majority leader whose seat was at stake because of his impending retirement. Senator Richard G. Lugar, chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, brought Governor Alexander polls indicating he could easily defeat his likely opponent.

title: OPERA: JOAN SUTHERLAND, 'LA FILLE DU REGIMENT'
description: THE Metropolitan Opera, as you may have heard, is celebrating a big birthday this season. And last night it had something to celebrate about: the return, after an 11-year absence, of its flamboyantly comical ''La Fille du Regiment,'' with Joan Sutherland as the tomboyish vivandi ere who is beloved of an entire regiment. Miss Sutherland, to get right to the point, put on a remarkable vocal show, giving no evidence whatever of any decline in her powers. Although reference books insist that she is a few weeks short of 57, the ear refuses to believe it. She is a genuine phenomenon, a bit of operatic history walking among us. She also can be, as she again proved in this revival of one of her favorite roles, an extremely funny lady.

title: HOUSE VOTES TO EXTEND EXPORTING ACT
description: The House of Representatives today approved a two-week extension of the Export Administration Act, which expires Sept. 30, as the Reagan Administration continued an internal debate over its position on renewal of the law.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: FEW foods mix better than seafoods; combining them seems like the most natural thing in the world. A favorite formula for this is to top fish with a shellfish, especially shrimp.

title: TAXI DRIVERS' COURSE IS PLANNED ON SAFETY AND CITY GEOGRAPHY
description: A 20-hour course on safe driving, courtesy to passengers and the geography of New York City would be required for all new taxicab drivers beginning next year under rules proposed by the city yesterday.

description: The Most Cheering News

title: THRIFT UNIT PLEA BY U.S.
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board has asked a Federal judge to dissolve his Sept. 9 decision to return the New Biscayne Federal Savings and Loan Association to its stockholders.

title: PLAN FOR AUTO TRACK IN FLORIDA IS TERMED MENACE TO PANTHERS
description: A proposal to build a Ford automobile test track in southwest Florida is being opposed by environmentalists, who say it would further narrow the range of the endangered Florida panther.

title: No Appeal on Nattress
description: The Montreal Canadiens will not appeal the National Hockey League's one-year suspension of the defenseman Ric Nattress for a minor drug conviction. Serge Savard, the club's managing director, said that the chances of winning an appeal were ''one in a million.'' Nattress, 21 years old, was arrested in August 1982.

title: No Headline
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company headquarters on Madison Avenue has been so widely photographed, pondered, discussed, debated and written about in the five years since its design was first made public that its actual completion threatened to be something of an anticlimax. But now that the $200 million building, designed by Philip Johnson and John Burgee, is virtually done, the opposite seems to be true - public interest in this curious skyscraper with its ''Chippendale'' split- pediment top and Renaissance-inspired base seems only to have grown as it has moved from paper to reality.

title: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 28, 1983
description: International

title: JAVITS, FRAIL BUT ELOQUENT, DEFENDS WAR POWERS ACT
description: Former Senator Jacob K. Javits returned today to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing room to defend the War Powers Resolution, which he drafted 10 years ago as a member of the committee.

title: HAYES-ALBION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
TV: 'DEMPSEY,' TALE OF FIGHT YEARS
description: THIS month's fight picture is ''Dempsey.'' Beginning at 8 tonight, it is being given three hours on CBS when two would have done nicely.

title: GERMANS AGHAST AS G.I.'S SIMULATE MASS BURIALS
description: For more than a year the Reagan Administration's international public relations specialists have been trying to persuade West Germans that Washington considers a limited nuclear war unthinkable.

title: Advertising; ABC's Olympics Pitch
description: NOW that the ABC Television Network has moved most of its $600 million inventory of commercial time on the 1984 Winter and Summer Olympics, it is time for a concerted effort by ABC-TV Spot Sales to sell almost $20 million worth of time for the Games on the five local stations that the network owns.

title: IRAN ISSUES WARNING ON SHIPPING
description: Iran said today that it would restrict shipping in the Persian Gulf if Arab states in the area continued to allow their ports to be used by ships delivering weapons for Iraq.

description: LIFE-STYLES

title: Group Buys Stock In 21st Century
description: The 21st Century Distribution Corporation, which owns and distributes full-length motion pictures, announced that an investment group had agreed to buy one million common shares from Tom Ward, president of 21st Century.

title: REAGAN PROMISES HE WILL CONSULT ON MARINES' ROLE
description: President Reagan promised today that he would ''seek Congressional authorization'' for any ''substantial expansion'' in the size or mission of the Marine contingent in Lebanon.

Dining in Italy
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: The vast turnout for the Metropolitan Museum of Art's current show prompts Moe Polenberg to ask: ''Would you say it's like Manet in the bank for the museum?''

title: Tino Rossi, 76, Singer; Recorded 2,000 Songs
description: Tino Rossi, a French singing star who sold some 200 million records in a 50-year career, died of cancer today at his home in the suburb of Neuilly. He was 76 years old.

title: REPUBLIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $572,000 for the quarter and $853,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $958,000 for the quarter and $1,809,000 for the year.

title: Florida Bonds Offered
description: A $110 million issue of double-A-rated Florida State Board of Education bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 6 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 8.2 percent in 1993, 9.25 percent in 2003 and 9.5 percent in 2013 through underwriters led by the Chase Manhattan Bank. By late afternoon, underwriters said all but $48 million of the issue was sold.

title: PROPOSAL: BAR SOME FEDERAL JUSTICE AID TO LOCALITIES THAT BAR GUNS
description: To the Editor:

title: Winslow's Lament
description: When Kellen Winslow, the San Diego Chargers' all-pro tight end, was called for interference in catching a 19-yard pass late in Sunday's game against the Cleveland Browns, the call infuriated Winslow and Coach Don Coryell, who called it ''the knockout punch'' in what became a 30-24 overtime loss.

title: Reagan's Conference With Reporters Is Off
description: President Reagan will not hold a news conference this week, a White House spokesman said today.

title: BUSINESS TRAVELERS' HOTELS THRIVING AT WHITE PLAINS
description: A prediction that 2,500 hotel rooms would be needed in the next few years to accommodate visitors would seem overly optimistic for most suburban cities. But White Plains, which has evolved in the last decade from a somewhat seedy county seat into a major office and retail center, figures it may need that many rooms.

title: 3 Die in Ambush in Venezuela
description: Guerrillas ambushed policemen transporting three captive Colombian guerrillas Monday, killing a detective and two guerrillas, an army commander said today. He said the attack occurred in a border zone where the Colombian National Liberation Army attacked a Venezuelan outpost recently.

title: Atari Parts Are Dumped
description: With the video game business gone sour, some manufacturers have been dumping their excess game cartridges on the market at depressed prices.

title: A LIFETIME HABIT OF DONATING HIS BLOOD
description: Leo Polk lay back in the sort of chair usually seen in dentists' offices, bared his arm and gave a pint of blood for the 320th time, a total of 40 gallons of donated whole blood, according to his records.

title: VALLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Electronic Mail Offered by MCI
description: The MCI Communications Corporation, as expected, introduced an electronic mail service yesterday that will put it into competition with the Postal Service, other data communications companies and the overnight couriers like Federal Express.

title: JETS ARE MOVING, KOCH EXPECTED TO SAY TODAY
description: The New York Jets will leave New York at the end of the current football season, sources close to the negotiations to extend the team's contract with the city said early this morning.

title: Cooking School Guide
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Bridge: Americans Defeat Pakistan, Adding to Lead in Standings
description: The crucial world championship clash this morning between U.S.A. II and Pakistan proved to be a decisive victory for the Americans.

title: CITY FINDS NO CHILDREN MALNOURISHED AT HOTELS
description: Disputing the findings of a state report, Mayor Koch and his Health Commissioner said yesterday that not a single child living in welfare hotels in New York City was suffering from malnutrition.

title: China Trade Rules Near
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today that a new policy on China trade was nearly complete and could sharply increase technology exports to China.

title: HOW HIGH TECH INCREASES JOB FLEXIBILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: GET THE PUNISHMENT TO FIT COMPUTER CRIME
description: To the Editor:

title: TRUCE IN LEBANON GENERALLY HOLDS
description: The Lebanese Army exchanged fire today with gunmen in Beirut's southeastern suburbs, and an Italian soldier was wounded by a stray bullet.

title: FORDHAM SAYS 2 STUDENTS VANDALIZED A SCULPTURE
description: Two Fordham students face a university hearing on charges they were responsible for the vandalism last weekend of one of several pieces of sculpture in an outdoor show at the Rose Hill campus in the Bronx.

title: GROMYKO ACCUSES WEST OF BLOCKING A PACT ON MISSILES
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko said today that the ''lopsided proposals'' on medium- range nuclear weapons put forward by the United States and its partners in the Western alliance can only mean that they wish to block agreement on the issue with the Soviet Union.

title: Pacific Air Corridor TRS
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that flights will resume Sunday on the North Pacific air corridor to which the South Korean Boeing 747 airliner had been assigned when it strayed into Soviet airspace and was shot down Sept. 1.

title: NO NEWS LIKE NO NEWS
description: During a single day in the 1680's William Penn, famous for giving us Pennsylvania, attended two public executions in London: a beheading at the Tower and a nasty business with rope and knives at Tyburn two miles away. Macaulay, writing ''The History of England,'' concluded from this and Penn's other eyewitness accounts of capital punishments that pacific Quakerism could not blunt his taste for the theater of scaffold and headsman's ax.

title: Dolphins Eye Move
description: The Miami Dolphins managing general partner, Joe Robbie, hopes to announce plans next month for a new, privately financed stadium featuring luxury boxes and adaptable for baseball, according to The Miami Herald.

title: PARADE OF 1,300 ARTISTS IS 'LOVE LETTER' TO CITY
description: Led for awhile by Mayor Koch and trailed by six street-sweeping machines twirling in a ''ballet,'' some 1,300 artists from all five boroughs marched with banners and floats down Madison Avenue from 104th Street to 72d Street last night in what was described as a ''living love letter to the city.''

title: 18 of 24 Ministers in Kenya Win Re-election to Assembly
description: Voters have returned Foreign Minister Robert Ouko and 17 other Cabinet members to Parliament, but six ministers lost their posts, according to official returns today.

title: AMERICA'S CUP IS PASSED TO AUSTRALIANS
description: The silver America's Cup stood glistening alone on a table centered on the terrace of the Marble House mansion at noon today.

title: INDIAN SATELLITE GETS FINAL TEST
description: The balky Indian satellite that refused to unfold its energy-collecting solar panel has been fixed and is undergoing final tests before being put in service next month as India's first commercial space system, Indian scientists said yesterday.

title: 'The Better Boat'
description: Congratulations to the Australians who will go back to their homeland with the fastest 12-meter yacht ever built and the trophy named for the yacht America that first captured it. Loss of the America's Cup is painful for Americans, who had successfully defended it for 132 years, but the Australians' victory was clear.

title: Surplus or No, Postal Chief Sees Rise in '84 Mail Costs
description: Postmaster General William F. Bolger said today that he would ask Postal Service governors next month to approve a postage increase to take effect in a year.

title: PIONEER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-Net loss.

title: U.S. SAID TO BE CLOSER TO 'BLACK BOX'
description: United States search ships were reported by Japanese news agencies tonight to have determined the location of flight recorders from the South Korean airliner shot down by Soviet fighters in the Sea of Japan.

title: HITTING HOME RUNS WITH MERV GRIFFIN PITCHING
description: One after the other, the easy questions were pitched across President Reagan's home plate, bigger than softballs, and Mr. Reagan batted them out of the park like the Sultan of Swat.

title: BOSTON BOOKSHOP'S BIRTHDAY: POETRY AND DANCING IN STREET
description: IT was an unusual birthday party. But then it was for a very special celebrant - the Grolier Book Shop, which has been an institution here in Cambridge for more than half a century.

title: EASTGROUP PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,666,000 from the sale of real estate investments. c-Includes a gain of $1,505,000 from the sale of real estate investments.

title: CHINESE OFFICIALS COOL TO IDEA OF MILITARY EXCHANGES WITH U.S.
description: Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China today brushed off the idea of exchanging military training missions with the United States, something that was a main objective of Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger's visit here.

title: A FAIRY TALE BY GRIMM COMES TO LIGHT
description: After more than 150 years, Hansel and Gretel, Snow White, Rumpelstiltskin and Cinderella will be joined by another Grimm fairy-tale character.

title: CONDE NAST BUYING GOURMET MAGAZINE
description: Conde Nast Publications, publisher of Vogue, Vanity Fair and other magazines, is acquiring Gourmet magazine, a leading food magazine, for an undisclosed price, the publishing company announced yesterday.

title: Only 6 Claims Filed For Free Alaska Land
description: Only six people filed claims on the first day of a program in which 10,250 acres of Federal land is being given away, the Bureau of Land Management said today.

title: MORRISON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid in September.

title: Careers; Middle Managers In Demand
description: THE end of the third quarter is a time for job prospect surveys, especially from the management recruiters, those firms that work for companies looking for new middle-management people, professional talent and top management executives.

title: MX FUNDS BACKED BY A HOUSE PANEL
description: The Defense Subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee has tentatively approved funds for the next fiscal year for several of the Defense Department's most controversial weapon programs. They include the MX intercontinental missile, the Pershing 2 intermediate missile and the B-1 bomber.

title: Plea to Shut Down Reactor Is Denied
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has turned down a request to shut down the James A. FitzPatrick reactor in Scriba, N.Y.

title: WOMEN'S HEALTH AND REPRODUCTION
description: THE subject was new developments in reproductive medicine, and according to participants in a symposium on women's health at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, there is much to applaud in the medical advancements.

title: 14 DIE AS NICARAGUAN BOAT SINKS
description: A wooden passenger vessel reportedly carrying 127 people caught fire and sank today in the country's largest lake. The Government said 14 people were dead and 28 missing.

title: TEXT OF KOCH'S LETTER
description: Following is the text of a letter sent by Mayor Koch yesterday to Leon Hess, the principal owner of the New York Jets.

description: Following is the text of a statement issued today by the State Department in response to a statement by Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader:

title: HOUSE VOTES STOPGAP BILL AS FISCAL YEAR NEARS END
description: The House of Representatives tonight speedily adopted a stopgap spending measure needed to keep the Government operating in the new fiscal year, which begins Saturday. The vote was 261 to 160.

title: POPE, EVANS & ROBBINS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Addenda
description: * Southern Living magazine is increasing its circulation rate base 2.4 percent, to 2.1 million, from 2.05 million, and its advertising rates about 7.5 percent, effective with the January issue.

title: BODY FOUND IN MAY IDENTIFIED AS MISSING GALLERY DIRECTOR
description: A body pulled from the East River in May has been identified as that of Gordon B. Washburn, the retired director of the Asia House Gallery who disappeared from his Manhattan home in March, the New York City Medical Examiner said last night.

title: NUCLEAR AGENCY REMOVES INVESTIGATIVE CHIEF
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that it had removed the director of its Office of Inspector and Auditor, but the agency did not say why.

title: EX-TENNESSEE GOVERNOR'S CONVICTION UPHELD
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit today upheld the convictions of former Gov. Ray Blanton of Tennessee and two aides for selling state liquor licenses in a kickback scheme.

title: MONDALE STRESSES HIS DIFFERENCES WITH GLENN AT ROCHESTER FORUM
description: Walter F. Mondale said here today that he and his principal competitor for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Senator John Glenn, differed on several areas of national defense.

title: APPRAISING SYMPTOMS AND CAUSES IN VALUATION OF THE DOLLAR
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERMETRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Allied Bancshares Sets 12.153% Yield
description: A $75 million issue of Allied Bancshares Inc. 12 percent notes due in 1993 was offered at a price of 99 1/8 to yield 12.153 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. At the time of pricing, the notes, rated Aa-3/AA, yielded 64 basis points more than 10-year Treasury notes.

title: FIVE ON YONKERS HIGH SCHOOL STAFF ARE SUSPENDED IN FOOTBALL DEATH
description: The Superintendent of Schools announced tonight that five members of the Yonkers High School staff had been suspended in connection with the death of a 17-year-old football player last Saturday.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: MANY people who became do-it-yourselfers out of necessity find that they enjoy tackling more ambitious projects. A number of books that have recently been published offer guidance on such undertakings. Here is a sampling. 201 Woodworking Projects for Indoors and Outdoors by Deco Plans (Van Nostrand Reinhold, $15.95 in soft-cover).This 358-page large-format book offers plans for a variety of woodworking projects that can be completed in the home workshop. All the plans are complete, neatly detailed and easy to follow, but the text is minimal in each case. A straightforward, no-nonsense book, it is really not for those without previous woodworking experience.

title: U.S. ASKS APPEALS COURT TO BAR FILES FOR DELOREAN
description: Five days before John Z. DeLorean was scheduled to be tried on charges of trafficking in cocaine, Government lawyers asked an appeals court today to deny him access to documents from 51 Government agencies that a lower court had granted. They said such access could delay the trial from ''two to five months.''

title: Blood-Data Study Is Questioned
description: A special prosecutor is seeking to determine who prepared an apparently bogus blood-analysis report in a Brooklyn manslaughter case, criminal-justice and medical authorities said yesterday.

title: X-Rays Show Pilfered Ring
description: A woman was charged with grand larceny after X-rays showed she had swallowed a stolen diamond ring, the police said today. The charges were brought against Pamela Perkins, 29 years old, of Norfolk.

title: ANACOMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income which includes an extraordinary credit of $1,830,000.

title: GOVERNORS URGE RELIEF FOR FARMS
description: Prodded by a pair of influential Democrats, the Southern Governors Conference today adopted a resolution calling for vastly expanded Federal relief for agricultural states reeling from the worst drought in decades.

title: WEATHERFORD, R V, CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings are restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split on Sept. 1.

title: Record Pact for Bird
description: Larry Bird and the Boston Celtics made it official yesterday. They announced that the all-star forward had signed a seven-year contract that is expected to bring him more than $2 million a year.

title: Marriott's Net Rises by 22.7%
description: The Marriott Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in its third fiscal quarter ended Sept. 9 rose 22.7 percent, to $36.7 million, or $1.32 a share, from $29.9 million, or $1.10 a share, in the period a year earlier.

title: CITY HAS LOST JETS TO JERSEY, KOCH DECLARES
description: The New York Jets have rejected the city's offer for a new lease at Shea Stadium and, beginning next year, will play their home games at Giants Stadium in New Jersey, Mayor Koch announced yesterday.

title: THE JUSTICE IN MERIT SELECTION FOR THE STATE BENCH
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: American Lead Diminished After Loss to New Zealand
description: The substantial American lead in the world team championship here shrank a little this afternoon when U.S.A. II lost to New Zealand, 13-17. This was the first American defeat in seven rounds of preliminary play, and the team still seems certain to qualify for the semifinals next week.

title: DANCE: PREMIERES BY THE BAT-DOR
description: TWO local premieres were on the fourth bill presented by the Bat-Dor Dance Company of Israel Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: 21 Portuguese Released By Angolan Insurgents
description: Twenty-one Portuguese released by rebels in Angola after months of captivity were flown to Johannesburg today aboard a Red Cross flight.

title: Man Freed on Bail In Anesthesia Case
description: A man accused of posing as a licensed physician at Fort Dix and administering anesthesia to a patient now considered brain dead has been released after posting $7,500 bail.

title: STATE DEPT. ASSERTS ANDROPOV RESPONSE DISMAYS THE WORLD
description: The State Department said yesterday that ''the world will be deeply disappointed'' with the statement issued in the name of Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader.

title: Bache Official Gets U.S. Energy Post
description: Raymond J. O'Connor, the 51-year-old executive vice president and director of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., was nominated yesterday by President Reagan to be chairman of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission.

title: CARROLS DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The latest quarter included 14 weeks of operations compared to 13 weeks in the year-ago quarter and also included the operations of Jo- Ann's Nut House for the first time.

title: KODAK UPGRADING DISK FILM
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, seeking to increase sales of the disk cameras that it introduced in May 1982, said yesterday that it would offer an improved film for the cameras next month. The quality of the current film has been criticized by photographers.

title: Appalachian Issue
description: The Appalachian Power Company's $50 million of 12 7/8 percent bonds due in 2013 are offered at a price of 100, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The bonds are rated Baa-1/BBB.

title: Candidate's Son Is Slain In Pakistani Elections
description: A man was stabbed to death and the police used tear gas against about 100 women occupying a polling station in Pakistan's Punjab Province today during local council elections.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: SHOWCASES OF DESIGN
description: Woodlands, Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I., 516-496-4440. On Monday, Woodlands, the former estate of Ailsa Mellon Bruce, will open as a designers' show house, with self-guided tours of the 28 redesigned rooms in the 35-room mansion.

title: How to Help Yeshiva U.
description: At Pennsylvania Station yesterday,

title: Edwin R. Wolfe Is Dead at 90; Active in Radio, Stage and TV
description: Edwin R. Wolfe, an actor, director and producer whose career spanned more than 50 years, died of heart disease last Thursday at his home in Holmes, N.Y. He was 90 years old.

title: NEW YORKERS: CUOMO IS SEEN AS A FRESH FACE . . .
description: Governor Cuomo of New York was settled comfortably recently in the library of the Washington home of one his predecessors, W. Averell Harriman, dispensing advice to a gathering of Democratic Party patrons on how to defeat Ronald Reagan next year.

title: HOUSE BILL WOULD LIMIT TELEPHONE ACCESS FEES
description: A House subcommittee approved legislation today that would spare residential telephone customers a long-distance ''access fee'' scheduled to start Jan. 1 but would let the new charge take effect for business customers.

title: THE JUSTICE IN MERIT SELECTION FOR THE STATE BENCH
description: To the Editor:

title: SEARCH NARROWED FOR WRECKAGE OF JET
description: Windy weather reportedly hampered the effort yesterday by United States Navy search ships to find the two flight recorders from the South Korean airliner that was shot down by a Soviet fighter on Sept. 1 in the Sea of Japan.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Sept. 10 on the Center for Investigative Reporting misidentified the center's former executive director and a founder of the center.

title: PRESIDIO OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A CRAFTSMAN'S CARVED MENAGERIE
description: IT looks like a furniture bestiary: lizards inhabiting a forest of leaves on the front of a chest; drawer fronts of triangulated fish with tiny knobs for eyes; a wriggle of snakes climbing up toward a clear- glass tabletop; leopards meeting nose to nose and insinuating their cat grace the length of a sofa.

title: N.B.A. WILL BAN DRUG USERS
description: The National Basketball Association and its players' union have forged a wide-ranging, innovative program that will ban from the league any player who is convicted of using or selling illegal drugs.

title: CO-PAYING HEALTH CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NIXON URGES A BIG LATIN AID PLAN
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon called today for a bold economic recovery program in Latin America and said such a plan could serve as a model for Western relations with the entire third world.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Debt Issues listing of Business Day on Tuesday misidentified the lead underwriter for a Eurobond financing by Comsat International N.V. It is Credit Suisse First Boston.

title: Finnish visitor Takes A Fresh Look at City
description: Manhattan shimmered in the sunlight yesterday as Tellervo Koivisto, wife of Mauno Koivisto, the president of Finland, and a group of Finnish diplomats took a cruise partway around Manhattan.

title: Birds of a Feather Join Together
description: ''I H NEW YAUK,'' their buttons read, displaying a penguin-like bird. One thousand ornithologists have flocked to the American Museum of Natural History this week where, 100 years ago today, the American Ornithologists' Union was founded by 23 bird lovers.

title: FURNITURE AND FASHION: CROSSOVERS BETWEEN TWO METIERS
description: IT is generally accepted that Italian designers and architects are the couturiers in the field of furniture design. For the past 20 years, they have been the innovators, trend setters and experimentalists. And while their modern designs have grown to be widely accepted in Europe, most of the avant-garde furniture by Italian designers and manufacturers is, save by the cognoscenti, virtually unknown in the United States.

title: Sampson Inspires Retiring Hayes
description: Elvin Hayes is looking forward with pleasant anticipation to his 16th and final season in the National Basketball Association. It would not take much to improve on the 14 victories that his Houston Rockets achieved in 82 games last season, but Hayes believes the Rockets are now a potential playoff team.

title: A COMEDY BY RESNAIS
description: ALAIN RESNAIS'S new film ''Life Is a Bed of Roses'' is nothing if not elliptical. So it was fortunate that Mr. Resnais appeared after its New York Film Festival press screening to discuss what his intentions had been. ''I never had the idea that the audience should go out of the theater scratching its head and asking questions about the meaning of the film,'' Mr. Resnais said. He also said: ''The important thing for us is that we wanted to make a comedy.''

title: GOLD FEVER RETURNS TO CALIFORNIA HILLS
description: Dennis Morgan and Dennis Hancock have gold fever, got it bad. Their eyes glow and their voices rise with excitement as they describe the new gold rush.

title: BIOSTIM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $43,500 for the quarter and $104,500 for the year. c-Net loss.

title: BANKRUPTCY AND THE UNIONS
description: The Federal Bankruptcy Act, once the last resort of companies on their deathbeds, is increasingly being used by ailing concerns in less immediate peril to escape labor contracts and other obligations that threaten their long-term health.

title: Thrift Unit's Bid in Florida
description: The Freedom Savings and Loan Association, with headquarters in Tampa, Fla., said yesterday that it had offered to purchase Miami's City National Bank for $40 million. City National is said to be indirectly owned by Alberto Duque, a Colombian coffee dealer who filed for bankruptcy last May. Mr. Duque and four companies that he owns have debts of about $122.4 million.

title: DR. MURRAY J. SHEAR, CANCER RESEARCHER, DIES
description: Murray J. Shear, a retired biochemist and pharmacologist at the National Cancer Institute who was a pioneer in the development of cancer chemotherapy, died of Parkinson's disease Tuesday at Suburban Hospital, Bethesda, Md. He was 83 years old.

title: U.S. TRADE GAP WIDER
description: The United States merchandise trade deficit swelled to a record $7.19 billion in August as the economic expansion encouraged imports and the strong dollar restrained exports, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Baltimore Paper Cut Back
description: The Evening Sun will stop publishing a Saturday issue next March, the publisher announced Tuesday. Gerry Smolinski, public affairs manager for the A. S. Abell Company, said ''a single Saturday newspaper with morning distribution'' would be produced on Saturday using the news staffs of both The Sun and The Evening Sun.

title: NEW HEART DRUG SEEN AS PROMISING
description: An experimental drug dramatically improves the condition of people with severe congestive heart failure, and doctors say it could revolutionize heart care by replacing digitalis as the standard treatment for this illness.

title: South African Prison Guards Get Jail Terms for Assaults
description: Six South African prison guards were sentenced today to jail terms ranging from 12 months to eight years for assaults on prisoners, three of whom died.

title: MAN WHO WARNED OF HITLER'S DESIGNS ON JEWS IS NAMED
description: Two historians have said that the German industrialist who warned the Allies of Hitler's ''Final Solution,'' the plan to kill millions of Jews in World War II, was Eduard Reinhold Karl Schulte.

title: METS SET BACK PIRATES AGAIN
description: With all the assurance of a team that has won more games than it lost this season, the Pittsburgh Pirates reacted coolly today when they were eliminated from the race in the National League's East.

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in April 1983.

title: DEATH STIRS POLICE BURTALITY CHARGES
description: A 25-year-old Brooklyn man, who some black leaders say was beaten by the transit police two weeks ago after he was arrested for scrawling graffiti on a subway station wall, died yesterday at Bellevue Hospital. Black activists described his death as the latest example of ''racially motivated police violence.''

title: PLANTING TO OBSERVE PARK'S 125TH YEAR
description: In celebration of the 125th birthday of Central Park, the Central Park Conservancy and the Department of Parks and Recreation are asking for help from industry, school, community and volunteer groups in the planting of 125,000 flower bulbs throughout the park this fall.

title: LOGIMETRICS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary income of $73,900. c-Net loss after a tax benefit of $137,000.

title: PETRO-LEWIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $636,000. Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in August.

title: Market Place; Merrill Lynch's Difficult Week
description: THIS has been a trying week in the stock market for Merrill Lynch & Company, Wall Street's standard-bearer in the brokerage business. Recent weakness in Merrill's stock, furthermore, has spread to the shares of other publicly owned investment houses.

title: EXCERPTS FROM 3 SPEECHES TO GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Following are excerpts from speeches to the General Assembly today by President Francois Mitterrand of France, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. The United Nations translated Mr. Mitterrand's remarks from the French and Mr. Mubarak's from the Arabic. Mitterrand's Remarks

title: COLUMBIA IS GIVEN $3.5 MILLION FOR A GALLERY AND ARTS CENTER
description: Schermerhorn Hall at Columbia University will be converted into a fine-arts center - with the university's first formal art gallery - with the help of a $3.5 million gift from an alumnus, the university announced yesterday.

title: Heating Oil Tumbles As Volume Hits Record
description: The prices of heating oil futures dropped sharply yesterday on record volume at the New York Mercantile Exchange. Traders cited the continuing warm weather and negative technical factors.

title: APL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-A tax credit of $505,000 brought the company to a break-even level. c-Net loss. d-Includes a tax credit of $614,000.

title: THEATER: 'BIG MAGGIE,' FROM IRELAND
description: JOHN B. KEANE'S ''Big Maggie,'' a 1969 play newly arrived Off Broadway, has received more performances in Ireland than any work of Sean O'Casey's. That's a fact, but what's in a fact? Not much, when you consider that ''Abie's Irish Rose'' has undoubtedly been seen by more Americans than ''The Iceman Cometh.'' Facts aside, the truth about ''Big Maggie'' is that it's soap opera. Stripped of its Irish accents - a task partially accomplished by the cast at the Douglas Fairbanks Theater - this play would make an entertaining episode or two of ''All My Children.''

title: Oh, What Fun to Bait the U.N.
description: Americans are periodically reminded by their politicians that a bunch of foreigners are on the loose in New York. Daring to call themselves the United Nations, these strangers insult American hospitality by refusing to think like Americans. So Mayor Koch calls the U.N. a ''cesspool,'' and Idaho's Senator Steven Syms thunders, ''Taxpayers are sick and tired of playing host to our enemies and critics abroad.''

title: Required Reading; Genuine Nonalignment
description: It was President John F. Kennedy, a great friend of Algeria, who said that America's goal was to help ''make the world safe for diversity.'' We do not wish to make over the world in our image.

title: WITNESS IN CAR-DEATH TRIAL RETRACTS HIS KEY TESTIMONY
description: The front-seat passenger in a car that killed a Hispanic boy today retracted earlier statements that suggested the driver ran over the boy intentionally because of ethnic bias.

title: Stocks Slide as Trading Pace Slows
description: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in slower trading after dropping sharply on Tuesday. The biggest movers were responding to specific news developments.

title: PRESIDENT DECLARES WATT FUROR IS OVER, BUT DEBATE GOES ON
description: President Reagan said today that he considered the controversy over Interior Secretary James G. Watt to be closed and that he did not anticipate Mr. Watt's resigning from office.

title: Search Goes On
description: New Jersey is apparently not finished searching for new sports franchises.

title: THE COWBOY FROM THE BRONX
description: The first time Bobby DelVecchio, the Bronx cowboy, rode off into the sunrise, it was on a bus headed for North Washington, Pa.

title: Merger Talks At Harris Bank
description: The Harris Bank corporation, owner of Chicago's third-largest bank, said yesterday that merger talks with a group it identified only as a major international bank were continuing ''on an intensive basis.'' It said it would be ''inappropriate'' to give details until an agreement was reached.

title: LTX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
IN ISRAEL, 'SESAME STREET' PROMOTING READING AND SOCIAL TOLERANCE...
description: Since its inception in 1969, ''Sesame Street,'' the educational television show for children, has been seen in more than 40 countries in 10 languages.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: Court Is Told to Decide Merrick Debt to CBS
description: A Federal appeals court has ordered back to trial court a suit by CBS Television against the show business producer David Merrick over a miniseries, ''Blood and Money,'' that was never produced.

title: Blowing the Whistle
description: ''If you know of any corrupt practices

title: IN THE NAME OF THE LAW; Legal Drama
description: Act I. When Congress passed TEFRA, the 1982 tax act, it included a provision that people who take ''frivolous'' liberties with their tax returns can be fined $500. Act II.

title: That Linchpin Fund Needs a Hand
description: President Reagan calls the International Monetary Fund ''the linchpin'' of world finance. Addressing its annual meeting in Washington, he warned that failure to increase America's contributions risked ''an economic nightmare that could plague generations to come.'' Now perhaps the President will let his deeds catch up with his words.

title: ANIMATED ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 28, 1983
description: International

title: Benefit Proposed
description: If all of the necessary arrangements can be made in time, a series of all-star baseball games will be played in Japan in November as a benefit for children of people who were killed when a Korean Air Lines plane was shot down by the Soviet Union earlier this month.

title: ISLANDERS TIED, 3-3
description: Mel Bridgman's goal at 1:11 of the third period tonight gave the New Jersey Devils a 3-3 tie with the New York Islanders in an exhibition game at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: DINGELL CHARGES JUSTICE DEPT. MISREPRESENTED MRS. BURFORD'S VIEWS
description: The chairman of a House investigative subcommittee charged today that the Justice Department misrepresented the views of Anne McGill Burford, former head of the Environmental Protection Agency, when it told President Reagan she supported withholding information from Congress.

title: PHOTOGRAPHIC SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
Former Teamster Aide Is Convicted in Ohio
description: Allen Friedman, a former official of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters who is the uncle of the union's president, Jackie Presser, was convicted by a Federal jury today of embezzling $165,000 from Mr. Presser's home local.

title: Walkout Ends At Supermarkets
description: Striking meat cutters decided yesterday to end a three-day walkout after a meeting with representatives of metropolitan-area supermarkets and a Federal mediator, union officials said.

title: Advertising; Thomas's Muffin Campaign
description: HOW many of you insular New Yorkers realize that for almost a century, while you and your kind were enjoying the melted butter in the nooks and crannies, the rest of your country was doing without Thomas's English muffins.

title: VAUGHAN-JACKLIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income of $101,275 from discontinued operations and a loss of $1,042,379 on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $267,227 for the quarter and $301,946 for the Year.

title: KOCH BARS DOING CITY BUSINESS IN RESTRICTIVE CLUBS
description: Mayor Koch yesterday prohibited city officials from conducting municipal business or spending city money at private clubs with restrictive membership policies.

title: Insurance Venture
description: Two major British insurance brokers, Willis Faber P.L.C. and Johnson & Higgins, said they had formed a joint venture to develop reinsurance business in North America. Under the deal, Willis Faber will acquire a 49 percent stake in Johnson's New York subsidiary, Willcox Inc., a firm of reinsurance intermediaries. Terms were not disclosed.

title: STOCK HALT BY TURNER HINTS BID
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc., which has been negotiating with the Westinghouse Electric Corporation about a merger of the two companies' cable television 24-hour news services, suspended trading in its stock yesterday afternoon, pending an announcement today on the negotiations.

title: STATE PRISONS AROUND NATION SCRAMBLE FOR RELIEF AS OVERCROWDING MOUNTS
description: Bowing to relentless pressure, South Carolina, where prisons were operating at about 115 percent of their official capacity, released the first of 330 prisoners Sept. 16 before their sentences expired.

title: New Food Riots in Brazil
description: One man was killed in a gunfight among looters as Brazilians stormed a supermarket in the poor suburb of Rio Pequena, the authorities said today.

title: YALE IS A STAGE TO STUDENTS SEEKING CAREERS IN DRAMA
description: In movement class, their legs rose and swiveled in time to the teacher's snapping fingers. In speech class, they practiced saying s's and r's. In acting class, they picked a scene apart. Later they will learn how to put it back together.

title: F.B.I. ASKED TO STUDY LEAKS OF DATA
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige has asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation to investigate leaks of secret Government economic statistics, the department said today.

title: CITY SEEKS ANOTHER N.F.L. TEAM FOR SHEA STADIUM
description: Within 30 minutes of Mayor Koch's announcement yesterday that the Jets were moving to New Jersey after this season, city officials met with Commissioner Pete Rozelle to tell him they plan to put another National Football League team in Shea Stadium.

title: ...IN MEXICO, LATIN VALUES STRESSED
description: Since its inception in 1969, ''Sesame Street,'' the educational television show for children, has been seen in more than 40 countries in 10 languages.

title: ANDROPOV ATTACKS U.S. MISSILE PLAN AS UNACCEPTABLE
description: Yuri V. Andropov said today that President Reagan's new proposals for limiting medium- range nuclear weapons in Europe were unacceptable.

title: 2 San Francisco Papers Reach Labor Pacts
description: Negotiators for eight unions and bargainers for San Francisco's two major daily newspapers today reached an accord on a new contract that averted a strike.

title: A.& P. Profits Advance 40%
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company today reported that net income for the second quarter, ended Sept. 10, rose 40 percent, to $11.2 million, or 30 cents a share, from $8 million, or 21 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 9 percent, to $1.2 billion, from $1.1 billion.

title: DRUSE PREVENT REOPENING OF BEIRUT'S AIRPORT
description: The Druse militia threatened today to take military action if the Lebanese Government went ahead with a plan to reopen the Beirut International Airport. Hours later, the Government announced it would put off opening the airport.

title: TV: COMEDY OF DIVORCE
description: TAKING divorce and the concept of an extended family to surprisingly comic lengths, ''It's Not Easy,'' developed, written and produced by Patricia Nardo, makes its debut on ABC-TV at 9:30 this evening. Despite the sensitive but very real subject, it turns out to be one of the season's more promising situation comedies.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: THE THEATER: 'FRIENDS'
description: AS Samm-Art Williams amply demonstrated in ''Home,'' his strong suit as a playwright is his warm, ingratiating humor. After a dour sidestep with ''The 16th Round,'' he has now turned his attention to domestic family comedy with ''Friends,'' at the Billie Holiday Theater in Brooklyn. Although the new play has its engaging moments, it is a contrived farce with a most curious premise.

title: APOLLO GOING BACK TO FILMS
description: The New Apollo Theater, the former 42d Street movie house that was converted with much fanfare into a legitimate theater in 1978 with its entrance on West 43d Street, is going to show movies again.

title: Super Bowl Fix Hinted
description: When the Jets, 18 1/2-point underdogs, beat the Baltimore Colts, 16-7, in 1969 in the third Super Bowl, it was considered the biggest upset in the history of professional football. Now, more than 14 years later, Bubba Smith, a former Baltimore defensive lineman, is suggesting that the game may have been fixed to give the American Football League credibility in its merger with the National Football League.

title: Eloquent Praise
description: Like almost all of the 40 hopefuls who were trying out for the Pittsburgh Spirit, Wes Hawkins never really had a chance of making the Major Indoor Soccer League team. But when he was cut from the free- agent tryout camp yesterday, team officials were outspoken in their praise of the 25-year-old player's courage and toughness.

title: BUTLER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
HERS
description: IF the truth be told, most parents have a favorite stage of child development. I found my children adorable as infants and bright and funny in their childhood years. But when all is said and done, I confess I have loved my children best as adolescents.

title: Armco in Accords To Sell Off Assets
description: Armco Inc., the nation's sixth-ranked steelmaker in terms of shipments, said yesterday that it had begun a major restructuring program - including the sale of $316 million in assets - in a bid to return to profitability.

title: Xerox Unit Selling Extendable Notes
description: The Xerox Credit Corporation's $100 million of extendable notes with a final maturity in 1995 were offered with an initial coupon of 10 3/4 percent at a price of 99.735 to yield 10.90 percent, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Pershing 1 Missiles Tested
description: The Army announced the successful testing today of five Pershing 1 missiles in an annual test of equipment and military personnel, officials said. Pershing 1 missiles have been part of the NATO forces in West Germany since 1969. The Pershing 1's are to be replaced in West Germany by the controversial Pershing 2 missiles.

title: INFLIGHT SERVICES INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $157,000. c-Includes a tax credit of $419,000.

title: Jordanians Rebuilding 20 Tanks for Lebanon
description: The Jordanian Army is refurbishing 20 of its American-made M-48 Sherman tanks to give to the Lebanese Army, diplomatic sources said here today.

title: Grand Trunk Bid Endorsed by Iowa
description: The Iowa Transportation Commission endorsed a bid by a subsidiary of the Canadian National Railways to obtain 3,100 miles of Milwaukee Road track in the Middle West.

title: BRINK'S DEFENSE SEEKS TO SWITCH SITE OF NEW TRIAL
description: Citing adverse publicity generated by the recent trial of three defendants in the Brink's murder and robbery case in Goshen, N.Y., lawyers for Kathy Boudin and Samuel Brown asked a state appellate court in Brooklyn yesterday to move their upcoming trial out of Orange County.

title: HARLEM RESIDENTS HELP IN ARREST OF 4 AS DANCE THEATER VANDALS
description: With the help of information provided by members of the community, detectives yesterday arrested four men and charged then with the weekend burglary and vandalism of the building that houses the Dance Theater of Harlem.

title: FPA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BOWL AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: b-Includes a gain of $125,748, or 10 cents a share, from the termination of a lease.

title: THRIFTIMART INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 11
NEW DOUBT CAST ON REAGAN PLAN TO VISIT MANILA
description: The scheduling of a visit to China by President Reagan for April has raised new questions about whether Mr. Reagan should go ahead with his visit to the Philippines in November, a senior Administration official said today.

title: Horse Farm To Go Public
description: Spendthrift Farm, one of the world's leading breeders and trainers of thoroughbred race horses, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of 1.5 million shares.

title: JUDGE BLOCKS WATT FROM SELLING RIGHTS TO MINE U.S. COAL
description: A Federal district judge today blocked Interior Secretary James G. Watt from selling 140 million tons of Federal coal reserves in North Dakota for mining by private interests, saying the issue raised a constitutional question.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;
description: Donald Trump, the owner of the New Jersey Generals of the United States Football League, said yesterday he had never offered Don Shula, the Miami Dolphins' coach, $1 million a year to coach the Generals.

title: RHETORIC AND REALITY
description: When a strongly ideological politician wins office in this country, we all wait for the move to the pragmatic center as he grapples with reality. It is a drama with an anticipated denouement: Ronald Reagan Faces Life.

title: THE CURIOUS BUSINESS OF ARCHITECTURE AWARDS
description: GIVING awards to works of architecture is a curious business, for the success of architecture is never immediately definable. A good performance in a film or a play looks good as it happens, but that is not enough for a building. For a building that has an immediate appeal may not function well, it may clash with the culture of which it is presumably a part, or it may not fit in gracefully with its physical surroundings. Or it may appear at first to succeed in all of these categories but turn out to age poorly.

title: ON STICKLEY DAY, HOUSES AND FURNITURE
description: GUSTAV STICKLEY, the early-20th-century furniture manufacturer, based his factories in the Syracuse area and his business offices in New York City. But from 1908 through 1917, he and his family lived on a 650-acre Parsippany, N.J., farm, which supplied produce for the Craftsman restaurant he owned and operated in his New York headquarters.

title: Suit on Ethnic Jokes In a Movie Dismissed
description: A federal judge has thrown out a $100 million lawsuit against Paramount Pictures that contended that Polish jokes in the movie ''Flashdance'' hurt Poles' chances of getting jobs.

title: Bank Rates Off Again
description: Interest rates on bank money market deposit accounts continued to fall in the week ended yesterday, The Bank Rate Monitor reported.

title: SORG PRINTING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss

title: News Analysis
description: The sharp criticism of the United States made yesterday by Yuri V. Andropov has raised the question whether Moscow has given up trying to work with the Reagan Administration because of what the Kremlin sees as intense hostility. ''Even if someone had any illusions as to the possible evolution for the better in the policy of the present American Administration,'' the Soviet leader said, ''the latest developments have finally dispelled them.''

title: GREAT ATLANTIC & PACIFIC TEA CO OF AMERICA (A&P) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 10
description: b-Includes tax credits of $4,000,000 for the quarter and $8,000,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $2,420,000 for the quarter and $4,970,000 for the 6 months.

title: SENATE PANEL SEES PRESSURE TO HALT BENEFITS TO DISABLED
description: A Republican-controlled Senate subcommittee said today that the Social Security Administration had improperly put pressure on agency hearing officers to cut off benefits for disabled people.

title: COMPUTER TERMINAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Soviet Jails Antiwar Activist
description: A member of an unofficial Soviet antiwar group has been jailed for 15 days for the second time this year, his wife said today. The activist, Vladimir Fleishgakker, was seized at his home here Tuesday, taken to court and convicted on charges that his wife, Maria, said were ill-defined. The couple are members of the self-styled Committee to Establish Trust Between the U.S. and the U.S.S.R.

title: IN THE NAME OF THE LAW; Legal ABC's
description: Over the years, as Government grew more complicated, names of Federal agencies were abbreviated - ACDA, BuPers, C.I.A., DoD, E.E.O.C., FERC and on through the alphabet to VISTA and YCC. Federal laws, meanwhile, retaining a vestigial human touch, were known by the names of their sponsors - Smoot-Hawley, McCarran-Walter, Landrum-Griffin.

title: Ranzany's Last Round
description: Pete Ranzany, the Sacramento, Calif., a welterweight who was once the World Boxing Association's top-ranked contender, has decided to contend no more. The 31-year-old boxer, who has a 59-8-2 record with 39 knockouts, said he had decided to retire after his doctor told him that another severe blow could cost him his vision in his right eye.

title: Avenue Plans Insert In Paris Newspaper
description: Judy Price, founder-publisher of Avenue, the magazine for folks with fancy East Side Manhattan addresses that is now also available in five other United States markets, will be adding an international dimension Monday when copy from Avenue's October issue appears as a full-size supplement in some copies The International Herald Tribune.

title: STRIDE RITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 2
New Jersey, New Jersey
description: Somewhere in a state to the west of New York City, a fortune is waiting for the first song writer who can catch the essence of New Jersey, the Garden State. With all the sports teams migrating westward, a New Jersey song is needed that could rival John Kander and Fred Ebb's ''New York, New York'' as a stadium theme song.

title: INSPECTION GUIDE FOR AN OLD HOUSE
description: ''BUYING an old house is like acquiring a spouse. And like all long-term relationships, it should be entered into with your eyes wide open.''

title: Shaws Co. Stake
description: J. Sainsbury Ltd., a leading British supermarket operator, said it would aquire up to a 25 percent interest in the Shaws Company, a New England- based food chain.

title: BRIEFS
description: Computer Sciences Corp. said it had received a Navy contract with a potential value of $67.5 million to supply automated data processing support services to the Naval Weapons Center at China Lake, Calif.

title: PRODIGAL OWNER RETURNS AFTER THE SUMMER RENTAL
description: WITH a quick intake of breath, you turn the key in the door of the house that is about to become yours again. Purely mercenary motives made you leave it, with all its charms and vulnerabilities, to the mercies of others for two long months.

title: THE JUSTICE IN MERIT SELECTION FOR THE STATE BENCH
description: To the Editor:

title: SPINOFF OF T.W.A. ADVANCES
description: The Trans World Corporation yesterday moved closer to spinning off its Trans World Airlines subsidiary, which has been beset by heavy losses.

title: DEVIL'S BAG WINS THE COWDIN
