description: Eddie Maple seemed a bit dazed as he walked away from the winner's circle at Belmont Park yesterday. The jockey had just ridden a 2-year-old colt named Devil's Bag to a three- length victory in the Cowdin Stakes, and everyone was asking him how good the colt was.

title: FOR RELIGIOUS NEUTRALITY SILENCE IS IDEAL
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVES
description: American Business Products, Atlanta, has appointed C. H. Jones president of its Curtis 1000 Inc. unit.

title: REVCO DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 20
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed April 26.

title: OUR ELDERLY'S FATE?
description: American society may be heading toward a de facto ''final solution'' to the problem of a growing elderly population. This trend raises the unthinkable prospect of the elderly one day being exterminated as a matter of law.

title: Jet Engine Debris Sets 15 House Fires on Coast
description: Flaming pieces from a damaged Republic Airlines DC-9 jet engine rained on the roofs of houses in this coastal area Tuesday, sending residents outside to fight 15 fires, the authorities said.

title: PIONEER INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: The latest quarter and 9 months include extraordinary gains attributed to tax credits of $277,000 and $957,000, respectively.

title: Univar Grain Spinoff Gets Its First Chairman
description: Curtis P. Lindley has been appointed chairman and chief executive of a yet-to-be-named grain-processing company that is a spinoff of the grain divisions of the Univar Corporation of Seattle.

title: China's Grain Forecast
description: China's 1983 grain output is expected to top the 1982 record of 353.43 million tons, the New China News Agency said today. It cited reforms that reward peasants for higher output and a wider use of scientific farming.

title: NEW ISSUE IN ULSTER: INFORMERS
description: For weeks, two ''supergrasses,'' as the police here call informers, have been testifying in separate Belfast courtrooms against former friends and allies inside outlawed republican ranks.

title: Kentucky (4-0) Cleans Image
description: The legacy of Fran Curci's nine-year reign as football coach at the University of Kentucky was player suspensions and arrests, not victories and bowl games.

title: VW's Outlook
description: Volkswagen of America will return to profitability this year and will remain profitable in 1984, the company's president, Noel Phillips, said. The company, a unit of Volkswagenwerk A.G. of West Germany, lost $140 million in 1982 and posted a slight profit in the first half of 1983. Mr. Phillips said Volkswagen was continuing to talk with Chrysler about the cross-supply of car components, but he said discussions about the possible joint production of small cars in the United States ''had died.''

title: NIXON BOOK SYNDICATED
description: A 107-page book that former President Richard M. Nixon wrote last summer and had privately printed and distributed to officials, journalists and friends has been sold by him for public distribution.

title: YASTRZEMSKI IN FAREWELL HERE
description: Carl Yastrzemski says he knew his decision to retire was right when he went to the plate in the last weeks of his 23d season not really caring if he got a hit.

title: A Yield of 12.358% At Texas Utility
description: The Texas Power and Light Company's $75 million of 12 1/4 percent bonds due in 2013 were offered at a price of 99.15 to yield 12.358 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: AMERICAN RECREATION CENERS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 24
Reagan Greets Sailors
description: ''Don't bolt that cup down too tightly,''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Our preference remains to keep the Jets, and we hope you listen to offers to buy the team to keep it here.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ON THE SQUARE

title: S.I. Man Guilty In Insurance Ruse
description: A 51-year-old private detective from Staten Island pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal charges that he had faked his death to enable his wife to file insurance claims for $600,000.

title: TEEN-AGERS WANT WORK, NOT ALLOWANCES
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA: JOAN SUTHERLAND BACK AT MET
description: THE Metropolitan Opera, as you may have heard, is celebrating a big birthday this season. And Tuesday night it had something to celebrate about: the return, after an 11-year absence, of its flamboyantly comical ''La Fille du Regiment,'' with Joan Sutherland as the tomboyish vivandi ere who is beloved of an entire regiment. Miss Sutherland, to get right to the point, put on a remarkable vocal show, giving no evidence whatever of any decline in her powers. Although reference books insist that she is a few weeks short of 57, the ear refuses to believe it. She is a genuine phenomenon, a bit of operatic history walking among us. She also can be, as she again proved in this revival of one of her favorite roles, an extremely funny lady.

title: Roughnecks Gain Soccer Bowl
description: Ron Futcher scored two goals to lead the Tulsa Roughnecks to a 3-0 victory over the Montreal Manic in the third and deciding game of their North American Soccer League semifinal playoff.

title: HENRY ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
APOGEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 25 percent stock dividend paid in November 1982.

title: RATES UP FOR TREASURY ISSUES
description: Interest rates on short- and long- term Treasury securities rose yesterday, guided by an increase in the rate on overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market and a weakening of investor demand for notes and bonds.

title: Father and Son
description: When Eric (Rusty) Hochberg gets his third start as the Rutgers quarterback Saturday, against Penn State at Giants Stadium, his father, Jim, will be on the opposite sideline.

title: TIMES WILL PRINT AT 2D COAST PLANT
description: The New York Times will begin printing its national edition at a fourth location around the end of the year, it was announced yesterday. The new site is the plant of Lesher Communications in Walnut Creek, Calif., near San Francisco. The edition is already being printed in Chicago; Lakeland, Fla.; and Torrance, Calif., near Los Angeles.

title: U.N. ROLE IN BIERUT REJECTED BY SYRIA
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria has informed the United Nations that he opposes the use of United Nations observers to police the cease-fire in Lebanon, Western diplomats and United Nations officials said today.

title: GIVING STUDIO APARTMENTS ILLUSIONS OF GRANDEUR
description: WHEN Virginia Woolf wrote about the importance of having a room of one's own, she was hardly thinking of life in a studio apartment, where a solitary room is all there is. Call it claustrophobic or cramped, one-room living has become a way of life in a city like New York, where spacious, affordable apartments are difficult to find. ''There are ways to design a studio so it is possible to forget there is only one room,'' said Richard Oliver, a New York architect. ''The key is not to think of the space as small. Instead, treat a studio as if it were big, big enough to build a house right inside of it.''

title: ALLEGATIN AGAINST GREEK REBUTTED BY C.I.A.
description: A Greek journalist, accused by American officals in 1977 of misrepresenting his war record and of working for foreign intelligence services, has made public a new Central Intelligence Agency review of his case that refutes the allegations against him.

title: Q & A
description: Q. All the floors on the second story of my 15-year-old house squeak when walked on. Some rooms are worse than others. What can be done to eliminate the problem?

title: Marsh Unit Appointment
description: Robert J. Newhouse Jr. has been named chairman of Marsh & McLennan Inc., the risk management and insurance brokerage subsidiary of the Marsh & McLennan Companies, effective Dec. 1, the New York-based company announced yesterday. Mr. Newhouse, 58, succeeds Alessandro C. di Montezemolo, who is retiring at 65. Mr. Newhouse has been vice chairman of the parent company. Robert Clements, 50, another vice chairman of the parent company, was named chairman of a newly formed executive committee of Marsh & McLennan Inc.

title: Dr. King Holiday Opposed
description: The Conservative Caucus, which calls itself a nonpartisan grass-roots lobbying organization, is working for a delay of at least 44 years in the establishment of a national holiday to honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Fingerprint Law For Pupils Signed
description: Mayor Koch signed into law yesterday a bill establishing a voluntary fingerprinting program for New York schoolchildren.

title: WEINBERGER HOPEFULE ON ARMS FOR CHINA
description: In a sign of warming Chinese-American relations, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger ended talks with Chinese leaders today by announcing that President Reagan and Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang would exchange official visits next year. He said there had also been progress toward eventual sales of American arms to China.

title: ...WHILE RANGEL'S ROLE IS THAT OF AN OLD HAND
description: A group of Texans, all of whom courteously addressed one another as Colonel, were testifying before a House committee on tax exemptions under the owl-like gaze of Representative Charles B. Rangel.

title: MRS. GANDHI SOUNDS A PLEA FOR THIRD WORLD
description: In a General Assembly session dominated by talk of military technology, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India took the podium of the General Assembly here today to put foward the problems of the developing countries.

title: Rouge Steel Recall
description: The Ford Motor Company said it will recall between 650 and 750 workers at its Rouge Steel subsidiary beginning next week.

title: No Headline
description: THE CHINESE BLACK CHAMBER. An Adventure in Espionage. By Herbert O. Yardley. Introduction by James Bamford. 225 pages. Illustrated. Houghton Mifflin. $13.95.

title: Quebec Offers 2 Issues Totaling $200 Million
description: A two-part bond financing by the Province of Quebec totaling $200 million was announced yesterday by underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The bonds had not been scheduled for sale this week, but a registration statement had been filed previously with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Dutch Town Votes to Reject Planned Missile Deployment
description: The municipal council of this southern Dutch town has voted against cooperating with the Government on the possible siting of United States nuclear missiles at a nearby airbase.

title: A BLOCK IN CHELSEA: STORE OWNERS GIVE NEW YORK THE HOMETOWN TOUCH
description: Early in the morning, when only the garbage and mail trucks rumble up Eighth Avenue, all the stores and restaurants between 17th and 18th Streets are closed.

title: SESSION ON CHECK-CLEARINGS
description: A bill that would force banks to reduce the length of time they take to clear checks and release funds to depositors drew bipartisan support today at a Senate banking subcommittee hearing.

title: Creusot-Loire Aid Debated
description: The board of Creusot-Loire, which makes steel and constructs nuclear reactors, failed to decide today whether to accept the terms of a Government- backed rescue package, industry sources said.

title: President Adds Job Of Chief at Viacom
description: Terrence A. Elkes, president of Viacom International Inc., has been named to the additional post of chief executive, the company said yesterday.

title: RELTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed on Aug. 1, 1983.

title: HOME CENTERS OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: b-Year-ago comparable figures are not available because the company went public in May.

title: NEARLY 600 BANKS ARE IN TROUBLE OVER BAD LOANS, REGULATORS SAY
description: Almost 600 banks are in deep financial trouble because of bad loans in the wake of the 1981-82 recession, according to Federal bank regulators in Washington.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: Asarco Layoffs
description: Asarco Inc. said it will lay off about 120 copper workers at its Mission Mine, about 20 miles south of here, on Friday. An Asarco official said the action was ''the direct result of the very depressed copper situation at the present time.'' The layoff, which will leave about 400 production workers at the mine, will not affect the reopening of the company's Silver Bell Mine, 45 miles northwest of Tucson.

title: Comsat Offers Issue in Europe
description: Comsat's financing subsidiary has started a $110 million offering in the Eurobond market through underwriters led by Credit Suisse First Boston.

title: COMMUNITY PSYCHIATRIC CENER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
ONE SLAIN, TWO WOUNDED IN CHINATOWN SHOOTING
description: A diner in a Chinatown restaurant was shot yesterday by a man who was then shot to death by a man identified as a part-owner of the restaurant, after a pursuit in streets crowded with lunchtime strollers.

title: MARRIOTT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 9
East Germany Removes Some Frontier Traps
description: East Germany has begun removing 1,500 of the nearly 54,000 booby-trap guns along its frontier with West Germany in an effort to improve relations.

title: HOUSE, 270 TO 161, VOTES TO INVOKE WAR POWERS ACT
description: By a decisive margin, the House of Representatives approved legislation today that would invoke the War Powers Act in Lebanon and authorize the deployment of American Marines in the Beirut area for an additional 18 months.

title: GRANGER ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a tax benefit of $348,000. c-Includes tax benefits of $197,000 for the quarter and $1,551,000 for the year. Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted to reflect 2-for-1 stock splits effective Oct. 18, 1982 and July 1, 1983.

title: ANALYSTS HAIL REPUBLIC-LTV LINK
description: The proposed merger of the Republic Steel Corporation into the LTV Corporation, which owns the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation, has stirred praise from the investment community, anxious questions from steelworkers and a tentative passing grade from antitrust experts.

title: PERENNIALS IN FASHION
description: GARDENERS hate to admit it, but they are subject to fashions that ebb and flow. The latest, according to Frederick McGourty, is a revival of interest in herbaceous perennials, hearty plants that reappear in spring after their tops have died the previous summer or fall.

title: Citizenship Upheld In Atrocities Case
description: A Federal judge rejected today a Justice Department bid to revoke the citizenship of a Clifton man accused of concealing his role in the World War II execution of 2,000 Jewish civilians.

title: U.S. LUTHERANS: LEGACY AND CHANGE
description: The third graders of St. Paul Evangelical Lutheran Church, each with a brand-new Bible, sat squirming one recent Sunday as Marilyn Reddemann, head of the Sunday School, read them a dense portion of Paul's letter to the Romans.

title: Erica Jong Returns To Barnard and Reflects
description: Erica Jong returned to her alma

title: Japan Air Lines
description: Japan Air Lines refused to confirm a report in a Japanese newspaper that it had selected Boeing's new 767 aircraft to replace its fleet of 20 McDonnell-Douglas DC-8's. J.A.L., the national flag carrier, has been studying both the Boeing jetliner and the European-built Airbus Industrie A310 as a replacement for the DC-8's, which were purchased in the 1960's. The newspaper Nihon Kezai reported that J.A.L. had decided to buy 15 Boeings at a total cost of $844 million, and said the decision would be announced Thursday.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Eric Fernsten , a 6-foot-10-inch center who was cut by the Boston Celtics a year ago, has signed a one-year contract with the Knicks. . . . Jeff Chandler will defend his World Boxing Association bantamweight title against Oscar Muniz Dec. 17 in Atlantic City. Muniz holds a nontitle decision over Chandler, the champion's only defeat in 35 pro fights. . . . . Wilbert Montgomery, the Philadelphia Eagles' running back who has been hobbled most of the season but played last Sunday, has undergone surgery to remove cartilage from his right knee and will be sidelined six weeks.

title: China Alters Banking Role
description: China announced a shake-up of its banking system today, saying a commercial bank would be established to take over the commercial role of the People's Bank.

title: HARTMARX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,765,000 from the sale of real estate.

title: CREEPING ABROGATION
description: When President Reagan offers lunch to Egypt's President, Hosni Mubarak, at the White House on Friday, one subject not planned for discussion is Egypt's recent decision to begin buying hundreds of tanks from Rumania.

title: MITTERRAND, AT U.N., REJECTS SOVIET ARMS DEMAND
description: President Francois Mitterrand said today that Soviet demands that French nuclear missiles be counted among NATO forces in arms reduction talks in Europe were unacceptable and would deprive France of an independent national defense.

title: REAGAN'S SLIDE TO WAR
description: The tone of President Reagan's speech to the United Nations on Monday was so different from the tone he has set for his Administration since the day he was elected that one might well ask: Has Ronald Reagan been born again?

title: TEXT OF ORDER ON CLUBS AND BARS
description: Following is the text of Mayor Koch's executive order forbidding city officials to conduct municipal business at clubs with discriminatory membership practices:

title: Key Rates
description: * Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: HOME BEAT
description: THE fact that the house in which Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt and their children lived from 1908 to 1928 has been redecorated by members of the International Society of Interior Designers, to benefit the March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation, would be reason enough for a visit.

title: Tropical Storm Heads Toward Eastern Coast
description: Tropical Storm Dean pushed northward off the Eastern Seaboard today with winds of up to 60 miles an hour and swept across the Outer Banks of North Carolina.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some editions of Sports Pages yesterday incorrectly characterized the Davis Cup match that starts tomorrow between the United States and Ireland. It is a playoff for the 1984 tournament cup, with the winner remaining in the championship division.

title: Finance Ministers Question Recovery
description: The world's deepest economic recession since World War II has ended, but big questions remain about the durability of the recovery and whether it will ease the distress of the poorest countries, finance ministers from many countries said today.

title: MORTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income includes extraordinary credits of $155,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $365,000, or 10 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: ARAFAT SAYS P.L.O. WILL STAY IN SHUF
description: Yasir Arafat said today that his guerrilla fighters who helped the Druse in their battle for control of the Shuf Mountains southeast of Beirut would remain there for operations against the Israelis.

title: 2 Die in Indian Clashes During a 24-Hour Strike
description: Two people died and several hundred were arrested today after the police fired on demonstrators during a 24- hour strike in the state of West Bengal, the Press Trust of India news agency said.

title: Technology; Laser Surgery: A Repair Tool
description: LASERS are being used by eye surgeons to reconnect blood vessels and restore vision. They are being used by throat surgeons to remove tumors from vocal cords so that people who might have lost their voices can speak. And gynecologists use these powerful beams of intense light to remove obstructions from Fallopian tubes so that otherwise childless women may become pregnant.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
UNUSUAL TOOLS
description: HARDWARE and gadget buffs will be pleased to know that Brookstone has opened a small store at 18 Fulton Street, in the South Street Seaport. The company is known for its catalogues of ''Hard-to-Find Tools and Other Fine Things,'' which offer a melange of woodworking, garden, painting and automotive tools and kitchen utensils along with such esoteric items as a candle that burns for three days, an automatic battery tester and a heavy-duty staple remover.

title: Texas Doctor Gets 15 Years For Murder in 1979 Abortion
description: A doctor convicted of murdering a fetus in a 1979 abortion, even though the corpse was never found, was sentenced today by a jury to 15 years in prison.

title: THUJRSDAY, SEPTEMBER 29, 1983
description: The Economy

title: POLL TAKEN FOR THE DEMOCRATS BUOYS HOPES FOR '84
description: Results of a new public opinion poll paid for by the House Democratic leadership suggest that the emerging issues in the 1984 national election favor Democratic candidates and that President Reagan could be more vulnerable in a re-election bid than some party leaders had thought.

title: Borges Is Given Award By Ingersoll Foundation
description: Jorge Luis Borges, the Argentine writer, has been awarded the T. S. Eliot Award for Creative Writing and Dr. James Burnham, the political and social philosopher who wrote ''The Managerial Revolution,'' has been awarded the Richard M. Weaver Award for Scholarly Letters.

title: ROLL-CALL IN HOUSE ON MARINES
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 270 to 161 by which the House of Representatives today approved a resolution to permit United States Marines to stay in Lebanon for 18 months. A ''yes'' vote was a vote in favor of the resolution. Voting yes were 130 Democrats and 140 Republicans. Voting no were 134 Democrats and 27 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes those not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House. ALABAMA

title: Cable TV Council Narrows Field to 6
description: After letting it be known that it was looking for an ad agency to create an image advertising campaign for cable TV, the Council on Cable Information in New York got responses from 32 shops.

title: Purchasing World Sold By Dun & Bradstreet
description: The latest trade publication purchase by International Thomson Business Press is Purchasing World, which had been owned by Dun & Bradstreet's Technical Publishing.

title: GTE in Japan Venture
description: The GTE Corporation said today that it would set up a marketing unit in Japan to sell high-technology communications systems and services in Asia. The new unit, GTE Communications Systems-Asia, will direct GTE's marketing in Japan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, South Korea, Indonesia, Australia and China. The marketing unit is to begin operations Oct. 30.

title: RITE AID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in January.

title: TEXT OF SOVIET STATEMENT ON RELATIONS WITH U.S.
description: Following is a statement yesterday by Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, as translated and distributed by Tass, the Soviet press agency:

title: Construction Contracts Up
description: Contracting for new construction rebounded in August, recouping more than half of July's decline, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

title: BELL'S BREAKUP OFFERS BONANZA
description: The impending breakup on Jan. 1 of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company will produce an unprecedented avalanche of stock trading, a financial windfall for the brokers who handle it and the largest printing orders in Wall Street history.

title: White Baltimore Officer Charged in Black's Death
description: A white police officer pleaded not guilty today to charges resulting from the shooting death of a black motorcyclist in a traffic dispute.

title: Bottom-Line Scrimmage
description: Since Leon Hess, the New York Jets' president, would rather look at Manhattan's skyline from East Rutherford than from Flushing, New Yorkers ought to accede to such dubious taste and wish him well in the team's new New Jersey home. Some clubs in the National Football League may demonstrate allegiance to their cities, but many bounce as erratically as the pigskin they carry.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allen Products Co., maker of Alpo Brand pet food, announced that it had changed its name to Alpo Petfoods Inc., ''to build identification for the Alpo brand and reduce confusion over who manufactures our product.''

title: LIPSKI'S 'BUILDING STEAM' OPENS SOHO GALLERY
description: MANY art patrons prefer to make their gallery rounds midweek. Crowds, they say, get in the way of the art. This may be true uptown, but it doesn't really hold for SoHo where, more and more, the audience is rivaling the art as a spectacle and may soon transcend it.

title: FRESH FROM THE MIDDLE EASTERN COCKPIT
description: Prince Bandar sat in his sumptuous study and stared at the amethyst worry beads, strung on a gold chain, that he was threading through his fingers.

title: All Nation's Inmates
description: President Gaafar al-Nimeiry freed all 13,000 of Sudan's prison inmates today to give them a second chance at life on the outside under a new Islamic penal code.

title: WEST GERMANS' FEAR
description: The arms control proposals that President Reagan made Monday at the United Nations do nothing to change the fundamental threat that will be posed to Europe and the Western alliance if intermediate-range nuclear missiles are deployed in West Germany this winter. As a member of the West German peace movement, which hopes for the eventual dissolution of both military blocs in Europe, I find it ironic that the President does not see what he is doing to alienate even those West Germans - and they are the vast majority - who want to maintain special ties with the United States.

title: Dr. Baden Gets Brooklyn Post
description: Dr. Michael M. Baden, who was ousted as New York City's Chief Medical Examiner in 1979 on the day before his appointment was to become permanent, was named yesterday to head the Brooklyn medical examiner's office.

title: Belt-Buckling Time for Airlines
description: Continental Airlines seeks survival in bankruptcy court and as a discount service . . . Eastern says its survival depends on major wage concessions . . . Trans World considers writing off domestic service as a lost cause.

title: COURT DENIES PLEA ON CHEMOTHERAPY
description: The Tennessee Supreme Court refused today to hear a preacher's argument that his family's religious objections to medicine outweighed any help that chemotherapy could offer his daughter.

title: WEST POINT ALUMNI GIVE ANNUAL AWARD TO GENERAL DOOLITTLE
description: James H. Doolittle, the general who led the first World War II bombing mission over Tokyo, in 1942, was honored here today by the United States Military Academy.

title: BANKS WILL SOON BE FREE TO OFFER HIGHER INTEREST ON CERTAIN SAVINGS
description: The ceiling on interest rates for certificates of deposits is to be lifted tomorrow, and banks all over the country will be free to pay whatever they want to attract consumers.

title: AM International Reorganization
description: AM International Inc., operating under protection of the bankruptcy statutes since April 1982, filed a reorganization plan with the Bankruptcy Court here.

title: Woman Wins Suit In Fall on Street
description: A jury has ordered the city to pay $1.8 million to a Manhattan woman who said she was crippled after she tripped over a city water-valve cover.

title: WORK IGNORED FOR 200 YEARS
description: ''Alcina,'' which Handel's librettist adapted from Ariosto's 16th-century epic poem ''Orlando Furioso,'' was first performed at Covent Garden in London in 1735 with the famous castrato Carestini as Ruggiero.

title: GRAHAM'S CHALLENGE TO THE NATIONAL ENDOWMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Drought Aid
description: The State Department of Agriculture said today that it would recommend asking the Federal Government to declare 12 New Jersey counties drought disaster areas.

title: FEDERAL PAPERBOARD CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 10
NEW MEXICO GOVERNOR'S POLITICAL TRAVELS HURT HIM AT HOME
description: Gov. Toney Anaya is encountering growing criticism in New Mexico because of his national activities as a Hispanic leader. As a result, he is reducing out-of-state travel and is spending more time courting voters in at home.

title: CONGRESS AGREES TO ALLOW MARINES TO STAY IN BEIRUT
description: Congress completed action tonight on landmark legislation that would authorize the continued deployment of American marines in Lebanon for 18 more months.

title: SALVADOR TALKS WITH REBELS CALLED AT CRISIS POINT
description: Representatives of the Salvadoran Government and leftist rebels met here today. After the three-and-a-half-hour meeting, the head of the Government peace commission, Francisco Quinonez, said the talks had reached a crisis point and would not continue unless the left changed its position.

title: Gannett-Chronicle TV Deal Dropped
description: The Gannett Company will not buy a San Francisco television station, KRON-TV, from the Chronicle Broadcast Company, the two companies said.

title: At the Garden, The Cycle Goes On
description: Madison Square Garden keeps 1.7 million pounds of dirt on Pier 70, and for good reason.

title: THE CAROUSELS OF YESTERYEAR JUST NEXT DOOR
description: SLIDE into the saddle, slip your shoes into the stirrups and dream of reaching for the ring - fall is a wonderful time to gallop off to nowhere on a carousel. This weekend, stout rainbow-color stallions and ornate jeweled jumpers will make their rounds on more than a dozen historic carousels that are all within about 90 minutes of Times Square.

title: Boxer Still Critical
description: Jeremia Richardson, a 25-year-old amateur boxer, remained in critical condition yesterday in a Miami hospital suffering from head injuries he suffered in a three-round bout last Friday. In a bout against Ramon Negron, two-time Florida Golden Gloves middleweight champion, Richardson was knocked down and took a mandatory eight count in the first round and received heavy punishment when he was trapped in his corner in the second round.

title: No Headline
description: Trio to Play Klezmer

title: U.S. MAY DREDGE PCB'S IN THE HUDSON
description: The Environmental Protection Agency, reversing a decision made last year, said today that it would consider dredging PCB-contaminated sediment from the upper Hudson River, but only after New York State authorities found an acceptable place to bury the toxic material.

title: STEINBRENNER SKIRTS BACKING OF MARTIN
description: George Steinbrenner expressed measured disappointment last night about the Yankees 1983 season, reiterated his interest in signing Rich Gossage as a free agent and studiously avoided any statement of support for Manager Billy Martin.

title: Jimmy Carter and his chairs.
description: JIMMY CARTER'S hickory ladder-back chairs with woven-bark seats - the ones he made by hand and signed - are expected to draw greater attention than Willie Nelson's Nike running shoes and Christopher Hemmeter's $5 million twin-engine Bac 1-11 jet at an auction next Friday at Sotheby Parke Bernet to benefit the Carter Presidential Library and the Carter Center of Emory University in Atlanta. The auction, involving more than 300 donated lots to be offered at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Sotheby's, York Avenue at 72d Street, is expected to bring at least $500,000 - and as much as $6 million if the jet sells.

title: 'THE ROUSTERS' TO BEGIN
description: ONE of several new series getting under way this weekend, ''The Rousters'' begins tomorrow night on Channel 4 at 8:30 with a 90-minute episode. On subsequent Saturdays, the regular time slot will be 9 to 10.

title: Banctec Settlement
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it had settled charges of fraud against a former director and a regional vice president of Banctec Inc. of Dallas, a company selling processing systems for computerized documents. The S.E.C. said it had charged Edwin Wattenbarger, the former director, and Philip Yarbrough, a vice president, with using inside information about the company's poor performance in late 1982 to make illegal profits from a stock sale. Without admitting or denying guilt, the defendants agreed to an order barring future violations, the commission said. Mr. Wattenbarger also agreed to repay $34,372.

title: JACKSON DISCUSSES POSSIBLE '84 RACE WITH BALCK LAWMAKERS
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson met with members of the Congressional Black Caucus today to discuss his possible Presidential candidacy. He received indications, according to some of the participants, that he could expect the support of a slim majority of the 21 members if he decided to seek the Democratic nomination.

title: OAKLAND ROOKIE HURLS NO-HITTER
description: Mike Warren, a rookie for the Oakland A's, pitched a no-hitter tonight in defeating the Chicago White Sox, 3-0.

title: U.S. DEFICIT WORRIES MRS. THATCHER
description: Amid mutual declarations of friendship, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain met with President Reagan today but came away ''not assured at all'' that Mr. Reagan planned any new actions to reduce the United States deficit.

title: House Acts to Extend Benefits for the Jobless
description: The House today overwhelmingly agreed to extend for another 45 days the Federal unemployment benefit program, which was to have expired Friday.

title: CITY FORGES PLAN TO REPLALCE JETS
description: Although there are no obvious candidates, New York City plans to have a professional football team at Shea Stadium next season, the official who is looking for one said yesterday.

title: DANCE: PREMIERES BY BEJART TROUPE
description: THUS far in its season at the City Center, the Ballet of the Twentieth Century has emphasized serious, even lugubrious, multi-act ballets by Maurice Bejart about such matters as death, angst and alienation. But on Wednesday night it presented the American premieres of two jaunty short ballets that might well charm dancegoers resistant to Mr. Bejart's solemnities.

title: HOW TO HELP AMERICA COMPETE
description: Question: Your company's widgets are losing out to low-cost imports. What do you do?

title: REV. R.L. CALHOUN, A PROFESSOR, DIES
description: The Rev. Robert L. Calhoun, Sterling Professor Emeritus of Historical Theology at Yale University, who was a leading figure in Protestant scholarship and ecumenism, died last Saturday at the Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Bethany, Conn.

title: MUSIC: A NEW 'ALCINA' BY CITY OPERA
description: THE New York City Opera took a fling with the theatrical avant-garde last night, presenting Andrei Serban's relentlessly novel version of Handel's ''Alcina.'' The evening, though a trial of patience in many ways, was redeemed by stirring singing by Carol Vaness as the cruel enchantress Alcina and by a supporting cast that could not always meet Handel's fierce demands but came through with honor.

title: Motorola Prices
description: Motorola Inc. said it had reduced prices for some of its mobile radio lines by 12 to 14 percent and on most portable radios by 11 to 23 percent.

title: 2 Democrats Spurn Bronx Liberal Line
description: The Hispanic and Black judicial candidates who were nominated by Bronx Democrats in a deal that denied renomination to two Supreme Court incumbents rejected the liberal Party line yesteray.

title: PENTAGON EXCERPT CITES MORE WASTE
description: A Pentagon official who disclosed wasteful military contracts in 1969 testified today that the Government was still often paying inexcusably high prices and getting ''horrible quality'' in return.

title: Money Fund Assets Drop
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds fell slightly in the week ended Wednesday, while rates on the funds dropped sharply.

title: 332 DANCE ON A RECORD 3,389TH 'CHORUS LINE'
description: From the four continents to which they had dispersed, from stardom and from unemployment lines, 332 dancers who once appeared in ''A Chorus Line'' gathered last night to share in the performance that made the musical the longest-running show in the history of Broadway.

title: First Woman Elected London's Lord Mayor
description: London broke with eight centuries of tradition today by electing a woman as its Lord Mayor.

title: French Car Output Up
description: French auto production in July and August rose 12.1 percent from the corresponding period of 1982, to 305,119 vehicles, the Automobile Manufacturers Association said today. Domestic demand for new cars remained steady, while exports rose 14.4 percent. Production in the first eight months rose 13.6 percent from a year earlier and exports increased 10.3 percent.

title: Apartment Hotels Faulted on Status
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday that 15 apartment hotels in Manhattan were taking advantage of their hotel status to raise rents and of their apartment status to keep real-estate tax payments down.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: She landed role and made a splash.
description: ''I HUNG up the phone and started to slowly stroll away from the phone, and I'd look around and smile a little; and then my pace slowly picked up, and I started to run out the door, and I ran down the hill and I jumped in the water. I had on shorts and a T-shirt. No shoes. And I played in the water for an hour, till I was calmed down.''

title: No Headline
description: George McGovern, who won only Massachusetts and the District of Columbia in the 1972 Presidential election, said tonight that he was ''a wiser and more thoughtful man'' as he started another quest for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: A SPECIAL NIGHT OF IRISH MUSIC
description: WITH its vigorous dance rhythms, rustic instrumentation and centuries-old storehouse of Celtic tunes, Irish music is one of the most evocative of Western folk traditions. And at Town Hall tomorrow night, De Danann and Touchstone, two of today's finest groups with Irish roots, will appear together for the first time on a New York stage.

title: John G. Thevos, Served As Prosecutor in Jersey
description: John G. Thevos, who held Federal, state and municipal legal posts in New Jersey and was active in Greek-American affairs, died Tuesday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 71 years old and lived in Paterson, N.J.

title: HERITAGE FOUNDATION 10 YEARS LATER
description: Ten years ago, Edwin J. Feulner recalled with a laugh, conservatives in Washington joked about holding meetings in a telephone booth.

title: 3 PIANISTS AND THEIR DEBT TO THELONIOUS MONK
description: THERE'S hardly a keyboardist alive who hasn't learned something from Thelonious Monk. What the late pianist showed keyboardists in jazz and rock was a new way to use the spaces between notes - in harmony, in rhythm and in the shape of a tune. Those lessons are being applied this weekend by three keyboardists whose styles have virtually nothing else in common - Cecil Taylor, Terry Adams of N.R.B.Q. and Jorge Dalto.

title: Judge Suspends Bicyclists' Fines
description: Young bicycle riders who were told they could be fined $15 to $60 for violating traffic laws were given suspended sentences in Municipal Court here, officials said.

title: COMPROMISE ON CIVIL RIGHTS PANEL REPORTED
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee has reached a compromise on the controversy over the Commission on Civil Rights that would enable President Reagan to make two nominations to the panel without dismissing any current members, Congressional sources said today.

title: PUBLIC TV ADS OPPOSED
description: A Federal commission that examined the experimental use of limited advertising on public television stations has concluded that the advertising was not a good substitute for continued Federal financing.

title: Dodgers Fail to Clinch
description: The Dodgers, needing only one victory - or a loss by Atlanta - to take the National League West title, were swept by the Padres in a doubleheader in San Diego last night. Meanwhile, the Braves rallied from to defeat the Astros in Houston and stay alive.

title: CONGRESS VOTES RADIO FOR CUBA
description: The House gave final Congressional approval today to legislation creating Radio Marti, a Voice of America broadcast service intended to give Cubans news of their country and elsewhere.

title: BILL WOULD KEEP BENEFITS TAX-FREE
description: Meeting behind closed doors, a House Ways and Means subcommittee approved a bill today that would protect the tax-free status of almost all employee fringe benefits, from free airline tickets and free parking to merchandise discounts. However, the panel included a new clause that could discourage employers from offering them.

title: MARCOS SHUTS PAPER FOR HINT THAT MILITARY HELPED KILL FOE
description: Government security men tonight raided and padlocked the office of a Manila newspaper that has suggested in recent issues that the military was involved in the assassination last month of President Ferdinand E. Marcos's chief opponent, Benigno S. Aquino Jr.

title: Dispute Continues
description: David Thompson, the Seattle SuperSonics' free-agent guard, has agreed to take a pay cut to stay with Seattle, according to the club's general manager, Les Habegger, but he has balked at a demand that part of the money would be tied to his performance. Habegger said the club was unwilling to guarantee Thompson's full salary because of uncertainties created by his recent drug problems.

title: 50 Years of Karsh
description: Photographer of celebrities, Karsh of Ottawa is something of one himself.

title: TINY LESOTHO TURNS TO WORLD TO PARRY PERTORIA
description: This small and poor mountain kingdom, with a military force of only 2,000 threadbare troops, is relying entirely on public relations and international diplomacy to defend itself against the tightening siege by South Africa, which surrounds it and dominates and sustains its economic life.

title: Soviet Trade Official Ordered to Leave Britain
description: Britain today gave a Soviet trade delegation official a week to get out of the country, charging he had engaged in ''activity incompatible with his position.'' That is diplomatic language for spying.

title: PUBLISHING: WHEN A SCHOLARLY BOOK IS SUBSIDIZED
description: A CONTROVERSY over ''The United States and the Middle East,'' a textbook for high schools and colleges by Philip L. Groisser, leads to questions that bear on scholarly-book publishing. The textbook was commissioned by the American Academic Association for Peace in the Middle East, a pro-Israel organization based in New York, and was published two years ago by the State University of New York Press. The university says that it has discontinued the textbook, of which it had printed only 2,200 copies, because sales had been disappointing. But the American-Arab Anti-Discrimination Committee, a pro-Arab group, says that the textbook was discontinued because of its charges that the book is biased.

title: WANTED: COACH AND SON
description: About a month ago, Danny Manning was routinely preparing for his senior year here at Walter Hines Page High School. Then, four days before classes were to begin, he and his father, Ed, came in and had a talk with the school's basketball coach, Mac Morris.

title: SETTING THE RECORD STRAIGHT ON FUTWANGLER
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil Seeking Funds for 1983
description: Brazil plans to press its private creditors at a meeting in New York Friday for quick release of $1.7 billion of the $4.4 billion loan package that commercial banks put together last autumn, Brazilian finance officials said here today.

title: FOREIGN POLICY COSTING REAGAN PUBLIC SUPPORT
description: For the first time since President Reagan took office, significantly more Americans now disapprove of his conduct of foreign policy than approve of it, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: WALDEMORE OF JETS IS LOST FOR SEASON
description: The situation that Coach Joe Walton feared - a unit suffering more than one serious injury, leaving it perilously weak - has become reality.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT RANGERS, 7-3
description: Pierre Larouche and Reijo Ruotsalainen each scored a pair of goals tonight, leading the Rangers to a 7-3 victory over the Islanders in an exhibition game at Nassau Coliseum.

title: NEW IDEAS AT QUEENS LAW SCHOOL
description: Jonathan G. Weber graduated last spring from the University of Michigan with honors and a score that put him in the top 5 percent of those who took the Law School Aptitude Test.

title: Semiconductor Earnings Jump
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in its first quarter, ended Sept. 18, climbed to $10.9 million, or 41 cents a share, from $64,000 a year earlier.

title: ANTIWAR 'TAX DEDUCTION' COSTS A NURSE $500
description: A registered nurse who claimed a tax deduction on her 1982 tax return, based on her religious convictions against war, has been penalized $500 by the Federal Government.

title: DAVID T. LEWIS
description: Former Chief Judge David T. Lewis of the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit died of emphysema Wednesday. He was 71 years old.

title: FUNDS SOUGHT TO HOUSE RETIRED HORSES
description: Almost 40,000 thoroughbred horses were born this spring, about 20,000 colts and as many fillies. A decade from now, about 8,000 of the fillies and only 200 of the colts will be of use to the breeding industry as broodmares and stallions. Of the others, a few hundred will still be racing in cheap races at small tracks and some other lucky ones will have found homes as pets or pensioners. The rest, however, are likely to have been destroyed.

title: AMERFORD INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. Results for the first three quarters of both years are restated.

title: WALCO NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: CUBA SAID TO JAIL ACADEMIC, UPSETTING THE FRENCH
description: Cuba has arrested the former vice rector of the University of Havana after promising France that he would be allowed to leave the country, French officials say.

title: SENATORS APPROVE INTERIM FINANCING
description: The Senate took 17 minutes today to approve, by voice vote, a stopgap spending resolution needed to keep the Government operating beyond Friday midnight, when the current fiscal year ends.

title: Washington Unit In $90 Million Sale
description: The Washington Suburban Sanitary District, Maryland, has sold $90 million of bonds, which were reoffered by a Chase Manhattan Bank group with yields ranging from 5.75 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 8 percent in 1993 and 9.2 percent in 2008.

title: FILM: 'BEYOND THE LIMIT,' FROM GRAHAM GREENE
description: WITH the exception of Sir Carol Reed's screen adaptation of ''The Third Man,'' which is a classic of sorts, the celebrated stories of Graham Greene have not been made into especially celebrated films. This is possibly because, although Mr. Greene writes exceptionally good, well-balanced narratives, the film versions don't have the time or the means to dramatize the crises of conscience that give the stories their weight.

title: OFFICER AND A GUNMAN KILLED IN BRONX
description: A police officer was killed in the Bronx yesterday when a mentally disturbed man holed up in a house fired a shotgun blast that ricocheted off a tree, pierced a fold of his bulletproof vest and struck the officer in the heart.

title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 18
PEERLESS RUG LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: Kissinger Panel Plans Central American Trip
description: Henry A. Kissinger, chairman of the commission on Central America, said today that the panel would visit Central America from Oct. 9 to 15 and meet with officials and opposition groups in all countries, including Nicaragua.

title: U.S. Mortgage Corp. Sets Sales of Obligations
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation yesterday announced interest rates on its $684.7 million of collateralized mortgage obligations to be sold through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: EMIGRES MOURN SLAIN HAITIAN EDITOR
description: The shades were drawn this week in the house at 896 Clarkson Avenue in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn. A crowd of Haitian men lingered outside the two-story gray row house. Inside, friends and relatives sat in the dimly lighted living room on folding chairs, speaking quietly in Creole.

title: NUCLEAR WASTE DISPOSAL IS NO EVERYDAY TASK
description: To the Editor:

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: TV Stations Won by 23 In First F.C.C. Lottery
description: The Federal Communications Commission today awarded 23 low-power television station licenses through the first license lottery it ever conducted.

title: 4 Solidarity Advisers Indicted in Poland
description: The Government indicted Jacek Kuron and three other Solidarity advisers today but reduced the charges, removing the threat of the death penalty.

title: ELMHURST ATTACHED HOUSES TO HAVE GARAGES IN REAR
description: The plot of land was deep enough and the builder was willing, so the new attached houses that the Overlook Construction Corporation is building in the Elmhurst section of Queens will have their garages in the rear, under the structure.

title: Amstar Weighing Leveraged Buyout
description: The nation's biggest cane sugar refiner, the Amstar Corporation, said yesterday that preliminary discussions were under way with unidentified interests about a possible leveraged buyout. Amstar said, however, that it was ''too early'' to say whether the talks would be successful.

title: Shearing to Play
description: The jazz pianist George Shearing will perform a free concert Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Jewish Guild for the Blind, 15 West 65th Street, 595-2200. He will be accompanied by Don Thompson on bass.

title: A SENSE OF LOSS FOR NEW YORK
description: ''The Jets moving won't kill New York,'' said Amelia Slattery, boarding a bus on 42d Street. ''New York is culture. Football ain't culture.''

title: Edwards Sues Studio
description: The film maker Blake Edwards has filed a $180 million lawsuit against M-G-M/U.A., charging a conspiracy by studio officials to sabotage promotion for his movie, ''The Curse of the Pink Panther.'' The suit, filed Tuesday in Superior Court, contends that the studio damaged its distribution of the movie because Mr. Edwards supported David Begelman in a dispute over Mr. Begelman's ouster as M-G- M/U.A. chief executive.

title: INTERNATIONAL LEASE FIANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes an unusual pre-tax gain of $4,456,000 from the insurance proceeds on the total loss of one of the company's Boeing 727-200 aircraft in Brazil.

title: Turner Deal In the Works
description: Ted Turner, chairman and president of Turner Broadcasting System Inc., confirmed that discussions had occurred about a merger of Turner's Cable News Network Headline News with the Satellite News Channel, a joint venture of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the American Broadcasting Companies. ''Discussions have been far-ranging and have included, among other things, several proposals whereby certain assets of SNC would be acquired by CNN Headline News,'' the company stated.

title: MUSIC: WEILERSTEIN RECITAL
description: DONALD WEILERSTEIN'S appearance Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y, at which he was deftly accompanied by his wife, Vivian Hornik Weilerstein, was billed as his New York recital debut. But Mr. Weilerstein is hardly an unknown figure here.

title: INJURIES OF A POLICE PRISONER DID NOT KILL, AUTOPSY FINDS
description: An autopsy on a 25-year-old Brooklyn man, who some black leaders say was beaten by Transit Authority policemen after he was arrested, showed that the man's injuries, including facial bruises, were not linked to his death, the city's Chief Medical Examiner said last night.

title: Johnnie Walker Red Focusing on the Color
description: Think how clever Somerset Importers and its agency Smith/Greenland are. With advertising they have pre- empted the color red for its Johnnie Walker Red Scotch and green for its Tanqueray Gin.

title: CORRECTION
description: Articles on Sept. 13, 16, 17 and 22 about the American Ballet Theater's financial problems incorrectly described last year's labor dispute. It was a lockout.

title: BRIEFING
description: On the Watts Line

title: Rates Drop in Quiet Trading
description: Interest rates for short- and long- term Treasury securities declined yesterday in quiet trading as many participants were on the sidelines waiting for money supply data and a clearer picture of Federal Reserve monetary policy.

title: Coppola Studio Sale Is Reported Near
description: An independent film producer and a mortgage broker have agreed in principal to purchase Francis Ford Coppola's financially ailing Zoetrope Studios for $16.6 million, a studio spokesman says. The sale, however, is ''contingent on certain conditions being met,'' the spokesman said.

title: BROOKS FASHION STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid Aug. 1.

title: Crime Rose in '82 In Grade Schools
description: Crime in New York City's elementary schools increased 11 percent last year over the year before, Board of Education officials said yesterday.

title: Homosexual Is Denied Citizenship in U.S.
description: A three-judge Federal appeals panel has ruled, 2 to 1, that homosexual aliens should not be allowed entry into the United States and therefore cannot become citizens.

title: Addenda
description: Addenda

title: STILL BATTING A THOUSAND
description: John Paciorek wasn't expecting to play baseball on the last day of the 1963 season. He was in Houston to have his aching back examined, and he was surprised when the Colt .45's management asked him to play right field, to give them an all-rookie team. The Colt .45's were in only their second year as an expansion team, and they wanted to give the home fans a glimpse of all their young players, including Jim Wynn, Joe Morgan and Rusty Staub.

title: Al Paul Lefton Sets TV Self-Promotion
description: The Al Paul Lefton Company, a New York and Philadelphia agency, is not only going to advertise itself, which is rare for an agency, but is going to do it on television, which is rarer still.

title: AVERY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The net income for the year-ago quarter includes a gain of 9 cents a share resulting from the settlement of a class action suit.

title: Martin Is Sued By Umpire
description: Umpire Dale Ford, upset at being called a ''stone liar'' by the Yankees' manager, Billy Martin, today sued Martin and the Yankees in United States District Court.

title: BAR OPPOSES COURT NOMINEE
description: The American Bar Association said today that it opposed President Reagan's nomination of the Commerce Department's chief lawyer, Sherman E. Unger, to a Federal appeals court.

title: GRAHAM'S CHALLENGE TO THE NATIONAL ENDOWMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: DIET TO CUT CANCER RISK IS OFFERED
description: Fruits, vegetables and whole grain cereals will be included on a new diet suggested by the American Cancer Society to reduce the risk of cancer, according to an official of the group.

title: Key Rates
description: * Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: JAPAN AIR TO BUY 9 BOEING JETS
description: In a significant victory for the Boeing Company over Airbus Industrie, the European plane-building consortium, Japan Air Lines announced today that it will buy nine Boeing 767 aircraft for approximiately $560 million over the next five years. The Japanese-flag carrier also said it might buy six additional 767's between 1989 and 1991.

title: Silver Futures Slide In New York Trading
description: All New York silver futures plunged the daily permissible limit of 50 cents an ounce yesterday, save the unrestricted spot October contract, which lost 53.5 cents at $11.29. The key December delivery closed at $11.412 on New York's Commodity Exchange.

title: Cuban Runners
description: There has been no horse racing in Cuba for nearly two decades and the interest of The Jockey Club was piqued recently when Cuban horsemen asked that their thoroughbreds be accepted by the Stud Book so they could be sold in North and South America.

title: Beyond Embarrassment in Trenton
description: New Jersey's Senate acted wisely in ruling that one of its members, Gerald Cardinale, could not invoke ''senatorial courtesy'' to block the reappointment of Judge Sylvia Pressler to the state's Superior Court. But the legislators are not off the hook in thus resolving one embarrassing case. New Jersey's traditional method of reviewing appointments needs a basic reform.

title: Coast Bank Franchising
description: First Interstate Bancorp, the nation's eighth-largest bank holding company, said today that two bank holding companies with 11 banks in Montana and Wyoming had agreed to be franchised under the First Interstate name.

title: PANEL OF TEACHERS' UNION RECOMMENDS ENDORSEMENT OF MONDALE
description: The National Education Association's political action committee recommended today that the association, the nation's largest teacher organization, endorse Walter F. Mondale for the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: A WASHINGTON HOSTESS WITH A FLAIR FOR FASHION
description: If this city could be said to have a doyenne of fashion who adroitly mixes the worlds of politics, diplomacy and society it would be Val Cook.

title: BRAZIL'S DEBTS CAST A SHADOW
description: Brazil, as such, never appears on the main agenda of the weeklong annual meeting here of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. But just as the Mexican economy menaced the annual meeting last year in Toronto, Brazil dominates this one, except more.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: INEVITABLY, a reviewer comes across a restaurant that falls between two ratings, better than one star, for example, but not quite up to two. In such instances, this reviewer has chosen the more conservative rating, feeling it was better to promote than to demote in the future.

title: New Limits Proposed For the Pesticide EDB
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration called today for a drastic lowering of the level at which some workers may be exposed to ethylene dibromide, a chemical widely used in refining gasoline and as a pesticide.

title: No Headline
description: Soviet Women Withdraw Team

title: L.I.R.R. to Allow Bikes on Trains
description: Riders on the Long Island Rail Road will be allowed to take bicycles on off-peak trains starting Oct. 17.

title: A GAME OF CHICKEN
description: All wars are boyish, and are fought by boys. - Herman Melville

title: Stadler Leading
description: Craig Stadler had nine birdies in an eight-under-par 62 today and took a two-stroke lead over Lance Ten Broeck and Fred Couples in the Texas Open.

title: Car Sales Up In Model Year
description: Americans bought a record 2.37 million imported cars in the 1983 model year ending Friday, according to preliminary figures. Domestic auto makers also gained, with sales of 6.4 million, up more than 15 percent from 1982's depressed levels.

title: AC&R and Marsteller Gain Some Business
description: AC& R Advertising, a subsidiary of Ted Bates Worldwide, and Marsteller, Los Angeles, a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam, have both picked up some new business.

title: SOVIET SAYS KOCH SLANDERS THE U.N.
description: The Government press agency Tass accused Mayor Koch today of a ''slanderous attack unprecedented in its rudeness'' on the United Nations.

title: BROADWAY
description: JACK LEMMON and Estelle Parsons, who spent summers together as childhood friends on Lake Winnipesaukee, N.H., will have a reunion in Los Angeles on Oct. 17. That is the day they will go into rehearsal with ''A Sense of Humor,'' Ernest Thompson's latest play. ''A Sense of Humor'' is scheduled to open in Denver in November and then play in Los Angeles and San Francisco before opening on Broadway in March. The production will be directed by Robert Greenwald and produced by Robert Fryer and Frank von Zerneck.

title: Jardine's Chairman In Early Departure
description: Dennis K. Newbigging, the chairman of Jardine, Matheson & Company, said yesterday in Hong Kong that he would step down today from his post at the British colony's oldest and largest trading company. He will also resign as chairman of the sister company, the Hongkong Land Company. He is being succeeded in both companies by Simon Keswick, the deputy chairman.

title: Witkowski Rates Another Look
description: Ray Walsh Jr., the director of research and development for the Giants, will get another look at John Witkowski, Columbia's senior quarterback, tonight at Giants Stadium when the Lions play Penn in an Ivy League game.

title: APPEALS FOR MISSILE ACCORD CONTINUE AT THE U.N.
description: Despite a rejection by Moscow of President Reagan's new proposals for arms reduction in Western Europe, speakers at the General Assembly here today continued to express the hope that some settlement could be reached.

title: People
description: * Eugene P. Gilmartin appointed president and chief operating officer of Hoffman York & Compton, Milwaukee.

title: STAGE: 'SERIOUS BIZNESS,' COMEDY REVUE, PART 2
description: WHEN New Yorkers wax nostalgic about the glory days of the city's night life, they inevitably get teary-eyed about those bright, sassy comedy revues that have now almost vanished from the scene. Some such revues still can be found, of course, but their character has changed. Gone are the days when The Revuers and, later, Julius Monk's Plaza 9 troupes seemed to epitomize everything that was worldly and sophisticated about Manhattan Island.

title: REAGAN GIVES PLAN ON PENSION EQUITY
description: The Reagan Administration today proposed legislative changes designed to promote equity for women in pension plans, including counting maternity leave as work time and providing a greater voice in sharing a spouse's benefits.

title: No Dioxin Found Near 2 Plant Sites
description: Residents living near two industrial sites in North Jersey need not fear dioxin contamination in their neighborhoods, the state said.

title: OMINUS INSIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: ASSOCIATE OF MARC RICH ENTERS NOT GUILTY PLEA
description: Clyde Meltzer, a business associate of the commodities trader Marc Rich, pleaded not guilty yesterday to Federal charges of racketeering, tax evasion and fraud.

title: Trump Would Like To Take On N.F.L.
description: Donald J. Trump, the new owner of the New Jersey Generals of the United States Football League, said yesterday that he favored the league playing its games eventually in the fall and winter rather than in spring and summer, thus competing directly with the National Football League.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE Fall Benefit for the No Elephant Circus the other night turned out to be a more momentous affair than expected. The 200 people who paid $25 each for cocktails and a light buffet supper at International House on East 46th Street were expecting a sampling of magic, mime and song, all of which they received. But they did not expect to witness a juggling act that will be entered in the Guinness Book of World Records. ''That's quite a treat,'' said Jack Beebe, chairman of the circus's board of advisers.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avis Rent A Car System Inc., Garden City, L.I., has appointed Robert J. McKenna senior vice president and general manager.

title: Boys Town Is Opening Branch in Tallahassee
description: Boys Town, founded near Omaha in 1917 to help troubled youths, announced plans today to start a pilot branch here.

title: Advertising; Ohlmeyer's Special Skills
description: IF there really is a move back to TV programming control by advertisers, then there will be a new agency in town that is prepared to ride the new wave.

title: CERBERONICS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
Itchy Business
description: The National Hockey League begins its 1983-84 season next week and rookies and veterans alike are itching to play.

title: OPERA: 'LA FORZA DEL DESTINO' AT THE MET
description: Grace Bumbry, Renato Bruson and Jose Carreras - made their first appearances in a Metropolitan Opera production of Verdi's ''Forza del Destino'' Wednesday night. It proved a stellar event and the celebrated triumvirate offered performances that were musically and dramatically convincing.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 30, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: SAFETY-KLEEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 10
Norfolk Southern
description: The Southeast Banking Corporation said the Norfolk Southern Corporation, a transportation holding company, had offered to buy a combination of its preferred, convertible and common stock for about $75 million. The proposed investment is subject to the completion and execution of a definitive agreement and to approval by Southeast's board. A Southeast spokesman said there was an understanding between the bank and the railroad that Norfolk Southern never would own 10 percent or more of the banking company.

title: ITALIANS MAY CHARGE TURK WITH SLANDER ON JAILED BULGARIAN
description: An Italian magistrate was reported today to be preparing a slander charge against the gunman who has said that Bulgarian agents masterminded both his attempt to kill Pope John Paul II and a plot to kill Lech Walesa.

title: WHITE HOUSE RESTRAINED IN REACTING TO ANDROPOV
description: The White House responded in mild terms today to the denunciation of the Reagan Administration by Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader.

title: No Headline
description: THE BEST AMERICAN SHORT STORIES 1983. Selected by Anne Tyler with Shannon Ravenel. With an introduction by Anne Tyler. 332 pages. Houghton Mifflin. Hard cover, $14.95; paperback,

title: John Paul Opens Sixth Bishops' Synod
description: Pope John Paul II opened a general synod of bishops today, the sixth such meeting since the Second Vatican Council established the synod as a permanent structure of the Roman Catholic Church in 1965.

title: Vote, Day and Night
description: There are no quick fixes, a new ABC News poll shows, to the problem of low voter turnout. Change the voting system? That won't accomplish anything dramatic because the main barriers are not in the system. They are in the nonvoters - the 48 percent who did not show up in 1980. When will they be more likely to vote? When they are older, richer and better educated, the ABC poll analysts conclude, offering a healthy dose of realism.

title: HOTEL DENIES IT FEATURES KOSHER FOOD
description: Betty Tessler, the 67-year-old owner, hostess and part-time chef of Tessler's Resort Hotel, will be the first to say the food served at her hotel is not kosher.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Statement in Sculpture On War and Peace
description: There wasn't much wind in Battery Park yesterday so Thomas (Tony) Price gave his sculpture a gentle shove to set it clanging. ''In New Mexico,'' he said, ''there's plenty of wind and it just chatters away.''

title: CLARK, J L, MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Dispute to Arbitrator
description: The Rangers' leading scorer of the last two seasons, Mike Rogers, has submitted his contract dispute with the team's general manager, Craig Patrick, to a National Hockey League arbitrator. Rogers has the contractual right either to ask for arbitration on a salary for this season and an option year, or to play out this season as his option year and become a free agent. . . . The Rangers signed the veteran defenseman Willie Huber to a new contract and assigned Dave Laurion, a goaltender, and Peter Dahl, a left wing, to the Peoria (Ill.)

title: AMPAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Economic Scene; I.M.F.'s Goal Of Confidence
description: NEW YORK'S leading banker, J. P. Morgan, quelled the Panic of 1907 by rebuilding public confidence in the banks. He began his campaign by calling together the Protestant clergymen of the city and telling them: ''It is a time for affirming faith. Beseech your congregations on Sunday to leave their money in the banks.''

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday GREEK ARTS IN ASTORIA

title: New Frates Bid For Kaiser Stock
description: A group of investors headed by J. A. Frates has made a new offer, with a face value of approximately $350 million, to acquire the Kaiser Steel Corporation. Kaiser's board is scheduled to consider the offer today.

title: THE POLICE BRUTALITY HEARING 'WAS A CONTRIVED POLITICAL SHAM'
description: To the Editor:

title: Poet in Residence
description: Tom Meschery, a published poet who spent 10 years as a muscular forward in the National Basketball Association, has had a variety of experiences in his 44 years. Now he is ready to try a new one.

title: Loss for Quarterback
description: Tulane's quarterback, Jon English, lost yesterday in his legal fight against a National Collegiate Athletic Association decree that he is ineligible to play football.

title: Chinese Preparing Campaign To Remove Party's 'Leftists'
description: The Communist Party's Central Committee will convene before Oct. 11 to begin a campaign to remove ''leftists'' who have resisted change, Hu Yaobang, the party's General Secretary, said today.

title: WORLD USES LESS OF A NEW MIX OF FUELS
description: Despite the sporadic energy shortages of the last decade, experts now concur that for the balance of this century, barring a major political upheaval in the Middle East, Americans have scant chance of sitting in a gasoline line or of seeing plants close because of a lack of fuel.

title: UNIVAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Steel and Ship Workers Protest in West Germany
description: Thousands of West German steel and shipyard workers demonstrated here today in a protest against unemployment and the economic policies of the conservative Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: ART: A HUGE EXHIBITION AT BROADWAY TERMINAL
description: THE proponents of ''Terminal New York,'' the colossal display of art on view at the former Brooklyn Army Terminal, have billed it as ''potentially the most controversial and innovative exhibition'' since the 1913 Armory Show, but that description doesn't work. The only way it can be related to the earlier exhibition is in its size (it's bigger), and its association with a military space.

title: Market Place; Wary Feelings About October
description: NEXT Monday will be the first trading day of October, and already there is talk of another possible ''October massacre'' in the stock market.

title: COURT IS TOLD CAR STRUCK BOY AT CURB
description: A 9-year-old girl testified today that a car driven by Gerald T. Gerlock Jr. hit a 7-year-old boy while he was standing astride his bicycle at the curb of an intersection in their neighborhood.

title: ROY SULLIVAN
description: Roy Sullivan, a retired Shenandoah National Park ranger who was struck by lightning seven times and survived, died Wednesday of a gunshot wound. He was 71 years old.

title: SCREEN: 'BRAINSTORM,' DISCOVERY GOES AWAY
description: IN a button-pusher's paradise, replete with the dazzling array of hardware that ''Brainstorm'' so effectively utilizes, a group of scientists is poised on the brink of an astonishing discovery. They have created a device that allows one person to experience vicariously the sensations of others. If Person A, wearing a specially designed helmet, eats a piece of steak with nuts, chocolate sauce and marshmallow on top (that's the meal used in the experiment), Person B can taste the same stuff and share in the same indigestion.

title: China Said to Execute Six
description: The Chinese Government executed a man convicted of spying for Taiwan, two leaders of a ''reactionary'' secret society and three other people in the northern city of Tianjin last Saturday, a local newspaper said today. The paper identified the spy as Jiang Bingkun and said he was a grain official who doubled as the local head of a Taiwanese intelligence network.

title: Manville Motion Filed by GAF
description: The GAF Corporation, a co-defendant in thousands of asbestos injury lawsuits filed against the Manville Corporation, said it had filed a motion to dismiss Manville's 13-month-old petition for bankruptcy protection.

title: COTTY WINNERS: SMITH AND FLUSSER
description: Willi Smith and Alan Flusser were the winners last night at the 41st annual Coty American Fashion Critics' Awards at the Fashion Institute of Technology.

title: Venezia's Ban Ended
description: The New York State Racing and Wagering Board yesterday trimmed three weeks off the three-month suspension it had imposed on Mike Venezia for failing to report a 1974 bribe offer from another jockey. In announcing the reduction, which will allow Venezia to return to riding tomorrow, the board said Venezia had shown ''a willingness to abide by the decisions of the board.''

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''It would be tragic if we did not accept this beginning of a first step toward the reinvigoration of a bipartisan foreign policy.''

title: HOLDOUT DEFENDERS NOT MISSED SO FAR
description: As the National Football League season enters its fifth week, three teams are still playing without a starting defensive back from a year ago. The cornerback Mike Haynes of the New England Patriots, the free safety Gary Barbaro of the Kansas City Chiefs and the cornerback Jeris White of the Washington Redskins have all withheld their services because of contract disputes.

title: Times Columnist Is Awarded Fellowship by Colby College
description: Anthony Lewis, columnist for The New York Times, has been named the 31st Elijah Parish Lovejoy Fellow by Colby College.

title: GTE Names a Director For New Office in Japan
description: The GTE Corporation, a major telecommunications and electronics company, yesterday indicated its growing interest in the markets of Japan and other nations of the Far East.

title: ELITE HIGH SCHOOLS ACCEPT 873 AFTER PUPILS FIND TEST ERRORS
description: Almost 900 students who were rejected last spring by the city's three elite high schools have now been accepted because the entrance examination, which contained three faulty questions, was rescored.

title: Books: A-Bombs
description: NUCLEAR WAR, NUCLEAR PEACE, Byreon Wieseltier. 84 pages. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $7.95.

title: Dime Savings' Stock Plans
description: The Dime Savings Bank, the second-largest savings bank in the state, with $6.4 billion in assets, yesterday announced a plan to change from a mutual, or depositor-owned, bank to a stock institution. The move is in line with a trend by several savings banks to raise capital by selling stock.

title: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 30, 1983
description: Companies

title: Thomas Purrington, 88, Western Electric Manager
description: Thomas Upton Purrington, a retired plant manager for the Western Electric Company who once worked for Thomas Alva Edison, died Tuesday at the Princeton Medical Center.

title: MISSION WEST PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After tax credits of $382,000 for the quarter and $595,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss after an extraordinary charge of $58,000. d-After a tax credit of $196,000.

title: Spot Oil Price Slips by 20/
description: Spot prices for crude oil fell a further 15 to 20 cents a barrel today, after dropping below official levels Wednesday, because of an oversupply and a lack of demand from refiners, trade sources said.

title: Newsweek Campaign By Leber Katz
description: Without disturbing either its trade advertising to potential advertisers or its consumer advertising to its potential subscribers, Newsweek tomorrow will spread an umbrella effort over them both that says: ''Newsweek, every week.

title: Stocks Continue to Fall, With Dow Slipping 1.83
description: Stock prices declined slightly yesterday in slower trading, with some of the technology issues the biggest losers.

title: Roll-Call Votes
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 54 to 46 today by which the Senate approved a war powers resolution allowing President Reagan to keep 1,600 United States marines in Lebanon for up to 18 months: FOR THE RESOLUTION - 54 Democrats - 2 Mitchell, Me. Zorinsky, Neb.

title: Bridge: Americans Add to Big Lead; Race for 2d Place Is Tighter
description: The American team scored two more big victories Thursday in the World Team Championship here, adding to its big lead. However, the race for second place became a little closer.

title: VISITORS FROM THE PAST
description: FOR five years, the Exxon Corporation has been making it possible for the Guggenheim Museum to send people out into the field to tell us what goes on, both in this country and in other parts of the world. This year's findings are disclosed in an exhibition called ''New Perspectives in American Art: The 1983 Exxon National Exhibition,'' which has just opened at the museum. It was organized by Diane Waldman, deputy director of the Guggenheim, who traveled throughout the United States in hopes of coming back with something good.

title: STANFORD SAYS NUCLEAR RESEARCH DISPUTE IS SETTLED
description: A dispute over use of Stanford University facilities for nuclear weapon research has been resolved in a way that allows access for weapon scientists but maintains the nonsecret character the university insists on.

title: Defendant Admits Biegenwald Role
description: An Asbury Park man pleaded guilty today to hindering the apprehension of Richard F. Biegenwald and agreed to cooperate in the prosecution of the convicted murderer, charged with killing five people and linked to another slaying since his parole.

title: SEGA ENTERPRISES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income. Sega Enterprises is a 90 percent- owned subsidiary of Gulf & Western Industries.

title: Not a Warren, But an Apartment
description: In the area of Columbus Avenue where side-street brownstones are chopped into tiny apartments for single people Phelps House was dedicated yesterday, a monument to the old ways.

title: SALANT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: b-After after-tax gains of $216,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,296,000, or 40 cents a share, for the 9 months from the reversal of a prior year provision pertaining to the disposal of the discontinued Salant & Salant division, and a special after-tax charge of $1,026,000 for the 9 months relating to the closure of two manufacturing facilities.

title: Baseball Crowds Set Mark Again
description: Major league attendance set a season record of 44,611,695 Wednesday night, surpassing the mark of 44,587,874 established last year.

title: PHOTOGRAPHS SHOWN AT MODERN MUSEUM
