description: Art Sinsabaugh, a photographer whose work has been shown at the Museum of Modern Art and a teacher of photography at the University of Illinois for more than 20 years, died of heart disease Tuesday in Evanston, Ill. He was 58 years old.

title: A STROLL THROUGH COBBLE HILL'S STREETS AND HOMES
description: George Washington stayed in the neighborhood, and so did Thomas Wolfe in the 1930's, when he wrote that only the dead know Brooklyn. Jennie Jerome, the mother of Winston Churchill, was born there in 1854.

title: Death Cited For Drop In Metals
description: The death yesterday of a California commodities dealer whose company was under investigation contributed to a decline in precious metals prices, traders said.

title: CHLORADINE FOUND IN BLUEFISH OFF JERSEY IN POLLUTION STUDY
description: State envirnmental officials conducting an ongoing study of contamination in migratory fish in New Jersey costal waters said today that they found no accumulations of the pesticide chloradane in bluefish.

title: 13 Arrested at White House
description: Thirteen demonstrators were arrested in front of the White House today while protesting new rules limiting the size of signs demonstrators can carry there.

title: THE GULF POWDERKEG
description: The three-year-old war between Iran and Iraq is reaching a point of new explosiveness. It could involve the U.S. Navy and Marines in a far more dangerous operation than in Lebanon, at a time when they are tightly stretched. It would create grave new tensions with the Russians.

title: DEVELOPER WON'T RECREATE PART OF BILTMORE PALM COURT
description: The developers of the Manhattan office tower that replaced the Biltmore Hotel said yesterday that, under a new agreement, they would not re-create parts of the hotel's famous Palm Court.

title: HELENE CURTIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 30, 1983
description: International

title: Harmonic Choir
description: The Harmonic Choir, a seven-member group that uses vocal techniques from Mongolia, Bulgaria and Tibet to produce multiple notes simultaneously, will perform at the WBAI Free Music Store on Sunday at 6 P.M. The concert will take place at P.S. 41, 116 West 11th Street; admission is free, but a $5 optional contribution is requested. The concert will also be broadcast live on WBAI-FM, 99.5.

title: 'One Singular Sensation'
description: ''Long before any reviewers, who must normally function as huff-and-puff artists blowing laggard theatergoers stagewards, were permitted to come near the entertainment,'' The Times's Walter Kerr wrote in May 1975, ''word had got about: something was brewing in one of Joseph Papp's downtown houses.''

title: Boy, 16, Suffocated By Sand-Pit Wall
description: A 16-year-old boy was buried alive when a tunnel he was digging at the base of a 60-foot-high wall of sand and gravel at a sand pit here collapsed and suffocated him, the police said Wednesday.

title: Murdoch Buys Warner Stock
description: Rupert Murdoch, the publisher, has purchased about a million shares of Warner Communications Inc. stock, Wall Street sources said last night. Discouraging speculation that the purchase, representing about 1.6 percent of the entertainment company's stock, might be the beginning of a takeover, these sources said that Mr. Murdoch had bought the stock as an investment.

title: REWARDS FOR FISHING RECORDS
description: If you have a yen for competitive angling - and a great many American fishermen seem to be so inclined - you might wish to enter Berkley and Company's world record contest, which began in July and runs through next year.

title: 17 ARE REPORTED KILLED IN PROTESTS IN PAKISTAN
description: The police said today that 17 people were killed and 48 injured in a village 125 miles northeast of here when troops fired into a crowd that had blocked a road in protest against the Government.

title: LEBANESE REOPEN BEIRUTS AIRPORT
description: Lebanon took its first tentative steps toward a return to relatively normal life today as Beirut International Airport reopened for the first time in more than a month.

title: Bernard Lamotte Dead at 80; Muralist and Book Illustrator
description: Bernard Lamotte, a French-born artist, illustrator and muralist whose work decorated several of New York's premier restaurants, died on Wednesday at St. Luke's Hospital of complications following surgery.

title: 2 SURPRISES IN SOCCER BOWL-83
description: When the championship of the North American Soccer League is decided here Saturday, the teams involved will be the Tulsa Roughnecks and the Toronto Blizzard, who were seeded third and seventh, respectively, among the eight teams that made the playoffs.

title: PILOTS SET STRIKE BUT CONTINENTAL PLANS TO OPERATE
description: Representatives of the 2,025 pilots of Continental Air Lines voted today to begin a work stoppage Saturday morning to protest what they called union-busting tactics. They said the airline was moving against its employees' unions under the guise of seeking Federal protection to stave off bankruptcy.

title: WEINBERGER'S CHINA VISIT: PLAYING THE SUPPLICANT
description: After a slow start, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger ended a five-day visit to China here today having apparently achieved most of what he called the ''modest goals'' of this venture. He accomplished this, however, by taking the position of supplicant. Through Mr. Weinberger, the United States offered assistance and asked for Chinese cooperation. But the Chinese offered nothing and asked for nothing, dealing with Mr. Weinberger the same way they have treated with foreigners for centuries.

title: Head of Bank Resigns
description: Harry E. Ekblom, chairman and chief executive officer of the European American Bank, said yesterday that he would be leaving the bank on Jan. 1. No successor was named to Mr. Ekblom, who is 55 years old and has been chief executive for 13 years. He explained his resignation by saying, ''I have decided that now is the time to look for a new challenge.''

title: THE SCREEN: 'HANNA K.,' WITH JILL CLAYBURGH
description: COMPARED with the explosive nature of Costa-Gavras's best melodramas, which would include his recent ''Missing,'' his new film, ''Hanna K.,'' is a large, soggy dud. The film, which opens today at Cinema 1, is a political melodrama without a payoff, based on a screenplay that seems unfinished, with characters who are still in the typewriter gasping for breath that will never come.
